About 500,000 participants were included in the UK Biobank. Of 498,103 participants included (54% of whom were women) aged 37-73 years, 8532 died during a median follow-up of 4.9 years (IQR 4.33-5.22) Self-reported health (C-index including age 0.74 [95% CI 0.73-0.75]) was the strongest predictor of all-cause mortality in men and a previous cancer diagnosis (0.73 [0.72-0,74] for women) When excluding individuals with major diseases or disorders (Charlson comorbidity index >0; n=355 043), measures of smoking habits were

UK Biobank is the largest retinal data repository in a prospective population-based cohort. Images were drawn from those of 68,554 participants who underwent retinal imaging at recruitment. Increasing age was associated with a reduced proportion of images that could be processed.

Common variants near the apolipoprotein E and nicotinic acetylcholine receptor subunit alpha 5 genes are associated with lifespan. The effects are strongly sex and age dependent, with APOE &#603;4 differentially influencing maternal lifespan. Rare homozygous carriers of the risk alleles at both loci are predicted to have 3.3-3.7 years shorter lives.

Verbal reasoning performance is an indicator of the ability to think constructively in everyday life. This study aimed to determine the effect of functional hearing on verbal reasoning when controlling for age, gender, and education.

Low fat-free mass (FFM) is a risk factor for morbidity and mortality in elderly and patient populations. FFM and FFMI were significantly associated with BMI and decreased with age. Because these reference values are BMI specific, they are of broad interest for overweight and obese populations.

A one kilogram increase in birthweight was associated with a lower risk of type 2 diabetes in the UK Biobank participants. Paternal diabetes was associated. with lower birthweight (45 g lower; 95% CI: 36, 54; P = 2 Ã— 10(-23) relative to individuals with no parental diabetes. Maternal diabetes is associated with higher birthweight. Findings with paternal diabetes are consistent with a role for the same genetic factors influencing foetal growth.

In this cross-sectional analysis of the UK Biobank cohort, a history of fracture was associated with increased risk of current widespread chronic pain. Individuals with prior fracture were significantly more likely to report CWBP than those without.

Several studies have shown that smoking may confer a greater excess risk for chronic diseases in women compared with men. The reasons for this excess risk of smoking in women are unclear, yet sex differences in smoking habits may play a role. In the oldest cohort, born 1935-1939, women started smoking 1.9 years (95% CI 1.7 to 2.1) later than did men.

Cross-sectional study using baseline data from the unique UK Biobank resource. Participants with and without RA were compared in terms of sociodemographic, lifestyle and other disease-related risk factors. Prevalence was significantly higher among female, South Asian and socioeconomically deprived participants.

Study examines relationship with self-reported health (SRH) and happiness. Compared with obese men, obese women are less likely to report poor health, but more likely to feel unhappy.

Previous studies on the association between adiposity and mood disorder have produced contradictory results. Few have used measurements other than body mass index (BMI) We examined association between probable major depression and several measurements of adiposity: BMI, waist circumference and waist-hip-ratio.

The UK Biobank offers cross-sectional epidemiological data collected on >500,000 individuals in the UK between 40 and 70 years of age. The aim of this study was to investigate the effects of functional hearing loss and hearing aid usage on visuospatial memory function. Age also showed strong main effects for both memory tasks.

Visuospatial working memory (VSWM) has been shown to be poorer in individuals with poorer hearing but better in profoundly deaf individuals. Using data from the UK Biobank resource, a large observational study, we showed that variance in card-pair matching was large among profoundly deaf participants.

Study investigated differences in cognitive performance between middle-aged adults with and without a lifetime history of mood disorder features. Cross-sectional analysis of baseline data from the UK Biobank cohort.

Low birth weight has been inconsistently associated with risk of developing affective disorders, including major depressive disorder (MDD) To date, studies investigating possible associations between birth weight and bipolar disorder (BD) have not been conducted in large cohorts. Very low/low birth weight were associated with higher neuroticism scores.

UK Biobank is a landmark cohort of over 500,000 participants. This is the first study to systematically assess the prevalence and validity of proposed criteria for probable mood disorders.

Cardiometabolic diseases (hypertension, coronary artery disease [CAD] and diabetes) are known to associate with poorer cognitive ability. There are limited data on whether having more than one of these conditions is associated with additive effects. We examined cognitive test scores in domains of reasoning, information processing speed and memory.

There was a weak correlation (r = 0.24) between energy from sugar and fat. The proportion of energy from fat in the diet, but not sugar, is higher among overweight/obese individuals. Focusing public health messages on sugar may mislead on the need to reduce fat and overall energy consumption.

UK Biobank includes 502,649 middle- and older-aged adults. Majority of participants completed tests of cognitive functioning. A sub-group of N = 20,346 participants repeated most of the assessment.

Insufficient physical activity is a determinant of obesity and cardiovascular disease. Active travel to work has declined in high-income countries in recent decades. We aimed to determine which characteristics predicted switching to or from active commuting.

Physical inactivity is a leading cause of obesity and premature mortality. We aimed to examine the relation between active commuting and obesity in mid-life using objectively measured anthropometric data from UK Biobank.

Study looked at 212,039 men aged 40-69 years in UK Biobank. A total of 62,022 (29%) men reported they had ever had a PSA test. A wide range of factors was associated with a higher likelihood of PSA testing. These included age, height, education level, family history of prostate cancer.

Study examined associations of sleep duration and morning-evening type with sociodemographic and cardiometabolic disease in adults participating in the UK Biobank study. Black ethnicity emerged as most strongly associated with sleep behavior.

Sleep duration has been implicated in the etiology of obesity but less is known about the association between sleep and other behavioral risk factors for cardiovascular disease. The aim of this study was to examine associations among sleep duration, chronotype, and physical activity, screen-based sedentary behavior, tobacco use, and dietary intake.

Sleep duration and morningness/eveningness (circadian preference) have separately been associated with cardiovascular risk factors. Interactive effects are plausible, resulting from combinations of sleep homeostatic and circadian influences. These have not been examined in a population sample.

Of the many common variants now associated with body mass index, those in an intron of the fat mass and obesity-associated (FTO) gene have the largest effect. We jointly examine the evidence for interactions between FTO (rs1421085) and various lifestyle and environmental factors.

Recent epidemiological data suggest the relation between hearing difficulty and depression is more evident in younger and middle-aged populations than in older adults. There are also suggestions that the relation may be more apparent in specific subgroups. Findings suggest that audiological services should facilitate psychosocial counselling.

Mark Caulfield, Paul Elliott and colleagues use data from the UK Biobank to perform genome-wide association analysis for blood pressure traits. They identify and validate 107 novel loci.

Jimmy Liu and colleagues perform genome-wide association by proxy (GWAX) in a large population cohort. They apply GWAX to 12 common diseases and show its utility by identifying new risk loci.

 genome-wide association study in 293,723 individuals identifies 74 genetic variants associated with educational attainment. Although only explaining a small proportion of the variation in educational attainment, highlights candidate genes.

A meta-analysis of subjective well-being, depressive symptoms and neuroticism. The study leverages a large sample size together with genetic correlations between the phenotypes to identify loci associated with each phenotype.

Researchers find 15 new significant loci and implicate 40 new genes, most of which are predominantly expressed in the brain. Danielle Posthuma and colleagues determine genetic overlap with several neuropsychiatric and metabolic traits.

Steven Gazal, Alkes Price and colleagues extend stratified LD score regression to continuous annotations. They analyze summary statistics from 56 complex diseases and traits. SNPs with low levels of linkage disequilibrium have larger per-SNP heritability.

 Variability in red blood cell volumes (distribution width, RDW) increases with age. RDW is strongly predictive of mortality, incident coronary heart disease and cancer. We investigated inherited genetic variation associated with RDW in 116,666 UK Biobank human volunteers.

A genetic risk score derived from these results was significantly associated with risk for chronic obstructive pulmonary disease in independent populations. Louise Wain, Ian Hall, Martin Tobin and colleagues report genome-wide association analyses of lung function.

Our sleep timing preference is a manifestation of our internal biological clock. Variation in chronotype has been linked to sleep disorders, cognitive and physical performance, and chronic disease. We identify 12 new genetic loci that implicate known components of the circadian clock machinery.

Loci associated with insomnia symptoms and excessive daytime sleepiness. Findings based on genome-wide association analyses in the UK Biobank cohort.

Alcohol consumption has been linked to over 200 diseases and is responsible for over 5% of the global disease burden. Well-known genetic variants in alcohol metabolizing genes, for example, ALDH2 and ADH1B, are strongly associated with alcohol consumption. We performed a genome-wide association study (GWAS) of self-reported alcohol consumption in 112 117 individuals in the UK Biobank.

Birth weight (BW) has been shown to be influenced by both fetal and maternal factors. BW is reproducibly associated with future risk of adult metabolic diseases including type 2 diabetes (T2D) and cardiovascular disease1.

People's differences in cognitive functions are partly heritable and are associated with important life outcomes. Previous genome-wide association studies of cognitive functions have found evidence for polygenic effects yet, to date, there are few replicated genetic associations. Here we use data from the UK Biobank sample to investigate the genetic contributions to variation in tests of three cognitive functions and in educational attainment.

 Differences in general cognitive function have been shown to be partly heritable and to show genetic correlations with several psychiatric and physical disease states. Few single-nucleotide polymorphisms (SNPs) have demonstrated genome-wide significance, hampering efforts aimed at determining which genetic variants are most important for cognitive function.

The identification of rare coding or splice site variants remains the most straightforward strategy to link genes with human phenotypes. We analyzed the association between 137,086 rare variants and 15 hematological traits in up to 308,572 participants. We found 56 such rare variants at P<5x10-8, including 31 that are associated with a blood-cell phenotype for the first time.

The lack of mechanistic explanations for many genotype-phenotype associations identified by GWAS precludes thorough assessment of their impact on human health. We conducted an expression quantitative trait locus (eQTL) mapping analysis in erythroblasts and found erythroid-specific eQTLs for ATP2B4.

The UK Biobank is a unique resource for biomedical research. We aimed to examine the effect of neurodevelopmental copy number variants (CNVs) on the cognitive performance of participants. Carriers of schizophrenia-associated CNVs and of the group of 41 other neuro developmental CNVs had impaired performance on cognitive tests. They also had lower educational and occupational attainment.

Cognitive impairment was least common in major depression. Prevalence in mania/bipolar was similar to that in multiple sclerosis and Parkinson's disease. Estimated population attributable prevalence of cognitive impairment was higher for major depression than for all other disorders.

Cancer and cardiovascular disease (CVD) are common causes of morbidity and mortality. We measured raw and adjusted rates of CVD for the following groups: individuals with Hodgkin or non-Hodgkin lymphoma, lung and trachea cancer, uterus cancer, colorectal cancer, prostate cancer, breast cancer, or no recorded diagnosed cancer.

The personality trait of neuroticism has also been associated with elevated rates of death in some studies. We tested the possibility that it is the neuroticism trait itself, rather than the distress state, that is generating an increased risk of mortality. Higher neuroticism was weakly associated with total mortality.

Five thousand sixty-five UK Biobank participants underwent CMR using steady-state free precession imaging at 1.5 Tesla. With advancing age, LV volumes were mostly smaller in both sexes. LV ejection fraction was significantly greater in females compared to males.

The T allele of the FSHB promoter polymorphism (rs10835638; c.-211G>T) results in longer menstrual cycles and later menopause. While having detrimental effects on fertility, it is protective against endometriosis.

Being part of a multiple birth was strongly associated with early menopause (odds ratio = 1.42, confidence interval: 1.11, 1.82, P = 8.0 Ã— 10-9) Earlier age at menarche and earlier year of birth were also associated with EM.

The minimum prevalence of any VRIA was 17.6% and 8.1% in the eyes with and without visual impairment, respectively. epiretinal membrane and vitreomacular traction were the most common VRIA. The degree of visual impairment was typically milder with these than with otherVRIA.

UK Biobank participants aged 40-69 had mild visual impairment or worse in one or both eyes. Increasing deprivation, age and ethnicity were independently associated with both monocular and binocular visual impairment. No primary diagnosis for the recorded level of visual impairment could be identified for 49.8% of eyes.

There is an international trend towards recommending medication to prevent cardiovascular disease (CVD) We assessed the cost-effectiveness of a population approach with a polypill including a statin.

Sex differences in adiposity storage may explain these findings. Body mass index and waist circumference were 1.94 (95% CI 1.82 to 2.07) and 4.84 (4.53 to 5.16) higher in women than in men, respectively. In type I diabetes, body size differed to a similar extent in women as in men.

Cross-sectional analysis of 502 664 individuals from the UK Biobank was conducted. Age at menarche was inversely associated with body mass index (BMI) Corresponding associations for other markers of general or abdominal adiposity were similar to those for BMI.

Biological evidence suggests that ethno-racial differences in morning-evening type are possible, whereby Blacks may be more likely to be morning type compared to Whites. However, population-level evidence of ethna-racial difference is limited. In an earlier study, we reported that morning type was more prevalent in Blacks compared to White in the UK Biobank cohort.

UK Biobank is a large prospective cohort comprising 502,637 men and women aged 40 to 69 years at recruitment. Of that number, 33,437 participants reported taking calcium supplements; 19,089 vitamin D; and 10,007 both. In crude and adjusted analyses, there were no associations between use of calcium supplements and risk of incident hospital admission with either IHD, or subsequent death.

Previous studies of the number of offspring and cardiovascular disease (CVD) report conflicting findings. We re-examined this association in both sexes to clarify the role of the cardiometabolic changes that women experience during pregnancy versus shared lifestyle characteristics.

Chronic pain has a strong association with major depressive disorder (MDD) There is a relative paucity of studies on the association between chronic multisite pain and bipolar disorder (BD) Such studies are required to help elucidate the complex biological and psychological overlap between pain and mood disorders.

UK Biobank recruited 263 450 participants (106 674 (52%) women; mean age 52.6), recruited from 22 sites across the UK. The exposure variable was the mode of transport used (walking, cycling, mixed mode  v  non-active (car or public transport) to commute to and from work on a typical day. Main outcome measures  Incident (fatal and non-fatal) CVD and cancer, and deaths from CVD, cancer, or any causes.

The CCL3L1-CCR5 signaling axis is important in a number of inflammatory responses, including macrophage function and T-cell-dependent immune responses. Small molecule CCR5 antagonists exist, including the approved antiretroviral drug maraviroc, and therapeutic monoclonal antibodies are in development.

Heart rate response to exercise provides useful information about the autonomic function. Its reproducibility over a long period of time, a critical requirement for using it as a clinical biomarker, is undetermined.

 increased bone mineral density is associated with a higher risk of type 2 diabetes (T2D), but the relationship with risk of coronary heart disease (CHD) is less clear. We identified 235 independent single nucleotide polymorphisms (SNPs) associated at p  -8 with estimated heel bone mineraldensity (eBMD) in 116,501 individuals from the UK Biobank study. For each eBMD-associated SNP, we extracted effect estimates from the largest available GWAS studies for T2D and CHD.

Male pattern baldness has been linked to adverse health outcomes such as prostate cancer and cardiovascular disease. We explored the genetic architecture of the trait using data from over 52,000 male participants of UK Biobank, aged 40-69 years. We identified over 250 independent genetic loci associated with severe hair loss.

Overall prevalence of facial pain (FP) was 1.9% (women 2.4%, men 1.2%) of which 48% was chronic. Highest prevalence was found in the 51 - 55 age group and lowest in the 66 - 73 age group. Prevalence of FP significantly associated with all measures of social class with the most deprived and on lowest income showing the highest prevalence.

The selective pressures that shape clonal evolution in healthy individuals are largely unknown. Here we investigate 8,342 mosaic chromosomal alterations that we uncovered in blood-derived DNA from 151,202 UK Biobank participants. At three such loci we identified a likely causal variant that acted with high penetrance (5-50%)

Community cohort participants (UK Biobank n = 502 637) aged 37-73 years were recruited between 2006 and 2010. Self-reported LTCs (n = 42) identified in people with AF at baseline. All-cause mortality was available for a median follow-up of 7 years (interquartile range 76-93 months) Co-morbid heart failure was associated with higher risk of mortality.

Even small reductions in risk factors helped to reduce frailty, as well as dementia, chronic pain, and other disabling conditions of old age. Optimizing cardiovascular disease risk factors may substantially reduce the burden of morbidity in later life.

Chronic inflammatory disorders (e.g. rheumatoid arthritis, psoriasis, inflammatory bowel disorders) were associated with a 14% increase in the mean arterial stiffness. The findings support the use of a stiffness index as means to stratify people with inflammatory disorders according to potential risk for future CVD events.

 GWAS confirmed 14 previously reported loci for migraine and identified 14 new loci. Headache and other psychological traits (such as neuroticism, depression, etc) share common genetic components.

Cognitive functioning was compared between persons with and without obstructive lung disease (OLD) The relationship between impairment in lung function and cognitive impairment was assessed among persons with OLD.

Study looked at 100 000 community-dwelling, 39-70 year-old volunteers. Data support an association between functional hearing and depression. The association was not alleviated by hearing-aid usage, but was partially confounded by other physical health problems.

Chronic pain is highly prevalent and a significant source of disability. Its relationship with major depressive disorder (MDD) is of particular importance. We sought to test the contribution of genetic factors and shared and unique environment to risk of chronic pain and its correlation with MDD in Generation Scotland: Scottish Family Health Study.

Higher body mass index (BMI) is a risk factor for cardiometabolic disease; however, the underlying causal associations remain unclear. The present study used UK Biobank data to report causal estimates of the association between BMI and disease outcomes and traits, such as pulse rate.

Data were available for more than 550,000 individuals and 51,623 cases of type 2 diabetes. PCSK9 variants associated with lower LDL cholesterol were also associated with circulating higher fasting glucose concentration, bodyweight, and waist-to-hip ratio.

Dorsal root ganglia (DRG) relay sensory information to the brain, giving rise to the perception of pain. Here, we mapped expression quantitative trait loci (eQTLs) in a collection of human DRGs. DRG eQ TLs were enriched within untranslated regions of coding genes of low abundance.

We have called CNVs in the full UK Biobank. 488,423 individual CEL files were downloaded in 2016 and 2017. They were analysed with Affymetrix Powertools, followed by PennCNV.

Alcohol use is correlated within spouse-pairs, but it is difficult to disentangle effects of alcohol consumption on mate-selection from social factors or the shared spousal environment. We hypothesised that genetic variants related to alcohol consumption may, via their effect on alcohol behaviour, influence mate selection. We find strong evidence that an individual's self-reported alcohol consumption and their genotype at rs1229984, a missense variant in ADH1B, are associated with their partner's alcohol use.

 intelligence and education are phenotypically and genetically correlated, which makes it difficult to elucidate causal relationships. We used univariate and multivariable Mendelian randomization to estimate the total and direct effects of intelligence and educational attainment on mental and physical health, measures of socioeconomic position, and longevity. Higher intelligence had positive direct effects on income, alcohol consumption, and vigorous physical activity.

Red and processed meat may be risk factors for breast cancer due to their iron content, administration of oestrogens to cattle or mutagens created during cooking. We studied the associations in UK Biobank and then included the results in a meta-analysis of published cohort studies.

The potential of Mendelian randomization studies is rapidly expanding due to the growing power of genome-wide association study (GWAS) meta-analyses. We build upon and synthesize recent advances in the literature on instrumental variables (IVs) estimation that test and relax the exclusion restriction. We illustrate the practical use of PRMR by estimating the causal effect of tobacco exposure on body mass index.

Genome Wide Association Study (GWAS) using age at death of parents of middle-aged UK Biobank participants of European decent. Offspring of longer lived parents had more protective alleles for coronary artery disease, systolic blood pressure, body mass index, cholesterol and triglyceride levels.

In human populations, assortative mating is almost univer&#173;sally positive. We find a correlation in genetic value among partners for a range of phenotypes. Our results imply that mate choice, combined with widespread pleiotropy, affects the genomic architecture of traits in humans.

This research was conducted using the UK Biobank Resource. Data, including genome-wide genotypes, were available for 105,421 European participants aged 40-69 years without kidney disease. Gout definitions and combinations of these definitions were identified from previous epidemiological studies.

Aging populations face diminishing quality of life due to increased disease and morbidity. These challenges call for longevity research to focus on understanding the pathways controlling healthspan. We identify 12 loci associated with healthspan at the whole-genome significance level.

Quantifying the effects of inbreeding is critical to characterizing the genetic architecture of complex traits. This study highlights the strengths and shortcomings of three SNP-based inbreeding measures commonly used to estimate inbreeding depression (ID) We find unique evidence of ID for handgrip strength, waist/hip ratio, and visual and auditory acuity.

A recent large-scale mega genome-wide association study identified, for the first time, genetic variants at 12 loci significantly associated with ADHD. We used a powerful polygenic approach to investigate the etiological overlap between ADHD and frequently co-occurring traits and disorders. We found no interaction effects between polygenic risk for ADHD and sex on any phenotypes.

Many common variants have been associated with hematological traits. Identification of causal genes and pathways has proven challenging. We performed a genome-wide association analysis in the UK Biobank and INTERVAL studies.

Higher grip strength was associated with a range of health outcomes and improved prediction of an office based risk score. In women and men, respectively, hazard ratios per 5 kg lower grip strength were higher (all at P)

Discretionary screen time is an important contributor to total sedentary behaviour. It is associated with increased risk of mortality and cardiovascular disease (CVD) The aim of this study was to determine whether the associations of screen time with cardiovascular disease and all-cause mortality were modified by levels of cardiorespiratory fitness, grip strength or physical activity.

Grip strength and diabetes are predictors of mortality and cardiovascular disease (CVD) But whether these risk factors interact to predispose to adverse health outcomes is unknown. Study determined the interactions between diabetes and grip strength and their association with health outcomes.

Genome-wide association studies of birth weight have focused on fetal genetics. We aimed to identify maternal genetic variants associated with birth weight. Maternal SNPs at 10 loci were associated with offspring birth weight at P.

Being a morning person is a behavioural indicator of a person's underlying circadian rhythm. Using genome-wide data from 697,828 UK Biobank and 23andMe participants we increase the number of genetic loci associated with being a morningperson from 24 to 351.

Macular thickness was positively correlated with older age, female gender, greater myopia, smoking, body mass index (BMI), and white ethnicity. We report macular thickness data derived from SD OCT images collected as part of the UK Biobank (UKBB) study.

Retinal pigment epithelium (RPE)-Bruch's membrane (BM) complex thickness as measured by spectral-domain (SD) optical coherence tomography (OCT) Study included people with no self-reported ocular disease, diabetes, or neurologic disorders. RPE-BM was significantly thinner with older age.

 Depression is a polygenic trait that causes extensive periods of disability. Previous genetic studies have identified common risk variants. Here, we conduct a genome-wide association study in 322,580 UK Biobank participants for three depression-related phenotypes.

UK Biobank plans to acquire 100,000 cardiac MRI studies by 2020. Fully-automated left ventricular (LV) analysis was performed in the original acquisition. This was not designed for unsupervised incorporation into epidemiological studies.

Cardiovascular resonance (CMR) imaging is a standard imaging modality for assessing cardiovascular diseases (CVDs), the leading cause of death globally. CMR enables accurate quantification of the cardiac chamber volume, ejection fraction and myocardial mass. For years, clinicians have been relying on manual approaches for CMR image analysis.

The framework reproduced significant reductions in circumferential strain in participants with diabetes, hypertensive participants, and participants with a previous heart attack. Typical processing time was approximately 260 frames (approximately 13 slices) per second on a GPU with 12 GB RAM compared with 6-8 minutes per slice for the manual analysis.

Little is known about the effect of cessation of menstruation on lung function. The study was performed in 141 076 women from the UK Biobank. The associations of lung function (forced vital capacity (FVC), forced expiratory volume in 1 s (FEV 1) and spirometric restriction (F VC) were stronger in women who had had a hysterectomy and/or oophorectomy.

People with a history of depression are at increased risk for developing autoimmune diseases and vice-versa. One explanation could be that there is shared genetic risk for depression and autoimmune diseases. In our study we looked at a region of the genome called the Major Histocompatibility Complex (MHC) The MHC is important in human immunity and harbours genetic variation that increases risk.

Physical activity and sleep duration are established risk factors for many diseases. Their aetiology is poorly understood, partly due to relying on self-reported evidence. Here we report a genome-wide association study (GWAS) of device-measured physical activity andSleep duration in 91,105 UK Biobank participants.

Lung function predicts mortality and is key to the diagnosis of chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD) In a genome-wide association study in 400,102 individuals of European ancestry, we define 279 lung function signals, 139 of which are new. In combination, these variants strongly predict COPD in independent populations.

Mood instability is a core clinical feature of affective and psychotic disorders. We conducted a genome-wide association study (GWAS) of mood instability in 53,525 cases and 60,443 controls from UK Biobank. We found a strong genetic correlation between mood instability and MDD and a small but significant correlation with schizophrenia.

People with more grey matter, and more intact connections between regions, had slightly higher scores on the abstract puzzle tests. The strongest effects were such that higher grey matter volume in the frontal pole and greater white matter microstructure in the posterior thalamic radiations were associated with higher fluid intelligence scores.

Neuroticism is an important risk factor for psychiatric traits, including depression1, anxiety2,3, and schizophrenia4-6. We conducted a large GWAS meta-analysis (n = 449,484) of neuroticism and identified 136 independent genome-wide significant loci. We show that neuroticism's genetic signal partly originates in two genetically distinguishable subclusters ('depressed affect' and 'worry')

Aortic distensibility can be calculated using semi-automated methods to segment the aortic lumen on cine CMR images. These methods require visual quality control and manual localization of the region of interest (ROI) of ascending (AA) and proximal descending (PDA) aorta. Using 5,100 scans from UK Biobank, this study sought to develop and validate a fully automated method.

Risk-taking behaviour is a key component of several psychiatric disorders. It could influence lifestyle choices such as smoking, alcohol use, and diet. Identifying genetic determinants of this trait has the potential to improve our understanding.

60 genetic variants have been robustly associated with birthweight. It is unclear whether these associations represent the effect of an individual's own genotype on their birthweight, their mother's genotype, or both. We demonstrate how structural equation modelling can be used to estimate both maternal and fetal effects.

Study included 126,182 postmenopausal women from UK Biobank. Overall, coffee consumption was not associated with breast cancer risk. Women with no PMH history who consumed &#8805; 4 cups/day had a 16% reduced risk of breast cancer.

Heritability estimation provides important information about the relative contribution of genetic and environmental factors to phenotypic variation. We demonstrate that common genetic variation contributes to a broad array of quantitative traits and human diseases in the UK population. We identify phenotypes whose heritability is moderated by age, sex and socioeconomic status.

Seasonality of total depressive symptom scores, anhedonia and tiredness scores was observed in women but not men, with peaks in winter. Shorter days were associated with increased feelings of low mood and anhedonian in women.

We used a Mendelian randomization approach to examine a potential causal effect of vitamin B12 and folate on hay fever, asthma, and selected biomarkers of allergy. We included 162,736 participants from 9 population-based studies including the UK Biobank. Results were combined in instrumental variable and meta-analyses and effects expressed as odds ratios (ORs)

Body mass index (BMI) is positively associated with asthma. We examined the causal effect of BMI on asthma, hay fever, allergic sensitization, serum total immunoglobulin E (IgE), forced expiratory volume in one-second (FEV1) and forced vital capacity (FVC) A genetic risk score was created using 26 BMI-associated single nucleotide polymorphisms (SNPs)

There is strong evidence that people born in winter and in spring have a small increased risk of schizophrenia. This 'season of birth' effect underpins some of the most influential hypotheses concerning potentially modifiable risk exposures. Here we sought to determine whether the season of birth effect reflects gene-environment confounding.

Study looked at the prevalence and incidence of chronic co-morbidities in people with inflammatory rheumatic and musculoskeletal diseases (iRMDs) The relationship between the presence (versus absence) of a (co-)morbidity and physical activity level (low, moderate, high) was assessed.

Low levels of blood cholesterol are known to be associated with increased risk of infectious disease. It remains unclear if this relationship is causal in nature. This study assessed the influence of common variants associated with blood lipid levels on infectious disease risk in individuals of British Caucasian ancestry from the UK Biobank.

Elevated intraocular pressure (IOP) is an important risk factor for glaucoma. We constructed polygenic risk scores (PRSs) for IOP using the UK Biobank (UKB) data set. We examined the associations of the PRSs with IOP and primary open-angle glau coma (POAG) using linear and logistic regression.

Time spent in moderate-to-vigorous physical activity (MVPA) and cardiorespiratory fitness (CRF) may reflect different pathways linking activity to brain health. Previous work has confirmed the benefits of aerobic exercise for brain aging, however mechanisms underlying these effects remain unclear.

Researchers analysed genetic variants that predict testosterone levels and their associations with blood clots (thromboembolism), heart failure and heart attack. Participants were aged 40 to 75 years and most were of British or European ancestry. Heart conditions were identified from self-reports, hospital and death records and results were validated using data from another large genome study.

Some of the most widely studied variants in psychiatric genetics include variable number tandem repeat variants (VNTRs) These loci remain absent from the largest available samples, such as the UK Biobank. Here, we report out-of-sample imputation accuracy estimates of >0.96 for all four VNTR variants.

Testosterone supplementation has been linked to increased cardiovascular disease risk in some observational studies. We assessed genetic associations of variants in two gene regions that are predictors of testosterone (SHBG and JMJD1C)

We propose a method based on deep learning to perform cardiac segmentation on short axis Magnetic resonance imaging stacks. At each iteration, a novel variant of the U-net is applied to propagate the segmentation of a slice to the adjacent slice below it. Results comparable or even better than the state of the art in terms of distance measures are achieved.

In a combined sample of over 1 million individuals, we conducted genome-wide association studies (GWAS) of general risk tolerance, adventurousness, and risky behaviors in the driving, drinking, smoking, and sexual domains. Across all GWAS, we identified hundreds of associated loci, including 99 loci associated with general riskolerance.

Atrial fibrillation (AF) is a common cardiac arrhythmia and a major risk factor for stroke, heart failure, and premature death. The pathogenesis of AF remains poorly understood, which contributes to the current lack of highly effective treatments. To understand the genetic variation and biology underlying AF, we undertook a genome-wide association study.

We performed a large genome-wide association study to discover genetic variation associated with muscular strength. In our analysis of 223,315 individuals, we identified 101 loci associated with grip strength.

We studied associations between different measures of fitness and physical activity and incident cardiovascular disease events. In addition, we evaluated these associations in individuals with different genetic risk for coronary heart disease and atrial fibrillation.

Prostate cancer is the most common cancer in British men but its aetiology is not well understood. We studied 219 335 men from the UK Biobank study. 4575 incident cases of prostate cancer occurred during 5.6 years of follow-up.

Men had greater intakes of energy and were less likely to have energy intakes above the estimated average requirement compared with women. Small, but significant, sex differences were found in the intakes of all macronutrients. Sex differences in dietary intakes moderated by age and to some extent by socioeconomic status.

 Educational attainment is associated with many health outcomes, including longevity. We used data from three large genetic epidemiology cohort studies. A 1 SD higher polygenic education score was associated with &#8764;2.7% lower mortality risk.

This project analysed data from UK Biobank participants with self-reported Chronic Obstructive Pulmonary Disease (COPD), compared to those who did not report that condition. The aim was to compare patterns of multimorbidity (more than one long term health condition) and polypharmacy.

Dietary habits are leading risk factors for life-altering diseases and mortality. Large-scale biobanks now enable genetic analysis of traits with modest heritability, such as diet. We identify 814 associated loci, including olfactory receptor associations with fruit and tea intake.

Deep learning (DL) algorithms can analyse cardiac magnetic resonance (CMR) images, but the presence of unanticipated analysis-errors currently excludes their use in clinical practice. We developed a pipeline for DL-based analysis of cine CMR, including quality control (QC) steps that prevent erroneous outputs.

Current public health guidelines on physical activity and sleep duration are limited by a reliance on subjective self-reported evidence. Using data from simple wrist-worn activity monitors, we developed a tailored machine learning model, using balanced random forests with Hidden Markov Models, to reliably detect a number of activity modes.

Genome-wide association studies (GWAS) promised to translate their findings into clinically beneficial improvements of patient management. However, the ability to translate genetic findings from GWAS into predictive tools that are of clinical utility has, so far, been encouraging but limited. Here we propose to use a more powerful statistical approach, the use of which has traditionally been limited due to computational requirements and lack of sufficiently large individual level genotyped cohorts.

Physical activity (PA) protects against a wide range of diseases. Habitual PA appears to be heritable, motivating the search for specific genetic variants. We examined genetic correlations of PA with other traits and diseases.

Machine learning algorithms can be trained to estimate age from brain structural MRI. The method was trained on a dataset of healthy Icelanders and tested on two datasets, IXI and UK Biobank, utilizing transfer learning to improve accuracy on new sites.

We constructed a genetic risk score for high BP by using 314 published BP loci in 277005 individuals without previous CVD. We scored participants according to their lifestyle factors including body mass index, healthy diet, sedentary lifestyle, alcohol consumption, smoking.

We identified variations in 6 genes associated with levels of liver inflammation and scarring. Participants with variations in 4 of these genes also had higher levels of markers of liver cell injury in blood samples.

We carried out meta-analyses of genome-wide association studies (GWAS) of the first two principal components (PCs) PC1 (global) captured variations of most regions, whereas PC2 (visual) was specific to the primary and secondary visual cortices. We then tested associations with occupational aptitudes and found that the global PC1 was associated with General Learning Ability.

Cross-sectional study examined impact of MHT on left ventricular (LV) and left atrial (LA) structure and function. In this large cohort of post-menopausal women free of cardiovascular disease, MHT was not associated with adverse, subclinical changes in cardiac structure andfunction.

Impaired capacity to increase heart rate (HR) during exercise (&#916;HRex), and a reduced rate of recovery post-exercise (&#915;HRrec) are associated with higher cardiovascular mortality rates. Currently, the genetic basis of both phenotypes remains to be elucidated. We conduct genome-wide association studies (GWASs) in 40,000 individuals and 27,000 independent samples.

This study sough to answer whether the risk of atherosclerotic cardiovascular disease was different between individuals with without genetic causes for high levels of low-density lipoprotein cholesterol in the blood. In this cohort study of 48 741 adults recruited by the UK Biobank, a monogenic cause for hypercholesterolemia was found in 277 participants (0.57%) and a polygenic cause in 2379 participants (4.9%).

 Differences in cardiac and aortic structure and function are associated with cardiovascular diseases and a wide range of other types of disease. Here we analyzed cardiovascular magnetic resonance images from a population-based study, the UK Biobank, using an automated machine-learning-based analysis pipeline. We report a comprehensive range of structural and functional phenotypes for the heart and aorts across 26,893 participants.

Using a meta-scoring approach, we develop a metaGRS for ischaemic stroke (IS) We analyse this score in the UK Biobank (n = 395,393; 3075 IS events by age 75) The MetaGRS hazard ratio for IS (1.26, 95% CI 1.22-1.31) doubles that of a previous GRS.

We present an atlas of genetic associations for 118 non-binary and 660 binary traits of 452,264 UK Biobank participants of European ancestry. Results are compiled in a publicly accessible database that allows querying genome-wide association results for 9,113,133 genetic variants.

 Moderate coffee consumption has been inversely associated with mortality. It remained unclear whether heavy intake, particularly among those with common genetic polymorphisms that impair caffeine metabolism, increases risk of mortality. In this large prospective cohort study of a half million people, we found inverse associations for coffee drinking.

 genome-wide association study identified 1,362 independent SNPs that clustered into 899 loci of which 613 are new. Data were used to train a genetic algorithm using 22,886 SNPs as predictors. Combining this genetic algorithm with height, weight, age and sex resulted in a correlation with heel bone mineral density of 0.496.

 Depression with atypical features shows different heritability and different degree of overlap with polygenic risk for psychiatric and immuno-metabolic traits than other depression subgroups.

This study aimed to investigate associations between fat mass (i.e., body mass index [BMI], waist circumference [WC], and waist to hip ratio [WTHR]) and hippocampal volumes. Our findings indicate that the detrimental effects of overweight/obesity on the neurological health of individuals may extend beyond the duration of overweight.

Common variant heritability has been widely reported to be concentrated in variants within cell-type-specific non-coding functional annotations. Little is known about low-frequency variant functional architectures. We partitioned the heritability of both low- frequency (0.5%&#8804; minor allele frequency) and high-frequency variants.

We conducted a Genome wide association study of a suicidality scale. We validated our results by using Polygenic risk scoring ( a method that allows us to calculate an individual s genetic loading for a trait. We found that the loading for suicIDality was higher in those who had committed suicide.

Coffee-related genetic variants could be used as proxies for coffee consumption in Mendelian randomization studies. Study examined their association with non-alcoholic beverage consumption and a range of socio-demographic and life-style factors. Genetic risk scores demonstrated positive associations with caffeinated and decaffeinated coffee and tea consumption.

Research examining associations between air pollution exposure and respiratory symptoms in adults has generally been inconclusive. This may be related in part to sample size issues, which also preclude analysis in potentially vulnerable subgroups. We estimated associations between. air pollution exposures and the prevalence of wheeze and shortness of breath. using harmonized baseline data from two very large European cohorts.

Ambient air pollution increases the risk of respiratory mortality. Evidence for impacts on lung function and chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD) is less well established. We used UK Biobank data on 303 887 individuals aged 40-69 years. COPD was associated with higher concentrations of PM 2.5 and PM 10.

The UK Biobank is a large-scale population-based study utilising cardiovascular magnetic resonance (CMR) to generate measurements of atrial and ventricular structure and function. Age, sex, ethnicity (non-modifiable), systolic blood pressure, diastolic blood. pressure, smoking status, exercise, body mass index (BMI), high cholesterol, diabetes, alcohol intake (modifiable) were considered important cardiovascular risk factors.

Genetic factors are believed to affect risk for irritable bowel syndrome (IBS) There have been no sufficiently powered and adequately sized studies. We performed a genome-wide association study (GWAS) of the large UK Biobank population-based cohort.

Those who very rarely consume alcohol performed better than moderate drinkers. As consumption increased beyond moderate consumption performance declined. To preserve cognitive performance drinkers should limit their average daily consumption to 8 grams of alcohol.

Habitual coffee consumption has been associated with lower risk of type 2 diabetes, cardiovascular disease, and sarcopenia. In addition, caffeine intake stimulates attention and vigilance, and reduces reaction time. A protective effect of coffee on the risk of falling can be hypothesized.

In observational studies, early menopause is associated with lower forced vital capacity (FVC) and a higher risk of spirometric restriction, but not airflow obstruction. It is, however, unclear if this association is causal. We used a Mendelian randomisation (MR) approach, which is not affected by classical confounding. We included 94 742 naturally post-menopausal women from the UK Biobank.

KnockoffZoom is a flexible method that localizes causal variants at multiple resolutions. It tests the conditional associations of genetic segments of decreasing width. The method can detect more associations than mixed effects models.

Cigarette smoking is associated with increased risk for myriad health consequences including cognitive decline and dementia. In the current study, we assessed the relationship of cigarette smoking with gray matter (GM) and white matter (WM) in the UK Biobank. Ever smoked and duration were associated with smaller total GM volume.

Some previous evidence has linked dairy products with greater muscle mass, bone mineral density and lower risk of osteoporosis. Other authors have found a detrimental effect of milk on the risk of hip fracture.

This paper tested for associations between depression, chronic inflammatory conditions (like rheumatoid arthritis), and cognitive abilities of memory, reasoning, and reaction time. It was found that both (sets of) conditions associated with worse cognitive abilities, but they did not interact.

The adverse impact of visual impairment and blindness and correlations with socioeconomic position are known. Understanding of the effect of the substantially more common near-normal vision (mild impairment) and associations with social position as well as health and life chances is limited.

One type of white blood cell which is commonly assessed with regular blood samples by your GP may be helpful in determining men at higher risk than others. This is taking into account all their other known risk factors.

For every additional drink consumed per day of total fluid, the risk of kidney stones declined by 13%. Similar patterns of associations were observed for tea, coffee, and alcohol. Fruit and fibre intake was also associated with a lower risk. Meat and salt intake was associated with higher risk. Vegetable, fish, and cheese intake was not associated with kidney stones.

Over 350,000 people from across the UK told us the mode(s) of transport they used to get to work. We linked this to information from hospital admission data, cancer registries and death certificates. More active patterns of travel were associated with a reduced risk of heart attacks and deaths.

To assess the relationship between physical activity levels and the risk of disease or death, researchers have to follow study participants over a period of time. Prior to this study, it was not known whether the length of that follow-up time makes a difference to the relationships seen. Using UK Biobank data, we investigated the relationships between. physical activity and mortality and cardiovascular disease.

Calcific aortic valve stenosis (CAVS) is a common and life-threatening heart disease. Current treatment options cannot stop or delay its progression. PALMD (palmdelphin) was found to be significantly associated with CAVS.

More severe depressive symptoms were associated with reduced likelihood of breast (OR = 0.960, 95% CI: 0.950,0.970) and cervical screening participation, in cross-sectional analyses. Higher neuroticism scores were linked to reduced cervical screening, but the opposite was found for breast cancer screening.

Suicide is a worldwide public health problem with more than 800,000 deaths due to suicide each year. Rates of suicide are far exceeded by suicide attempts, which occur up to 20 times more frequently, making suicidality a huge personal, social and economic burden.

Dental caries and periodontitis account for a vast burden of morbidity and healthcare spending, yet their genetic basis remains largely uncharacterized. We identify self-reported dental disease proxies which have similar underlying genetic contributions to clinical disease measures. We then combine these in a genome-wide association study meta-analysis, identifying 47 novel and conditionally-independent risk loci for dental caries.

Fifty four percent of participants aged 40-69 years had refractive error. 27% had myopia (4% high myopia), which was more common amongst younger people, those of higher socio-economic status, or of White or Chinese ethnicity. frequency of hypermetropia increased with age, was higher in women and its severity was associated with ethnicity.

UK Biobank study included 117 278 participants aged 40 to 69 years in 6 regional centers in England and Wales. Patients underwent autorefraction measurement. Spherical equivalent in the more extreme eye was used to categorize myopia and hypermetropia.

Women with premature and early menopause had a substantially increased risk of a non-fatal cardiovascular disease event before the age of 60 years, but not after age 70 years. Compared with women who hadMenopause at age 50 51 years, women with premature had an increased risk.

Mean ages were 12.9 years at menarche, 25.7 years at first birth, and 50.5 years at natural menopause. The prevalence of nulliparity rose progressively from 14% of women born from 1940 49 to 22% of woman born 1970 84. Women with higher education levels had fewer children, later first birth and laterMenopause than women with lower education levels.

Early menopause is associated with an increased risk of subsequent cardiovascular disease (CVD) Few studies have investigated the converse. We examined whether premenopausal CVD events are associated with early age atMenopause. We pooled data of 177,131 women from nine studies.

 duration of smoking was a strong predictor of age at natural menopause. Smokers who had quit smoking for more than 10 years had similar risk as never smokers.

A group of experts in mental health disorders in the population worked together with UK Biobank scientists to design and send out a questionnaire about mental health. The questionnaire aimed to tell the difference between participants who had experienced depression, anxiety or addiction disorders and those who had not. They also asked about self-harm and unusual experiences, and about their overall wellbeing. The people who responded tended to be more educated and slightly more healthy.

Between 2009 and 2010, 117 281 subjects recruited by UK Biobank undertook an ophthalmic assessment, including autorefraction. Of those with refractive error within a range eligible for laser refractive surgery (n = 60 352), 1892 (3.1%) reported having bilateralRefractive surgery and 549 (0.9%) unilateral surgery. Frequency of bilateral surgery decreased with increasing age and was higher in women.

Heart failure (HF) is a morbid and heritable disorder for which the biological mechanisms are incompletely understood. We examined genetic associations with HF in a large national biobank. We refined the HF phenotype by classifying individuals with left ventricular dysfunction as having nonischemic cardiomyopathy (NICM)

We performed large-scale, deep-coverage whole genome sequencing to identify genetic variants related to atrial fibrillation. Rare variation in the gene TTN, encoding the sarcomeric protein titin, was associated with early-onset AF. The findings from common and rare variant analyses were successfully replicated using UKBB and MyCode studies.

Cardiac rhythm abnormalities are prevalent in community-dwelling adults. New rhythm abnormalities developed at a rate of nearly 0.5%/year. Risk of incident cardiac rhythm abnormalities is increased in the setting of older age, male sex, traditional cardiac risk factors, and chronic kidney disease.

Using the UK Biobank, we performed a phenome-wide association study (pheWAS) for 12 AF risk factors. Distinct clusters of variants were associated with AF as well as height, BMI, and hypertension. Results extend our understanding of the biological pathways underlying AF and may facilitate the development of therapeutics for AF.

Lifetime risk of AF is nearly 37 % in individual of European ancestry. Individuals who have higher genetics risk or clinical risks would have higher chance to develop AF. Patients who have a lower clinical risk burden were associated with a later AF onset time.

The UK Biobank assessed Major Depressive Disorder (MDD) and self-reported lifetime exposure to traumatic events in 126,522 genotyped individuals of European ancestry. The SNP-based heritability of MDD with reported trauma exposure (24%) was greater than MDD without trauma exposure.

Tobacco and alcohol use are leading causes of mortality that influence risk for many complex diseases and disorders. They are heritable2,3 and etiologically related behaviors that have been resistant to gene discovery efforts. In sample sizes up to 1.2 million individuals, we discovered 566 genetic variants in 406 loci associated with multiple stages of tobacco use.

Smoking and alcohol use have been associated with common genetic variants in multiple loci. Rare variants within these loci hold promise in the identification of biological mechanisms in substance use. Exome arrays and genotype imputation can now efficiently genotype rare nonsynonymous and loss of function variants.

APOE e4 genotype is found in about 25% of the general population. It is a known risk factor for dementia. It has sometimes been called the 'frailty gene' partly because it seems to increase vulnerability.

Ever-drinking versus non-drink was positively associated with hay fever and inversely with asthma. Genetic predisposition to consume more alcohol did not affect risk of hay fever, asthma, allergic sensitization or serum levels of total IgE. The discrepancy of results between observational and Mendelian randomization analyses could be due to potential residual confounding.

There is no "correct" indicator - all will have advantages and disadvantages. The decision of which indicators to use, and how to combine, will depend on the aims of the study.

Cannabis use is a heritable trait that has been associated with adverse mental health outcomes. UK Biobank data was combined to create the largest genome-wide association study (GWAS) for lifetime cannabis use to date (N=184,765)

Alzheimer's disease (AD) is highly heritable and recent studies have identified over 20 disease-associated genomic loci. Yet these only explain a small proportion of the genetic variance, indicating that undiscovered loci remain. We performed a large genome-wide association study of clinically diagnosed AD and AD-by-proxy (71,880 cases, 383,378 controls)

The Default-mode network (DMN) is a key functional network of the human brain. We conducted genome-wide association analysis to find regions of the genome linked to variation in the functional activity of the DMN. We found that the set of brain-expressed HAR genes to be significantly associated with the phenotypic variation in DMN amplitude.

The link between personality traits and cognitive performance has been extensively studies. Neuroticism and executive functions seem to be particularly involved, and reduced executive function has been proposed to underlie the association of neuroticism with sedentary behaviors and fatty food consumption.

Mosaic loss of the Y chromosome (mLOY) is the most commonly reported large structural somatic event. Previous studies have indicated age and cigarette smoking increase the risk of mLOY. Relationship of other exposures with mLOY and mLOY with disease has not been adequately investigated.

Apolipoprotein (APOE) e4 genotype is an accepted risk factor for accelerated cognitive aging and dementia. The deleterious effects of this genotype on brain structure may increase in magnitude into older age. This study aimed to investigate the association between APOE e4 allele presence vs. absence and brain imaging variables that have been associated with worse cognitive abilities.

Stroke increases the likelihood of social isolation and stroke survivors are at high risk of cognitive decline. We assessed the association between social engagement and cognitive function in a sample of stroke survivors.

Osteoporotic fractures are a major healthcare problem affecting worldwide more than 9 million individuals every year. Genetic predisposition to other clinical risk factors like vitamin D levels and calcium intake were not found to be directly predisposing fracture. interventions aimed at increasing bone and muscle strength are more likely to be successful in preventing fractures.

Study explored impact of our physical health, such as body weight, heart health and blood pressure. We tested 11 measures of physical health including coronary artery disease, heart attack, cholesterol, blood pressure, body fat and BMI. Results suggested a consistent causal effect of higher BMI on lower mental wellbeing.

Frailty indices (FIs) measure variation in health between aging individuals. Researching FIs in resources with large-scale genetic and phenotypic data will provide insights into the causes and consequences of frailty. We aimed to develop an FI using UK Biobank data, a cohort study of 500,000 middle-aged and older adults.

Research analyses whether personalised weight feedback resulted in individuals losing weight over a period of between 2 and 7 years. The effect of feedback was found to be strongly moderated by household income, with those in higher income households accounting for seemingly all of the estimated effect due to increased physical activity.

COPD is the leading cause of respiratory mortality worldwide. We performed a genome-wide association study in 35,735 cases and 222,076 controls. We identified 82 loci associated with P.

Coffee is one of the most widely consumed stimulants worldwide. Increased risk of myocardial infarction and hypertension has been suggested for individuals who carry a functional variant at cytochrome P450 1A2 (CYP1A2)

Coffee's long-term effect on cognitive function remains unclear with studies suggesting both benefits and adverse effects. We used Mendelian randomization to investigate the causal relationship between habitual coffee consumption and cognitive function. This included up to 415,530 participants and 300,760 coffee drinkers from 10 European ancestry cohorts.

 serum 25(OH)D concentration as a causal factor for cognitive performance in mid- to later life. In this study, we combined results from 17 cohorts (with UK Biobank being the largest study)

UK Biobank recruited over 500,000 people aged 40 to 69 years. Participants provided detailed information on health and lifestyle factors including pain and alcohol consumption. Total units consumed per week were calculated for current drinkers. Information was also collected on changes in alcohol consumption and reasons for such changes.

UK Biobank, a cohort study of 0.5 million people aged 40-69 years, recruited throughout Great Britain in 2006-2010. Participants reporting 'pain all over the body' for >3 months were compared with persons without chronic pain.

Hearing loss is associated with changes in brain volume in regions supporting auditory and cognitive processing. Whole-brain gray matter volume was significantly lower for individuals with poorer SRTn. The greatest percentage difference (-0.57%) in ROI volume was found in the left superior temporal gyrus. There was no conclusive evidence that this effect is moderated by hearing aid use.

Study aims to test whether polygenic risk for Alzheimer's disease, Amyotrophic Lateral Sclerosis (ALS), or frontotemporal dementia (FTD) is associated with cognitive function and physical health in the UK Biobank. Higher polygenicrisk for AD, ALS, and FTD was associated with lower cognitive performance.

Alzheimer's disease (AD) is a public health priority for the 21st century. Risk reduction currently revolves around lifestyle changes with much research trying to elucidate the biological underpinnings. We show that self-report of parental history of Alzheimer's dementia is a valid proxy for an AD genetic study.

Study looked at 449,073 UK Biobank participants. Suicide occurred more frequently in those who had high levels of distress. Also scored high in neuroticism and had history of seeing a psychiatrist.

Early menarche, early menopause, earlier age at first birth, and a history of miscarriage, stillbirth or hysterectomy were each associated with a higher risk of CVD in later life. Women who had given birth to more children also had higher subsequent CVD risk.

Excess adipose tissue is a major risk factor for myocardial infarction (MI) There are substantial differences in the distribution of fat between women and men. Measures of central adiposity, particularly waist-to-hip ratio, were more strongly associated with the risk of MI.

Low birthweight has been associated with a higher risk of hypertension, type 2 diabetes mellitus (T2D), and cardiovascular disease. The Barker hypothesis posits that intrauterine growth restriction resulting in lower birthweight is causal for these diseases. We performed regression analyses to assess associations of birthweight with cardiovascular disease and T2D.

Coronary artery disease (CAD) is a common complication among individuals with diabetes. A better understanding of the genetic background of CAD in this population could suggest novel molecular targets for screening, risk assessment and drug development.

Large-scale studies of risk factors for varicose veins may highlight important aspects of pathophysiology and identify groups at increased risk for disease. Machine learning confirmed several known (age, sex, obesity, pregnancy, history of deep vein thrombosis) and identified several new risk factors, including height.

Higher blood pressure indices, smoking intensity, body mass  index, and the presence of diabetes were associated with an increased risk of MI in men and women. Sex specific associations between risk factors and MI declined with age, but, where it occurred, the higher relative risk in women remained.

To date, the effects of the co-occurrence of stroke with other long term conditions have been poorly explored. Increasing multimorbidity was associated with higher all-cause mortality. Mortality risk was double for those with =5 comorbidities.

Isolated and lonely people are at increased risk of death. Health policies addressing risk factors such as adverse socioeconomic conditions, unhealthy lifestyle, and lower mental wellbeing might reduce excess mortality.

More than one in three adults worldwide is either overweight or obese. The location and distribution of excess fat is more informative for predicting risk of obesity sequelae, including cardiometabolic disease and cancer.

Muscle mass measures are used in the current definitions of sarcopenia. Their usefulness is uncertain because of limited data on their association with health outcomes. This study compared the performance of different muscle mass measures in predicting incident osteoporosis in postmenopausal women.

In December 2019, a novel disease, coronavirus disease 19 (COVID-19), emerged in Wuhan, People's Republic of China. To date, over 300,000 cases of CO VID-19 have been reported in England and over 40,000 patients have died. Recent studies have identified links between air pollution and death rates.

Ongoing studies show that higher hemoglobin A 1c (A1C) predicts coronary artery disease (CAD) It remains unclear whether this association is driven entirely by glycemia. We used Mendelian randomization to test whether A1C is causally associated with CAD through glycemic and/or nonglycemic factors.

UK Biobank study recruited 40-70-year-olds in 2006-2010. 2658 had been tested for SARS-CoV-2 and 948 tested positive (726 in hospital) Black and south Asian groups were more likely to test positive.

Coffee consumption and cigarette smoking are strongly associated, but whether this association is causal remains unclear. We used Mendelian randomization (MR) analyses of observational data. In-vitro experiments assessed the effect of caffeic acid, quercetin and p-coumaric acid on the rate of nicotine metabolism.

Cigarette smokers are at increased risk of poor sleep behaviors. It is largely unknown whether these associations are due to shared (genetic) risk factors and/or causal effects (which may be bidirectional) We found evidence that smoking more cigarettes causally decreases the odds of being a morning person.

We found some evidence that personality traits are causally linked to certain smoking phenotypes. Among current smokers each additional neuroticism risk allele was associated with smoking an additional 0.07 cigarettes per day. Evidence in the reverse direction, from smoking initiation to personality was weaker.

Recent studies have suggested that even low-intensity smoking might be associated with increased mortality. Smoking is associated with lower socio-economic status as well as other potential risk factors. Disease onset might motivate smoking cessation, thus residual confounding and reverse causality might bias results.

 Observational studies on smoking and risk of hay fever and asthma have shown inconsistent results. However, observational studies may be biased by confounding and reverse causation. Mendelian randomization uses genetic variants as markers of exposures to examine causal effects.

Cigarette smoke increases metabolism of caffeine, so this may represent a causal effect of smoking on caffeine intake. Each additional cigarette per day consumed by current smokers was associated with higher coffee consumption. There was weak evidence for an increase in tea consumption per additional cigarette smoked per day.

There is strong evidence of a positive association between cigarette and alcohol consumption. We tested whether smoking is likely to increase alcohol consumption using a genetic variant (rs1051730/rs16969968)

Frailty and multimorbidity have been suggested as risk factors for severe COVID-19 disease. We investigated whether these factors were associated with risk of hospitalisation. We intend to further investigate the prognostic value of these markers for adverse clinical sequelae.

 increases in fat-free mass and fat mass have been associated with higher risk of atrial fibrillation (AF) in observational studies. Our aim was to evaluate independent causal roles of fat- free mass andfat mass on AF.

UK Biobank participants without cardiovascular disease aged 39-70 completed psychiatric questions relating International Classification of Diseases-10 Revision (ICD-10) diagnostic criteria on a touchscreen questionnaire at baseline interview in 2006-2010.

Urine biomarkers reflecting kidney function and handling of dietary sodium and potassium are strongly associated with several common diseases. Knowledge about the genetic determinants of these biomarkers may shed light on pathophysiological mechanisms underlying the development of these diseases. We highlight GIPR, a potential diabetes drug target, as possibly implicated in the genetic control of urinary potassium excretion.

Data on 36 chronic conditions from 502,643 participants aged 40 to 69 years were extracted from the UK Biobank. The likelihood of co-occurrence of these conditions is 13 times higher than in isolation. Conditions such as diabetes, hypertension, and asthma are the epicenter of disease clusters for multimorbidity.

We examined whether social isolation and loneliness predict acute myocardial infarction (AMI) and stroke among those with no history of AMI or stroke. We also examined the extent to which these associations are explained by known risk factors or pre-existing chronic conditions. Participants were 479,054 individuals from the UK Biobank.

Multimorbidity is associated with higher mortality, but the relationship with cancer and cardiovascular mortality is unclear. The influence of demographics and type of condition on the relationship of multimorbidy with mortality remains unknown. We examine the relationship between multim orbidity and cause of mortality and the impact of demographic factors on this relationship.

People with higher cognitive ability tend to behave in a healthier fashion as regards risk factors for lower respiratory tract infection. There is evidence that they have a lower risk of dying from respiratory disease as a whole.

It is traditional to use data on the underlying cause of death on death certificates. We found associations with known risk factors were essentially the same. This finding has implications when studying risk factors for rare causes of death.

UK Biobank is unusual in that only 6% of people invited to take part in its initial survey agreed to do so. The low response rate has led to debate as to whether findings of links between risk factors and disease are likely to be generalizable.

Using Mendelian randomization, the researchers analyzed genetic variants that predict HbA1c levels and their associations with systolic and diastolic blood pressure. The researchers applied the usual selection criteria for participants in genetic studies, such as including only participants of genetically verified white British descent. The positive association was clearer when invalid genetic instruments were excluded.

Associations between cardiovascular disease (CVD) risk factors and the biventricular geometry of the right ventricle (RV) and left ventricles (LV) have been difficult to assess. We sought to quantify reference RV morphology as well as bivocentular variations associated with common cardiovascular risk factors. A biv centrifugal shape atlas was automatically constructed using contours and landmarks from 4329 UK Biobank cardiovascular magnetic resonance studies.

Urinary sodium excretion correlates with elevated blood pressure in subjects at low cardiovascular risk. No pattern of increased cardiovascular disease, heart failure, or mortality risk was demonstrated with either high or low sodium intake. Hypertension is a risk factor for cardiovascular disease.

Total cholesterol and high-density lipoprotein cholesterol (HDL-C) measurements are central to cardiovascular disease (CVD) risk assessment. There is continuing debate around the utility of other lipids for risk prediction.

UK Biobank is a prospective study of half a million subjects, almost all aged 40-69 years. 14,285 subjects were diagnosed with cancer during a median of 5.1 years of follow-up. A healthy lifestyle based on all five behaviours was associated with a reduction of about one-third in incident cancer.

Machine learning was used to identify risk factors for incident heart failure. Leg bioimpedance was identified as a new marker which was further explored in confirmatory analyses.

Study of association between genetic variants in PCSK9 and phenotypes across the spectrum of human disease. Uses UK Biobank data for discovery and replication of findings.

Using a continuous exposure variable that is measured with random error in a univariable linear regression model leads to regression dilution bias. A repeatability sub-study, where a sample of study participants have their data measured again, can be used to correct for this bias. It is important to perform a sample size calculation for such a sub- study to ensure that correction factors can be estimated with sufficient precision.

Arterial stiffness index (ASI) is a non-invasive measure of arterial stiffness using infra-red finger sensors (photoplethysmography) ASI is a well-suited measure for large populations as it is relatively inexpensive to perform.

Heart rate (HR) responds to exercise by increasing during exercise and recovering after exercise. HR is an important predictor of mortality that researchers believe is modulated by the autonomic nervous system. The mechanistic basis underlying inter-individual differences has yet to be explained.

 driving is a common type of sedentary behaviour; an independent risk factor for poor health. Study explores whether driving is also associated with other unhealthy lifestyle factors.

Vitamin D deficiency (serum 25-hydroxyvitamin D 60 years), and those living outside of Greater London (OR=0.53 to 0.77), with borderline trends for a lower body mass index, higher oily fish intake and higher household income.

This work investigates whether genetic makeup moderates the effects of education on health. The additional schooling affected body size, lung function, and blood pressure in middle age. The improvements in body size and lung function were larger for individuals with high genetic predisposition to obesity.

Graph representations are commonly used to model structural or functional connectivity between a set of brain regions. Most existing methods fail to accommodate the graph structure. We propose to learn a graph similarity metric using a siamese graph convolutional neural network (s-GCN) in a supervised setting.

We have found no evidence that maternal circulating 25(OH)D affects offspring birth weight. We also used genetic variants for serum Calcium (from the O Seaghdha et al 2013 GWAS) to perform Mendelian Randomisation.

A number of open questions in human evolutionary genetics would become tractable if we were able to directly measure evolutionary fitness. We found only a few common variants with large effects on age-specific mortality: tagging the APOE &#949;4 allele and near CHRNA3.

Gene-set analysis provides insight into which functional and biological properties of genes are aetiologically relevant for a particular phenotype. We applied our approach to blood pressure phenotypes in the UK Biobank data. We confirm and further refine several associations with multiple processes involved in heart and blood vessel formation.

Intelligence is highly heritable1 and a major determinant of human health and well-being. Recent genome-wide meta-analyses have identified 24 genomic loci linked to variation in intelligence. Here, we present a large-scale genetic association study of intelligence (n = 269,867)

Multi-trait analysis of GWAS (MTAG) is a method for joint analysis of summary statistics from genome-wide association studies (GWAS) of different traits. MTAG increases the number of associated loci to 64, 37, and 49, respectively.

 Observational and Mendelian Randomization analyses of urinary biomarkers in the UK Biobank. In observational analyses, urinary sodium and potassium ratio showed significant inverse associations with atrial fibrillation, coronary artery disease, ischemic stroke,  lipid-lowering medication, and T2D. In contrast, urine albumin adjusted for creatinine showed significant positive associations with heart failure and hemorrhagic stroke.

Study explores contribution of anthropometric and reproductive factors in UK females developing BC. Data from the UK Biobank prospective study of 273,467 UK females were analyzed.
