Increase in age, height, having low BMI, low waist to hip ratio, first degree family history of BC, early menarche age, nulliparous, late age at first live birth, and high reproductive interval index were all significantly associated with an increased risk of BC.

The use of cannabis has previously been linked to both depression and self-harm. The role of genetics in this relationship is unclear. This study aimed to test for evidence of genetic associations. We found that in UK Biobank, cannabis use is associated with an increased likelihood of depression.

Study examined associations of current and lifetime night shift work exposure with type 2 diabetes risk. Compared with day workers, all current night shift workers were at higher multivariable-adjusted odds. Working more night shifts per month was associated with higher type 2 Diabetes odds.

Timmers et al. used genetic data from UK Biobank and other European cohorts alongside information on their parents lifespans to pinpoint DNA regions. They identified 12 such regions, of which five were new and had not been linked to lifespan before.

There is clear evidence that smoking lowers weight. It is possible that individuals with higher body mass index (BMI) smoke in order to lose or maintain their weight. The relationship is likely to be complex due to opposing effects on behaviour and metabolism.

Hair colour within European populations is a complex genetic trait. MC1R variants are the principal genetic cause of red hair colour, but with variable penetrance. Blonde hair is associated with over 200 genetic variants. Many of the associated genes are involved in hair growth or texture.

Physical inactivity is a highly modifiable risk factor for the development of osteoporosis. There is a lack of research that has precisely and objectively meaured physical activity (PA) relevant to bone. This study examined whether a more precise measure of PA relelvant to bone was associated with meaures of bone health.

Birth weight variation is influenced by fetal and maternal genetic and non-genetic factors. In expanded genome-wide association analyses, we identified 190 independent association signals. Using maternal birth weight-lowering genotypes to proxy for an adverse intrauterine environment provided no evidence.

Male pattern baldness (MPB) is a sex-limited, age-related, complex trait. We study MPB genetics in 205,327 European males from the UK Biobank. MPB is strongly heritable and polygenic. Correlations with reproductive traits imply an effect on fitness.

More research is needed on the safety of diuretics in routine care. Physicians and pharmacists are advised to clarify additional laxative use in users of non-potassium-sparing diuretic.

Previous studies have mostly used body mass index (BMI) as the main exposure of interest. Whether more precise measures of body fat, such as body fat percentage and fat mass estimated by bioimpedance analyses, are better indicators of risk than BMI is unknown.

Major depressive disorder (MDD) has been the subject of many neuroimaging case-control classification studies. Although some studies report accuracies &#8805;80%, most have investigated relatively small samples of clinically-ascertained, currently symptomatic cases. We here first aimed to replicate previously reported classification accuracies in a small, well-phenotyped community-based group of current MDD cases.

Previous studies have found common genetic factors that influence educational achievement, cognitive performance and total brain volume (i.e., brain size) Here, we investigate the shared genetic basis between educational attainment and fine-grained cerebral cortical morphological features. We associate this genetic variation with a related aspect of cognitive ability.

Study looked at 86,759 middle- to older-aged adults from the UK Biobank general population cohort. Small but consistent negative associations between air pollutant exposure and baseline cognitive performance. Follow-up analyses of cognitive change scores did not show evidence of associations.

 Associations between driving and physical-activity (PA) intensities are unclear, particularly among older adults. We studied 90 810 UK Biobank participants (56.1 +/- 7.8 years) Driving status, specific travel modes (non-work travel; commuting to/from work) and covariates were assessed by questionnaire. PA was assessed over 7 days by wrist-worn accelerometers (2013-15)

Identifying genes that contribute to the variability in brain regions involved in language processing may shed light on the evolution of brain structures essential to the emergence of language in Homo sapiens. The superior temporal asymmetrical pit (STAP), which is not observed in chimpanzees, represents an ideal phenotype to investigate the genetic variations that support human communication.

The Human Pain Genetics Database (HPGDB) is a comprehensive variant-focused inventory of genetic contributors to human pain. After curation, the HPGDB currently includes 294 studies reporting associations between 434 distinct genetic variants and various pain phenotypes.

Genome-wide association studies (GWAS) have identified thousands of loci that are robustly associated with complex diseases. The use of linear mixed model (LMM) methodology for GWAS is becoming more prevalent due to its ability to control for population structure and cryptic relatedness.

Comorbidity patterns have become a major source of information to explore shared mechanisms of pathogenesis between disorders. In hypothesis-free exploration of comorbid conditions, disease-disease networks are usually identified by pairwise methods. We used a subset of the UK Biobank Resource, a cross-sectional dataset including 247 diseases.

Overweight and obesity are increasing worldwide. To help assess their relevance to mortality in different populations we conducted individual-participant data meta-analyses of prospective studies of body-mass index (BMI) The associations of both overweight and obesity with higher all-cause mortality were broadly consistent in four continents.

Major depression is a debilitating psychiatric illness that is typically associated with low mood and anhedonia. Depression has a heritable component that has remained difficult to elucidate with current sample sizes due to the polygenic nature of the disorder. We identified 102 independent variants, 269 genes, and 15 genesets associated with depression.

The problem drinking is genetically correlated with psychopathology. Alcohol consumption shares a genetic profile with a more favourable health profile. The last 7 questions of the AUDIT questionnaire are important to detect genetic variation which is specific to problem drinking. These items should be retained when attempting to uncover the genetic basis of alcohol use disorders.

People carrying the protective TYK2 variant were no more likely to have serious infections or to develop cancer than people without the variant. This suggests TYK 2 as a potential therapeutic target with few side effects.

Major depressive disorder is a result of the complex interplay between a large number of environmental and genetic factors. The primary aim of this work was to create a Bayesian dependency map of environmental factors of depression.

4.1% of the variation in the mate height choice is determined by a person's own genotype, as expected in a model where one's height determines the choice of mate height. The genotype of an individual predicts their partners' height in an independent dataset of 15,437 individuals with 13 % accuracy, which is 64 % of the theoretical maximum achievable with a heritability of 0.041.

A positive relationship between brain volume and intelligence has been suspected since the 19th century. This claim is controversial because of concerns about publication bias and the lack of systematic control for critical confounding factors (e.g., height, population structure) We conducted a preregistered study of the relationship. using a new sample of adults from the United Kingdom.

A large dataset of about 32,000 subjects scanned from neck to knee and aged 44-82 years from the UK Biobank study was used for a machine-based analysis. We trained a convolutional neural network based on the VGG16 architecture to predict the age of a given subject.

Recent genome-wide association studies (GWAS) of height and body mass index (BMI) have led to the discovery of nearly independent single nucleotide polymorphisms (SNPs) associated with these traits. We identified 3290 and 941 near-independent SNPs associated with height and BMI, respectively. Overall, our combined GWAS meta-analysis reaches N &#8764;700000 individuals.

Physical inactivity is associated with an increased risk of major chronic diseases. We compared the physical activity of those with chronic diseases to healthy individuals. Participants in every chronic-disease subgroup undertook less physical activity than those without chronic disease.

We present a new software package with a library of standardised tractography protocols devised for the robust automated extraction of white matter tracts both in the human and the macaque brain. Using in vivo data from the Human Connectome Project (HCP) and the UK Biobank, we obtain white matter atlases for both species.

Age-related hearing impairment (ARHI) is the most common sensory impairment in the aging population. A third of individuals are affected by disabling hearing loss by the age of 65. It causes social isolation and depression and has recently been identified as a risk factor for dementia.

Health risk factors such as body mass index (BMI) and serum cholesterol are associated with many common diseases. It often remains unclear whether the risk factors are cause or consequence of disease, or whether the associations are the result of confounding. We identify a number of causal associations.

The macula, located near the center of the retina in the human eye, is responsible for providing critical functions, such as central, sharp vision. Structural changes in the macula are associated with many ocular diseases, including age-related macular degeneration and glaucoma. Although macular thickness is a highly heritable trait, there are no prior reported genome-wide association studies (GWASs) of it.

Risk models based on easily obtainable data have relatively good discrimination in a UK population. Modelling studies are now required to estimate the potential health benefits and cost-effectiveness of implementing stratified risk-based CRC screening.

Clonally expanded blood cells that contain somatic mutations (clonal haematopoiesis) are commonly acquired with age and increase the risk of blood cancer. The sources of selective advantage that drive the expansion of most clones remain unknown. We analysed genotyping data from the blood-derived DNA of 482,789 participants from the UK Biobank.

 Increased levels of the urinary albumin-to-creatinine ratio (UACR) are associated with higher risk of kidney disease progression and cardiovascular events. Here, we conduct trans-ethnic and European-ancestry specific meta-analyses of genome-wide association studies of UACR. Results generate a priority list of genes and pathways to reduce albuminuria.

Elevated serum urate levels cause gout and correlate with cardiometabolic diseases via poorly understood mechanisms. We identified 183 loci (147 previously unknown) that improve the prediction of gout in an independent cohort of 334,880 individuals. Transcriptional coregulation within and across organs may be a general mechanism underlying the observed pleiotropy.

Chronic kidney disease (CKD) is responsible for a public health burden with multi-systemic complications. A genetic risk score for lower eGFR was associated with clinically diagnosed CKD in 452,264 independent individuals. Fine-mapping highlighted missense driver variants in 11 genes and kidney-specific regulatory variants. These results provide a comprehensive priority list of molecular targets for translational research.

Disease variants identified by genome-wide association studies (GWAS) tend to overlap with expression quantitative trait loci (eQTLs) It remains unclear whether this overlap is driven by gene expression levels 'mediating' genetic effects on disease. Here, we introduce a new method, mediated expression score regression (MESC), to estimate disease heritability.

The hippocampus is a heterogeneous structure, comprising histologically distinguishable subfields. These subfields are differentially involved in memory consolidation, spatial navigation and pattern separation. Complex functions often impaired in individuals with brain disorders characterized by reduced hippocampal volume, including Alzheimer s disease and schizophrenia.

Using structural MRI data from 45,615 individuals aged 3 96 years, we demonstrate distinct patterns of apparent brain aging in several brain disorders. We also reveal genetic pleiotropy between apparent brain Aging in healthy individuals and common brain Disorders. Common risk factors for psychiatric and other brain disorders are likely to converge on biological pathways.

The grey and white matter volumes are known to reduce with age. We found that the heritability of the sulcal opening ranges from 15 to 45% (SE = 4.8%). We identified 4 new loci that contribute to this opening, including one that also affects the sulci grey matter thickness.

Few large-scale population-level cardiac imaging studies have been conducted. We present and evaluate a cardiac magnetic resonance (CMR) image analysis pipeline that properly scales up and can provide a fully automatic analysis.

Multifactorial disease signatures provide unique insights into the architecture of complex disease populations. These insights can be used to better stratify patient groups, aiding the delivery of precision medicine.

Alzheimer's disease (AD) is a devastating neurodegenerative condition with significant genetic heritability. Several genes have been implicated in the onset of AD with the apolipoprotein E (APOE) gene being the strongest single genetic risk loci. Evidence suggests that the effect of APOE alters with age during disease progression.

To further dissect the genetic architecture of colorectal cancer (CRC), we performed whole-genome sequencing of 1,439 cases and 720 controls. We discovered a strongly protective 0.3% frequency variant signal at CHD1. New signals implicate lower-frequency variants, Kr ppel-like factors, Hedgehog signaling, Hippo-YAP signaling and long noncoding RNAs.

Researchers identified 153 new loci associated with heel bone mineral density. They also conducted in vivo studies that implicated GPC6 and several other genes in osteoporosis.

Neuroticism is a relatively stable personality trait characterized by negative emotionality. Increased neuroticism is associated with poorer mental and physical health. Genome-wide association studies (GWAS) of neuroticism have identified up to 11 associated genetic loci.

Fine-mapping aims to identify causal variants impacting complex traits. We propose PolyFun, a computationally scalable framework to improve fine- mapping accuracy. PolyFun prioritizes variants for functional follow-up and provides insights into complex trait architectures.

Deep-learning models for the automated measurement of retinal vessel calibre in retinal photographs. The models performed comparably to or better than expert graders in associations of measurements with cardiovascular disease (CVD) risk factors.

The melanocortin 4 receptor (MC4R) is a G protein-coupled receptor whose disruption causes obesity. We functionally characterized 61 MC4R variants identified in 0.5 million people from UK Biobank and examined their associations with body mass index (BMI) and obesity-related cardiometabolic diseases. We found that the maximal efficacy of &#946;-arrestin recruitment to MC4r, rather than canonical G&#945; s -mediated cyclic adenosine-monophosphate production, explained 88% of the variance in the association with BMI.

Autosomal variants have successfully been associated with trait neuroticism in genome-wide analysis of adequately powered samples. Most of the lead neuroticism-related X chromosome variants were located in intergenic regions. Involvement of HS6ST2, previously associated with sociability behaviour in the dog, was supported by single SNP and gene-based tests.

The genetic risk for schizophrenia was not randomly distributed across the UK. Risk alleles were more common in urban/densely populated areas, consistent with the reporter higher rates of schizophrenia observed in urban area.

Genome-wide association studies (GWAS) of psychological traits are generally conducted on (dichotomized) sums of items or symptoms. We conduct large-scale GWAS on 12 neuroticism items and observe notable and replicable variation in genetic signal between items. We conclude that the items used to measure neuroticism are genetically heterogeneous.

Low back pain (LBP) is a common disabling condition. Lumbar disc degeneration (LDD) may be a contributing factor for LBP. Modic change (MC), a distinct phenotype of LDD, is strongly associated with LBP and has heritability around 30%. Our objective was to identify genetic loci associated with MC using a genome-wide meta-analysis.

Chronic musculoskeletal pain affects all aspects of human life. The mechanisms of its genetic control remain poorly understood. Here, we apply principal component analysis to reduce phenotype heterogeneity of pain at four locations.

Body fat accumulation is associated with back pain, but a causal association is unclear. We hypothesized that BMI would have causal effects on back pain. We conducted a two-sample Mendelian randomization study to assess the causal effect of body mass index (BMI) on the outcomes of back pain and chronic back pain (duration > 3 months)

Back pain (BP) is a common condition of major social importance and poorly understood pathogenesis. We identified and replicated 3 BP-associated loci, including one novel region implicating SPOCK2/CHST3 genes. We provide evidence for pleiotropic effects of genetic factors underlying BP, height, and intervertebral disk problems.

Back pain is the #1 cause of years lived with disability worldwide. Little is known regarding the biology underlying this symptom. We conducted a genome-wide association study (GWAS) meta-analysis of chronic back pain (CBP)

Study finds that adding genetic information improves the performance of established tools for calculating disease risk. Researchers used data from UK Biobank both to build a better disease risk model and to evaluate its effectiveness.

A new integrated risk tool combines clinical and polygenic risk scores. Prediction is significantly enhanced in multiple ethnicities and ancestries. This is the first positive cross-ethnicity cross-ancestry validation of such a tool.

Back pain (BP) is a common condition of major social importance and poorly understood pathogenesis. Intervertebral lumbar disc degeneration in all its guises is one of the major biological risk factors for BP. Previously, we identified the locus at 8q24.21 associated with chronic BP, which has been found elsewhere associated with sciatica after surgery.

Lipoprotein(a) is an atherogenic low-density lipoprotein like particle and circulating levels are largely determined by genetics. Patients with familial hypercholesterolemia, an autosomal dominant genetic disorder, have been observed to have elevated levels of lipop protein(a), but it remains unclear why. In this cohort study of the UK Biobank, levels were not statistically different between individuals with and without a familialhypercholesterolesmia-associated variant.

Coronavirus disease 2019 (COVID-19) is a novel coronavirus strain disease caused by severe acute respiratory syndrome coronav virus 2 (SARS-CoV-2) The disease is highly transmissible and severe disease including viral sepsis has been reported in up to 16% of hospitalized cases. The admission characteristics associated with increased odds of hospital mortality include severe hypoxia, low platelet count and elevated bilirubin.

As many as 20% of individuals who test positive for COVID-19 develop severe symptoms that can require hospitalization. These symptoms include low platelet count, severe hypoxia, increased inflammatory cytokines and reduced glomerular filtration rate. Severe CO VID-19 is associated with several chronic co-morbidities, including cardiovascular disease and type 2 diabetes mellitus.

SBayesR is a Bayesian multiple regression model that uses summary statistics from genome-wide association studies. In simulation and cross-validation using 12 real traits and 1.1 million variants on 350,000 individuals from the UK Biobank, it improves prediction accuracy.

The CMO test integrates genetically regulated DNA methylation and enhancer-target gene pairs with genome-wide association study (GWAS) summary results. By analyzing to date the largest AD GWAS of 71,880 cases and 383,378 controls, CMO identified six novel loci for AD.

Metabolic syndrome (MetS) and its components may link to pancreatic cancer risk. Current epidemiological evidence is limited, and the potential mechanisms underlying the associations remain unclear. To investigate this, we carried out a prospective cohort study of 474 929 participants without a diagnosis of cancer based on UK Biobank dataset.

Serum uric acid was measured at baseline and the incidence and mortality of kidney cancer was determined through contact with the cancer and death registry. People with the highest quartile had a 45% increased risk of kidney. cancer compared to those with the lowest uri acid quartile.

UK Biobank studied 230&#x2009;390 commuters (52.1% women; mean age 52.4 years) Cyclists to work had a lower risk of cardiovascular disease, cancer, and death than those who did not. Longer cycling distances during commuting were associated with a higher risk of injury.

A DL algorithm was trained using a retrospective dataset of 86,618 images. It was assessed for glaucomatous ONH features and referable GON (defined as ONH appearance worrisome enough to justify referral for comprehensive examination)

Adversity experiences (AEs) are major risk factors for psychiatric illness. Evidence suggests that adversity-related changes in brain structure enhance this vulnerability. To achieve greater understanding of the underlying biological pathways, increased convergence among findings is needed.

Air pollution has consistently been associated with cardiometabolic outcomes, but associations with obesity have only been recently reported. We used the UK Biobank, a large, prospective cohort study in the United Kingdom, to explore the relationship between air pollution and adiposity. All air pollution measures except IDTR were positively associated with at least one continuous measure of adiposity at enrollment.

Machine learning-based phenotyping in genetic association analysis is misclassification problem. To evaluate chances and challenges, we performed a GWAS based on automatically classified age-related macular degeneration (AMD) in UK Biobank. We demonstrate our MLA guards against bias and artifacts in simulation studies.

It is known that vascular disease risk factors, such as smoking or diabetes, are related to cognitive performance. This paper investigates whether measurements of brain health derived from the MRI data, namely measures of how well the various areas of the brain are connected to each other, mediate the relationship between vascular risk factors and cognition.

We used data from the UK Biobank to combine polygenic risk scores (PRS) for 13 diseases and 12 mortality risk factors into a sex-specific composite PRS. These cPRS were moderately associated with all-cause mortality. These associations were substantially attenuated after adjusting for non-genetic mortality Risk factors measured at study entry.

We evaluated how robust signals of polygenic adaptation are to the choice of GWAS cohort used to identify associated variants. We show that meta analysis creates overdispersion across populations which appears likes signs of polygenetic seleciton.

This study presents an automated framework for tissue characterisation from native shortened modified Look-Locker inversion recovery ShMOLLI T1 mapping at 1.5 T using a Probabilistic Hierarchical Segmentation (PHiSeg) network. We use the uncertainty information provided by the PHiSeg network in a novel automated quality control (QC) step to identify uncertain T1 values.

This study aims to evaluate the causal association of blood pressure (BP) with cardiovascular diseases (CVDs) Two-sample Mendelian randomization was performed using a large genome-wide association study (n=299&#x2009;024) and the UK Biobank cohort. Genetically predicted BP was significantly positively associated with total CVD.

Genotype-by-environment interaction (GEI) is a fundamental component in understanding complex trait variation. It remains challenging to identify genetic variants with GEI effects in humans largely because of the small effect sizes and the difficulty of monitoring environmental fluctuations. Here, we demonstrate that GEI can be inferred from genetic variants associated with phenotypic variability in a large sample.

Applying deep learning in population genomics is challenging because of computational issues and lack of interpretable models. We propose GenNet, a novel open-source deep learning framework for predicting phenotypes from genetic variants. In this framework, interpretable and memory-efficient neural network architectures are constructed.

Few studies have explored the interplay between monogenic and polygenic risk. We study 80,928 individuals to examine whether polygenic background can modify penetrance of disease in tier 1 genomic conditions. Among carriers of a monogenic risk variant, we estimate substantial gradients in disease risk.

Coffee consumption might have a beneficial effect on hearing function because of the antioxidant and anti-inflammatory properties of some of its compounds. No previous longitudinal study has assessed the association between coffee consumption and the risk of hearing impairment.

In most human societies, there are taboos and laws banning mating between first- and second-degree relatives. But actual prevalence and effects on health and fitness are poorly quantified. Here, we leverage a large observational study of ~450,000 participants of European ancestry from the UK Biobank to quantify extreme inbreeding.

Deciphering the shared genetic basis of distinct cancers has the potential to elucidate carcinogenic mechanisms and inform broadly applicable risk assessment efforts. We undertake genome-wide association studies (GWAS) and comprehensive evaluations of heritability and pleiotropy across 18 cancer types.

There is evidence that mental disorders are more frequently reported among emergency services personnel due to the stressful nature of the job in combination with a high exposure to traumatic events. Most of this research is based on occupational surveys that may lead to a contextual bias in the prevalence estimates or lack an adequate comparison group.

Study identified 3 loci that reached genome-wide statistical significance. TIMP2, Col5A1, TGFBR1, and TNC genes were found to have significantly upregulated tissue expression in cases vs. controls supporting a biologic role in tearing for these genes. Expression of the THSD7A gene was significantly downregulated in rotator cuff tears.

Among 4855 participants tested for SARS-CoV-2 in hospital, 839 were positive and of these 189 died from COVID-19. BMI was more strongly related to test positivity and death in non-whites (predominantly South Asians and Afro-Caribbeans), compared with whites. If future studies confirm causality, lifestyle interventions to improve adiposity status may be important.

Anhedonia is a core symptom of several psychiatric disorders but its biological underpinnings are poorly understood. We performed a genome-wide association study of state anhedonia in 375,275 UK Biobank participants and assessed for genetic correlation. Strong positive genetic correlations were found between anhedoni and major depressive disorder, schizophrenia and bipolar disorder. Polygenic risk for anhedonian was associated with poorer brain white matter integrity, smaller total grey matter volume, and smaller volumes of brain regions linked to reward and pleasure.

Excretion of albumin in urine is associated with the development of multiple cardiovascular and metabolic diseases. Whether pathways leading to albuminuria are causal for cardiometabolic diseases is unclear. We addressed this question using a Mendelian randomization framework in the UK Biobank, a large population-based cohort.

Telomeres are DNA-protein structures at the ends of chromosomes essential in maintaining chromosomal stability. Observational studies have identified associations between telomeres and elevated cancer risk, including hematologic malignancies. Biologic mechanisms relating telomere length to cancer etiology remain unclear.

IBDkin is a software package written in C for estimating kinship coefficients from identity by descent (IBD) segments. We use IBDkin to estimate kinship coefficient for 7.95 billion pairs of individuals in the UK Biobank who share at least one detected IBD segment with length &#8805; 4 cM.

 Pharmacogenetics studies the influence of genetic variation on drug response. We analyzed PGx allele and phenotype frequencies for 487,409 participants in the UK Biobank, the largest PGx study to date. Non-European populations carry a greater frequency of variants that are predicted to be functionally deleterious.

Urinary sodium and potassium excretion are associated with blood pressure (BP) and cardiovascular disease (CVD) The exact biological link between these traits is yet to be elucidated. Here, we identify 50 loci for sodium and 13 forassium excretion in a large-scale genome-wide association study.

Vitamin D deficiency is a candidate risk factor for a range of adverse health outcomes. In a genome-wide association study of 25 hydroxyvitamin D (25OHD) concentration in 417,580 Europeans we identify 143 independent loci.

Study evaluated the effect of AMP-activated protein kinase (AMPK), the target of metformin, on risk of cardiovascular disease and cancer. Genetically predicted reduction in HbA1c (%) instrumented by AMPK variants was associated with a 61% reduction in risk of type 2 diabetes. Results were similar using median or quartiles of AMPK score.

Hippocampal volume is an important biomarker of Alzheimer's disease (AD) Genetic risk of AD is associated with hippocampal atrophy. The hippocampus is not a uniform structure and has a number of subfields. Age was negatively associated with all the hippocampal subfield volumes and females had smaller volumes than men.

Alzheimer's disease is a neurodegenerative condition where the underlying etiology is still unclear. Investigating the potential influence of apolipoprotein E (APOE), a major genetic risk factor, on common blood biomarkers could provide a greater understanding of the mechanisms of AD and dementia risk.

This paper looks at whether higher body mass index and systolic blood pressure are associated with worse cognitive abilities. We show associations between these factors, and in particular that a range of brain structural features mediate the link.

PCSK9 inhibitors are an effective medication for lowering low-density lipoprotein levels. Use has been associated with lower risk of poor cardiometabolic health. Some questions remain from trial data, however, relating to whether their use may have cognitive side-effects.

We calibrated 14 self-reported behavioural variables from the UK Biobank main cohort using the wrist accelerometry sub-cohort. We used published equations to estimate physical activity energy expenditure (PAEESR) Cox regression was used to estimate associations between PAEESr and fatal and non-fatal outcomes including all-cause, cardiovascular diseases, respiratory diseases and cancers.

We consider the problem of performing an association test between functional data and scalar variables. We propose a functional projection regression model and an associated global test statistic. An optimal functional projection direction is selected to maximize signal-to-noise ratio with ridge penalty.

Opioids have, at most, small benefits for non-cancer pain in the medium and long-term but there is good evidence that they cause harm. The current study describes the characteristics and clinical status of people taking regular opioids in Great Britain and determines whether use is associated with mortality risk.

Brain genetics is an active research area. The degree to which genetic variants impact variations in brain structure and function remains largely unknown. We examined the heritability of regional brain volumes captured by single-nucleotide polymorphisms (SNPs) in UK Biobank. We found that common genetic variants can explain up to 80% of their variabilities.

Diffusion tensor imaging (DTI) and genome-wide single-nucleotide polymorphism (SNP) data from 17,706 UK Biobank participants offer the opportunity to identify novel genetic variants of WM tracts. We found that DTI parameters are substantially heritable for all WM tracts (mean heritability 48.7%). We observed a highly polygenic architecture of genetic influence across the genome.

Volumetric variations of the human brain are heritable and are associated with many brain-related complex traits. We performed genome-wide association studies (GWAS) of 101 brain volumetric phenotypes using the UK Biobank sample including 19,629 participants. GWAS identified 365 independent genetic variants exceeding a significance threshold of 4.9 Ã— 10-10.

Poor socio-economic status has been reported in chronic kidney disease (CKD) patients. We aimed to investigate the causal effects of education attainment on the risk of CKD. Study was an observational cohort study including Mendelian randomization (MR) analysis.

Asthma is a chronic and genetically complex respiratory disease that affects over 300 million people worldwide. Here, we report a genome-wide analysis for asthma using data from the UK Biobank and the Trans-National Asthma Genetic Consortium. We identify 66 previously unknown asthma loci.

While most patients with myocardial infarction (MI) have underlying coronary atherosclerosis, not all patients with coronary artery disease (CAD) develop MI. We carried out a genome-wide association study for MI in the UK Biobank. Eight novel regions were identified for MI at the genome wide significance level, of which effect sizes at six loci were more robust for MI than for CAD without the presence of MI.

The link between metabolic syndrome and SARS-CoV-2 infection remains unclear. A 10 mg/dl increase in serum HDL-cholesterol or apolipoprotein A1 levels was associated with 10% reduced risk of infection. Individuals homozygous for apollipoprotein E4 alleles had a 2- to 3-fold higher risk.

Diabetes has shown to be a stronger risk factor for myocardial infarction (MI) in women than men. Whether sex differences exist across the glycemic spectrum is unknown. We investigated sex differences in the associations of diabetes status and glycated hemoglobin (HbA 1c ) with the risk of MI.

UK Biobank is a prospective population-based cohort study. 364,899 adults (51.6 % females, mean age 56.0 years) were included. The exposure variable was physical activity level derived from the International Physical Activity Questionnaire-Short Form.

Daily recreational screen time, particularly TV viewing, was associated with small increased risks of oesophago-gastric and colon cancer. Replacing 1-h/day of TV viewing with 1-H of moderate-intensity physical activity or walking was linked with lower risk of oropharyngeal, lung, breast and colorectal cancers. Findings were inconsistent for daily recreational computer use.

Prostate cancer is a highly heritable disease with large disparities in incidence rates across ancestry populations. Men of African ancestry were estimated to have a mean GRS that was 2.18-times higher (95% CI, 2.14-2.22) than men of European ancestry.

X-linked ichthyosis (XLI) is an uncommon dermatological condition resulting from a deficiency of the enzyme steroid sulfatase (STS) It is often caused by X-linked deletions spanning STS. Some medical comorbidities have been identified in XLI cases, but small samples of relatively young patients has limited this.

Quantitative genetics theory predicts that X-chromosome dosage compensation (DC) will have a detectable effect on the amount of genetic and therefore phenotypic trait variances at associated loci in males and females. We systematically examine the role of DC in humans in 20 complex traits in a sample of more than 450,000 individuals from the UK Biobank.

We examined associations between BMI and the number of formal physical activity (PA) facilities within 1 km of each individual's home. We found that the association between a greater number of local PA facilities and lower BMI was stronger among people with fewer urban green spaces in their neighbourhood. We conclude that formal PA facilities may buffer against a lack of informal, green resources for PA.

Genome-wide association studies (GWASs) of medication use may contribute to understanding of disease etiology. GWASs could generate new leads relevant for drug discovery and can be used to quantify future risk.

Dilated cardiomyopathy (DCM) is an important cause of heart failure and the leading indication for heart transplantation. Many rare genetic variants have been associated with DCM, but common variant studies of the disease have yielded few associated loci. We report a genome-wide association study of cardiac magnetic resonance imaging (MRI)-derived left ventricular measurements in 36,041 UK Biobank participants.

Ivabradine is a heart rate lowering drug with protective effects on heart failure despite increasing the risk of atrial fibrillation. In patients with coronary artery disease without heart failure, the drug does not protect against major cardiovascular adverse events prompting questions about the ability of genetics to have predicted those effects. This study evaluates the effect of a variant in HCN4 on safety and efficacy endpoints.

We construct risk predictors using polygenic scores (PGS) computed from common Single Nucleotide Polymorphisms (SNPs) for a number of complex disease conditions. We obtain values for the area under the receiver operating characteristic curves (AUC) in the range of 0.58-0.71 using SNP data alone. Substantially higher predictor AUCs are obtained when incorporating additional variables such as age and sex.

Genomic prediction of complex human traits and disease risks has advanced considerably in recent years. Using data from the UK Biobank, predictors have been constructed using penalized algorithms that favor sparsity. The state of these SNPs cannot be determined from exome-sequencing data.

We test 26 polygenic predictors using tens of thousands of genetic siblings from the UK Biobank. We compare validation results obtained using non-sibling subjects to those obtained among siblings. We find that typically most of the predictive power persists in between-s sibling designs.

We construct genomic predictors for heritable but extremely complex human quantitative traits (height, heel bone density, and educational attainment) The constructed predictors explain, respectively, &#8764;40, 20, and 9% of total variance for the three traits. The proportion of variance explained for height is comparable to the estimated common SNP heritability from genome-wide complex trait analysis.

Physical activity (PA) levels between individuals with and without cancer. Current cancer, cancer survivor and cancer-free groups were identified from the UK Biobank. Participants in the two cancer groups had fewer minutes in moderate-to-vigorous PA per day.

Multiple studies have reported genetic associations with prognostic outcomes of urinary bladder cancer. We have used SNPTEST software to replicate previously reported associations. Using our algorithm, we have identified 618 recurrence and 58 UBC progression events. In total, there were 209 deaths (106 UBC-specific)

 Mutations in UGT1A gene have been associated with the development and prognosis of urinary bladder cancer (UBC) We investigated the potential effect of mild hyperbilirubinemia on UBC risk. No effects were observed for events of UBC recurrence, progression, or survival.

Fish oil supplementation is widely used for reducing serum triglycerides (TAGs) but has mixed effects on other circulating cardiovascular biomarkers. Many genetic polymorphisms have been associated with blood lipids, including high- and low-density-lipoprotein cholesterol (HDL-C, LDL-C), total cholesterol, and TAGs. Here, the gene-diet interaction effects of fish oil supplementation on these lipids were analyzed in a discovery cohort of up to 73,962 UK Biobank participants.

It is commonly assumed that high oestradiol levels in women are cardioprotective. We assessed the association between ostradiol and the risk of incident myocardial infarction (MI) in women. After a mean follow-up of 9 years, 2206 incidents of MI had been recorded.

Moderately raised serum bilirubin levels are associated with lower rates of lung cancer, particularly among smokers. It is not known whether these relationships reflect antioxidant properties or residual confounding. This study aimed to investigate potential causal relationships between serum total bilirubsin and lung cancer incidence using Mendelian randomisation.

Obesity and metabolic syndrome (MetS) appear in clusters and are both associated with an increased risk of cancer. It remains unknown whether obesity status with or without MetS increases the risk of site-specific cancers. We used data derived from 390,575 individuals (37-73 years old) from the UK Biobank.

Left ventricular (LV) mass and volume are important indicators of clinical and pre-clinical disease processes. Much of the shape information present in modern imaging examinations is currently ignored. We compared two independent LV atlases using MRI scans of 4547 UK Biobank participants. The strength of associations between atlas principal components and cardiovascular risk factors were quantified.

Asthma hospitalizations account for a high proportion of asthma-related healthcare costs. In 2016, asthma affected 9.3% of people and caused ~93,000 hospitalizations in the United Kingdom (U.K.)

The recent availability of large-scale neuroimaging cohorts facilitates deeper characterisation of the relationship between phenotypic and brain architecture variation in humans. Here, we investigate the association (previously coined morphometricity) of a phenotype with all 652,283 measures of cortical and subcortical morphology in a large data set from the UK Biobank and Human Connectome Project.

Polygenic indexes (PGIs) are DNA-based predictors. Their value for research in many scientific disciplines is growing rapidly. A PGI can be understood as an unbiased but noisy measure of a latent variable. Regressions in which the true regressor is this factor but the PGI is used as its proxy therefore suffer from errors-in-variables bias.

Insulin-like growth factor I (IGF-I) is positively associated with the risks of colorectal, breast, and prostate cancer. But evidence for other less common cancers is limited. In this study, we investigated associations between serum IGF-I concentrations and incidence of lesscommon cancers in the UK Biobank study.

Red and processed meat have been consistently associated with colorectal cancer risk. Evidence for other cancer sites and for poultry intake is limited. We analyzed data from 474 996 participants (54% women) in UK Biobank.

Less than 0.1% of the NDNS sample adhere to all nine EWG recommendations and 30.6% adhere to at least five recommendations. Compared with very low adherence, intermediate-to-high adherence was associated with a reduced risk of mortality. Increased adherence to the recommendation on red and processed meat consumption was. associated with the largest decrease in environmental footprints.

Artificial intelligence (AI) can identify the sex of an individual from color fundus photographs (CFPs) However, the mechanism(s) involved in this identification has not been determined. This study was conducted to determine the information in CFPs that can be used to determine sex.

Using UK Biobank data, we tested the association of 391 genes known to influence lung development with FVC and FEV 1 /FVC. Of the 55 genes, 53 fell into four biological categories whose function is to regulate organ size and cell integrity.

Rare genetic variants in LDLR, APOB and PCSK9 are known causes of familial hypercholesterolaemia. Rare variants in other genes will also have effects on hyperlipidaemia risk. Such genes remain to be identified.

Indirect genetic effects are environmental factors associated with human disease and complex trait variation. Here, we study indirect genetic effects in 80,889 human couples of European ancestry for 105 complex traits.

Red blood cell transfusion and erythropoiesis-stimulating agent administration are cornerstones of clinical practice. This study aims to identify RBC traits most relevant to venous thromboembolism (VTE) and assess their genetically predicted effects on VTE in the general population.

FastSMC is an IBD detection algorithm that combines a fast heuristic search with accurate coalescent-based likelihood calculations. We apply FastSMC to 487,409 UK Biobank samples and detect ~214 billion IBD segments transmitted by shared ancestors within the past 1500 years.

Vigorous physical activity (PA) in highly trained athletes has been associated with heightened left ventricular (LV) trabeculation extent. It has been hypothesised that LV trabECulation extent may participate in exercise-induced physiological cardiac remodelling. In a community-based general population cohort, there was no relationship at, or between, extremes, between PA and NC/C, suggesting that at typical general population PA levels, trab Ceculation extent is not influenced by PA changes.

Genome-wide association studies (GWAS) in Parkinson's disease have increased the scope of biological knowledge about the disease. We aimed to use the largest aggregate of GWAS data to identify novel risk loci and gain further insight into the causes. We identified 90 independent genome-wide significant risk signals across 78 genomic regions, including 38 novel independent risk signals in 37 loci.

Previous studies have suggested that altered asymmetry of the planum temporale (PT) is associated with neurodevelopmental disorders. Shared genetic factors have been suggested to link PT asymmetry to these disorders. In a dataset of unrelated subjects from the general population, we found that PT volume asymmetry had a significant heritability of roughly 14%.

 kidney function does not feature in current CVD risk-prediction models. We tested three formulae for estimated glomerular filtration rate (eGFR) to determine which was the most clinically informative. We show that eGFRcys is most strongly associated with CVD and mortality.

Few risk factors for rotator cuff disease (RCD) and corresponding treatment have been firmly established. The aim of this study was to evaluate the relationship between numerous risk factors and the incidence of surgery for RCD in a large cohort. The risk factors which were considered included age, sex, race, education, Townsend deprivation index, body mass index (BMI), occupational demands, and exposure to smoking.

The aim of this study was to compare and externally validate risk scores developed to predict incident colorectal cancer that include common genetic variants. We externally validated 23 risk models from a previous systematic review in 443,888 participants ages 37 to 73 from the UK Biobank cohort.

We used data from the UK Biobank, a large prospective study of middle-aged and older adults. Living with a spouse or partner was associated with substantially lower odds of lifetime depression. Amongst those not cohabiting, having any number of children was linked to higher odds of depression.

UK Biobank recruited > 500,000 participants, aged 37-73, between 2006 and 2010. Exposures were sociodemographic (age, sex, ethnicity, education, income and deprivation), psychosocial (loneliness and social isolation), lifestyle (smoking, alcohol intake, sleep duration, BMI, physical activity and stair climbing) and environmental (air pollution, noise and residential greenspace) factors. Low income, being male, neighbourhood deprivation, loneliness, social isolation, short or long sleep duration and low or high BMI and smoking were associated with poor health.

Hand preference is a conspicuous variation in human behaviour. Around 90% of people prefer to use the right hand for many tasks, and 10% the left hand. We used the large cohort of the UK biobank (~500,000 participants) to study possible relations between early life factors and adult hand preference.

An increased serum level of free testosterone was associated with lower odds of physician-diagnosed asthma and current wheeze in women and men. Higher serum free testosterone levels were also associated with higher lung function in men.

We trained a deep learning algorithm to predict refractive error from a total of 226,870 images. We validated it on 24,007 UK Biobank and 15,750 AREDS images. The algorithm had a mean absolute error (MAE) of 0.56 diopters.

Anaemia can be detected via machine-learning algorithms trained using retinal  fundus images, study participant metadata (including race or ethnicity, age, sex and  blood pressure) or the combination of both data types. In a validation dataset of 11,388 study participants from the UK Biobank, the metadata-only, fundus-image-only and combined models predicted haemoglobin  concentration (in g dl-1)

Deep learning can extract new knowledge from retinal fundus images. We predicted cardiovascular risk factors not previously thought to be present or quantifiable in retinal images. The models used anatomical features, such as the optic disc or blood vessels, to generate each prediction.

Sex differences have been shown in laboratory biomarkers, but the extent to which this is due to genetics is unknown. In this study, we infer sex-specific genetic parameters across 33 quantitative biomarker traits in 181,064 females and 156,135 males from the UK Biobank study. We find that the genetics of most biomarker trait are shared between males and females.

The UK Biobank is collecting extensive data on health-related characteristics of over half a million volunteers. The biological samples of blood and urine can provide valuable insight on kidney function.

This paper gives a brief overview of common non-invasive techniques for body composition analysis. It also reviews a body composition assessment method based on fat-referenced quantitative MRI. Earlier published studies of this method are summarized.

UK Biobank participants without baseline CVD or known diabetes were included. Associations of HbA1c with CVD was assessed using Cox models adjusting for classical risk factors.

Polygenic scores (PGS) have been widely used to predict disease risk using variants identified from genome-wide association studies (GWAS) To date, most GWAS have been conducted in populations of European ancestry, which limits the use of GWAS-derived PGS in non-European ancestry populations. Here, we derive a theoretical model of the relative accuracy (RA) of PGS across ancestries.

UK Biobank recruited 502,624 participants aged 37-73 years between 2006 and 2010. Baseline exposure data, including 25(OH)D concentration and ethnicity, were linked to test results. Vitamin D was associated with COVID-19 infection univariably, but not after adjustment for confounders.

25(OH)D concentration was associated with severe COVID-19 infection and mortality univariably. Vitamin D insufficiency or deficiency was not independently associated with either infection or linked mortality. Randomised trials are needed to prove a beneficial role for vitamin D.

The genome-wide association study (GWAS) has been widely used as an experimental design to detect associations between genetic variants and a phenotype. Two major confounding factors, population stratification and relatedness, could potentially lead to inflated GWAS test statistics and hence to spurious associations. Mixed linear model (MLM)-based approaches can be used to account for sample structure.

Evidence suggests that diabetes and glycated hemoglobin (HbA1c) levels are associated with cancer risk. Previous studies have been limited by failure to adjust for cancer-specific risk factors, and failure to stratify by obesity.

Myeloid clonal hematopoiesis (CH) increased by 1.1-fold per annum in the UK Biobank cohort. 53% of myeloid CH cases were smokers compared to 44% of controls. ASXL1 loss of function mutations most strongly associated with current smoking status.

Cross-sectional analysis of 157,357 UK Biobank participants. Experience of four maltreatment types (physical/sexual/emotional/neglect) identified. People experiencing all four types of maltreatment were more likely to have poor self-rated health. Greater number of types of Maltreatment was associated with higher prevalence of combined physical/mental health LTCs.

Frailty is associated with older age and multimorbidity (two or more long-term conditions) Little is known about its prevalence or effects on mortality in younger populations. This paper aims to examine the association between frailty and mortality in a middle-aged and older aged population.

Anticholinergic burden (ACB) is associated with adverse outcomes in older people. ACB is less studied in middle-aged populations. Numerous scales exist to quantify ACB. We performed a longitudinal analysis of the UK Biobank community cohort.

To examine the association between the MTNR1B G risk allele, type 2 diabetes (T2D) and chronotype in the UK Biobank.

Common MTNR1B single nucleotide polymorphism associates with risk of type 2 diabetes mellitus (T2D) Here, we examine the association between this gene variant and the risk of myocardial infarction (MCI)

Mendelian randomization is the use of genetic variants to assess the effect of intervening on a risk factor using observational data. We test for gene-gene interactions in the associations of variants with a modifiable risk factor. One genetic variant is treated as pharmacomimetic and the other as an effect modifier to find genetic subgroups of the population with different predicted response to treatment.

Cerebral small vessel disease is a major cause of stroke and dementia. Its genetic basis is incompletely understood. We perform a genetic study of three MRI markers of the disease in UK Biobank imaging data and other sources.

In December 2019, a coronavirus began infecting humans, causing a novel disease. This was first described in the Wuhan province of the People's Republic of China. To date, thousands of cases of COVID-19 have been reported in the United Kingdom.

Child maltreatment is associated with cardiovascular disease (CVD), but mediation pathways have not been fully elucidated. The aim of the current study was to determine and quantify the underlying pathways linking child maltreatment and CVD.

Measurement of lipoprotein(a) and/or LPA genetic risk score (GRS) have clinical utility in risk prediction of incident atherosclerotic cardiovascular disease (ASCVD) Findings  In this cohort of 283 540 adults recruited by the UK Biobank, both measured lipop protein(a), and LPA GRS were associated with comparable risk of incident ASCVD events.

Deep learning models using ECG to infer cardiac magnetic resonance (CMR)-derived LV mass may improve LVH detection. LVM-AI-predicted LVH was associated with incident atrial fibrillation, myocardial infarction, heart failure, and ventricular arrhythmias.

Recent studies have suggested that a higher body mass index (BMI) and serum urate levels were associated with a lower risk of developing dementia. However, these reverse relationships remain controversial. We analyzed a cohort of 502 528 individuals derived from the UK Biobank that included people aged 37-73 years.

Evidence links the liver to development of colorectal cancer (CRC) It remains unknown how liver function may influence CRC risk in the general population. We conducted a prospective cohort study in the UK Biobank of 375 693 participants.

It remains unclear whether serum lipids influence colorectal cancer risk. We conducted a prospective cohort study of 380,087 adults aged 40-69 years in the UK Biobank. None of the lipid biomarkers was associated with the risk of CRC after adjusting for potential confounding factors.

Vitamin D status and mortality has been reported in observational studies. The precise association shape and optimal vitamin D status remain undetermined. Higher 25(OH)D concentrations are nonlinearly associated with lower risk of all-cause, CVD, and cancer mortality.

Coronavirus disease 2019 (COVID-19) deteriorates suddenly primarily due to excessive inflammatory injury. Insulin-like growth factor-1 (IGF-1) is implicated in endocrine control of the immune system. We investigated the association between circulating IGF-1 concentrations and mortality risk.

Oral contraceptive use has been suggested to influence the risk of breast, ovarian, and endometrial cancer. We performed an observational study in 256,661 women from UK Biobank, born between 1939 and 1970. Odds were lower among ever users, compared with never users, for ovarian cancer.

UK Biobank comprises around half a million people aged 40-69 years at study induction. Hospitalisations for COVID-19 were ascertained between 16th March and 26th April 2020. An elevated risk of the disease was related to disadvantaged levels of education.

We determined differential gene expression in response to high glucose in lymphoblastoid cell lines derived from matched individuals with type 1 diabetes with and without retinopathy. Expression quantitative trait loci (eQTLs) of the glucose response genes were tested for association with diabetes. We identified folliculin ( FLCN ) as a susceptibility gene for diabetic ret inopathy.

Women with previous HDP had a higher risk for future hypertension and cardiovascular diagnoses, increased blood pressures, and lower risk for breast cancer compared with women without HDP. When taking genotype into account, HDP-positive women carrying at least 1 thymine (T) allele of rs2016347 had a lower risk of developing nonbreast cancer.

The electrocardiogram (ECG) is one of the most useful non-invasive diagnostic tests for a wide array of cardiac disorders. Traditional approaches to analyzing ECGs focus on individual segments. We performed comprehensive deep phenotyping of 77,190 ECGs in the UK Biobank.

Data from 50,000 exome-sequenced UK Biobank participants was analysed. Subjects were treated as cases if they had seen a psychiatrist for "nerves, anxiety, tension or depression"

Aims Type 2 diabetes (T2D) is affected by a combination of genetic and environmental factors. However, comprehensive genomic risk scores (GRSs) for T2D prediction have not been evaluated. We developed a metaGRS using 1,692 genetic variants in the UK Biobank training set.

Some studies reported that mildly elevated serum bilirubin levels were associated with decreased risk of cardiovascular disease (CVD) and diabetes. Whether these are causal relationships remains unclear. This study aims to examine the causal effects of bilirubs on CVD, diabetes and their subtypes. Data we used in this study includes individual data from the UK Biobank cohort with 331,002 white British participants.

The TyG index significantly increased the risk of overall CVD, ischemic heart diseases (IHD), and cerebrovascular diseases (CED) The effect of GLU and TG was independent of each other genetically and presented dose-response effects in bivariate meta-regression analysis.

C-reactive protein (CRP) has been used as a biomarker of chronic low-grade inflammation in observational studies. We aimed to determine whether genetically determined CRP was associated with hundreds of human phenotypes to guide anti-inflammatory interventions. We found CRP robustly associated with several diseases in the UK Biobank and the FinnGen population, but could not be replicated.

Mendelian randomization study aims to investigate causal associations between genetically predicted insomnia and 14 cardiovascular diseases (CVDs) as well as the potential mediator role of 17 cardiometabolic risk factors. Genetic predicted insomnia was consistent significantly positively associated with 9 of 14 CVDs. insomnia was consistently associated with higher body mass index, triglycerides, and lower high-density lipoprotein cholesterol.

Researchers found that annual birth rate peaks in April and May. Poorer subjective general health and slower reaction time were observed in May. People reported shorter periods of sleep, easier waking, earlier chronotype, more daytime dozing and napping in summer compared to winter.

Longitudinal sleep timing and genotype data from 1449 participants were collected for up to 27 years. Gene-environment interaction analysis was performed for 445 candidate single nucleotide polymorphisms. The strongest associated gene for sleep trajectories was ALKBH5, which has functions of DNA repair and epigenetic regulation.

Odds of being hospitalised due to COVID-19 were higher among those who had lower birthweight and mothers who were smoking during pregnancy. Maternal smoking was positively associated with infection. Breastfeeding was negatively associated with the infection.

Multiple sclerosis (MS) is a common and disabling condition. The importance of healthy lifestyle for this disease is poorly explored. To test whether adherence to healthier lifestyle patterns is associated with a lower presence of MS, 728 participants with MS were matched with healthy controls.

 COVID-19 may present with neurological signs, but whether people already affected by neurological conditions are at a higher risk of contracting it is still not known. 502,536 community-dwelling UK Biobank participants (54.4% male, mean age 56.6 +/- 10.3 years) were included. Nerve, nerve root and plexus disorders (G50-G59) were the most common conditions identified. The presence of CO VID-19 was almost doubled in neurological conditions compared to the general population.

Using the UK Biobank cohort, we extracted quintiles of self-reported weekly physical activity. Categories of measured BMI, waist circumference, and BF were generated. High physical activity was associated with lower risk of premature mortality in all strata of adiposity except for those with BMI &#8805;35 kg/m2.

Stair climbing has the potential to lower the risk of premature death, but current evidence is scarce. We aimed to examine whether daily stair climbing is associated with lower risk of all-cause, cancer, and cardiovascular disease (CVD) mortality. We extracted information of self-reported daily flights of stairs climbed at home.

Age and female sex are risk factors for dementia. Menopause is associated with cognitive dysfunction. We studied whether age interacts with sex or menopause in explaining biomarkers of dementia during midlife.

Sex and sexual differentiation are pervasive across the tree of life. Because females and males often have substantially different functional requirements, we expect selection to differ between the sexes. Theory and population-level simulations indicate that sex-specific differences in viability would need to be very large to maintain reported levels of between-sex allelic differentiation.

ApoE e4 allele is associated with reduced longevity and increased Coronary Artery Disease (CAD) and Alzheimer's disease. Data were from 379,000 UK Biobank participants, aged 40 to 70 years. e2e3 had mostly lower lipid-related biomarker levels including reduced total and LDL-cholesterol.

Homozygosity for the SERPINA1  Z allele causes rare condition that can cause lung and liver disease. We conducted a large, population-based study to determine Z allele effects on >2400 phenotypes in the UK Biobank (N=303 353) Heterozygosity was strongly associated with increased height and with other nonrespiratory phenotypes.

In human and nonhuman primates, sex differences typically explain much interindividual variability. Male and female behaviors may have played unique roles in the likely coevolution of increasing brain volume and more complex social dynamics. We applied probabilistic generative modeling to 10,000 UK Biobank participants.

Low-frequency 1q21.1 distal deletion and duplication copy number variant (CNV) carriers are predisposed to multiple neurodevelopmental disorders, including schizophrenia, autism and intellectual disability. The underlying brain structural diversity remains largely unknown.

Chronological age is the strongest risk factor for most chronic diseases. Developing a biomarker-based age may shed light on the effects of age on later-life health and inform opportunities for disease prevention.

Abdominal size is associated positively with the risk of some cancers. influence of body mass index (BMI) and gluteofemoral size is unclear. waist and hip circumference are strongly correlated with BMI. We examined associations of 33 cancers with A Body Shape Index (ABSI) and hip index (HI)

Education is strongly genetically correlated with intelligence (rg = 0.70). We used a novel approach - multi-trait analysis of genome-wide association studies (MTAG) - to combine two large GWASs of education and intelligence. We found 187 independent loci associated with intelligence, implicating 538 genes.

Fibroblast growth factor 21 (FGF21) is a hormone that has insulin-sensitizing properties. Some trials of FGF21 analogs show weight loss and lipid-lowering effects. Recent studies have shown that a common allele in the F GF21 gene alters the balance of macronutrients consumed.

Strabismus refers to an abnormal alignment of the eyes leading to the loss of central binocular vision. As such, it is inherited as a complex genetic trait, affecting 2-4% of the population. A genome-wide association study (GWAS) for self-reported strabismes revealed a single genome- wide significant locus on chromosome 17q25.

Vitamin D has been intensively studied for its association with human health. The scope of such association and the causal role of vitamin D remain controversial. We aim to comprehensively investigate the links between vitamin D and human health through both epidemiological and Mendelian randomization (MR) analyses.

Using genetic liability (rather than phenotypic measures of disease) as a proxy for psychiatric disease risk can be a useful alternative for research questions that would traditionally require large cohort studies with long-term follow up. We conducted a hypothesis-free phenome-wide association study in about 330,000 participants from the UK Biobank to examine associations of polygenic risk scores.

Current genome-wide association studies do not yet capture sufficient diversity in populations and scope of phenotypes. To expand an atlas of genetic associations in non-European populations, we conducted 220 deep-phenotype genome- wide association studies. Meta-analyses with the UK Biobank and FinnGen identified 5,000 new loci.

Preeclampsia, gestational diabetes, preterm birth, and placental abruption are among the most studied ones. Using publicly available data, we confirm that immune system and, in particular, T-cell related pathways are one of the most important drivers of pregnancy-related traits. Pathway analysis of the data reveals that cell adhesion and matrisome-related genes are also commonly involved in pregnancy pathologies.

Conventional human leukocyte antigen (HLA) imputation methods drop their performance for infrequent alleles. This reduces reliability of trans-ethnic major histocompatibility complex (MHC) fine-mapping due to inter-ethnic heterogeneity in allele frequency spectra. We develop DEEP*HLA, a deep learning method for imputing HLA genotypes.

The etiology of most complex diseases involves genetic variants, environmental factors, and gene-environment interaction (G Ã— E) effects. Compared with marginal genetic association studies, G Ã— E analysis requires more samples and detailed measure of environmental exposures. Large-scale population-based biobanks with detailed phenotypic and environmental information, such as UK-Biobank, can be ideal resources for identifying G â†’ E effects.

Time-to-event data analysis has attracted increasing attention in the genetics studies of human diseases. The Cox proportional hazards (PH) regression model is one of the most used approaches. SPACox requires fitting a Cox PH regression model only once across the genome-wide analysis and then uses a saddlepoint approximation to calibrate test statistics.

The UK Biobank is a very large, prospective population-based cohort study across the United Kingdom. It provides unprecedented opportunities for researchers to investigate the relationship between genotypic information and phenotypes of interest.

We present a method for detecting identical-by-descent haplotype segments in phased genotype data. Our method, called hap-IBD, combines a compressed representation of haplotype data, the positional Burrows-Wheeler transform, and multi-threaded execution. Analysis of 485,346 UK Biobank samples with 12 computational threads detects 231.5 billion autosomal IBD segments with length &#8805;2 cM in 24.4 h.

Many genetic markers have been associated with variations in treatment response to analgesics, but none have been assessed in the context of combination therapies. In this study, the treatment effects of nortriptyline and morphine were tested for an association with genetic markers relevant to pain pathways. The presence of the C allele accounted for 51% of pain variance in this subgroup in response to combination treatment.

FastGWA-GLMM is a GLMM-based GWA tool that is severalfold to orders of magnitude faster than the state-of-the-art tools. It is scalable to cohorts with millions of individuals. We applied it to the UKB data of 456,348 individuals, 11,842,647 variants and 2,989 binary traits.

Only a minority of excess alcohol drinkers develop cirrhosis. We developed and evaluated risk stratification scores to identify those at highest risk. A combination of 3 single nucleotide polymorphisms (SNPs) (PNPLA3:rs738409, SUGP1-TM6SF2:rs10401969, HSD17B13:rs6834314) and diabetes status (UK Biobank: relevant n = 6,898) worked best.

Schizophrenia has a genetic component, however it cannot be isolated to a single gene. We tested several machine learning algorithms to determine which was most effective in predicting schizophrenia. We found that the stacked ensemble, performed best with an area under the receiver operating characteristic curve (AUC) of 0.545 (95% CI 0.539-0.550)

Study was to identify genetic variants associated with rotator cuff disease. Used genome-wide association study (GWAS) for shoulder impingement using the UK Biobank (UKB) cohort. Combining data with a prior GWAS for rotators cuff tears resulted in identification of an additional 7 loci.

Carpal tunnel syndrome (CTS) is a common and disabling condition of the hand. It is caused by entrapment of the median nerve at the level of the wrist. Estimates of prevalence range between 5-10%. Here, we undertake a genome-wide association study (GWAS)

Common musculoskeletal conditions include pain in the neck and shoulder areas. This study seeks to identify the genetic variants associated with neck or shoulder pain. It used 203 309 subjects from the UK Biobank cohort and looked for replication evidence from the Generation Scotland: Scottish Family Health Study (GS:SFHS) and TwinsUK.

The rapid rise in prevalence over recent decades and high heritability of myopia suggest a role for gene-environment (G Ã— E) interactions in myopia susceptibility. We aimed to test the hypothesis that genetic analysis of susceptibility to visual experience-induced myopia in an animal model would identify novel G Ã— E interaction loci. Chicks aged 7 days were monocularly deprived of form vision for 4 days.

Frozen shoulder affects up to 5% of individuals aged 40-60 years. Little is known about the causes of the condition, but diabetes is a strong risk factor. We have identified genetic loci associated with frozen shoulder. Diabetes is a likely causal risk factor for the painful condition.

Raised albumin-creatinine ratio (ACR) is an indicator of microvascular damage and renal disease. We aimed to identify genetic variants associated with raised ACR. After excluding variants at the CUBN locus, an ACR genetic risk score was associated with a higher risk of hypertension.

Aberrant connectivity of large-scale brain networks has been observed among individuals with alcohol use disorders (AUDs) as well as in those at risk. Electroencephalographical (EEG) coherence, which measures the degree of synchrony between brain regions, may be a useful measure of connectivity patterns in neural networks for studying the genetics of AUD.

Frailty is a common geriatric syndrome and strongly associated with disability, mortality and hospitalization. The mechanisms underlying FI are multifactorial and not well understood, but a genetic basis has been suggested. Understanding the genetic determinants and biological mechanisms underpinning FI may help to delay or even prevent frailty.

Research suggests that the pro-inflammatory cytokine interleukin-1&#946; has a modulatory effect on the hippocampus. The hippocampus is a brain structure important for learning and memory as well as linked with both psychiatric and neurodegenerative disorders. Here, we used an imaging genetics strategy to test an association between an IL-1 &#9 46; polygenic score and hippocampal volume.

Blood pressure (BP) was inconsistently associated with migraine. The mechanisms of BP-lowering medications in migraine prophylaxis are unknown. Cross-trait meta-analysis reveals 14 shared loci (P &#8804; 5 Ã— 10-08)

We analyzed genome-wide SNP data for asthma and allergic diseases in 33,593 cases and 76,768 controls of European ancestry from UK Biobank. Cross-trait analysis identified 38 genomes-wide significant loci. Computational analysis showed that shared genetic loci are enriched in immune/inflammatory systems and tissues with epithelium cells.

Osteoporosis is the most common metabolic bone disorder globally. We aimed to identify pleiotropic loci associated with bone mineral density and nonbone phenotypes in genome-wide association studies.

11,285 multimorbidities among 439 common diseases were identified. 46% of them were genetically interpretable at the loci, network, or overall genetic architecture levels. Multimorbidity affecting the same and different physiological systems displayed different patterns of the shared genetic components.

Maternal brain adaptations occur in response to pregnancy. Little is known about how parity impacts white matter and white matter ageing trajectories later in life. Study looked at 8,895 women in the UK Biobank cohort (age range = 54-81 years)

Age-related hearing impairment (ARHI) can be mitigated, but not cured or eliminated. To identify genetic influences underlying ARHI, we conducted a genome-wide association study of ARHI in 6,527 cases and 45,882 controls among the non-Hispanic whites from the Genetic Epidemiology Research on Adult Health and Aging (GERA) cohort.

Body mass index (BMI), a proxy measure for obesity, is determined by both environmental (including ethnicity, age, and sex) and genetic factors. However, the impact, interplay, and underlying biological mechanisms among BMI, environment, genetics, and ancestry are not completely understood. We utilized 427,509 calendar year-averaged BMI measurements from 100,418 adults.

Cataract is the leading cause of blindness among the elderly worldwide. Cataract surgery is one of the most common operations performed in the United States. As the genetic etiology of cataract formation remains unclear, we conducted a genome-wide association meta-analysis.

We conducted an integrated study of prostate cancer genetic etiology in two cohorts using custom genotyping microarrays, large imputation reference panels, and functional annotation approaches. 11,984 men (6,196 prostate cancer cases and 5,788 controls) of European ancestry from Northern California Kaiser Permanente were genotyped and meta-analyzed with 196,269 men from the UK Biobank. Three novel loci, including two rare variants (European ancestry minor allele frequency  HOXB13 ), were identified.

Few efforts have been paid to evaluate the potential relationships between brain imaging and intelligence until now. We performed a two-stage analysis to systematically explore the relationships between 3144 brain image-derived phenotypes (IDPs) and intelligence. Our findings may help to understand the genetic mechanisms of the effects of brain structure and function on the development of intelligence.

Lung function is a heritable complex phenotype with obesity being one of its important risk factors. Most genome-wide association studies (GWASs) for lung function have been based on European populations. Large-scale lung function GWASs in other populations are lacking.

Different exposures, including diet, physical activity, or external conditions can contribute to genotype-environment interactions (GÃ—E) Although high-dimensional environmental data are increasingly available, multi-environment tests for GÃ—E are not established. Here, we propose the structured linear mixed model (StructLMM), a computationally efficient method to identify and characterize loci that interact with one or more environments.

Nasal polyps (NP) are lesions on the nasal and paranasal sinus mucosa and are a risk factor for chronic rhinosinusitis (CRS) We performed genome-wide association studies on NP and CRS in Iceland and the UK. Most notably, a missense variant in ALOX15 that causes a p.Thr560Met alteration in arachidonate 15-lipoxygenase (15-LO) confers significant protection against NP.

Machine-learning techniques have helped solve a broad range of prediction problems. They are not widely used to build polygenic risk scores for the prediction of complex traits. We propose a novel heuristic based on machine- learning techniques (GraBLD) to boost the predictive performance of polygenicrisk scores.

CKD is highly prevalent in the elderly population. It is rarely investigated whether kidney function is causally linked to biological aging itself. Genetic instruments for telomere attrition were applied to a CKDGen genome wide association study results for 41,395 cases of CKD.

Urinary albumin-to-creatinine ratio (ACR) is a marker of diabetic nephropathy and microvascular damage. Metabolic-related traits are observationally associated with ACR, but their causal role is uncertain. MR suggested that seven traits have causal effects on ACR.

Interactions between genetic variants-epistasis-is pervasive in model systems. Interactions can profoundly impact evolutionary adaption, population disease dynamics, genetic mapping, and precision medicine efforts.
