We develop a model for structured polygenic epistasis, called coordinated epistasis (CE)

Primary open-angle glaucoma (POAG) is a leading cause of irreversible vision loss. Much of the genetic risk remains unaccounted for, especially in African-Americans. We identify 24 loci (P)

Motion atlases can be used to learn descriptors that are linked to different pathologies and which can subsequently be used for diagnosis. In this work we propose a framework to build a multimodal cardiac motion atlas from 3D magnetic resonance and 3D ultrasound data.

The identification of gene-gene and gene-environment interactions in genome-wide association studies is challenging due to the unknown nature of the interactions. Parametric regression models are suitable to look for prespecified interactions. Nonparametric models such as tree ensemble models have previously been difficult to interpret.

Gene-environment (GxE) interactions are one of the least studied aspects of the genetic architecture of human traits and diseases. The environment of an individual is inherently high dimensional, evolves through time and can be expensive and time consuming to measure. We show that GPLEMMA is more computationally efficient than LEMMA on large datasets.

The genetic variant rs72824905-G (minor allele) in the PLCG2 gene was previously associated with a reduced Alzheimer's disease risk (AD) We found an association with reduced risk of dementia with Lewy bodies (DLB) and frontotemporal dementia (FTD) We did not find evidence for an effect on Parkinson's disease (PD), amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (ALS) and multiple sclerosis (MS)

Osteoarthritis (OA) is a complex disease, but its genetic aetiology remains poorly characterised. To identify novel susceptibility loci for OA, we carried out a genome-wide association study (GWAS) in individuals from the largest UK-based OA collections to date.

Depression is a leading cause of worldwide disability. There remains considerable uncertainty regarding its neural and behavioural associations. We report 77 traits that are significantly associated with depression-PRS. Mendelian Randomisation analysis supports a potential causal effect of liability to depression on brain white matter microstructure.

Using human phenotype ontology (HPO) terms, we systematically mapped 60 phenotypes related to AS, MS, DS and NS in 337,198 unrelated white British. We performed logistic regression adjusting for age, sex, and the first 5 genetic principal components. Overall, we observed multiple phenotype-genotype correlations, such as the association between variation in JAG1, FBN1, PTPN11 and SOS2 with blood pressure.

Some commonly prescribed drugs are associated with increased risk of osteoporotic fractures. fracture risk stratification using skeletal measures is not often performed to identify those at risk before these medications are prescribed. We tested whether a genomically predicted skeletal measure, speed of sound (gSOS) from heel ultrasound, is an independent risk factor for fracture in users of fracture-related drugs.

 LDL-C (low-density lipoprotein cholesterol) risk score (PRS) not well understood, both within the general population and individuals with familial hypercholesterolemia (FH) We developed the HDL-C PRS using Least Absolute Shrinkage and Selection Operator regression in 377 286 White British participants from UK Biobank. We tested its association with LDL- C according to FH variant carrier status in another 41 748 whole-exome sequenced individuals.

Adult height is highly heritable, yet no genetic predictor has demonstrated clinical utility compared to mid-parental height. A polygenic risk score was constructed based on meta-analysis of genomewide association studies and evaluated on the Avon Longitudinal Study of Parents and Children.

Increasing childhood obesity rates are associated with not only adverse physical, but also mental health outcomes, including depression. These negative outcomes may be caused and/or exacerbated by the bullying and shaming overweight individuals experience. We hypothesized that a genetic risk for higher BMI, will predict higher early life stress (ELS), which in turn will Predict higher depressive symptoms in adulthood.

An individual's genetics can dramatically influence breast cancer (BC) risk. Clinical measures for prevention do exist, but non-invasive personalized measures for reducing BC risk are limited. No previous study has explored whether a range of widely taken approved drugs modulate BC genetics.

Parkinson's disease (PD) is a complex neurodegenerative disease. Rare point mutations and copy number gains of the SNCA gene have been shown to cause autosomal dominant PD. Common DNA variants identified using Genome-Wide Association Studies are a moderate risk factor for PD.

Tests of association between a phenotype and a set of genes in a biological pathway can provide insights into the genetic architecture of complex phenotypes. Most existing gene set tests have limited power to detect gene set-phenotype association when a small fraction of the genes are associated with the phenotype.

We propose a deep probabilistic model for local anomaly detection in sequences of heart shapes, modelled as point sets, in a cardiac cycle. A deep recurrent encoder-decoder network captures the spatio-temporal dependencies to predict the next shape in the cycle. We demonstrate the versatility of the method using two shape datasets derived from: one million biventricular CMR images from 20,000 participants in the UK Biobank.

We present a massive investigation into the genetic basis of human lifespan. We mapped six genome-wide significant loci associated with parental lifespan. By combining the  AncestryDNA results with those of an independent UK Biobank dataset we identified fifteen parental lifespan-associated loci.

Obesity has been consistently associated with a greater colorectal cancer risk, but this relationship is weaker among women. In the UK Biobank, we investigated the associations between body size (body mass index [BMI], height, waist circumference, and waist-to-hip ratio) and body fat composition.

The role of growth factors and inflammation in the onset of glioma is poorly understood. We examined associations between C-reactive protein (CRP), white blood cell count (WBC), neutrophil-to-lymphocyte ratio (NLR), and insulin-like growth factor-1 (IGF-1) in the UK Biobank cohort.

The nature and underlying mechanisms of the observed increased vulnerability to posttraumatic stress disorder (PTSD) in women are unclear. We investigated the genetic overlap of PTSD with anthropometric traits and reproductive behaviors and functions in women. The top association was related to BMI-adjusted waist circumference.

Exome sequencing identified a rare (minor allele frequency 0.0023) mutation in SMAD9 segregating with HBM in this autosomal dominant family. Affected individuals have bone mineral density (BMD) Z-scores +3 to +5, mandible enlargement, a broad frame, torus palatinus/mandibularis, pes planus, increased shoe size, and a tendency to sink when swimming.

In recent years, conditional and joint multiple-SNP analysis (GCTA-COJO) has been successful in allowing the discovery of additional association signals within detected loci. This suggests that many loci mapped in GWASs harbor more than a single causal variant. In order to interpret the underlying mechanism regulating a complex trait of interest in each discovered locus, researchers must assess the magnitude of allelic heterogeneity within the locus.

Single nucleotide polymorphism-based genetic risk scores (GRS) model genetic risk as a continuum and can discriminate coeliac disease. Human leukocyte antigen (HLA) DQ gene testing is available in clinic but does not include non-HLA attributed risk and is limited by discrete risk stratification.

Functional dyspepsia (FD) is a common gastrointestinal condition of poorly understood pathophysiology. While symptoms' overlap with other conditions may indicate common pathogenetic mechanisms, genetic predisposition is suspected but has not been adequately investigated. We surveyed FD comorbidities, heritability, and genetic correlations across a wide spectrum of conditions and traits.

Study looked for interaction effects between well-established environmental risk factors and common genetic variants exerting main effects on colorectal cancer risk. Seventy of the 1,500 tested interactions were nominally significant in phase I. After testing these 70 interactions in phase II, an interaction between rs11903757 (2q32.3) and body mass index (BMI) was nominallysignificant ( P  = 0.02)

We introduce a method for training neural networks to perform image or volume segmentation. Prior knowledge about the topology of the segmented object can be explicitly provided and then incorporated into the training process. We find that embedding explicit prior knowledge in neural network segmentation tasks is most beneficial when the task is especially challenging.

Uterine fibroids affect up to 77% of women by menopause and account for up to $34 billion in healthcare costs each year. Although fibroid risk is heritable, genetic risk is not well understood. We conducted a two-stage case-control meta-analysis of genetic variants in European and African ancestry women.

Plasma lipids are known heritable risk factors for cardiovascular disease. Increasing evidence also supports shared genetics with diseases of other organ systems. We devised a comprehensive three-phase framework to identify new lipid-associated genes.

Familial relatedness (FR) and population structure (PS) are two major sources for genetic correlation. In the human population, both FR and PS can further break down into additive and dominant components. This study introduces a dominant genomic relationship matrix. A unified linear mixed model is also developed, which can account for both the additive and dominance effects.

Colorectal cancer risk stratification is crucial to improve screening and risk-reducing recommendations. Current screening guidelines in the UK, USA and Australia focus solely on family history. We investigated adding a polygenic risk score based on 45 single-nucleotide polymorphisms to a family history model.

Study looked at brain white matter microstructural differences associated with normotension, pre-hypertension and hypertension. 4659 participants without known neurological or psychiatric disease (62.3+/-7.4 yrs, 47.0% male) in UK Biobank. Brain white matter intracellular volume fraction was significantly lower in hypertensive individuals.

Study: ABO gene, chr 9q34.2, which determines blood type, may affect COVID-19 disease severity. Danish study identified ABO blood group as a risk factor for SARS-CoV-2 infection but not for hospitalization or death.

Brain structure in later life reflects both influences of intrinsic aging and those of lifestyle, environment and disease. We developed a deep neural network model trained on brain MRI scans to predict "healthy" brain age. Brain regions most informative for the prediction included the cerebellum, hippocampus, amygdala and insular cortex.

Higher levels of physical activity (PA) are associated with a lower risk of cardiovascular disease (CVD) However, uncertainty exists on whether the inverse relationship between PA and incidence of CVD is greater at the highest levels of PA. We investigated the association between accelerometer-measured moderate, vigorous, and total PA and incident CVD in the UK Biobank cohort.

106,053 UK Biobank participants wore a wrist-worn GENEactiv monitor. Men and women with the worst cardio-metabolic disease perform around half of moderate to vigorous physical activity on a daily basis compared to healthy individuals.

The COVID-19 pandemic has necessitated novel approaches and collaborative efforts across multiple disciplines. Circadian biology may inform our diagnostic and therapeutic strategies in this pandemic.

Accurate construction of polygenic scores (PGS) can enable early diagnosis of diseases and facilitate the development of personalized medicine. Accurate PGS construction requires prediction models that are both adaptive to different genetic architectures and scalable to biobank scale datasets. Here, we develop a method called Deterministic Bayesian Sparse Linear Mixed Model.

Deep learning has huge potential for accurate disease prediction with neuroimaging data. But prediction performance is often limited by training-dataset size and computing memory requirements. To address this, we propose a deep convolutional neural network model, Simple Fully Convolutional Network (SFCN), for accurate prediction of brain age.

 SNP-heritability is a fundamental quantity in the study of complex traits. It remains unclear which estimates reported in the literature are reliable. We show that genome-wide SNP-Heritability can be accurately estimated from biobank-scale data irrespective of genetic architecture.

ShAPEIT4 substantially improves upon other methods to process large genotype and high coverage sequencing datasets. It notably exhibits sub-linear running times with sample size, provides highly accurate haplotypes and allows integrating external phasing information.

ACE inhibitors reduce the risk of type 2 diabetes using a Mendelian randomization (MR) approach. A genetic risk score (GRS) underpinning lower ACE concentration was then tested for association. Genetically lower ACE concentrations were associated with a lower risk of Type 2 diabetes.

Tobacco smoking is a well-established risk factor for cardiovascular disease. This study investigated the effects of smoking using a nested matched case-control study design. 5,668 participants of the UK Biobank study who underwent cardiovascular magnetic resonance imaging were screened for inclusion.

This retrospective longitudinal study included 58,897 UK Biobank participants tested for COVID-19 between March 2020 and February 2021. The hospital admission rate was 57% higher in the obese group with periodontal disease than without. The results could inform health providers, policy makers, and the general public of the importance to maintain good oral health.

Study included 283,443 adults from UK Biobank without CVD and cancer at baseline. One point increase of the healthy sleep score was associated with a 4-11% lower risk of all-cause mortality. Those with a favourable sleep pattern had 24-42% lower risks.

International dietary guidelines aim to reduce risks of all-cause mortality, cardiovascular disease (CVD), and fatal CVD often associated with poor dietary habits. Most studies have examined associations with individual nutrients, foods, or dietary patterns, as opposed to quantifying the pooled health effects of adherence to international dietary recommendations. We investigated associations between total adherence to the World Health Organization (WHO) dietary recommendations for saturated fats, free sugars, fibre, and fruits and vegetables.

Body size is an important modifiable risk factor for postmenopausal breast cancer. It remains unclear whether direct measures of fat mass are better indicators of risk than anthropometric measures. We analyzed data from 162,691 women in UK Biobank followed from 2006 to 2014.

We used information from 321,472 participants in the UK biobank, including 30,561 cases of obesity-related cancer. We looked at associations with 14 types of cancer, previously suggested to be associated with obesity. All genetic instruments had a strong association with BMI (p)

Study aimed to determine longitudinal associations of body mass index (BMI), waist circumference (WC) and grip strength (GS) with objectively measured PA. Data are from the UK Biobank study.

Analysis included 153,139 adults from the UK Biobank, aged 40 to 70 years at baseline (2006-2010) Cataract was ascertained using hospital inpatient, and self-reported data until 2021. Anthropometric measures, body fat percentage, and glycosylated hemoglobin (HbA1c) were measured at baseline.

The obesity paradox in which overweight/obesity is associated with mortality benefits is believed to be explained by confounding and reverse causality rather than by a genuine clinical benefit of excess body weight. We aimed to gain deeper insights into the paradox through analyzing mortality relationships with several adiposity measures. We assessed subgroups with type 2 diabetes, with coronary heart disease (CHD), with cancer, and by smoking status.

Adult height is associated with risk of a range of diseases, but the breadth of such associations and whether these associations are primary or due to confounding are unclear. We examined the association of adult height with 50 diseases using both epidemiological and genetic approaches to identify un-confounded associations and possible underlying mechanisms.

Neurocognitive impairment is a common complication of congenital heart disease (CHD) as well as acquired cardiovascular disease. Data are limited on neurocognitive function in adults with CHD (ACHD) Individuals with ACHD had significantly poorer performance on alpha-numeric trail making, a measure of visual attention and cognitive flexibility. These differences appear to be driven by increased burden of cerebro- and cardiovascular disease among individuals with A CHD.

Low platelet count, or thrombocytopenia, is a common haematological abnormality. It can be acquired or hereditary and indicative of a complex disorder. We review how large cohorts, such as the UK Biobank and INTERVAL studies, have enabled an accurate description of platelet parameters in adult populations.

The UK Biobank Exome Sequencing Consortium (UKB-ESC) is a private-public partnership. It will complete the sequencing of exomes for all ~500,000 UKB participants. As a result, exome data from 200,643 UKB enrollees are now available.

Coronavirus disease 2019 (COVID-19) disproportionately affects older people. Observational studies suggest indolent cardiovascular involvement after recovery from acute CO VID-19. However, these findings may reflect pre-existing cardiac phenotypes. We tested the association of baseline cardiovascular magnetic resonance (CMR) phenotypes with incident COVID- 19.

Shiftwork is an emerging social factor that contributes to disease in the urban environment across the working population. Studies have linked shiftwork to obesity and diabetes in nurses and industry workers. Little is known about the implications of shiftwork for the general workforce.

Adverse muscle composition (MC) as measured by magnetic resonance imaging has previously been linked to poor function, comorbidity, and increased hospitalization. The aim of this study was to investigate if adverse MC predicts all-cause mortality using data from UK Biobank.

Age-related cognitive decline is a well-known phenomenon after age 65. Little is known about earlier changes and prior studies are based on relatively small samples. We investigated the impact of age on cognitive decline in the largest population sample to date.

A comprehensive characterization of the brain's white matter is critical for improving our understanding of healthy and diseased aging. Here we used diffusion-weighted magnetic resonance imaging (dMRI) to estimate age and sex effects on white matter microstructure in a cross-sectional sample of 15,628 adults aged 45-80 years old.

APOE genotypes are associated with ischemic heart disease (IHD), several other cardiovascular diseases and dementia. Previous studies have not comprehensively considered all genotypes. In the UK Biobank, including 391,992 white British participants, we compared effects of APOE genotype on IHD and its risk factors.

Previous studies have shown an increased risk for mental health problems in children born to both younger and older parents. We previously used a novel design to reveal a latent mechanism of genetic association between schizophrenia and age at first birth in women (AFB) Here, we use independent data from the UK Biobank (N = 38,892) to replicate the finding of an association between predicted genetic risk of schizophrenia and AFB in women.

Mendelian randomization (MR) technique is not limited by traditional confounding. MR uses genetic variants as instruments under the assumption that they act on BMI only through age at menarche (no pleiotropy) MR-Egger regression did not suggest directional bias.

A trend towards earlier menarche in women has been associated with childhood factors (e.g. obesity) and hypothesised environmental exposures. We used Mendelian randomization where genetic variants are used as proxies for age atMenarche. In adult women, in line with previous evidence, we found an effect on restrictive lung impairment with a 24.8 mL increase in FVC per year increase in age.

It is unclear if puberty timing influences future physical activity (PA) Data were from two British cohorts. Per 1-year older age at menarche, PA was associated with higher mean counts/minute at age 14 years. associations attenuated at age 16 years.

Phenotypic biomarkers (e.g. cholesterol, weight, and glucose) are important to diagnose and treat diseases associated with aging. While many biomarkers are co-dependent, it is generally unknown how age influences their co-dependence. In the following, we analyzed 50 biomarkers in 27,508 National Health and Nutrition Examination Survey (NHANES) participants.

Quantifying the microstructural properties of the human brain's connections is necessary for understanding normal ageing and disease. Here we examine brain white matter magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) data in 3,513 generally healthy people aged 44.64-77.12 years from the UK Biobank.

The aim of this study was to identify genetic risk variants associated with the age at which symptoms of allergic disease first develop. Self-reported age-of-onset information was available for 117,130 genotyped individuals of European ancestry from the UK Biobank study.

Study examined age-differences in surface-based morphometric measures of cortical thickness, volume, and surface area in a well-defined sample of 8137 generally healthy UK Biobank participants aged 45-79 years. Age of about 60 is a break point for increasing negative associations between age and brain morphology.

Both genetic and environmental factors contribute to lung cancer, but the degree to which air pollution modifies the impact of genetic susceptibility on lung cancer remains unknown. We analyzed data from 455,974 participants (53% women) without previous cancer at baseline in the UK Biobank. The results showed significant associations between the risk of lung cancer and PM 2.5, PM 10, NO 2 and NO x.

We used Mendelian randomization to explore causal relationships between the degree of alcohol consumption and several cardiometabolic traits in the UK Biobank. We found that one additional drink of alcohol per day was positively associated with systolic blood pressure, hemorrhagic stroke, and atrial fibrillation. Alcohol was also associated with all cardiovascular disease and all-cause death. Findings were generally null in replication with two-sample analyses.

UK Biobank is a UK-wide cohort of 502,655 people aged 40-69, recruited from National Health Service registrants between 2006-10. Type 2 diabetes is a key exposure and outcome. We developed algorithms to define prevalent and incident diabetes.

Chronic liver disease (CLD) is a growing cause of morbidity and mortality worldwide. Coffee consumption has been linked with lower rates of CLD, but little is known about the effects of different coffee types. This study aimed to investigate associations of coffee consumption with chronic liver disease outcomes.

Using genetic scores for fasting plasma glucose (FPG GS) and type 2 diabetes (T2D GS), we investigated whether the fasting, 1-hour and 2-hour glucose thresholds from the WHO 2013 criteria for gestational diabetes (GDM) have different implications for genetic susceptibility to raised fasting glucose. We looked at women from the Hyperglycemia and Adverse Pregnancy Outcome (HAPO) and Atlantic Diabetes in Pregnancy (DIP) studies.

Adenine phosphoribosyltransferase deficiency is a rare, autosomal recessive disorder of purine metabolism that causes nephrolithiasis and progressive chronic kidney disease. The small number of reported cases indicates an extremely low prevalence. It has been suggested that missed diagnoses may play a role.

The genetic locus 3p21.31 has been associated with severe coronavirus disease 2019 (COVID-19) The underlying pathophysiological mechanism is unknown. To identify intermediate traits associated with the 3p.31 locus, we first performed a phenome-wide association study.

Secondhand smoke exposure is a major public health risk that is especially harmful to the developing brain. It is unclear if early exposure affects brain structure during middle age and older adulthood. We hypothesized that PSE would be associated with cortical disruption in primary sensory areas compared to unexposed adults.

The apolipoprotein (APOE) e4 locus is a genetic risk factor for dementia. Carriers of the e4 allele may be more vulnerable to conditions that are independent risk factors for cognitive decline.

PM 10 or NO 2 higher by 10 &#181;g.m -3 was associated with 12.8% (95% CI 9.5-16.3%) and 1.9% ( 95% CI 1.1-2.8%) higher lifetime asthma prevalence, respectively. Noise exposure was not significantly associated with asthma prevalence.

Mitochondrial DNA variation in common diseases has been underexplored, partly due to a lack of genotype calling and quality-control procedures. We show correlations between nuclear and mitochondrial genomic structures within subpopulations of Great Britain. We establish a UK Biobank reference atlas of mtDNA-phenotype associations.

We have analysed 162 PRS (p -05 ) derived from GWAS and 551 heritable traits from the UK Biobank study (N = 334,398) Findings can be investigated using a web application.

Mendelian randomization (MR) is a powerful tool in epidemiology that can be used to estimate the causal effect of an exposure on an outcome. This has been extended to multivariable MR (MVMR) to estimate effect of two or more exposures. We use simulations and theory to clarify the interpretation of estimated effects in a MVMR analysis.

UK Biobank is a major prospective epidemiological study, including multimodal brain imaging, genetics and ongoing health outcomes. Previously, we published genome-wide associations of 3,144 brain imaging-derived phenotypes, with a discovery sample of 8,428 individuals. We now include the X chromosome and new classes of imaging- derived phenotypes.

Efforts to prevent depression have focused on a limited number of candidate factors. Using phenotypic and genomic data from over 100,000 UK Biobank participants, the authors sought to systematically screen and validate a wide range of potential modifiable factors for depression.

Polygenic risk score (PRS) has been shown to be predictive of disease risk such as type 2 diabetes (T2D) However, existing studies on genetic prediction for T2D only had limited predictive power. We proposed a new three-step filtering procedure, which aimed to include truly predictive single-nucleotide polymorphisms (SNPs) into PRS model.

Up to 30% of people who test positive to SARS-CoV-2 will develop severe COVID-19 and require hospitalisation. Age, gender, and comorbidities are known to be risk factors but are generally considered independently without accurate knowledge of the magnitude of their effect on risk. We have developed a model that enables accurate prediction of severe CO VID-19.

Few tools exist that can integrate the genome and exposome for complex trait analyses. We propose a linear mixed model approach to bridge this gap. We illustrate our approach using traits from the UK Biobank. The joint model explains substantially more phenotypic variance.

A growing body of evidence suggests that vitamin D deficiency has been associated with an increased susceptibility to viral and bacterial respiratory infections. In this study, we aimed to examine the association between vitamin D and COVID-19 risk and outcomes. Ambient UVB was strongly and inversely associated with hospitalization and death overall.

Genome-wide association studies (GWASs) have identified many variants associated with complex traits, but identifying the causal gene(s) is a major challenge. We present an open resource that provides systematic fine mapping and gene prioritization across 133,441 published human GWAS loci. We identify 729 loci fine mapped to a single-coding causal variant.

Researchers continue to exclude participants of non-European ancestry in human genetics studies. This practice perpetuates existing research disparities and can lead to important and large effect size associations being missed. Here, we conducted genome-wide association studies (GWAS) of 31 serum and urine biomarker quantitative traits in African, East Asian, and South Asian ancestry UK Biobank participants.

The electrocardiogram (ECG) is a commonly used clinical tool that reflects cardiac excitability and disease. Many parameters are can be measured and with the improvement of methodology can now be quantified in an automated fashion, with accuracy and at scale. These measurements can be heritable and thus genome wide association studies inform the underpinning biological mechanisms.

Weighted burden analysis of rare variants was applied to exome sequenced UK Biobank subjects with hyperlipidaemia as the phenotype. There was a tendency for genes on the X chromosome to produce strongly negative SLPs, and this was found to be due to the fact that rare X chromosome variants were identified less frequently in men than women.

Genetic background strongly influenced both baseline refractive development and susceptibility to environmentally-induced myopia. Baseline refractive errors ranged from - 21.2 diopters (D) in 129S1/svlmj mice to + 22.0 D in CAST/EiJ mice. Expression levels of 2,302 genes correlated with the baselineRefractive state of the eye, whereas 1,917 genes. correlated with susceptibility to induced myopia, including 847 genes implicated in the development of human myopia for first time.

Less than 3% of protein-coding genetic variants are predicted to result in loss of protein function. Such predicted loss-of-function (pLOF) variants provide insight into effector transcript and direction of biological effect. We identified 18 new low-frequency or rare (allele frequency) pLOF variants.

GIGYF1 has not previously been identified as a diabetes risk gene. Its product appears to be involved in the modification of insulin signalling. Loss of function (LOF) variants were associated with T2D in GCK and GIGyF1. nonsynonymous variants annotated as probably damaging were associated inGCK and HNF4A.

We quantified the genetic sharing of 25 brain disorders from genome-wide association studies of 265,218 patients and 784,643 control participants. We also identified significant sharing between disorders and a number of brain phenotypes, including cognitive measures. These results highlight the importance of common genetic variation as a risk factor for brain disorders.

Genotype-stratified variance of a quantitative trait could differ in the presence of gene-gene or gene-environment interactions. Genetic markers associated with phenotypic variance are considered promising candidates for follow-up interaction or joint location-scale analyses. As males carry only one copy of the X-chromosome, the inherent sex-genotype dependency could bias the trait-genotypes association.

Chronic facial pain often overlaps with pain experienced elsewhere in the body. Previous studies have focused on a few, selected pain conditions when assessing the degree of overlap. Findings were replicated in the UK Biobank study and the US National Health Interview Survey.

Vitamin D has been shown to be beneficial at reducing the risk of cancer. Studies examining esophageal and gastric cancer have been scarce and findings inconsistent. The UK Biobank cohort was used for this nested case-control study (N = 3732)

The UK Biobank recruited &#8764;500,000 middle-aged participants throughout the United Kingdom in 2006-2010. Anthropometric indexes (height, weight, waist and hip circumference, body composition) and other physiologic characteristics (heel bone mineral density, grip strength, blood pressure, pulse rate) were measured. In white women, non-red meat eaters had lower adiposity (e.g., 4.5% lower body fat in vegan women) and lower systolic and diastolic blood pressure.

Obesity has been positively associated with upper gastrointestinal cancers. Obesity influences hormonal factors, which may play a role in these cancers. We examined anthropometry, body fat and reproductive factors in relation to oesophageal and gastric cancer by subtype/subsite in the UK Biobank cohort.

Apolipoprotein E &#949;4 is the strongest genetic risk factor for late-onset Alzheimer's disease (AD) The Translocase of Outer Mitochondrial Membrane-40 (TOMM40) gene maintains cellular bioenergetics, which is disrupted in AD. TOMM40 '650 G versus A carriage is consistently related to neural and cognitive outcomes.

Coincident geographical variation in genotypes and health traits can bias these analyses. Understanding and accounting for this phenomenon will be important when making inference from genotype data in large studies.

People with obesity and a normal metabolic profile are sometimes referred to as having 'metabolically healthy obesity' (MHO) Whether this group of individuals are actually 'healthy' is uncertain. This study aims to examine the associations of MHO with a wide range of obesity-related outcomes.

We investigated a cohort from the MH - GRID (Minority Health Genomics and Translational Research Bio-Repository Database) and tested the association between ARMC 5 variants and blood pressure in black s. Sixteen rare variants were significantly associated with hypertension ( P=0.0402) in the gene-based (optimized sequenced kernel association test) analysis. The presence of the rs116201073 variant was associated with lower blood pressure.

Recent studies have demonstrated the important role played by gut microbiota in regulating bone development. The aim of this study is to assess the causal relationship from gut microbiota to bone development and to identify specific causal bacteria taxa. A genome-wide association study (GWAS) summary statistic based two-sample MR analysis was performed.

A major challenge for GWAS in population biobanks is ascertaining disease cases from heterogeneous data sources such as hospital records, digital questionnaire responses, or interviews. We find that hospital record and questionnaire GWAS largely identify similar genetic effects for many complex phenotypes and that combining together both phenotyping methods improves power to detect genetic associations.

 Circulating 25-hydroxyvitamin D (25OHD) has been associated with oral and oropharyngeal cancer risk but evidence is inconsistent. Five genetic variants reliably associated with circulating 25OHD were used to create a relative genetic measure of 25O HD. In the GAME-ON study, there was little evidence of a causal association between circulating 25 OHD and oral cancer.

Hyperuricemia is closely associated with insulin resistance syndrome. Whether these two conditions are causally related has long been debated. This study investigated the potential causal nature and direction of the relationship. Reducing insulin resistance could lower the SU level and gout risk, but not the other way around.

Cumulative evidence shows that gut microbiome can influence brain function and behavior via the inflammatory processes. However, the role of interaction between gut dysbiosis and C-reactive protein (CRP) in the development of anxiety and depression remains to be elucidated. In this study, 3321 independent single nucleotide polymorphism (SNP) loci associated with gut microbiome were driven from genome-wide association study.

The relationship between the genetic loci that influence mean corpuscular volume (MCV) and those associated with excess alcohol drinking is unknown. We used white British participants from the UK Biobank (n = 362 595) to assess the association between alcohol consumption and MCV. Increasing alcohol consumption by 40 g/week resulted in a 0.30% increase in MCV (P = 0.31)

More than 100,000 genetic variants are classified as disease causing in public databases. True penetrance of many of these rare alleles is uncertain and might be over-estimated by clinical ascertainment. We use data from 379,768 UK Biobank (UKB) participants of European ancestry to assess the pathogenicity of rare variants.

Major depressive disorder (MDD) and Alzheimer's disease (AD) are both common in older age and frequently co-occur. Both illnesses are polygenic, and shared genetic risk factors could explain some of the observed association. We used genotype data to test whether MDD and AD have an overlapping polygenic architecture.

Telomere length is an important indicator of tumor progression and survival for cancer patients. Previous work investigated the associations between genetically predicted telomere. length and cancers. We found that the GRS of leukocyte telitere length was associated with a decreased risk of nine types of cancer.

Cortisol's immunosuppressive, obesogenic, and hyperglycaemic effects suggest that it may play a role in cancer development. We investigated the potential causal association between plasma cortisol and risk of overall and common site-specific cancers using Mendelian randomisation.

Night shift work, behavioral rhythms, and the common  MTNR1B  risk single nucleotide polymorphism (SNP) associate with type 2 diabetes. Whether these factors exert joint effects to exacerbate type 2 Diabetes risk is unknown. Among employed participants of European ancestry in the UK Biobank, we aimed to test the cross-sectional independent associations and joint interaction effects of these risk factors.

Hugh Watkins and colleagues meta-analyze data from the UK Biobank. They identify 13 new loci that were genome-wide significant and 243 loci at a 5% false discovery rate.

Coronavirus disease 2019 (COVID-19) is a current pandemic. Studies reported that older people have higher rates of infection and more severe cases. Study aimed to investigate the correlation between genetic and exposure factors.

Shift workers had higher risk of incident and fatal CVD compared with non-shift workers. The risk was higher with longer duration of shift work, in women and in jobs with little heavy manual labour. Current smoking, short sleep duration, poor sleep quality, adiposity, higher glycated haemoglobin and higher cystatin C were identified as the main potentially modifiable mediators.

Study looked at UK Biobank data for adult men and women aged 37-73 years from 22 cities across the UK. Baseline examinations were done between 2006 and 2010. A turning point at a residential density of 1800 units per km 2 identified.

Pathological myopia is one of the leading causes of blindness globally. Lower birth weight within the normal range has been reported to increase the risk of myopia. We sought to estimate the causal effect of BW on refractive error using Mendelian randomisation.

Birth weight has been linked to cardiovascular disease (CVD) risk in adulthood. No consensus has emerged on the threshold of birth weight for the lowest CVD risk. A total of 256,787 participants, who had birth weight data and were free of CVD at baseline, were included from UK Biobank.

 increased cardiorespiratory fitness is related to decreased risk of major chronic illnesses, including cardiovascular disease, type 2 diabetes, and cancer. But its association with colorectal cancer specifically has received very little attention. We examined the relation of cardiorespiratory fitness to coloreCTal cancer in 59,191 UK Biobank participants aged 39-70 years.

A smaller frontopolar cortex (FPC) was associated with both childhood abuse (CA) and higher BMI. White-matter connectivity analysis was conducted to study the structural connectivity between the identified brain region and subdivisions of the hypothalamus in the HCP.

Insulin-like growth factor 1 (IGF1) is an important growth factor modulating development, homeostasis, and aging. Whether and how circulating IGF1 concentrations influence early death risk in the general population remains largely unknown. We included 380 997 participants who had serum IGF1 measurement and no history of cancer, cardiovascular disease (CVD), or diabetes at baseline.

Previous studies have suggested that coffee intake may be associated with a reduction in cancer risk. Mendelian randomization (MR) studies can help clarify whether the observed associations are likely to be causal.

 asthma is one of the most common chronic diseases throughout all age groups. We examined the causal effects of various environmental factors on asthma using Mendelian randomization. We found that BMI causally affects the development of asthma and that the adult-onset moderate-to-severe asthma subtype is the most susceptible to causal inference.

The prefrontal cortex is vulnerable to environmental insult. Among other factors, toxins in air pollution have been associated with damage to the prefrontal cortex in children and older adults. We used data from the UK Biobank to assess further associations between an array of toxins and gray matter.

Total brain gray-matter and white-matter volumes can be indicators of overall brain health. We found significant inverse associations between PM 2.5 concentration and total white- Matter volume. If replicated, these findings suggest that air pollution could be a risk factor for neurodegeneration.

From the UK Biobank cohort, 470 804 participants with fish oil supplementation data were included. A higher risk of breast cancer was observed in participants who consumed fatty fish at least two times per week. Findings underscore the need to refine recommendations for nutritional supplements according to inherent diet habits.

Urban residence has been highlighted as an environmental risk factor for schizophrenia and, to a lesser extent, several other psychiatric disorders. Few studies have explored genetic effects on the choice of residence. Cross-sectional retrospective cohort study including genotypes, address history, and geographic distribution of population density in the UK was conducted.

Cross-sectional study used baseline data from the UK Biobank study on 418 656 white European, black and South-Asian participants, aged 40-69 years. Diabetes prevalence was approximately three- to fourfold higher in South- Asian and two- to threefoldHigher in black participants.

Coffee is the most commonly consumed beverage in the world after water. Current evidence of the link between coffee and health outcomes is predominately observational. This study used information from up to 333,214 participants of White-British ancestry in the UK Biobank.

Inflammatory bowel disease (IBD) is an established risk factor for colorectal cancer. Recent reports suggest IBD is also a risk factors for prostate cancer (PC) We studied 218 084 men in the population-based UK Biobank cohort, aged 40 to 69 at study entry between 2006 and 2010.

Major depressive disorder (MDD) genetic risk score (GRS) and 925 disease outcomes. GRS-disease outcome associations passing the multiple-testing corrected significance threshold (P)

Refractive errors, particularly myopia, are common and a leading cause of blindness. This study aimed to explore associations between medications and refractive error in an aging adult cohort. Anti-glaucoma drugs were associated with 1 to 2 diopters greater myopic refraction.

Chronic obesity is associated with several complications, including cognitive impairment and dementia. We found that body mass index, waist-to-hip ratio, and body fat percentage were positively related to higher plasma C-reactive protein, dyslipidemia, hypertension, and diabetes.

Study looked at the association between musculoskeletal pain at multiple sites and physical work capacity (PWC) and objectively measured physical activity (PA) Data from a subsample of the UK Biobank were utilised. Increase in number of painful sites was associated with lower PWC, moderate and vigorous PA.

Cross-sectional analysis of participants recruited into UK Biobank in 2006-2010. For people with the same BMI, those who were more active had a lower body fat percentage.

Physical activity reduces cardiovascular disease burden and mortality, although its relationship with cardiac arrhythmias is less certain. The aim of this study was to assess the association between self-reported physical activity and atrial fibrillation (AF), ventricular arrhythias and bradyarrhythmia.

Physical activity has been positively related to malignant melanoma. However, that association may be confounded by ultraviolet radiation. We examined physical activity, grip strength and sedentary behaviour in relation to risk of melanoma using data from a prospective cohort study.

Polygenic scores for psychiatric disorders are associated with nutrient intake in UK Biobank. Attention-deficit/hyperactivity disorder, bipolar disorder, and schizophrenia showed the highest number of associations. The relatively weaker obsessive-compulsive disorder polygenic score showed the greatest effect sizes.

LOAD-PGR is associated with differences in structural brain imaging and cognitive values in a relatively large sample of non-demented, generally healthy adults (UK Biobank) In fully adjusted models, LOAD-PGr was associated with worse fluid intelligence, smaller left hippocampal total and smaller body volumes.

Congenital heart disease is the most common birth defect in newborns. It is the leading cause of death in infancy, affecting nearly 1% of live births. A locus in chromosome 4p16, adjacent to MSX1 and STX18, has been associated with atrial septal defects.

Toxoplasma gondii has been associated with worsened cognitive function in animal models and in humans. The mechanisms by which it might affect cognitive function remain unknown. The parasite does produce physiologically active intraneuronal cysts and appears to affect dopamine synthesis.

Antioxidants users were defined as participants who indicated to regularly use at least one of the following: multivitamins, vitamin C, vitamin E, selenium, and zinc. Median age of antioxidants users and non-users at baseline was 57 years. During 3.9 million person-years and a median follow-up of 11.5 years, 19,491 deaths occurred.

Lipid management typically focuses on levels of low-density lipoprotein cholesterol (LDL-C) and, to a lesser extent, triglycerides ( TG) However, animal models and genetic studies suggest that the atherogenic particle subpopulations are both important. The number of particles is more predictive of cardiac events than their lipid content.

Body mass index (BMI), waist and hip circumference are strongly correlated and do not reflect body composition. We examined differences in body composition between body-shape phenotypes defined with ABSI and HI. We used data from the UK Biobank Resource for 15,520 men, 16,548 women with dual-emission X-ray absorptiometry (DXA) measurements.

A history of 2 or more of the following: diabetes mellitus, stroke, myocardial infarction (MI) Life expectancy was substantially lower in people with multimorbidity. At the age of 60 years, a history of any 2 of these conditions was associated with 12 years of reduced life expectancy.

A cross-sectional study of UK Biobank participants aged 40-70 years was performed. Logistic regression was used to calculate the odds of psoriasis, PsA and RA occurrence compared with controls without these conditions by waist circumference. The ORs remained significant after further adjustment for BMI.

Genome-wide association (GWA) analyses were performed utilizing data from the Kaiser Permanente Research Board (KPRB) and the UK Biobank. Patellar tendinopathy cases were identified based on electronic health records. Two single nucleotide polymorphisms located in the intron of the cytochrome c oxidase assembly factor 1 (COA1) gene showed a genome-wide significant association in the meta-analysis.

Mental health score was created using information about depressive symptoms, anxiety, loneliness, and neuroticism. During a median follow-up of 11.3 years (3.7 million person-years), we documented 22,688 CVD cases.

Deletion of a non-imprinted 500kb genomic region at chromosome 15q11.2, between breakpoints 1 and 2 of the Prader-Willi/Angelman locus (BP1-BP2 deletion), has been associated in previous studies with congenital cardiovascular malformations (CVM) Using the UK Biobank (UKB) cohort of ~500,000 individuals, we identified individuals with CVM and investigated the association with deletions at the BP1- BP2 locus.

Microdeletions and duplications in the genomic region 15q11.2 between breakpoints 1 (BP1) and 2 (BP2) are associated with neurodevelopmental disorders. These structural variants are present in 0.5% to 1.0% of the population. It is unknown to what extent this CNV influences brain structure and cognitive abilities.

Short sleep duration has been linked to negative health effects, but is a complex phenotype with many contributing factors, including genetic. We evaluated 27 common single nucleotide polymorphisms (SNPs) in candidate genes for association with self-reported habitual sleep duration in the UK Biobank. Genetic variation in DAT1 (rs464049) was significantly associated with sleep duration after correction for multiple testing.

Study used the UK Biobank resource, a large cross-sectional study of adults aged 40-69. Dietary factors included portions of fruit and vegetables per day, weekly fish consumption (oily and non-oily), bread type, cups of caffeinated coffee per day and avoidance of dairy, eggs, wheat and sugar.

Study looked at associations of objectively measured cardiorespiratory fitness (CRF) and grip strength (GS) with incident heart failure (HF) Higher CRF was associated with 18% lower risk for HF (hazard ratio [HR], 0.82; 95% CI, 0.76-0.88) per 1-metabolic equivalent increment increase. Higher GS was linked to 19% lower incidence of HF risk (HR,0.81; 0.77- 0.86) per 5-kg increase.

Levels of activity are often affected in psychiatric disorders and can be core symptoms of illness. Advances in technology now allow the accurate assessment of activity levels. It remains unclear whether alterations in activity arise from shared risk factors for developing psychiatric disorders, such as genetics.

UK Biobank participants without dementia with Caucasian genetic ancestry completed a Digit Triplets Test of speech-in-noise hearing and hearing with background noise. A genetic risk score for AD (AD-GRS) was calculated as a weighted sum of 23 previously identified AD-related polymorphisms.

An association was recently reported between genetic markers related to high testosterone and increased risk of thromboembolism in men. This work aimed to determine whether endogenous estradiol has a causal role in the disease. The study involved 170 593 unrelated men of White ancestry in the UK Biobank. It found that genetically predicted estradio was inversely associated with the risk of ischemic stroke.

Habitual use of glucosamine supplement to relieve osteoarthritis pain might also be related to lower risks of CVD events.

Among 12,014 genes evaluated in the UK Biobank, we identify 38 associated with PrCa, many replicating in the Kaiser Permanente RPGEH. We report the association of elevated TMPRSS2 expression with increased PrCa risk.

Data was from 147,478 individuals from the UK Biobank (UKB) and 2,905 from the Netherlands Study of Depression and Anxiety (NESDA) Circulating C-reactive protein (CRP) was measured in both cohorts and interleukin-6 (IL-6) in NESDA. Depressive and anxiety symptoms were assessed with self-report questionnaires. Inflammation was associated with core depressive symptoms of low mood and anhedonia. Less consistent associations were found for anxiety.

Spending more time active is associated with health benefits such as improved cardiovascular health and lower risk of all-cause mortality. It is unclear whether these associations differ depending on whether time spent sedentary or in moderate-vigorous physical activity (MVPA) is accumulated in long or short bouts. In this study, we used a novel method that accounts for substitution (i.e., more time in MVPA means less time sleeping, in light activity or sedentary) to examine whether length of sedentary and MVPA bouts associates with all- Cause mortality.

Major depressive disorder (MDD), schizophrenia (SCZ) and bipolar disorder (BP) are common, disabling and heritable psychiatric diseases with a complex overlapping polygenic architecture. Individuals with these disorders, as well as their unaffected relatives, show widespread structural differences in corticostriatal and limbic networks. Structural variation in many of these brain regions is also heritable and polygenic.

Study assessed associations of poor sleep burden, and its trajectory, with delirium risk during hospitalization. About 321 818 participants from the UK Biobank reported sleep traits (sleep duration, excessive daytime sleepiness, insomnia-type complaints, napping) New-onset deliriam (n = 4 775) was obtained from hospitalization records.

Several forms of pulmonary hypertension (PH) disproportionately affect women. Animal and human studies suggest that estradiol exerts mixed effects on the pulmonary vasculature. Whether premature menopause represents a risk factor for PH is unknown.

There is growing evidence of, and biological plausibility for, elevated levels of high-density lipoprotein cholesterol (HDL-C) We tested whether pre-pandemic HDL-C within the normal range is associated with subsequent COVID-19 hospitalisations and death. The effect was linear (p-value for trend 0.001), whereby a 0.2 mmol/L increase in cholesterol was associated with a lower risk.

Brain age is a metric that quantifies the degree of aging of a brain based on whole-brain anatomical characteristics. We found that daily or almost daily consumption of tobacco and alcohol were both significantly associated with increased RBA.

Vitamin D insufficiency and deficiency are common in patients with cardiovascular disease (CVD) We aimed to examine the associations of serum 25-hydroxyvitamin D [25(OH)D] concentrations with all-cause and cause-specific mortality among adult patients with existing CVD. We included 37,079 patients with CVD from the UK Biobank study.

There is some evidence to suggest that levels of sex hormones might influence the etiology of cancers of the pancreas, kidney, and brain, but epidemiologic data are lacking. We evaluated the association of circulating levels of total and free testosterone, and of sex hormone-binding globulin (SHBG), with the risk of cancers.

Study included 360 403 participants without T2D at baseline from the UK Biobank. Genetic risk was categorised as high (highest quintile), intermediate (quintiles: 2-4), and low (lowest quintile) Sleep scores, including insomnia, snoring, late chronotype, and excessive daytime sleepiness, were categorized as an unfavourable, intermediate, or favourable sleep and circadian pattern.

Excessive Ca intakes have been proposed to associate with vascular calcification and a higher risk of prostate cancer. We investigated the associations of supplemental and dietary Ca intake with mortality using data from 497 828 UK Biobank participants.

Hereditary transthyretin-mediated (hATTR) amyloidosis is an underdiagnosed, progressively debilitating disease. V122I, a common pathogenic TTR mutation, is found in 3-4% of individuals of African ancestry in the United States and has been associated with cardiomyopathy and heart failure. We conducted a phenome-wide association study scanning 427 ICD diagnosis codes.

UK Biobank Study is one of the largest cohort studies of health, enrolling over 500,000 participants aged 40-69 years between 2006 and 2010 across the UK. VI was defined as a habitual distance visual acuity (VA) worse than 0.3 logarithm of the minimum angle of resolution (LogMAR)

UK Biobank participants in employment or self-employed at baseline (2006-2010) and with linked COVID-19 data to 31st August 2020. Participants were grouped as neither a health worker nor shift worker (reference category) at baseline, health worker only, shift worker only or both.

Study examined the phenotypic associations and shared genetic aetiology between BPD and various cardiometabolic traits. Several traits were significantly associated with increased risk for BPD. BPD was associated with higher polygenic risk for triglycerides and coronary artery disease.

Population cohort of over 500 000 people recruited from 22 centres across the UK. Participants aged between 40 and 69 years were recruited between 2006 and 2010. Cycling exclusively or in combination with walking was most strongly associated with increased dietary consumption of FV and reduced consumption of red and processed meat.

Harmful alcohol use is a leading cause of premature death and is associated with age-related disease. Biological ageing is highly variable between individuals and may deviate from chronological ageing. biomarkers of biological ageing (derived from DNA methylation or brain structural measures) may be clinically relevant.

Being an evening type is associated with increased mortality in the UK Biobank. Greater eveningness, particularly being a definite evening type, was significantly associated with a higher prevalence of all comorbidities. The associations were strongest for psychological disorders.

The aim of the current study was to investigate the association between diet and handgrip strength. Diet and nutritional data (carotene, retinol, potassium, vitamin C, foliate, vitamin B12 and iron) were collected from UK Biobank.

Dietary data was collected using a 24-h online dietary assessment on two or more occasions (n = 116,806) Two dietary patterns were retained that jointly explained 63% of variation in energy density, free sugars, saturated fat, and fiber intakes. The main dietary pattern was characterized by high intakes of chocolate and confectionery, butter and low-fiber bread.

The built environment might be associated with development of obesity and related disorders. We examined whether neighbourhood exposure to fast-food outlets and physical activity facilities were associated with adiposity in UK adults. Greater density of facilities within 1000 m of home was independently associated with smaller waist circumference and lower BMI and body fat percentage. Living further from a fast- food outlet was weakly associated with waist circumference.

People with unilateral hearing impairment were more likely to report difficulties following conversations in noise, tinnitus presence, feeling depressed, lonely, unhappy, and being in poor health or dissatisfied with health. SRTN/N was associated with increased risk of self-reported poor health by 18%.

Human leukocyte antigens (HLA) have been associated with renal function. This study included 401,307 white British subjects aged 39-73 when they were recruited by UK Biobank.

Cross-sectional analysis of the UK Biobank. 4366 participants (54% female, mean age 61 years) underwent magnetic resonance imaging to assess LV function. Augmentation index (AIx) was used as a measure of arterial stiffness.

Major depressive disorder (MDD), schizophrenia (SCZ), and bipolar disorder (BD) have both shared and discrete genetic risk factors. The relationships between such genetic architectures and blood-based markers are, however, unclear. We investigated relationships between polygenic risk scores (PRS) for these disorders and peripheral markers in the UK Biobank cohort.

The "healthy obese" hypothesis suggests the risks associated with excess adiposity are reduced in those with higher muscle quality. Alternative possibilities include loss of muscle quality as people become unwell (reverse causality) or unmeasured confounding. We conducted a cohort study using the UK Biobank (n=452 931) Baseline body mass index ( BMI) was used to quantify adiposity and handgrip strength ( HGS ) used for musclequality. Low genetically predicted HGS was associated with an increased risk of mortality.

Multimorbidity is common among breast cancer survivors, with 32.9% of women experiencing one and 30.1% experiencing two or more chronic health conditions. Hypertension (25.8%), painful conditions (18.3%), and asthma (11.6%) were the three most common co-morbid conditions. 5.3% of participants had current depression.

Seventy-seven occupations were associated with level of alcohol consumption in drinkers. The largest ratios for heavy drinkers were observed for publicans and managers of licenced premises. Clergy, physicists, geologists and meteorologists were least likely to be heavy drinkers. There was evidence of gender-specific outcomes with the proportion of jobs associated with heavy drinking accounted for by skilled trade occupations.

Baseline data were available for 502,643 participants (2006-2010, United Kingdom) Cognitive tests included prospective memory, visual-spatial memory, fluid intelligence, and short-term numeric memory. Sedentary behaviors (television viewing, driving, and nonoccupational computer-use time) were measured at baseline.

Data from the UK Biobank were analysed (n = 487,728, mean follow-up time = 8.9 years) Frequent sleep disturbances were associated with increased risk of all-cause mortality. Mortality risk was highest in those with both diabetes and frequent sleep disturbances.

Study enrolled 328,850 participants aged between 37 and 73 years from the UK Biobank. End of health span was defined by eight events strongly associated with longevity. Compared with poor sleep quality, participants with healthy sleep quality had a 15% reduced risk of terminated health span.

Smoking accelerates the ageing of multiple organs. Few studies have quantified the association between smoking, especially smoking cessation, and brain ageing. A brain age predictor was trained using a machine learning technique in the non-smoker group and then tested in the smoker group. On average, smokers showed a larger BrainAge Gap (+0.304 years, Cohens'd = 0.083) than controls.

There is limited evidence on associations between multiple vascular risk factors (VRFs) and detailed aspects of brain macrostructure and microstructure. Smoking, hypertension, pulse pressure, diabetes, hypercholesterolaemia, body mass index, and waist-hip ratio were examined. A larger number of VRFs was associated with greater brain atrophy, lower grey matter volume, and poorer white matter health.

In many species, the offspring of related parents suffer reduced reproductive success, a phenomenon known as inbreeding depression. In humans, the importance of this effect has remained unclear, partly because reproduction between close relatives is both rare and frequently associated with confounding social factors. Here, using genomic inbreeding coefficients (FROH) for >1.4 million individuals, we show that FROH is significantly associated (p)

Between 2006 and 2010, a total of 354,976 participants (age 40-70 years) in the UK Biobank free of stroke and coronary heart disease were examined and thereafter followed up to 2020. The risk of stroke decreased significantly and linearly with both increasing behavioral CVH score and biological CVH Score.

Adequate dietary protein intake is important for the maintenance of bone health. Data in this area is ambiguous with some suggestion that high protein intake can have deleterious effects. The aim of the current study was to explore the associations of protein intake with bone mineral density (BMD)

Adequate dietary protein intake is important for the maintenance of fat-free mass (FFM) and muscle strength. Our aim was to explore the associations of protein intake with FFM and grip strength. We used baseline data from the UK Biobank (a study of 146,816 participants aged 40-69 years)

Increase in the number of food outlets has been proposed as a key factor driving obesity. This study aimed to investigate the association between the densities of food establishments serving meals, with body mass index. BMIs, WHR, %fat and socioeconomic factors were obtained from 456,079 individuals.

Habitual use of fish oil seems to be associated with a lower risk of all cause and CVD mortality. The association seemed to be stronger among those with prevalent hypertension (P for interaction=0.005).

Greater red and processed meat consumption has been linked to adverse cardiovascular outcomes. However, the impact of these exposures on cardiovascular magnetic resonance (CMR) phenotypes has not been adequately studied. We studied 19,408 UK Biobank participants with CMR data available. Oily fish was studied as a comparator, previously associated with favourable cardiac outcomes.

Study included 495 077 women and men from the UK Biobank study. At baseline, 19.1% of the participants reported regular use of glucosamine supplements. 19 882 all-cause deaths were recorded, including 3802 CVD deaths, 8090 cancer deaths, 3380 respiratory disease deaths and 1061 digestive disease deaths.

There is debate whether body mass index is a good predictor of health outcomes. Different tissues, namely skeletal muscle mass (SMM) and fat mass (FM), may be differentially associated with risk. We studied 356 590 UK Biobank participants aged 40 to 69 years. FM showed a strong positive association with CVD risk.

Previous studies have reported conflicting findings on the association of sleep apnoea with glaucoma. There are limited reports on the link between sleep apNoea and age-related macular degeneration (AMD) Middle-aged and older participants from the UK Biobank and the Canadian Longitudinal Study on Aging were included in this analysis.

A total of 499,159 participants were recruited from the UK Biobank between 2006 and 2010. Severe ISH was based on hospital inpatient records or a death cause of ICD-10 codes X60-X84. Sleep phenotypes, including sleep duration, chronotype, insomnia, sleepiness, and napping, were assessed at the initial assessments.

Vitamin D has numerous anticancer functions, but associations between vitamin D status and colorectal cancer (CRC) risk and survival remain inconclusive. Based on UK Biobank, we prospectively evaluated the associations of season-standardized 25-hydroxyvitamin D (25(OH)D) concentrations with CRC risk. The highest quartile was associated with a 13% (HR, 0.87) lower risk of CRC.

Study looked at associations of physical and demographic factors with Goldmann-correlated intraocular pressure (IOPg) and corneal-compensated intraocular Pressure (Iopcc) in a British cohort. IOPg and IOPcc were both significantly associated with older age, male sex, higher systolic blood pressure (SBP), faster heart rate, greater myopia, self-reported glaucoma, and colder season.

Spectral-domain OCT (SD-OCT) provides high resolution images enabling identification of individual retinal layers. SD OCT measured photoreceptor layer thickness: inner nuclear layer-retinal pigment epithelium (INL-RPE) In multivariate regression models, the total average INL- RPE was observed to be thinner in older aged, females, Black ethnicity, smokers, participants with higher systolic blood pressure, more negative refractive error.

Spousal comparisons have been proposed as a design that can both reduce confounding and estimate effects of the shared adulthood environment. Assortative mating could distort associations when comparing spouses. Analyses using UK Biobank spouse pairs found that WSP genetic association estimates were smaller than estimates from random pairs for height, educational attainment, and BMI.

Histone deacetylase 9 (HDAC9) has been demonstrated as a key regulator of vascular smooth muscle cell (VSMC) phenotype. HDAC9 is associated with abdominal aortic calcification, myocardial infarction, and ischemic stroke.

Study investigated the causal effects between atrial fibrillation (AF) and kidney function. A genetic predisposition to AF was significantly associated with decreased eGFR.

Atrial fibrillation (AF) patients have enlarged left atria (LA) Previous studies suggested enlarged atria as both cause and consequence of AF. Aim of this study is to investigate the causal association between AF and LA size and function.

Cupping of the optic nerve head, a highly heritable trait, is a hallmark of glaucomatous optic neuropathy. Two key parameters are vertical cup-to-disc ratio (VCDR) and vertical disc diameter (VDD) We show convolutional neural network models can accurately estimate VCDR and VDD for 282,100 images.

The morphometric characteristics of the retinal vasculature are associated with future risk of many systemic and vascular diseases. This requires automated systems that extract quantitative measures of vessel morphology from large numbers of retinal images. This paper presents a deep learning approach for the automatic classification of arterioles and venules.

The aim of the study was to develop a machine-learning glaucoma detection model. The model was trained on macular optical coherence tomography volumes and color fundus photographs. It highlights biological features known to be related to the disease, such as age, intraocular pressure and optic disc morphology.

Wearable devices are increasingly used in research to provide continuous physical activity monitoring. How to effectively extract features remains challenging for researchers. To analyze the generated actigraphy data in large-scale population studies, we developed computationally efficient methods.

The trend towards large-scale studies including population imaging poses new challenges in terms of quality control (QC) This is a particular issue when automatic processing tools such as image segmentation methods are employed. Manual inspection and visual QC of each segmentation result is not feasible at large scale.

Pericardial adipose tissue (PAT) may represent a novel risk marker for cardiovascular disease. We developed a fully automated quality-controlled tool for cardiovascular magnetic resonance (CMR) PAT quantification in the UK Biobank. Larger CMR PAT area was associated with significantly greater odds of diabetes independent of age, sex and body mass index.

Morphological changes in the retinal vascular network are associated with future risk of many systemic and vascular diseases. Analysis of data from large population based studies will help to resolve these uncertainties. A random subset of 800 retinal images from UK Biobank (a large prospective study of 500,000 middle aged adults; where 68,151 underwent retinal imaging) was used to examine the performance of the image quality algorithm.

Cardiac magnetic resonance (CMR) images play a growing role in the diagnostic imaging of cardiovascular diseases. Full coverage of the left ventricle (LV), from base to apex, is a basic criterion for CMR image quality. A two-stage framework is proposed to identify missing basal and apical slices in measurements of CMR volume.

Good quality of medical images is a prerequisite for the success of subsequent image analysis pipelines. For large population studies such as the UK Biobank, manual identification of artefacts such as those caused by unanticipated motion is tedious and time-consuming. We propose a method to automatically detect the presence of motion-related artefacts in cardiac magnetic resonance (CMR) cine images.

Estimates from Mendelian randomization studies of unrelated individuals can be biased due to uncontrolled confounding from familial effects. We show that family-based analyses can reduce such biases. We illustrate how familial effects can affect estimates using data from 61,008 siblings from the Nord-Tr&#248;ndelag Health Study.

SARS-CoV-2 is a rapidly spreading coronavirus responsible for the Covid-19 pandemic. Many factors have been identified as risk factors for SARS- cov-2. Higher BMI, type II diabetes and HbA1c were associated with increased odds. Elevated HDL-C and ApoA-I levels associated with reduced odds.

Vitamin D has been associated with the risk of type 2 diabetes (T2D), but the results are inconsistent. Emerging evidence suggests that vitamin D metabolism is linked to sleep behaviors. We investigated the prospective association between serum 25-hydroxyvitamin D (25OHD) and risk of incident T2D.

Gil McVean and colleagues present a new Bayesian analysis framework that exploits the hierarchical structure of diagnosis classifications. Their method displays increased power to detect genetic effects over other approaches and identifies novel associations between classical HLA alleles and common immune-mediated diseases.

The enormous variation in human lifespan is in part due to a myriad of sequence variants, only a few of which have been revealed to date. Since many life-shortening events are related to diseases, we developed a Mendelian randomization-based method combining 58 disease-related GWA studies to derive longevity priors for all HapMap SNPs.

We created a suite of packages to enable analysis of extremely large genomic data sets. The package is accessible through CRAN and GitHub. In this note, we describe the classes and methods implemented in each of the packages that make the suite.

Major depressive disorder is the most common neuropsychiatric disorder, affecting 11% of veterans. We report results of a large meta-analysis of depression using data from the Million Veteran Program, 23andMe, UK Biobank and FinnGen. Transcriptome-wide association study analyses revealed significant associations with expression of NEGR1 and DRD2.

Two-sample Mendelian randomization (MR) allows the use of summary association results from genome-wide association studies (GWAS) Some GWAS adjust for heritable covariables in an attempt to estimate direct effects of genetic variants on the trait of interest. In the absence of residual confounding, using covariable-adjusted summary associations for two-sample MR eliminated bias.

The relationship between physical activity and muscular strength has not been examined in detail among older adults. The objective of this study was to examine the associations between physical. activity and hand grip strength among adults aged 60 years and older.

Single nucleotide polymorphisms (SNPs) in the bridging integrator 1 (BIN1) gene indicate the second highest odds-ratios for sporadic AD. Apolipoprotein E (APOE) e4 genotype, which increases the risk of Alzheimer's disease (AD), predicted severe COVID-19 infection in one UK Biobank (UKB) cohort.

Until recently, pharmacogenes could not be studied at biobank scale. In EUR, N-acetyltransferase 2 (NAT2) metabolizer phenotype and activity score were associated with simvastatin use. Testing NAT2 alleles may be useful for making clinical decisions regarding the potential benefit of statin treatment.

The tendency to conceive spontaneous dizygotic twins is a complex trait with important contributions from both environmental factors and genetic disposition. The aim of this study was to identify genetic variants influencing multiple births and to genetically correlate the findings across a broad range of traits.

UK Biobank recruited 500,000 participants aged 40-69 y (54.4% women) throughout the United Kingdom in 2006-2010. Blood and urine were collected at recruitment and assayed for more than 30 biomarkers related to cardiovascular diseases, bone and joint health, cancer, diabetes, renal disease, and liver health.

Study aimed to characterize the biomarker profile of sarcopenic vs nonsarcopenic men and women. Thirty-three biomarkers, standardized to sex-specific z-scores, were included in the analysis. Sarcopenia was associated with higher concentrations of phosphate, lipoprotein A, and lower of diastolic blood pressure.

The UK Biobank study has successfully imaged more than 32,000 volunteer participants with magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) Each scan is linked to extensive metadata, providing a comprehensive medical survey of imaged anatomy and related health states.

The risk for hypertension decreased as birth weight increased up to approximately 3.80 kg. Compared with the participants with the fourth quintile of birth weight, those with the first quartile had the highest risk. These associations were largely consistent in the stratified and sensitivity analyses. Our findings indicate that lower birth weight is nonlinearly correlated with higher risk of hypertension.

The relationship between birth weight and osteoporosis was inconsistent in previous observational studies. We performed a systematic evaluation to determine the inconsistent relationship and further make causal inference based on the UK Biobank datasets. Birth weight was causally associated not only with three BMD phenotypes but also with the risk of fracture using different Mendelian randomization methods.

Fetal intrauterine growth is influenced by complex interactions between the maternal genes, environment and fetal genes. The aim of this study was to assess the effect of GWAS-identified genetic variants associated with birth weight on fetal growth in 665 children.

Medical research increasingly includes high-dimensional regression modeling with a need for error-in-variables methods. The Convex Conditioned Lasso (CoCoLasso) utilizes a reformulated Lasso objective function and an error-corrected cross-validation. We develop a Block coordinate Descent ConveX Conditioning Lasso. This algorithm separately optimizes the estimation of the uncorrupted and corrupted features.

The association between blood pressure (BP) and bladder cancer (BC) risk remains unclear with confounding by smoking being of particular concern. We found a positive association between systolic BP and BC risk in Swedish cohorts. BP levels were positively associated with muscle-invasive BC (MIBC) but not with non-muscle invasive BC, which could be analyzed in the Swedish cohorts only.

Figure 1 shows the size of the human body. Figure 1: The human body is made up of more than 100 million cells. Figure 2: The number of human cells is estimated to be around 100 million.

Hypertension or elevated blood pressure (BP) is an important risk factor for aortic dissection (AD) Few prospective studies on this topic have been published. We investigated the association between hypertension/elevated BP and AD in 2 cohorts.

Mitochondrial DNA copy number (mtDNA-CN) is a proxy for mitochondrial function and is associated with aging-related diseases. It is unclear how mtDNA- CN measured in blood can reflect diseases that primarily manifest in other tissues. Using the Genotype-Tissue Expression Project, we interrogated relationships between mt DNA-CN measured in whole blood and gene expression in 47 additional tissues.

Elevated blood pressure (BP) is a modifiable risk factor for atrial fibrillation (AF) We tested whether the association between BP and risk of AF is causal, and whether it varies according to individual's genetic susceptibility for AF. We also tested the extent to which specific BP-lowering drugs are expected to reduce this risk.

The recognition of adiposity as a risk factor for gastric cancer is mainly based on traditional anthropometric indices, such as body mass index.
