We undertook this study to examine body composition and subsequent risk of Gastric cancer. We documented 326 cases of cancer from 474,929 participants over a median follow-up of 6.6 years.

The UK Biobank measured baseline body composition and confirmed cancer diagnosis. For premenopausal women, whole body fat-free mass (WBFFM) was associated with an increased risk of uterine corpus cancer. No association of body composition with ovarian or cervical cancer was observed.

Study aimed to investigate the value of imaging-based multivariable body composition profiling by describing its association with coronary heart disease (CHD), type 2 diabetes (T2D), and metabolic health on individual and population levels.

Study aimed to quantify associations of regional fat mass and fat-free mass with systolic blood pressure. Among 10,260 participants (mean age 49; 96% white), systolic blood pressure was positively associated with visceral android fat. There was no evidence of an association with subcutaneous android or gynoid fat.

Study looked at the relationship between body mass index (BMI) and mortality. An increase of 1 unit in genetically predicted BMI led to a 5% (95% confidence interval 1% to 8%) higher risk of mortality in overweight participants. But a 34% (16% to 48%) lower risk in underweight participants.

Evidence for the impact of body size and composition on cancer risk is limited. This mendelian randomisation study investigates evidence supporting causal relationships of body mass index, fat mass index and fat-free mass index with cancer risk.

We investigated associations between body size and composition, physical activity and sedentary time and serum concentrations of oestradiol (premenopausal women only), testosterone, sex hormone binding globulin (SHBG) and insulin-like growth factor-I (IGF-I) in UK Biobank. In premenopausal women, higher BMI was associated with a lower concentration of total ostradiol and a higher concentration of SHBG.

Predicting a person's age using brain features can aid the detection of abnormalities in the ageing process. Existing studies on such "brain age prediction" vary widely in terms of their methods and type of data.

Brain imaging can be used to study how individuals' brains are aging, compared against population norms. This can inform on aspects of brain health; for example, smoking and blood pressure can be seen to accelerate brain aging.

Between-individual variability in brain structure is determined by gene-environment interactions. Magnetic resonance imaging studies have revealed thinner cortices and smaller subcortical volumes in patients with schizophrenia. Group-level comparisons may mask considerable within-group heterogeneity, which has largely remained unnoticed in the literature.

Seasonal differences in mood and depressive symptoms affect a large percentage of the general population. SAD affects up to 3% of the world's population, and it tends to be more predominant in females than males. The brainstem has been shown to be affected by photoperiodic changes. Longer Photoperiod days are associated with larger brainstem volumes and lower depressive scores.

A previous genome-wide association study found three genetic loci to increase the risk of Brugada Syndrome (BrS) Since the effect of these loci in the general population is unknown, we aimed to investigate the effect on electrocardiogram (ECG) parameters and outcomes. A cohort of 6,161 individuals with available digital ECGs was genotyped and followed for a median period of 13 [IQR 12.6-13.4] years. Data on outcomes were collected from Danish administrative healthcare registries.

Cross-sectional studies of carotid artery atherosclerosis in 24,822 Chinese adults from the China Kadoorie Biobank and 2579 Europeans from the UK Biobanks. Carotid intima-media thickness (cIMT) findings in Chinese were compared with a European population (mean age 62 years) Overall, the mean cIMT in Chinese was 0.70 mm (SD 0.16) and increased with age.

Cam morphology was more prevalent in males than females (15.4% and 1.8% respectively) In males, cam morphology was associated with rHOA [OR 3.20 (95% CI 2.41-4.25)], JSN [1.53 (1.24-1.88)], and acetabular dysplasia (AD) Neither pincer morphology nor AD showed any associations with hip pain.

COVID-19 is a disease that has shown to have outcomes that vary by certain socio-demographic and socio-economic groups. It is increasingly important that an understanding of these outcomes should be derived not from the consideration of one aspect, but by a more multi-faceted understanding of the individual.

"Deep learning" (DL) techniques such as Multilayer Perceptrons (MLPs) and Convolutional Neural Networks (CNNs) have not been comprehensively tested. We analyzed a total of five phenotypes: height, bone heel mineral density, body mass index, systolic blood pressure, and waist-hip ratio. For height, a highly heritable phenotype, all methods performed similarly, although CNNs were slightly but consistently worse.

UK Biobank recruited 503,325 persons aged 40-69 years. Participants completed questionnaires, including pain, lifestyle and environment factors. Prevalence of chronic pain and most regional musculoskeletal pains were all within 2% of that in NCDS.

Cannabis is known to produce acute, transient psychotic-like experiences. It is unclear whether cannabis disproportionately increases the risk of specific types of psychotic experiences and whether genetic predisposition influences the relationship between cannabis use and psychotic experiences. In this cross-sectional study of 109,308 UK Biobank participants, we examined how schizophrenia polygenic risk modulates the association between self-reported cannabis use.

There were significant associations between mood disorder features and 'any cardiovascular disease' Individuals with features of mood disorder taking psychotropic medication were significantly more likely than controls not on psychotropics to report myocardial infarction. Psychotropic medication may also be a risk factor for cardiometabolic disease.

High VAT-high LF and high VAT-low LF were associated with prevalent atherosclerosis. Low VAT- high LF was not. In the UK Biobank, only high VAT -low LF remained associated with CVD after multivariable adjustment.

Cardiorespiratory fitness (CRF) is associated with mortality and cardiovascular disease. We develop and validate a novel framework to estimate CRF from heart rate response to low-risk personalised exercise tests. We apply the method to examine associations between CRF and health outcomes.

About 4% of the study population were diagnosed with a chronic inflammatory disorder. The most common inflammatory disorder was psoriasis, and the least common was SLE (n=654). SLE showed the strongest association with multiple (relative risk) risk of cardiometabolic diseases.

Risk prediction models currently recommended by clinical guidelines are typically based on a limited number of predictors with sub-optimal performance across all patient groups. Data-driven techniques based on machine learning might improve the performance of risk predictions by agnostically discovering novel risk predictors and learning the complex interactions between them.

5065 consecutive UK Biobank participants underwent CMR using cine balanced steady-state free precession imaging at 1.5 T. With advancing age, end-diastolic TA diameter became larger and posterior MV leaflet angle smaller in both sexes.

Population-based, case-control study investigated cardiovascular risk factors and body composition in Norwegian adults with achondroplasia. Participants had lower age-adjusted mean blood pressure, total and low-density lipoprotein (LDL) cholesterol, and triglycerides compared with controls.

It is uncertain to what extent established cardiovascular risk factors are associated with venous thromboembolism (VTE) This study included individual participant data mostly from essentially population-based cohort studies from the Emerging Risk Factors Collaboration and the UK Biobank. Older age, smoking, and adiposity were consistently associated with higher VTE risk.

Excessive coffee consumption can lead to unpleasant sensations such as tachycardia and heart palpitations. We used information from up to 390,435 European ancestry participants in the UK Biobank, aged 39-73 y. Participants with essential hypertension, angina, or heart arrhythmia were more likely to drink less caffeinated coffee.

There was a distinct increase in the number of CVD-related deaths in the UK Biobank population at the beginning of the COVID-19 outbreak. The shortage of medical resources for hospital care and stress reactions to the pandemic might have partially contributed to the excess mortality.

Polygenic risk scores (PRS) can be a powerful tool for detecting global patterns of interaction. We show how a linear regression of the PRS on E in a sample of cases can be used to efficiently estimate the interaction parameter. We applied the proposed method to investigate interactions between a PRS and epidemiologic factors on breast cancer risk in the UK Biobank.

We conducted a two-sample Mendelian randomization study to investigate the associations between genetic predisposition to thyroid dysfunction and 22 site-specific cancers. Genetically predicted thyroid dysfunction was associated with breast cancer, with similar patterns of associations in the Breast Cancer Association Consortium and UK Biobank. The role of TSH and hypothyroidism for thyroid cancer needs further exploration.

Study was an observational cohort study investigating the UK Biobank. Lower alcohol use was observationally associated with a higher risk of prevalent CKD or incident ESKD. However, the genetic risk of CKD was significantly associated with lower alcohol use, suggesting reverse causation.

Gallstone disease (GSD) is associated with a higher risk of gastrointestinal (GI) cancer. However, it is unclear whether the associations are causal.

Blood homocysteine level and related vitamin levels are associated with various health outcomes. We aimed to assess causal effects of blood homocy Steine, folate, and cobalamin on kidney function in the general population by performing Mendelian randomization analysis.

Physical activity and television watching affect kidney function in the general population. A higher degree of moderate-to-vigorous physical activity was associated with a higher eGFR. A longer time spent watching television was significantly associated with higher prevalence of CKD. The other sedentary behaviors yielded inconsistent results.

Genetic instruments for positive affect, life satisfaction, depressive symptoms, and neuroticism were introduced from a previous genome-wide association study meta-analysis of European individuals. In summary-level MR with the CKDGen data, depressive Symptoms were a significant causative factor for kidney function impairment. A genetic predisposition for positive Affect was significantly associated with better kidney function.

Study was an observational cohort study mainly based on the UK Biobank. Median relative macronutrient intake composition at baseline was 35% fats, 15% protein, and 50% carbohydrates. Higher relative protein intake was significantly associated with a lower risk of incident ESKD.

We aimed to investigate the causal effects of n-3 and n-6 polyunsaturated fatty acids (PUFAs) on the risk of coronary artery disease (CAD) through Mendelian randomization (MR) analysis. Higher genetically predicted eicosapentaenoic acid and dihomo-gamma-linolenic acid levels were significantly associated with a lower risk of CAD both in the allele-score-based and summary-level MR analyses.

Study comprised 1,211 European participants tested positive for severe acute respiratory syndrome coronavirus 2 (SARS-CoV-2) and 387,079 participants who were either untested or tested negative between 16 March 2020 to 31 May 2020. Higher BMI, WC, HbA1c and lower HDL-cholesterol were associated with higher odds of COVID-19 infection.

As adult height is linked to various health outcomes, further investigation of its causal effects on kidney function later in life is warranted. This study involved a cross-sectional observational analysis and summary-level Mendelian randomization (MR) analysis.

Obesity traits are causally implicated with risk of cardiometabolic diseases. It remains unclear whether there are similar causal effects of obesity traits on other non-communicable diseases. We constructed sex-specific genetic risk scores (GRS) for three obesity traits.

We studied 493 280 UK residents enrolled in the UK Biobank cohort study. Of 27 729 deaths, 20.4% were primarily attributed to CVD, 53.6% to cancer and 5.0% to infection. As cardiovascular multimorbidity increased, the proportion of cardiovascular and infection-related deaths was greater.

The gastric epithelium is often exposed to injurious elements. Failure of appropriate healing predisposes to ulcers, hemorrhage, and ultimately cancer. CD36 expresses on corpus ECs, on PC basolateral membranes, and in gastrin and ghrelin cells.

Study followed 130,473 UK Biobank participants aged 60-69 y (baseline 2006-2010) for &#8804;8.3 y ( n  = 2974 deaths) Current smokers and individuals with recent or disease-associated weight loss were excluded, yielding a "healthier agers" group. Being overweight with a higher WHR was associated with substantial excess mortality.

Commuters were selected from the UK Biobank cohort if they completed assessment centre visits between 2006 and 2016. Participants were categorised as 'inactive' (car only) or 'active' commuters (any other mode(s), including walking, cycling and public transport). Transitions between categories were defined between pairs of visits.

Asthma is a complex disease that is reportedly associated with insomnia. However, the causal directionality of this association is still unclear. We used asthma and insomnia-associated single nucleotide polymorphisms (SNPs) and genome-wide association study (GWAS) summary statistics.

Liver fat was able to be measured as the MRI proton density fat fraction (PDFF) with an overall success rate of 96.4%. The overall hepatic fat distribution was centred between 1-2%, and was highly skewed towards higher fat content. The mean PDFF was 3.91%, and median 2.11%.

It is thought that alcohol intake and body mass index (BMI) interact supra-additively to modulate the risk of cirrhosis, but evidence for this phenomenon is limited. We investigated the interrelationship between alcohol and BMI on the incidence of Cirrhosis morbidity for participants of the United Kingdom Biobank study.

Characteristics of the environment influence health and may promote physical activity. We explored the associations between neighborhood environmental characteristics and physical activity in adults from UK Biobank. We found participants living in areas with higher concentrations of air pollution recorded and reported lower levels of physical activity and those in rural areas and more walkable areas had higher levels of activity.

Atypical depression (AD) characterized by reversed neurovegetative symptoms is associated with a more pernicious course and a different sociodemographic, lifestyle, and comorbidity profile. AD was associated with female gender, unhealthy behaviours, more lifetime deprivation and adversity, higher rates of psychiatric disorders and obesity.

The ABO gene contains three major alleles that encodes different antigens; A, B, and O, which determine an individual's blood group. Previous studies have primarily focused on identifying associations between ABO blood groups and diseases risk. Here, we sought to test for association between A BO genotypes and a large set of common inflammatory and cardiovascular diseases.

UK Biobank participants of White ethnicity aged 40-69 years old underwent autorefraction. Logistic regression analysis was used to calculate the odds ratio (OR) for myopia or high myopia associated with a diagnosis before age 17 years of each of nine febrile illnesses.

Higher childhood body mass index (BMI) has been associated with an increased risk of multiple sclerosis (MS) We examined whether childhood BMI has a causal influence on MS, and whether this putative effect is independent from early adult obesity and pubertal timing. Findings were replicated using the UK Biobank.

Autistic individuals experience significantly elevated rates of childhood trauma, self-harm and suicidal behaviour and ideation. Is this purely the result of negative environmental experiences, or does this interact with genetic predisposition? In this study we investigated if a genetic predis position for autism is associated with childhood trauma using polygenic scores.

Haematopoietic clones with acquired mutations become common with advancing age and can lead to blood cancers1-10. In this long-lived Japanese population, mosaic chromosomal alterations were detected in more than 35.0% (s.m., 1.4%) of individuals older than 90 years. Three different mutational precursors of chronic lymphocytic leukaemia (including trisomy 12, loss of chromosomes 13q and 13q, and copy-neutral loss of heterozygosity) were between two and six times less common among Japanese individuals.

Spontaneous coronary artery dissection (SCAD) is a non-atherosclerotic cause of myocardial infarction (MI) typically in young women. We undertook a genome-wide association study of SCAD (Ncases = 270/Ncontrols = 5,263) and identified an association of rs12740679 at chromosome 1q21.2.

Diurnal preference for evening time has been associated with increased odds for current depression and a number of indices of the disorder. Previous work has also suggested that larger hippocampal volume may be protective against depression.

The study sample was a subset of the UK Biobank Resource, 164,770 adults aged between 40 and 69 years. Hearing loss was defined as speech recognition in noise in the better ear poorer than 2 standard deviations below the mean. Current smokers were more likely to have a hearing loss than non-smokers. For both smoking and passive smoking, there was evidence of a dose-response effect.

Elevated CRP levels were associated with a 22% increased lung cancer risk per 1 SD increase. Positive associations were observed in small cell lung cancer. When added to a risk model of lung cancer, CRP improved the performance of model as long as 8 years among current smokers.

Insulin-like growth factor-1 (IGF-1) has been implicated in several malignancies. Few studies have examined multiple cancers simultaneously. We conducted a prospective analysis between IGF-1 and incident total and 19 site-specific cancers among 412,645 individuals.

There is strong epidemiological evidence that circulating insulin-like growth factor-I is associated with a higher risk of several cancers. Little is known about its association with non-cancer outcomes. We investigated associations of circulating IGF-I with risk of 25 common conditions, other than cancer, in a large British cohort.

Insulin-like growth factor-I (IGF-I) and testosterone have been implicated in prostate cancer aetiology. We investigated the associations of circulating IGF-I, sex hormone-binding globulin (SHBG), and total and calculated free testosterone concentrations with prostate cancer incidence and mortality. For prospective analyses, risk was estimated using multivariable-adjusted Cox regression in 199 698 male UK Biobank participants.

 Epidemiologic studies evaluating associations between sex steroid hormones and colorectal cancer risk have yielded inconsistent results. To elucidate the role of circulating levels of testosterone, and sex hormone-binding globulin (SHBG), we conducted observational and Mendelian randomization (MR) analyses. In the observational analysis, there was little evidence that total testosterone was associated with cancer risk.

Evidence is mixed on whether cholesterol plays a role in the pathogenesis of glioma. We explored the associations between circulating lipids and gli cancer risk in three prospective cohorts.

This study investigated the causal relation between circulating phylloquinone (vitamin K 1 ) concentrations and type 2 diabetes. We used data from three studies: the European Prospective Investigation into Cancer and Nutrition (EPIC)-InterAct case-cohort study, Diabetes Genetics Replication and Meta-analysis (DIAGRAM) and the UK Biobank.

Gastrointestinal cancers show an unexplained male predominance. Few prospective studies have investigated sex hormones and gastrointestinal cancer risk. This study aimed to determine the impact of circulating sex hormones on risk of esophageal, gastric, and colorectal cancers in men and women.

Circulating vitamin C concentrations have been associated with several cancers. Little is known about the causal direction of the associations. This study aims to explore the potential causal relationship between circulating vitamin C and risk of five most common cancers in Europe.

 Observational studies strongly supported the association of low levels of circulating 25-hydroxyvitamin D (25OHD) and cognitive impairment or dementia in aging populations. However, randomized controlled trials have not shown clear evidence that vitamin D supplementation could improve cognitive outcomes.

Breast cancer is the most common solid organ malignancy and most frequent cause of cancer death among women worldwide. Previous research has yielded insights into its genetic etiology, but there remains a gap in the understanding of genetic factors that contribute to risk. National Cancer Institute's "Up for a Challenge" competition provided an opportunity to further elucidate the genetic basis of the disease.

Non-melanoma skin cancer (NMSC) incidence has been dramatically increasing worldwide. Psoralen, a known photocarcinogen, is naturally abundant in citrus products. High citrus consumption was not associated with an increased risk of NMSC in our UKBB sample.

High citrus consumption may increase melanoma risk. Little is known about the biological mechanisms of this association, or whether it is modified by genetic variants. We conducted a genome-wide analysis of gene-citrus consumption interactions.

Hearing relies on mechanically gated ion channels present in actin-rich stereocilia bundles at the apical surface of cochlear hair cells. Clrn2 clarinet/clarinet mice exhibit a progressive, early-onset hearing loss, with no overt retinal deficits.

Liver dysfunction, growth hormone and testosterone deficiency, innate immunity, anemia, macrocytosis, and insulin resistance were associated with MDD incidence in a large community-based cohort. All 30 significant associations with extreme laboratory test results were directionally consistent with an increased MDD risk.

Covid-19 has rapidly infected millions of people worldwide. Recent studies suggest that racial minorities and patients with comorbidities are at higher risk. In this study, we analyzed the effects of clinical, regional, and genetic factors on Covid- 19 positive status.

We sought to determine the relationship between age-related clonal hematopoiesis (CH) and chronic kidney disease (CKD) CH, defined as mosaic chromosome abnormalities (mCA) and/or driver mutations, was identified in 5449 (2.9%) eligible UK Biobank participants. CH was negatively associated with glomerular filtration rate estimated from cystatin-C (eGFR.cys; &#946; = -0.75, P = 2.37 Ã— 10-4)

There are few examples of robust associations between rare copy number variants (CNVs) and complex continuous human traits. We present a large-scale CNV association meta-analysis on anthropometric traits in up to 191,161 adult samples from 26 cohorts. The study reveals five CNV associations at 1q21.1, 3q29, 7q11.23, 11p14.2, and 18q 21.32. The discovered CNVs are recurrent and rare (0.01-0.2%), with large effects on height, weight, and body mass index.

Coffee and tea are the major contributors of caffeine in the diet. Evidence points to the premise that caffeine may benefit cognition. We examined the associations of habitual regular coffee or tea and caffeine intake with cognitive function whilst additionally accounting for genetic variation in caffeine metabolism.

UK Biobank captured self-reported coffee consumption and cancer-registry recorded incident digestive cancers. Risk of every type of digestive cancer was investigated in association with coffee consumption by dose-response and by coffee type.

This study examines the causal genetic associations between cognitive ability and physical health. BMI, systolic blood pressure, coronary artery disease and type 2 diabetes showed negative associations with cognitive ability. Higher educational attainment predicted lower BMI and higher blood pressure. The lack of evidence for causal associations could be explained by weak instrumental variables.

Rare copy number variants (CNVs) are associated with risk of neurodevelopmental disorders. These include schizophrenia, autism spectrum disorder and intellectual disability. The effects of many individual CNVs in carriers without neuro developmental disorders are not yet fully understood.

The UK Biobank is a large-scale biomedical resource, containing sociodemographic and medical information. We identified participants who either self-reported or were identified from a nurse-led interview, having suffered a stroke or a TIA. Hypertension, smoking, higher WHR, lower alcohol consumption and diabetes were all more common in people with cerebrovascular disease.

Collider bias can induce associations between two or more variables which affect the likelihood of an individual being sampled. The optimal way to mitigate the problem is to use appropriate sampling strategies at the study design stage.

Previous studies using additive genetic models failed to identify robust evidence of associations between colorectal cancer risk variants and survival outcomes. Here, we tested all currently known CRC-risk variants in a discovery analysis of 5675 patients from a Scottish cohort. We found that the TT genotype of the intron variant rs7495132 in the CRTC3 gene was associated with poorer CRC-specific survival.

Body mass index (BMI) and waist circumference (WC) are measures of general and central obesity, respectively. Both have been shown to be associated with cancer. However, there is insufficient evidence of their combined association with the risk of cancer.

Prostate cancer is known to have a strong genetic basis and is influenced by both common and rare variants. We conducted an investigation of 81 094 men from the UK Biobank, including 3568 prostate cancer cases. The absolute risk of prostate cancer for HOXB13, BRCA2, ATM, and CHEK2 P/LP/D carriers ranged from 9% to 56%.

A genetic risk score (GRS) for fatty liver disease influences the risk of cirrhosis and hepatocellular carcinoma (HCC) Three genetic variants were combined into a risk score ranging from 0 to 6 for risk-increasing alleles. A higher GRS was associated with an increase in plasma alanine aminotransferase (ALT) level of 26% in those with score 5 or 6.

Atrial fibrillation (AF) is associated with a five-fold increased risk of ischemic stroke. Current risk stratification tools (CHA 2 DS 2 -VASc) do not include family history or genetic risk. We hypothesized that we could improve stroke prediction in patients with AF by incorporating polygenic risk scores.

Polygenic risk scores (PRS) may soon be used to predict inflammatory bowel disease (IBD) risk in prevention efforts. We leveraged exome-sequence and single nucleotide polymorphism (SNP) array data from 29,358 individuals in the multiethnic, randomly ascertained health system-based BioMe biobank. Lower predictive power for non-Europeans was observed.

Aspirin and ibuprofen have been reported to reduce the mortality rate. Omeprazole can increase mortality. The FDA has approved only one drug, remdesivir, for the treatment of COVID-19.

Diseases with the same onset profile are genetically more similar. This similarity was not explained by disease categories, co-occurrences or disease cause-effect relationships. Two of the four disease clusters had an increased risk of occurrence from ages 20 and 40.

A prolonged T-peak-to-Tend (Tpe) interval on the electrocardiogram is an independent predictor of increased arrhythmic risk. Tpe changes with heart rate are even stronger predictors. We identify 32 loci for resting Tpe and 3 for Tpe response to exercise and recovery. Sex-specific analyses indicated seven additional loci.

Genome-wide association studies (GWAS) have identified 190 loci associated with maternal or fetal effects on birth weight. Numerous monogenic developmental syndromes are associated with birth weights at the extreme ends of the distribution. We found birth weight GWAS single nucleotide polymorphisms (SNPs) fall closer to such genes than expected.

We analyzed the effects of the common BMI-increasing melanocortin 4 receptor (MC4R) rs17782313-C allele with a minor allele frequency of 0.22-0.25 on cardiovascular disease outcomes. We additionally analyzed whether potential associations were modified by sex or explained by changes in body mass index. We confirmed the BMI- Increasing effects of +0.22 kg/m 2 per additional copy of the C allele.

Drugs used for nervous system disorders were associated with poorer cognitive performance. Drugs used for non-nervous system conditions also showed significant negative association with cognitive score. Only a few medications and health supplements showed association towards a positive effect on cognitive function.

The National Health Service England classifies individuals as eligible for lung cancer screening using two risk prediction models, PLCOm2012 and Liverpool Lung Project-v2. No study has compared the performance of lung cancer risk models in the UK.

We developed a central processing and graphics processing unit (CPU and GPU) accelerated Fast and Powerful Heritability Inference (FPHI) approach that linearizes likelihood calculations. We calculated for 60 regional and 1.3 Ã— 10 5 voxel-wise traits in N = 1,206 twin and sibling participants from the Human Connectome Project.

Polygenic scores now explain approximately 10% of the variation in educational attainment. This is because of passive gene-environment correlation, whereby the correlation between offspring and parent genotypes results in an association between offspring genotypes and the rearing environment. Adoptees' genotypes were less correlated with their rearing environments because they did not share genes with their adoptive parents.

Accurate estimation of genetic correlation requires large sample sizes and access to genetically informative data, which are not always available. Cheverud's conjecture asserts that the use of phenotypic correlations as proxies for genetic correlations is appropriate. Empirical evidence of the conjecture has been found across plant and animal species.

The Regional Vulnerability Index (RVI) was developed toquantify brain similarity by comparing individual white matter microstructure, cortical gray matter thickness and subcortical gray matter structural volume measures. We tested the specificity of the RVI approach for major depressive disorder (MDD) and Alzheimer's disease (AD)

The UK Biobank cohort is a population-based cohort of 500,000 participants recruited in the United Kingdom between 2006 and 2010. Compared with the general population, participants were less likely to be obese, to smoke, and to drink alcohol on a daily basis. At age 70-74 years, rates of all-cause mortality and total cancer incidence were 46.2% and 11.8% lower, respectively, in men and 55.1% lower in women.

Of UK Biobank participants included, 802 were admitted to hospital with and/or died from COVID19 (323 deaths and 479 hospitalisations) After analyses were adjusted for sociodemographic and lifestyle factors, a higher risk of COVID-19 was observed for pre-frail and frail individuals compared to those classified as robust.

Population-based biobanks provide opportunities for generating effective therapeutic hypotheses and understanding the genomic role in disease predisposition. We apply truncated singular value decomposition (DeGAs) to matrices of summary statistics derived from genome-wide association analyses across 2,138 phenotypes measured in 337,199 White British individuals in the UK Biobank study. We systematically identify key components of genetic associations and contributions of variants, genes, and phenotypes.

Obesity is a major risk factor for a wide range of cardiometabolic diseases. The impact of specific aspects of body morphology remains poorly understood. We combined the GWAS summary statistics of fourteen anthropometric traits from UK Biobank through principal component analysis.

Multiple genes have been associated with monogenic Parkinson's disease and Parkinsonism syndromes. Mutations in PINK1 (PARK6) have been shown to result in autosomal recessive early-onset Parkinson's Disease. In the past decade, several studies have suggested that carrying a single heterozygous Pink1 mutation is associated with increased risk for Parkinson's.

Circulating biomarkers have been previously associated with atherosclerosis-related risk factors, but the nature of these associations is incompletely understood. We found a total of 15, 9, 21, 22, 26, 24, and 26 biomarkers strongly associated with coronary artery disease, ischemic stroke, atrial fibrillation, type 2 diabetes, systolic blood pressure, body mass index, and waist-to-hip ratio.

Open-science and team-based scientific discovery offer hope for tackling some of the difficult challenges associated with managing, modeling, and interpreting of large, complex, and multisource data. Translating raw observations into useful information and actionable knowledge depends on effective domain-independent reproducibility, area-specific replicability, data curation, analysis protocols, and organization.

 REGENIE is a novel machine-learning method for fitting a whole-genome regression model. It is substantially faster than alternatives in multi-trait analyses while maintaining statistical efficiency. We demonstrate the accuracy and computational benefits of this approach using the UK Biobank dataset.

Jian Yang and colleagues explore the uses and abuses of heritability estimates derived from pedigrees and from GWAS SNPs. They make recommendations for best practice in future applications of SNP-based heritability.

Spatial Confidence Sets (CSs) on clusters found in thresholded Cohen's d effect size images. CSs convey information about magnitude and reliability of effect sizes that is usually given separately in a t-statistic and effect estimate map.

Dealing with confounds is an essential step in large cohort studies to address problems such as unexplained variance and spurious correlations. UK Biobank is a powerful resource for studying associations between imaging and non-imaging measures.

Previous studies have revealed the involvement of coffee and tea in the development of stroke and dementia. Little is known about the association between coffee/tea consumption and the risk of stroke, dementia, and poststroke dementia. This prospective cohort study included 365,682 participants from the UK Biobank.

Genomic contribution to adverse health sequelae in babies born very preterm. We studied 488 parent-offspring trios using Illumina Infinium OmniExpress Arrays. We identified 14 de novo CNVs, representing a mutation rate of 2.9%.

Visceral adipose tissue (VAT) has been suggested as an independent risk factor for cardiovascular and metabolic disease. Yet the contribution of genetics to VAT, as well as its disease-related effects, are largely unexplored. Here, we develop sex-stratified, nonlinear prediction models for VAT mass using the UK Biobank cohort. Predicted VAT mass was associated with increased risk of hypertension, heart attack/angina, type 2 diabetes and hyperlipidemia.

South Asians had a higher risk for CVD mortality (HR: 1.42, 95% CI 1.07 to 1.89) and incidence, but a decreased risk for cancer mortality. Compared with individuals without T2D, both white Europeans and South Asians with T2d had aHigher risk for all-cause mortality (1.59) and CVD incidence and mortality.

Major depressive disorder emerges from the complex interactions of biological systems that span genes and molecules through cells, networks, and behavior. Establishing how neurobiological processes coalesce to contribute to depression requires a multiscale approach. We examine anatomical and functional correlates of depression and negative affect across three population-imaging datasets.

Classic LMMs assume independence between random effects, which can be violated, causing bias. We introduce a generalized GREML that explicitly estimates the covariance betweenRandom effects. CORE GREML outperforms the conventional GREML, providing variance estimates free from bias due to correlated random effects.

Hearing impairment is ranked fifth globally for years lived with disability. Yet hearing aid use is low among individuals with a hearing impairment. No studies have investigated a wide range of variables, this has limited intervention development.

The extent of major health consequences of COVID-19 is unclear, including risks of severe secondary infections. We conducted a matched cohort study based on 445,845 UK Biobank participants registered in England. Life-threatening secondary infections were defined as diagnoses of severesecondary infections with high mortality rates. The follow-up period was limited to 3 months after the initial CO VID-19 diagnosis.

SARS-CoV-2 is known to preferentially target older subjects and those with pre-existing conditions. Case fatality rate for COVID-19 grows exponentially with age in all countries tested.

Most studies of severe/fatal COVID-19 risk have used routine/hospitalisation data without detailed pre-morbid characterisation. We investigated demographic, social (education, income, housing, employment), lifestyle (smoking, drinking, body mass index), biological (lipids, cystatin C, vitamin D), medical (comorbidities, medications) and environmental (air pollution) data from UK Biobank. Age, male sex and Black ethnicity, as well as comorbidity and oral steroid use at enrolment were associated with increased risk of death.

Genome-wide association studies have identified several loci associated with increased susceptibility and severity for COVID-19. However, it is not clear whether these associations are genetically determined or not. We used a Phenome-Wide Association (PheWAS) approach to investigate the role of genetically determined CO VID-19 susceptibility on disease related outcomes.

Excessive alcohol intake is associated with 5.9% of global deaths. 7.6% of deaths can be attributed to alcohol intake. Previous studies identified a significant interaction between genotypes of the galanin (GAL) gene with anxiety and alcohol abuse in different male populations.

We conducted a phenome-wide analysis of loci with heterogeneous effects across African, Admixed-American, Central/South Asian, East Asian, European and Middle Eastern participants. We identified 82 independent genomic regions mapping variants showing genome-wide significant (GWS) associations.

We investigate polygenic risk score (PRS)-specific pleiotropy across 16 cancers in European ancestry individuals. Two pairs show bidirectional associations; the melanoma PRS is positively associated with oral cavity/pharyngeal cancer and vice versa.

Active living approaches seek to promote physical activity and reduce sedentary time across different domains. There is little information on how movement behaviours in different domains relate to each other. We used compositional data analysis to explore associations between active commuting and patterns of movement behaviour during discretionary time.

Higher waist-to-hip ratio and BMI are independently positively associated with albuminuria. Adiposity-albuminuria associations appear strong among people with normal HbA1c, as well as people with pre-diabetes or diabetes.

People with 'CVD' or 'Type 2 diabetes + CVD' more likely to report simultaneous low physical activity, high TV viewing and poor sleep duration than those without disease. Non-diet behaviours were clustered, with people with CVD and Type 2 diabetes changing their diet in the past 5 years.

Genetic and hormonal factors have been suggested to influence human sexual orientation. Previous studied proposed brain differences related to sexual orientation and that these follow cross-sex shifted patterns. How genetic factors relate to brain structural variation remains largely unexplored.

Mapping gene-by-sex (GÃ—S) interactions remains a challenge likely because the magnitude of such an interaction is typically and exceedingly small. Traditional genome-wide association techniques may be underpowered to detect such events, due partly to the burden of multiple test correction. Here, we developed a local Bayesian regression (LBR) method to estimate sex-specific SNP marker effects.

Efforts to link variation in the human genome to phenotypes have progressed at a tremendous pace in recent decades. We discuss the natural next steps in data collection and methodology development. We focus on what can be gained by analyzing genotype and phenotype data from close relatives.

Segmenting anatomical structures in medical images has been successfully addressed with deep learning methods for a range of applications. However, this success is heavily dependent on the quality of the image that is being segmented. A commonly neglected point in the medical image analysis community is the vast amount of clinical images that have severe image artefacts.

 Classification of whole-brain functional connectivity MRI data with convolutional neural networks (CNNs) has shown promise, but the complexity of these models impedes understanding which aspects of brain activity contribute to classification. We introduce a stochastic encoding method in an ensemble of CNNs to classify functional connectomes by sex.

Study used whole-body magnetic resonance (MR) images from UK Biobank (UKBB) and German National Cohort (GNC) MR imaging studies. Liver, spleen, left and right kidney, and pancreas were segmented manually on all 400 data sets, providing labeled ground truth data for training of deep learning models.

There is significant interest in the development and application of deep neural networks (DNNs) to neuroimaging data. Here, we compared the performance of three DNNs and a classical machine learning algorithm ( kernel regression) in predicting phenotypes from whole-brain resting-state functional connectivity (RSFC) patterns.

Dementia has been associated with COVID-19 prevalence, but whether this reflects higher infection, older age of patients, or disease severity remains unclear. We investigated a cohort of 12,863 UK Biobank community-dwelling individuals > 65 years old.

Vitamin B6, B12, and folate have an effect on brain structure, especially among depressed people who follow a specific diet. Depression was more prevalent, and intake of vitamin B6 and B12 was lower among vegetarians, while non-vegetarians had a lower intake of folate. Vitamin B12 intake was positively associated with right pallidum.

Study used data on 251,125 individuals of white British ancestry from the UK Biobank. Found observational and genetic evidence for an association between depression and BMI. Carrying 10 additional BMI increasing alleles was associated with 0.24 standard deviation (SD) higher BMI among depressed individuals compared to 0.20 SD (95%CI 0.19-0.21) in controls.

Study employed data from 502,641 participants in the UK Biobank. Out of 58,833 participants with asthma and 13,462 with AD, the prevalence of DAS was 11.7% and 2.7%. DAS increased among participants with either asthma or AD, being highest within patients having both. Asthma and AD were associated with increased DAS during mid-adult years.

Abdominal aortic aneurysm (AAA) can occur in patients who are ineligible for routine ultrasound screening. A simple AAA risk score was derived and compared with current guidelines used for ultrasound screening of AAA. Components of the risk score were age, weight, antihypertensive and cholesterol-lowering medication use, height and diastolic blood pressure.

UK Biobank study collected detailed dietary data using a web-based self-administered 24 h assessment tool, the Oxford WebQ. Top contributors to energy, saturated fat, and free sugars were broadly similar by sex and education category. Wine, beer, and fruit juices were the top beverage contributors to overall energy intake.

Oxford WebQ is a web-based 24-h dietary assessment method used in UK Biobank. The food composition table used to calculate nutrient intakes has been replaced with the UK Nutrient Databank. 35 new nutrients were incorporated in the updated version.

We scanned for deviations in chromosome X genotyping array intensity data in a population-based survey of 196,219 UK Biobank men. We detected 12 (0.006%) men with mosaic chromosome X gains &#8805; 2 Mb and found no evidence for mosaic X loss. This level of detection substantially lower than for autosomes or other sex chromosomes.

Mendelian randomization (MR) has developed into an established method for strengthening causal inference and estimating causal effects. However, genetic instruments remain controversial, as horizontal pleiotropic effects can introduce bias into causal estimates. We introduce MR using Gene-by-Environment interactions (MRGxE) as a framework capable of identifying and correcting for pleiotsropic bias.

Heterogeneity in the phenotypic mean and variance across populations is often observed for complex traits. Here, we introduce a novel concept of genotype-by-population (G Ã— P) interaction where population is defined by the first and second ancestry principal components (PCs) We applied a reaction norm model fitting each of 70 complex traits with significant SNP-heritability.

 Parkinson's disease (PD) is a chronic movement disorder that produces a variety of characteristic movement abnormalities. The ubiquity of wrist-worn accelerometry suggests a possible sensor modality for early detection of PD symptoms and subsequent tracking of PD symptom severity.

New method, Ward clustering, identifies Internal Node branch length outliers using Gene Scores. The objective of WINGS is to identify groups of phenotypes, or "clusters," sharing a core set of genes enriched for mutations in cases.

Hundreds of thousands of genetic variants have been reported to cause severe monogenic diseases. The probability that a variant carrier develops the disease (termed penetrance) is unknown for virtually all of them. The clinical utility of common polygenetic variation remains uncertain.

Previously generated genetic risk scores (GRSs) for type 1 diabetes (T1D) have not captured all known information at non-HLA loci or, particularly, at HLA risk loci. We aimed to more completely incorporate HLA alleles, their interactions, and recently discovered non- HLA locs into an improved T1D GRS. The improved GRS, the T1d GRS2, is highly useful for classifying adult incident diabetes type and improving newborn screening.

Head and neck cancer (HNC) is the eighth most common cancer in the UK. Over 12,000 new cases every year. The incidence of HNC is predicted to increase by 33% by 2035. Risk modelling produces personalised risk estimates for specific diseases.

Esophageal squamous cell carcinoma (ESCC) carries a poor prognosis, but earlier tumor detection would improve survival. We aimed to develop and externally validate a risk prediction model based on exposure to readily available risk factors to identify high-risk individuals. Candidate predictors were age, sex, tobacco smoking, alcohol consumption, body mass index (BMI), education, cohabitation, physical exercise, and employment.

Risk prediction models for a range of heterogeneous CVDs, including coronary artery disease (CAD), stroke, deep vein thrombosis (DVT), and abdominal aortic aneurysm (AAA) The models incorporate various blood biomarkers and comorbidities to improve both individual and population stratification.

 multivariable risk prediction models have been developed to asses an individual's risk of developing specific cancers. Such models can be used in a variety of settings for prevention, screening, and guiding investigations and treatments.

Dietary interventions might have potential to protect against age-related cognitive decline and neurodegeneration. There are associations between some nutrients, food groups, dietary patterns, and some domains of cognition. We observed associations between better general cognitive ability and higher intakes of fish, and unprocessed red meat; and moderate intakes of fibre, and milk.

A total of 416,588 participants (54% women) from the UK Biobank were included in the present study. High intake of red meat and processed meat was associated with an increased risk of lung cancer. However, the consumption of fruits, vegetables, breakfast cereals, and dietary fiber was inversely associated with the risk.

UK Biobank recruited 77 004 men and women between 2006 and 2010. Dietary intake (Oxford WebQ) was used to calculate Recommended Food Score (RFS), Healthy Diet Indicator (HDI) and Mediterranean Diet Score (MDS) Higher RFS was also associated with lower risk of CVD mortality and MI.

Disinhibition is a prominent feature of multiple psychiatric disorders. It has been associated with poor long-term somatic outcomes. Modifiable lifestyle factors including diet and moderate-to-vigorous physical activity (MVPA) may be associated with disinhibition. Their contributions have not previously been quantified among middle-aged/older adults.

UK Biobank is an open access prospective cohort of 500 000 men and women. Information on the frequency of consumption of main foods was collected at recruitment with a touchscreen questionnaire. The objectives of the present paper are to describe the repeatability of the touchscreen questionnaire in participants.

The 93-single-nucleotide polymorphism (SNP) GPRS was associated with a higher BMI. The findings were broadly similar using WC as the outcome. These data suggest that the benefits of reducing the intake of fats may be more important in individuals with high genetic risk for obesity.

Study investigated 105,592 participants (47,308 men and 58,284 women) aged &#8805; 40 years. Dietary intake of total fatty acids, polyunsaturated fatty acids and saturated fatty acids was assessed at baseline. Over a median follow-up of 3.2 years, 832 men and 872 women developed disabling hearing impairment.

Few population-based studies of dietary habits have assessed depression and fluid intelligence. In total, 814 independent loci were utilized to calculate the individual polygenic risk score (PRS) for 143 dietary habit-related traits. For interaction analysis, we detected that OLFM1 interacted with champagne/white wine in depression, while  SYNPO2 interacted with coffee type in fluid Intelligence.

Low-carbohydrate diets are becoming increasingly popular, although their dietary quality outside of clinical studies is unknown. Both NCHO and LCHO groups consumed significantly more high-sugar, high-fat snacks.

Vegetarian diets are defined by the absence of meat and fish. Differences in the intake of other foods between meat-eaters and low or non-meat eaters are also important to document. We examined intakes of high-protein foods (meat, poultry, fish, legumes, nuts, vegetarian protein alternatives, dairy products, and eggs)

Dietary magnesium is integral to bone and muscle physiology. Relationship between magnesium and skeletal muscle and bone health has not been investigated concurrently to date. We analysed cross-sectional associations between dietary magnesium and muscle mass, grip strength, and bone density.

The fat type consumed is considered a risk factor for developing obesity and type 2 diabetes (T2D) This study aimed to investigate associations between dietary patterns with varying proportions of SFAs, MUFAs, or PUFAs and obesity, abdominal obesity, and self-reported T2D incidence. Two dietary patterns, DP1 and DP2, were identified.

Dietary intake and blood concentrations of vitamins E and C, lycopene, and carotenoids have been associated with a lower risk of incident (ischemic) stroke. Here, we investigated the associations between genetically influenced antioxidant levels in blood and ischemic stroke using Mendelian randomization. For absolute antioxidants levels, the odds ratios (ORs) ranged between 0.94 (95% CI, 0.85-1.05) for vitamin C. For metabolites, ORs ranged between 1.01 ( 95% CI,. 0.98-1,03) for retinol and 1.12 (95! CI,0.88- 1.42) for Vitamin E.

Diffusion weighted imaging (DWI) is a widely recognized neuroimaging technique to evaluate the microstructure of brain white matter. The objective of this study is to establish an improved automated DWI marker for estimating white matter integrity and investigating ageing related cognitive decline. The concept of Wasserstein distance was introduced to help establish a new measure: difference in distribution functions (DDF)

The identification of robust endotypes-disease subgroups of clinical relevance-is fundamental to stratified medicine. We hypothesized that HLA-C&#8727;06:02 status is the major genetic determinant of psoriasis. We compared demographic, environmental, and clinical variables of interest with those in people with a negative HLA.

Resting-state functional magnetic resonance (rsfMRI) work has revealed changes in static connectivity related to age, sex, cognitive abilities and psychiatric symptoms. Little is known how these factors may alter the information flow. Dynamic graphical models (DGMs) can yield novel insight into directed functional connectivity.

The diversity in our genome is crucial to understanding the demographic history of worldwide populations. We have yet to know whether subtle genetic differences within a population can be disentangled. Here we apply dimensionality reduction methods to biobank-derived genomic data of a Japanese population.

Brain activity is a dynamic combination of the responses to sensory inputs and its own spontaneous processing. Such brain activity is continuously changing whether or not one is focusing on an externally imposed task. Previously, we have introduced an analysis method that allows us to model task or rest brain activity as a dynamic sequence of distinct brain networks.

We conducted genome-wide association analyses of asthma and body mass index (BMI; weight (kg)/height (m)2) among 305,945 White British subjects recruited into the UK Biobank in 2006-2010. We identified a genome- wide-significant cross-phenotype association at rs705708 (asthma odds ratio = 1.05, 95% confidence interval: 1.03, 1.07; P = 7.20 Ã— 10-9; and BMI &#946; = -0.065, 95â€™s confidence intervals: 0.087, 0.042) The association resides on 12q13.2.

Genes underneath signals from genome-wide association studies (GWAS) for kidney function are promising targets for functional studies, but prioritizing variants and genes is challenging. By GWAS meta-analysis for creatinine-based estimated glomerular filtration rate (eGFR) from the Chronic Kidney Disease Genetics Consortium and UK Biobank (n = 1,201,909), we expand the number of eGFRcrea loci.

Body composition (fat, skeletal muscle and bone mass) is an important determinant of overall health and risk of endocrine disorders such as type 2 diabetes and osteoporosis. Although diet and physical activity are strongly implicated, body composition is also heritable. We conducted a discovery genome-wide association study on 31 phenotypes.

Study aims to discover new genetic loci associated with heart rate from Exome Chip meta-analyses. Heart rate measured from either elecrtrocardiograms or pulse recordings. Lead variants in four of the novel loci are non-synonymous variants in genes C10orf71, DALDR3, TESK2 and SEC31B.

24,130 patients diagnosed with depression were compared to 120,366 matched individuals without such a diagnosis. The median age at the time of the depression diagnosis was 62.0 years, and most of the patients were female (63.63%). 129 medical conditions were found to be significantly associated with a prior diagnosis of depression.

In midlife, transitions in social networks can relate to new leadership roles at work or becoming a caregiver for aging parents. Social behavior, personality predisposition, and demographic profile all have intimate links to the medial prefrontal cortex (mPFC)

Major depressive disorder (MDD) is characterized by low mood, psychomotor slowing and increased levels of the personality trait neuroticism. Factors also associated with schizophrenia (SCZ) It is possible that some cases of MDD may have a substantial genetic loading for SCZ. The presence of SCZ-like MDD subgroups would be indicated by an interaction between MDD status and polygenic risk ofSCZ on cognitive, personality and mood measures.

Clonal hematopoiesis (CH) results from somatic genomic alterations that drive clonal expansion of blood cells. Somatic gene mutations associated with hematologic malignancies have been associated with myeloid malignancy. mosaic chromosomal alterations (mCAs) associated with lymphoidmalignancies. These genetic alterations can be readily detected in clinical sequencing panels and used with blood count parameters to identify individuals at high risk.

Vitamin D status varied among different ethnic groups and by season and geographical area within the UK. Male sex, abnormal body mass index, non-white ethnic backgrounds, smoking and being more socioeconomically deprived were associated with higher odds of vitamin D deficiency. Increasing age, taking vitamin D supplements and drinking alcohol was associated with lower odds of deficiency. These findings support the vitamin D supplementation recommendations of Public Health England.

Physical activity is a critical component of overall health and quality of life. There is a natural decline in physical activity associated with the aging process. Establishing normative trends of physical activity in aging populations is essential to developing public health guidelines.

 Eveningness is associated with a number of negative health outcomes and risk and prevalence for psychiatric disorder. Our understanding of the anatomical substrates of diurnal preference is limited. The current study used Voxel-Based Morphometry to compare grey matter volume in a large sample of healthy adults.

A genetic predisposition to higher waist-to-hip ratio adjusted for BMI associates with increased risk for type 2 diabetes. We identified four variants in the gene ACVR1C which independently associated with reduced WHRadjBMI. Carriers of these variants exhibited reduced percent abdominal fat in DEXA imaging.

Osteoporosis is caused by an imbalance of osteoclasts and osteoblasts in the bone marrow. Recurrent somatic mutations that lead to an expanded population of mutant blood cells is termed clonal hematopoiesis of indeterminate potential (CHIP) We found CHIP to be associated with increased incident osteoporotic diagnoses and decreased bone mineral density.

Multiple sclerosis (MS) is a chronic autoimmune condition in which inflammation plays a central role that also affects the white matter. We used statistical genetics techniques to assess whether having genetically elevated white matter hyperintensity (WMH) volume was associated with increased MS risk. Whole genome analysis did not reveal any overlap of risk between the traits.

GPRS-obesity was associated with BMI (&#946;:0.54 kg.m-2 per standard deviation (SD) increase in GPRS, [95% CI: 0.53; 0.56]; P = 2.1 Ã— 10-241) among inactive individuals. There was a significant interaction between GPRs-ob obesity and objectively measured PA. No significant interactions were found for commuting mode (car, public transport, active commuters) The adiposity benefits of high PA and low sedentary behaviour may be particularly important in individuals with high genetic risk for obesity.

Major depressive disorder (MDD) is a heritable and highly debilitating condition. It is commonly associated with subcortical volumetric abnormalities, the most replicated of these being reduced hippocampal volume. In this study, we provide some evidence that hippocampusal volume and MDD may share genetic architecture in a subgroup of individuals.

Physical activity (PA) has beneficial effects on many alcohol related outcomes. Data suggest PA may offset the association between alcohol consumption and mortality. Study examined the joint associations of PA and alcohol on all-cause, CVD and cancer mortality.

We analysed the UK Biobank Cohort study linked to Hospital Episode Statistics. Surgery patients were matched with controls who did not have bariatric surgery. Annual and cumulative hospital costs were assessed for the surgery and control groups. Compared with controls, surgical patients had significantly higher inpatient expenditures.

In men, height was positively associated with incidence risk of all-cause cancer and at five sites. In women, it was associated with breast, melanoma, lymphatic, non-Hodgkin lymphoma and all- Cause cancer. The strength of the association did not differ by IGF-1 concentration.

TV viewing is associated with an increase in body mass index (BMI) as well as overall cardiovascular disease (CVD) risk. UK Biobank recruited across 35 centres in the UK between 2006 and 2010. Each additional hour of television viewing per day was associated with a 0.54 increase in BMI.

The incidence of thyroid cancer is rising, and relatively little is known about modifiable risk factors for the condition. Observational studies have suggested a link between adiposity and thyroid cancer, but these are subject to confounding and reverse causality. Here, we used data from the UK Biobank to investigate whether adiposity causes benign nodular thyroid disease and differentiated thyroid cancer.

Pregnancy history was reported by women participating in UK Biobank between 2006 and 2010 at age 40-69 years. Cardiac structure and function were assessed by magnetic resonance (CMR) steady-state free precession imaging at 1.5 Tesla. Carotid intima-media thickness (CIMT) measurements were taken for both common carotid arteries using a CardioHealth Station. No significant differences were evident in women who reported pregnancy loss compared to other groups.

Study looked at 279,030 participants from the UK Biobank. Handgrip strength and walking pace were the exposures. All-cause mortality, CVD mortality and incidence were the outcomes.

The study employed data from the UK Biobank participants: 495,327 in cross-sectional (2006-2010) and 16,875 in longitudinal (2014-2016) analyses. Musculoskeletal pain was diagnosed by the participants' reports of back, knee, hip, or neck/shoulder pain.

Fitness was estimated using a submaximal cycle ergometer test. All results were adjusted for sociodemographic, lifestyle and dietary factors, body composition, and morbidity at baseline. High level of fitness was associated with a greater incidence of atrial fibrillation and prostate cancer.

Every one mmol/mol increase in genetically proxied HbA1c was associated with an 11% higher CHD risk (HR 1.11, 95% CI 1.05, 1.18) There was no evidence favouring a non-linear relationship over a linear one. In individuals without diabetes mellitus, lowering average blood glucose levels may reduceCHD risk in a dose-dependent way.

The otherwise common HLA haplotype DR15-DQ6 is rare, and highly protective. Adult-onset type 1 diabetes is now known to represent more overall cases than childhood onset. We assessed the proportion of type 1. diabetes cases presenting through the first 50 years of life with DR15. DQ6 compared with population controls.

Over 500,000 participants were recruited to the UK Biobank cohort. Alcohol consumption was self-reported as pints beer/cider, glasses champagne/white wine, glasses of red wine, and measures of spirits per week. All-cause mortality, cardiovascular events, ischemic heart disease, cerebrovascular events, and cancer were studied.

 Pharmacogenetics studies how genetic variation leads to variability in drug response. Guidelines for selecting the right drug and right dose for patients based on their genetics are clinically effective, but are widely unused. Without measurements of genotype, physicians and patients may adjust dosage in a manner that reflects the underlying genetics.

UK Biobank is an international health resource enabling research into the genetic and lifestyle determinants of common diseases of middle and older age. Public Health England's Second Generation Surveillance System is a centralized microbiology database covering English clinical diagnostics laboratories.

Study looked at 334,507 white British participants from the UK Biobank cohort. Found that 1 additional year of education was significantly related to higher total amount of alcohol intake. Causal relations with total amount and frequency of alcohol drinking were more evident among women.

Colorectal cancer is a common malignancy worldwide. Physical activity and a healthy diet contribute to energy balance. We suggest that individual differences in energy balance can be explained by genetic polymorphisms involved in mitochondria.

Between 2006 and 2010, 357,419 participants with genetic and complete dietary data from the UK Biobank were enrolled and prospectively followed up to 2017. The genetic risk score (GRS) was calculated on the basis of 424 variants associated with T2D risk.

Study aimed to estimate the causal effect of education on refractive error using regression discontinuity analysis. The analysis sample comprised 21,548 UK Biobank participants born in a nine-year interval centered on September 1957. In OLS analysis, the ROSLA 1972 reform was associated with a -0.29 D.

Lead is pervasive, although lead exposure has fallen in response to public health efforts. Lead is positively associated with cardiovascular disease and hypertension. We used separate-sample instrumental variable analysis with genetic instruments.

Obesity may prevent people from being in paid work through poor health or through social discrimination. We studied genetic variants robustly associated with body mass index (BMI) to investigate its causal effects on employment. Socioeconomic indicators also investigated were hours worked, household income, educational attainment and Townsend deprivation index.

Mendelian randomization analyses were performed to infer phenome-wide effects of free testosterone on 461 outcomes in 161,268 males from the UK Biobank study. Lifelong increased free testosterone had beneficial effects on increased bone mineral density, and decreased body fat. It had adverse effects on decreased HDL, and increased risks of prostate cancer, androgenic alopecia, spinal stenosis, and hypertension.

Thyroid hormone is essential for optimal human neurodevelopment and may modify the risk of attention-deficit/hyperactivity disorder (ADHD) The brain structures involved are unknown and it is unclear if the adult brain is also susceptible to changes in thyroid status.

 Randomized trials of salt restriction have consistently demonstrated that decreasing salt consumption lowers blood pressure. Results of observational studies of salt intake and cardiovascular disease have been conflicting. We examined the within-person variability in spot urinary sodium excretion and its impact on associations with systolic blood pressure and risk of incident cardiovascular disease.

Existing statistical methods become rate limiting for large biobank-scale sequencing studies with correlated samples. We propose efficient Mixed-model Association tests for GEne-Environment interactions. The computational complexity is dramatically reduced in a whole genome GEI analysis.

There is an increasing need for conducting genetic genealogical searches efficiently. Computationally, this task amounts to identifying shared DNA segments between a query individual and a very large panel containing millions of haplotypes. The existing algorithm (Durbin's Algorithm 5) can only identify set-maximal matches.

In genome-wide association studies, ordinal categorical phenotypes are widely used to measure human behaviors, satisfaction, and preferences. We propose an efficient mixed model association test, proportional odds logistic mixed model (POLMM) POLMM is computationally efficient to analyze large datasets with hundreds of thousands of samples.

Polygenic risk scores are emerging as a potentially powerful tool to predict future phenotypes of target individuals. 5,000 individuals with first-degree relatives of target Individuals can achieve a prediction accuracy similar to that of around 220,000 unrelated individuals.

Principal component analysis (PCA) of genetic data is routinely used to infer ancestry and control for population structure in various genetic analyses. However, conducting PCA analyses can be complicated and has several potential pitfalls. These pitfalls include capturing linkage disequilibrium (LD) structure instead of population structure, and projected PCs that suffer from shrinkage bias.

Asthma is one of the most common chronic diseases affecting both children and adults. We report a genome-wide association meta-analysis of 69,189 cases and 702,199 controls. We find 88 asthma risk variants at 56 loci, 19 previously unreported.

Study looked at C-reactive protein (CRP), genetic, and phenotypic data from the UK Biobank. CRP levels were significantly higher in patients with depression relative to control subjects. The association between depression and increased CRP level was substantially reduced.

Anxiety and depression show substantial genetic overlap and share pharmacological treatments. We investigated self-reported current medication use in UK Biobank participants of European ancestry. Data on prescribed medication could be effective for inferring case status.

Hormone concentrations were measured in serum collected in 2006-2010, and in a repeat subsample (N ~ 5000) in 2012-13. Incident cancers were identified through data linkage. Cancer risk was positively associated with testosterone in post-menopausal women.

BRCA1/2 mutation carriers had a 2- to 3-fold increased risk for EC. Highest risk observed for the rare subgroups of serous-like and p53-abnormal EC in BRCa1 mutation carriers.

Data were obtained from 398 628 UK Biobank prospective cohort study participants (40-69 years) recruited between 2006 and 2010. Hazard ratios between 24-hour sodium excretion were estimated from spot urinary sodium concentrations across incident CVD and its components. In restricted cubic splines analyses, there was little evidence for an association. An inverse association was observed with heart failure, but that was no longer apparent.

Genomic structural equation modelling (SEM) outperforms the other methods in accurately estimating conditional genetic effects and their standard errors. We apply Genomic SEM to fertility data in the UK Biobank and partition the genetic effect into female and male fertility and a sibling specific effect. We identify a novel locus for fertility and genetic correlations between fertility and educational attainment.

Parental genetic effects may be defined as the influence of parental genotypes on offspring phenotypes over and above that which results from the transmission of genes from parents to their children. Given the relative paucity of large-scale family-based cohorts around the world, it is difficult to demonstrate parental genetic effects on human traits, particularly at individual loci. In this manuscript, we illustrate how parental. genetic effects can be estimated at individual Loci in principle using large.-scale genome-wide association study (GWAS) data.

The effective sample size (ESS) is a metric used to summarize in a single term the amount of correlation in a sample. It is of particular interest when predicting the statistical power of genome-wide association studies (GWAS) based on linear mixed models. We introduce an analytical form of the ESS for mixed-model GWAS of quantitative traits.

Study assesses evidence of causality for various CVDs in a 2-sample Mendelian randomization framework. Estimates potential reduction in the prevalence of these diseases attributable to long-term population shifts in systolic blood pressure (SBP)

Non-additive genetic variance for complex traits is traditionally estimated from data on relatives. It is notoriously difficult to estimate without bias in non-laboratory species, including humans. Here, we jointly estimate the proportion of variance explained by additive (h SNP  2 ) and dominance (&#948; SNP 2 ) genetic variance in a single analysis model. We first show by simulations that our model leads to unbiased estimates.

Gene-&#949; is a new approach for identifying statistical associations between sets of variants and quantitative traits. We reformulate the genome-wide SNP-level null hypothesis to identify spurious small-to-intermediate SNP effects and classify them as non-causal. We identify enriched genes in biologically relevant pathways.

 differences in the content and distribution of body fat and ectopic lipids may be responsible for ethnic variations in metabolic disease susceptibility. The aim of this study was to examine the ethnic distribution ofBody fat in two separate UK-based populations.

People from South Asian and black minority ethnic groups are disproportionately affected by the COVID-19 pandemic. It is unknown whether deprivation mediates this excess ethnic risk. The excess risk could be substantially reduced with population level policies targeting material deprivation.

Serum urate is associated with BMD and may be a protective factor. However, the exact association and mechanism are still unclear. We performed a genome-wide gene-environmental interaction study to explore the interaction effects between gene and urate on BMD.

Genome-wide association studies (GWAS) have identified many genetic risk variants for cancers. We constructed a site-specific polygenic risk score (PRS) for each of these nine cancers using their GWAS-identified risk variants. Using PRS, 63.0% of the participants could be classified as having an over twofold elevated risk for at least one cancer.

It has been hypothesised that nonsyndromic cleft lip/palate (nsCL/P) and cancer may share aetiological risk factors. Several genes (e.g., CDH1, AXIN2) have been implicated in the aetiologies of both phenotypes. Using a primary sample of 5,048 OC/OPC cases and 5,450 controls of European ancestry and a replication sample of 750 cases and 336,319 controls from UK Biobank we estimate genetic overlap.

The polygenic risk score (PRS) of sex hormone traits was calculated from individual-level genotype data of the United Kingdom (UK) Biobank cohort. We observed positive association between SHBG and the frequency of alcohol consumption in middle-aged males and females. In addition, estradiol was positively associated with alcohol consumption (b = 0.0128, p = 1.96 Ã— 10-8) in middle aged males. Finally, Tenascin R (TNR) (rs34633780) interacting with total testosterone for fluid intelligence was identified.

The course of COVID-19 varies from asymptomatic to severe in patients. One possibility is that genetic variation is partly responsible for the highly variable response. We evaluated how well a genetic risk score based on chromosomal-scale length variation and machine learning classification algorithms could predict severity of response.

A small number of circulating proteins have been reported to be associated with breast cancer risk. Herein, we attempted to identify novel protein biomarkers for breast cancer via the integration of genomics and proteomics data. In the Breast Cancer Association Consortium (BCAC), with 122,977 cases and 105,974 controls of European descendants, we evaluated the associations of the genetically predicted concentrations of >1,400 circulating proteins.

The predictive utility of polygenic scores is increasing, and many polygenic scoring methods are available, but it is unclear which method performs best. Eight polygenic score methods were tested: p-value thresholding and clumping (pT+clump), SBLUP, lassosum, LDpred1, LDPred2, PRScs, DBSLMM and SBayesR.

Study included 409   692 adults of European ancestry. 2 were associated with T1DM and 3 with T2DM, after adjusting for age, sex, body mass index, smoking, alcohol use, and population structure. Common host genetic effects may play a role in the molecular mechanism linking TB and diabetes.

High milk intake has been associated with cardio-metabolic risk. We conducted a Mendelian Randomization (MR) study to obtain evidence for the causal relationship. We used the lactase persistence (LCT-13910 C > T, rs4988235) variant as an instrumental variable.

Erythropoietic protoporphyria (EPP) results from pathogenic variants in ferrochelatase (FECH) EPP results from coinheriting a rare pathogenic variant in trans of a common hypomorphic variant c.315-48T>C (minor allele frequency 0.05). The estimated prevalence of EPP derived from the number of diagnosed individuals in Europe is 0.00092%, but this may be conservative due to underdiagnosis.

Prostate cancer is a leading cause of cancer death. We aimed to identify novel biochemical factors for prostate cancer incidence and mortality in UK Biobank. Prostate cancer incidence was positively associated with circulating vitamin D, urea and phosphate concentrations and inversely associated with glucose, total protein and aspartate aminotransferase.

Intrahepatic cholangiocarcinoma (ICC) is the second most common type of liver cancer. Studies in women and men have reported higher circulating oestradiol is associated with increased ICC risk. No observational studies have examined the associations between exogenous hormone use and reproductive factors.

Exome sequencing explored protein-altering variants and their consequences in 454,787 participants in the UK Biobank study. We identified 12 million coding variants, including 1 million loss-of-function and around 1.8 million deleterious missense variants. When these were tested for association with 3,994 health-related traits, we found 564 genes with trait associations at P &#8804; 2.18 Ã— 10-11.

The UK Biobank is a prospective study of 502,543 individuals. The data include 198,269 autosomal predicted loss-of-function (LOF) variants. Nearly all genes (more than 97%) had at least one carrier with a LOF variant.

Integration of DNA sequencing data with electronic health records (EHRs) could enhance our understanding of the contribution of rare genetic variation to human disease. The clinical impact of rare loss-of-function variants has yet to be determined for most genes.

It is estimated that up to 10% of cancer incidents are attributed to inherited genetic alterations. It was theorized that ultra-rare variants partially account for the missing heritable component.

Cigarette smoking is the leading cause of preventable morbidity and mortality. Genetic variation contributes to initiation, regular smoking, nicotine dependence, and cessation. We present a Fagerstr&#246;m Test for Nicotine Dependence (FTND)-based genome-wide association study in 58,000 smokers.
