Ethnic inequalities in coronavirus disease 2019 (COVID-19) hospitalizations and mortality have been widely reported, but there is scant understanding of how they are embodied. The UK Biobank prospective cohort study comprises approximately half a million people who were aged 40-69 years at study induction.

 Mechanisms underlying adiposity-colorectal cancer (CRC) association are incompletely understood. Using UK Biobank data, we investigated the role of C-reactive protein (CRP), hemoglobin-A1c (Hb a1c) and (jointly) sex hormone-binding globulin (SHBG) and testosterone, in explaining this association.

Method for performing Mendelian randomization studies using only summary statistics. We apply the approach to the UK Biobank cohort to investigate the causal role of sleep disturbance on HbA1c.

Family history contains information on disease status of relatives, adding valuable information about the probands' health problems and risk of diseases. Incorporating data from FH is a cost-effective way to improve statistical evidence in genetic studies. The development of sequencing technology calls for new powerful methods to detect disease associations.

Short and long sleep durations have adverse effects on physical and mental health. Most studies are based on self-reported sleep duration and health status. This longitudinal study aims to investigate objectively measured sleep duration.

Weighted burden analysis can incorporate variants with different frequencies and annotations into a combined test for association between a gene and a phenotype. There are marked differences in optimal weighting schemes between genes, both with respect to allele frequency and to annotation. It seems helpful to weight rare variants more highly than common ones and to give loss of function variants higher weights.

We leveraged a large prospective cohort, the UK-Biobank (UKBB,  N  ~ 397,000), and studied associations of prior use of all level-4 ATC drug categories with COVID-19 diagnosis and severity. We observed strong and highly consistent protective associations with statins. We also observed protective associations by influenza, pneumococcal, and several other vaccines.

There is a well-established relationship between cannabis use and psychosis, although the exact nature of this relationship is not fully understood. Recent studies have observed significant genetic overlap between a diagnosis of schizophrenia and lifetime cannabis use. This study aimed to examine whether genetic overlap also occurs for subclinical psychosis (schizotypy) and cannabis use, as well as examining the phenotypic association.

Previous observational evidence has suggested an association between smoking and inflammatory bowel disease (IBD) We used observational techniques followed by Mendelian randomization to explore whether smoking is a causal factor in the development of IBD and its subtypes.

 contactins are a family of genes involved in development of the nervous system. They are implicated in a wide range of psychological, psychiatric and cardiometabolic conditions. There is growing evidence to suggest that shared biology (including genetic variation) is likely to contribute to comorbidity between mental and physical illness.

Weight loss or lower body mass index (BMI) could be an early symptom of Alzheimer disease (AD) When this begins to emerge is difficult to estimate with traditional observational data. We leveraged variation in genetic risk for late-onset AD risk to estimate the causal effect of AD on BMI.

Wearing eyeglasses more than 8 hours per day may be protective against SARS-CoV-2 infection. Men are 1.24-times more likely to be infected than women.

Study looked at all UK Biobank participants who underwent imaging up to December 2015. Brain, cardiac and body magnetic resonance, and dual-energy x-ray absorptiometry images from the first 1000 participants were reviewed systematically by radiologists for PSIFs. Thereafter, radiographers flagged concerning images for radiologists' review.

Women, people aged over 65 years, underweight people and those with rheumatoid arthritis were most likely to have sarcopenia. Overweight, obesity, as well as a self-reported higher intake of energy, protein, vitamins (B12 and B9) and minerals (potassium, calcium and magnesium) were associated with lower odds.

We present a comprehensive statistical framework to analyze data from genome-wide association studies of polygenic traits. In contrast with standard approaches, our method can leverage sophisticated multivariate algorithms but makes no parametric assumptions about the unknown relation between genotypes and phenotype.

Diet and familial factors have a major role in the development of cardiovascular disease (CVD) It remains unclear whether familial predisposition to CVD modifies the association between dietary factors and CVD. In this prospective cohort of the UK Biobank, 462,155 CVD-free participants were included in 2006-2010 and followed for CVD incidence until 2020.

Genome-wide studies often exclude family members, even though they are a valuable source of information. We identified parent-offspring pairs, siblings and couples in the UK Biobank and implemented a family-based DNA-derived heritability method. Compared to estimates from unrelated individuals, total heritability increased from 10 to 27%.

UK Biobank, an observational cohort recruited between 2006 and 2010. Of 401,268 participants in total, 13,331 tested positive for SARS-CoV-2 and 2282 had severe infection by end of January 2021. In unadjusted models, participants with &#8805;2 family members with diabetes were more likely to be tested positive. The excess risk for severe infection was no longer significant after adjusting for demographics.

Population stratification (PS) is a major confounder in genome-wide association studies. To adjust for PS, principal component analysis (PCA)-based ancestry prediction has been widely used. We propose two alternative approaches: bias-adjusted projection (AP) and online ADP (OADP)

Haplotype phasing is the estimation of haplotypes from genotype data. We present a fast, accurate, and memory-efficient method that scales to large-scale SNP array and sequence data. The method uses marker windowing and composite reference haplotypes to reduce memory usage and computation time.

Nonalcoholic fatty liver disease is common and is associated with rising morbidity and mortality in the UK. We found significant association between fatty liver index and incident cardiovascular disease in the fully adjusted model. Fatty liver index significantly associated with a wide range of cardiovascular risk factors at baseline.

Genome-wide-association studies (GWAS) indicated potential CRF and disease genetics overlap. We characterise 135 CRF loci following GWAS in 76029 UK Biobank participants. Fine-mapping identifies a subset of 55 highly likely causal variants, 91% of which are non-coding.

The UK Biobank is a prospective study of more than 500 000 participants. The impact of unmeasured geographical confounding on genome-wide association studies (GWAS) of complex human traits has not been investigated. We observe significant genetic correlation of birth location with a range of lifestyle-related traits, even after adjustment for population structure.

Cardiorespiratory fitness was estimated as watts per kilogram from a submaximal bicycle test in 77 169 men and women from the UK Biobank cohort. Over a median follow-up of 7.7 years, 1731 participants died. Mortality risk was 1.78 times higher in unfit-obese men but not higher in obese-fit men (0.94 [95% CI, 0.60-1.48]). In contrast, there was no increased risk in obesity-unfit women (1.09 [95%) as compared with the reference.

Autoimmune thyroid disease is the most common autoimmune disease and is highly heritable. A low-frequency (1.36%) intronic variant in FLT3 (rs76428106-C) has the largest effect on risk of autoimmune thyroid disease. It is also associated with systemic lupus erythematosus (OR = 1.90, P = 6.46 Ã— 10-4), rheumatoid factor and/or anti-CCP-positive rheumatic arthritis and coeliac disease.

Both fat mass and lean mass are under strong genetic determinants and are correlated. We identified four loci that were significant at the genome-wide significance (GWS, &#945; = 5.0 Ã— 10-8) level at the discovery meta-analysis. The above four pleiotropic loci may play a pleiotropeic role for fat mass development.

Frailty has been linked to increased risk of COVID-19 mortality, but evidence is mainly limited to hospitalized older individuals. This study aimed to assess and compare predictive abilities of different frailty and comorbidity measures for COVID.19 mortality in a community sample and inpatients.

Frailty, sarcopenia, cachexia and malnutrition are clinical conditions that share similar diagnostic criteria. This study aimed to investigate the clustering and mortality risk among these clinical conditions in middle- and older-aged adults.

Analysis included a subsample of 107,452 participants of the UK Biobank study. Participants were recruited from across the United Kingdom between 2006 and 2010. The characteristics significantly associated with higher corneal astigmatism (P) were lighter skin colour and lower alcohol intake.

Keratitis is a complex condition in humans and is the second most common cause of legal blindness worldwide. We performed functional annotations of SNP-based and gene-based genome-wide association studies of keratitis in the UK Biobank (UKB) cohort with 337 199 subjects of European ancestry. A total of 34 SNPs from 14 distinct loci were identified as being associated with the condition.

High alcohol consumption is a risk factor for morbidity and mortality. Few genetic loci have been robustly associated with alcohol intake. We identified six loci attaining genome-wide significant association with alcohol consumption. A conserved role in phenotypic responses to alcohol was observed for all genetic targets available for investigation.

We conducted a large-scale genetic association analysis of educational attainment in a sample of approximately 1.1 million individuals. We identify 1,271 independent genome-wide-significant SNPs. The SNPs implicate genes involved in brain-development processes and neuron-to-neuron communication.

We used gene-based collapsing tests to identify genes associated with glucose, HbA1c and type 2 diabetes (T2D) diagnosis in 379,066 exome-sequenced participants in the UK Biobank. We identified associations for variants in GCK, HNF1A and PDX1, which are known to be involved in Mendelian forms of diabetes. We uncovered novel associations for GIGYF1, a gene not previously implicated by human genetics in diabetes.

The genetic aetiology of broad sense (non-suicidal and suicidal) self-harm has not been characterised on the molecular level. In the present study, we conduct genome-wide association studies (GWAS) using data from the UK Biobank. We also perform genome wide gene-based tests and characterize the SNP heritability and genetic correlations between these traits.

Genome-wide association study of sex in 3.3 million males and females identified 158 autosomal loci spuriously associated with sex. Sex exhibits artifactual autosomal heritability in the presence of sex-differential participation bias. Findings highlight a new challenge that genetic studies may face as sample sizes continue to grow.

The burden of infections on an individual and public health is profound. Many observational studies have shown a link between infections and the pathogenesis of disease. A greater understanding of the role of host genetics is essential. Children from the longitudinal birth cohort, the Avon Longitudinal Study of Parents and Children had 14 antibodies measured in plasma at age 7.

Serum concentration of hepatic enzymes are linked to liver dysfunction, metabolic and cardiovascular diseases. We perform genetic analysis on serum levels of alanine transaminase (ALT), alkaline phosphatase (ALP) and gamma-glutamyl transferase (GGT) using data on 437,438 UK Biobank participants.

Machine Learning (ML) approaches are increasingly being used in biomedical applications. The goals of this study were to assess applicability of TPOT to genomics and to identify combinations of single nucleotide polymorphisms associated with coronary artery disease (CAD)

Treatment-resistant depression (TRD) is a major contributor to the disability caused by major depressive disorder (MDD) Primary care electronic health records provide an easily accessible approach to investigate TRD clinical and genetic characteristics. MDD defined from primary care records in UK Biobank (UKB) and EXCEED studies was compared with other measures of depression.

The inner surfaces of the human heart are covered by a complex network of muscular strands that is thought to be a remnant of embryonic development. The function of these trabeculae in adults and their genetic architecture are unknown. Here we performed a genome-wide association study to investigate image-derived phenotypes. We identified 16 significant loci that contain genes associated with haemodynamic phenotypes and regulation of cytoskeletal arborization.

Males have a higher prevalence of asthma in childhood than females. The 'adolescent switch' observed between sexes during puberty has been hypothesised to be due to fluctuating sex hormones. Robust evidence of the involvement of sex hormones in asthma could lead to development of therapeutic interventions.

Using over 38,000 abdominal MRI scans in the UK Biobank, we used deep learning to quantify volume, fat, and iron in seven organs and tissues. We show that these traits have a substantial heritable component (8-44%) and identify 93 independent genome-wide significant associations.

Subcortical brain structures are integral to motion, consciousness, emotions and learning. We identified common genetic variation related to the volumes of the nucleus accumbens, amygdala, brainstem, caudate nucleus, globus pallidus, putamen and thalamus. 199 genes putatively implicated in neurodevelopment and susceptibility to neurological disorders.

Biological age measures outperform chronological age in predicting various aging outcomes, yet little is known regarding genetic predisposition. We performed genome-wide association scans of two age-adjusted biological age measures. The strongest signals were found in the APOE gene. Genes associated with BioAgeAccel were enriched in lipid related pathways.

 genome-wide association analysis to investigate how much of an individual's fall susceptibility can be attributed to genetics. Analysis revealed a small, but significant SNP-based heritability (2.7%) and identified three novel fall-associated loci.

Study examined whether there is a genetic association between major depression and cardio-metabolic traits and if this association is stratified by age at onset for major depression. Significant genetic correlations were found between depression and body mass index, coronary artery disease, and type 2 diabetes.

Traditional methods have used brain regions from predetermined parcellation schemes as phenotypes for genetic analyses. We found that anatomical SBM networks constructed on individuals from the UK Biobank were heritable and shared functionally meaningful genetic overlap with each other. We additionally identified 27 unique genetic loci that contributed to one or more S BM networks.

Higher scores on the personality trait of neuroticism are associated with worse mental and physical health. This study found that, although individuals who were higher on general neuroticism lived shorter lives, individuals whose neuroticism was characterized by worry and vulnerability lived longer lives.

Human DNA polymorphisms vary across geographic regions. Most commonly observed variation reflects distant ancestry differences. Of 33 traits analysed, 21 showed significant geographic clustering at the genetic level. Alleles associated with educational attainment showed the most clustering.

We found associations between type 2 diabetes (T2D) instruments and forced vital capacity (FVC) as well as FEV1/FVC. Body mass index (BMI) instruments were associated to all lung function traits and C-reactive protein (CRP) instruments to FVC. These genetic associations provide evidence for a causal effect of cardio-metabolic traits on lung function.

Cortical thickness, surface area and volumes vary with age and cognitive function, and in neurological and psychiatric diseases. Here we report heritability, genetic correlations and genome-wide associations of these cortical measures across the whole cortex.

Pain, neuroticism and depression share partially overlapping genetic risk factors. All pain phenotypes, except hip pain and knee pain, had significant and positive genetic correlations with depressive symptoms, major depressive disorders and neuroticism.

Infectious diseases are causally related to a large array of noncommunicable diseases. Identifying genetic determinants of infections and antibody-mediated immune responses may shed light on this relationship and provide therapeutic targets for drug and vaccine development.

Acute lymphoblastic leukemia (ALL) is the most common childhood cancer. Despite overlap between genetic risk loci for ALL and hematologic traits, the etiological relevance of dysregulated blood-cell homeostasis remains unclear. Study shows that a genetically induced shift toward higher lymphocyte counts, overall and in relation to monocytes, neutrophils, and platelets, confers an increased susceptibility to ALL.

The metabolic syndrome (MetS) is a description of a clustering of cardiometabolic risk factors in the same individual. This study searched for genetic loci associated with all five prespecified components of MetS to find a common pathophysiological link for this risk factor clustering.

Adiposity and ectopic fat play a role in type 2 diabetes and cardiometabolic diseases. We aimed to identify two clusters of adiposity genetic variants: one with "adverse" metabolic effects (UFA) and the other with, paradoxically, "favorable" metabolic effect (FA) UFA was associated with an adverse metabolic profile, higher risk of disease, higher CRP, and higher fat in subcutaneous and visceral adipose tissue, liver, and pancreas for UFA and a favorable metabolic profile for FA.

Gastro-oesophageal reflux disease (GORD) is associated with multiple risk factors but determining causality is difficult. We used a genetic approach [Mendelian randomization (MR)] to identify potential causal modifiable risk factors for GORD. We tested associations between GORD and four adiposity measures.

A favorable lifestyle was associated with 22% and 31% reductions in invasive breast cancer risk, respectively. For premenopausal women, the greatest risk reduction in association with the HLI was seen among those with a high PRS. There was an additive but not multiplicative interaction between HLI score and PRS for postmenopausal and, to a lesser extent, pre menopausal women.

Depression is a clinically heterogeneous disorder. Previous large-scale genetic studies of depression have explored genetic risk factors of depression case-control status or aggregated sums of depressive symptoms.

The majority of those who experience clinical anxiety and/or depressive symptoms in the population do not receive treatment. If genes influence who seeks and receives treatment, selection bias will confound genomic studies of treatment response.

 Reproductive longevity is essential for fertility and influences healthy ageing in women. But insights into its underlying biological mechanisms and treatments to preserve it are limited. Here we identify 290 genetic determinants of ovarian ageing, assessed using normal variation in age at natural menopause (ANM)

Genetic liability to insomnia was associated with higher odds of six CVDs. The patterns of associations remained with mild attenuation in multivariable MR analyses adjusting for genetically correlated phenotypes and potential mediators, including sleep duration, depression, body mass index, type 2 diabetes and smoking.

We sought to perform a genomic evaluation of the risk of incident cancer in statin users, free of cancer at study entry. Patients who previously participated in two phase IV trials (TNT and IDEAL) with genetic data were used (npooled = 11,196). A GWAS meta-analysis using Cox modeling was conducted in the pooled cohort and sex-stratified.

Birth weight (BW) is an important predictor of newborn survival and health. Twins have a lower BW than singletons as a result of a different pattern of fetal growth and shorter gestational duration. We found a positive correlation of beta values with 150 previously reported genome-wide significant variants for singleton BW.

Biobanks with exomes linked to electronic health records (EHRs) enable the study of genetic pleiotropy between rare variants and seemingly disparate diseases. We analyzed 213,084 exomes, along with a targeted set of retinal, cardiac, and immune phenotypes from two large-scale EHR-linked biobanks. A burden of deleterious variants in ERCC6 was strongly associated with (1) retinal disorders; (2) cardiac and electrocardiogram perturbations; and (3) immunodeficiency.

Large studies such as UK Biobank are increasingly used for GWAS and Mendelian randomization (MR) studies. However, selection into and dropout from studies may bias genetic and phenotypic associations. We examine genetic factors affecting participation in four optional components in up to 451,306 participants.

Preeclampsia is a serious complication of pregnancy, affecting both maternal and fetal health. In genome-wide association meta-analysis of European and Central Asian mothers, we identify sequence variants that associate with preeclampedia in the maternal genome.

Mosaic loss of chromosome Y (LOY) in circulating white blood cells is the most common form of clonal mosaicism1-5. We estimate that 20% of the male population represented in the UK Biobank study (n = 205,011) has detectable LOY. We identify 156 autosomal genetic determinants of LOY, which we replicate in 757,114 men of European and Japanese ancestry.

The aim of this study was to use Mendelian randomization (MR) to determine the causality of the association between smoking and 14 different cardiovascular diseases. The primary genetic instrument comprised 361 single-nucleotide polymorphisms (SNPs) associated with smoking initiation. Genetic predisposition to smoking initiation was most strongly and consistently associated with higher odds of coronary artery disease, heart failure, abdominal aortic aneurysm, ischaemic stroke, peripheral arterial disease, and arterial hypertension.

Tinnitus has been reported by 15% of the world's population. Many patients report major deficits to cognition and mood. We performed a genome-wide association study of the UK Biobank's 49,960 whole exome sequencing participants to identify any loci strongly associated with tinnitus.

Growing evidence has suggested an association between sleep duration and Alzheimer's disease. It is unclear if sleep duration is a manifestation of the AD disease process. We studied whether genetic liability for AD predicts sleep duration using a genetic risk score.

Depression is a common and clinically heterogeneous mental health disorder. Stratification of depression may align sub-diagnoses more closely with their underling aetiology and provide more tractable targets for research and effective treatment.

Sociability is a trait that is continuously distributed in the general population. decreased sociability represents an early manifestation of several brain disorders. We performed a genome-wide association study (GWAS) of a sociability score based on four social functioning-related self-report questions from 342,461 adults in the UK Biobank. The score was significantly heritable (SNP h2 of 6%).

 Optical Coherence Tomography (OCT) enables non-invasive imaging of the retina. We identify 46 loci associated with thickness of the retinal nerve fibre layer or ganglion cell inner plexiform layer. Only one of these loci has been associated with glaucoma. Mendelian randomisation does not support inner retinal thickness being on the same genetic causal pathway as glau coma.

Atezolizumab-induced thyroid dysfunction is associated with longer survival. Genetic variation associated with thyroid autoimmunity interacts with biological pathways driving the systemic immune response to PD-1 blockade.

Inhibition of sodium-glucose cotransporter 2 (SGLT2) represents an emerging pharmaceutical approach for the treatment of heart failure. The mechanisms by which SGLT 2 inhibitors reduce the risk of heart Failure are not well understood. The objective of this study was to investigate the association between single nucleotide polymorphisms (SNPs) in the SLC5A2 gene, encoding S GLT2, and heart failure, and to assess potential mediators of this association.

Most of the genetic basis of chronic liver disease remains undiscovered. We identified a genetic locus in mitochondrial glycerol-3-phosphate acyltransferase (GPAM) associated with increased levels of ALT, AST, ALP, and total bilirubin. This common genetic variant was also associated with an allele dose-dependent risk of alcohol-associated liver disease.

The number of gluten-free diet followers without celiac disease (CD) is increasing. Little is known about the characteristics of these individuals. A genome-wide association study (GWAS) of following a gluten- free diet was performed.

We used germline genetic variants for nevus count to test whether this phenotypic trait is a risk-marker for cancer. We calculated polygenic risk scores (PRS) using individual-level data in the UK Biobank and QSkin cohort. In both cohorts, those in the highest nevUS PRS quartile had higher risks of melanoma. We found no consistent evidence that nevu count PRS were associated with risks of developing internal cancers.

Genetic components of intelligence affect measured intelligence and educational attainment. These factors affect the prevalence of CAD via a series of unfavorable risk factor profiles. We found significant inverse correlations between gIQ and risk factors of CAD including smoking, BMI, T2D, hypertension, and a positive correlation with HDL cholesterol.

Lower levels of physical activity (PA) have been associated with increased risk of cardiovascular disease. One of the suggested mechanisms behind the association between PA and disease development is through systemic inflammation. In this study we investigated the relationship between genetically determined PA and circulating blood cells.

 Epidemiological studies have consistently documented an increased risk of developing primary non-cutaneous malignancies among people with a history of keratinocyte carcinoma (KC) We conducted two separate analyses to test whether genetically predicted KC is related to the risk of cancers at other sites.

Telomere length (TL) shortens over time in most human cell types and is a potential biomarker of aging. The causal association of TL on physical and cognitive traits that decline with age has not been extensively examined in middle-aged adults. Using a Mendelian randomization (MR) approach, we utilized genetically increased TL (GI-TL) to estimate the impact ofTL on aging-related traits.

Folate, vitamin B6 and vitamin B12 have been associated with digestive system cancers. We conducted a two-sample Mendelian randomisation study to assess the causality of these associations. Genetically predicted folate and B6 concentrations were not associated with overall cancer, overall digestive system cancer or oesophageal, gastric, colorectal or pancreatic cancer.

We conducted a two-sample Mendelian randomization (MR) study to assess the associations of genetically predicted circulating vitamin C levels with cardiovascular diseases (CVDs) Genetically predicted Vitamin C levels were not associated with any CVD after accounting for multiple testing. We found limited evidence with MR techniques for an overall protective role of vitamin C in the primary prevention of CVD.

Elevated blood pressure is a major cause of cardiovascular morbidity and mortality. It is not known whether midlife blood pressure affects later life cardiovascular risk independent of later life blood pressure. In both univariable and multivariable mendelian randomization analyses, there was consistent evidence of higher genetically predicted MAP at age &#8804;55 years increasing CAD risk.

Genetic instruments proxying coagulation factor inhibition were identified from genome-wide association studies for activated partial thromboplastin time and prothrombin time in BioBank Japan. Genetically proxied inhibition of fibrinogen alpha, beta, and gamma chain, factor II, and factor XI were associated with reduced risk of venous thromboembolism and large-artery stroke. There were suggestive protective associations of genetically proxied inhibited factors V, VII, and X with ischemic stroke.

Milk consumption was proxied by a genetic variant (rs4988235 or rs182549) upstream of the gene encoding lactase, which catalyzes the breakdown of lactose. The odds ratio (OR) for each additional milk intake increasing allele was 0.95 (95% confidence interval [CI] 0.91-0.99). There was no overall association of genetically predicted milk consumption with bladder.

Thyroid status is hypothesized to be causally related with the risk of diabetes mellitus (DM) Previous results were conflicting possibly because of a complex interaction between thyrotropin (TSH), body mass index (BMI) and DM. This work aims to investigate the causal association between thyroid status with DM and glucose homeostasis.

ECG markers of ventricular depolarization and repolarization are associated with an increased risk of arrhythmia and sudden cardiac death. We investigated whether serum calcium is a causal risk factor for changes in ECG measures using Mendelian randomization. A decrease of 0.1 mmol/L serum calcium was associated with longer QT and JT intervals.

Risk-taking behaviour is an important component of several psychiatric disorders, including attention-deficit hyperactivity disorder, schizophrenia and bipolar disorder. Two genetic loci have been associated with self-reported risk taking and significant genetic overlap with psychiatric disorders was identified within a subsample of UK Biobank. We identified 10 independent loci for risk- taking behaviour, of which eight were novel and two replicated previous findings.

A genome-wide association study was undertaken in 423,992 adult participants of UK Biobank. The study identified 74 independently associated genetic loci, to our knowledge previously unreported. Common genetic variation was estimated to account for 14% of variation in perceived age.

Glaucoma is the leading cause of irreversible blindness globally. Despite its gravity, the disease is frequently undiagnosed in the community. Raised intraocular pressure (IOP) is the most important risk factor for POAG.

Genome-wide association studies (GWAS) have discovered numerous genetic variants associated with human behavioural traits. However, behavioural traits are subject to misreports and longitudinal changes (MLC) which can cause biases in GWAS and follow-up analyses. We demonstrate that individuals with higher disease burden in the UK Biobank are more likely to misreport or reduce their alcohol consumption levels.

Chronic pain is often present at more than one anatomical location, leading to chronic overlapping pain conditions. We found that different genetic signals underlie chronic single-site and multisite pain with much stronger genetic contributions for the latter. Functional genomics identified axonogenesis in brain tissues as the major contributing pathway to chronic multisitePain.

In modern era Great Britain, genetic effects contribute towards some of the observed socioeconomic inequalities. We identify intelligence as one of the likely causal, partly-heritable phenotypes that might bridge the gap between molecular genetic inheritance and phenotypic consequence.

Genome-wide association studies (GWAS) have identified several risk loci for gallstone disease. As with most polygenic traits, it is likely that many genetic determinants are undiscovered. We performed a GWAS of 28,627 gallstone cases and 348,373 controls in the UK Biobank, replicated findings in a Scottish cohort, and conducted a GWA meta-analysis with the FinnGen cohort. Seventy-five risk loco were identified, of which 46 were new.

Identifying susceptibility genes could highlight the underlying pathophysiological mechanisms. Implicated genes included NCAM1, CADM2, PHF2/FAM120A, DOCK9, CKAP2/TPTE2P3 and BAG6.

Knockoff-based methods have become increasingly popular due to their enhanced power for locus discovery and their ability to prioritize putative causal variants. Because of the substantial computational cost for generating knockoffs, existing knockoff approaches cannot analyze millions of rare genetic variants in biobank-scale whole-genome sequencing. We propose a scalable KnockoffScreen-AL method for the analysis of common and rare variants across the genome.

Insomnia is the second most prevalent mental disorder, with no sufficient treatment available. Despite substantial heritability, insight into the associated genes and neurobiological pathways remains limited. We identify 202 loci implicating 956 genes through positional, expression quantitative trait loci, and chromatin mapping. Our findings highlight key brain areas and cell types implicated in insomnia.

Shoulder impingement syndrome (SIS) is a common shoulder disorder with unclear genetic mechanism. Genome-wide Association Study (GWAS) was conducted to identify the candidate loci associated with SIS by using the UK Biobank samples. The results provide novel clues for understanding the genetic mechanism of SIS.

Leukocyte telomere length (LTL) is a heritable biomarker of genomic aging. We perform a genome-wide meta-analysis of LTL by pooling densely genotyped and imputed association results across large-scale European-descent studies.

Previous studies have not explained a large part of the genetics behind these diseases. We identified 141 loci, of which 41 are novel, to be associated with asthma, hay fever or eczema. The largest number of loci was associated with the combined phenotype (asthma/hay fever/eczema)

We measured the vertical optic disc diameter (DD) of the UK Biobank (UKBB) cohort. We identified 81 loci (66 novel) for vertical DD. 44 of the 66 novel loci were significant at P.

Excessive daytime sleepiness affects 10-20% of the population and is associated with substantial functional deficits. We identify 42 loci for self-reported sleepiness in GWAS of 452,071 individuals from the UK Biobank. The 42 sleepiness variants primarily cluster into two predominant composite biological subtypes - sleep propensity and sleep fragmentation. Shared genetic links are also seen with obesity, coronary heart disease, psychiatric diseases, cognitive traits and reproductive ageing.

Serum alanine aminotransferase (ALT) and aspartate aminosferase(AST) are biomarkers for liver health. Largest genome-wide association analysis to date of serum ALT and AST levels in over 388k people of European ancestry from UK biobank and DiscovEHR.

Venous thromboembolism is a significant cause of mortality. Yet its genetic determinants are incompletely defined. We performed a discovery genome-wide association study in the Million Veteran Program and UK Biobank, with testing of approximately 13 million DNA sequence variants. We identified 22 previously unknown loci.

POP is a downward descent of one or more of the pelvic organs, resulting in a protrusion of the vaginal wall and/or uterus. We performed a genome-wide association study of POP using data from Iceland and the UK Biobank. We found eight sequence variants at seven loci associating with POP.

Age-related macular degeneration (AMD) is a leading cause of blindness. Little is known about the genetic architecture of early AMD. We conducted a genome-wide association study (GWAS) meta-analysis.

Corneal curvature is a key clinical endophenotype for myopia - a major cause of visual impairment and blindness in the world. Here we present a trans-ethnic meta-analysis of corneal curvatures GWAS in 44,042 individuals of Caucasian and Asian. We identified 47 loci (of which 26 are novel), with population-specific signals as well as shared signals across ethnicities.

Mitral valve prolapse (MVP) is a common cardiac valve disease, which affects 1 in 40 in the general population. Previous genome-wide association study has identified 6 risk loci for MVP, but these loci explained only partially the genetic risk for MVP. We aim to identify additional risk locus for MVP by adding data set from the UK Biobank.

Peripheral artery disease (PAD) is a leading cause of cardiovascular morbidity and mortality. We identified 19 PAD loci, 18 of which have not been previously reported. Eleven of the 19 loci were associated with disease in three vascular beds.

Leisure sedentary behaviours are associated with increased risk of cardiovascular disease. Whether this relationship is causal is unknown. Genome wide association analyses of leisure television watching, leisure computer use and driving behaviour in the UK Biobank identify 145, 36 and 4 genetic loci (P)

Identifying genetic risk factors for lumbar spine disorders may lead to knowledge regarding underlying mechanisms and the development of new treatments. Genome-wide association study used logistic regression with additive genetic effects adjusting for age, sex, site-specific factors, and ancestry.

Only a minority of heavy drinkers progress to alcohol-associated cirrhosis (ALC) The aim of this study was to identify common genetic variants that underlie risk for ALC. We analyzed data from 1,128 subjects of European ancestry with ALC and 614 heavy-drinking subjects without known liver disease.

We aimed to increase our understanding of the genetic determinants of vitamin D levels by undertaking a large-scale genome-wide association study. We used imputed genotypes from 401,460 white British UK Biobank participants with available 25OHD levels. 138 conditionally independent SNPs were detected (p value  -9 ) among which 53 had MAF.

Benign prostatic hyperplasia (BPH) is common noncancerous prostate enlargement. Majority of elderly men will be affected by BPH as age increases. We conducted a genome-wide association study of BPH.

The genetic basis of spastic cerebral palsy is largely unknown. We used whole-genome genetic information linked to a deidentified electronic health record (BioVU) with replication in the UK Biobank and FinnGen. We identify 1 SNP (rs78686911) reaching genome-wide significance with spastic CP. Our study indicates that genetic variation contributes to CP risk.

Chronic widespread musculoskeletal pain (CWP) is a symptom of fibromyalgia and a complex trait with poorly understood pathogenesis. CWP is heritable (48%-54%) but its genetic architecture is unknown. We conducted a genome-wide association study to get insight into the genetic background of CWP.

The skin's tendency to sunburn rather than tan is a major risk factor for skin cancer. Here we report a large genome-wide association study of ease of skin tanning in 176,678 subjects of European ancestry.

Circulating cardiac troponin proteins are associated with structural heart disease and predict incident cardiovascular disease in the general population. We identified 12 genetic loci (8 novel) associated with cTnI concentrations. Associated protein-altering variants highlighted putative functional genes: CAND2, HABP2, ANO5, APOH, FHOD3 and KLKB1.

Cognitive impairment is a frequent and serious problem in patients with various forms of severe mental illnesses (SMI), including schizophrenia (SZ) and bipolar disorder (BP) Recent research suggests genetic links to several cognitive phenotypes in both SMI and in the general population. Our goal in this study was to identify potential genomic signatures of cognitive functioning in veterans with severe mental illness.

Estradiol is the primary female sex hormone and plays an important role for skeletal health in both sexes. Few genome-wide association studies (GWAS) have been performed to characterize the genetic contribution to variation in estrogen levels.

Rupture of an intracranial aneurysm leads to subarachnoid hemorrhage, a severe type of stroke. We performed a cross-ancestry, genome-wide association study in 10,754 cases and 306,882 controls of European and East Asian ancestry. We discovered 17 risk loci, 11 of which are new.

Genome-wide association studies (GWAS) have identified several risk loci for nonalcoholic fatty liver disease (NAFLD) Previous studies have largely relied on small sample sizes and have assessed quantitative traits. We performed a case-control GWAS in the UK Biobank using recorded diagnosis of NAFLD.

Occupational attainment is a known proxy marker of cognitive reserve for Alzheimer's disease. We performed a large-scale genome-wide association study of occupational attainment with 248 847 European individuals. We identified 30 significant loci (P)

Self-reported walking pace has been associated with a range of cardiorespiratory and cancer outcomes, and is a strong predictor of mortality. We identify 70 independent associated loci (P) in 450,967 European ancestry UK Biobank participants.

Serum liver enzyme concentrations are the most frequently-used laboratory markers of liver disease, a major cause of mortality. We conduct a meta-analysis of genome-wide association studies of liver enzymes from UK BioBank and BioBank Japan. Associated variants implicate genes that demonstrate diverse liver cell type expression and promote a range of metabolic and liver diseases. These findings provide insight into the pathophysiology of liver and other metabolic diseases.

The metabolic syndrome (MetS) is a description of a clustering of cardiometabolic risk factors in the same individual. Previous genome-wide association studies (GWASs) have identified 29 independent genetic loci linked to MetS as a binary trait. This study used data from UK biobank to search for additional loci.

Tinnitus is often associated with pre-existing hearing loss or noise-induced damage to the auditory system. Evidence suggests that tinnitus has a heritable component. Previous genetic studies have not established specific risk factors.

Muscle bulk in adult healthy humans is highly variable even after height, age, and sex are accounted for. Low muscle mass, due to fewer and/or smaller constituent muscle fibers, would exacerbate the impact of muscle loss occurring in aging or disease. Genetic variability substantially influences muscle mass differences, but causative genes remain largely unknown.

Stress is associated with poorer physical and mental health. We performed genome-wide association studies (GWAS) of depressive symptoms and stressful life events. No SNP was individually significant in either GWAS, but gene-based tests identified six genes associated with depressive symptoms in UK Biobank.

Risk of chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD) is determined by both cigarette smoking and genetic susceptibility. Little is known about gene-by-smoking interactions. We performed a genome-wide association analysis of 179,689 controls and 21,077 COPD cases.

Diet is a significant modifiable risk factor for type 2 diabetes (T2D) Its effect on disease risk is under partial genetic control. Identification of specific gene-diet interactions (GDIs) influencing risk biomarkers is a critical step towards precision nutrition for T2D prevention.

Gene-environment interactions (GxE) are often suggested to play an important role in the aetiology of psychiatric phenotypes. We investigated interactions on the level of SNPs, genes, and gene-sets. We computed interaction-based polygenic risk scores (PRS) to predict neuroticism in an independent sample subset.

Neuroimaging-genetics cohorts gather two types of data: brain imaging and genetic data. They allow the discovery of associations between genetic variants and brain imaging features. This study presents a genome-wide haplotype analysis for 123 brain sulcus opening value across the whole brain.

Underlying genetic and phenotypic mechanisms are not fully understood, partially due to lack of coordinated genotypic-phenotypic data. Study identified 549 significant single-variant associations ( p   -9 ), many in chromosome 11's triglyceride hotspot. A well-known protective loss-of-function variant in APOC3 (R19X) was associated with a 51% decrease in triglyceride levels.

Primary open-angle glaucoma (POAG), is a heritable common cause of blindness world-wide. We conduct a large multi-ethnic meta-analysis of genome-wide association studies on a total of 34,179 cases and 349,321 controls. We identify 44 previously unreported risk loci and confirm 83 loci that were previously known. The majority of loci have broadly consistent effects across European, Asian and African ancestries.

Age-related macular degeneration (AMD) is the leading cause of irreversible blindness among the elderly. We identified 12 novel AMD loci near or within C4BPA - CD55, ZNF385B, ZBTB38, NFKB1, LINC00461, ADAM19, CPN1, ACSL5, CSK, RLBP1, CLUL1, and LBP. Most of the novel genes are expressed in retinal tissue and could be involved in the pathogenesis of AMD.

 Understanding the impact of rare variants is essential to understanding human health. We analyze rare (MAF) variants to find out how they affect the human body.

The resting QT interval is a heritable risk marker of cardiovascular mortality. The mechanisms remain incompletely understood. We identified 40 loci, 13 of which were novel, including 2 potential sex-specific loci. Candidate genes at novel loci were involved in myocardial structure and arrhythmogenic cardiomyopathy.

Bayesian approach (BayesW) provides probabilistic inference of the genetic architecture of age-at-onset phenotypes. We show in extensive simulation work the benefits BayesW provides in terms of number of discoveries and genomic prediction.

Across species, offspring of related individuals often exhibit significant reduction in fitness-related traits, known as inbreeding depression (ID) The genetic and molecular basis for ID remains elusive. Here, we develop a method to quantify enrichment of ID within specific genomic annotations and apply it to human data.

Circulating testosterone levels are a heritable trait with anabolic properties in various tissues, including skeletal muscle. Hundreds of single nucleotide polymorphisms (SNPs) associated with testosterone levels have been identified. The aim of the present study was to test the association of 822 testosterone-increasing SNPs with muscle-related traits.

Colorectal cancer (CRC) survival has environmental and inherited components. The expression of specific genes can be inferred based on individual genotypes. In this study, we used the PrediXcan method to predict gene expression in normal colon tissue.

 differences in local contexts influencing how much a given neighbourhood characteristic matters for the health of local residents. Linking UK Biobank data from 302,952 urban-dwelling adults in England, collected between 2006 and 2010.

The G84E mutation was found in 1,545 (0.34%) of 460,224 participants of European ancestry. While mutation status did not associate with cancer risk in females, it was significantly associated with increased risk in males.

With the development of genome-wide association studies, how to gain information from a large scale of data has become an issue of common concern. Traditional methods are not fully developed to solve problems such as identifying loci-to-loci interactions. We developed a two-stage global search algorithm, Greedy Equivalence Search with Local Modification.

Mosaic loss of chromosome Y (LOY) in leukocytes is the most common form of clonal mosaicism. We find that loss of function of two genes - CHEK2 and GIGYF1 - reach exome-wide significance.

Glucosamine is a widely used supplement typically taken for osteoarthritis and joint pain. Emerging evidence suggests potential links of glucosamine with glucose metabolism, inflammation, and cardiometabolic risk. We analyzed 404,508 participants from the UK Biobank who were free of diabetes, cancer, or cardiovascular disease at baseline.

Glucosamine is widely used in many countries and may have anti-inflammatory properties. Chronic inflammation exerts pleiotropic effects in the aetiology and progression of chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD) We aimed to evaluate the association of regular glucosamine use with incident COPD risk in the UK Biobank cohort.

Gluten has been linked to adverse effects on metabolic and vascular health. Gluten intake was estimated in 159,265 participants of the UK Biobank which is a large multicenter, prospective cohort study.

Gluten intake was estimated in 39,927 participants of the UK Biobank who completed a dietary questionnaire. Multiple linear regression analyses were performed between gluten intake and markers of metabolic health with Holm adjustment for multiple comparisons.

Gout and/or rheumatoid arthritis (RA) are risk factors for coronavirus disease 2019 (COVID-19) diagnosis and death. We used data from the UK Biobank. RA, but not gout, was associated with COVID- 19 diagnosis in analysis A.

Causal inference via Mendelian randomization requires making strong assumptions about horizontal pleiotropy. Here, we present causal Graphical Analysis Using Genetics (cGAUGE), a pipeline that overcomes these limitations using instrument filters with provable properties. cGAUGE also uses ExSep (Exposure-based Separation), a novel test for the existence of causal pathways.

Polygenic risk scores (PRS) were measured in a large sample of adults from the UK Biobank. Polygenic risk was significantly associated with reduced neurite density index (NDI) at global brain scale. Risk-related reduction in NDI is plausibly indicative of reduced density of myelinated axons and dendritic arborization in cortico-subcortical networks.

A total of 406,834 participants from the UK Biobank, with baseline measurements between March 13, 2006, and October 1, 2010, without CVD at baseline were included in this study. Associations of grip strength and walking pace with CVD outcomes were investigated using Cox models.

Genome-wide association study of A Body Shape Index (ABSI), Hip Index (HI) and the new Waist-to-Hip Index. Data from the UK Biobank Resource for 219,872 women and 186,825 men with white British ancestry. One to two thirds of the loci identified for allometric body-shape indices were novel.

Genome-wide association studies (GWAS) have been used to study the genetic basis of a wide variety of complex diseases and other traits. UK Biobank GWAS results for three molecular traits-urate, IGF-1, and testosterone-with better-understood biology than most other complex traits.

Thyroid stimulating hormone (TSH) is critical for normal development and metabolism. We identify 74 genome-wide significant loci for TSH, of which 28 are previously unreported. Phenome-wide association analysis in the UK Biobank demonstrates the pleiotropic effects of TSH-associated variants.

Genotype-by-environment interaction (GxE) is fundamental in the biology of complex traits and diseases. Existing methods are computationally demanding and infeasible to handle biobank-scale data. We introduce GxEsum, a method for estimating the phenotypic variance explained by genome-wide GXE based on GWAS statistics.

H2AX can be of prognostic value in breast cancer, since in advanced stage patients with high levels, there was an association with worse overall survival. However, the clinical relevance of H2AX in ovarian cancer (OC) remains to be elucidated. Polymorphisms in the area around the gene were associated with both OC prevalence and worse OS.

Mechanisms linking habitual consumption of coffee and tea to the development of type 2 diabetes and cardiovascular diseases remain unclear. We leveraged dietary, genetic, and biomarker data collected from the UK Biobank. Each additional cup of coffee was significantly associated with higher total cholesterol, HDL-ch cholesterol, and LDL-cholesterol concentrations.

Study included 492,713 participants from the UK Biobank who completed a questionnaire on habitual fish oil supplement use between 2006 and 2010. Compared with nonuse, habitual use of fish oil supplements was associated with a lower risk of total fractures (HR = 0.93; 95% CI: 0.89, 0.97)

Vitamin D insufficiency is related to a higher risk of coronavirus disease 2019 (COVID-19) infection. Previous studies have related vitamin D supplementation to a lower risk of acute respiratory tract infection. We aimed to investigate the prospective association between habitual use of vitamin D supplements and risk of CO VID-19 infection.

Red blood cell, platelet, and white blood cell indices may be markers of a range of exposures that might be related to prostate cancer risk. Blood count data from 209,686 male UK Biobank participants who were free from cancer at study baseline were analyzed.

10% of the human population is left-handed, and this rate is increased in some brain-related disorders. The neuroanatomical correlates of hand preference have remained equivocal. We resampled structural brain image data from 28,802 right- handers and 3,062 left-handers (UK Biobank population dataset) to a symmetrical surface template.

Ninety per cent of the human population has been right-handed since the Paleolithic. Yet the brain signature and genetic basis of handedness remain poorly characterized. Here, we correlated brain imaging phenotypes from &#8764;9000 UK Biobank participants with handedness. We found four significant loci (rs199512, rs45608532, rs13017199, and rs3094128) for human handedness in the general population.

Calcium is essential for the normal functioning of the cardiovascular system, muscles, and nerves. We conducted a phenome-wide Mendelian randomization analysis to survey health effects associated with high normal serum calcium. We found causal evidence for conditions related to renal function, bone and joint health, and cardiovascular risk.

IT worker health is under-studied and large-scale studies are lacking. IT workers reported similar overall health, but lower lifestyle risk factors for smoking and obesity. Sedentary work was a substantially higher occupational exposure risk for IT workers.

A total of 480,940 middle-aged adults were analysed in the UK Biobank. A total of 93,746 (19.5%) participants had multimorbidity. Engaging in a healthier lifestyle was associated with up to 6.3 years longer life for men and 7.6 years for women. However, not all lifestyle risk factors equally correlated with life expectancy.

Data from a subsample of the U.K. Biobank were analyzed to determine to what extent differences in levels of hearing difficulties and tinnitus in high-risk industries could be attributable to demographic, health, and lifestyle factors. Older age, low socioeconomic status, and non-White ethnic background partially accounted for higher levels of Hearing difficulties in the construction industry. The levels of tinn Titus were greatest for music and construction industries compared with finance.

Obesity is a risk factor for SARS-COV2 infection and is often associated with hepatic steatosis. The aim of this study was to determine if pre-existing hepatic Steatosis affects the risk of infection and severity for COVID-19.

CeD, Crohn&#180;s disease (CD) and ulcerative colitis (UC) cohorts assessed. Baseline liver function tests and the frequency of hepatobiliary diseases were analyzed. Elevated ALP and cholelithiasis were significantly more common in all intestinal disorders.

We introduce an approach to identify disease-relevant tissues and cell types. We analyzed gene expression data together with genome-wide association study (GWAS) summary statistics. We found significant tissue-specific enrichments (false discovery rate (FDR)

Four major forms of Alzheimer's disease (AD) genetic risk are associated with 273 traits in 500,000 individuals in the UK Biobank. The traits cover blood biochemistry and cell traits, metabolic and general health, psychosocial health and cognitive function.

High coffee consumption was associated with smaller total brain volumes and increased odds of dementia. The association between coffee consumption and dementia was non-linear. Evidence for higher odds for non-coffee and decaffeinated coffee drinkers and those drinking >6 cups/day.

Elevated serum uric acid (SUA) levels have been previously reported to play a role in multiple types of cancers. However, epidemiological studies evaluating SUA levels and colorectal cancer risk remain sparse. This cohort study included 444 462 participants between the ages of 40 and 69 years from the UK Biobank.

High-definition likelihood (HDL) method to improve precision in genetic correlation estimation. Compared to LDSC, HDL reduces the variance of genetic correlation estimates by about 60%, equivalent to a 2.5-fold increase in sample size.

Higher adiposity is an established risk factor for psychiatric diseases including depression and anxiety. The associations between adiposity and depression may be explained by the metabolic consequences and/or by the psychosocial impact of higher adiposity. We performed one- and two- sample Mendelian randomization (MR) in up to 145 668 European participants from the UK Biobank.

Measurement of hippocampal volume has proven useful to diagnose and track progression in several brain disorders, most notably in Alzheimer's disease. However, clinicians and researchers require access to age-related normative percentiles to reliably categorise a patient's hippocampus as being pathologically small. In this report, we provide normative values for hippocampal and total grey matter volume as a function of age for reference in clinical and research settings.

Fluvoxamine strongly binds to the sigma-1 receptor (S1R) that regulates inflammation by inhibiting the production of cytokines, believed to be responsible for severe COVID-19. We evaluated the S1R locus on chr 9p13.3 in subjects tested positive for SARS-CoV-2. The effect of rs17775810 genotype on survival was significant.

Pneumonia is a lung disease that can cause respiratory failure and hypoxia. Few genome-wide association studies (GWASs) of host susceptibility and severity of pneumonia have been conducted. Two regions of large effect were identified: the CFTR locus in EA and HBB in AA. Mutations in these genes cause cystic fibrosis (CF) and sickle cell disease (SCD)

Childhood maltreatment has been consistently associated with cardiovascular disease (CVD) We explored the relative contribution of anxiety/depression, smoking, body mass index (BMI) and inflammation (C-reactive protein, CRP) to the association between childhood maltreatment and CVD in the UK.

A larger waist circumference (WC), but not BMI, was associated with an increase in fracture risk in men. In women, neither BMI nor WC affected the risk. Trunk fat mass, visceral adipose tissue (VAT) mass, and limb fat mass were negatively associated with vertebral body BMD and geometry in men and women.

Previous studies have yielded conflicting results on the association between human cytomegalovirus (HCMV) and cardiovascular disease (CVD) This study examined associations between HCMV and incident CVD, ischaemic heart disease (IHD) and stroke.

Human leukocyte antigens (HLA) have been associated with renal function, but previous studies report contradictory findings. There has been a lack of research into how HLA affects renal function in Black, Asian and Minority Ethnic (BAME) people in the UK. BAME people are disproportionately affected by renal dysfunction.

Hyperopia (farsightedness) has been associated with a deficit in children's educational attainment in some studies. We aimed to investigate the causality of the relationship between refractive error and educational attainment. Mendelian randomization (MR) analysis in 74,463 UK Biobank participants was used.

Iiopathic pulmonary fibrosis (IPF) is a fatal disorder characterised by progressive, destructive lung scarring. Despite substantial progress, the genetic determinants of this disease remain incompletely defined. We found a novel association between a rare missense variant in SPDL1 and IPF (NM_017785.5:g.169588475 G > A p.Arg20Gln)

We identified a novel association between a variant in the CREB5 gene and RCD surgery. Validation of this finding in studies with imaging data to confirm diagnoses will be an important next step. Identification of genetic RCD susceptibility markers can guide understanding of biological processes.

Familial aggregation is known for both hernia development and recurrence. To date, only one genome-wide association study (GWAS) limited to inguinal hernia has been reported. We aim to investigate the polygenic architecture of abdominal wall hernia subtypes and identify specific single nucleotide polymorphisms (SNPs)

Endometrial cancer is the most commonly diagnosed cancer of the female reproductive tract in developed countries. Through genome-wide association studies (GWAS), we have previously identified eight risk loci. Here, we present an expanded meta-analysis of 12,906 endometrial. cancer cases and 108,979 controls (including new genotype data for 5624 cases) and identify nine novel genome- wide significant loci, including a locus on 12q24.12.

Handgrip strength is a widely used measure of muscle strength and a predictor of a range of morbidities including cardiovascular diseases and all-cause mortality. Previous genome-wide association studies have focused on common variants primarily in persons of European descent. We aimed to identify rare and ancestry-specific genetic variants associated with handgrip Strength.

Study: 1,363 individuals with AAA compared to 27,260 age, ancestry, and sex-matched controls. Analysis was repeated for 435 individuals with TAA compared to 8,700 controls. Novel loci near LINC01021, ATOH8 and JAK2 genes that achieved genome-wide significance for AAA. For TAA, three novel loci in CTNNA3, FRMD6 and MBP achieved genomewide significance.

Oral inflammatory diseases (OIDs) are a group of dental diseases with multiple clinical manifestations that impact the majority of the world's population. Many studies have investigated the associations between individual OID traits and genomic variants. Here, we conducted multitrait joint analyses based on the summary statistics of genome-wide association studies (GWASs) of five dental traits from the UK Biobank.

Atrial fibrillation (AF) is the most common cardiac arrhythmia, with an estimated prevalence of around 1.6% in the adult population. The analysis of the electrocardiogram (ECG) data acquired in the UK Biobank represents an opportunity to screen for AF in a large sub-population. The combined classical machine-learning and deep learning method achieved an F1 score of 84.8%.

Bone mineral density (BMD) is a key indicator for diagnosis and treatment for osteoporosis. The reduction of BMD could increase the risk of osteop orotic fracture. SNP rs62048221 was located at the enhancer region (HEDD enhancer ID 2331049) of gene PIEZO1.

Bone mineral density (BMD) and lean body mass (LBM) not only have a considerable heritability each, but also are genetically correlated. Common genetic determinants shared by both traits are largely unknown. We identified 2 loci that nearly attained the genome-wide significance.

Breast cancer is the most commonly diagnosed malignancy in women. More cancer prevention research is urgently needed. The aim of this study was to predict potential therapeutic agents for breast cancer and determine their molecular mechanisms using integrated bioinformatics.

Study aimed to screen the entire genome for genetic markers associated with risk for Achilles tendon injury. Genome-wide association analysis was performed using data from the Kaiser Permanente Research Board and the UK Biobank.

Disease-agnostic approach to cluster genetic risk profiles for 3,025 genome-wide independent loci across 19,155 disease classification codes from 320,644 participants in the UK Biobank. We identify 339 distinct disease association profiles and use multiple approaches to link clusters to the underlying biological pathways.

Phenotype Latent variable Extraction of disease misdiagnosis (PheLEx) is a GWAS analysis framework that learns and corrects misclassified phenotypes using structured genotype associations within a dataset. We demonstrate the potential of PheLEX for extracting new potential loci from existing GWAS data by analyzing bipolar disorder and epilepsy phenotypes available from UK Biobank.

Mendelian randomization phenome-wide association study (MR-pheWAS) of age at menarche with 17,893 health-related traits in UK Biobank (n = 181,318) using PHESANT. After exclusion of variants associated with BMI, the genetic risk score for age atMenarche was related to 37 traits. Follow-up analyses indicated imprecise evidence of an effect of younger age at Menarche on greater bone-mineral density, lower lung function, and higher neuroticism score.

Machine learning approach ranked the tissue-specific transcription regulatory effects for T1D SNPs. An eQTL (rs6679677) associated with changes to AP4B1-AS1 transcript levels in lung tissue makes the largest gene regulatory contribution to the risk of T1d development.

Identifying AD neuroimaging markers may help study early mechanisms of neurodegeneration. We aimed to identify brain regions of the highest vulnerability to AD using a data-driven search in the AD Neuroimaging Initiative. Whole-genome analysis revealed a common variant in SHARPIN that was associated with this imaging feature.

Lung cancer is genetically correlated with reduced forced expiratory volume in one second. Mendelian randomization analyses demonstrate that reduced FEV1 increases squamous cell carcinoma risk. Findings support a causal role of pulmonary impairment in lung cancer etiology.

Odds of persisting amblyopia were 5.91 (5.24-6.66) and 2.49 (2.21-2.81) times greater in cohort 1 and cohort 2, respectively, than cohort 3. The odds were also higher for more socioeconomically deprived groups and for white ethnicity. Reduced participation in sport, adverse general and mental health, and well-being were all independently associated with persisting Amblyopia. The observed adverse outcomes were largely those not directly mediated by vision.

Analyzing the NHLBI Trans-Omics for Precision Medicine (TOPMed) sequence data in 10,338 individuals from five studies and four ancestries. The most associated G6PD variant (rs1050828-T, p.Val98Met, MAF = 12% in African-Americans, 2% in Hispanics) lowered HbA1c (-0.88% in hemizygous males, -0.34% in heterozygous females)

We conducted a prospective cohort study in 60,235 UK Biobank participants (mean age: 56; 56% female) Exposure was baseline daily movement behaviours and self-reported total sleep. Outcomes were depression and anxiety symptoms at follow-up. Replacing 60 min of sedentary behaviour with light activity, moderate-to-vigorous activity, and sleep was associated with lower depression symptom scores.

Of 502,543 participants, 3849 (1.4%) of women and 1643 (0.7%) of men had a diagnosis of RA. Corticosteroid and DMARD therapy, but not biologic therapy, were associated with a lower eBMD with RA.

Sex hormone-binding globulin (SHBG) is a circulating glycoprotein and a regulator of sex hormone levels. The molecular nature of SHBG makes it a feasible target for preventative or therapeutic interventions. A systematic study of its effects across the human phenome may uncover novel associations.

Exposure to different workplace hazards were analyzed among 119,413 participants from the UK Biobank cohort. Shift workers had a higher prevalence ratio (PR) than other workers of being exposed to almost all identified hazards both before or after 1980.

LDAK-Bolt-Predict outperforms existing tools Lasso, BLUP, Bolt-LMM and BayesR for all 14 phenotypes. When we improve the heritability model, the proportion of phenotypic variance explained increases by on average 14%. This is equivalent to increasing the sample size by a quarter.

To study genetic factors associated with brain aging, we first need to quantify brain aging. Statistical models have been created for estimating the apparent age of the brain. A more accurate PBA enables the discovery of novel genetic associations.

Convolutional neural network (CNN) based segmentation methods provide an efficient and automated way for clinicians to assess the structure and function of the heart in cardiac MR images. While CNNs can generally perform the segmentation tasks with high accuracy when training and test images come from the same domain, their performance often degrades dramatically on images from different scanners or clinical sites. We propose a simple yet effective way for improving the network generalization ability by carefully designing data normalization and augmentation strategies.

Study explores the predictive utility of gene expression risk scores (GeRS) calculated using imputed gene expression and transcriptome-wide association study (TWAS) results. GeRS significantly predicted a range of outcomes, with elastic net models combining GeRS across SNP-weight sets improving prediction. The proportion of SNP-based heritability attributable to cis-regulated expression was modest for most outcomes.

Mosaic chromosomal alterations (mCAs) are large chromosomal gains, losses and copy-neutral losses of heterozygosity in peripheral leukocytes. Many individuals with detectable mCAs have no notable adverse outcomes. MCA-associated gene dosage alterations as well as clonal expansion of mutated leukocyte clones could increase susceptibility to disease.

The majority of polygenic risk scores (PRSs) have been developed and optimized in individuals of European ancestry. We find that including into the PRS variants discovered in African ancestry individuals has the potential to achieve unbiased estimates of genetic risk across global populations and admixed individuals.

The US Preventive Services Task Force (USPSTF) recently proposed to widen the current lung cancer screening guideline to include less-heavy smokers. We constructed a polygenic risk score (PRS) using lung cancer risk variants. During a median follow-up of 5.8 years, 1449 incident cases of lung cancer were identified.

Polygenic risk prediction is a widely investigated topic because of its promising clinical applications. Genetic variants in functional regions of the genome are enriched for complex trait heritability. We introduce a method for polygenic prediction, LDpred-funct, that leverages trait-specific functional priors to increase prediction accuracy.

Extreme presentations of common disease in children are often presumed to be of Mendelian etiology, but their polygenic basis has not been fully explored. We tested whether children with significant fracture history and no osteogenesis imperfecta are at increased polygenic risk for fracture. We generated a polygenic score of heel ultrasound-derived speed of sound, termed "gSOS"

Study looked at the association between osteoarthritis (OA), rheumatoid arthritis (RA), and frailty. Participants of the UK Biobank age 40-69 years at baseline were included. Frailty was assessed using a frailty index (FI) and a modified frailty phenotype (robust, pre-frail)

13,502 participants were tested for Covid-19 (mean age 70 +/- 8 years, 48.9% male) 1582 tested positive, of which 305 died. For every unit increase in BMI, WHR and body fat, the odds of death amongst Covid19-positive participants increased by 1.04 (95% CI 1.01-1.07) 35 kg/m2 had significantly higher odds of Covids-19-related death (OR 1.70, 95%CI 1.06-2.74)

Several forms of physical fitness could be modifiable risk factors for common mental disorders in the population. We examined associations between individual and combined markers of cardiorespiratory fitness and grip strength with the incidence of mental disorders.

Brain age is a widely used index for quantifying individuals' brain health. Higher-than-expected brain age is thought partially to reflect above-average rate of brain aging. We tested this assumption by assessing the relationship between cross-sectional and longitudinal estimates of  brain age.

We identified patients with one of five common complex diseases among 44,550 individuals who underwent exome sequencing in the UK Biobank. We derived PRS for these five diseases, and identified pathogenic rare variant heterozygotes. Rare pathogenic variants were more prevalent among affected patients with a low PRS.

Identifying disease subtypes and corresponding biomarkers can substantially improve clinical diagnosis and treatment selection. Discovering these subtypes in noisy, high dimensional biomedical data is often impossible for humans and challenging for machines. Instead of analyzing the original data, we train a diagnostic classifier and extract instance-wise explanations for the classifier's decisions.

The contribution of gene-by-environment (GxE) interactions for many human traits and diseases is poorly characterized. We propose a Bayesian whole-genome regression model for joint modeling of main genetic effects and GxE interactions. The method is called LEMMA (Linear Environment Mixed Model Analysis)

Modeling how individuals evolve over time is a fundamental problem in the natural and social sciences. Existing datasets are often cross-sectional with each individual observed only once. Motivated by the study of human aging, we present an interpretable latent-variable model.

Study of 461 563 participants from the UK Biobank. During a median follow-up of 8.1 years, 2 233 dementia cases were recorded. Individuals with diabetes had higher risk of all-cause dementia. Risk increased with increasing duration of diabetes.

Although snoring is common in the general population, its aetiology has been largely understudied. We identify 42 genome-wide significant loci, with an SNP-based heritability estimate of 10%. Gene-based associations identify 173 genes, including DLEU7, MSRB3 and POC5.

Retinal detachment (RD) is a serious and common condition, but genetic studies to date have been hampered by the small size of the assembled cohorts. In the UK Biobank data set, where RD was ascertained by self-report or hospital records, genetic correlations between RD and high myopia or cataract operation were 0.46 and 0.44. Replication in the 23andMe data set firmly establishes six RD risk loci.

Insulin-like growth factor-1 (IGF-1) is involved in several processes relevant to carcinogenesis. We used 416 single-nucleotide polymorphisms associated with serum IGF-1 levels to assess the potential causal associations between this hormone and site-specific cancers through Mendelian randomization. The odds ratio (OR) per standard deviation increase of IGF- 1 levels was 1.11 (95% confidence interval [CI] 1.01-1.22; P = .03) in UK Biobank.

Processed meat and high sodium intake are common in Western diet. objective was to examine their independent effects on the risk of colorectal cancer (CRC) We performed both observational analysis with UK Biobank and genetic analysis with Mendelian randomization.

Gene-based association tests aggregate genotypes across multiple variants for each gene. They provide an interpretable gene-level analysis framework for genome-wide association studies (GWAS) Most GWAS associations to date are non-coding. Identifying causal genes from regulatory associations remains challenging.

Large scale neuroimaging datasets present the possibility of providing normative distributions for a wide variety of neuroim imaging markers. A major challenge is our current poor ability to integrate measures across different large-scale datasets. Here we explore the harmonisation of white matter hyperintensity (WMH) measures across two major studies of healthy elderly populations.

Integration of genome-wide association studies (GWAS) and expression quantitative trait loci (eQTL) studies is needed to improve our understanding of the biological mechanisms underlying GWAS hits. Gene-level association methods such as PrediXcan can prioritize candidate targets. However, limited eQTL sample sizes and absence of relevant developmental and disease context restrict our ability to detect associations.

We evaluated whether the association between cigarette smoking and dementia risk is modified by genetic predisposition including apolipoprotein E (APOE) genotype and polygenic risk. We included 193,198 UK Biobank participants aged 60-73 years without dementia at baseline. Of non-APOE-&#949;4 carriers, 0.89% (95% CI 0.73-1.08%) current smokers developed dementia compared with 0.49% of never smokers.

Alcohol consumption and genetic risk for Alzheimer disease (AD) are among many factors known to be associated with brain structure in cognitively healthy adults. We hypothesized that there is an interaction effect of alcohol consumption and a 33-SNP AD polygenic risk score (PRS) on the cortical thickness of brain regions. We found a significant, positive association with AD Cortical Thickness Signature among high-risk subjects.

Both lifestyle and genetic factors confer risk for cardiovascular diseases, type 2 diabetes, and dyslipidemia. The interactions between these 2 groups of risk factors were not comprehensively understood due to previous poor estimation of genetic risk. We developed enhanced polygenic risk scores (PRS) and systematically investigated multiplicative and additive interactions between PRS and lifestyle.

Mendelian randomization has been previously used to estimate the effects of binary and ordinal categorical exposures-e.g. Type 2 diabetes or educational attainment defined by qualification-on outcomes. We show that a higher educational-attainment PGS is strongly associated with lower smoking initiation and higher odds of glasses use at age 15&#x2009;years. These associations were replicated in sibling models.

We combined genome-wide and metabolome-wide datasets generated from large-scale cohorts. Five trauma-response traits ascertained in the UK Biobank (52,816)

Statins, PCSK9 inhibitors and ezetimibe have pleiotropic effects on ischemic heart disease (IHD) via testosterone in men or women. Using previously published genetic instruments we conducted a sex-specific univariable and multivariable Mendelian randomization study in the UK Biobank.

 Epidemiological studies report increased comorbidity between depression and autoimmune diseases. We investigated the evidence for pleiotropy between these traits in the UK Biobank. The prevalence of depression was significantly higher in autoimmune cases than in controls.

We tested the association between schizophrenia polygenic risk scores (PRSs) and behavioural traits in the UK Biobank. Higher schizophrenia PRSs were associated with a range of traits, including lower verbal-numerical reasoning and higher nervous feelings. We follow-up the risk-taking association, hypothesising that the association may be due to a genetic propensity for risk- taking.
