Non-invasive retinal fundus imaging enables evaluation of the microvascular network and may offer insight to systemic risk associated with CKD. Microvascular parameters were quantified from macula-centred fundus images.

Study included 323,373 participants, free of terminated healthspan at baseline. Four sleep behaviors (insomnia/sleeplessness, napping, daytime sleepiness) were self-reported and measured on Likert scales.

We conducted a two-sample Mendelian randomization study to explore the associations of iron status with overall cancer and 22 site-specific cancers. Genetically predicted iron status was positively associated with liver cancer and inversely associated with brain cancer.

Study examines whether neuroticism is differentially associated with risk of incident Alzheimer's disease (AD), vascular dementia (VD), and frontotemporal dementia (FTD) Participants from the UK Biobank (N = 401,422) completed a self-report neuroticism scale in 2006-2010.

UK Biobank baseline data ( n  = 280,183, 48.3% female) were used to examine the associations between alcohol consumption with body mass index (BMI) and body fat percentage. Compared to those who never drink wines, drinkers of these alcoholic beverages had lower BMI. Beer and spirits drinkers had higher BMI compared to never drinkers of beer and spirits.

The current study found causal detrimental effects of T2DM on several cancers. Genetically predicted fasting insulin levels were positively associated with cancers of the uterus, kidney, pancreas, and lung. There was limited evidence supporting causal associations between fasting glucose and cancer.

Most existing analysis methods for genome-wide association studies (GWAS) perform only univariate regression. We extend and efficiently implement iterative hard thresholding (IHT) for multiple regression, treating all SNPs simultaneously. In our simulations, IHT recovers up to 30% more true predictors than SNP-by-SNP association testing.

Overweight/obese participants who reported alcohol consumption above the guidelines had a greater HR for liver disease incidence and mortality than normal weight individuals. The results for the associations of alcohol consumption and WC with ALD, NAFLD and liver disease mortality were similar.

Little is known about the relation between the long-term joint exposure to various ambient air pollutants and the incidence of heart failure (HF) This study included 432 530 participants free of HF, atrial fibrillation, or coronary heart disease in the UK Biobank study. All participants were enrolled from 2006 to 2010 and followed up to 2018.

Study was a bidirectional two-sample Mendelian randomisation (MR) analysis. It found increased kidney function was significantly associated with increased FEV 1 /FVC z-scores. The PGS for increased eGFR showed a significant association with a reduced risk.

Large copy-number variants (CNVs) are strongly associated with both developmental delay and cancer. We used microarray data from UK Biobank to investigate the prevalence and penetrance of large autosomal CNVs and chromosomal aneuploidies. There was no evidence of mosaicism in the blood for many of these large CNVs.

Restless legs syndrome (RLS) is a common neurological sensorimotor disorder. We report findings from a meta-analysis of genome-wide association studies of RLS. At four of the 22 RLS loci, cis-eQTL analysis indicates a causal impact on gene expression.

AAM is a highly polygenic puberty trait associated with various diseases later in life. Both AAM and diseases associated with puberty timing vary by race or ethnicity. The majority of GWAS of AAM have been performed in European ancestry women. We analysed a total of 38 546 women who did not have predominantly European ancestry backgrounds.

A growing number of genetic loci have been shown to influence individual predisposition to type 2 diabetes (T2D) Despite longstanding interest, the ability to detect significant gene-gene interaction (GGI) effects has been limited to date. We combined recent advances in the fine-mapping of causal T2D risk variants with the increased sample size available within UK Biobank.

Psoas muscle measurements are frequently used as markers of sarcopenia and predictors of health. Manually measured cross-sectional areas are most commonly used, but there is a lack of consistency regarding the position of the measurement. We have developed a fully automated method to measure iliop soas muscle volume. Magnetic resonance images were obtained from the UK Biobank for 5000 participants.

Genome-wide association study (GWAS) on 477,522 individuals revealed five loci significantly associated with same-sex sexual behavior. All tested genetic variants accounted for 8 to 25% of variation in same- sex sexual behavior, but only partially overlapped between males and females.

Machine learning model predicts glaucomatous optic nerve head features from color fundus photographs. Model used to predict vertical cup-to-disc ratio (VCDR) in 65,680 Europeans in the UK Biobank. A GWAS of ML-based VCDR identified 299 independent genome-wide significant hits in 156 loci.

The human cerebral hemispheres show a left-right asymmetrical torque pattern, which has been claimed to be absent in chimpanzees. The functional significance and developmental mechanisms are unknown. Here, we carried out the largest-ever analysis of global brain shape asymmetry in magnetic resonance imaging data.

In large population studies such as the UK Biobank (UKBB), quality control of the acquired images by visual assessment is unfeasible. We apply a recently developed fully-automated quality control pipeline for cardiac MR (CMR) images to the first 19,265 short-axis (SA) cine stacks from the UKBB.

In the present study, we performed an exome-wide investigation of the burden of rare disease-causing variants for major depressive disorder (MDD) using 16,702 samples from UK biobank. Gene-based association analysis and candidate gene prioritization analysis indicated that FOXH1 have significant association with MDD.

Genome-wide association studies (GWAS) have identified thousands of genetic variants that are associated with complex traits. A stringent significance threshold is required to identify robust genetic associations. Leveraging relevant auxiliary covariates has the potential to boost statistical power to exceed the significance threshold.

The accuracy of polygenic risk scores (PRSs) to predict complex diseases increases with the training sample size. PRSs are generally derived based on summary statistics from large meta-analyses of multiple genome-wide association studies (GWASs) It is now common for researchers to have access to large individual-level data as well as the UK Biobank data.

CliP (Correlated Liability Predictors) is a method to detect heterogeneity in single GWAS cohorts. It calculates a weighted sum of correlations between SNPs contributing to a PRS on the case/control liability scale. We apply CLiP to heterogeneity detection in schizophrenia cohorts totaling > 50, 000 cases and controls.

 genetic predisposition for complex traits often acts through multiple tissues at different time points during development. Here we describe a statistical approach that leverages tissue-specific expression quantitative trait loci (eQTLs) corresponding to tissue- specific genes. We show that our approach can predict the relevant tissue accurately and can cluster individuals according to their tissue- Specific genetic architecture.

There is increasing evidence that many risk loci found using genome-wide association studies are molecular quantitative trait loci. Here we introduce a new set of functional annotations based on causal posterior probabilities of fine-mapped molecular cis-QTLs. We show that these annotations are more strongly enriched for heritability across 41 diseases and complex traits.

The large majority of variants identified by GWAS are non-coding. Existing high-throughput computational predictors have lacked large gold standard sets of regulatory variants for training and validation. Here, we leverage a set of 14,807 putative causal eQTLs in humans. We use 6121 features to directly train a predictor of whether a variant modifies nearby gene expression.

It is unclear how to best combine case-control status and family history of disease. We developed an association method based on posterior mean genetic liabilities under a liability threshold model. LT-FH was 63% (standard error (s.e.) 6%) more powerful than GWAS.

Genetic predisposition to low birth weight and childhood obesity were associated with higher risk of adult T2D. These excess risks were attenuated by adherence to a healthy lifestyle in adulthood, particularly among those at high genetic risk of childhood obesity.

We conducted the first large-scale general population study on lifestyle risk factors (smoking, physical inactivity, obesity, and excessive alcohol intake) for COVID-19. Participants were 387,109 men and women (56.4 +/- 8.8 yr; 55.1% women) residing in England.

Genome-wide association studies (GWAS) have recurrently associated sequence variation nearby LIN28B with pubertal timing, growth and disease. This study sought to elucidate the mechanisms behind these associations. Using CRISPR-Cas9 technology, we first generated lin28b knockout (KO) zebrafish. Compared to controls, the KO fish showed both accelerated growth tempo and reduced adult size.

To efficiently transform genetic associations into drug targets requires evidence that a particular gene, and its encoded protein, contribute causally to a disease. We employ a three-step proteome-by-phenome Mendelian Randomization (MR) approach. Step 2 yielded 38 proteins that significantly predicted variation in traits and diseases in 509 instances.

Comorbidities including ischemic heart disease (IHD) worsen outcomes after SARS-CoV-2 infections. High lipoprotein(a) [Lp(a)] concentrations are a strong risk factor for IHD and possibly for thromboembolic events.

Tobacco smoking is the leading cause of preventable death globally. Smoking quantity is influenced both by the age of onset of regular smoking (AOS) and by genetic factors, including a strong effect of the nonsynonymous single-nucleotide polymorphism rs16969968. A previous study by Hartz et al. reported an interaction between these two factors.

Carotid artery atherosclerotic disease (CAAD) is a risk factor for stroke. We used a genome-wide association (GWAS) approach to discover genetic variants associated with CAAD in participants in the electronic Medical Records and Genomics (eMERGE) Network. We identified adult CAAD cases and controls without evidence of stenosis from electronic health records at eight eMERGE sites.

A total of 158,444 subjects from UK Biobank were used in this study. We found negative associations of long-term antibiotic use during early life with remembrance (p value=1.74 Ã— 10-6, b = -0.10) and intelligence. We also found positive associations with anxiety and depression.

Women in the UK Biobank age 40 to 69 years who reported &#8805;1 live birth were included. Of 220,024 women included, 2,808 (1.3%) had prior HDP. Women with HDP had elevated arterial stiffness indexes and greater prevalence of chronic hypertension.

Survivors of aneurysmal subarachnoid haemorrhage (aSAH) frequently suffer from cognitive dysfunction. The aim of this study was to assess the characteristics of cognitive dysfunction following aSAH and explore whether cognitive deficits mediate employment outcome.

 weak grip strength is associated with a range of adverse health outcomes. The factors associated with change in grip strength in mid-life remain to be fully determined. We used data from 44,315 UK Biobank participants.

Study included 283 657 participants in paid employment or self-employed without AF and 276 009 participants free of CHD, stroke, and HF at baseline in the UK Biobank. During a median follow-up of 10.4 years, 5777 incident AF cases were documented. Usual or permanent night shifts were associated with the highest risk.

The identification of disease alleles underlying human autoinflammatory diseases can provide important insights into the mechanisms that maintain neutrophil homeostasis. Here, we focused our attention on generalized pustular psoriasis (GPP), a potentially life-threatening disorder presenting with cutaneous and systemic neutrophilia.

Delirium is common in older adults, especially following hospitalization. Low vitamin D levels may be associated with increased delirium risk. We used time-to-event models to estimate hazard ratios (HRs) and 95% confidence intervals (CIs)

High levels of testosterone have been associated with better lung function in cross-sectional population-based studies. We studied 5114 men and 5467 women in the UK Biobank with high-quality spirometry at baseline (2006-2010) and 8.4 years later. Men with higher levels of TT had higher FEV 1 (27.56 mL per interquartile range increase TT) and FVC (48.06 mL, 95% CI 22.07-74.06) at baseline. In women, higher FAI and cFT levels were associated with lower lung function.

The COVID-19 pandemic has created an urgent need for robust, scalable monitoring tools supporting stratification of high-risk patients. This research aims to develop and validate prediction models. The model design and feature selection enables utility in outpatient settings.

Whole-exome sequencing data derived from 1181 female breast cancer patients within the UK Biobank was collected. We found feature genes (n = 50) regarding total mutation burden using the long short-term memory model. Then, we developed the XGBoost survival model with selected feature genes.

Polygenic prediction has the potential to contribute to precision medicine. Clumping and thresholding (C+T) is a widely used method to derive polygenic scores. We find that optimizing over these four hyper-parameters improves the predictive performance of C+T in both simulations and real data applications.

Pleiotropy (i.e., genes with effects on multiple traits) leads to genetic correlations between traits and contributes to the development of many syndromes. Identifying variants with pleiotropic effects on health-related traits can improve the biological understanding of gene action and disease etiology.

Maternal smoking (MS) is associated with low birthweight (BW) but adult obesity in offspring. It remains unknown whether it modifies offspring's genetic susceptibility to obesity on BW, adult body weight, and birth-to-adulthood body weight tracking pattern.

Meat consumption has been cross-sectionally associated with dementia risk. Specific amounts and types related to risk of incident dementia remain poorly understood. We aimed to investigate associations between meat consumption and risk of dementia in the UK Biobank cohort.

Deletions spanning the STS (steroid sulfatase) gene at Xp22.31 are associated with X-linked ichthyosis, corneal opacities, testicular maldescent, cardiac arrhythmia, and higher rates of developmental and mood disorders. The consequences of duplication of the same genomic region have not been systematically assessed in large or adult samples.

In clinical applications, using erroneous segmentations of medical images can have dramatic consequences. Current approaches dedicated to medical image segmentation automatic quality control do not predict segmentation quality at slice-level (2D), resulting in sub-optimal evaluations. Our 2D-based deep learning method simultaneously performs quality control at 2D and 3D levels for cardiovascular MR image segmentations.

Rare monogenic disorders of the primary cilium, termed ciliopathies, are characterized by extreme presentations of otherwise common diseases. We performed association studies of 16,874 common genetic variants across 122 ciliary genes. 101 statistically significant associations were identified across 42 of the 122 examined ciliopathy genes.

There is evidence that lower height is associated with a higher risk of coronary artery disease (CAD) and increased risk of type 2 diabetes (T2D) It is not clear though whether these associations are causal, direct or mediated by other factors. Here we show that one standard deviation higher genetically determined height (~6.5 cm) is causally associated with 16% decrease in CAD risk. We observe no direct causal effect of height on the risk of T2D.

Recent analyses have shown educational attainment to be associated with a number of health outcomes. This association may, in part, be due to an effect of educational attainment on smoking behaviour. In this study, we apply a multivariable Mendelian randomisation design to determine whether the effect is due to educational attainment or general cognitive ability.

Gut microbiota GWAS in 1126 twin pairs from the TwinsUK study were used as exposure data. The gut microbiota were classified at family, genus, and species levels. Results of MR analyses provided evidence of a causal association between 3 microbiota features and TFM.

How insulin-like growth factor-1 (IGF-1) is related to OA is not well understood. We determined relationships between IGF-1 and hospital-diagnosed hand, hip and knee OA in UK Biobank, using Mendelian randomization (MR) to determine causality. Using 1SMR, we found strong evidence for an increased risk of hip [odds ratio per. s.d. increase&#x2009;=&#X2009;1.21, 2.01] and knee [1.30 (1.07, 1.58)] OA with increasing IGF- 1 concentration. By contrast, there was no evidence for a causal effect of IGF-one

Study aims to estimate the impact of obesity on annual inpatient healthcare costs in the UK using linked data from the UK Biobank and Hospital Episode Statistics (HES)

Study included 14,550 postmenopausal female participants in the UK Biobank. Earlier age at menopause was significantly and independently associated with smaller left ventricular end-diastolic volume and smaller stroke volume.

Education is inversely associated with cardiovascular disease (CVD) Several mediators of this have been established; however, a proportion of the protective effect remains unaccounted for. Mental health is a proposed mediator, but current evidence is mixed and subject to bias from confounding factors.

The UK Biobank (UKB) is a highly promising dataset for brain biomarker research into population mental health. In this study, we aimed to provide a shared foundation for UKB neuroimaging research into mental health with a focus on anxiety and depression.

We identified shared genetic determinants of Crohn's Disease (CD), a type of inflammatory bowel disease, and body height. The association of PRS-CD with height was replicated in UK Biobank (p = 1.1 Ã— 10-5) and an independent cohort of 510 CD cases and controls.

Smoking is a major heritable and modifiable risk factor for many diseases. Fourteen genetic loci have previously been associated with smoking behaviour-related traits. We tested up to 235,116 single nucleotide variants (SNVs) on the exome-array for association with smoking initiation, cigarettes per day, pack-years, and smoking cessation.

Rapid decline of glomerular filtration rate estimated from creatinine (eGFRcrea) is associated with severe clinical endpoints. We meta-analyzed 42 genome-wide association studies from the Chronic Kidney Diseases Genetics Consortium and United Kingdom Biobank. Seven independent variants were identified across six loci for Rapid3 and/or CKDi25. Individuals at high compared to those at low genetic risk had a 1.20-fold increased risk of acute kidney injury.

Obesity is among the main determinants of nonalcoholic fatty liver disease progression towards severe liver disease (SLD) Risk factors for SLD in individuals with obesity have not been examined.

Biomarkers of low-grade inflammation have been associated with susceptibility to a severe infectious disease course, even when measured prior to disease onset. We investigated whether metabolic biomarkers measured by nuclear magnetic resonance (NMR) spectroscopy could be associated with. susceptibility to severe pneumonia and severe COVID-19.

Aging and obesity-related conditions seem to worsen the effect of Coronavirus Disease 2019 (COVID-19) We studied 353,299 UK Biobank participants from England with a mean age of 67.7 years. Vitamin D insufficiency and metabolic/obesity phenotypes were significantly associated with illness severity.

Study included 220 622 PCa-free men with baseline measurements of triglycerides (TGs), HDL-cholesterol (HDL), glycated hemoglobin (HbA1c), blood pressure (BP), and waist circumference (WC) A total of 5409 men in the study developed PCa during a median follow-up of 6.9 years. No associations were found with PCa risk and individual measurements of TG, HDL, BP, or WC. However, an inverse association was observed with elevated Hb a1c (&#8805;42 mmol/mol)

We identified 19 new low-frequency or rare (minor allele frequency (MAF)   5%) pLOF variant-metabolite associations. A small minority ( 400,000 subjects in UK Biobank - with metabolites.

Methylmercury (MeHg) is an environmental neurotoxin with human exposure mainly from dietary intake of contaminated fish. Exposure to MeHg has been implicated in neurological damage, but research on its role in cancers, specifically glioma, is limited. Toenail Hg was not found to be significantly associated withglioma risk.

White matter fiber tracts demonstrate heterogeneous vulnerabilities to aging effects. We estimated age-related differences in tract properties using UK Biobank diffusion magnetic resonance imaging data of 7167 47- to 76-year-old neurologically healthy people. The dominant pattern was lower generalized fractional anisotropy and higher axial diffusivity.

Midlife clustering of vascular risk factors has been associated with late-life dementia. causal effects of individual biological and lifestyle factors remain largely unknown. Adherence to the biological metrics of LS7 (blood pressure, cholesterol, glycemic status) was associated with lower incident dementia risk.

Migraine often co-occurs with gastrointestinal disorders, but the direction of a potential causal link is unclear. Study examined whether migraine is associated with irritable bowel syndrome (IBS), peptic ulcers, Helicobacter pylori (HP) infections, celiac disease, Crohn's disease and ulcerative colitis. Migraine was significantly associated with IBS.

Higher milk intake has been associated with a lower stroke risk, but not with risk of CHD. Residual confounding or reverse causation cannot be excluded. We estimated the causal association of milk consumption with stroke and CHD risk through instrumental variable (IV) and gene-outcome analyses.

Mitochondrial genome copy number (MT-CN) varies among humans and across tissues and is highly heritable. When measured by bulk DNA sequencing in blood, MT-CN may reflect a combination of the number of mitochondria per cell and cell-type composition. Using a Mendelian randomization framework, we show evidence that MT- CN measured in blood is causally related to insulin levels.

The prognosis for most patients with esophageal adenocarcinoma (EAC) is poor. Models developed to identify patients at risk for EAC and increase early detection have been developed based on data from case-control studies. We analyzed data from a prospective study to identify factors available to clinicians that identify individuals with a high absolute risk of EAC.

UK Biobank study looked at demographic, lifestyle, socioeconomic and clinical risk factors for COVID-19. Compared them to risk Factors for pneumonia and influenza in UK Biobanks. modifiable risk factors were higher body mass index and higher glycated haemoglobin (HbA1C) Smoking, slow walking pace as a proxy for physical fitness and use of blood pressure medications were also associated with lower risk.

The glucagon receptor is involved in maintaining blood glucose and amino acid homeostasis. Naturally occurring missense variants of G protein-coupled receptors with loss of function have been linked to metabolic disease in case studies and in animal experiments. We performed molecular pharmacological phenotyping of 38 variants with previously suggested clinical implications.

Mendelian randomization (MR) analyses are now possible to assess causal links between diurnal preference and food intake. We used genetic variants associated with a morning preference from a genome-wide association meta-analysis. We also examined potential causal effects on objectively captured response performances to email-administered 24-h diet recalls.

The increasing liver-related mortality calls for hepatic surveillance programs. We analyzed mortality data from 467,558 individuals recruited by the community-based UK Biobank. Only homozygous TM6SF2 mutation and SERPINA1 mutation conferred elevated overall mortality.

Brisk walking and a greater muscle strength have been associated with a longer life. Brisk walkers had a survival advantage over slow walkers, irrespective of the degree of engagement in other lifestyle behaviours, except for smoking.

Mosaic loss of Y chromosome (mLOY) is the most frequently detected somatic copy number alteration in leukocytes of men. Associations between mLOY and blood cell counts were assessed by multivariable linear models adjusted for relevant risk factors. Stratified analyses indicate these associations are independent of the effects of aging and smoking.

Magnesium is integral to many physiological processes. variations in its levels, even within the normal range, can have critical implications for health. We performed a two-sample Mendelian randomization and phenome-wide association study (MR-PheWAS) in the UK Biobank cohort.

Mendelian randomization (MR) is an established approach to evaluate the effect of an exposure on an outcome. We used PHESANT to test for the presence of effects of smoking heaviness, instrumented by genetic variant rs16969968, among never and ever smokers respectively. We ranked results by the strength of interaction between ever and never smokers. Novel results included a detrimental effect of heavier smoking on facial aging.

The clinical approval process is able to filter out medications whose utility does not offset their adverse drug reaction profile in humans. With a growing abundance of real-world evidence databases containing hundreds of thousands of patient records, it is now feasible to build machine learning models.

Brain age is becoming a widely applied imaging-based biomarker of neural aging and potential proxy for brain integrity and health. We estimated multimodal and modality-specific brain age in the Whitehall II (WHII) MRI cohort using machine learning. Cardiovascular risk factors, including high blood pressure, alcohol intake, and stroke risk score, were each associated with brain aging.

Most brain-age research uses structural neuroimaging to index brain volume. However, aging affects multiple aspects of brain structure and function, which can be examined using multimodality neuroim imaging. Brain-age paradigm is proving increasingly useful for exploring aging-related disease.

periodontitis is a multifactorial condition linked to increased risk of systemic diseases. This study aimed to identify disease trajectories of people with periodontitis using the process mining technique as a heuristic approach.

There is emerging interest in multimorbidity in type 2 diabetes. It can be either concordant (T2D related) or discordant (unrelated) This study explores associations between. total condition counts, baseline HbA1c, and all-cause. mortality in people with T2D.

We conducted PrediXcan analysis of hydrocephalus risk in ten neurological tissues and whole blood. Decreased expression of MAEL in the brain was significantly associated.

Cross-species translational approaches to human genomic analyses are lacking. The present study uses an integrative framework to investigate how genes associated with nicotine use in model organisms contribute to the genetic architecture of human tobacco consumption.

There is a paucity of longitudinal research examining how multiple lifestyle factors relate to depressed mood. We assessed relationships between 6 key lifestyle factors and depressed mood in individuals with a history of or current MDD and healthy controls (HCs) Cross-sectional analyses were performed in the UK Biobank baseline sample.

Weighted burden analysis has been used in exome-sequenced case-control studies to identify genes in which there is an excess of rare and/or functional variants associated with phenotype. Implementation in a ridge regression framework allows simultaneous analysis of all variants along with relevant covariates such as population principal components.

Biologically Annotated Neural Networks (BANNs) are a nonlinear probabilistic framework for association mapping in genome-wide association (GWA) studies. BANNs are feedforward models with partially connected architectures that are based on biological annotations. The software uses variational inference to provide posterior summaries.

Glaucoma is a disease characterized by progressive optic nerve degeneration. A polygenic risk score (PRS) enables effective risk stratification in unselected glaucomA cases. The PRS will facilitate the development of a personalized approach for earlier treatment of high-risk individuals.

T2DM has a substantial genetic component with an estimated heritability of 40-70%. More than 500 genetic loci have been associated with T2DM. One tool for risk assessment is genome-wide genetic risk scores (GRS)

Existing TWAS methods focus on analyzing one outcome trait at a time. Many complex traits are correlated with each other and share a common genetic basis. analyzing multiple traits jointly through multivariate analysis can potentially improve the power of TWASs.

Human variation in brain morphology and behavior are related and highly heritable. It is largely unknown to what extent specific features of brain morphology are genetically related. Here, we introduce a computationally efficient approach to estimate the genetic correlation between a large number of phenotypes simultaneously.

Whole brain estimation of the haemodynamic response function (HRF) is critical to get insight on the global status of the neurovascular coupling of an individual in healthy or pathological condition. Most of existing approaches in the literature works on task-fMRI data and relies on the experimental paradigm as a surrogate of neural activity.

Genetic evidence of disease association has often been used as a basis for selecting of drug targets for complex common diseases. The propagation of genetic evidence through gene or protein interaction networks has been shown to accurately infer novel disease associations at genes for which no direct genetic evidence can be observed. An empirical test of the utility of combining these approaches for drug discovery has been lacking.

Neuroimaging PheWAS is a web-based system for searching over a wide variety of brain-wide imaging phenotypes to discover true system-level gene-brain relationships. This design features a user-friendly graphical user interface for anonymous data uploading, study definition and management.

Neuroticism is associated with poor health outcomes, but its contribution to the accumulation of health deficits in old age is largely unknown. We aimed to explore associations between neuroticism and frailty cross-sectionally and longitudinally, and to investigate the contribution of shared genetic influences.

Personality traits, such as neuroticism, are postulated to be robust predictors of health and health behaviours. To date neuroticism in emergency personnel has primarily been associated with adverse health outcomes. High neuroticism was positively associated with poorer subjective health outcomes in all emergency personnel.

Excessive alcohol consumption is one of the main causes of death and disability worldwide. Alcohol consumption is a heritable complex trait. We identified 46 new common loci and investigated their potential functional importance.

Migraine is the most common neurological cause of disability worldwide. Migraine heritability is estimated to up to 57%. Much of the genetic risk remains unaccounted for, especially in non-European ancestry populations.

Cardiovascular magnetic resonance (CMR) radiomics may capture subtle cardiac changes associated with these two diseases providing new insights into the brain-heart interactions. We extracted 446 shape, first-order, and texture radiomics features from three regions of interest in end-diastole and end-systole.

Individual differences in human perception of sweetness are partly due to genetics. Which genes are associated with the perception and the consumption of sweet substances remains unclear. The aim of this study was to verify previous reported associations within genes involved in the peripheral receptor systems and reveal novel loci.

European Working Group on Sarcopenia in Older People (EWGSOP) established a new operational definition and cut-off points for sarcopenia. The aim of this study was to compare the prevalence of sarc Openia and its associations with different health outcomes in the UK Biobank cohort.

SCN9A gene variants, in particular a c.1921A>T p.(Asn641Tyr) substitution, have been identified as a likely autosomal dominant cause of febrile seizures. The Amish community has seizure phenotypes indistinguishable from those associated with SCN1A.

For many traits, estimates of genetic effects may be inflated by passive gene-environment correlation. Biological offspring inherit both their genotypes and rearing environment from their parents. We found no evidence for inflation of heritability or polygenic scores in non-adoptees compared to adoptees for a range of body composition traits.

Upper respiratory tract infections are reportedly more frequent and more severe in individuals with lower vitamin D levels. Based on these findings, it has been suggested that vitamin D can prevent or reduce the severity of COVID-19. We used two-sample Mendelian randomisation (MR) and genome-wide association analysis (GWA) to assess the causal effect of vitamin D.

Genome-wide association studies (GWAS) have revealed that the genetic contribution to certain complex diseases is well-described by Fisher's infinitesimal model. Of 146 GWAS variants examined in a discovery sample of 228,423 individuals, only 8 had even nominal evidence of non-additive effects.

Visceral adipose tissue (VAT) plays an important role in the pathogenesis of insulin resistance (IR), prediabetes and type 2 diabetes. VAT volume alone might not be the best marker for insulin resistance and predi diabetes or diabetes, as a given VAT volume may impact differently on these metabolic traits based on body height, gender, age and ethnicity.

Pairwise comparison problems arise in many areas of science. This approach is very efficient for calling identical by descent (IBD) segments between all pairs of individuals in the UK Biobank dataset. This efficiency should extend to other methods of IBD calling.

There is a growing interest in fast and reliable assessment of abdominal visceral adipose tissue (VAT) volume for risk stratification of metabolic disorders. However, imaging based measurement of VAT is costly and limited by scanner availability. We aimed to develop equations to estimate abdominal VAT volume from simple anthropometric parameters.

Assumptions are made about the genetic model of single nucleotide polymorphisms (SNPs) when choosing a traditional genetic encoding. We present a novel and flexible encoding for genetic interactions, the elastic data-driven genetic encoding (EDGE) EDGE outperformed the traditional encoding methods across 10%, 30%, and 50% minor allele frequencies (MAFs)

Study looked at genetics of weighted functional brain network graph theory measures. 18,445 participants of the UK Biobank (44-80 years) showed low heritability. One genome-wide significant locus was associated with strength of somatomotor and limbic networks.

DNA methylation and gene expression are known to play important roles in the etiology of human diseases such as prostate cancer (PCa) However, it has not yet been possible to incorporate this information into polygenic risk scores (PRSs) Here, we aimed to develop and validate an improved PRS for PCa risk by incorporating genetically predicted gene expression and DNA methylation.

One region suggested to play a key role in the pathophysiology of obesity is the nucleus accumbens (NAcc) We performed a meta-analysis of findings regarding NAcc volume and overweight/obesity. We additionally examined whether grey matter volume in the NAcc and other mesolimbic areas depends on the longitudinal trajectory of obesity.

We used data from the UK Biobank to assess the risk of COVID-19 mortality associated with various anthropometric measures in women and men. A higher body mass index (BMI), waist circumference, waist-to-hip ratio and waist- to-height ratio were each associated with a greater risk of death in both sexes. The relative effects of a higher BMI on COVID19 mortality may be stronger in women than men.

Obesity has been associated with increased risk of accelerated cognitive decline and dementia, which suggests underlying neurobiological changes. To investigate the associations between obesity and brain structure (overall and regional brain volumes, and white matter microstructure) assessed at MRI, 12 087 participants underwent 3.0-T multiparametric brain imaging.

Obesity is an emerging risk factor for coronavirus disease-2019. Simple measures of physical fitness, such as self-reported walking pace, may also be important risk markers. Slow walkers had the highest risk regardless of obesity status.

Sleep is vital for all physical and mental health. Many sleep-related studies depend on self-reported sleep measurements, which have limitations. This study aims to investigate the association of physical activity and sociodemographic characteristics including age, gender, coffee intake and social status.

The study was a cross-sectional dietary investigation using UK Biobank data and MR analysis. Higher vegetable intake was cross-sectionally associated with a higher eGFR and lower odds of CKD. The association with CKD remained nonsignificant.

Around 10% to 15% of COPD burden can be attributed to workplace exposures. Little is known about the role of different airborne occupational pollutants (AOP) High exposure to vapours increased the risk of occupational AFO by 26%.

Current consensus is to combine a functional measure with muscle quantity to assess/confirm sarcopenia. However, the proper body size adjustment for muscle quantity is debated. Further, functional measures are not muscle-specific or sensitive to etiology. For effective detection/treatment/follow-up, muscle- specific biomarkers linked to function are needed.

We investigate the behavior of the Lasso for selecting invalid instruments in linear instrumental variables models. Invalid instruments are such that they fail the exclusion restriction and enter the model as explanatory variables. We propose a median estimator that is consistent when less than 50% of the instruments are invalid. This estimator can be used for adaptive Lasso estimation.

Quantitative traits analyzed in Genome-Wide Association Studies (GWAS) are often nonnormally distributed. For such traits, association tests based on standard linear regression are subject to reduced power and inflated type I error in finite samples. Applying the rank-based inverse normal transformation (INT) has become common practice in GWAS.

There is no single widely-accepted standard pipeline for analyzing functional connectivity. We investigated strengths and short-comings, both independently and jointly, of the following measures. We have run more than 9000 different pipeline variants on a total of &#8764;14000 individuals.

It is unknown how sequential drug patterns convey information on a patient's health status and treatment guidelines rarely account for this. In this cohort study, we used 24 years of data (1.1 billion prescriptions) from the Danish prescription registry to model the risk of sequentially redeeming a drug after another.

Previous small-scale studies have found that oral antidiabetic therapy is associated with sleep difficulties among patients with type 2 diabetes (T2D) Here, we used data from 11 806 T2D patients from the UK Biobank baseline investigation.

The aim was to investigate whether there are underlying functional connectivity differences between humans that relate to food reward. In 37 286 humans from the UK Biobank, resting-state functional connectivities of the orbitofrontal cortex (OFC), especially with the anterior cingulate cortex, were positively correlated with the liking for sweet foods.

Many phenotypes more naturally take ordered, discrete values. Dichotomizing can lead to a range of arbitrary cutoff values, generating inconsistent, hard to interpret results. Using multinomial regression ignores trait value hierarchy and potentially loses power. This approach increases power and leads to more interpretable results.

Parent-of-origin effects (POE) exist when there is differential expression of alleles inherited from the two parents. A genome-wide scan for POE on DNA methylation in 5,101 individuals identifies 733 independent methylation CpGs potentially influenced by POE. Methylation variation at 14 of the POE-influenced CpGS is associated with multiple metabolic traits.

Human longevity is moderately heritable and is influenced by both genetic and environmental factors. There remains considerable uncertainty regarding its relationship with brain aging. We found lower volumes of WMHs to be significantly associated with longer parental life span in the discovery and replication samples.

Previous studies of the association between parity and long-term cognitive changes have focused on women. We found that in both females and males, having offspring was associated with a faster response time and fewer mistakes made in the visual memory task.

We perform unsupervised analysis of image-derived shape and motion features extracted from 3,822 cardiac Magnetic resonance imaging (MRIs) of the UK Biobank. After analysis, we identify 2 small clusters that probably correspond to 2 pathological categories.

Autism spectrum disorder (ASD) and schizophrenia have been conceived as partly opposing disorders in terms of systemizing vs. empathizing cognitive styles. Left-right asymmetry of the brain is an important aspect of its organization that shows average differences between the sexes and can be altered in both ASD and schizophrenia. Polygenic risks for the two disorders were positively correlated and both were higher in females compared to males.

We used data from the UK Biobank linked to laboratory confirmed test results for SARS-CoV-2 infection and mortality data from Public Health England between March 16 and July 26, 2020. We derived a multimorbidity index including: angina, asthma, cancer, chronic kidney disease, heart failure, hypertension, myocardial infarction, atrial fibrillation, peripheral vascular disease and stroke.

75.7% of participants with RA had multimorbidity. These individuals were at increased risk of all-cause mortality and MACE. Of the comorbid LTCs studied, osteoporosis was most strongly associated with adverse outcomes.

Single nucleotide polymorphism-based genetic risk score (GRS) has been developed and validated for prostate cancer (PCa) risk assessment. As GRS is population standardized, its value can be interpreted as a relative risk to the general population. A prospective cohort was derived from the UK Biobank where 208 685 PCa diagnosis-free participants were followed.

Perinatal light may imprint the circadian timing system, subsequently affect later life physiology, and possibly disease risk. We combined individual time-of-year of birth and corresponding latitude to determine perinatal photoperiod characteristics for UK Biobank participants. Increased 3 rd  trimester relative range was associated with decreased odds of DM (OR 0.63 95%CI 0.49-0.81) in the NEP group.

Observational research suggests that periodontitis affects pulmonary function. However, observational studies are subject to confounding and reverse causation. We used Mendelian randomization to assess the potential causal association.

Copy-number variations (CNVs) represent a significant proportion of the genetic differences between individuals. Many CNVs associate causally with syndromic disease and clinical outcomes. We characterize the landscape of copy-number variation and their phenome-wide effects in a sample of 472,228 array-genotyped individuals.

Childhood obesity is reported to be associated with the risk of many diseases in adulthood. We aimed to systematically assess the causal associations between childhood body mass index (BMI) and various adult traits/diseases. We found that higher childhood BMI was associated with low calorie density food intake.

Data-driven discovery of patterns of population variability in the brain has the potential to be extremely valuable for early disease diagnosis and understanding the brain. The resulting patterns can be used as imaging-derived phenotypes (IDPs)

For pancreatic cancer, traditional methods for screening have been largely unsuccessful in identifying high-risk individuals in advance of disease progression. Electronic health records (EHR) linked to genetic profiles provide an opportunity to integrate multiple sources of patient information for risk prediction and stratification.

Anhedonia is a core symptom of multiple psychiatric disorders and has been associated with alterations in brain structure. Few studies have explored the association between genetic loading for anhedonia and structural brain imaging phenotypes. We found that state anhedoni was significantly associated with reduced total grey matter volume.

Hyperlipidemia is traditionally considered a risk factor for type 2 diabetes (T2D) Evidence has emerged from statin trials and candidate gene investigations suggesting that lower LDL cholesterol (LDL-C) increases T2D risk. We sought to more comprehensively examine the phenotypic and genotypic relationships of LDL-C with T1D.

We analysed data from 47,456 premenopausal and 126,704 postmenopausal women in UK Biobank. Physical activity was self-reported at baseline, and at resurvey in a subsample of 6443 participants.

Physical activity may reduce the risk of some types of cancer in men. Biological mechanisms may involve changes in hormone concentrations. However, this relationship is not well established. We aimed to investigate associations of physical activity with circulating hormones.

Previous studies have identified physical activity as an important lifestyle factor in the pathogenesis of chronic liver diseases (CLD) It is unknown whether physical activity affects the risk of liver disease development in the general population. We analysed data from 96,688 participants that recorded their physical activity through the use of a wrist accelerometer. Walking an additional 2,500 steps per day was associated with 44% reduction in liver disease progression.

Physical activity (PA) is recommended as one of the main lifestyle behaviours. We assessed the benefits of PA on mortality and life expectancy in people with and without multimorbidity. Leisure-time PA and total PA were measured by questionnaire.

It is unclear what combinations of physical capability markers used to define sarcopenia have the strongest associations with health outcomes. 469,830 UK Biobank participants were included in this prospective study. Outcomes studied were all-cause mortality, as well as incidence and mortality from cardiovascular disease (CVD), respiratory disease and chronic obstructive pulmonary disease.

Mean Platelet Volume (MPV), a cell trait partially associated with markers of platelet activity, is more commonly available. We investigated the association of metabolic syndrome and diabetes with platelet aggregation to three physiological agonists, ADP, collagen, and epinephrine, in the Framingham Heart Study Offspring cohort. After a median of 18.1 years follow-up, no Platelet aggregation trait was associated with increased risk of diabetes ( n  = 344 cases).

Osteoporosis and obesity are two severe complex diseases threatening public health worldwide. Both diseases are under strong genetic determinants as well as genetically correlated. We identified one novel locus, 17q21.31, which may have pleiotropic effects to both hip BMD and TBFM. KIF18B, C1QL1, and PRPF19 were highlighted as candidate genes.

We identified 2 novel loci at 2q37.1 and 6q26 for bone mineral density and bone size. Findings provide insight into common genetic architecture underlying both traits.

 Epilepsy is clinically heterogeneous, and neurological or psychiatric comorbidities are frequently observed in patients. It has not been tested whether common risk variants for generalized or focal epilepsy are enriched in people with other disorders or traits related to brain or cognitive function. Here, we perform two brain-focused phenome association studies of polygenic risk scores (PRS) for generalized epilepsy and focal epilepsy for 334,310 European-ancestry individuals of the UK Biobank.

We analyzed the genomic architecture of neuroanatomical diversity using magnetic resonance imaging and single nucleotide polymorphism (SNP) data. SNPs captured from 40% to 54% of regional brain volume variance. Chromosomal length correlated with the amount of phenotypic variance captured, r ~ 0.64 on average.

Telomeres, the end fragments of chromosomes, play key roles in cellular proliferation and senescence. Here we characterize the genetic architecture of naturally occurring variation in leukocyte telomere length (LTL) We identify causal links between LTL and biomedical phenotypes in 472,174 well-characterized UK Biobank participants.

Polygenic scores (PGS) for eight common diseases, disorders, or traits, including psychiatric disorders, were calculated in 274 participants (125 mood disorder cases) who each reported three or four grandparents born in the community. Ancestry-matched controls were selected from the UK Biobank (UKB; three sets of N = 1,822 each) The mean PGSs were significantly higher in the U.S. community for major depression, bipolar disorder, and schizophrenia. The results are consistent with enrichment of polygenic risk factors for psychiatric disorders in this community.

Using polygenic risk scores (PRS) from a European-ancestry genome-wide association study in generalized and focal epilepsy, we quantified common genetic burden. Across 8386 patients with epilepsy and 622 212 population controls, we found and replicated significantly higher GE-PRS in patients with generalized epilepsy compared to patients with focal epilepsy. European ancestry-derived PRS did not predict generalized epilepsy or focal epilepsy in Japanese-ANCestry individuals.

We examined whether polygenic risk scores (PRS) for consumption and problem subscales of the Alcohol Use Disorders Identification Test (AUDIT-C, AUDIT-P) in the UK Biobank (UKB; N = 121 630) correlate with alcohol outcomes in four independent samples. In COGA, AUDit-P PRS was associated with alcohol dependence, AUD symptom count, maximum drinks, and increased likelihood of onset of alcohol dependence.

Polygenic risk scores (PRS) provide an opportunity to understand risk factors since they reflect etiologic pathways from the entire genome. We tested the association of a CHD PRS with CHD and its traditional clinical risk factors amongst individuals with type 2 diabetes in UK Biobank.

Research has shown differences in subcortical brain volumes between participants with schizophrenia and healthy controls. None of these differences have been found to associate with schizophrenia polygenic risk. In a large sample (n = 14,701) of unaffected participants from the UK Biobank, we test whether schizophreniapolygenic risk scores (PRS) are limited to specific gene-sets. We compare associations with schizophrenia PRS at the whole genome level.

Polygenic risk models have led to significant advances in understanding complex diseases and their clinical presentation. While polygenic risk scores (PRS) can effectively predict outcomes, they do not generally account for disease subtypes or pathways which underlie within-trait diversity. Here, we introduce a latent factor model of genetic risk based on components from Decomposition of Genetic Associations (DeGAs)

A combination of healthy lifestyles is associated with lower risk of depression regardless of genetic risk. Data were obtained from the UK Biobank and consisted of 339,767 participants (37-73 years old) without depression between 2006 and 2010.

Organ-transplant recipients have an elevated risk of keratinocyte cancers. The top 20% PRS individuals had an absolute risk of 23%. The risk in the bottom 20% was similar to that in the general nontransplantee population. The BCC PRS improves prediction over and above the traditional skin cancer risk factors by 3%.

There is growing evidence that polygenic risk scores (PRSs) can identify individuals with elevated lifetime risk of coronary artery disease (CAD) Whether they can also be used to stratify the risk of subsequent events among those surviving a first CAD event remain uncertain, with possible biological differences between CAD onset and progression.

Genome-wide association studies have revealed numerous loci for kidney function (eGFR) The relationship between polygenic predictors of eGFR, risk of incident adverse kidney outcomes, and the plasma proteome is not known. We developed a genome-wide polygenic risk score (PRS) for eG FR. We then tested the association of the PRS with incident CKD, ESKD, kidney failure, and AKI.

Type 2 diabetes increases the risk of cardiovascular and renal complications. Early risk prediction could lead to timely intervention and better outcomes. Genetic information can be used to enable early detection of risk.

Solid organ transplant recipients (SOTRs) have elevated risks for basal cell carcinoma (BCC) and squamous cell carcinomas (SCC) We assessed whether polygenic risk scores can improve the prediction of BCC and SCC risks and multiplicity.

Osteoporosis and ischemic heart disease (IHD) represent important public health problems. Existing research suggests an association between the two conditions beyond that attributable to shared risk factors. In this study, we tested the association of bone speed of sound (SOS) from quantitative heel ultrasound with measures of arterial compliance from cardiovascular magnetic resonance.

Previous studies link obesity and components of metabolic health to increased hospitalizations and mortality of patients with COVID-19. We investigate whether metabolic health as measured by waist circumference, dyslipidemia, hypertension, type 2 diabetes, and systemic inflammation is related to increased infection and mortality rate.

Machine learning can be used to build proxy measures of psychological constructs. We built proxy measures by applying machine learning on multimodal MR images and rich sociodemographic information from the largest biomedical cohort to date: the UK Biobank.

The social brain hypothesis proposes that the complexity of human brains has coevolved with increasing complexity of social interactions in primate societies. The present study explored the possible relationships between brain morphology and the richness of more intimate 'inner' and wider 'outer' social circles.

We investigated associations between brain structure and anthropometric and body composition measures using brain magnetic resonance imaging. Anthropometric measures showed negative, nonlinear, associations with cerebellar/cortical gray matter, and brain stem structures. Adipose tissue measures, including liver fat and muscle fat infiltration, were negatively associated with cortical/cerebellum structures.

Maternal brain adaptations have been found across pregnancy and postpartum. Little is known about the long-term effects of parity on the maternal brain. Parous women showed less evidence of brain aging compared to their nulliparous peers.

Few prospective studies have evaluated the relation between fat-soluble vitamins and glioma risk. In 346,785 participants (444 cases) in UKB, associations with vitamin D were evaluated by Cox proportional hazards regression. In NHS (52 cases, 104 controls) and HPFS (32 cases, 64 controls), associations with 25(OH)D, vitamin A (retinol), and vitamin E were assessed using conditional logistic regression. Nonsignificant associations were observed for &#945;-tocopherol.

A model was trained on 84,743 retinal fundus photos from the UK Biobank dataset. The model performed significantly worse when foveal pathology was present in the external validation dataset. Automated machine learning (AutoML) may enable clinician-driven automated discovery of novel insights and disease biomarkers.

Study looked at risk of cancer for 367,703 individuals in the UK Biobank. Variants in the HMGCR gene region were associated with overall cancer risk. But variants in gene regions representing alternative lipid-lowering treatment targets were not. This suggests that statins reduce cancer risk through a cholesterol independent pathway.

Study aimed to determine whether risk prediction based on common genetic variants might enable stratification for CRC risk. Meta-analysis of 11 genome-wide association studies comprising 16 871 cases and 26 328 controls was performed. A weighted PRS of 116 CRC single nucleotide polymorphisms was found with the best predictive performance.

Both clinical and genetic factors drive the risk of venous thromboembolism. Whether clinically recorded risk factors and genetic variants can be combined into a clinically applicable predictive score remains unknown. Using Cox proportional-hazard models, we analyzed the association of risk factors.

Hospitalized COVID-19 patients tend to be older and frequently have hypertension, diabetes, or coronary heart disease. Preexisting diagnoses of dementia, type 2 diabetes, chronic obstructive pulmonary disease, pneumonia, depression, atrial fibrillation, and hypertension emerged as independent risk factors. Chronic kidney disease and asthma were risk factors for hospitalization in women but not men.

Coronavirus disease 2019 (COVID-19), a respiratory disease of unknown origin, has a high rate of morbidity and mortality. Individuals with mental disorders may have a higher risk of infection and worse clinical outcomes because of a variety of factors such as poorer general resilience and lower immune function.

Poorer performance on standard tests of pre-morbid cognitive function is related to an elevated risk of death from lower respiratory tract infections. But the link with coronavirus (COVID-19) mortality is untested. Participants in UK Biobank, aged 40 to 69 years at study induction (2006-10), were administered a reaction time test.

 Essential fructosuria (EF) is a benign, asymptomatic, autosomal recessive condition caused by loss-of-function variants in the ketohexokinase gene. Despite a basic understanding of the genetic and molecular basis of EF, relatively little is known about the long-term clinical consequences of these variants. We examined the frequency of keto hexokinase variants in a UK Biobank sample.

Uveitis describes intraocular inflammation of the uveal tract. It may occur in the absence of a predisposing underlying condition. An association with Multiple Sclerosis (MS) has been observed.

This cohort study examines the prevalence of hypertrophic cardiomyopathy in the UK Biobank population. The study was published in the British Journal of Cardiology.

Preserved ratio impaired spirometry (PRISm) is a precursor to chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD) Previous research has indicated that PRISm is associated with respiratory symptoms. We aimed to determine the prevalence, risk factors, clinical implications, and mortality of PRism in a large adult general population.

To identify candidate causal genes of asthma, we performed a genome-wide association study (GWAS) in UK Biobank. The GWAS reveals 72 asthma-associated loci from 116 independent significant variants (PGWAS)

The relationship between natural selection and phenotypic variation has been a long-standing challenge in human population genetics. We calculated a per-individual deleterious load score by summing the total number of derived alleles per individual after incorporating a weight that approximates strength of purifying selection. The load score amongst coding sites had an excess of nominally significant associations on many medical phenotypes.

Hypertension-associated cardiovascular events are particularly associated with elevated systolic blood pressure (SBP) in late life. Long-term interactions between SBP, diastolic BP (DBP) and arterial stiffness in development of late-life hypertensive phenotypes remain unclear. In 169 742 participants at baseline, ASI was more strongly associated with DBP than SBP.

Loneliness is linked to increased risk for Alzheimer's disease. Little is known about factors potentially contributing to adverse brain health in lonely individuals. We used data from 24,867 UK Biobank participants to investigate risk factors related to loneliness.

We investigated the associations of estimated free and total circulating testosterone and sex hormone-binding globulin (SHBG) with cancer risk in men and postmenopausal women. Risk was estimated using multivariable-adjusted Cox regression in up to 182 608 men and 122 112 women who were cancer-free at baseline. In men, higher free testosterone was associated with higher risks of melanoma and prostate cancer.

Study assesses prospective associations between vitamin D status and depression in middle-aged adults enrolled in the UK Biobank. Findings suggest both vitamin D deficiency and insufficiency might be risk factors for the development of new-onset depression.

Sleep duration was not associated with incident glioma in either the UKB or the NHS/HPFS cohorts. Results did not materially change after lagging 2 years, or after accounting for factors known to disrupt sleep.

Study: Better protein nutritional status may contribute to prevention of frailty. outcome measure was the Rockwood frailty index (FI) based on 49 deficits from 356,432 individuals (53.3% of them were women) In the full sample, genetically predicted serum total protein was inversely associated with FI.

A lack of genetic data across generations makes transgenerational Mendelian randomization (MR) difficult. We used UK Biobank and a novel proxy gene-by-environment MR to investigate effects of maternal smoking heaviness in pregnancy on offspring health. Each additional smoking-increasing allele in offspring (G1) was associated with a 0.018 kg lower birthweight in maternal (G0) smoking stratum.

Polygenic risk score (PRS) analyses have become an integral part of biomedical research. PRSice-2 is an efficient and scalable software program for automating PRS analyses on large-scale data.

Anxiety and depression are more important comorbidities of long-term cognitive change than diabetes and cardiovascular disease, and demographic factors. Findings suggest that psychiatric disorders may have a deleterious effect on long- term cognition.

Posttraumatic stress disorder (PTSD) and major depressive disorder (MDD) are commonly reported co-occurring mental health consequences of psychological trauma exposure. The disorders have high genetic overlap. Research suggests that trauma sensitivity has a heritable basis. We investigated whether sensitivity to trauma in those with MDD reflects a similar genetic component.

Schizophrenia is a highly heritable disorder with considerable phenotypic heterogeneity. Assessing genetic risk and psychotic-like experiences (PLEs) in non-clinical populations can offer valuable insights into symptom-associated brain mechanisms.

PWAS aggregates the signal of all variants jointly affecting a protein-coding gene. It assesses their overall impact on the protein's function using machine learning and probabilistic models.

The growing sample size of genome-wide association studies has facilitated the discovery of gene-environment interactions (GxE) We propose a maximum likelihood method to estimate the contribution of GxE to continuous traits. Applying our method to 32 traits in the UK Biobank reveals that GRSxE explains an additional 1.9%.

The proportion of variation in complex traits that can be attributed to non-additive genetic effects has been a topic of intense debate. Here, we present an efficient method to estimate the variation in a complex trait. We find that additive heritability on array SNPs is 21.86% while dominance heritability is 0.13%.

The thickness of the cerebral cortical sheet and its surface area are highly heritable traits. Despite large-scale efforts, the majority of their genetic determinants remain unknown. Our ability to identify causal genetic variants can be improved by employing brain measures that better map onto the biology we seek to understand.

Objective measures of physical activity (PA) derived from wrist-worn accelerometers are compared with traditional risk factors in terms of mortality prediction performance in the UK Biobank. Age was the best predictor of all-cause mortality.

Cardiovascular magnetic resonance (CMR) radiomics is a novel technique for advanced cardiac image phenotyping. In this paper, we assess, in the largest sample published to date, the performance of CMR radiomics models for identifying changes in cardiac structure and tissue texture due to cardiovascular risk factors. We evaluated five risk factor groups from the first 5,065 UK Biobank participants.

Inference of relationships from whole-genome genetic data of a cohort is a crucial prerequisite for genome-wide association studies. Current leading methods are based on pairwise comparisons, which may not scale up to very large cohorts (e.g., sample size >1 million) We propose an efficient relationship inference method, RAFFI.

iLASH is an algorithm based on similarity detection techniques. It shows equal or improved accuracy in simulations compared to current leading methods. It speeds up analysis by several orders of magnitude on genomic datasets. iLASH enables efficient analysis of very large-scale datasets.

IBIS is an IBD detector that locates long regions of allele sharing between unphased individuals. Phasing these with Beagle 5 takes 4.3 CPU days, followed by either Refined IBD or GERMLINE segment detection in 2.9 or 1.1 h. By comparison, IBIS finishes in 6.8 min with IBD2 functionality enabled: speedups of 805-946Ã— including phasing time.

Current IBD detection methods are not efficient at such a scale. RaPID achieves a time and space complexity linear to the input size and the number of reported IBDs. In UK Biobank, RaP ID identified 3,335,807 IBDâ€™s with a length &#8805; 10 cM among 223,507 male X chromosomes in 11 min.

Genome-wide association studies have identified numerous common genetic variants associated with spirometric measures of pulmonary function. We conducted a large-scale gene-smoking interaction meta-analysis on exonic rare and low-frequency variants involving 44,429 individuals of European ancestry.

Alterations in electrocardiographic (ECG) intervals are well-known markers for arrhythmia and sudden cardiac death (SCD) risk. We examined associations between low-frequency and rare coding variants with 5 routinely measured traits. We found that rare variants associated with population-based ECG intervals identify established monogenic SCD genes.

Using 200,000 UK Biobank (UKB) exomes, we assess the burden of ultra-rare, potentially pathogenic variants in the largest case/control cohort of predominantly mild CHD to date. We find an association with GATA6, a member of the GATA family of transcription factors that play an important role during heart development.

Protein-altering variants that are protective against human disease provide in vivo validation of therapeutic targets. We use genotyping data from UK Biobank (n = 337,151 unrelated White British individuals) and FinnGen (n + 176,899) to conduct a search for protein- altering variants conferring lower intraocular pressure (IOP)

UK Biobank contains detailed phenotypic data linked to medical records for approximately 500,000 participants. We studied relationships between rare protein-coding variants and 17,361 binary and 1,419 quantitative phenotypes. Gene-based collapsing analyses revealed 1,703 statistically significant gene-phenotype associations for binary traits.

Cardiovascular disease (CVD) is the leading cause of death in women and men. Biological and social factors differ between the sexes. The importance of CVD in women may be underestimated due to the higher age-specific rates in men.

Machine-learning methods classified movement behaviours accurately in free-living accelerometer data. Reallocating time from any behaviour to MVPA was associated with lower CVD risk. This should be promoted by interventions and guidelines.

Study included up to 434,900 UK Biobank participants aged 37-73 years. Recent caffeine drinking (yes/no in the last hour) was recorded during a physical assessment. No significant and consistent effect modification by age, sex, smoking, test time, habitual caffeine intake, or CMS was observed.

Up to 447 794 UK Biobank participants aged 37-73 years in 2006-2010 provided a non-fasting blood sample. Men and women reporting recent caffeine drinking had clinically and significantly higher glucose levels than those not recently drinking caffeine.

Several recent papers have reported strong signals of selection on European polygenic height scores. These analyses used height effect estimates from the GIANT consortium and replication studies. Here, we describe a new analysis based on the the UK Biobank (UKB), a large, independent dataset. We find that the signals ofselection using UKB effect estimates are strongly attenuated or absent.

Study used UK Biobank data to estimate dietary patterns of healthy individuals. Data on fibre content in different foods were used to calculate the reference values which were then calibrated using real-world data on total fibre intake.

Diet may affect susceptibility of the inner ear to noise and age-related effects that lead to tinnitus and hearing loss. Study used complementary single nutrient and dietary pattern analysis based on statistical grouping of usual dietary intake in a large population study sample.

Study looked at the association of rheumatoid arthritis (RA) with pulmonary function measures on spirometry among subjects in the UK Biobank. RA was associated with lower FEV 1  % and FVC% compared to controls.

New evidence suggests a potential role of interleukin-6 pathways-trans-signaling with soluble interleuka-6 receptors in the asthma pathobiology. Despite the evidence for their associations with asthma, the causal role of soluble. interleuko-6 receptor remains uncertain. We investigated the relations of soluble InterleukIn-6. receptors with asthma and its major phenotypes.

Retinal neuroanatomy may be a biomarker for more neurodegenerative processes. Can be quantified in vivo using optical coherence tomography (OCT), which is inexpensive and noninvasive. We examined the association of neuroretinal morphology with brain MRI image-derived phenotypes.

U-shaped association observed for sleep duration and lung cancer risk. 18% higher risk for short sleepers compared with normal sleepers (7-8 h/day) Evening preference was associated with elevated lung cancerrisk compared with morning preference. No association was found for insomnia or snoring.

Red and processed meat has been associated with a higher risk of morbidity and mortality. This study examined the associations of red and processed. meat consumption with all-cause, cardiovascular, and cancer mortality. It investigated whether markers of physical function modified the associations.

UK Biobank is a health resource with data from over 500,000 adults. The cognitive assessment in UK Biobanks is brief and bespoke, and is administered without supervision on a touchscreen computer. Despite the non-standard nature of these tests and the limited psychometric information, the UKBiobank cognitive data have been used in numerous scientific publications.

Venous thromboembolism (VTE) is a common, life-threatening complication of COVID-19 infection. However, it is unclear whether remote history of VTE also confers increased risk. Study looked at UK Biobank participants recruited between 2006 and 2010.

Sedentary time was quantified by summing up the time spent on television watching, computer use, and driving. The association was more profound among participants with a lower genetic risk of T2D.

The reproducibility of dietary intakes of macronutrients, food groups and dietary patterns (vegetarian and Mediterranean) was assessed in adults in the UK Biobank study on up to five occasions. Analyses of diet-disease relationships need to correct for both measurement error and within-person variability in dietary intake in order to reliably assess any such associations.

The diagnosis of multiple sclerosis is based on a combination of clinical and paraclinical tests. We tested the feasibility of OCT measures of retinal asymmetry as a diagnostic test for multiple sclerosis at the community level. Retinal OCT imaging is accurate, rapid, non-invasive and may help to reduce need for invasive and more costly procedures.

The aim of this study was to assess whether adiposity or body composition relates to microvascular characteristics of the retina. A fully automated QUARTZ software processed retinal images from 68,550 UK Biobank participants (aged 40-69 years) Differences in retinal vessel diameter and tortuosity with body composition measures from the Tanita analyzer were obtained.

Identifying gene-environment (GÃ—E) interactions contributing to human cardiometabolic disorders is challenging. Here we apply a reverse GÃ—E candidate search by deriving candidate variants from promoter-enhancer interactions. We then test all variants residing in lipid-responsive open chromatin sites for interaction effects between genotype and dietary saturated fat intake on body-mass index (BMI)

Ductal carcinoma in situ of the breast (DCIS) is considered to be a non-obligate precursor of invasive breast cancer (IBC) This suggests that risk factors for DCIS should be a subset of those for IBC. We investigated whether demographic, lifestyle, and reproductive factors that have been linked to IBC risk are also associated with DCIS risk.

Diabetes is observed to increase cancer risk, leading to hypothesized direct effects of hyperglycemia or medication. We investigated associations between glycosylated hemoglobin (HbA1c) across the whole glycemic spectrum and incidence of 16 cancers in a population sample with comprehensive adjustment for risk factors and medication.

UK Biobank recruited 502 651 individuals aged 40-69 years across the UK during 2006-10. Road traffic noise (Lden and Lnight) exposure for 2009 was estimated at baseline address using a simplified version of the Common Noise Assessment Methods model. Exposure to road-traffic Lden >65 dB[A], as compared to &#8804;55dB[A] was associated with 0.77% [95% confidence interval (CI) 0.60%, 0.95%], 0.49% (95% CI 0.32%, 065%), 0.79% ( 95% CI 1.11%, 1.47%), and 0.12% (96% CI -0.04

Study aimed to investigate the effects of long-term exposure to road traffic noise and air pollution on incident cardiovascular disease (CVD) in three large cohorts: HUNT, EPIC-Oxford and UK Biobank.

Low lung function has been associated with increased body mass index (BMI) The aim of this study was to investigate whether the effect of BMI on lung function is mediated by DNA methylation. We used individual data from 285,495 participants in four population-based cohorts.

Concentrations of C-reactive protein (CRP), interleukin 6 (IL-6) and other inflammatory markers are elevated in people with depression and anxiety compared to controls. Evidence for disorder-specificity, linearity and potential causality is sparse. Using population-based data from up to 144,890 UK Biobank cohort participants, we tested associations of circulating CRP concentrations.

The UK Biobank holds around 85,000 well-characterized saliva samples, together with blood and urine samples, the results of a battery of physiological tests, a full medical history and a detailed description of the subject's lifestyle.

Sarcopenia, the loss of muscle strength and mass, predicts adverse outcomes and becomes common with age. There is recognition that sarcopenia may occur at younger ages in those with long-term conditions (LTCs) as well as those with multimorbidity. We used data from 499 046 participants in the baseline of UK Biobank. The main outcome was probable sarc Openia based on maximum grip strength below sex-specific cut-points.

Sarcopenic obesity is defined as a combination of sarcopenia and obesity. Previous studies have shown a positive association between sarc Openia and respiratory disease. Other studies have identified that obese individuals have a lower risk for respiratory diseases. This study aimed to investigate the association of obesity, sarc openia and sarcopenic Obesity with respiratory disease incidence and mortality.

Coronavirus disease 2019 (COVID-19) is an infectious disease caused by severe acute respiratory syndrome coronavirus 2. The role of skeletal muscle mass in modulating immune response is well documented. No study has examined the influence of both sarcopenia (low muscle mass) and obesity, termed 'sarcopenic obesity' on the risk of severe COVID- 19.

Angiotensin-converting enzyme 2 (ACE2) has been identified as the entry receptor for coronaviruses into human cells. ACE2 gene is associated with severe acute respiratory syndrome coronavirus 2 (SARS-CoV-2) that causes coronav virus disease 2019 (COVID-19)

SAIGE-GENE can efficiently analyze large-sample data (N > 400,000) with type I error rates well controlled. It is applicable to exome-wide and genome-wide region-based analysis for hundreds of thousands of samples.

Principal component analysis (PCA) is a key tool for understanding population structure and controlling for population stratification in genome-wide association studies (GWAS) There is a need for methods that can compute principal components (PCs) with scalable computational and memory requirements. We present ProPCA, a highly scalable method based on a probabilistic generative model, which computes the top PCs on genetic variation data efficiently.

Seasonal disease outbreaks are perennial features of human infectious disease. The factors generating these patterns are unclear. Here we investigate seasonal and daytime variability in multiple immune parameters in 329,261 participants in UK Biobank.

Shift work is associated with increased cardiometabolic disease risk. This observation may be partly explained by cardiometric risk factors having a role in the selection of individuals into or out of shift work. We performed Mendelian randomization (MR) analyses in the UK Biobank (UKB) to test this hypothesis. Liability to lower educational attainment and higher BMI may influence selection into shift work, but sleep timing preference did not.
