The spatial signals in neuroimaging mass univariate analyses can be characterized in a number of ways. Peak locations and magnitudes provide a useful summary of activation. The magnitudes reflect selection bias as these points have both survived a threshold and are local maxima. We propose the use of resampling methods to estimate and correct this bias.

Age-related hearing impairment (ARHI) is very common in older adults and has major impact on quality of life. The heritability of ARHI has been estimated to be around 50%. The present study aimed to estimate heritability and environmental contributions to liability of AR HI.

Poor sleep is associated with multiple age-related neurodegenerative and neuropsychiatric conditions. The hippocampus plays a special role in sleep and sleep-dependent cognition. accelerated hippocampal atrophy is typically seen with higher age. It is critical to establish how relationship between sleep and hippocampal volume loss unfolds across the adult lifespan.

Intrinsic functional flexibility is evident in the brain's dynamic ability to switch between alternative spatiotemporal states during resting state. The relationship between brain connectivity states, associated psychological functions during restingState, and the changes in normal aging remain poorly understood.

Urine dipstick tests are widely used in routine medical care to diagnose kidney and urinary tract and metabolic diseases. Several environmental factors are known to affect the test results, whereas the effects of genetic diversity are largely unknown. We tested 32.5 million sequence variants for association with urinary biomarkers in a set of 150 274 Icelanders.

Serum testosterone concentrations decline with age, while serum sex hormone-binding globulin (SHBG) concentrations increase. Men with lower testosterone had a higher mortality rate from any cause. Lower SHBG is independently associated with lower all-cause, CVD-related, and cancer-related mortality.

Serum urate is the most abundant small molecule with antioxidant properties. It is found in blood and the epithelial lining fluid of the respiratory system. Raised measured urate was associated with a lower baseline FEV1.

There is ongoing debate about the associations between drug therapies targeting the renin-angiotensin-aldosterone system (RAAS) and adverse outcomes in coronavirus disease 2019 (COVID-19) This study aims to examine associations between using medications for the cardiovascular system and the risks associated with CO VID-19 in middle-aged and older adults.

Experiences of reported trauma are common and are associated with a range of mental health problems. Sex differences in how reported traumas are experienced over the life course in relation to mental health require further exploration.

Males and females present differences in complex traits and in the risk of a wide array of diseases. Genotype by sex (GxS) interactions are thought to account for some of these differences. However, the extent and basis of GxS are poorly understood.

Sex differences in major cardiovascular risk factors for incident (fatal or non-fatal) all-cause dementia were assessed in the UK Biobank. Smoking, diabetes, high adiposity, prior stroke and low SES were associated with a greater risk of dementia. Sex difference in the effect of raised BP was consistent for dementia subtypes (vascular dementia and Alzheimer's disease)

A total of 471,971 UK Biobank participants without a history of cardiovascular disease were included. During 9 years of follow-up, 4,662 (44% women) cases of stroke were recorded. Hypertension, smoking, and a low socioeconomic status were associated with a greater HR of any stroke in women than men.

 type 2 diabetes is a stronger risk factor for coronary heart disease (CHD) in women compared with men. However, it is not clear whether this reflects a sex differential in the causal effect of diabetes on CHD risk or results from sex-specific residual confounding. We performed a sex-stratified Mendelian randomization (MR) study using individual participant data in UK Biobank.

Sex hormone-binding globulin (SHBG) has been reported to be a risk factor associated with the development of arthritis. This study aimed to determine whether the concentrations of circulating SHBG are causally associated with risk of OA, RA, and AS.

Testosterone is a critical determinant of health in both genders. Relationship between circulating levels of testosterone and mortality remains undetermined. We examined associations of serum total testosterone (TT) and free testosterone (FT) with all-cause and cause-specific mortality in 154 965 men and 93 314 postmenopausal women from UK Biobank.

Elevated Lp(a) levels are associated with coronary artery disease (CAD), ischemic stroke (IS), and calcific aortic valve stenosis (CAVS) Studies investigating the association between Lp('a') levels and these diseases in women have yielded inconsistent results. To investigate the association of Lp'a' with sex-specific cardiovascular outcomes, we determined the association using individual participant data from the UK Biobank.

Insulin resistance may have sex-specific effects on the reproductive axis. Impaired kidney function may also cause insulin resistance. We assessed these possibilities using bi-directional, sex- specific, two-sample Mendelian randomisation.

Genetically predicted insulin is positively associated with ischemic heart disease. Sex differences are unclear, despite different disease rates and reproductive strategies by sex. Mitigating the effects of insulin might address sexual disparities in health.

Chronic pain is highly prevalent worldwide and imparts a significant socioeconomic and public health burden. Sex is thought to play a significant role, and chronic pain is more prevalent in women than in men. We carried out a sex-stratified genome-wide association study of Multisite Chronic Pain.

Recalled childhood sexual and physical abuse were both associated with current depressive symptoms score in adults. Higher risk of suicidal behaviours associated with childhood sexual/physical abuse are of particular concern. Longitudinal research into sex-specific associations for individual depressive symptoms is required.

Study looked at data from the UK Biobank on individuals with asthma. Found 61 independent asthma loci: 23 were childhood-onset specific, one was adult-onsets specific, and 37 were shared. 19 loci were associated with age of asthma onset.

Heart muscle diseases hypertrophic (HCM) and dilated (DCM) cardiomyopathies are leading causes of sudden death and heart failure in young, otherwise healthy individuals. We conducted genome-wide association studies and multi-trait analyses in HCM (1,733 cases), DCM (5,521 cases) and nine left ventricular (LV) traits (19,260 UK Biobank participants with structurally normal hearts) We identified 16 loci associated with HCM, 13 with DCM and 23 with LV traits.

 Epidemiological studies demonstrate an association between asthma and mental health disorders. Little is known about the shared genetics and causality of this association. We found a strong genetic correlation with ADHD, ANX and MDD at the genome-wide level.

Data from UK Biobank participants who were tested for COVID-19 infection. Ethnic minorities and people in night-shift-based jobs had a significantly higher prevalence of infection. Shift workers, particularly night shift workers, seem to be at high risk.

Shift work is associated with lung disease and infections. We investigated the impact of shift work on significant COVID-19 illness. 501&#x2009;000 UK Biobank participants were linked to secondary care SARS-CoV-2.

Short sleep duration was a significant moderator of new BP medicine use in shift workers. Among short sleepers, shift workers had a 2.1-fold increased odds of new blood pressure medicine use compared with nonshift workers. Interaction between circadian preference and shift work on BP Medicine use was nonsignificant.

Both physical inactivity and poor sleep are deleteriously associated with mortality. But the joint effects of these two behaviours remain unknown. This study aimed to investigate the joint association of physical activity (PA) and sleep with all-cause and cause-specific mortality risks.

Short sleepers had a 20% higher multivariable-adjusted risk of incident MI. Healthy sleep duration mitigated MI risk even among individuals with high genetic liability. Investigation of sleep extension to prevent MI may be warranted.

Study included 385 292 participants initially free of CVD from UK Biobank. Participants with poor sleep pattern and high genetic risk showed the highest risk of CHD and stroke. Nearly 10% of cardiovascular events in this cohort could be attributed to poor sleep.

Analysis of sleep data from 41,094 participants (51.9% females) with a median age of 57 years. Socio-economic disadvantage, ethnic minority background, shift work, unhealthy lifestyle, poor health, depressive symptoms and obesity were the main risk factors associated with poor sleep.

There is little evidence about smoking and risk of infection. We aim to examine association between smoking and COVID-19 infection and subsequent mortality. Participants who lived in England were followed up from 01/02/2020 to 28/06/2020.

 Meta-analyses and Mendelian randomization (MR) may clarify the associations of smoking, blood cells and myeloproliferative neoplasms (MPN) We investigated the association of smoking with blood cells in the Danish General Suburban Population Study (GESUS, n = 11 083) and MR of smoking variant CHRNA3 (rs1051730[A]) in UK Biobank. Smoking is observationally and genetically associated with increased leukocyte counts and red blood cell indices (MCH, MCV, RDW) and observationally with risk of MPN.

Whether smoking-associated DNA methylation has a causal effect on lung function has not been thoroughly evaluated. We first investigated the causal effects of 474 smoking- associated CpGs on forced expiratory volume in 1 s (FEV 1 ) in UK Biobank (n = 321,047) and then replicated this investigation in the SpiroMeta Consortium. By using "moloc", we found evidence of shared causal variants between lung function, gene expression, and DNA methylated. These findings highlight potential therapeutic targets for improving lung function and possibly smoking cessation.

Of 472 946 participants alive when COVID-19 was first apparent in the UK, 217 (34% women) died from the disease over the next 10 months. Greater social deprivation, quantified using the Townsend Deprivation Score, was associated with greater risk of fatal COVD-19.

We explored the role of socioeconomic inequalities in COVID-19 incidence among cancer patients during the first wave of the pandemic. Compared with the least deprived cancer patients, those living in the most deprived areas had an almost three times higher risk of testing positive. This socio-demographic profiling of vulnerable cancer patients at increased risk of infection can inform prevention strategies and policy improvements for the coming pandemic waves.

 Variant Call Format (VCF) suffers rapid size growth as larger cohorts are sequenced. Sparse Project VCF delivers >10Ã— size reduction for modern studies with practically minimal information loss. We demonstrate its effectiveness with the DiscovEHR and UK Biobank whole-exome sequencing cohorts.

There is increasing interest in using data-driven unsupervised methods to identify structural underpinnings of common mental illnesses. However, studies are often limited to severe clinical cases with small sample sizes and most do not include replication. Here, we examine two relatively large samples with structural magnetic resonance imaging (MRI), measures of lifetime MDD and cognitive variables.

Little is known about the association between speech-in-noise (SiN) hearing impairment and dementia. In 82,039 dementia-free participants aged &#8805;60 years, 1285 participants developed dementia. Insufficient and poor SiN hearing were associated with a 61% and 91% increased risk of developing dementia, respectively.

Researchers found that 90% of human genetic loci are associated with more than one trait. Recently, multivariate methods have been proposed to effectively identify pleiotropy. The statistical performance in natural biomedical data is largely known.

The pathogenesis of type 2 diabetes (T2D) might change with increasing age. Here, we used a stratification based on age of diagnosis to gain insight into the genetics and causal risk factors of T2D across different age-groups. We identified 208 independent lead single nucleotide polymorphism (SNPs) mapping to 69 loci associated with T1D.

Brain structural networks have been shown to consistently organize in functionally meaningful architectures covering the entire brain. To what extent brain structural architectures match the intrinsic functional networks in different functional domains remains under explored. In this study, based on independent component analysis, we revealed 45 pairs of structural-functional (S-F) component maps.

 associations between indices of brain structure and measured intelligence are unclear. This is partly because the evidence to-date comes from mostly small and heterogeneous studies. Here, we report brain structure-intelligence associations on a large sample from the UK Biobank study.

Obstructive sleep apnea (OSA) is a common disorder with an increased risk for left ventricular and right ventricular dysfunction. Most studies to date have examined populations with manifest cardiovascular disease using echocardiography. Our aim was to explore these parameters with cardiac MRI. We analyzed cardiac MRI data from 4978 UK Biobank participants free from cardiovascular disease.

Modified Haseman-Elston regression has been found a bridge that connects and develops various parallel heritability estimation methods. We applied this method to 81 traits in UK Biobank data and compared the chromosome-wise partition heritability with the whole-genome heritability.

ChREBP (carbohydrate responsive element binding protein) is a transcription factor that responds to sugar consumption. Sugar-sweetened beverage (SSB) consumption and genetic variants in the CHREBP locus have separately been linked to HDL-C (high-density lipoprotein cholesterol) and triglyceride concentrations. We hypothesized that SSB consumption would modify the association between genetic variants and dyslipidemia.

Identifying genetic biomarkers for brain connectivity helps us understand genetic effects on brain function. The challenge in detecting associations between brain connectivity and genetic variants is that the phenotype is a matrix rather than a scalar. We study a new concept of super-variant for genetic association detection.

A supervariant is a combination of alleles in multiple loci, but the contributing loci can be anywhere in the genome. We hypothesize that supervariants are easy to detect and the aggregated signals are more stable in their associations with the disease.

The prediction performance of Cox proportional hazard model suffers when there are only few uncensored events in the training data. This scenario is common in the UK Biobank dataset. By analyzing these responses together, we hope to achieve higher prediction performance than when they are analyzed individually.

Cross-sectional study consisted of 25 261 self-reported White UK Biobank participants with major depression. Four broad symptom dimensions were identified, encompassing negative cognition, functional impairment, insomnia and atypical symptoms. Every dimension was associated with increased risk of nearly every psychiatric diagnosis and polygenic risk score.

Depression and anxiety are highly prevalent and comorbid psychiatric traits that cause considerable burden worldwide. We use factor analysis and genomic structural equation modelling to investigate the genetic factor structure underlying 28 items assessing depression, anxiety and neuroticism. Symptoms of depression and anxiety loaded on two distinct, although highly genetically correlated factors.

Systemic inflammation markers have been linked to increased cancer risk and mortality. Few studies have estimated pre-diagnostic associations of systemic inflammation markers and cancer risk. Blood cell ratios could serve as biomarkers of cancer incidence risk with potential for early identification of disease.

We tested associations between genetically determined telomere length and aging-related health outcomes. Data were from n = 379,758 UK Biobank participants aged 40-70, followed up for mean of 7.5 years. Genetically determined longer telomer length was associated with lowered risk of coronary heart disease (CHD) but raised risk of cancer.

PMR-Egger is a probabilistic Mendelian randomization (MR) method for TWAS applications. It unifies many existing TWAS and MR methods, accommodates multiple correlated instruments, and tests the causal effect of gene on trait in the presence of horizontal pleiotropic effects. We illustrate its benefits in applications to 39 diseases and complex traits from three GWASs including the UK Biobank.

Recent research suggests genetic variation in the Klotho locus may modify the association between APOE &#603;4 and cognitive impairment. We tested for associations and interactions between these genotypes versus risk of dementia, cognitive abilities and brain structure in older UK Biobank participants.

The observational analyses included 159,702 women (80% postmenopausal) enrolled in the UK Biobank. Higher circulating concentrations of testosterone and sex hormone-binding globulin (SHBG) were associated with higher endometrial cancer risk. No association was found between genetically predicted IGF-1 concentration and endometriosis risk.

Insulin-like growth factor-1 (IGF-1) is a well-established modulator of aging and longevity in model organisms. Its role in humans has been controversial. In this study, we used the UK Biobank to resolve previous ambiguities in the relationship between serum IGF-1 levels and clinical disease.

The association between body fat composition and risk of cancer in normal weight individuals (body mass index (BMI) 18.5-24.9 kg/m2) is unclear. We examined the association of measures of adiposity with risk of incident cancers of the breast (postmenopausal), endometrium, ovary and colon/rectum.

Little is known about the associations between obesity-related blood markers and risk of breast cancer among these individuals. We examined associations of glycated hemoglobin, triglycerides, high-density lipoprotein cholesterol, C-reactive protein (CRP), testosterone and sex hormone-binding globulin (SHBG) A total of 1268 postmenopausal breast cancer cases were ascertained during a median follow-up period of 7 years.

Study investigates relationship of blood lipid and lipoprotein levels with leukocyte counts in the UK Biobank cohort. A higher eosinophil count was associated with lower HDL cholesterol and apolipoprotein A-I concentration.

Loneliness significantly predicted acute (OR:1.887; 95%CI1.857-1.917) and chronic pain. Poor sleep has a potential mediating effect on these associations. Exploration of pain in loneliness and social exclusion in the general population is warranted.

Fossil fuels dominate domestic heating in temperate climates. Reducing domestic demand temperatures would reduce energy demand. But cold exposure has been shown to be associated with adverse health conditions.

UK Biobank study included 198,285 men and women aged 40-69 years. Of whom 3166 (1.6%) died over a mean of 7 years follow-up. All-cause mortality was associated with total sugar intake and sugar-sweetened beverages.

Little is known about the bidirectional association of these two behaviors. The present analyses included 38,601 UK Biobank participants. Physical activity was categorized by the weekly metabolic equivalent of task minutes.

Age-related loss of white matter microstructural integrity is a major determinant of cognitive decline, dementia and gait disorders. We identified 18 loci that were associated at genome-wide significance with either mean diffusivity or fractional anisotropy. Among the top loci was a region on chromosome 6 encoding the human major histocompatibility complex (MHC)

Reverse causality has made it difficult to establish the causal directions between obesity and prediabetes and obesity and insulin resistance. We performed a Mendelian randomization (MR) analyses in non-diabetic individuals. Our results suggest that both predi diabetes and systemic insulin resistance are caused by obesity (p = 1.2Ã—10-3)

Genetically predicted higher blood levels of iron and copper are both associated with lower risks of iron deficiency anemia and hyperlipidemia. Consistently, they are also associated withLower blood. levels of total cholesterol and low-density lipoprotein cholesterol.

Pulmonary inflammatory responses lie under circadian control. However, the importance of circadian mechanisms in the underlying fibrotic phenotype is not understood. Here, we identify a striking change to these mechanisms resulting in a gain of amplitude and lack of synchrony within pulmonary Fibrotic tissue.

Study looked at 245,731 control and 55,114 statin-taking individuals from the UK Biobank. Cognitive performance in terms of reaction time, working memory and fluid intelligence was analysed. The effect of statin use differed considerably between the two age groups.

We use attributable fraction to compare the relative contribution of genetic, dietary, urate-lowering therapy (ULT) and other exposures to HU. We use Mendelian randomisation to test for the causality of diet in urate levels.

There is evidence in humans for genetic influences on the probability (P boy ) that a birth yields a boy instead of a girl. To quantify this variation, we analyze the survey data from over 300,000 UK Biobank participants born between 1940 and 1970. We find that the observed deficit in SR variation is explainable by 3.3% of "coupon-collecting" families.

Lonely individuals display stronger functional communication in the default network, and greater microstructural integrity of its fornix pathway. The findings fit with the possibility that the up-regulation of these neural circuits supports mentalizing, reminiscence and imagination.

It has recently been shown that epidermal growth factor receptor (EGFR) contributes to the pathogenesis of pain. We found that only epiregulin (EREG) was associated with pain. The strongest effect was observed for a minor allele at rs6836436 in EREG. We investigated the functional role of EREG using mouse models of chronic and acute pain.

Duffy-null (CC) genotype at rs2814778 in the ACKR1 gene. 21% of those with the Duffy-null genotype (21%) had a neutrophil count below the threshold often used as a cut-off for access to relevant treatments, compared with 1% of people with the TC/TT genotype. Despite its strong association with lower average neutrophIL counts, the DuffyÂ null genotypes was not associated with an increased risk of infection, viral or bacterial.

Human genetic variants predicted to cause loss-of-function of protein-coding genes (pLoF variants) can be valuable indicators of gene function and the potential toxicity of therapeutic inhibitors targeting these genes. We systematically analyze pLoF. variants in LRRK2 observed across 141,456 individuals sequenced in the Genome Aggregation. Database (gnomAD)9, 49,960 exome-sequenced individuals from the UK Biobank and. over 4 million participants in the 23andMe genotyped dataset.

There are limited evidences clarifying the impact of metabolic syndrome (MS) and its components on head and neck cancer (HNC) incidence risk. We explored the correlation between MS, MS components, and the combined effects of MS and C-reactive protein (CRP) and HNC risk.

Whole-brain structural networks can be constructed using diffusion MRI and probabilistic tractography. Faithful disentanglement of spurious and genuine connections is hindered by a lack of comprehensive anatomical information at the network-level.

There is substantial variation in the timing of significant reproductive life events such as menarche and first sexual intercourse. Life history theory explains this variation as an adaptive response to an individual's environment. It is important to examine how traits within life history strategies affect each other.

A growing literature has sought to tie educational attainment with later-life cognition and Alzheimer's disease outcomes. We find that the effects of education on cognition are confounded by family background factors and by genetics. College graduates have cognition scores that are approximately 0.75 SD higher than those who report no credentials.

Biobanks linked to electronic health records provide rich resources for health-related research. However, there are many obvious and subtle challenges with the design and analysis of biobank-based studies. We summarize the current body of literature for addressing these challenges.

Anxiety and depressive disorders can be classified under a bidimensional model. Depression and generalized anxiety disorder are represented by distress and the other anxiety disorders, by fear. Twin studies only show partial evidence for genetic and environmental distinctions between distress and fear.

Appendicular lean mass (ALM) is a heritable trait associated with loss of lean muscle mass and strength. Its genetic determinants are largely unknown. We conducted a genome-wide association study (GWAS) with 450,243 UK Biobank participants to uncover its genetic architecture.

Left-right hemispheric asymmetry is an important aspect of healthy brain organization. It can be altered in cognitive and psychiatric disorders. No mechanism has yet been identified for establishing the human brain's left-right axis.

UK Biobank data (N = 220,685) evaluated the association between five female reproductive traits and polygenic risk scores (PRS) projected from genome-wide association study summary statistics of six psychiatric disorders. We found that the PRS of attention-deficit/hyperactivity disorder (ADHD) was strongly associated with age at first birth (AFB)

The genetic architecture of testosterone is highly distinct between sexes. Obesity is associated with higher testosterone in females but lower testosterone in males. We ask whether male-specific testosterone variants are associated with a male pattern of obesity and type 2 diabetes (T2D) in females.

The sensitivity of electrocardiogram (ECG) criteria to detect left ventricular hypertrophy (LVH) is low, especially in women. We determined sex-specific sensitivities of ECG-LVH criteria, and developed new criteria, using cardiovascular magnetic resonance imaging (CMR) Newly developed Groningen- LVH criterion for women outperformed all ECG. criteria with a sensitivity of 42% (95% CI 35-49%). In men, newly developed criterion was equally sensitive as 12-lead sum.

Rheumatic heart disease (RHD), an autoinflammatory heart disease, was recently declared a global health priority by the World Health Organization. Here we report a genome-wide association study (GWAS) of RHD susceptibility in 1,163 South Asians and 1,459 Europeans. We identify a novel susceptibility signal in the class III region of the human leukocyte antigen (HLA) complex that clearly replicates in the Europeans.

Human-specific duplications at chromosome 16p11.2 mediate recurrent pathogenic 600 kbp BP4-BP5 copy-number variations, which are among the most common genetic causes of autism. These copy- number polymorphic duplications are under positive selection and include three to eight copies of BOLA2, a gene involved in the maturation of cytosolic iron-sulfur proteins. We assessed hematological traits and anemia prevalence in 379,385 controls and individuals who have lost or gained copies.

Inherited genetic variation contributes to individual risk for many complex diseases and is increasingly being used for predictive patient stratification. Previous work has shown that genetic factors are not equally relevant to human traits across age and other contexts. We find evidence for age-varying relative risk profiles in nine diseases.

The aim of this study was to quantify the impact of periodontal disease on hospital admission and mortality during the COVID-19 pandemic. Painful gums, bleeding gums and loose teeth were reported in 2.7, 11.2 and 3.3% of participants with CO VID-19 infection. Risk of infection in participants with painful gums was not increased compared to controls.

Common and rare variants have been implicated in the risk of developing atrial fibrillation (AF) The effect of genetic variants on risk of AF compared with established modifiable risk factors is unclear. We used whole exome sequencing data of 49,881 individuals and genotyping data of 408,572 individuals from the UK Biobank to examine the associations of TTN variants, polygenic risk, and 4 risk factors with AF.

Sarcopenia and frailty are strongly associated with disease incidence and mortality. However, there is limited evidence regarding their joint association with health outcomes. This study aimed to investigate the joint association of sarcopenia. with cardiovascular disease (CVD), respiratory disease and cancer incidence and. mortality in middle-aged and older adults.

Genetic mechanisms of immune response to viral infection provide insight into disease etiology and therapeutic opportunities. We identified specific amino acid (AA) residues that are associated with seroreactivity. The strongest associations were found for Epstein-Barr virus (EBV), Varicella zoster virus (VZV), human herpesvirus 7, (HHV7), and Merkel cell polyomavirus (MCV)

A SH2B3 missense variant (rs3184504) is associated with cardiovascular diseases plus breast, colorectal, and lung cancers. Data were obtained from 379,758 European-descent UK Biobank participants aged 40-70 at baseline.

Study used the UK Biobank cohort, a large sample of middle aged and older adults in the UK. Participants with type 2 diabetes had a significantly shorter digit span than those without diabetes. Comorbid conditions explain some of the observed association between type 2 Diabetes and cognitive deficits.

First release of Medical Genome Reference Bank (MGRB) comprises whole genome sequence and phenotype of 2570 elderly Australians depleted for cancer, cardiovascular disease, and dementia. MGRB individuals have fewer disease-associated common and rare germline variants, relative to both cancer cases and the gnomAD and UK Biobank cohorts.

Working memory is a basic human cognitive function. However, the genetic signatures and their biological pathway remain poorly understood. In the present study, we explored the potential associations and pathways among genetic variants, brain morphometry and working memory performance.

Occupational exposures are important, preventable causes of chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD) Identification of COPD high-risk jobs is key to focus preventive strategies. A definitive job-list is unavailable.

Schizophrenia, Bipolar Disorder and Major Depressive Disorder have increased risk of cardiometabolic disease. We explored whether genetic variation could identify sub-groups with different metabolic profiles. Loci associated with schizophrenia, bipolar disorder and major depressive disorder were selected.

Blood cells play essential roles in human health, underpinning physiological processes such as immunity, oxygen transport, and clotting. When perturbed cause a significant global health burden. Here we integrate data from UK Biobank and a large-scale international collaborative effort, including data for 563,085 European ancestry participants.

Glaucoma is more common in urban populations than in others. Ninety percent of the world's population are exposed to air pollution above World Health Organization (WHO) recommended limits. Few studies have examined the association between air pollution and glaucomas.

We investigated the relationship between glycemia and cognitive function, brain structure and incident dementia using bidirectional Mendelian randomization (MR) Data were from the UK Biobank ( n  = &#8764;500,000). Our exposures were genetic instruments for type 2 diabetes (157 variants) and HbA 1c  (51 variants) We also investigated associations between genetic variants for RT (43 variants)  and diabetes and HBA 1C  We used conventional inverse-variance-weighted (IVW) MR alongside MR sensitivity analyses.

A few studies report that parental longevity is associated with preserved cognition and physical function and lower risk of Alzheimer's disease. This study aims to examine relationships of parental longevity with regional brain structure and to explore sex differences. We identified 12,970 UK Biobank participants with data on parental longevity, regional gray matter volumes, and white matter microstructure.

Study was to identify genetic variants on chromosome X associated with intraocular pressure. Association analyses were performed across chromosome X using 102,407 participants from the UK Biobank. We identified three loci associated with IOP at genomewide significance.

Thrombosis and platelet activation play a central role in stroke pathogenesis. Whether haematological traits contribute equally to all ischaemic stroke subtypes is uncertain. Identification of associations with new traits may offer novel treatment opportunities.

There is growing evidence that the Mediterranean (Medi) diet may lower the risk of type 2 diabetes mellitus (T2DM) Whether this association is due to the Medi diet by itself or is mediated by a diet-associated lower rate of overweight is uncertain. Our aim was to disentangle these relationships among UK adults.

Chronic kidney disease (CKD) has an apparent sex disparity, with a more rapid progress in men than in women. Whether the well-established sex-specific evolutionary biology trade-off between reproduction and longevity might inform CKD has not previously been considered.

Microstructure of axons affects neural circuit activity through characteristics such as conduction speed. To what extent axonal microstructure in white matter relates to functional connectivity (synchrony) between brain regions is largely unknown. Using MRI data in 11,354 subjects, we constructed multivariate models that predict functional connectivity of pairs of brain regions.

In this paper we review the methodological underpinnings of the general pharmacogenetic approach for uncovering genetically-driven treatment effect heterogeneity. A decision framework is then described to decide when a particular estimation strategy is most appropriate. Triangulation of evidence from different data sources, each with their inherent biases and limitations, is becoming a well established principle.

Alpha-1 antitrypsin deficiency (AATD) is mainly due to the PI*ZZ genotype in SERPINA1. Since it is associated with a high disease burden and partially prevented by smoking cessation, identification of PI*zz individuals through genotyping could improve health outcomes.

The UK Biobank is an unprecedented resource for human disease research. In March 2019, 49,997 exomes were made publicly available to investigators. Thousands of variant calls are unexpectedly absent from this dataset. 641 genes showing zero variation.

Both bone mineral density (BMD) and lean body mass (LBM) are important physiological measures with strong genetic determination. Aiming to identify pleiotropic genomic loci underlying BMD and LBM, we performed bivariate genome-wide association study meta-analyses. Combining the results from discovery meta-analysis and replication sample, we identified three genomic locus at the genome- wide significance level.

This study aimed to evaluate the association between thyroid dysfunction and breast cancer risk. We included 239,436 females of the UK Biobank cohort. 3,227 (1.3%) and 20,762 (8.7%) women had hyper- and hypothyroidism prior to the baseline. During a median follow-up of 7.1 years, 5,326 (2.2%) women developed breast cancer.

Thyroid dysfunction is associated with higher anemia prevalence, although causality remains unclear. This study aimed to investigate the association between thyroid function and anemia. The study included 445 482 European participants from the UK Biobank.

Hypothyroidism and hyperthyroidism are observationally associated with sex hormone concentrations and sexual dysfunction, but causality is unclear. We investigated whether TSH, fT4, hypo- and hyper thyroidism are causally associated. Outcomes from UK Biobank and ReproGen were sex hormones (sex hormone binding globulin [SHBG], testosterone, estradiol, free androgen index [FAI]) and sexual function.

Light has powerful effects on mood, sleep, and the circadian system. UK Biobank participants reported spending a median of 2.5 daylight hours (IQR = 1.5-3.5 h) outdoors per day. Each additional hour spent outdoors during the day was associated with lower odds of lifetime major depressive disorder.

Polygenic risk scores (PRSs) are poised to be translated into clinical practice through prediction of inborn health risks. We investigated the association of the genetic susceptibility to complex traits with human lifespan in collaboration with three worldwide biobanks. A high systolic blood pressure PRS was trans-ethnically associated with a shorter lifespan.

Major depressive disorder (MDD) is the single largest contributor to global disability. Up to 20-30% of patients do not respond to at least two antidepressants (treatment-resistant depression, TRD) This study leveraged imputed gene expression in TRD to perform a drug repurposing analysis.

Measuring aberrant gene expression has aided in identifying functional, large-effect rare variants (RVs) We analyzed gene expression, allele-specific expression, and alternative splicing from multitissue RNA-sequencing data. We developed Watershed, a probabilistic model that integrates multiple genomic and transcriptomic signals.

Destabilised transthyretin (TTR) can result in a progressive, fatal disease. A stabilising  TTR  mutation, T119M, is the basis for a therapeutic strategy to reduce destabilised TTR. Recently, T 119M was associated with extended lifespan and lower risk of cerebrovascular disease in a Danish cohort. We aimed to determine whether this finding could be replicated in the UK Biobank.

We aimed to explore the underlying genetic mechanisms of traumatic events during childhood affecting the risks of adult substance use. Using UK Biobank cohort, linear regression model was first applied to assess the relationships between cigarette smoking and alcohol drinking in adults with traumatic events. We found that the frequency of cigarette smoking was significantly associated with felt hated by family member.

We performed a bivariate GWAS meta-analysis of femoral neck BMD (FNK-BMD) and trunk fat mass adjusted by trunk lean mass (TFMadj) in 11,496 subjects from 6 samples. We identified two novel pleiotropic loci 12q15 (lead SNP rs73134637, p = 3.45 Ã— 10-7) and 10p14 that were suggestively associated. Cis-eQTL analysis demonstrated that allele C was positively associated with IFNG expression in whole blood. Mouse model analysis showed that heterozygous PRKCQ deficient mice presented decreased fat mass.

MindCrowd is a cross-sectional web-based assessment of simple visual (sv) reaction time (RT) and paired-associate learning (PAL) Results were combined with 22 survey questions. Analysis of svRT revealed education and stroke as potential modifiers of changes in processing speed and memory from younger to older ages.

Type 1 diabetes is an autoimmune disease with rising incidence in high-income countries. Strongest known associations with genetic variation map to classical HLA class II genes. We hypothesize that genetic variation in EHMT2 could impact autoimmunity in type 1 diabetes development.

Excess risks of type 2 diabetes in UK South Asians (SA) and African Caribbeans (AC) compared with Europeans remain unexplained. We studied risks and determinants in first- and second-generation (born in the UK) migrants, and in those of mixed ethnicity.

In biobank data analysis, most binary phenotypes have unbalanced case-control ratios. This can cause inflation of type I error rates. Recently, a saddle point approximation (SPA) based single-variant test has been developed to provide an accurate and scalable method to test for associations.

UkbREST is a RESTful API for UK Biobank data. It exposes a REST API that makes data highly accessible inside a private and secure network. It is implemented in Python using the Flask-RESTful framework.

Study examined associations between ultra-processed food consumption and risk of obesity among UK adults. Participants aged 40-69 years at recruitment in the UK Biobank (2006-2019) had significantly higher risk of developing overall obesity (BMI &#8805; 30 kg/m2)

Ultra-processed foods account for more than 50% of daily calories consumed in several high-income countries. Sales of ultra- Processed foods are soaring globally, especially in middle- income countries.

Medical images have been acquired for over 40,000 male and female UK Biobank participants, aged 44-82, since 2014. Phenotypes derived from these images can reveal new links between genetics, cardiovascular disease, and metabolic conditions.

More accurate prediction of those at risk of developing severe infections is of high clinical importance. The top 5 contributing factors for severity were age, number of drugs taken, cystatin C (reflecting renal function), waist-to-hip ratio (WHR), and Townsend deprivation index (TDI) For mortality, the top features were. age, testosterone, cnt_tx, waist circumference (WC), and red cell distribution width.

Cognitive impairment is strongly linked with persistent disability in people with mood disorders. The factors that explain cognitive impairment in this population are unclear. The potential mediators were cardiometabolic disease and psychotropic medication.

Study looked at 129,731 individuals in the UK Biobank of European descent. Hearing loss, older age, male gender, high BMI, higher deprivation, higher blood pressure, smoking history, as well as numerous comorbidities were associated with higher odds of current tinnitus.

From 2006 to 2010, 490,966 UK Biobank participants, aged 37 to 73 years, were recruited. Primary outcomes were mortality: all-cause, cardiovascular disease (CVD) and cancer. Secondary outcomes were incident myocardial infarction, stroke, and heart failure and colon, lung, breast, and prostate cancer.

MOSTest identifies 347 genomic loci associated with regional brain morphology, more than any previous study. Our findings implicate more than 5% of all protein-coding genes and provide evidence for gene sets involved in neuron development and differentiation.

A dataset from UK Biobank was used to evaluate the impact of pre-analytical variability on the power of association studies. The results showed that the majority of the analytes investigated in our analysis, were stable over a period of 36&#x2009;h.

Network analysis provides a rich framework to model complex phenomena, such as human brain connectivity. It has proven efficient to understand their natural properties and design predictive models. In this paper, we study the variability within groups of networks, i.e., structure of connection similarities and differences across a set of networks.

Most genome-wide association and fine-mapping studies to date have been conducted in individuals of European descent. Genetic studies of populations of Hispanic/Latino and African ancestry are limited. We demonstrated that using TOPMed sequencing data as the imputation reference panel improves genotype imputation quality in these populations.

Having a larger genetically predicted body size in early life was associated with an increased odds of coronary artery disease and type 2 diabetes. However, little evidence was found of a direct effect (ie, not through adult body size) on breast cancer.

Studies have shown increased gastric cancer risk in users of proton pump inhibitors (PPI) and histamine-2 receptor antagonists. We conducted a case-control study within the Scottish Primary Care Clinical Informatics Unit (PCCIU) and a cohort study in the UK Biobank. We observed little consistent evidence of an increased risk with PPI use.

Gene-environment interactions (GxE) play a central role in the theoretical relationship between genetic factors and complex traits. While genome wide GxE studies of human behaviors remain underutilized, in part due to methodological limitations.

Head and neck squamous cell carcinoma (HNSCC) is a cause of substantial global morbidity and mortality. Statins are commonly prescribed for lowering circulating cholesterol by inhibiting HMG-CoA reductase (HMGCR) Results from some observational studies suggest that statin use may reduce HNSCC risk.

Testosterone supplementation is commonly used for its effects on sexual function, bone health and body composition. We identified genetic determinants of testosterone levels and related sex hormone traits in 425,097 UK Biobank study participants. We found that genetically higher testosterone is harmful for metabolic diseases in women but beneficial in men.

Policy makers need reliable information of the health burden of different risk factors. To estimate the attributable fraction from observational data, we have to make appropriate adjustment for confounding. By using Mendelian randomization, it has been claimed that low educational qualifications is a causal risk factor for coronary heart disease.

Major depression (MD) is often characterised as a categorical disorder. This study sought to understand if polygenic risk for MD could provide insight into the continuous nature of depression.

Serum C-reactive protein (CRP) has been associated with age-related macular degeneration (AMD) in observational studies. It remains unclear whether the association between circulating CRP levels and AMD is causal. We used two-sample Mendelian randomization to evaluate the potential causal relationship.

Normative modelling is an emerging method for quantifying how individuals deviate from the healthy populational pattern. We assessed normative models based on deep autoencoders using structural neuroimaging data from patients with Alzheimer's disease and mild cognitive impairment.

Despite poorer health and healthcare outcomes experienced by lesbian, gay and bisexual adults, data for research to characterize and address these disparities remain limited. We describe sexual history information from 502,543 UK Biobank participants recruited between 2006 and 2010. We compare this with sexual history and sexual identity responses to the third National Survey of Sexual Attitudes and Lifestyles collected between 2010 and 2012.

UK Biobank collected accelerometer traces from 103,712 volunteers aged between 40 and 69 years using wrist-worn triaxial accelerometers for 1 week. Data set has been used in the past to verify that individuals with chronic diseases exhibit reduced activity levels compared with healthy populations.

The increasing availability of large biobanks linked to electronic healthcare records enables the potential to identify novel drug-gene interactions in large populations of patients. We identify eight novel associations after Bonferroni correction, three of which are replicated or validated in the UK Biobank or have other supporting results.

Current lipid guidelines suggest measurement of Lp(a) and ApoB for atherosclerotic cardiovascular disease risk assessment. Polygenic risk scores (PRSs) may identify individuals unlikely to have elevated Lp('a') or Apo'B and thus reduce such suggested testing.

Preimplantation genetic testing (PGT) has been successfully applied to reduce the risk of miscarriage, improve IVF success rates, and prevent inheritance of monogenic disease and unbalanced translocations. Study provides the first method capable of simultaneous testing of aneuploidy, structural rearrangements, and monogenic disorders using a single platform.

Nonalcoholic fatty liver disease (NAFLD) is a global public health crisis that affects one quarter of the world population. Preventing either cardiometabolic or liver-related complications would be the central goal of a NAFLD screening program in the primary care setting.

Humans are a highly social species. Complex interactions for mutual support range from helping neighbors to building social welfare institutions. By translating pattern-learning algorithms to the UK Biobank imaging-genetics cohort, we have delineated manifestations of regular social support in multimodal whole-brain measurements.

Recent work has shown that polygenic scores have limited portability across groups of different genetic ancestries. This restricts the contexts in which they can be used reliably and potentially creating serious inequities in future clinical applications. Using the UK Biobank data, we demonstrate that even within a single ancestry group, prediction accuracy can depend on characteristics.

Existing gene-environment interaction (G Ã— E) tests for rare variants largely focus on detecting gene-based G Ã— E effects in a single study. Meta-analysis methods that synthesize summary statistics of GÃ—E effects from multiple studies are still limited. Based on variance component models, we propose four methods of testing GÃ—e effects for rare variant. Our methods are further validated via testing 12 candidate gene-age interactions in blood pressure traits.

Lung function is highly heritable and differs between the sexes throughout life. Little is known about sex-differential genetic effects on lung function. We tested for interactions between 7,745,864 variants and sex on spirometry-based measures of lung function in UK Biobank.

Exome sequence data was obtained for 49,953 UK Biobank subjects, of whom 82 had tested positive for SARS-CoV-2 and could be presumed to have severe disease.

The stress hormone cortisol modulates fuel metabolism, cardiovascular homoeostasis, mood, inflammation and cognition. The CORtisol NETwork (CORNET) consortium previously identified a single locus associated with morning plasma cortisol. Identifying additional genetic variants that explain more of the variance in cortisol could provide new insights into cortisol biology.

Brain morphology has been shown to be highly heritable, yet only a small portion of the heritability is explained by the genetic variants discovered so far. Here we extended the Multivariate Omnibus Statistical Test (MOSTest) and applied it to genome-wide association studies. We identified 695 loci for cortical surface area and 539 for cortical thickness, in total 780 unique genetic loci associated with cortical morphology.

Little research has assessed serum 25-hydroxyvitamin D (25(OH)D) concentration and its predictors in Western-dwelling South Asians in a relatively large sample size. This observational, cross-sectional analysis assessed baseline prevalence of vitamin D deficiency in South Asians aged 40-69 years.

 Visual impairment has emerged as a potential modifiable risk factor for dementia. There is a lack of large studies with objective measures of vision and with more than 10 years of follow-up. We investigated whether visual impairment is associated with an increased risk of incident dementia.

 Observational evidence has implicated vitamin D levels as a risk factor in major depressive disorder (MDD) Confounding or reverse causation may be driving these observed associations, with studies using genetics indicating little evidence of an effect. We explored the associations between vitamin D and two subtypes of MDD.

White matter lesions are a common finding on MRI in older adults. Their presence increases the risk of stroke and dementia. Accurate and computationally efficient modelling methods are necessary to map the association of lesion incidence with risk factors.

The high prevalence of vitamin D deficiency and obesity drives the need for successful strategies that elevate vitamin D levels, prevent adipogenesis, and stimulate lipolysis. This study provides a theoretical model to evaluate how physical activity (PA) and sunlight exposure influence serum vitamin D and regional adiposity.

Normative modelling is becoming more popular in neuroimaging due to its ability to make predictions of deviation from a normal trajectory at the level of individual participants. So far, most normative modelling approaches used Gaussian process regression, and although suitable for smaller datasets, it does not scale well to the large cohorts currently available and being acquired.

Biomedical repositories such as the UK Biobank provide increasing access to prospectively collected cardiac imaging. These data are unlabeled, which creates barriers to their use in supervised machine learning. We develop a weakly supervised deep learning model for classification of aortic valve malformations using up to 4,000 cardiac MRI sequences.

We used a network harmonization approach to map dominant-wrist acceleration to PAEE in 96,476 UK Biobank participants. We also calculated the fraction of PAEE accumulated from moderate-to-vigorous-intensity physical activity (MVPA) Over the median 3.1-year follow-up period, 732 deaths were recorded.

The contribution of measurable immunological and inflammatory parameters to lung cancer development remains unclear, particularly among never smokers. We investigated relationship between total and differential white blood cell (WBC) counts and incident lung cancer risk overall and among subgroups defined by smoking status and sex.

Tobacco smoking is an addictive behavior that supports nicotine dependence and is an independent risk factor for cancer and other illnesses. Its neurogenetic mechanisms are not fully understood but may act through alterations in the cerebral white matter (WM) We hypothesized that the vertical pleiotropic pathways, where genetic variants influence a trait that in turn influences another trait, link genetic factors, integrity of cerebral WM, and nicotine addiction.

Chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD) is a leading cause of morbidity and mortality. We performed whole genome sequence (WGS) analysis of lung function and COPD in a multi-ethnic sample of 11,497 participants. We identify at genome-wide significance 10 known GWAS loci and 22 distinct, previously unreported loci.

Exome association studies to date have generally been underpowered to systematically evaluate the phenotypic impact of very rare coding variants. We leveraged extensive haplotype sharing between 49,960 exome-sequenced UK Biobank participants and the remainder of the cohort. Association and fine-mapping analyses of 54 quantitative traits identified 1,189 significant associations.

Whole lean body mass (WLBM) is a heritable trait predicting sarcopenia. We performed a whole-exome sequencing (WES) of WLBM variation in 101 Chinese subjects. Four single-nucleotide polymorphisms (SNPs) were significant both in the discovery stage and replication stage. Functional annotations highlighted two candidate genes, including FZR1 and SOAT2, that may exert pleiotropic effects.

White matter hyperintensities (WMH) are among the most common radiological abnormalities in the ageing population and an established risk factor for stroke and dementia. We conducted a comprehensive analysis of this burden in the UK Biobank using publicly available whole-exome sequencing data (n up to 17 830) We found damaging missense and loss-of-function variants in HTRA1 to associate with an increased WMH volume.

We used a novel whole-genome approach to estimate the genetic and nongenetic effects on-and hence their predispositions to-cardiovascular risk. We performed analyses on the ARIC (Atherosclerosis Risk in Communities) Study. Lifestyle modulation was evident for many cardiovascular traits such as body mass index and resting heart rate.

Study looked at 686 childhood cancer survivors of European ancestry treated with cranial radiotherapy (CRT) Of those, 116 (17%) had clinically diagnosed stroke. There was a genome-wide significant association between 5p15.33 locus and stroke.

Mortality and HF risk were almost doubled in those with diabetes compared to those without diabetes in the UK Biobank population. Women with diabetes (both types) experience a 22% increased risk of HF compared to men.

Women's exposure to estrogen may influence their heightened risk of Alzheimer's disease (AD) relative to men. Little is known about how it affects normal brain aging. Recent findings demonstrate less apparent brain aging in women with a history of multiple childbirths.

The X-chromosome has long been hypothesized to have a disproportionate influence on the brain based on its enrichment for genes that are expressed in the brain. Here, we verify this hypothesis through partitioned heritability analysis of X- Chromosome influences (XIs) on human brain anatomy in 32,256 individuals from the UK Biobank.

Liver fibrosis is associated with worse cognitive performance and corresponding brain imaging changes. We examined the association of liver fibrosis with cognition and brain imaging parameters in the UK Biobank study. Liver fibrosis was associated with lower hippocampal and total brain volumes.

The SIX6 gene codes for a transcription factor believed to be critical to the eye, retina and optic disc development and morphology. CRX regulates photoreceptor specification and expression of over 700 genes in the retina.

We introduce AbdomentNet, a deep neural network for the automated segmentation of abdominal organs on two-point Dixon MRI scans. A pre-processing pipeline enables to process MRI scans from different imaging studies. The mean Dice similarity coefficient is above 0.9 for larger organs liver, spleen, and kidneys.

Type 2 diabetes and lifestyle factors have been associated with dementia risk. The effect of a healthy lifestyle on diabetes-related dementia remains largely unknown. We aimed to investigate whether the increased risk of dementia among individuals with diabetes can be offset by a broad combination of healthy lifestyle factors.

The fatty liver index (FLI) is frequently used as a non-invasive clinical marker for research, prognostic and diagnostic purposes. It is also used to stratify individuals with hepatic steatosis such as non-alcoholic fatty liver disease.

Proton pump inhibitors (PPIs) and histamine-2 receptor antagonists (H2RAs) were studied in the UK Biobank. Regular PPIs use was associated with a higher risk of ASCVD and every subtype of the disease.

Sex differences in the fitness effects of genetic variants can influence the rate of adaptation and the maintenance of genetic variation. For example, "sexually antagonistic" (SA) variants can both constrain adaptation and increase genetic variability for fitness components such as survival, fertility, and disease susceptibility. detecting variants with sex-differential fitness effects is difficult.

 Complex brain networks play a central role in integrating activity across the human brain. Such networks can be identified in the absence of any external stimulus. We found that the heritability of global network efficiency was largely explained by blood oxygen level-dependent (BOLD) resting state fluctuation amplitudes (RSFA)

l-carnitine is emerging as an item of interest for cardiovascular disease (CVD) prevention and treatment, but controversy exists. We assessed how genetically different levels of l-c Carnitine are associated with CVD risk and its risk factors. Given higher CVD incidence in men, we also examined sex-specific associations.

Sex is seldom considered as a potential moderator of the impact of bipolar disorder (BD) on cardiovascular disease (CVD) risk. We aimed to characterize the sex-specific association of CVD and BD using data from the UK Biobank. We found a two- to three-fold stronger association among women than among men.

Depression has been acknowledged as a risk factor for cardiometabolic diseases. We aimed to investigate how depression affected the development of CM based on the UK Biobank study. Depression was significantly associated with all transitions from baseline to diabetes, stroke, and CHD.

We study variance estimation and associated confidence intervals for parameters characterizing genetic effects from genome-wide association studies. We develop practical and computationally convenient methods for estimating such asymptotic variances. Performance of the proposed methods is evaluated empirically based on Monte-Carlo simulations and real-data application.

Average and slow walking pace was associated with a higher risk of incident T2D in both men and women, independent of major confounding factors. Compared with slow walkers, brisk walkers have the same diabetes incidence rate 18.6 and 16.0 years later.

Exposure polygenic risk scores (ExPRS) offer an alternative to study the influence of exposures on various phenotypes. We established ExPRSs for 27 exposures and demonstrated their applicability in phenome-wide association studies and as predictors for common chronic conditions.

Both walking pace and genetic risk were strongly associated with CAD. The absolute 10-year risk of CAD was highest in slow walkers at high genetic risk (top 20% of PGS)

Depression was associated with a 51% higher risk of dementia, among which the increasing, chronically high, and chronically low courses were associated with increased dementia risk. No association was found in the decreasing course.

Genetically informed drug development and repurposing is an attractive prospect for improving patient outcomes in psychiatry. However, effectiveness of these endeavors is confounded by heterogeneity. We propose an approach that links interventions implicated by disorder-associated genetic risk, at the population level, to a framework that can target these compounds to individuals.

Genotype-to-phenotype prediction is a central problem of human genetics. In recent years, it has become possible to construct complex predictive models for phenotypes. This is thanks to the availability of large genome data sets and efficient machine learning tools.

Evidence for the effect of elevated blood pressure (BP) on the risk of venous thromboembolism (VTE) has been conflicting. We sought to assess the association between systolic BP and therisk of VTE. Each 20 mmHg increase in BP was associated with a 7% lower VTE risk.

Despite reported psychological hazards of information technology (IT) work, studies of diagnosed mental health conditions in IT workers are lacking. We investigated self-reported mental health outcomes in the UK Biobank cohort. IT workers had lower incident anxiety/depression (HR = 0.84, 95%CI 0.77-0.93) compared to all other employed participants.

Although there are pronounced sex differences for psychiatric disorders, relatively little has been published on the heterogeneity of sex-specific genetic effects for these traits until very recently for adults. Much less is known about children because most psychiatric disorders will not manifest until later in life and existing studies for children are underpowered.

Traditional PRS prediction methods are predominantly for the European population. accuracy of PRS is diminished due to much smaller sample size of genome-wide association studies (GWAS) We introduced a novel method to construct PRS for non-European populations, abbreviated as TL-Multi.

Atrial fibrillation (AF) frequently occurs in patients with type 2 diabetes (T2D) However, the longitudinal associations of new-onset AF with risks of adverse health outcomes remain unclear. We aimed to determine the associations of AF with subsequent risks of atherosclerotic cardiovascular disease (ASCVD), heart failure, chronic kidney disease (CKD), and mortality among patients with T2D.

Of 377,909 UK Biobank participants having European ancestry, 3,210 (0.8%) died due to CV disease during a median follow-up of 8.9 years. CV mortality risk was significantly associated with CAD PRS and T2DM PRS. There was no evidence of significant interaction between PRSs and age, sex, or lifestyle behavior in predicting the risk of CV mortality.

Latent class analysis detected groups of middle-aged individuals clustering by cardiometabolic health. The relationship of age with brain volumes varies by sex, menopausal status, and cardiometric health profile. In those aged >60 years, negative associations of age were greater in the class comprising healthier older women.

We investigated the dynamics of the relationship between SHBG, total testosterone (total-T), and body mass index (BMI) throughout puberty. The directionality of this relationship was explored using polygenic scores of SHBG and total-T. Two-sample Mendelian Randomization (in male adults) showed the effect of BMI on SHBG but no effect of SH BG on BMI. These results shed new light on their possible relationship with obesity.

A total of 440,693 white European (55.9% women), 7305 South Asian (48.6%) and 7628 black African or Caribbean (57.7%) people were included from UK Biobank. Over a median (IQR) of 12.6 (11.8, 13.3) follow-up years, there were 22,711 (5.15%) cardiovascular events in white European, 463 (6.34%) in South Asian and 302 (3.96%) in black African/Caribbean individuals. For South Asian people, the cardiovascular hazard ratio (HR) compared to white European people was 1.28 (99% CI [1.16, 1.43]

 MR-GxE requires an interaction to be explicitly identified, while MR-GENIUS does not. We find both approaches share similar assumptions, though differences between the approaches lend themselves to differing research settings. We explore the effect of body mass index (BMI) upon systolic blood pressure using data from the UK Biobank.

Lung cancer incidence (hazard ratio [HR]: 1.59, 95% confidence interval [CI], 1.44-1.76) increased among participants with  in utero  tobacco exposure. High PRSs with smoking initiation in childhood had HRs of 18.71 for incidence (95% CI, 14.21-24.63,  P  interaction  = 0.004) and 19.74 for mortality.

The combined effects of ambient air pollution, lifestyle, and genetic predisposition on incident Type 2 Diabetes (T2D) have not been well documented. A total of 263,733 participants without T2D at baseline were identified from the UK Biobank. During a median follow-up of 11.94 years, 7827 (2.97 %) incident T1D cases were identified. Lifestyle was the leading risk factor with a weighted PAF of 25.54 %.

Copy number variation (CNV) is known to influence human traits. Progress on copy-number-based genome-wide association studies (GWASs) from next-generation sequencing (NGS) data has been limited. Here we present a novel method for large-scale copy number analysis from NGS data generating robust copy number estimates.

Study included 348,290 participants from UK Biobank who completed eligible food frequency questionnaires. Western Pattern was associated with an increased risk of multimorbidity. More frequent intakes of processed meat and poultry were associated with higher risks.

No previous study has examined social and spatial determinants of biomarkers together. We present a novel extension of quantitative intersectional analyses using cross-classified multilevel models. Our results suggest intersectional inequalities in biomarkers of healthy ageing are mostly established by age 40-49, but different intersections show different relationships with deprivation.

High levels of IMD were significantly associated with higher risks of BD, depression and anxiety. Multiple candidate genetic loci interacting with IMD provided novel insights into the biological mechanism.

SuperSTR is used to process whole-genome and whole-exome sequencing data. It efficiently screening and identifying known and potential disease-associated STRs in the exomes of 49,953 biobank participants.

Coffee was inversely associated with CKD in a dose-dependent manner. The effects of coffee did not differ across different strata of genetic risk for CKD. Testosterone and sex hormone-binding globulin (SHBG) modified the coffee-CKD association.

In a prospective cohort study based on UK Biobank, 501,376 dementia-free participants were recruited in 2006-2010. During a mean follow-up of 10.66 years, 5,185 dementia cases were identified. When analyzed separately, multiple studied items related to physical and mental activity showed significant associations with the risk of dementia. A higher level of adherence to activity patterns related to frequent vigorous and other exercises, housework-related activity, and friend/family visit was associated with a lower risk.

There has been a growing body of evidence associating consumption of ultraprocessed foods (UPF) with adverse health outcomes including depression, cardiovascular disease, and all-cause mortality. Whether UPF are associated with dementia is unknown. Authors investigated the associations between UPF and dementia incidence in the UK Biobank.

Protein intake linked to type 2 diabetes (T2D) remains unclear. The aim of this study was to investigate the associations of protein intake with development of T2D. Red meat, processed meat, poultry, and eggs were associated with an increased risk.

Systemic chronic inflammation (SCI) is associated with poor sleep outcomes. The role of SCI in diet health and sleep quality relationship has not been well established.

In high-dimensional regression problems, often a relatively small subset of the features are relevant for predicting the outcome. When multiple correlated outcomes are available (multitask), reduced rank regression is an effective way to borrow strength and capture latent structures that underlie the data.

The burden of kidney function impairment is increasing in modern medicine. The effects from kidney function on diverse biochemical parameters are not yet fully understood. A higher genetically predicted eGFR was significantly associated with higher lymphocyte percentage, HDL cholesterol, and alanine aminotransferase.

Mendelian Randomisation (MR) can be used to estimate the causal effect of an exposure on an outcome in the presence of unobserved confounding. Multivariable MR (MVMR) allows for multiple, potentially highly related, exposures to be included in an MR estimation. MVMR estimates the direct effect of each exposure on the outcome conditional on all the other exposures included in the estimation.

Multiple sclerosis (MS) is a chronic neurodegenerative disease. It has a strong genetic component and is more prevalent in women. MS is caused by an autoimmunity initiated inflammatory response. The goal of this article was to explore X-linked genetic factors that are associated with MS susceptibility.

Maternal genetic effects can be defined as the effect of a mother's genotype on the phenotype of her offspring. We present a simple extension to the basic adoption design to partition maternal genetic effects into prenatal and postnatal effects. We apply our model to polygenic scores of educational attainment and birth weight associated variants, in up to 5,178 adopted singletons.

The recent novel coronavirus disease (COVID-19) outbreak is threatening global health. An understanding of the interaction of SARS-CoV-2 with human cells is still lacking. We identified six nonsense and missense variants of hACE2 from 2585 subjects in the UK Biobank covering 500000 individuals.

Estimating effects of parental and sibling genotypes (indirect genetic effects) can provide insight into how the family environment influences phenotypic variation. We used UK Biobank data to estimate polygenic score (PGS) associations for height, BMI and educational attainment in self-reported singletons and non-singletons. We estimate that a 1 SD increase in sibling educational attainment PGS corresponds to a 0.025 year increase in the index individual's school years.

Polygenic risk score (PRS) is often used to estimate an individual's genetic susceptibility to complex traits and disorders. PRSs for these traits are often based on Genome-Wide Association Studies (GWAS) data with both male and female samples included, ignoring sex differences.

Endometriosis is a condition characterized by implants of endometrial tissues into extrauterine sites, mostly within the pelvic peritoneum. The prevalence of the condition is under-diagnosed and is estimated to account for 5-10% of all women of reproductive age. We applied machine learning algorithms to train an endometiosis prediction model. The informative features of the model may improve clinical utility for endometriotic diagnosis.

The integration of PRS and lifestyles can improve the prediction of RA risk. High RA risk can be alleviated by adopting healthy lifestyles. Those with high genetic risks and unfavorable lifestyles had as high as OR of 4.637.

HaploNet is a method for performing dimensionality reduction and clustering of genetic data. It uses neural networks from whole-genome sequencing or dense genotype data. We show that our approach is better at distinguishing closely related populations than standard admixture and principal component analysis software.

Bayesian EstimatioN of CHange (BENCH) is a Bayesian framework to make inference on changes in the parameters of biophysical models. In this paper, we apply the approach in the context of microstructural modelling of diffusion MRI data, where the models are usually over-parameterised and not invertible.

Little is known about the molecular bases of individual differences in EFs. We found 129 independent genome-wide significant lead variants in 112 distinct loci. cEF was associated with fast synaptic transmission processes in gene-based analyses.

Sex differences in the relationship between brain structural complexity and general intelligence (g) in UK and Indian populations are investigated. Brain complexity and volume were both positively corelated with intelligence, with the correlations being significant in women but not always in men. This relationship is seen across populations of differing ages and geographical locations.

Modelling and predicting individual differences in task-fMRI activity can have a wide range of applications from basic to clinical neuroscience. We show that features extracted using Stochastic Probabilistic Functional Modes (sPROFUMO) outperform the previously proposed dual-regression approach.

Outlier DetectIon for Networks (ODIN) was successful in identifying moderate to extreme outliers. Removing such outliers can significantly change inferences in downstream applications. ODIN has been implemented in both Python and R.

Clinical heterogeneity is common in Mendelian disease. Small sample sizes make it difficult to identify specific contributing factors. If a disease represents the severely affected extreme of a spectrum of phenotypic variation, then modifier effects may be apparent.

SCHEMA consortium has identified 10 genes in which protein-truncating variants (PTVs) confer a substantial risk of schizophrenia. Study aimed to determine whether carrying these PTVs was associated with neuropsychiatric impairment in the general population.

Age-related hearing loss is a common, heterogeneous disease with a strong genetic component. More than 100 loci have been reported to be involved in human hearing impairment to date. Most of the genes underlying human adult-onset hearing loss remain unknown.

Prostate cancer (PCa) screening is not routinely conducted in men aged 55 and younger. Polygenic risk scores (PRSs) and patient data applied toward early prediction of PCa may lead to earlier interventions and increased survival.

A total of 69 524 hypertensives without a history of diabetes mellitus, coronary heart disease, or stroke at baseline were enrolled. Five dimensions of healthy sleep at baseline including early chronotype, sleep 7-8 h/d, free of insomnia, no snoring, and no frequent excessive daytime sleepiness were used to generate a healthy sleep score ranging from 0 to 5.

Multistage disease processes are often characterized by a linear relationship. We used a Weibull distribution to model diseases that occur through an ordered sequence of stages. The rate at which disease risk increases with age was used to distinguish between "sporadic" diseases and "late-onset" diseases.

Gene-based association studies have shown that integrating genome-wide association studies (GWAS) with expression quantitative trait locus (eQTL) data can boost statistical power. We propose a new gene-based statistical method that leverages gene-expression measurements and new PRSs to identify genes associated with phenotypes of interest.

Male p.C282Y homozygotes have markedly increased hepatic malignancy incidence. No increases in risks were found for other studied cancers. Replication of results in other large community genotyped cohorts needed.

Trans-ancestry association mapping (TRAM) offers an exciting opportunity to fill the gap of disparities in genetic studies between non-Europeans and Europeans. We showed that LOG-TRAM can greatly improve the statistical power of identifying risk variants in under-represented populations.

Higher circulating polyunsaturated fatty acids (PUFAs), especially omega-3 fatty acids, have been linked to a better prognosis in patients of coronavirus disease 2019 (COVID-19) However, the effects and causality of pre-infection PUFA levels remain unclear. This study aimed to investigate the observational and causal associations of circulating PUFAs with CO VID-19 susceptibility and severity.

Hippocampal formation plays a major role in complex human functions across the lifespan. Much of the genetic architecture of the hippocampal formation is currently unexplored. We reveal 177 unique genetic loci with distributed associations across the hippocampus. We identify genetic overlap with eight brain disorders.

High baseline diastolic BP was associated with a slightly smaller relative increase in reaction time and a slightly greater reduction in depression scores. White matter microstructural changes were consistent with those seen in the aging process. These results are congruent with the view that a higher BP in the aged brain has a complex role.

The UK Biobank (UKBB) is a population-scale dataset of genotype and phenotype data collected from the United Kingdom. The exact content of these non-UK ancestries is largely uncharacterized. Study could highlight valuable intracontinental ancestry references.

Physical activity data from 222,031 female participants with an intact uterus in the UK Biobank study were analyzed. Each 1 MET-h/week increase in total physical activity was associated with a 0.2% [95% confidence interval (CI), 0.1-0.4; P = 0.020] reduction in endometrial cancer risk.

Study included participants from the UK Biobank Infectious Disease pilot study with valid serum antibody (IgG) measurements taken at cohort entry (2006-2010) for herpes simplex virus type 1 (HSV1), varicella zoster virus (VZV), and cytomegalovirus (CMV) Linked hospital and mortality records up to December 30 2019 provided information on rates of (1) incident first stroke or MI and (2) all-cause mortality. Human herpesvirus titers were not associated with outcomes.

The prevalence of cardiometabolic multimorbidity (CMM), which significantly increases the risk of mortality, is increasing globally. The role of healthy lifestyle in the secondary prevention of CMM is unclear.
