CMM was defined as coexistence of at least two of hypertension (HTN), diabetes mellitus (DM), coronary heart disease (CHD), and stroke (ST)

Within-family genetic variation is random, enabling unbiased estimation of direct genetic effects when parents are genotyped. However, parental genotypes are often missing. We introduce a method that imputes missing parental genotype and estimates direct genetic effect. Our method, implemented in the software package snipar, gives more precise estimates of direct Genetic effects than existing approaches.

There is substantial literature on how loneliness is associated with poor health. But little detailed research on the extent of its economic gradients. We provide this evidence using a sample of around 400,000 respondents aged 40-70 years from the UK Biobank.

The relationship between obesity and neurocognitive consequences is complex. Here we investigated associations between body mass index (BMI) and subsequent changes in brain structures, cognitive changes, and the onset of dementia. After correcting for confounding factors, higher BMI was associated with greater retention in visuospatial memory performance.

 sumSTAAR is a framework for gene-based association analysis using summary statistics obtained from genome-wide association studies. It is an extended and modified version of STAAR framework proposed by Li and colleagues in 2020. The methods used in the framework were adapted to analyse genes with large number of SNPs.

Varicose veins affect one-third of Western society. Current management consists of either compression stockings, or surgical ablation for more advanced disease. Most patients report a positive family history, and heritability is 17%.

Older, overweight men, and those with type 2 diabetes, have lower testosterone concentrations and poorer COVID-19-related outcomes. Younger age, higher BMI, non-White ethnicity, lower educational attainment, and socioeconomic deprivation were associated with incidence of SARS-CoV-2 infections.

Study included 242,754 participants with complete shift work information in the UK Biobank. The results showed a significant association of permanent night shift work with incident HF among females. The association between the risk of HF and shift work was strengthened by high genetic risk.

Anxiety disorders are leading contributors to the global disease burden. UK Biobank study recruited >500 000 adults, aged 37-73, between 2006 and 2010. Individuals with anxiety disorders had a lower hand-grip strength and lower blood pressure.

Accurate 3D modelling of cardiac chambers is essential for clinical assessment of cardiac volume and function, including structural, and motion analysis. To study the correlation between cardiac morphology and other patient information within a large population, it is necessary to automatically generate cardiac mesh models of each subject within the population. In this study, we introduce MCSI-Net (Multi-Cue Shape Inference Network), where we embed a statistical shape model inside a convolutional neural network.

Sleep health is considered a key determinant of human physiological and psychological well-being. Previous studies have found that poor sleep is associated with various psychiatric disorders, in particular, with anxiety and depression. Recent findings suggest essential dimensions of SH are associated with altered amygdala reactivity.

Myelin, iron, and calcium are major constituents of brain tissue with magnetic properties that can be detected non-invasively using MRI. Using quantitative susceptibility mapping, we estimated the magnetic susceptibility of brain structures in 35,273 participants.

The role of copy number variants (CNVs) in susceptibility to asthma is not well understood. The recent availability of whole-exome sequencing (WES) in large biobank studies provides an unprecedented opportunity to study the role of CNVs in asthma.

This is the first study to utilize PRS as a phenotype-agnostic group classification in AD genetic studies. We identify potential new loci for AD and detail phenotypic analysis of these PRS extremes. We also show highly significant genetic correlations with multiple health-related outcomes that provide insights into prodromal symptoms and comorbidities.

The spleen plays a key role in iron homeostasis. It is the largest filter of the blood and performs iron reuptake from old or damaged erythrocytes. Despite this role, spleen iron concentration has not been measured in a large, population-based cohort.

We performed the HyPrColoc colocalization analysis to detect possible shared causal genes between dementia or Alzheimer's disease (AD) and 5 selected traits: stroke, diabetes, atherosclerosis, cholesterol level, and alcohol consumption. Rs150562240 in the LPIN3 gene was identified as a candidate shared causal variant across dementia, AD and Atherosclerosis.

We present a graph embedded topic model (GETM) We integrate existing biomedical knowledge graph information in the form of pre-trained graph embedding. GETM-inferred phenotypes not only accurately predict the status of chronic musculoskeletal (CMK) pain but also reveal known pain-related topics.

Transition from acute to chronic pain is critically important but not well understood. We found thousands of dynamic transcriptional changes over 3 months in LBP participants with resolved pain but none in those with persistent pain. Transient neutrophil-driven up-regulation of inflammatory responses was protective against the transition to chronicPain.

For many complex phenotypes, the assumptions of the linear regression models are not always met. We compared the prediction accuracy of the neural network models to that of classical approaches based on linear regression. The models performed similarly unless the observed distribution of the phenotype was skewed, in which case the neural networks had smaller mean squared error.

Type 2 diabetes (T2D) is a complex chronic disease characterized by considerable phenotypic heterogeneity. We applied a reverse graph embedding method to routinely collected data from 23,137 Scottish patients with newly diagnosed diabetes to visualize this heterogeneity.

The association of cardiovascular diseases (CVDs) with dementia differs by sex. The role of socioeconomic, lifestyle, genetic, and medical factors in their association is unknown. We used data from the UK Biobank, a population-based cohort study.

The UK Biobank is a large middle-aged cohort recruited in 2006-2010. We used data from its participants to analyze mortality, survival, and causes of death associated with mental disorders. We found significantly increased mortality risk associated with all mental disorders identified by symptom-based outcomes, except for lifetime generalized anxiety disorder.

Evidence about the risk of breast cancer according to women's bone mineral density (BMD) is scarce, and little is known about their causal associations. Women participating in the UK Biobank cohort were used to investigate the association between BMD and breast cancer using Cox regression models.

Health disparity across layers of society involves reasons beyond the healthcare system. Socioeconomic status (SES) shapes people's daily interaction with their social environment. Using generative probabilistic modeling, we investigate health satisfaction and complementary indicators of socioeconomic lifestyle in the human social brain.

 Epidemiologic studies have highlighted smoking as an important driver of somatic mutations across multiple tissues. Establishing the causal role of smoking in clonal hematopoiesis has been limited by observational study designs, which may suffer from confounding and reverse-causality.

Pathological brain appearances may be so heterogeneous as to be intelligible only as anomalies. Detecting such anomalies requires models of the normal brain that combine compactness and expressivity. We combine the latent representation of vector quantised variational autoencoders with an ensemble of autoregressive transformers to enable unsupervised anomaly detection and segmentation.

The molecular determinants of tissue composition of the human brain remain largely unknown. Recent genome-wide association studies (GWAS) on this topic have had limited success due to methodological constraints. Key molecular pathways involved in axonal growth, astrocyte-mediated neuroinflammation and synaptogenesis during development are found to significantly impact the measured variations in tissue-specific imaging features.

Evidence for the association between vitamin D and risk of recurrent stroke remains sparse and limited. We aimed to assess the relationship between serum circulating 25-hydroxyvitamin D (25(OH)D) level and risk. Data from the nationwide prospective United Kingdom Biobank were used for analyses.

Study aimed to evaluate whether polygenic risk scores could be helpful in addition to family history for triaging individuals. Monogenic causes of complex diseases were more prevalent among individuals with a parental disease history than in the rest of the population.

UK Biobank recruited 502,624 participants aged 37 to 73 years between 2006 and 2010. Of 441,403 participants with complete data, 3180 were hospitalised for COVID-19 and 1040 (0.2%) died from the disease. Chronic pain was associated with hospital admission for CO VID-19 even after adjustment for all covariates.

With the advent of high throughput genetic data, there have been attempts to estimate heritability from genome-wide SNP data. Fitting such an LMM in a large scale cohort study is tremendously challenging due to its high dimensional linear algebraic operations. PredLMM has substantially better computational complexity than most of the existing LMM based methods and thus, provides a fast alternative for estimating heritability.

Walking pace is a strong predictor of health status, but the nature of its association with leucocyte telomere length (LTL) is unclear. LTL is causally associated with several chronic diseases and has been proposed as a marker of biological age.

Genome-wide association studies (GWASs) have demonstrated that most common diseases have a strong genetic component from many genetic variants each with a small effect size. Here, we propose to improve PGS-based risk estimation by incorporating genetic ancestry derived from genome-wide genotyping data.

Vitamin D has been associated with reduced risk of developing invasive breast cancer. However, their association with risk of ductal carcinoma in situ (DCIS) of the breast has received little attention.

Antidepressant-related adverse drug reactions depend partly on genetic variation. We hypothesized that candidate genetic polymorphisms are associated with fall risk in older antidepressant users. The association between antidepressant use and falls was cross-sectionally investigated in a cohort of Dutch older adults.

High stress in Childhood and Adulthood was associated with decreases in executive function and working memory in both males and females. Stress across the lifespan was also positively associated with the number of diagnosed mental health problems, with a stronger effect in females than in males.

Heritability is a fundamental concept in genetic studies, measuring the genetic contribution to complex traits. Linkage disequilibrium (LD) score regression (LDSC) estimates both heritability and confounding biases, such as cryptic relatedness and population stratification. We propose LD eigenvalue regression (LDER), an extension of LDSC, by making full use of the LD information.

The study is based on the data from the UK Biobank, which recruited 500,000 participants. Genetic risk was categorized into low, intermediate, and high groups. The lifestyle score comprised the body mass index, smoking, physical activity, and diet.

Two recently reported neuroanatomical signatures of schizophrenia-signature 1, with widespread reduction of gray matter volume, and signature 2, with increased striatal volume-were replicated. Authors compared cognition, psychopathology, and polygenic risk between signatures. Signature 1 was associated with worse cognitive performance than signature 2.

Rheumatoid arthritis (RA) is a chronic inflammatory disease that affects the joints. Diet can represent both a risk factor and a protective factor. Oily fish, alcohol, coffee and breakfast cereals have protective roles in RA.

PolyPred combines two predictors: a new predictor that leverages functionally informed fine-mapping to estimate causal effects (instead of tagging effects) and BOLT-LMM, a published predictor. We applied PolyPred to 49 diseases/traits in four UK Biobank populations and observed relative improvements ranging from +7% in south Asians to +32% in Africans. We propose PolyPred+ which further incorporates the non-European training data.

The pathogenesis of COVID-19 is unknown, and relevant mortality predictors are lacking. De-identified data from 113,882 were collected from the UK Biobank. Data from 14,876 patients were input into the machine learning model for risk-level mortality prediction. Age, lifestyle, illness, income, and family disease history were identified as important predictors of CO VID-19 mortality.

A lack of internationally agreed standards for combining available data sources at scale risks inconsistent disease phenotyping limiting research reproducibility. We developed a rules-based algorithm to identify coronary artery disease (CAD) sub-phenotypes using electronic health records (EHR) and questionnaire data.

Heritability is the proportion of phenotypic variance explained by genome-wide single nucleotide polymorphisms (SNPs) in unrelated individuals. We develop a fast approach, minimum norm quadratic unbiased estimator (MINQUE) with batch training, to estimate variance components from LMM (LMM.MNQ.BCH)

Study looked at 273,240 women and 228,957 men from the UK Biobank. Over a median of 11.8 years follow-up, 1,866 dementia cases were recorded in women and 2,202 in men. U-shaped associations between the number of children and the risk of dementia were similar for both sexes.

Study included 165,493 participants who are free of hypertension at baseline from the UK Biobank. Sleep behaviors, including chronotype, sleep duration, insomnia, snoring, and daytime sleepiness were used to construct a healthy sleep score. We also derived a healthy lifestyle score based on smoking status, diet quality, physical activity, and body mass index.

Since 2005, genome-wide association (GWA) datasets have been largely biased toward sampling European ancestry individuals. Recent studies have shown that GWA results estimated from self-identified European individuals are not transferable to non-European individuals. We demonstrate that enrichment analyses that aggregate SNP-level association statistics at multiple genomic scales can generate biologically interpretable hypotheses.

Many studies on prostate cancer (PCa) germline variants have been published in the last 15 years. SNP-based GRS and RPMs in four genes were significantly and consistently associated with PCa risk in large well-designed studies. Prospective studies evaluating the performance of all three inherited measures in predicting PCa detection rate from contemporary multiparametric MRI are lacking.

Study included individuals free of stroke at baseline from the UK Biobank. Night-shift work was assessed by the self-reported questions. Incident stroke was ascertained through hospital records and death registries. Night shift work increased the risk of incident stroke.

Previous studies have found that the susceptibility of coronavirus disease 2019 and the risk of severe COVID-19 are not increased in patients with celiac disease (CeD) This study aimed to further clarify the underlying relationship by both observational and Mendelian randomization (MR) analysis.

Several diseases are linked to increased risk of Coronavirus disease 19 (COVID-19) Our aim was to investigate whether depressive and anxiety symptoms predict subsequent risk. Depressive symptoms but not anxiety predicted (i) being tested for SARS-CoV-2.

Previous observational studies examining the risk of cancer among patients with chronic kidney disease (CKD) are conflicting. We explore the causal relationship between estimated glomerular filtration rate (eGFR) and albuminuria, two principal measurements of CKD, and 19 site-specific cancers.

The association between hyperuricemia/gout with cardiovascular diseases (CVD) has not been investigated. We conducted a cohort analysis including 431,967 participants. During mean 10.20 years of follow-up, hyperurICemia patients were associated with increased CVD. The risk elevation was even higher for gout patients (HR = 1.54)

Age-related macular degeneration (AMD) is the principal cause of blindness in developed countries. AMD severity is quantified by Color Fundus Photographs (CFP) of the retina. Many machine-learning-based methods are proposed for grading AMD severity. Few models were developed to predict the longitudinal progression status.

A quantitative classification of sleep phenotypes would lead to the advancement of biomedical mechanisms underlying human sleep diversity. This kind of quantitative pipeline of sleep analysis is expected to promote data-based diagnosis of sleep disorders.

A total of 120,343 participants from the U.K. Biobank study with at least two 24 h dietary assessments were studied. Two DPs were identified that jointly explained a total of 63% variation in four nutrients. DP1 was characterized by high intakes of chocolate and confectionery, butter, low-fiber bread, and sugars and preserves.

Inferring the structure of human populations from genetic variation data is a key task in population and medical genomic studies. Current methods are impractical to run on biobank-scale genomic datasets containing millions of individuals. SCOPE infers population structure in about a day on a dataset containing one million individuals and variants.

 Frailty is common in early and established RA and associated with hospitalisation and mortality. Frailty in RA is dynamic and, for some, may be ameliorated through controlling disease activity in early disease.

A lack of physical activity (PA) is one of the most pressing health issues today. Our individual propensity for PA is influenced by genetic factors. Stated liking of different PA types may help capture additional and informative dimensions of PA behavior genetics.

Over 4.2 million person-years, 4270 dementia cases occurred in 351,436 UK Biobank participants. Wine intake showed a significant U-shaped association with the lowest risk for incident dementia. In contrast, non-wine is positively related to dementia risk in a linear fashion. No clear association is found for coffee.

Between 2006 and 2010, a total of 341,331 participants (age 37-73 years) in the UK Biobank were examined and thereafter followed up to 2020. The CVH raised by the AHA included 4 behavioral (smoking, diet, physical activity, body mass index) and 3 biological (fasting glucose, blood cholesterol, blood pressure) metrics.

The ability to accurately predict an individual's risk for cancer is critical to the implementation of precision prevention measures. Current cancer risk predictions are frequently made with simple models that use a few proven risk factors, such as the Gail model for breast cancer.

A high healthy lifestyle index (HLI) is a composite score based on good diet quality, low alcohol consumption, no smoking, moderate to high physical activity, and waist circumference. In postmenopausal women, compared with a low HLI, higher scores were associated with a reduced risk of breast cancer.

Use of the dietary supplement glucosamine has been associated with reduced risk of colorectal cancer. However, it remains unclear if the association varies by screening status, time, and other factors. We evaluated these questions in UK Biobank.

Sleep behaviors were believed to be associated with mental disorders (MD) But the underlying mechanism of such association relationship remains unclear. A total of 402,290 participants from UK Biobank who don't have MD at baseline were included.

Study included 152,611 participants free of diabetes and cardiovascular disease in the UK Biobank. Per-SD increase in ASI was associated with a 3% higher T2D risk (95% CI 2-4%). The hazard ratio (HR) of T2d was 1.58 (1.39-1.80) in the highest quintile group.

Biobanks linked to massive, longitudinal electronic health record (EHR) data make numerous new genetic research questions feasible. High blood pressure measurements over visits strongly predict stroke onset, and consistently high fasting glucose and Hb1Ac levels define diabetes.

Sex-specific differences have been noted among people with chronic obstructive pulmonary disease. Whether these differences are attributable to genetic variation is poorly understood. The availability of large biobanks with deeply phenotyped subjects such as the UK Biobank enables the investigation of sex-specific genetic associations.

A polygenic risk score estimates the genetic risk of an individual for some disease or trait. It is calculated by aggregating the effect of many common variants associated with the condition. With the increasing availability of genetic data in large cohort studies such as the UK Biobank, inclusion of this genetic risk is becoming more widespread.

A selection of state-of-the-art approaches were assessed. Different methods were also applied to a section of the UK biobank cohort for Atrial Fibrillation. PLINK's implementation of BOOST recovered the highest number of correct interactions.

There is a paucity of epidemiological evidence on alcohol and the risk of bradyarrhythmias. We studied 407 948 middle-aged individuals (52.4% female) over a median follow-up time of 11.5 years. Increasing total alcohol consumption was not associated with an increased risk. Beer and cider intake were associated with increased brady arrhythmia risk up to 12 drinks/week.

Cardiometabolic diseases are the leading cause of death worldwide. Despite a known genetic component, our understanding of these diseases remains incomplete. We analyzed data from 200,337 UK Biobank participants with whole-exome sequencing. There was a striking risk associated with mutations in known Mendelian disease genes.

Cardiovascular diseases (CVDs) are the primary cause of all death globally. Timely and accurate identification of people at risk of developing an atherosclerotic CVD and its sequelae is a central pillar of preventive cardiology. One widely used approach is risk prediction models.

Drug development and biological discovery require effective strategies to map existing genetic associations to causal genes. We selected 12 common diseases and quantitative traits for which highly powered genome-wide association studies (GWAS) were available. We found that positive control genes were highly enriched in proximity to GWAS-associated single-nucleotide variants (SNVs)

Physical activity (PA) is recognized as one of the key lifestyle behaviors that reduces risk of developing dementia late in life. However, PA also leads to increased respiration, and in areas with high levels of air pollution, PA may increase exposure to pollutants linked with higher risk of dementia. Here, we investigate whether air pollution attenuates the association between PA and dementia risk.

The fibrous annulus of the mitral valve plays an important role in valvular function and cardiac physiology. Normal variation in the size of cardiovascular anatomy may share a genetic link with common and rare disease. We derived automated estimates of mitral valves annular diameter in the 4-chamber view from 32,220 MRI images.

Diabetes-related complications reflect longstanding damage to small and large vessels throughout the body. Early heritability studies found strong familial clustering of both macrovascular and microvascular complications. More severe diabetes retinopathy possessed higher genetic contributions.

It is unclear how different diets may affect human brain development. We investigated diet effects in the UK Biobank data from 18,879 healthy adults. We found anticorrelated brain-wide gray matter volume (GMV)-association patterns between coffee and cereal intake.

Current models implicate adaptive neuroplastic changes in the visual system and their pro-cognitive effects as a schizophrenia resilience mechanism. We investigated whether common genetic resilience variants might affect brain structure in similar neural circuits.

The calcium ion channel ORAI1 has emerged as a promising therapeutic target for the Coronavirus Disease 19 (COVID-19)-associated pneumonia. A pharmacological inhibitor of ORAi1 has now reached clinical trials for severe COVID- 19 pneumonia. Whether ORA I1 itself is associated with an increased risk for severe CoV-19 presentation is still unknown.

Among 449,595 participants, 22,338 (5.0%) were diagnosed with IBS. During a median of 12.2-year follow-up, 2,937 cases of incident cancer were identified in patients with Ibs. Compared with non-IBS, the adjusted hazard ratio for overall cancer and cancer-specific mortality was 0.97 (95% confidence interval: 0.93-1.00, P = 0.062)

Heritability of a trait is measured as the proportion of total variance explained by the additive effects of genome-wide single nucleotide polymorphisms. Heritability is usually estimated by the restricted maximum likelihood or method of moments approaches such as Haseman-Elston regression. Our proposed method is computationally scalable on biobank datasets and gives an asymptotically unbiased estimate of heritability in presence of discrete substructures.

Large-scale prospective cohort study included 370,671 participants without CKD at baseline. Five sleep behaviors were made up of sleep duration, insomnia, snoring, chronotype, and daytime sleepiness. 17.1% of CKD in this cohort could be attributed to total poor sleep pattern.

Longer sleep was positively associated with lung cancer risk compared with normal sleep duration. Frequent insomnia symptoms increased the risk of lung cancer compared with never/rarely experiencing symptoms. In analysis excluding participants reporting shift work at baseline, evening chronotypes were at a greater risk.

UK Biobank (UKB) is widely employed to investigate mental health disorders and related exposures. We present the first validation study using secondary care mental health data with linkage to UKB from Oxford - Clinical Record Interactive Search (CRIS) We calculated the positive predictive value (PPV, proportion of true positives cases detected) for mental health diagnosis and relevant medication.

Many neuroimaging studies have demonstrated the potential of functional network connectivity patterns estimated from resting functional magnetic resonance imaging (fMRI) to discriminate groups and predict information about individual subjects. In this study, we investigate the use of pairwise-relationships between resting-state independent spatial maps to characterize individuals.

Melatonin receptor 1B gene (MTNR1B) rs10830963 influences the dynamics of melatonin secretion. Night shift work, which disrupts our internal circadian rhythms, also dysregulates the production ofmelatonin. A significant interaction was found between night shift work and MTNR1b rs108 30963 on the incidence of prostate cancer.

Pancreatitis is a complex syndrome that results from many etiologies. Large well-characterized cohorts are needed to further understand disease risk and prognosis. A pancreatitis cohort of more than 4,200 patients and 24,000 controls were identified. Gallstones and smoking were confirmed as key risk factors for AP and CP.

Higher body mass index (BMI) and metabolic consequences of excess weight are associated with increased risk of severe COVID-19, though their mediating pathway is unclear. We examined associations of total adiposity, body composition and fat distribution with incidence and severity of the disease.

Polygenic risk scores (PRS) are valuable to translate the results of genome-wide association studies (GWAS) into clinical practice. To date, most GWAS have been based on individuals of European-ancestry leading to poor performance in populations of non-European ancestry. We introduce the polygenic transcriptome risk score (PTRS), which is based on predicted transcript levels (rather than SNPs) and explore the portability of PTRS across populations.

The algorithm was trained on retinal images from 50,077 UK Biobank participants and tested on 12,185 participants. The addition of the algorithm to the TRFs model improved risk stratification with an overall NRI of 50.8%. Our results demonstrate that this deep learning algorithm can be a useful tool for stratifying individuals at high risk of type 2 diabetes in the general population.

DeepNull is a method that identifies and adjusts for non-linear and interactive covariate effects using a deep neural network. When applied to 10 phenotypes from the UK Biobank, DeepNull discovered more hits (+6%) and loci (+7%), on average, than conventional association analyses.

P-smoother runs a bidirectional PBWT-based panel scanning that flips mismatching alleles based on the overall haplotype matching context. In a simulated panel with 4000 haplotypes and a 0.2% error rate, we show it can reliably correct 85% of errors. We also showed that PS-cluster is adequately efficient for UK Biobank data.

There is growing interest in the clinical application of polygenic scores as their predictive utility increases for a range of health-related phenotypes. However, providing polygenic score predictions on the absolute scale is an important step for their safe interpretation. We have developed a method to convertpolygenic scores to theabsolute scale for binary and normally distributed phenotypes using summary statistics.

Mood disorders are characterised by pronounced symptom heterogeneity. This presents a substantial challenge both to clinical practice and research. Identification of subgroups of individuals with homogeneous symptom profiles could provide insights in to the transdiagnostic relevance of individual symptoms.

The polygenic risk score (PRS) can help to identify individuals' genetic susceptibility for various diseases. We developed novel network-based comorbidity risk scores to quantify associations among multiple phenotypes from phenome-wide association studies (PheWAS)

Iron homeostasis is associated with several neurodegenerative diseases, including Alzheimer's disease (AD) and may be partially modulated by genetic risk factors. We found that ApoE4 carriers had higher hippocampal. and amygdalar magnetic susceptibility, particularly individuals aged 65 years or older, while those carrying Apo.E2 (which protects against AD) had higher QSM only in the hippocampus.

Analysis included 93,389 adults aged 60-75 years from the UK Biobank. Diet was assessed using a web-based 24-h recall questionnaire between 2009-2012. Dementia was ascertained using hospital inpatient, death records, and self-reported data.

We compared EDP to the Quantile Regression Index (QRI; a linear alternative to the brain age metric)

A healthy sleep pattern is characterized by sleep of 7 to 8 h/d, no insomnia, no frequent snoring, and no daytime sleepiness. We included 392,218 European adults, aged 38 to 73 years, who were free of CKD at recruitment between March 13, 2006, and October 1, 2010.

There is little evidence on how factors relatively affect physical activity (PA) Using a socioecological approach, it was discovered that obesity and disease-related factors were the most important determinants. PCs related to body composition and chronic diseases were suggested as key determinants of objectively measured MVPA.

Prior studies have established that higher educational attainment is associated with a longer telomere length (TL), a marker of cellular aging. However, it is unclear whether extant associations are causal, since they are likely confounded by unobserved genetic, early-life and family background factors. We leverage sibling differences in TL, education and measured genetics to estimate associations between educational attainment and TL in midlife.

Outliers have usually been detected in a supervised or semi-supervised manner for labeled neuroimaging cohorts. There has been much less work using unsupervised outlier detection on large unlabeled cohorts like the UK Biobank brain imaging dataset. Given its large sample size, rare imaging phenotypes within this unique cohort are of interest.

One of the most commonly studied loci is the serotonin transporter (SLC6A4) promoter polymorphism. The genetic association signals between 5-HTTLPR and psychiatric phenotypes have been inconsistent across many studies. We developed a GWAS summary-statistics-based approach for testing the variable number of tandem repeat (VNTR) associations with various phenotypes.

 Transcriptome-wide association studies (TWAS) incorporated expression quantitative trait loci (eQTL) cohorts as a reference panel. We conducted tissue-specific TWAS on cigarettes per day (CPD) over thirteen brain tissues. We identified three major clusters of genes with different meta-patterns across tissues consistent in both cohorts. Downstream enrichment analyses on each gene cluster identified unique biological pathways associated with CPD.

Previous studies have demonstrated a U-shaped relationship between alcohol and sudden cardiac death (SCD) There is a paucity of evidence on the role of alcohol specifically on incident ventricular arrhythmias (VAs) The purpose of this study was to characterize associations of total and beverage-specific alcohol consumption with incident VA and SCD using data from the UK Biobank.

UK Biobank (UKB) is a large prospective cohort capturing numerous health outcomes, but limited occupational information. Job titles and UK Standard Occupational Classification (SOC) codes were collected. UK SOC codes were mapped to US SOC codes allowing linkage to O*NET variables.

Recent studies have found that women with obstetric disorders are at increased risk for a variety of long-term complications. The underlying pathophysiology of these connections remains undetermined.

Dietary and nutrition and dietary patterns are associated with the development of dementia. Participants of a longitudinal cohort study that included European adults who were middle to old aged at baseline and who had not been diagnosed with dementia at baseline (2006-2010)

Associations between colorectal cancer (CRC) and other health outcomes have been reported. We set out to determine whether genetic predisposition to CRC is also associated with the risk of other phenotypes. Under the phenome-wide association study (PheWAS) and tree-structured phenotypic model (TreeWAS), we studied 334,385 unrelated White British individuals.

Left atrial (LA) structure and function with prevalent and incident cardiovascular disease (CVD), independent of left ventricular (LV) metrics, in 25 896 UK Biobank participants. Lower LAEF was associated with diabetes, smoking, and all the prevalent and incidents CVDs. Diabetes, smoking and high cholesterol were associated with smaller LAV. Hypertension, IHD, AF (incident and prevalent), incident stroke, and CVD mortality were associated.

People from Black African, Black Caribbean and Indian groups were less likely to report hearing difficulty than their White British or Irish counterparts. For equivalent levels of hearing loss, the use of hearing aids is lower among ethnic minority groups. Inequalities are partly due to lower levels of self-reported hearing difficulty among minorities.

A significant proportion of patients with elevated LDL do not carry known genetic mutations associated with hypercholesterolemia, such as defects in the LDL receptor. To identify new genes involved in the cellular uptake of LDL, we developed a novel whole-genome clustered regularly interspaced short palindromic repeat-Cas9 KO screen in HepG2 cells. We identified transgelin ( TAGLN), an actin-binding protein, as a potentially new gene involved in LDL endocytosis.

Obesity and kidney diseases are common complex disorders with an increasing clinical and economic impact on healthcare around the globe. Our objective was to examine if modifiable anthropometric obesity indices show putatively causal association with kidney health and disease.

Wellbeing has a fundamental role in determining life expectancy and major depressive disorder (MDD) is one of the main modulating factors of wellbeing. This study evaluated the modulators of wellbeing in individuals with lifetime recurrent MDD, single-episode MDD and no MDD in the UK Biobank.

Researchers have developed a clustering technique for analysing activity data. The data was collected as part of the UK Biobank study. The findings sit alongside existing summary measures of physical activity.

Cataract is the most common cause of blindess globally. It is biologically plausible that cataract risk is increased by pollution exposure. This was a prospective, observational study involving 433,727 UK Biobank participants. Higher exposure to PM2.5 was associated with a 5% increased risk of incident cataracts surgery.

Evidence from several groups indicates that Klotho (KL), a gene encoding a single-pass transmembrane protein that acts as an FGF23 co-receptor, may be associated with longevity and healthy aging. We aimed to explore this area further by comparing the genotype counts in 642 long-lived individuals from the Newcastle 85+ Study with 18 295 middle-aged Newcastle-based controls.

Study included 13,366 participants with baseline type 2 diabetes from the UK Biobank. Lifestyle information was collected through a baseline questionnaire. During a median follow-up of 11.7 years, 1,561 deaths were documented.

Study included 449,971 (38-73 years old) participants, including 199,617 (44.36%) men in the UK Biobank Study. Both frailty and pre-frailty status significantly were associated with an increase of the CVD incidence and all-cause mortality across a wider age range.

TyG index is a substitute measure for insulin resistance (IR) Relationship between IR and lung cancer has been examined in previous studies. Findings have been controversial and previous studies had small sample sizes.

The functional significance and mechanisms determining the development and individual variability of structural brain asymmetry remain unclear. Here, we systematically analyzed all relevant components of the most prominent structural asymmetry, brain torque. Age-, sex-, and handedness-related effects on BT were assessed.

Human T-cell lymphotropic virus 1 (HTLV-1) has been associated with cognitive function and neuropsychiatric outcomes in humans. In this study, we sought to further generalize previously reported associations of cognitive function with the virus. The results of adjusted linear regression models showed no associations with reasoning, pairs-matching, or reaction-time cognitive tasks or with depression.

Brain structure, psychosocial, and physical factors underpin back pain conditions. Less is known about how these factors differ based on pain duration and location. We found differences in structural brain measures in the chronic pain groups alone.

The number of variants that have a non-zero effect on a trait is a fundamental parameter in the study of the genetic architecture of a complex trait. Although many previous studies have investigated polygenicity at a genome-wide scale, a detailed understanding of how it varies across genomic regions is currently lacking. In this work, we propose an accurate and scalable statistical framework to estimate regionalpolygenicity for acomplex trait.

Behavioral disinhibition is observed to be an important characteristic of many neurodevelopmental and psychiatric disorders. Recent studies have linked dietary quality to levels of behavioral inhibition. It is currently unclear whether brain factors might mediate this. The current study investigates whether cortical and subcortical brain volumes mediate part of the association.

Psychosis is associated with many forms of adversity, deprivation and living in urban areas. We sought to understand mechanisms by which childhood, recent/contemporary and place-based adversities might cluster and interact.

Figure 1 shows the size of the human body. Figure 1: The human body is made up of more than 100 million cells. Figure 2: The number of human cells is estimated to be around 100 million.

 sequencing of the human genome has allowed the study of the genetic architecture of common diseases. Common diseases are polygenic, with many loci contributing to phenotype. The cumulative burden of risk alleles determines individual risk in conjunction with environmental factors.

Study analyzed baseline UK Biobank data on plasma glycated hemoglobin (HbA1c) to compare the prevalence of pre-diabetes and undiagnosed diabetes mellitus in white, South Asian, black, and Chinese participants. The overall and ethnic-specific results were standardized to the UK general population.

Diet has long been the focus of attention as a leading risk factor for non-communicable diseases. A better understanding of it is crucial to establish priorities for dietary guidelines. The aim of the current study is to conduct the largest investigation of diet, sleep, and mental health to date.

Cumulative dietary risk factors were represented using a score ranging from 0 (healthiest) to 9 (least healthy) This was derived from 9 food items based on current UK guidelines. Follow-up was conducted until June 2020 for mortality, and for incidence, up to June 2020 in England.

Meaning in life is associated consistently with greater self-reported physical activity. Participants between the ages of 40 and 70 years old from the UK Biobank wore an accelerometer for up to seven days and reported on their meaning in life. Higher meaning was associated with greater engagement in physical activity, an association robust across age, gender, and education.

Sickle cell trait (SCT) carriers inherit one copy of the Glu6Val mutation in the hemoglobin gene. SCT carriers are particularly common in Black individuals (5-10%). Considering the roles of hemoglobin in immune responses and the higher risk for coronavirus disease (COVID-19) among Black individuals, we tested whether Black S CT carriers were at increased risk for infection and mortality.

There is increasing evidence that red and processed meat consumption is associated with increased risk of cardiovascular (CV) disease. Little literature reported the association among people with obesity versus those without obesity. We sought to investigate this using the UK Biobank data.

Physical activity, and the timing and balance of physical activity and sleep/rest, were associated with SARS-CoV-2 positivity and COVID-19 severity. Data from 91,248 UK Biobank participants with accelerometer data to July 19, 2020, were included.

We develop a scalable and highly efficient algorithm to fit a Cox proportional hazard model. We analyze a large genotype-survival time dataset across 306 disease outcomes from the UK Biobank. We provide a publicly available implementation of the proposed approach for genetics data.

Chondrocytes from osteophytic cartilage showed widespread differences to low-grade articular cartilage chondroytes. These differences were similar to, but more pronounced than, differences between chondrosomes from high-grade cartilage and osteophytes. We identified 56 genes with significant differences.

Males had higher raw volumes, raw surface areas, and white matter fractional anisotropy; females had higher cortical thickness and higher white matter tract complexity. Subregional differences were not fully attributable to differences in total volume, total surface area, mean cortical thickness, or height. Functional connectome organization showed stronger connectivity for males in unimodal sensorimotor cortices.

The causes of microscopic colitis are currently poorly understood. Previous reports have found associations with coeliac disease and genetic associations at the human leukocyte antigen [HLA] locus on the ancestral 8.1 haplotype.

Polygenic scores (PSs) are becoming a useful tool to identify individuals with high genetic risk for complex diseases. Several projects are currently testing their utility for translational applications. It is not well known how the population genetic properties of the training and target samples affect the geographic distribution of PSs.

UK Biobank includes detailed health-related data on about 500,000 individuals. Data files vary in format, may be very large, and have numerical codes for column names. ukbtools removes all the upfront data wrangling required to get a single dataset.

Few replicable genetic associations for Major Depressive Disorder (MDD) have been identified. Genome-wide meta-analysis of MDD in males yielded one genome-wide significant locus on 3p22.3.

200 632 subjects who have undergone exome sequencing by the UK Biobank were investigated to identify any variants predicted to cause HIRA haploinsufficiency. Four were found, three with frameshift variants and one with a stop variant. One of these subjects had depression but the others did not have any major neuropsychiatric phenotypes.

Colocalization is a statistical method used in genetics to determine whether the same variant is causal for multiple phenotypes. Current colocalization methods require full summary statistics for both traits. We propose a new approximation to the popular coloc method that can be applied when limited summary statistics are available.

Alpha1-antitrypsin deficiency (AATD) is the most prominent genetic predisposition to chronic obstructive pulmonary disease and emphysema. AAT plays important immunomodulatory and tissue-protective roles. It was suggested to protect from severe acute respiratory syndrome coronavirus 2 (SARS-CoV-2) infection.

Colorectal cancer (CRC) screening reduces CRC incidence and mortality. It is unclear whether the reduction in CRC risk may differ by genetic susceptibility. We evaluated this question in a cohort of 304,740 participants of European descent aged 50 years and older.

Cigarette smoking and obesity pose a particular impairment to health. Genetic factors have been shown to influence both traits. We examined the observed and genetic relationship between adiposity and cigarettes smoked per day in a large sample of current, former, and never smokers.

Higher grip strength is associated with better health outcomes. The optimal way to report grip strength (i.e. absolute vs. relative) for prediction, however, remains to be established.

We performed a systematic evaluation of the relationships between locomotor activity and signatures of frailty, morbidity, and mortality risks. We used physical activity records from the 2003-2006 National Health and Nutrition Examination Survey (NHANES) and UK BioBank (UKB) The Principal Component Analysis of the transformed data revealed a winding trajectory with distinct segments corresponding to subsequent human development stages.

Biobanks have facilitated the conduct of large-scale genomics studies. They are challenged by the difficulty of validating some phenotypes. The guideline definition of COPD, based on objective spirometry measures, has been preferred in genome-wide association studies.

Neanderthal DNA affects skin tone and hair color, height, sleeping patterns, mood, and smoking status in present-day Europeans. Multiple Neanderthal alleles at different loci contribute to skin and hair colour in current Europeans. This suggests that Neanderthals themselves were most likely variable in these traits.

Mendelian randomization and colocalization are two statistical approaches that can be applied to summarized data from genome-wide association studies. Despite similarities in scope, they are different in their objectives, implementation, and interpretation. In this review, we discuss how the two approaches can provide complementary information on potential therapeutic targets.

Identifying gene sets associated to disease can provide valuable biological knowledge. A fundamental challenge of gene set analyses of GWAS data is linking disease-associated SNPs to genes. We developed a method, gene co-regulation score (GCSC) regression, to identify gene sets that are enriched for disease heritability explained by predicted expression.

An important goal of clinical genomics is to estimate the risk of adverse disease outcomes. Between 5% and 10% of individuals with ulcerative colitis require colectomy within 5 years of diagnosis. By contrast, gene expression profiling of GWAS-significant genes provides some stratification of risk of progression to complicated disease.

Most methods for fast detection of identity by descent (IBD) segments report identity by state segments. We present a method for determining the posterior probability distribution of IBD segment endpoints. Our approach accounts for genotype errors, recent mutations, and gene conversions which disrupt DNA sequence identity within IBD segments.

Cancer-PRSweb is an online repository of polygenic risk scores (PRSs) for 35 common cancer traits. PRSs are compiled from genome-wide association studies (GWASs) summary statistics. We expect this integrated platform to accelerate PRS-related cancer research.

Recombination rates vary significantly across the genome. Estimates of recombination rates are needed for downstream analyses. Existing methods for recombination rate estimation are limited by insufficient amounts of informative genetic data or by high computational cost. We present a method and software, called IBDrecomb, for using segments of identity by descent to infer recombining rates.

In complex trait genetics, the ability to predict phenotype from genotype is the ultimate measure of our understanding of genetic architecture underlying the heritability of a trait. We propose a polygenic risk prediction method that does not require explicitly modeling any underlying genetic architecture. NPS improves the identification of groups at high risk for breast cancer, type 2 diabetes, inflammatory bowel disease, and coronary heart disease.

Bayesian model comparison approach called MRP (multiple rare variants and phenotypes) for rare-variant association studies. We apply our method to exome sequencing data (n = 184,698) across 2,019 traits from the UK Biobank. MRP demonstrates an ability to recover signals such as associations between PCSK9 and LDL cholesterol levels.

Study looked at a group of 168 348 participants aged between 40 and 69 years. The 4-year incidence of tinnitus was 8.7%. Age, hearing difficulties, work noise exposure, ototoxic medication and neuroticism were all positively associated with both tinn Titus and bothersome tinnitis.

Previous studies suggest that changes in body weight can lead to an increased risk of mortality in the general population. The current study sought to investigate this association further using data from the UK Biobank.

Frequency and quantity of alcohol consumption are metrics commonly used to measure alcohol consumption behaviors. Epidemiological studies indicate that these alcohol consumption measures are differentially associated with (mental) health outcomes and socioeconomic status (SES) The current study aims to elucidate to what extent genetic risk factors are shared between alcohol consumption and SES.

Genome-wide genotyping and machine learning algorithms offer the ability to genotype embryos for polygenic disease risk. Results indicate a 45-72% reduced risk with blinded genetic selection of one sibling. First clinical case of polygenic risk scoring in human preimplantation embryos from patients with a family history of complex disease.

Genetic variation in melanocortin-1 receptor (MC1R) has a known role in red hair. Studies on responses to noxious stimuli in red-haired individuals have also been conducted. To investigate a possible divergence between variants responsible for red hair and pain sensitivity, we performed a genewide association analysis.

The circumstances in which selection causes bias in an instrumental variable (IV) analysis are not widely understood by practitioners of IV analyses. We present an application from the UK Biobank study, which is known to be a selected sample of the general population. We show that selection can result in a biased IV estimate with substantial confidence interval (CI) undercoverage.

The UK Biobank is a rich national health resource that provides enormous opportunities for international researchers to examine, model, and analyze multisource healthcare data. Using 7,614 imaging, clinical, and phenotypic features of 9,914 subjects we performed deep computed phenotyping using unsupervised clustering.

Recent genome wide association studies (GWAS) suggest pleiotropic effects on human complex traits are widespread. A number of classic and recent meta-analysis methods have been used to identify genetic loci. The overall performance of these methods is not well understood. We use extensive simulations and case studies of GWAS datasets to investigate the power and type-I error rates of ten meta- analysis methods.

Genomic prediction has the potential to contribute to precision medicine. To date, the utility of such predictors is limited due to low accuracy for most traits. Theory and simulation study are used to demonstrate that widespread pleiotropy among phenotypes can be utilised to improve genomic risk prediction.

Polygenic risk scores (PRS) have shown promise in predicting human complex traits and diseases. We present PRS-CS, a polygenic prediction method that infers posterior effect sizes of single nucleotide polymorphisms (SNPs) using genome-wide association summary statistics and an external linkage disequilibrium (LD) reference panel. Simulation studies using data from the UK Biobank show that PRs-CS outperforms existing methods across a wide range of genetic architectures.

Osteoarthritis is a common complex disease imposing a large public-health burden. Here, we performed a genome-wide association study for osteoarth arthritis, using data across 16.5 million variants from the UK Biobank resource. After performing replication and meta-analysis in up to 30,727 cases and 297,191 controls, we identified nine new osteaarthritis loci.

UK Biobank is a prospective cohort study in which baseline data were captured between 2006 and 2010 in 502,649 participants aged 37 to 73 years. Follow-up for ALS hospitalisations and death was made via national registries.

Genome-wide association study (GWAS) analyses based on 456,327 UK Biobank (UKB) individuals identify 8 independent and significant loci for PUD at, or near, genes MUC1, MUC6, FUT2, PSCA, ABO, CDX2, GAST and CCKBR.

X-linked causes have been hypothesised to underlie the higher developmental disorder rates in males. We evaluate the burden of X-linked coding variation in 11,044 developmental disorder patients. We identify 23 significant genes, all of which were previously known. We estimate that only 13% of inherited rare missense variants in known developmental disorder-associated genes are likely to be pathogenic.

Many human proteins contain domains that vary in size or copy number because of variable numbers of tandem repeats (VNTRs) in protein-coding exons. The relationships of VN TRs to most phenotypes are unknown because of difficulties in measuring such repetitive elements. We developed methods to estimate VNTR lengths from whole-exome sequencing data and impute VnTR alleles into single-nucleotide polymorphism haplotypes.

People aged 40-69 years from the UK Biobank cohort and Korean National Health Insurance Service cohort were included in this observational cohort study. The study groups were stratified into normotension, controlled hypertension and uncontrolled hypertension groups. The outcomes were MACCEs and all-cause mortality, analysed by Cox regression analysis.

Mendelian randomization has been used to estimate the causal effect of body mass index (BMI) on traits thought to be affected by BMI. BMI may also be a modifiable, causal risk factor for outcomes where there is no prior reason to suggest that a causal effect exists. We performed a MR phenome-wide association study (MR-pheWAS) to search for the causal effects of BMI in UK Biobank.

Osteoporosis is an age-associated disease characterised by low bone mineral density (BMD) and micro-architectural deterioration leading to enhanced fracture risk. Conventional dual-energy X-ray absorptiometry (DXA) analysis has facilitated our understanding of BMD reduction in specific regions of interest (ROIs) within the femur. A new technique, termed DXA region free analysis, is proposed to eliminate morphological variation between DXA scans.

UK Biobank recruited adults across England, Scotland and Wales, between March 2006 and July 2010. Fluid intelligence was measured as the number of correct answers during a two minute logic/reasoning-test. Reaction time was measured in average time taken to respond to matching symbols on a computer screen. Cardiorespiratory fitness was measured through a sub-maximal exercise test.

An online mental health questionnaire completed by UK Biobank participants was expected to expand the potential for research into mental disorders. Thirty-five per cent of participants had at least one defined syndrome, of which lifetime depression was the most common.

Walking pace is associated with all-cause and cardiovascular disease (CVD) mortality. Whether this association extends to other health outcomes and whether it is independent of total amount of time walked are currently unknown. UK Biobank participants (318,185 women) age 40 to 69 yr were included.

Handgrip strength may provide an easily-administered marker of cognitive functional status. relationships between grip strength and cognitive functioning in people with schizophrenia have yet to be explored. Baseline data from the UK Biobank (2007-2010) was analyzed.

Hair color is one of the most recognizable visual traits in European populations and is under strong genetic control. We identified 123 autosomal and one X-chromosome loci significantly associated with hair color; all but 13 are novel. These results confirm the polygenic nature of complex phenotypes and improve our understanding of melanin pigment metabolism in humans.

There is considerable interest in estimating the causal effect of a range of maternal environmental exposures on offspring health-related outcomes. Previous attempts to do this using Mendelian randomization methodologies have been hampered by the paucity of epidemiological cohorts with large numbers of mother-offspring pairs.

Identifying causal effects in nonexperimental data is an enduring challenge. Mendelian randomization (MR) is problematic because many variables of interest are genetically correlated. Here, we propose an alternative approach, genetic instrumental variable (GIV) regression. GIV regression uses polygenic scores (PGSs) for the outcome of interest.

The risk of mortality from cardiovascular disease (CVD) is higher in wintertime. It is not known if this reflects annual changes in diet or lifestyle, or an endogenous photoperiodic mechanism that is sensitive to changes in day length. In this cross-sectional study, we report annual variations in cardiovascular risk factors and mortality that were associated with day length independent of environmental and lifestyle factors.

Diffusion MRI data can be affected by hardware and subject-related artefacts that can adversely affect downstream analyses. Automated quality control (QC) is of great importance, especially in large population studies where visual QC is not practical. We introduce an automated diffusion MRI QC framework for single subject and group studies.

Loneliness may be more important as a risk factor for self-harm than for suicide. Loneliness also appears to lessen the protective associations of cohabitation.

Polygenic risk scores (PRS) provide a personalized genetic susceptibility profile that may be leveraged for disease prediction. Using data from the UK Biobank, we quantify the added predictive value of integrating cancer-specific PRS with family history and modifiable risk factors for 16 cancers. We show that incorporating PRS measurably improves prediction accuracy for most cancers.

"Brain age" is the apparent age of a subject, as inferred from brain imaging data. The difference between brain age and actual age (the "delta") is typically computed. This may reflect accelerated aging (positive delta) or resilience (negative delta)

Rare variants in ten genes have been reported to cause Mendelian sleep conditions characterised by extreme sleep duration or timing. The association of variants in these genes with extreme sleep conditions were usually based on clinically ascertained families. We aimed to determine the effects of these variants on sleep traits in large population-based cohorts. Analyses were performed using 191,929 individuals with data on sleep and whole-exome or genome-sequence data.

Grip strength is a widely used and well-validated measure of overall health that is increasingly understood to index risk for psychiatric illness and neurodegeneration in older adults. This study investigated the behavioral and neural correlates of handgrip strength using a linear mixed effect model and mediation analysis. The results revealed widespread associations between stronger grip strength and increased grey matter volume.

CeVD is the second leading cause of disability worldwide. Understanding who may be genetically predisposed to cerebrovascular disease can help guide preventative efforts. The UK Biobank based ICD10 study identified 2 groups of variants that were associated with CeVD.

Human iron nutrition is a result of interplays between genetic and environmental factors. There has been scarcity of data on the genetic variants associated with altered iron homeostasis. In this study, we compared between the Taiwanese Han Chinese (HC) and European Whites the genetic determinants of hemoglobin (Hb) concentration.

Study looked at the association between microvascular disease (MVD) and risk of heart failure (HF) among individuals with type 1 diabetes mellitus (T1DM) or type 2 diabetes mellitis (T2DM) There were 145 and 2,515 incident cases of HF among participants with T1DM and T2DM, respectively, during a median follow-up of 11.5 years.

Transcriptome-wide association studies (TWASs) have shown great promise in interpreting the findings. Almost all TWAS methods only focus on one gene at a time. We developed a Network Regression method in a two-stage TWAS framework (NeRiT) to detect whether a given network is associated with traits of interest.

Identifying genetic variants associated with lower waist-to-hip ratio can reveal new therapeutic targets for abdominal obesity. In vitro characterization of the most common INHBE pLOF variant in our study, indicates an in-frame deletion resulting in a 90% reduction in secreted protein levels. We detect associations with lower WHRadjBMI for variants in ACVR1C.

Clinical and epidemiological studies have shown that circulatory system diseases and nervous system disorders often co-occur in patients. Genetic susceptibility factors shared between these disease categories remain largely unknown. Using a formal test of pleiotropy, five genomic loci demonstrated statistically significant evidence of Pleiotropy.

Indication extension or repositioning of drugs can, if done well, provide a faster, cheaper, and derisked route to the approval of new therapies. This is exemplified by a systematic analysis of all development candidates and on-market drugs, which identified 477 indication extension opportunities.

Dietary fat enhances intestinal fructose metabolism, which releases glycerate into the blood. Chronic high systemic Glycerate levels induce glucose intolerance by slowly damaging pancreatic islet cells and reducing islet sizes.

Polygenic risk scores (PRSs) are indices of genetic liability for illness. Their clinical utility for predicting risk for a specific psychiatric disorder is limited. Genetic overlap among disorders and their effects on allied phenotypes may be a possible explanation. We constructed PRSs for 5 psychiatric disorders and 3 nonpsychiatric control traits.

Study investigated whether active, former and passive smoking were associated with sleep disturbance. Long-sleep duration was more common among current smokers. Existing global tobacco control interventions need to be enforced.

Those taking opiates and CM drugs had the worst CM health profile with a 95%, 82% and 63% increased odds of reporting obesity, 'very high risk' waist circumference and hypertension, respectively.

In the current precision medicine era, more and more samples get genotyped and sequenced. It has been reported that there is a sample mix-up rate of between 0.1% and 1%. This translates to a significant number of mislabeled samples.

Only seven methods could effectively control the type I error, and these well-calibrated approaches had varying power performance under the simulation scenarios. The burden test was generally underpowered and score-based variance component tests (e.g., sequence kernel association test) were much powerful under the polygenic genetic architecture.

Previous studies have often evaluated methods for Mendelian randomization (MR) analysis based on simulations that do not adequately reflect the data-generating mechanisms. We use a simulation framework that generates data on full GWAS for two traits under a realistic model for effect-size distribution. We further use recent data generated from GWAS of 38 biomarkers in the UK Biobank and performed down sampling to investigate trends in estimates of causal effects of these biomarkers on the risk of type 2 diabetes (T2D)

The development of accurate risk prediction models is hindered by the wide diversity of genetic architecture across different traits. We develop a summary statistics-based nonparametric method that does not rely on validation datasets to tune parameters. We show that our method is adaptive to different genetic architectures and statistically robust.

Analyzing 12,361 all-cause cirrhosis cases and 790,095 controls from eight cohorts, we identify a common missense variant in the Mitochondrial Amidoxime Reducing Component 1 gene (MARC1 p.A165T) This variant also associates with lower levels of hepatic fat on computed tomographic imaging.

Hearing loss is associated with poor cognitive performance and incident dementia. Treating hearing loss with hearing aids may ameliorate cognitive decline. The purpose of this study was to test whether use of hearing aids was associated with better cognitive performance.

Clinical studies indicate increased risk for depression and anxiety among tinnitus patients. However population data are scarce, and no studies have controlled for neuroticism. We examined associations between tinn Titus and symptoms of depression and Anxiety in a large UK population.

It is unclear what the contribution of prenatal versus childhood development is for adult cognitive and sensory function and age-related decline in function. We examined hearing, vision and cognitive function in adulthood according to self-reported birth weight and adult height. Within the normal range of birth weight (10th to 90th percentile), there was a positive association between birth weight.

Study aimed to explore how healthy lifestyles and genetic factors influence the risk of Osteoporosis (OP) Results:  People with higher GRS have a lower risk of OP and fracture.

We performed logistic regression for ICU admission against a polygenic score (PGS) for Cystatin C (CyC) production in patients with COVID-19. In four cohorts spanning European and African ancestry populations, we identified a significant association between CyC-production PGS and odds of critical illness. Our findings suggest that CyC may be useful for stratification of patients.

Genome-wide association studies (GWAS) have successfully identified common variants associated with BMI. However, the stability of aggregate genetic variation influencing BMI from midlife and beyond is unknown. We analysed 165,717 men and 193,073 women from the UKBiobank.

Mendelian randomization (MR) and polygenic risk score (PRS) studies can induce overfitting bias. We evaluated a block jackknife resampling framework for genome-wide association studies (GWAS) and PRS construction. Based on a P-value threshold to derive genetic instruments for MR studies (P), we simulated PRS and MR under three scenarios.

There is a need for improved risk stratification to guide surgical decision-making that could be fulfilled by PRS. We derived a PRS with 44 single-nucleotide polymorphisms associated with diverticular disease in the UK Biobank and validated this score in the Michigan Genomics Initiative. Patients in the highest PRS decile were more likely to have diverticulitis.

We show that existing sensitivity analyses can be formulated in our framework. We demonstrate that our method can produce informative bounds using plausible population-level auxiliary constraints. We conclude with a motivating example on the causal effect of education on income in the highly selected UK Biobank cohort.

We determined the whole-genome sequences of 150,119 individuals from the UK Biobank. We identified more than 600 million sequence variants. The comprehensive data identify novel associations with human traits.

Genetic and phenotypic analyses of data from over 400,000 participants in the UK Biobank identified 10 new loci associated with the development of clonal hematopoiesis. DNA damage, oncogene signaling, telomere maintenance and blood cell homing in its pathogenesis.

There is substantial overlap in recruitment across the two cohorts. The women in both studies were more likely to be married, have higher levels of education attainment and more financial stability. It is possible these characteristics are reflected more generally within UKBB compared to the wider population.

Natural selection has been documented in contemporary humans, but little is known about the mechanisms behind it. We test for natural selection through the association between 33 polygenic scores and fertility, across two generations, using data from UK Biobank. The direction of natural selection is reversed among older parents.

Single nucleotide polymorphisms (SNPs) associated with BP were identified in a genome-wide association study. SNPs were used to assess the BP versus IOP relationship in a distinct sample (n = 70,832) Corneal-compensated IOP (IOPcc) was measured.

Family history of complex traits may reflect transmitted rare pathogenic variants, intra-familial shared exposures to environmental and lifestyle factors, as well as a common genetic predisposition. We developed a latent factor model to quantify trait heritability in excess of that captured by a common variant-based polygenic risk score.

Population-scale neuroimaging studies offer the promise of discovery and characterisation of subtle risk factors. Massive sample sizes increase the power for meaningful associations and those attributable to confounds. This motivates the need for causal modelling of observational data that goes beyond statements of association.

Human cardiac function is characterized by a complex interplay of mechanical deformation and electrophysiological conduction. We propose a novel multi-domain Variational Autoencoder (VAE) network to capture combined Electrocardiogram (ECG) and Magnetic Resonance Imaging (MRI)-based 3D anatomy information in a single model.

A U-shape relationship was observed between BMI and fracture, with the lowest risk of fracture in overweight participants. The obesity individuals had higher fracture risk when BMD was adjusted. The protective effect of moderate-high BMI on fracture was mostly mediated by bone mineral density.

SARS-CoV-2 has resulted in a global pandemic with a rapidly developing global health and economic crisis. Variations in the disease have been observed and have been associated with the genomic sequence of either the human host or the pathogen.

Taller adult height is associated with lower risks of ischemic heart disease in mendelian randomization (MR) studies. Little is known about the causal relevance of height for different sub types of stroke. Height-associated genetic variants were used to construct genetic instruments in different ancestral populations.

Study looked at effects of sleep traits on glycated hemoglobin (HbA1c) Found a higher frequency of insomnia symptoms was associated with higher Hb a1c. Findings could have important implications for developing and evaluating strategies that improve sleep habits.

Despite decades of methods development for classifying relatives, pairwise relatedness methods' recalls are above 90% only for first through third-degree relatives. Top-performing approaches, which leverage identity-by-descent segments, often use only kinship coefficients. To quantify the potential for using segment numbers in relatedness inference, we leveraged information theory.

Genome-wide sequencing of human populations has revealed substantial variation among genes in the intensity of purifying selection acting on damaging genetic variants. Most genes under the strongest selective constraint are highly enriched for associations with Mendelian disorders. We show that genetic variants that damage these genes are associated with markedly reduced reproductive success.

Large-scale molecular profiling and genotyping provide a unique opportunity to compare the genetically predicted effects of therapeutic targets on the human metabolome. Genetically predicted effects were generally consistent among drug targets, which were intended to modify the same lipoprotein lipid trait.

In women, higher BioT was associated with obesity, upper-body fat distribution, and low HDL-cholesterol. Conversely, obesity and android fat distribution were associated with elevated serum BioT in men. Adipose tissue and metabolic dysfunction are associated with deranged sex hormone levels in both sexes.

Disease-disease networks (DDNs) can provide an intuitive way of understanding the relationships between phenotypes. Using summary statistics from a phenome-wide association study (PheWAS), we can generate a corresponding DDN where edges represent shared genetic variants between diseases.

We used genetically informed brain atlases in genome-wide association studies of regional cortical surface area and thickness in 39,898 adults and 9136 children. Inferior frontal regions, encompassing Broca's area, which is important for speech, were enriched for human-specific genomic elements.

Low frequency mutations within the filaggrin ( FLG ) gene are established genetic risk factors for atopic dermatitis. Studies of FLG have typically used sequencing or bespoke genotyping. Large-scale population cohorts with genome-wide imputed data offer powerful genetic analysis opportunities.

Time-varying correlations (Functional Connectivity) in resting fMRI have been shown to be predictive of behavioural traits, and psychiatric and neurological conditions. Typically, methods that measure time varying Functional Connectivity (FC) do not separately model when changes occur in the mean activity levels and in the FC. We show that this can bias the estimation of time-varies FC to appear more stable over time than it actually is.

A total of 95,854 participants with complete data on plasma FA from the UK Biobank were enrolled between 2006 and 2010. Plasma concentrations of SFA and MUFA were positively associated with T2D risk, while plasma PUFA were inversely associated. Circulating MUFA and n-3 PUFA had significant interactions with genetic predisposition to T2d and FA-associated variants.

The OAS1/2/3 cluster has been identified as a risk locus for severe COVID-19 among individuals of European ancestry. It has a protective haplotype of approximately 75 kilobases (kb) derived from Neanderthals in the chromosomal region 12q24.13. This haplotype contains a splice variant of OAS 1, which occurs in people of African ancestry independently of gene flow from Neanderthal.

Alterations in the anatomic and biomechanical properties of the ascending aorta (AAo) can give rise to various vascular pathologies. The aim of the current study is to gain additional insights in the biology of the AAo size and function.

Genome-wide association studies (GWAS) of coffee drinking have identified genetic variants involved in caffeine-related pathways but not in taste perception. The taste of coffee can be altered by addition of milk/sweetener, which has not been accounted for in GWAS.

Sex hormone binding globulin (SHBG) which lowers circulating testosterone might protect men against IHD. SHBG may also affect IHD independent of testosterone, which has not previously been examined. Exploring intervention strategies that increase SHBG is important for targeting IHD treatments.

Higher resting heart rate (RHR) may be associated with increased cardiometabolic risk. However, causal associations are not fully understood. We examined the direction, strength, and causality of the associations of RHR with cardiometric traits. We identified significant directionally concordant observational associations between RHR and higher total cholesterol, triglycerides, low-density lipoprotein, C-reactive protein (CRP), glucose, body mass index, waist-hip ratio (WHR), systolic blood pressure (SBP), and diastolicBlood pressure (DBP)

Higher number of pain sites was associated with increased risk of all-cause mortality compared to having no pain. At least half of the association of chronic musculoskeletal pain with increased all- Cause mortality may be accounted for by four mediators. All four mediator proportions ranged from 53.4% to 122.6%.

Problematic alcohol use (PAU) is positively genetically correlated with internalizing psychopathology. Alcohol consumption ranges from not significantly correlated to moderately negatively correlated. Brain tissues contribute significantly to positive genetic covariance between PAU and PAU, but not to the genetic correlation between internalizing. psychopathology and quantity of alcohol consumption.

Schizophrenia is a heritable neurodevelopmental disorder characterized by neuroanatomical changes in the brain. How increased genetic burden for schizophrenia influences brain structure is unknown. How environmental risk factors for schizophrenia impact brain Structure is not fully understood.

Cardiovascular diseases (CVDs) are among the leading causes of death worldwide. Predictive scores providing personalized risk of developing CVD are increasingly used in clinical practice. Most scores utilize a homogenous set of features and require the presence of a physician. Aim was to develop a new risk model (DiCAVA) using statistical and machine learning techniques.

Modern molecular genetic datasets can be used to directly measure the action of natural selection. Here we leverage the UK Biobank data to test for the presence of linear and nonlinear natural selection in a contemporary population of the United Kingdom.
