Osteoarthritis causes pain and functional disability for over 500 million people worldwide. To develop disease-stratifying tools and modifying therapies, we need a better understanding of the molecular basis of the disease in relevant tissue and cell types.

Three loss-of-function single-nucleotide variants have been established as strongly correlated with red hair. We report a correlation with red. hair for both strong-effect variants (rs1805007, rs1805008 and rs18 1905009) and weak-effect. variants. Our best model for predicting red versus other hair colours yields an unparalleled area under the receiver operating characteristic of 0.96.

Polygenic risk scores (PRS) can provide useful information for personalized risk stratification and disease risk assessment. However, their construction depends on the availability of summary statistics from genome-wide association studies (GWAS) independent from the target sample. GWAS, especially in the field of cancer, often lack diversity and are predominated by European ancestry.

Estimated glomerular filtration rate (eGFR), albuminuria and serum uric acid (SUA) are markers of kidney function that have been associated with cognitive ability. However, whether these associations are causal is unclear. We performed one-sample Mendelian randomization to estimate the effects of these kidney function markers on cognitive performance.

 Variation in obesity-related traits has a genetic basis with heritabilities between 40 and 70%. The global obesity pandemic is usually associated with environmental changes. Most genetic studies do not include all relevant environmental covariates.

Most age-related human diseases are accompanied by a decline in cellular organelle integrity. Here, we evaluate if genetic loci encoding organelle proteomes confer greater-than-expected disease risk. We find that genes encoding several organelles tend to be 'haplosufficient'

 increasing evidence has shown adverse effects of loneliness on cardiometabolic health. Oxytocin has been linked with social cognition and behaviour, but also with energy metabolism and obesity. We calculated the genetic contribution of single nucleotide polymorphisms in the oxytocin pathway to the polygenic architecture of loneliness and body mass index.

Stochastic Probabilistic Functional Modes (sPROFUMO) is scalable to UK Biobank (UKB) with expected 100,000 participants. It hierarchically estimates functional brain networks in individuals and the population, while allowing for bidirectional flow of information.

SARS-CoV-2 has resulted in a global pandemic with a rapidly developing global health and economic crisis. Variations in the disease have been observed and have been associated with the genomic sequence of either the human host or the pathogen.

Eosinophilic asthma is one of the most common subtypes of asthma diagnosed in adulthood. This study suggests a negative association between individual-level exposures to greenness and eosinophile asthma in adults. It provides new evidence to the existing investigations on health effect of green space https://bit.ly/3fVKWS3

Segmentation of the left and right ventricles in cardiac MRI (Magnetic Resonance Imaging) is a prerequisite step for evaluating global and regional cardiac function. This work presents a novel and robust schema for MRI segmentation by combining the advantages of deep learning localization and 3D-ASM (3D Active Shape Model) restriction.

Nonalcoholic fatty liver disease (NAFLD) is prevalent worldwide. UK Biobank study participants were diagnosed for whether NAFLD presented at baseline. Compared with participants who were non-obese and had low genetic risk, those with obesity and high genetic risk had an 75% increased risk for developing SLDs, T2D, CVDs, and CKDs.

Men with more advantaged socioeconomic position (SEP) have higher levels of testosterone. It is unclear whether these associations arise because testosterone has a causal impact on SEP. In 306,248 participants of UK Biobank, we performed sex-stratified genome-wide association analysis to identify genetic variants associated with testosterone.

The coronavirus disease 2019 (COVID-19) has become a global pandemic. Here, we performed a study on host susceptibility to the infection. The data consisted of 27,713 samples including 2740 positive cases.

The characterization of germline genetic variation affecting cancer risk is fundamental to preventive and personalized medicine. Studies of genetic cancer predisposition typically identify significant genomic regions based on family-based cohorts or genome-wide association studies (GWAS) However, results of such studies rarely provide biological insight or functional interpretation.

Brain regions communicate with each other through tracts of myelinated axons, commonly referred to as white matter. We identified common genetic variants influencing white matter microstructure using diffusion magnetic resonance imaging of 43,802 individuals.

Few tools exist for the visualization of colocalization between eQTL and GWAS results. eQTpLot takes as input standard GWAS and cis-eQTL summary statistics, and optional pairwise LD information. It generates a series of plots visualizing colocalized, correlation, and enrichment.

Study included 284,767 white British participants of UK Biobank. Incidence of overall, ischemic, and hemorrhagic stroke was adjudicated during 11.5-year follow-up. Stroke hazards for the top muscle strength tertile were consistently lower across genetic risk strata, with no evidence of interaction.

Coffee consumption has been linked to a lower risk of cardiovascular disease in observational studies. We conducted a Mendelian randomization investigation to assess the potential causal role of coffee consumption in cardiovascular disease. Genetic predisposition to higher coffee consumption was not associated with any of the 15 studied cardiovascular outcomes.

Genotypes, cell type, and treatment have not been comprehensively studied together. Cellular responses involved different genes and pathways for gene expression and splicing. For thousands of genes, we identified variable allelic expression across contexts.

Loneliness, social isolation then cigarette smoking were associated with an increased risk of mortality from all-causes and all cancers combined. When cardiovascular disease mortality was the endpoint, both smoking and social isolation, though not loneliness, revealed similar relationships.

Brain-age delta has become a meaningful biomarker for the health of the brain. We report the details of our brain age prediction models and results in the Predictive Analysis Challenge 2019.

Genome-wide association studies (GWASs) often adjust for covariates, correct for medication use, or select on medication users. If these statistics are used in two-sample Mendelian randomization analyses, estimates may be biased. We used simulations to investigate how GWAS adjustment, correction and selection affects estimates.

Germline predisposition variants associated with colorectal cancer (CRC) have been identified but all are not yet identified. We sought to identify the responsible predisposition germline variant in an extended high-risk CRC pedigree. DNA from two distantly related carriers of the hypothesized predisposition haplotype on 18q12.2 was sequenced to identify candidate variants.

Most research on large multimodal databases has been focusing on studying the associations among the available measurements. We propose an approach in which the parameter personalisation of a lumped cardiovascular model is constrained by the statistical relationships observed between model parameters and brain-volumetric indices.

High-resolution (HR), isotropic cardiac Magnetic Resonance (MR) cine imaging is challenging since it requires long acquisition and patient breath-hold times. We propose a novel adversarial learning super-resolution algorithm based on conditional generative adversarial nets (GANs) that incorporates a state-of-the-art optical flow component to generate an auxiliary image.

CNNs achieve high levels of performance by leveraging deep, over-parametrized neural architectures. To improve robustness and obtain more computationally and memory efficient models, better inductive biases are needed. We propose tensor dropout, a randomization technique that can be applied to tensor factorizations.

The severity of coronavirus disease 2019 (COVID-19) caused by SARS-CoV-2 is highly heterogeneous. Studies have reported that males and some ethnic groups are at increased risk of death from COVID- 19. This implies that individual risk might be influenced by host genetic factors. We perform a genome-wide association study (GWAS) of data for 1778 infected cases.

The ever-growing genome-wide association studies (GWAS) have revealed widespread pleiotropy. To exploit this, various methods that jointly consider associations of a genetic variant with multiple traits have been developed. We provide a protocol for replicating multi-trait genetic associations in practice.

Diffusion tensor imaging (DTI) consistently detects increased mean diffusivity and decreased fractional anisotropy with advancing age. However, findings have been inconsistent in regions of more complex fiber architecture. The present study uses an orthogonal diffusion tensor decomposition based on the 3 eigenvalue moments to yield clear voxelwise degeneration patterns.

We found decreased colorectal cancer risk for genetically represented measures of MVPA and AMPA that were additional to effects mediated through genetic measures of obesity. The proportion of effect mediated through BMI was 2% (95% CI: 0, 14) and 32% ( 95%CI: 12, 46) for MVPA & AMPA, respectively. No association has been found between sedentary time and colorctalcancer risk.

 Hypercholesterolemia is a causal and modifiable risk factor for atherosclerotic cardiovascular disease. A critical pathway regulating cholesterol homeostasis involves the receptor-mediated endocytosis of low-density lipoproteins into hepatocytes. We applied genome-scale CRISPR screening to query the genetic determinants of cellular LDL uptake.

Nonlinear data visualization methods often neglect the local density of data points in the original space. den-SNE and densMAP are density-preserving visualization tools. They are readily applicable to visualizing high-dimensional data in other scientific domains.

Alzheimer's disease is the leading cause of dementia. The long progression period in Alzheimer's disease provides a possibility for patients to get early treatment by having routine screenings. Current diagnostic imaging tools do not meet the specific requirements for screening procedures.

Large MRI neuroimaging datasets are becoming available, including many highly multi-site multi-scanner datasets. Combining the data from the different scanners is vital for increased statistical power. This leads to an increase in variance due to nonbiological factors such as the differences in acquisition protocols and hardware. We propose a deep learning based training scheme, inspired by domain adaptation techniques, which uses an iterative update approach.

Female sex, age and carriage of the apolipoprotein E e4 allele are the greatest risk factors for sporadic Alzheimer's disease. The hippocampus has a selective vulnerability to atrophy in ageing that may be accelerated in Alzheimer's.

Paired-End short Reads-based HAPlotyping from next-generation Sequencing data. Concordance rates between WES directly called diplotypes and the ones generated through statistical pre-phasing and imputation of SNP-array data are extremely high. We were able to determine the existence of the rare APOE*1 haplotype in two unrelated African subjects.

Physical activity (PA) is known to be a protective lifestyle factor against several non-communicable diseases. However, its impact on infectious diseases, including Coronavirus Disease 2019 (COVID-19), is not as clear. We found that increased acceleration vector magnitude PA (AMPA) was associated with a decreased probability of overall and outpatient CO VID-19.

For decades, it has been known that gliomas follow a non-random spatial distribution. We combined neuroimaging data from 335 adult patients with high- and low-grade glioma to form a replicable tumour frequency map. Gliomas were localized to brain regions enriched with expression of genes associated with chromatin organization and synaptic signalling.

Several risk factors are associated with multiple sclerosis (MS) in adulthood. Evidence for risk factors acting from birth to adolescence is scarce. We used a 2-step study design to examine the association of early-life factors with risk of MS. An increase per 1 year in age at menarche was associated with a lower risk ofMS.

Toxoplasma gondii has been associated with cognitive function. Here, we sought to further characterize the association. Neither age nor educational attainment moderated associations. Sex, however, moderated the association between the sag1 titer and digit-symbol substitution.

Many aspects of sleep are heritable, but understandings of genetic factors involved in its physiology remain limited. We found two novel genome-wide loci on chromosomes 2 and 7 associated with global sleep quality. While NPY is an important sleep gene, we tested for an independent functional role of MPP6.

Heritability analysis plays a central role in quantitative genetics to describe genetic contribution to human complex traits. Existing works largely focus on modeling single phenotype and currently available multivariate phenotypic methods often suffer from scaling and interpretation. We develop an integrative Bayesian heritability analysis to jointly estimate heritabilities for high-dimensional neuroimaging traits.

Deep learning has unlocked unprecedented success in various domains. However, deep learning is only beneficial if the data have nonlinear relationships and if they are exploitable at available sample sizes. We systematically profiled the performance of deep, kernel, and linear models as a function of sample size on UKBiobank brain images.

The prevalence of myopia, or nearsightedness, has skyrocketed in the past few decades. In the UK alone, natural selection adds more than 100 000 myopia cases per generation.

Homozygous loss-of-function mutations in SLC39A8 result in undetectable serum manganese (Mn) and a Congenital Disorder of Glycosylation (CDG) N-glycome profiling revealed reduced complexity and branching.

Sketching is a probabilistic data compression technique that has been largely developed by the computer science community. Numerical operations on big datasets can be intolerably slow. We argue that the sketched data can be modelled as a random sample.

Machine Learning (ML) methods are widely used in the areas of risk prediction and classification. The primary objective of such algorithms is to use several features to predict dichotomous responses (e.g., healthy/at risk) ML modelling is subject to the problem of class imbalance and is affected by the majority class.

Evidence from observational studies suggest a positive association between serum thyroid-stimulating hormone (TSH) levels and differentiated thyroid carcinoma. This study aimed to investigate the causal role of TSH in both benign thyroid nodules and thyroid cancer in up to 451,025 UK Biobank participants. Mendelian randomization provided evidence of a causal link.

Preimplantation genetic testing for polygenic disease risk (PGT-P) represents a new tool to aid in embryo selection. When applied to select adult siblings with known type I diabetes status, a reduction in disease incidence of 45-72% was achieved.

 Linear mixed effects models (LMM) can account for correlations due to relatedness but have not been applicable in high-dimensional settings. We develop a blockwise coordinate descent algorithm with automatic tuning parameter selection. We show that ggmix leads to more parsimonious models compared to the two-stage approach.

Air pollution has been associated with cognitive function and brain volume. This study evaluated the association between PM2.5, PM10, nitrogen dioxide, and nitrogen oxides and volume of the thalamus in adults using the UK Biobank resource. In adjusted models, the left but not right thalamic volume was significantly inversely associated with PM 2.5-10.

Identifying the causal gene(s) that connects genetic variation to a phenotype is a challenging problem in genome-wide association studies (GWASs) Here, we develop a systematic approach that integrates mouse liver co-expression networks with human lipid GWAS data to identify regulators of cholesterol and lipid metabolism.

Genome-wide association studies have associated thousands of genetic variants with complex traits and diseases. pinpointing the causal variant(s) among those in tight linkage disequilibrium with each associated variant remains a major challenge. We use seven experimental assays to characterize all common variants at the multiple disease-associated TNFAIP3 locus in five disease-relevant immune cell lines.

The phecode system was built upon the International Classification of Diseases, Ninth Revision, Clinical Modification (ICD-9-CM) The goal of this paper was to develop and perform an initial evaluation of maps from ICD-10 and I CD-10-CM. Of the unique codes observed in the UKBB and VUMC cohorts, >90% were mapped to phecodes.

Chronic pain is a complex trait that is moderately heritable and genetically, as well as phenotypically, correlated with major depressive disorder (MDD) Use of the conditional false discovery rate (cFDR) approach has been successful in discovering novel associated variants in related phenotypes. Using a moderately conservative threshold, we identified a total of 11 novel single nucleotide polymorphisms (SNPs)

Ancient DNA has identified changes in genetic ancestry over time, but it is not clear whether those changes in ancestry are associated with changes in height. We directly test whether changes over the past 38,000 y in European height predicted using DNA from 1,071 ancient individuals are consistent with changes observed in 1,159 skeletal remains. We show that the observed decrease in height between the Early Upper Paleolithic and the Mesolithic is qualitatively predicted by genetics.

Linear mixed-effects models (LMM) are a leading method in conducting genome-wide association studies (GWAS) They require residual maximum likelihood (REML) estimation of variance components, which is computationally demanding. We introduce two novel algorithms that exploit problem structure via the principle of Krylov subspace shift-invariance to speed computation.

Brain imaging data are increasingly made publicly accessible. volumetric imaging measures derived from population-based cohorts may serve as normative data for individual patient diagnostic assessment. Yet, these normative cohorts are usually not a perfect reflection of a patient's base population.

Growth factor-independent 1B (GFI1B) variants are a rare cause of thrombocytopenia. This case highlights how diagnoses of exclusion can be confounded by genetic variation.

Chronic pain is highly prevalent worldwide and represents a significant socioeconomic and public health burden. We carried out a large-scale genome-wide association study (GWAS) of MCP in ~380,000 UK Biobank participants. Our findings were consistent with MCP having a significant polygenic component, with a Single Nucleotide Polymorphism (SNP) heritability of 10.2%.

Study aimed to develop novel prediction algorithms using machine-learning, in addition to standard survival modelling. 502,628 participants aged 40-69 years were recruited to the UK Biobank from 2006-2010.

This article presents the results of 2 studies that investigated mood instability in the Eysenck neuroticism scales. The mood instability factor was positively correlated with impulsivity. The remaining factors, largely reflecting trait anxiety, were also positively correlated. Taken together, the results suggest that mood instability and trait anxiety are separable components of Eysanckian neuroticism.

18 candidate genes for depression that have been studied 10 or more times were identified. No clear evidence was found for any candidate gene polymorphism associations with depression phenotypes or any polymorphism-by-environment moderator effects. The authors demonstrate that phenotypic measurement error is unlikely to account for these null findings.

Circulating levels of glycine have previously been associated with lower incidence of coronary heart disease (CHD) and type 2 diabetes (T2D) It remains uncertain if glycine plays an aetiological role. We present a meta-analysis of genome-wide association studies for glycine in 80,003 participants.

Schizophrenia is a highly heritable disorder for which anatomical brain alterations have been repeatedly reported in clinical samples. Unaffected at-risk groups have also been studied to identify brain changes that do not reflect reverse causation or treatment effects. No robust associations have been observed between neuroanatomical phenotypes and known genetic risk factors for schizophrenia.

Individual response to stress is correlated with neuroticism. It is an important predictor of both neuroticism and the onset of major depressive disorder (MDD) Identification of the genetics underpinning individual differences in response to negative events (stress-sensitivity) may improve our understanding of the molecular pathways involved.

Adult height inspired the first biometrical and quantitative genetic studies. It is a test-case trait for understanding heritability. The studies of height led to formulation of the classical polygenic model.

Deep convolutional neural networks (CNNs) have demonstrated remarkable success in image segmentation but typically require large training datasets. We developed a way to enhance cardiac MRI multi-class segmentation by combining the strengths of CNN and interpretable machine learning algorithms.

Large biobanks linking phenotype to genotype have led to an explosion of genetic association studies across a wide range of phenotypes. Sharing the knowledge generated by these resources with the scientific community remains a challenge due to patient privacy and the vast amount of data. Global Biobank Engine is a web-based tool that enables exploration of the relationship between genotype and phenotype in biobank cohorts.

Ankylosing Spondylitis (AS) is an inflammatory rheumatic disease. It affects the axial skeleton and the sacroiliac joints. Recent studies investigated the link between AS and oral diseases.

The UK Biobank recruited 500,000 participants aged between 40 and 69 years. Participants were classified by genotype according to alleles of the rs1229984 single-nucleotide polymorphism. Chronic widespread pain was defined as pain all over the body for more than 3 months that interfered with activities.

Several studies have demonstrated the accuracy, precision, and reproducibility of proton density fat fraction (PDFF) quantification using vendor-specific image acquisition protocols and PDFF estimation methods. This work is to validate a confounder-corrected, cross-vendor, cross field-strength, in-house variant of the University of Wisconsin method.

We performed a meta-analysis of two genome-wide association studies of leiomyoma in European women. We uncovered 21 variants at 16 loci that associate with the disease. Four signals are located at established risk loci for hormone-related traits.

New method can estimate coalescence times using only SNP array data. We applied ASMC to detect recent positive selection in 113,851 phased British samples from the UK Biobank. We detected 12 genome-wide significant signals, including 6 novel loci.

Inbreeding increases the risk of certain Mendelian disorders in humans but may also reduce fitness through its effects on complex traits and diseases. Such inbreeding depression is thought to occur due to increased homozygosity at causal variants that are recessive with respect to fitness.

Existing methods are mostly developed for datasets without missing values. In practice, genotype imputation is not always effective. Using the new method, we identified novel independently associated variants at known loci for tobacco use.

Phrenology was a nineteenth century endeavour to link personality traits with scalp morphology. We were able to re-examine phrenology using 21st century methods and thousands of subjects. High-quality structural MRI was used to quantify local scalp curvature.

 Numerous studies have shown associations between genetic variants and neuropathic pain disorders. In this review, we survey the reported genetic contributors to neuropathy pain and submit them for validation in a 150,000-participant sample of the U.K. Biobank cohort. Successfully replicated association with a neuropathicPain construct for 2 variants in IL10 underscores the importance of neuroimmune interactions.

Elevated blood pressure (BP) is a major global risk factor for cardiovascular disease. Genome-wide association studies have identified several genetic variants at the NPR3 locus associated with BP. Here we confirmed the existence of two independent BP-related signals within NPR3.

PHESANT is a software package for performing comprehensive phenome scans in UK Biobank. It tests the association of a specified trait with all continuous, integer and categorical variables. PHESANT uses a novel rule-based algorithm to determine how to appropriately test each trait.

Common dysfunctional variants of ATP binding cassette subfamily G member 2 (Junior blood group) (ABCG2) that result in decreased urate excretion are major causes of hyperuricemia and gout. In the ABCG2 gene, 18 intronic (one dysfunctional splicing) and 11 exonic variants were detected: 9 were non-synonymous (2 common, 7 rare including 1 novel) The p.Q141K (rs2231142) variant had a significantly higher minor allele frequency (0.23) in the gout patients compared with the European-origin population.

The amplitudes of spontaneous fluctuations in brain activity may be a significant source of within-subject and between-subject variability. This variability is likely to be carried through into functional connectivity (FC) estimates. improving our understanding of amplitude fluctuations is of great relevance to the interpretation of FC findings.

 Reduced ventilatory function is an established predictor of all-cause mortality in general population cohorts. We sought to verify this in lifelong non-smokers, among whom confounding by active smoking can be excluded. We investigated associations with circulatory and cancer deaths.

Genome-wide association analysis for insomnia complaints in 113,006 individuals from the UK Biobank. Finds associations with variants near seven genes.

Neuroticism is a risk factor for selected mental and physical illnesses. It is inversely associated with intelligence. Intelligence appears to interact with neuroticism and mitigate its detrimental effects on physical health and mortality.

John Perry and colleagues identify genetic variants at 19 genomic regions associated with mosaic loss of the Y chromosome (mLOY) in blood. They further highlight a shared genetic architecture between mLOY and cancer susceptibility.

A low-frequency missense variant in ADCY7 doubles risk of ulcerative colitis. Researchers detect a burden of very rare, damaging missense variants in known Crohn's disease risk genes.

Poorer self-rated health (SRH) predicts worse health outcomes. Twin studies indicate SRH has a heritability of up to 60% and that its genetic architecture may overlap with that of personality and cognition. We carried out a genome-wide association study (GWAS) of SRH on 111 749 members of the UK Biobank sample.

Thomas Hoffmann, Neil Risch and colleagues use longitudinal electronic health records from almost 100,000 individuals to conduct genome-wide association studies. They find new significant loci that replicate in independent cohorts.

Individuals with lower socio-economic status (SES) are at increased risk of physical and mental illnesses and tend to die at an earlier age. It is possible that phenotypic associations between SES and health arise partly due to a shared genetic etiology. We conducted a genome-wide association study (GWAS) on social deprivation and on household income using 112,151 participants of UK Biobank. We find that common SNPs explain 21% of the variation in social deprived and 11% of household income.

Pim van der Harst and colleagues report a genome-wide association study for resting heart rate in individuals of European ancestry. They identify 64 associated loci, 46 of which have not been previously reported. A genetic risk score constructed using the associated variants is significantly associated with increased mortality risk.

Eagle2 is a reference-based phasing algorithm that allows for highly accurate and efficient phasing of genotypes across a broad range of cohort sizes. They demonstrate an approximately 10% improvement in accuracy and 20% improvement on speed compared to a competing method.

Disrupted circadian rhythms and reduced sleep duration are associated with several human diseases, particularly obesity and type 2 diabetes. Until recently, little was known about the genetic factors influencing these heritable traits. We performed genome-wide association studies of self-reported chronotype and sleep duration in 128,266 white British individuals from the UK Biobank study.

Po-Ru Loh, Pier Francesco Palamara and Alkes Price develop a new long-range phasing method, Eagle. Eagle harnesses long, shared identical-by-descent tracts and can be applied to large outbred populations.

Jonathan Marchini and colleagues develop a new method for haplotype phasing, SHAPEIT3. They find that their method is fast and accurate, with a low switch error rate.

Recent genetic studies have identified some alleles associated with higher BMI but lower risk of type 2 diabetes, hypertension, and heart disease. These "favorable adiposity" alleles are collectively associated with lower insulin levels and higher subcutaneous-to-visceral adipose tissue ratio and may protect from disease through higher fat storage capacity.

Genome-wide association study for reproductive ability, behavior and success. Find 38 variants associated with age of first sexual intercourse. Both physical and neurobehavioral traits influence onset of reproductive activity.

UK Biobank recruited 502,682 U.K. residents aged 40-69 years. Nonwhite participants were two- to fourfold more likely to have diabetes. Obesity should be defined at lower thresholds in nonwhite populations.

10.7% of adults aged 40 to 69 had significant hearing impairment. Prevalence of tinnitus was 16.9% and hearing aid use was 2.0%. Odds of hearing impairment increased with age, with a history of work-related noise exposure.

Previous research has suggested that a substantial proportion of the population are severely affected by tinnitus. There is growing evidence that the perception of severity is closely related to personality factors such as neuroticism. In a subset of a large population sample of >500,000 adults aged 40 to 69years, we calculated the prevalence of tinn Titus.

The UK Biobank dataset provided the opportunity to determine new normative values for handgrip strength in men and women aged 39 to 73 years. These normative values take into consideration age, height, and measurement side.

Data-driven modeling of age progression has been conducted successfully in diverse applications such as face or brain aging. Age has important implications for health, and understanding how age manifests in the human body is the first step for a potential intervention.

Assortative mating (AM) is a pattern characterized by phenotypic similarities between mating partners. Detecting the evidence of AM has been challenging due to the lack of large-scale datasets. Gametic phase disequilibrium between trait-associated alleles is a signature of parental AM on a polygenic trait.

Risk stratification is critical for the early identification of high-risk individuals and disease prevention. Here we explored the potential of nuclear magnetic resonance (NMR) spectroscopy-derived metabolomic profiles to inform on multidisease risk beyond conventional clinical predictors.

Exome-wide rare genetic variant association study for 30 blood biomarkers in 191,971 individuals in the UK Biobank. Genes associated with biomarkers were.&#x2009;~&#X2009;4.5-fold enriched for conferring Mendelian disorders. We introduce local collapsing by amino acid position for missense variants.

Study looked at 94 739 UK Biobank participants who had device-measured PA in 2013 to 2015. Overall incidence of HF was 98.5 per 10 000 person-years over a median 6.1 years of follow-up. Compared with participants who undertook no moderate- to vigorous-intensity PA, those who performed 150 to 300 min/wk of moderate- intensity PA (hazard ratio, 0.37 [95% CI,0.34-0.41]) were at lower HF risk.

Cancer-driving mutations might be enriched in genic subregions that are depleted of germline variation relative to somatic variation. We introduce a new metric, OncMTR (oncology missense tolerance ratio), which uses 125,748 exomes in the Genome Aggregation Database (gnomAD) to identify these genicsubregions. We demonstrate that OncmTR can significantly predict driver mutations implicated in hematologic malignancies.

Publicly available genome-wide association studies (GWAS) summary statistics exhibit uneven quality, which can impact the validity of follow-up analyses. We show that additional information such as imputation INFO scores, allele frequencies, and per-variant sample sizes in GWAS summary statistics can be used to detect possible issues and correct for misspecifications.

Cost-utility analysis was conducted using UK Biobank prospective cohort study participants. The optimal economic strategy was when intermediate risk individuals with a PRS in the top 70% are eligible for statins. At a $0 genotyping cost, PRS-guided strategies dominated standard care.

Napping was associated with a higher risk of essential hypertension, stroke, and ischemic stroke. Both the 1-sample and 2-sample MR results indicated that increased daytime napping frequency was likely to be a potential causal risk factor for essential hypertension in FinnGEN and UK Biobank.

BMI was cross-sectionally associated with risk of PsA and psoriasis. Genetically predicted glycated haemoglobin (surrogate for diabetes) increased PsA risk. Psoriatic disease is associated with increased CAD risk.

Insomnia is a heritable, highly prevalent sleep disorder for which no sufficient treatment currently exists. Previous genome-wide association studies with up to 1.3 million subjects identified over 200 associated loci. The current study almost doubled the sample size to 593,724 cases and 1,771,286 controls, thereby increasing statistical power.

Clonal hematopoiesis (CH) affects over a third of people, yet remains poorly understood. Here we analyze genetic data from 200,453 UK Biobank participants to map the landscape of inherited predisposition to CH.

Coronary artery disease (CAD) and major adverse cardiovascular events (MACE) are the leading causes of death in the general population. CAD genetic risk scores (GRSs) predict risk independently from clinical tools, like QRISK3. We assessed the added value of GRSs for a variety of cardiovascular traits.

Population-based prospective cohort study (n=346 627) is based on the UK Biobank data. 13 869 participants died from all causes, 2650 from CVD and 4522 from PDAR cancers. Compared with quartile 1 (Q1, 0-210 min/week), Q2-Q4 of MVPA were associated with lower risks of all-cause and CVD mortality.

Study included 258 531 European descendants with hypertension at baseline from UK Biobank. Genetic risk of CHD and stroke was estimated using polygenic risk scores. Lifestyle scores were calculated based on 4 lifestyle components (no obesity, no current smoking, regular physical activity and healthy diet)

Study aimed to identify clinical, socio-demographic and genetic risk factors for severe COVID-19 (hospitalization, critical care admission or death) in the general population. Risk increased with age and obesity, and was higher in men, current smokers and those living in socio-economically deprived areas.

Pneumonia remains one of the leading causes of death worldwide. We use genome-wide meta-analysis of lifetime pneumonia diagnosis to identify four association signals. These signals support clinically tractable targets, including the mucin MUC5AC and tumour necrosis factor receptor superfamily member TNFRSF1A.

Study looked at associations of infertility, recurrent miscarriage, and stillbirth with the risk of first non-fatal and fatal stroke, further stratified by stroke subtypes. Infertility was associated with an increased risk of non-Fatal stroke (hazard ratio 1.14, 95% confidence interval 1.08 to 1.20) Recurrent miscarriage (at least three) was also associated with higher risk. The increased risk was mainly driven by a single stroke subtype.

Unipolar mania/hypomania (UM) characterised by a higher proportion of males, early chronotype, increased activity and shorter sleep duration. Both mood disorder groups had later chronotype preference, more disturbed sleep and increased difficulty getting up in the morning.

We identify two transdiagnostic genetic liabilities that distinguish between common forms of psychopathology versus rarer forms of serious mental illness. Biological annotation revealed divergent genetic architectures that differentially implicated prenatal neurodevelopment and neuronal function and regulation. These findings inform psychiatric nosology and biological models of psychopathologist.

It is critical to identify biomarkers for neurological diseases (NLDs) to accelerate drug discovery for effective treatment. We retrieved genotyping and clinical data from 1,223 UK Biobank participants to identify genetic and clinical biomarkers. We found evidence for shared genetic risk loci among NLDs.

We evaluated independent associations of cardiovascular magnetic resonance (CMR)-measured pericardial adipose tissue (PAT) with cardiovascular structure and function. We considered underlying mechanism in 42 598 UK Biobank participants. Higher PAT was associated with cardiometabolic disease (hypertension, diabetes, high cholesterol)

Measuring genetic diversity is an important problem. We define 21 distinct ancestry groups from all four corners of the world. These ancestry groups can serve as a global reference of worldwide populations.

Gene-SCOUT is a tool used to identify genes with similar continuous trait fingerprints to a gene of interest. A fingerprint reflects the continuous traits identified to be statistically associated with a gene. Similarities between genes are evaluated by the cosine similarity measure, to capture concordant effect directionality.

Proposed method first uses the 'nnU-Net' segmentation model to extract segmentations of the heart over the full cardiac cycle. Next, a multimodal deep learning classifier is used for CRT response prediction. This combines the latent spaces of the segmentation models of the two modalities.

Not many studies have directly compared vaccine effectiveness in the population. We analyse 235,181 UK Biobank participants aged 50 years or older and vaccinated with one or two doses of BNT162b2 or ChAdOx1. We find that, compared with one dose of ChAd Ox1, vaccination with BNT 162b2 is associated with a 28% (95% CI, 12-42) decreased risk of SARS-CoV-2 infection.

RAREsim efficiently simulates the expected variant distribution and enables real-variant annotations. We highlight RAREsim's utility across various genetic regions, sample sizes, ancestries, and variant classes.

Clinical features from electronic health records (EHRs) can be used to build a complementary tool to predict coronary artery disease (CAD) susceptibility. The EHR score reclassified 25.8% and 15.2% individuals in each cohort, compared with the PCE score.

Rupture of an intracranial aneurysm (IA) leads to ASAH, a severe type of stroke. Majority of genetic causes, as well as the biological mechanisms of IA development and rupture, remain unknown. We identified six rare and damaging variants for which all cases within one of the families were heterozygous.

Genome-wide association studies (GWAS) have identified thousands of genetic variants linked to the risk of human disease. We combined whole-exome sequencing in 392,814 UK Biobank participants with imputed genotypes from 260,405 FinnGen participants to conduct association meta-analyses for 744 disease endpoints. We identified 975 associations, with more than one-third being previously unreported.

Previous genome-wide association studies (GWAS) of hematological traits have identified over 10 000 distinct trait-specific risk loci. At these loci, the underlying causal mechanisms remain incompletely characterized. To elucidate novel biology and better understand causal mechanisms, we performed a transcriptome-wide. association study (TWAS) in 399 835 UK Biobank (UKB) participants of European ancestry.

Study utilised UK Biobank linked to national SARS-CoV-2 laboratory test data. Of 401,910 individuals, 3612 were identified as having suffered from a severe COVID-19 infection and 11,264 (2.8%) from a non-severe infection, between 16 March 2020 and 16 March 2021.

Study aimed to investigate associations of serum calcium, phosphate, and vitamin D levels with the risk of developing aortic stenosis (AS) Included 296 415 participants who were free of prior diagnosis of any valvular heart disease from the UK Biobank.

There were 199,807 exome sequenced subjects for whom BMI was recorded. Weighted burden analysis of rare, functional variants was carried out. In MC4R, disruptive variants were associated with an increase in BMI of 2.72 units and probably damaging nonsynonymous variants with 2.02 units.

Osteoporosis was strongly associated with respiratory disease and COPD in both sexes. Compared with women, men had a higher risk of all-cause mortality, mortality from respiratory diseases including COPD and cancer incidence.

Small vessel disease is associated with age, mean blood pressure (MAP) and blood pressure pulsatility (PP) We used data from the UK Biobank cohort study to determine the relative importance of MAP versus PP driving white matter injury. The associations between blood pressure and diffusion indices in 27 major tracts were analysed.

Common polymorphic inversions underlie the shared genetic influence of these disorders. Inversions at 8p23.1, 16p11.2, and 11q13.2 were strongly associated with the co-occurrence of obesity with other common diseases. Transcriptome analysis across numerous tissues revealed strong candidate genes for obesity-related traits.

Study aimed to identify the hierarchy of demographic characteristics associated with the sedentary behaviours of television viewing, recreational computer use and driving. Age, sex, race, college attendance, employment, shift-work, urban versus rural residence as well as physical activity were considered as predictors.

Lower grip strength was associated with a higher risk of T2DM in both sexes. The associations were stronger when grip strength is expressed relative to body weight, which could reflect the importance of muscle quality.

LDpred is a popular method for deriving polygenic scores based on summary statistics and a matrix of correlation between genetic variants. LDpred has limitations that may reduce its predictive performance. We present LDpred2, a new version of LDpred that addresses these issues.

Macrothrombocytopenia is a heterogeneous group of disorders characterized by enlarged and reduced numbers of circulating platelets. In most MTP, this phenotype arises because of altered regulation of platelet formation from megakaryocytes. We report the identification of DIAPH1, which encodes the Rho-effector diaphanous-related formin 1, as a candidate gene for MTP.

Analysis included 12&#x2009;364 adults aged 55-73 years from the UK Biobank cohort. Incident dementia was ascertained using hospital inpatient, death records and self-reported data. Diabetes, heart disease, stroke and depression at baseline were all associated with an increased risk of dementia.

Rare variants are collectively numerous and may underlie a considerable proportion of complex disease risk. Identifying genuine rare variant associations is challenging due to small effect sizes, presence of technical artefacts, and heterogeneity in population structure. We hypothesize that rare variant burden over a large number of genes can be combined into a predictive rare variant genetic risk score (RVGRS)

Microglia are the primary innate immune cells in the brain. Changes in immune function are associated with variance in cognitive functioning in schizophrenia. Increased microglial schizophrenia polygenic risk was associated with significantly lower performance across several measures of cognitive functioning.

Premorbid body mass index, physical activity, diabetes and cardiovascular disease have been associated with an altered risk of developing amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (ALS) There is evidence of shared genetic risk between ALS and lipid metabolism.

Dietary intake is a major contributor to the global obesity epidemic. It represents a complex behavioural phenotype that is partially affected by innate biological differences. We present a multivariate genome-wide association analysis of overall variation in dietary intake to account for the correlation between dietary carbohydrate, fat and protein.

Polygenic risk scores (PRSs) are able to stratify individuals based on their genetic risk of developing various common diseases. PRSs could potentially be used to optimize the use of screening and preventative treatments and improve personalized care. Many challenges are yet to be overcome, including PRS validation, healthcare professional and patient education, and healthcare systems integration.

Lp(a) levels are higher in individuals of African ancestry (AA) than in people of European ancestry (EA) Lp was associated with atherosclerotic cardiovascular disease in four major arterial beds in EA but only with peripheral artery disease and abdominal aortic aneurysm in AA. Novel associations were detected in EA.

Rheumatoid arthritis (RA) is associated with increased localized and generalized bone loss. The complex genetic mechanism between them is still unknown. Linkage disequilibrium score regression reveals a shared genetic correlation between RA and estimated bone mineral density (eBMD)

Dyslexia is a common heritable developmental disorder involving impaired reading abilities. Its genetic underpinnings are thought to be complex and heterogeneous, involving common and rare genetic variation. We identified a locus on chromosome 7q21.11 which cosegregated with dyslexia status, with the exception of two cases of phenocopy.

Atrial fibrillation (AF) and ventricular arrhythmia (Arr) are among the most common and fatal cardiac arrhythmias in the world. Electrocardiogram data, collected as part of the UK Biobank, represents an opportunity for analysis and classification of these two diseases in the UK.

Osteoclasts are large multinucleated bone-resorbing cells formed by the fusion of monocyte/macrophage-derived precursors. Inhibiting RANKL blocked this cellular recycling and resulted in osteomorph accumulation.

Daytime napping is a common, heritable behavior, but its genetic basis and causal relationship with cardiometabolic health remain unclear. We perform a genome-wide association study of self-reported daytime napping in the UK Biobank. Findings include missense variants in established drug targets for sleep disorders and genes suggesting an obesity-hypersomnolence pathway.

Despite considerable progress on pathogenicity scores prioritizing variants for Mendelian disease, little is known about the utility of these scores for common disease. Here, we assess the informativeness of Mendelians disease-derived pathogenicicity scores forCommon disease and improve upon existing scores. We then develop AnnotBoost, a machine learning framework to impute and denoise pathogenity scores.

Polygenic risk scores (PRS) use the results of genome-wide association studies (GWAS) to predict quantitative phenotypes or disease risk at an individual level. A major barrier to the use of PRS is that the majority of GWAS come from cohorts of European ancestry. The predictive power ofPRS constructed from these studies is substantially lower in non-European ancestry cohorts.

Calcific aortic valve stenosis (CAVS) is a frequent heart disease with significant morbidity and mortality. Recent genomic studies have identified a locus near the gene PALMD (palmdelphin) strongly associated with CAVS. Here, we show that genetically-determined expression of PALMD in the aorta is inversely associated withCAVS, with a stronger effect in women.

Corneal hysteresis and corneal resistance factor are parameters that reflect the dynamic biomechanical properties of the cornea. In this genome-wide association study of over 100 000 participants, we identified over 200 genetic loci, all but eight novel, significantly associated with either of these traits.

The timing of puberty is highly variable and is associated with long-term health outcomes. To date, understanding of the genetic control of puberty timing is based largely on studies in women. We find moderately strong genomic correlation in puberty timing between sexes.

In recent years, deep learning has become more widespread in the fields of cognitive and clinical neuroimaging. Using deep neural network models is an efficient method to classify brain disorders and identify individuals who are at increased risk of age-related cognitive decline and neurodegenerative disease.

Heart failure is a major public health problem affecting over 23 million people worldwide. Heart failure sub-phenotyping shows that a new locus in chromosome 1 is associated with left ventricular adverse remodeling and clinical heart failure.

ScSplit is a tool to demultiplex pooled samples in a single cell RNA sequencing (scRNA-seq) experiment. We show that scSplit prediction is highly concordant with demuxlet predictions. It is ideally suited to samples without external genotype information.

Growing evidence suggests that inflammation is a significant contributor to different cardiovascular diseases (CVDs) Mendelian randomization was performed to assess the causal inference between plasma soluble IL6 receptor (sIL6R) and different cardiovascular and immune-related disorders. Genetically-determined reduced IL6 signaling lowers the risk of multiple CVDs and is associated with increased longevity.

Modern societies are experiencing an epidemic of loneliness. Loneliness is more strongly associated with mortality than obesity. Although circumstantial factors such as marital status and age influence loneliness, there is evidence of a genetic predisposition toward loneliness.

Short and long sleep duration have been linked with poorer cognitive outcomes. It remains unclear whether these associations are causal. We conducted the first Mendelian randomization (MR) study with 77 single-nucleotide polymorphisms (SNPs) for sleep duration.

Hand preference is a prominent behavioural trait linked to human brain asymmetry. A handful of genetic variants have been reported to associate with hand preference or quantitative measures related to it. Here we performed a genome-wide association analysis of hand preference in the UK Biobank cohort. We found no evidence supporting any of the previously suggested variants or genes.

A growing number of studies clearly demonstrate a substantial association between chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD) and cardiovascular diseases (CVD) Little is known about the shared genetics that contribute to this association. We conducted a large-scale cross-trait genome-wide association study.

Cross-trait penalized regression (CTPR) is a powerful and practical approach for polygenic risk prediction in large cohorts. We illustrate our method using large-scale GWAS data (~1M SNPs) from the UK Biobank. We show that our method outperforms the recently proposed multi-Trait analysis of GWAS (MTAG) for predictive performance. The prediction accuracy for height by the aid of BMI improves from R2&#x2009;=&# x2009;35.8% to 42.5% (MCP&#X2009;+&# X2009;CTPR).

Identifying genetic variants with effects on trait variability can provide insights into the biological mechanisms that control variation. We propose a two-degree-of-freedom test for jointly testing mean and variance effects to identify such variants. We apply our approach to body mass index in the subsample of the UK Biobank population with British ancestry (n ~408,000)

Diverticular disease is common and has a high morbidity. Treatments are limited owing to the poor understanding of its pathophysiology. We identified 42 loci associated with diverticular disease; 39 of these loci are novel. Genes in associated loci have roles in immunity, extracellular matrix biology, cell adhesion, membrane transport and intestinal motility.

Higher educational attainment (EA) is negatively associated with schizophrenia (SZ) However, recent studies found a positive genetic correlation between EA and SZ. Using EA as a proxy phenotype, we isolate FOXO6 and SLITRK1 as novel candidate genes for Sz.

The Asp358Ala variant in the interleukin-6 receptor (IL-6R) gene has been implicated in asthma, autoimmune and cardiovascular disorders. Its role in other respiratory conditions such as chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD) has not been investigated. In vitro studies using blood samples from 37 participants, we found that shedding of sIL- 6R from neutrophils was greater in carriers of the Asp 358Ala minor allele than in non-carriers.

COPD is the third leading cause of death worldwide. Smoking is the main risk factor for COPD, but genetic factors are also relevant contributors. Genome-wide association studies (GWAS) of lung function measures used in the diagnosis of COPD have identified a number of loci.

A 2007 World Health Organization review concluded that shift work involving circadian disruption is probably carcinogenic to humans. We aimed to generate prospective epidemiological evidence on night shift work and breast cancer incidence. Overall, 522 246 Million Women Study, 22 559 EPIC-Oxford, and 251 045 UK Biobank participants answered questions on shift work.

Study of UK Biobank participants recruited from 2006 to 2010. Myopia and high myopia were defined as autorefraction of -0.75 diopters (D) or less. Risk for myopia became progressively lower for later birth orders.

Heritability in the immune tumor microenvironment (iTME) has been widely observed yet remains largely uncharacterized. Here, we developed a machine learning approach to map iTME modifiers within loci from genome-wide association studies (GWASs) for breast cancer (BrCa) incidence.

Patatin-like phospholipase domain-containing protein 3 (PNPLA3) I148M polymorphism and alpha-1 antitrypsin (AAT) E342K variant, termed PiZ, are major modifiers of metabolic CLD. Both variants are known to affect metabolicCLD through increased endoplasmic reticulum stress but their combined effect on CLD progression remains largely unknown.

The sterol regulatory element binding proteins (SREBPs) are transcription factors that govern cholesterol and fatty acid metabolism. We recently identified SPRING as a post-transcriptional regulator of SREBP activation. Constitutive or inducible global ablation of Spring in mice is not tolerated.

Genome-wide association studies have identified multiple Alzheimer's disease risk loci with small effect sizes. Polygenic risk scores, which aggregate these variants, are associated with grey matter structural changes. Pathway-specific profiling could further define pathophysiology in individuals, moving towards precision medicine in Alzheimer's.

Principal component analysis (PCA) is widely used in statistics, machine learning, and genomics for dimensionality reduction and uncovering low-dimensional latent structure. To address the challenges posed by ever-growing data size, fast and memory-efficient PCA methods have gained prominence.

Shift work has become an increasingly common work mode globally. This study aimed to investigate the association between shift work and the risk of incident gastroesophageal reflux disease (GORD)

Mid/late-life cognitive activities are associated with a lower rate of subsequent cognitive decline and lower subsequent dementia risk over time. In this study, we found that participation in adult education classes preceded greater retention of subsequent fluid intelligence. This association did not change after adjusting for cognitive function at baseline or genetic predisposition to dementia.

Previous evidence has mainly supported transient changes in cardiac function during interictal or peri-ictal phases in people with epilepsy. This study aimed to assess the long-term association of epilepsy with cardiac arrhythmias. It also considered the potential role of genetic predisposition and antiseizure medications (ASMs)

Copy number variants (CNVs) are major contributors to genetic diversity and disease. Technical challenges have confounded uniform large-scale CNV analyses from whole-exome sequencing (WES) data. GATK-gCNV is a flexible algorithm to discover rare CNVs from sequencing read-depth information.

The American Heart Association recently updated Life's Essential 8 (LE8) score. This amalgamation of health factors provides a robust tool to assess overall cardiovascular health. Study aimed to investigate the association between levels of CVH, as measured by the LE8 score, and risk of CKD.

Functional magnetic resonance imaging (fMRI) has been widely used to identify brain regions linked to critical functions, such as language and vision. Large sample sizes are necessary for fMRI studies to detect small effect sizes and produce reproducible results.

Parallels have been drawn to median nerve decompression for carpal tunnel syndrome (CTS) 2 previous studies have demonstrated an association between migraine and CTS. This study replicates past reports of an epidemiologic association between CTS and migraine, albeit in women only. This association is underpinned by a genetic correlation, with shared genetic susceptibility at the TRIM32 locus.

Autoimmune diseases are more common among people with unhealthy sleep behaviors. These conditions have been linked to aging-related bone health. Few studies examined the correlation between recently developed sleep patterns based on sleep duration, sleepiness, chronotype, snoring, insomnia, and the incidence of falls and fractures.

Study included 277,057 individuals free of CVDs or cancer at baseline in the UK Biobank. Genetic scores of plasma cystatin C comprising 67 single-nucleotide polymorphisms were calculated on the basis of data from a large genome-wide association study.

The genetic correlation is a well-known means of quantifying and testing for genetic similarity between traits. This makes it unsuitable for use in a small-sample context. We discuss the use of a nonparametric test of genetic similarity for application to GWAS summary statistics.

Brain imaging-derived phenotypes (IDPs) are critical markers for early diagnosis of both brain disorders and cardiovascular diseases. However, it remains unclear about the shared genetic landscape between brain IDPs and the risk of brain disorders. Here, we reported genetic correlations and putative causal relationships between 921 brain IDP, 20 brain disorders, and six cardiovascular diseases in a large-scale genome-wide association study.

The human brain is generally anatomically symmetrical, boasting mirror-like brain regions in the left and right hemispheres. Despite this symmetry, fine-scale structural asymmetries are prevalent and are believed to be responsible for distinct functional divisions within the brain. Prior studies propose these asymmetric structures are predominantly primate specific or even unique to humans.

It remains unclear whether inflammatory bowel disease is associated with long-term risk of chronic kidney disease (CKD) and acute kidney injury (AKI) in the general population. A total of 417,302 participants, including 2,940 patients with ulcerative colitis and 1,261 patients with Crohn's disease, without previous CKD and AKI at baseline (2006-2010) were included.

Sleep disturbance is an increasingly recognized non-motor trait in dystonia. We examined sleep in a UK Biobank derived Dystonia cohort using subjective self-reported sleep symptoms and objective accelerometer-derived sleep measures.

Chronic pain affects nearly 20% of the U.S. population. It is a leading cause of disability globally and is associated with a heightened risk for suicide. Specific brain circuitries involved have yet to be mapped across pain types.

Genome-wide association studies have identified numerous risk loci for venous thromboembolism. We employed an integrative analytical pipeline to transform genetic associations to identify novel plasma proteins for VTE. PLEK, SERPINA1, and SERPINE2 are compelling proteins that may provide key hints for future research.

Alzheimer's disease (AD) is one of the most common neurodegenerative diseases. The AD mechanism has not yet been fully elucidated to date, hindering the development of effective therapies. This study connects genetics, molecular and cellular signatures, regional brain morphologic endophenotypes, and AD diagnosis. The findings can provide valuable guidance for subsequent therapeutic target identification and drug discovery in AD.

Population screening for non-alcoholic fatty liver disease (NAFLD) remains an unaddressed clinical need. We aimed to assess the utility of the fatty liver index (FLI) for risk stratification of NAFLD and related comorbidities using the UK Biobank. Intermediate and high-risk FLI was associated with increased cardiometabolic and malignant disease.

We identified 63 AMD risk loci alongside the well-established AMD loci CFH and ARMS2, including 9 loci that were not reported in previous GWASs. A new PRS was constructed using the PRS method, PRS-CS, and significantly improved the prediction accuracy of AMD risk. The PRS shows potential for predicting risk in people of East Asian, South Asian and Latino ancestry.

Branch-chain amino acids (BCAAs) are linked to higher risk of diabetes. Valine metabolite, 3-hydroxyisobutyrate (3-HIB), also plays an important role in metabolism. We assessed the role of BCAAs and 3-Hib in IHD and diabetes using Mendelian randomization to minimize confounding. We also examined sex-specific associations.

Many regions in the human genome vary in length among individuals due to variable numbers of tandem repeats (VNTRs) We applied a statistical imputation approach to estimate the lengths of 9,561 autosomal VNTR loci in 418,136 unrelated UK Biobank participants and 838 GTEx participants.

Red wine and dairy products have been staples in human diets for a long period. However, the impact on brain network activity remains ambiguous. This study investigated the associations between dairy and red wine consumption and seven neural networks' connectivity.

Germ line variants in the DDX41 gene have been linked to myelodysplastic syndromes (MDS) and acute myeloid leukemia (AML) development. The risks associated with different variants remain unknown, as do the basis of their leukemogenic properties and impact on steady-state hematopoiesis.

Biallelic PKD1 variants, including hypomorphic variants, can cause very early onset polycystic kidney disease (VEO-PKD) A family with unexplained recurrent VEO- PKD and neonatal demise in one dizygotic twin was referred for clinical testing. Further individuals with the putative hypomorphicPKD1 variant, p.(Ile3167Phe), were identified from the UK 100,000 genomes project.

Habitual use of calcium supplements was significantly associated with higher risk of CVD events and mortality in people with diabetes. No significant association was observed in participants without diabetes.

Objectively measured physical activity (PA) data were collected in the accelerometry substudy of the UK Biobank. Data also contains information about multiple sclerosis (MS) diagnosis at the time of and after PA collection. Study aimed to quantify the difference in PA between prevalent MS cases and matched healthy controls.

The effective size of a population (Ne) in the recent past can be estimated through analysis of identity-by-descent (IBD) segments. Several methods have been developed for estimating Ne from autosomal IBD segments, but no such effort has been made with X chromosomes. We show how to use the estimated autosome Ne and X chromosome Ne to estimate the female and male effective population sizes.

Stroke is a significant health issue in the United States. This study aims to identify circulating metabolite signatures that may be associated with stroke pathophysiology by performing discovery and validation studies.

Daily mobile phone use is significantly associated with a reduced risk of incident dementia in community-dwelling adults in the UK Biobank population. This association seems to be mediated by improved social and mental activities.

Low socioeconomic status (SES) is associated with cardiovascular risk factors and increased coronary artery disease (CAD) risk. We tested whether SES is an effect modifier of the association between classical cardiovascularrisk factors and CAD using SES-stratified Mendelian Randomization in European-ancestry participants.

Alcohol misuse (AM) is highly prevalent and harmful, with theorized subgroups differing on internalizing and externalizing dimensions. Despite known heterogeneity, genome-wide association studies are usually conducted on unidimensional phenotypes. This study aimed to address phenotypic heterogeneity in GWAS to aid gene finding and to uncover the etiology of different types of AM.

Study included 498,200 participants from UK Biobank (2006-2021) During a median follow-up of 12.49 years, 2,477 deaths due to respiratory diseases were recorded. Short sleep duration associated with 14% higher risk of total respiratory diseases mortality. Long sleep duration was associated with 35% higher rate of respiratory diseases deaths.

IT workers have occupational health risks of sedentary behaviour, physical inactivity and poor diet. Yet studies of their non-communicable disease risk, notably cancer, are lacking.

The human skeletal form underlies bipedalism, but the genetic basis of skeletal proportions (SPs) is not well characterized. We applied deep-learning models to 31,221 x-rays from the UK Biobank to extract a comprehensive set of SPs, which were associated with 145 independent loci genome-wide.

UK Biobank is a prospective study of adults aged 40-69 in 2006-2010. 3,815 incident cases of CHD occurred during a median follow-up of 11.8 years. CHD risk was positively associated with saturated fatty acids and monounsaturated fatty acids. Inversely associated with omega-3 polyunsaturated fatty acid (PUFA)

Recent work within neuroimaging consortia has aimed to identify reproducible brain signatures of psychiatric or neurological conditions. To allow for high-powered brain imaging analyses, it is often necessary to pool MR images that were acquired with different protocols across multiple scanners. Current retrospective harmonization techniques have shown promise in removing site-related image variation.

Sustainable cognitive health is heavily influenced by cognitive reserve (CR) CR delays cognitive decline or reduces its severity by enhancing cognitive function through life experiences. This study explored whether CR moderates the relationship between white matter integrity and cognitive function in cognitively intact older adults.

UK Biobank recruited 84,166 men and women (aged 40-69) for an average of 6.4 years. Survival rates differed by PA volume quartile, with poorer outcomes for the lowest PA volumes. Participants with more sedentary to light intensity PA ( 250 mg) than average for a given volume of PA, had higher mortality rates.

Habitual use of fish oil was assessed by repeated questionnaires. Cox proportional hazard models were applied to calculate hazard ratios (HRs) and 95% confidence intervals (CIs) Over a median follow-up of 11.6 years, 4304 and 3294 CHD cases were documented among 47,663 individuals with prediabetes and 22,146 patients with diabetes.

The trait of participating in a genetic study probably has a genetic component. Identifying this component is difficult as we cannot compare genetic information of participants with nonparticipants directly. Taking participation behaviour into account would improve the analyses of the study data, including those of health traits.

Excess weight and colorectal cancer (CRC) risk may have been underestimated due to potential weight loss during pre-clinical sojourn time of CRC. We aimed to investigate this association and the corresponding population attributable fraction (PAF), accounting for prediagnostic weight loss.

Cerebral microbleeds (CMBs) are associated with white matter damage, and various neurodegenerative and cerebrovascular diseases. Accurate automated detection of CMBs would help to determine quantitative imaging biomarkers (e.g., CMB count) on large datasets.

QRISK3 had moderate overall discrimination in UK Biobank, which was best in younger participants. The observed CVD risk was lower than that predicted by QRISk3, particularly for older participants.

Polygenic scores (PGSs) are individual-level measures that aggregate the genome-wide genetic predisposition to a given trait. PGS have predominantly been developed using European-ancestry samples. We investigate the effect of sample size and ancestry composition on PGS performance.

This study aimed to investigate the association between the Life's Essential 8 (LE8) score and incident all-cause dementia in UK Biobank. Smoking, non-HDL cholesterol, blood pressure, body mass index, HbA1c, physical activity, diet, and sleep were used to create the score. Over a median follow-up of 10.6 years, 4958 participants were diagnosed with dementia.

A GT(n) repeat length in the heme oxygenase 1 gene (HMOX1) has been widely associated with a variety of phenotypes, including susceptibility to and outcomes in diabetes, cancer, infections, and neonatal jaundice. However, studies have generally been small and results inconsistent. Despite high-quality imputation, clinical associations were not identified.

Growing evidence suggests that individuals with anxiety disorder have an elevated risk of cardiovascular disease. Few studies have assessed this association independently of or jointly with depression. Diagnoses of anxiety disorder, depression, and CVDs were ascertained through linked hospital admission and mortality data.

Higher cardiorespiratory fitness is associated with lower risk of type 2 diabetes. However, the causality of this relationship and the biological mechanisms that underlie it are unclear. Here, we examine genetic determinants of fitness in 450k European-ancestry individuals in UK Biobank.

Sleep health is assumed to be a key determinant of future morbidity and mortality. Little is known about brain structural abnormalities underlying this association. To our knowledge, this is the largest study to test associations between sleep health and grey matter volume.

 Reduced lung function is common and associated with increased cardiovascular morbidity and mortality. Previous studies have identified relationships between lung function and cardiovascular structure in individuals with pulmonary disease. But the relationships in those free from diagnosed cardiorespiratory disease have not been fully explored.

A polygenic risk score (PRS) derived from 112 single-nucleotide polymorphisms (SNPs) for gastric cancer has been reported in Chinese populations. However, its performance in other populations is unknown. A functional PRS using functional SNPs may improve the generalizability of the PRS across populations with distinct ethnicities.

Non-linear Mendelian randomization is an extension to Mendel's randomization. It explores the shape of the causal relationship between an exposure and outcome using an instrumental variable. The standard implementation of stratification relies on strong parametric assumptions of linearity and homogeneity.

ShAPEIT5 is a new phasing method that quickly and accurately processes large sequencing datasets. We apply it to UK Biobank whole-genome and whole-exome sequencing data. We identify 549 genes where both gene copies are knocked out. These genes complement current knowledge of gene essentiality in the human genome.

A total of 18 509 participants diagnosed with diabetes from the UK Biobank were included. During a mean follow-up of 10.7 years, 3247 total CVD incidents were documented, including 2771 coronary heart disease and 701 strokes.

People have a circadian preference termed chronotype. Those with an evening preference may be better suited to shift work, but also carry higher risk of adverse health. Shift work leads to misalignment of circadian rhythms and is associated with increased risk of inflammatory disease.

Helicobacter pylori causes chronic gastritis and increases the risk of gastroduodenal ulcer and gastric cancer. Chronic colonization triggers aberrant epithelial and inflammatory signals that are also associated with systemic alterations.

We explored cardiovascular disease biomarkers, events, and mortality in the UK Biobank stratified by BMI and diabetes. Overweight/obesity was associated with higher CIMT, arterial stiffness, and CCI and lower LVEF. Normal-weight diabetes had comparable adjusted cardiovascular mortality to obese nondiabetes.

The association between long-term joint exposure to all kinds of ambient air pollutants and the risk of mortality is not known. Our study prospectively assessed the joint associations of various air pollutants with cause-specific and all-cause mortality risk. A total of 400,259 individuals aged 40-70 years were included in this study.

Previous studies have reported genetic overlap between psychiatric disorders and population-level mental health. Here, we map the genetic associations between self-reported mental health and resting-state fMRI-based measures of brain network function. The findings provide further genetic evidence of an association between brain function and mental health traits in the population.

Complications of coronary artery disease (CAD) represent the leading cause of death among adults globally. This study examined the associations and clinical utilities of genetic, sociodemographic, lifestyle, and clinical risk factors on CAD recurrence.

No previous study has examined the impact of air pollution on the cardiovascular disease (CVD) trajectory, especially among asthmatic subjects. Based on the UK Biobank cohort, we retrieved 292,227 adults free of asthma and CVD aged 37-73 years at recruitment (2006-2010) Annual mean concentrations of particulate matter (PM 10 and PM 2.5 ) and nitrogen oxides (NO 2  and NO x ) were assessed at each individual's addresses.

In this study we examined how genetic risk for asthma associates with different features of the disease and with other medical conditions and traits. We identified 228 total significant associations across a variety of organ systems. Our results highlight pervasive pleiotropy between asthma and numerous other traits and conditions.

Liver fibrosis showed significant associations with cognitive performance in reasoning, working memory, visual memory, prospective memory, executive function, and processing speed. CRP levels were significantly higher in adults with advanced liver fibrosis than those without, indicating an elevated systemic inflammation.

The cardioprotective diet has been previously reported to be inversely associated with the development of inflammatory bowel disease. Whether it is beneficial to improve adverse outcomes in IBD remains unknown. We conducted a prospective cohort study of 5549 participants with IBD from the UK Biobank. Compared with participants with the lowest adherence to the cardiop rotective diet, those with the highest score had a lower risk of enterotomy.

CyC, a secreted cysteine protease inhibitor, has unclear biological functions. Many patients exhibit elevated plasma CyC levels, particularly during glucocorticoid (GC) treatment. GC receptor directly targets CyC, leading to GC-responsive CyC secretion in macrophages and cancer cells.

 Hyper-secretion and/or hyper-concentration of mucus is a defining feature of multiple obstructive lung diseases, including chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD) Mucus itself is composed of a mixture of water, ions, salt and proteins, of which the gel-forming mucins, MUC5AC and M UC5B, are the most abundant. Recent studies have linked the concentrations of these proteins in sputum to COPD phenotypes.

Parkinson's disease has a large heritable component and genome-wide association studies have identified over 90 variants with disease-associated common variants. However, there have not been large-scale rare variant analyses for Parkinson's disease. To address this gap, we investigated the rare genetic component of the disease at minor allele frequencies.

AutoPrognosis 2.0 is an open-source machine learning framework for developing diagnostic and prognostic models. It leverages state-of-the-art advances in automated machine learning to develop optimized machine learning pipelines. The models produced by our automated framework achieve greater discrimination for diabetes than expert clinical risk scores.

Cox regression has remained one of the most popular statistical models for the analysis of survival data to-date. We propose Cox regression subsampling-based estimators that approximate their full-data partial-likelihood-based counterparts. The suggested methodology is applied on the UK-biobank for building a colorectal cancer risk-prediction model.

Energy harvesting from human motion can reduce reliance on battery recharging in wearable Internet of Things (IoT) devices. To date, studies estimating energy harvesting potential have largely focused on small scale, healthy, population groups in laboratory settings. This article presents detailed stratification into how the day of the week and participant age affect harvesting potential.

Previous studies have shown that dietary patterns are associated with the incidence of depressive symptoms. This study aimed to investigate the association between dietary patterns and depressive symptoms in two large cohort studies. The Tianjin Chronic Low-grade Systemic Inflammation and Health cohort study included a total of 7,094 participants living in Tianjin, China from 2013 to 2019. The UK Biobank cohort study includes 96,810 participants who were recruited from 22 assessment centers across the UK between 2006 and 2010.

We conduct the pan-cancer and cross-population genome-wide association study (GWAS) meta-analysis and replication studies on 13 cancers. We identify ten cancer risk variants including five pleiotropic associations. Quantifying shared heritability among the cancers detects positive genetic correlations between breast and prostate cancer across populations.
