Cross-sectional analysis of data from subjects enrolled in the UK Biobank cohort. More men and smokers reported psoriasis and were older, had higher weight and body mass index, and lower pulmonary function.

Study used data from 17 840 cancer-free postmenopausal women. High estimated CRF (eCRF) was categorised as being >80th percentile. Over a median follow-up of 11.0 years there were 529 cases of invasive breast cancer.

Alzheimer's disease (AD) is a severe public health issue in the world. Magnetic Resonance Imaging (MRI) offers a way to study brain differences between AD patients and healthy individuals. In most previous works, the extracted features were not aimed to be causal, hindering biological understanding and interpretation. We propose using instrumental variable (IV) regression with genetic variants as IVs.

Accumulating evidence has reported the associations of coffee consumption with physical conditions and mortality, but the associations with mental disorders were limited. In this prospective cohort study, we utilized data from the UK Biobank and included a total of 146,566 participants who completed the touchscreen questionnaire between 2006 and 2010. We found J-shaped associations between coffee consumption and both incident depression and anxiety.

The ability to accurately predict whether a woman will develop breast cancer later in her life, should reduce the number of breast cancer deaths. Different predictive models exist for breast cancer based on family history, BRCA status, and SNP analysis. The best of these models has an accuracy (area under the receiver operating characteristic curve, AUC) of about 0.65.

Evidence for the effects of dietary fiber on adverse outcomes in individuals with inflammatory bowel disease (IBD) is insufficient and controversial. We aimed to explore the association between dietary fiber intake and the risk of IBD-related surgery. We identified 5580 individuals with diagnosed IBD at baseline in the UK Biobank.

Age-related cognitive decline is a global phenomenon that affects individuals worldwide. The course and extent of this decline are influenced by numerous factors, such as genetics, lifestyle, education, and cognitive engagement. Theory of brain and cognitive reserve/maintenance posits that these factors have a significant impact on the degree of cognitive decline.

In this study, we adopted individual baseline data from the UK Biobank cohort of participants aged 40-69 across the UK. First, we used multilevel models to decompose the variation in body mass index (BMI) values. Next, we looked at whether key predictors of obesity differ across 6 cities in England by using a machine learning approach.

This is the first study to use the UK Biobank database to test whether participants of a low socioeconomic position are less likely to drink, but more likely to suffer alcohol-related harm. The database contains health-related information from 500,000 UK residents that were recruited aged 40-69 between 2006 and 2010.

 Muscle strength is highly heritable and predictive for multiple adverse health outcomes including mortality. We show that the exome-wide burden of rare protein-truncating and damaging missense variants is associated with a reduction in hand grip strength. We identify shared mechanisms between brain and muscle function and uncover additive effects between rare and common genetic variation.

A healthy lifestyle is the cornerstone of management in nonalcoholic fatty liver disease (NAFLD) However, the associations between dietary macronutrient composition and different aspects of NAFLD pathology are unclear. This work aimed to evaluate the associations of dietary macronsutrients with hepatic steatosis, hepatic fibroinflammation, and NAFLd.

Cerebral small vessel disease is a major cause of stroke and dementia. Metabolomics can help identify novel risk factors to better understand pathogenesis and predict disease progression and severity.

H. pylori has been associated with decreased cognitive function and dementia. We used data from the UK Biobank to further examine associations between H. plyori seropositivity and serointensity and performance on several cognitive tasks in adults 40 to 70 years of age.

Few studies have examined the relationship between vitamin D and the risk of recurrent cardiovascular (CV) events in people with coronary heart disease (CHD) This study aimed to investigate the associations of serum 25-hydroxyvitamin D (25(OH)D) concentration and the vitamin D receptor (VDR) polymorphisms.

30 min/day of moderate-intensity physical activity is suggested for preventing type 2 diabetes (T2D) The current recommendations exclusively rely on self-reports and rarely consider the genetic risk. We examined the prospective dose-response relationships between total/intensity-specific physical activity and incident T2D accounting for and stratified by different levels of genetic risk in the UK Biobank.

Lipoprotein(a) (Lp(a)) is a largely genetically determined biomarker for cardiovascular disease (CVD) Its potential interplay with family history (FHx) of CVD, a measure of both genetic and environmental exposures, remains unclear. We examined the associations of Lp( a) in terms of circulating concentration or polygenetic risk score (PRS), and FHx of Cvd with risk of incident heart failure (HF)

Early rhythm control reduces cardiovascular events in patients with recently diagnosed atrial fibrillation (AF) compared with usual care. How genetic predisposition to AF and stroke interacts with early rhythm-control therapy is not known.

The 16p11.2 and 22q11. 2 copy number variants (CNVs) are associated with neurobehavioral traits including ASD, schizophrenia, bipolar disorder, obesity, and intellectual disability. Identifying specific genes contributing to each disorder has been difficult, inspiring hypotheses of more complex models, such as multiple genes acting together.

Efforts to predict trait phenotypes based on functional MRI data from large cohorts have been hampered by low prediction accuracy and/or small effect sizes. We aim to replicate previous work and test multiple data manipulations that may improve prediction accuracy by addressing data pollution challenges.

Clonal hematopoiesis of indeterminate potential (CHIP) is frequent in aging. Risk factors that contribute to CHIP are poorly understood. Obesity induces a proinflammatory state and fatty bone marrow, which may influence CHIP-associated pathologies.

Study looked at 499 341 participants without VHD at baseline. Assessment of lifestyle included smoking, alcohol consumption, diet, activity, and sleep. Genetic susceptibility was separately measured by polygenic risk scores (PRSs) and family history of cardiovascular disease (CVD)

Mendelian randomization (MR) is an increasingly popular approach to estimating causal effects. Although the assumptions underlying MR cannot be verified, they imply certain constraints, the instrumental inequalities, which can be used to falsify the MR conditions. The instrumental inequalities are rarely applied in MR. We aimed to explore whether they could detect violations of MR conditions in case studies.

Metabolic syndrome has been linked to an increased risk of colorectal cancer (CRC) incidence and mortality. Whether adopting a healthy lifestyle could attenuate the risk of CRC conferred by metabolic syndrome remains unclear. The aim of the study is to investigate the individual and joint effects of modifiable healthy lifestyle and metabolic health status.

Genome-wide association studies (GWAS) have identified thousands of genetic variants associated with human traits or diseases. Much of the heritability of many traits is still unaccounted for. Multi-trait methods improve statistical power by integrating association evidence across multiple traits.

The SWIF(r) reliability score (SRS) reflects the trustworthiness of the classification of a specific instance. The concept of the reliability score has the potential to generalize to other machine learning methods. We explore these applications of the SRS using a range of biological datasets.

High-grade gliomas account for 60-75% of all adult glioma. The complexity of treatment, recovery and survivorship creates a need for novel monitoring approaches. Digital wearable tools could help us address unmet needs.

Mendelian randomization confirmed multiple risk factors for primary events of coronary artery disease (CAD) No such studies have been performed on recurrent major coronary events despite interesting insights derived from other designs. We examined the associations between genetically-influenced classical cardiovascular risk factors.

Genome-wide association studies have identified thousands of variants for disease risk. Of particular interest are admixed populations, usually defined as populations with recent ancestry from two or more continental sources. Admixed genomes contain segments of distinct ancestries that vary in composition across individuals in the population.

Study looked at associations of environmental and genetic factors with the risk of sporadic early-onset colorectal cancer (EOCRC) Study found 12 risk factors and three protective factors. No significant associations between the examined genetic variants and EOCRC risk.

Study aims to examine associations between midlife Life's Simple 7 (LS7) status, psychosocial health (social isolation and loneliness), and late-life multidimensional frailty indicators. We used cohort data from the UK Biobank. Frailty was assessed using physical frailty phenotype, hospital frailty risk score, and frailty index. A better LS7 score in midlife was associated with a reduced risk of physical, hospital and comprehensive frailty.

It remains unknown to what extent gene-gene interactions contribute to complex traits. Here, we introduce a new approach using predicted gene expression to perform exhaustive transcriptome-wide interaction studies (TWISs) for multiple traits.

Mendelian randomization analysis-identified HMGCR and PCSK9 genetic variants were used to predict the low-density lipoprotein (LDL) cholesterol-lowering effects of medications targeting related molecules. Summary-level MRs using an inverse variance weighted method and pleiotropy-robust methods were performed. Genetically predicted HMG-CoA reductase inhibition was associated with low eGFR.

Telomere length has been linked to various health outcomes. We conducted a phenome-wide Mendelian randomization study (MR-PheWAS) and a systematic review of MR studies. Of the 1 035 phenotypes tested, PheWas identified 29 and 78 associations of telomerelength GRS at a Bonferroni- and false discovery rate-corrected threshold.

Glaucoma is a progressive optic neuropathy and a leading cause of irreversible blindness. The etiology of this multifactorial disease is poorly understood. We aimed to identify plasma metabolites associated with the risk of developing POAG.

Aging has important effects on specific functional networks of the brain and leads to brain functional connectivity decline. No studies have addressed the effect of aging at the whole-brain level. The study was based on a large sample size of neuroimaging data including 6300 healthy adults aged between 49 and 73 years.

Mendelian randomization (MR) has emerged as a powerful approach to leverage genetic instruments to infer causality between pairs of traits in observational studies. Results of such studies are susceptible to biases owing to weak instruments, as well as the confounding effects of population stratification and horizontal pleiotropy. Here, we show that family data can be leveraged to design MR tests that are provably robust to confounding.

Primary open-angle glaucoma (POAG) is an optic neuropathy characterized by progressive degeneration of the optic nerve that leads to irreversible visual impairment. Multiple epidemiological studies suggest an association between POAG and major neurodegenerative disorders (Alzheimer's disease, amyotrophic lateral sclerosis, frontotemporal dementia, and Parkinson's disease) This study found a genetic overlap and causal relationship betweenPOAG and its related phenotypes.

Human same-sex sexual behavior (SSB) is heritable and leads to fewer offspring. It is puzzling why SSB-associated alleles have not been selectively purged. Having more sexual partners no longer predicts more offspring since the availability of oral contraceptives.

The current study was conducted to provide a general guidance for model specifications in polygenic risk score (PRS) analyses of the UK Biobank. We evaluated three continuous outcomes (BMI, smoking, drinking) and two binary outcomes (Major Depressive Disorder and educational attainment) We applied 3280 (656 per phenotype) different models including different sets of covariates.

A diverse set of factors influence cardiovascular diseases (CVDs), but a systematic investigation of the interplay between these determinants is largely missing from the literature. We leverage one of the most comprehensive biobanks worldwide, the UK Biobank, to investigate the contribution of different risk factor categories. The investigated categories include the history of medical events, behavioural factors, socioeconomic factors, environmental factors and measurements.

No studies have investigated such associations in heart failure (HF) Study aimed to explore the associations of the consumption of sugar-sweetened beverages (SSBs) with the risk of incident HF.

eGFR Cr underestimates risk of ischaemic stroke and major bleeding in women compared to eGFR Cys. The difference between measures is likely explained by non-GFR biology of creatinine and cystatin C.

High myopia (HM) is one of the leading causes of visual impairment and blindness worldwide. We report a whole-exome sequencing (WES) study in 9,613 HM cases and 9,606 controls of Han Chinese ancestry to pinpoint HM-associated risk variants.

Male gender was the highest-ranked risk factor, followed by elevated serum insulin-like growth factor 1 (IGF-1), lymphocyte count, and neutrophil/lymphocyte ratio. Factors aligned with the symptoms of frailty also ranked highly.

Study included 214244 participants of the UK Biobank who were initially free of CKD. During a median of 11.9 years of follow-up, 6583 incidents of chronic kidney disease were documented. Secondhand smoke exposure increased the risk of CKd (HR=1.09; 95% CI: 1.03-1.16, p)

In this study, the asymptotic distributions of the likelihood ratio test (LRT) and other test statistics are examined. The statistics are used to test an additive effect of the expected familial relatedness (FR) in a linear mixed model. The four test statistics were also applied to a data set from the UK Biobank.

Using UK Biobank data, we included around 0.29 million middle- to old-aged participants. Glucosamine supplementation was measured by questionnaire at baseline. Incident cases of dementia and Parkinson's disease were identified through linkage.

Genome-wide association studies have identified more than 200 genomic loci for breast cancer risk. Specific causal genes in most of these loci have not been identified. To identify candidate genes, we performed a GWAS analysis in a breast cancer dataset from UK Biobank.

Diffuse idiopathic skeletal hyperostosis (DISH) is a condition where adjacent vertebrae become fused through formation of osteophytes. The genetic and epidemiological etiology of this condition is not well understood. We implemented a machine learning algorithm to assess the prevalence and severity of the pathology in the UK Biobank Imaging cohort.

Study aimed to assess the relations between potato consumption and the risk of T2D. Potato consumption was evaluated using the 24-hour dietary questionnaire. Theoretically, replacing one serving/day of total potatoes with the same amount of non-starchy vegetables was related to a 12% (95% CI: 0.84-0.91) lower T1D risk.

Hypertension is a polygenic disease that affects over 1.2 billion adults aged 30-79 worldwide. It is a major risk factor for renal, cerebrovascular, and cardiovascular diseases. The heritability of hypertension is estimated to be high; nevertheless, our understanding of its underlying mechanisms remains scarce.

Human diseases are traditionally studied as singular, independent entities. We construct a disease representation as points in a continuous, high-dimensional space. We use time-stamped clinical records of over 151 million unique Americans.

Study aimed to investigate the association between an overall plant-based diet and the incidence of dementia or depression. Dementia and depression were evaluated using hospital inpatient records in UK Biobank.

Most existing deep learning based methods for vessel segmentation neglect two important aspects of retinal vessels. In this paper, we propose a robust orientation and context entangled network (OCE-Net), which can extract complex orientation andcontext information from blood vessels.

In this work, we investigate image registration in a variational framework and focus on regularization generality and solver efficiency. We first propose a model combining the state-of-the-art sum of absolute differences (SAD) and a new arbitrary order total variation regularization term. We then break down the resultant convex optimization into several point-wise, closed-form subproblems using a fast, over-relaxed alternating direction method of multipliers.

Cognitive decline significantly elevates the risk of diabetic vascular complications and is correlated with retinal and renal microcirculation damage. Cognitive screening tests are strongly recommended as routine tools for management of diabetes.

This study used cross-sectional UK Biobank data to estimate the influence of active and passive commuting modes and commuting distance on cardiovascular disease (CVD) -related biomarkers. The study sample comprised 208,893 UKBiobank baseline survey participants aged 40 to 69 who use various modes of transport to commute to work at least once a week.

A higher dietary diversity score (DDS) and a lower energy-adjusted dietary inflammatory index (E-DII) may be associated with lower risks of type 2 diabetes (T2D) and mortality. A total of 181,360 participants without all types of diabetes at baseline from the UK Biobank and 42,139 participants from the US NHANES were included. No evidence was observed of the interactive effects of DDS and E-D II on either all-cause mortality or the incidence and mortality of T2D.

Little is known about the combined relationship between night shifts and lifestyle risks with incident dementia or their potential interactions. A total of 276 059 participants were included in this study from the UK Biobank cohort. The combined impact was higher than the increase in the risks related to each single factor.

 MN is one of the most common causes of nephrotic syndrome worldwide. Its biological and environmental determinants are poorly understood in large-part due to it being a rare disease. This study aims to address this gap in understanding using the UK Biobank.

This paper aims to present the first Frequentist framework on signal region detection in high-resolution and high-order image regression problems. We propose nonconvex optimization problems for one-term and multi-term SKPDs and develop path-following algorithms. Effectiveness of SKPD is validated by real brain imaging data in the UK Biobank database.

Low hemoglobin and anemia are associated with cognitive impairment and Alzheimer's disease. Anemia was associated with a 56% higher risk of developing dementia. Hemoglobin and red blood cell distribution width were causally associated with AD.

Few studies have considered the effects of both sleep duration and efficiency on predicting the risks of mortality. The UK Biobank is a cohort study of over 500 000 individuals recruited between 2006 and 2010. The study included participants wearing wrist accelerometers for 7 consecutive days.

The interplay between host genetic factors, colonization of specific bacteria, production of short-chain fatty acids (SCFA), and intake of whole grains and fiber could alter the protective role of carbohydrates against colorectal cancer. We assessed intakes of types and sources of carbohydrates in 114,217 UK Biobank participants with detailed dietary data.

There is growing need to distinguish between sex and gender. While sex is assigned at birth, gender is socially constructed and may not correspond to one's assigned sex. In most research studies, sex or gender is assessed in isolation.

Sex-specific pan-cancer risk scores (PCRSs) are defined by the combination of body mass index, smoking, family history of cancers, and cancer-specific polygenic risk scores. We demonstrate the added value of PRSs in improving the predictive performance of the risk factors only model and project the positive and negative predictive values for two promising multicancer screening tests.

Atrial fibrillation (AF) is one of the major causes of ischaemic stroke. The impact of genetic factors on the risk of AF-related thromboembolic stroke has been largely unknown. Among them, the gasdermin D (GSDMD) gene was related to inflammation.

We developed a machine learning model to quantify cardiac fibrosis using cardiac MRI data from 41,505 UK Biobank participants. We identified 11 independent genomic loci, 9 of which were implicated in in vitro cardiac fibroblast activation.

 Theory predicts that biological processes of aging may contribute to poor mental health in late life. To test this hypothesis, we evaluated prospective associations between biological age and incident depression and anxiety in 424,299 UK Biobank participants.

Psychiatric disorders frequently co-occur and share common symptoms and genetic backgrounds. Previous research has used genome-wide association studies to identify the interrelationships among psychiatric disorders. In this study, we explored the network structure of the polygenic risk score (PRS) for 13 psychiatric disorders in a general population.

Chronic back pain (CBP) is a common debilitating condition with substantial societal impact. Few large-scale studies investigating this topic for CBP have been done. The results indicate a modest, if any, modification of genetic effects by examined risk factors in CBP.

Growing evidence suggests that red meat consumption is a risk factor for cardiovascular health. The metabolic mechanisms have not been fully understood. Unprocessed red meat and processed meat consumption was associated with higher IHD mortality overall and in men. Triglycerides and VLDL-related lipid metabolism may contribute to the sex-specific associations.

We perform targeted attack, a systematic computational unlinking of the network. We analyze its effects on global communication across the brain network through its giant cluster. We find that targeted attack procedures on increasing white matter tract lengths and densities are remarkably invariant to aging and disease.

Little cohort evidence is available on the effect of healthy behaviours and socioeconomic status (SES) on respiratory disease mortality. We included 372,845 participants from a UK biobank (2006-2021) SES was derived by latent class analysis. A healthy behaviours index was constructed. Participants were categorized into nine groups on the basis of combinations of them.

Medical imaging studies investigating COVID-19 to date have mostly been limited to small datasets and post-hoc analyses of severe cases. UK Biobank recruited recovered SARS-CoV-2 positive individuals and matched controls who were extensively imaged prior to the pandemic and underwent follow-up scanning.

Genome-wide association study (GWAS) summary data have become extremely useful in daily routine data analysis. A severe limitation with the current use of GWAS summary data is its exclusive restriction to only linear single nucleotide polymorphism (SNP)-trait association analyses. We propose a nonparametric method for large-scale imputation of the genetic component of the trait for the given genotypes.

Study used data from UK Biobank, included 316568 participants aged 37 to 73 years recruited from 22 centers between 2006 and 2010. Lower levels of TPA, MVPA, and VPA independently associated with elevated risk of all-cause and cancer mortality.

The cognitive reserve (CR) hypothesis is reinforced by negative moderating effects. Those with higher CR are less reliant on brain structure for cognitive function. Previous research has yielded inconsistent results. Study III showed age influenced CR proxies' moderating effect in hippocampal regions.

Sex differences in complex traits are suspected to be in part due to widespread gene-by-sex interactions (GxSex) Here, we infer the mixture of ways in which polygenic effects on physiological traits covary between males and females. We find that GxSex is pervasive but acts primarily through systematic sex differences.

Genome-wide association studies (GWAS) have significantly advanced our understanding of the genetic underpinnings of diseases. Case and control cohort definitions for a given disease can vary between different published studies. Two GWAS for the same disease using the UK Biobank data set might use different data sources.

Biological aging of human organ systems reflects the interplay of age, chronic disease, lifestyle and genetic risk. Using longitudinal brain imaging and physiological phenotypes from the UK Biobank, we establish normative models of biological age for three brain and seven body systems.

The ongoing release of large-scale sequencing data in the UK Biobank allows for the identification of associations between rare variants and complex traits. SAIGE-GENE+ is a valid approach to conducting set-based association tests for quantitative and binary traits.

There is widespread interest in identifying genetic variants that exhibit parent-of-origin effects. Traditional tests for POEs require family data to determine parental origins of transmitted alleles. We propose a method to improve discovery of POE variants in large-scale GWAS samples.

The goal of medical imaging is to be able to precisely detect patterns of disease specific to individual scans. Traditional methods, based on image registration, historically fail to detect variable features of disease. In this paper we develop a method for simultaneous classification and feature attribution.

Polygenic scores allow novel assessments of young children's abilities that are uncontaminated by parental investments. Family-based samples allow indirect tests of whether children're abilities are reinforced or compensated. We find evidence consistent with compensatory processes.

Cross-sectional analysis of UK Biobank participants without pre-existing coronary artery disease. Genetic risk factors PRSCAD and HeFH were most strongly associated with FHHD. A combined model of clinical and genetic risk factors explains only 36% of the likelihood of FH HD.

 Epistasis, or non-additive interaction between genes, exists across the genome but often goes undetected because of a lack of statistical power. We hypothesize that uncovering long-range interactions between loci with strong LD due to epistatic selection can elucidate genetic mechanisms underlying common diseases.

Risk for COVID-19 positivity and hospitalization due to diverse environmental and sociodemographic factors may change as the pandemic progresses. "participant having son and/or daughter in household" was associated with an increase in incidence from 20% to 32% between timepoints.

Machine learning (ML) has transformed neuroimaging research by enabling accurate predictions and feature extraction from large datasets. Despite the plethora of proposed ML models, there is no clear consensus on how to achieve better performance in brain age prediction for this population. We found that the predictive performance of brain age is more reliant on the image modalities used than the ML algorithms.

The association between sleep pattern and chronic kidney disease (CKD) incidence has not been addressed. We sought to investigate the association of multidimensional sleep pattern with CKD in consideration of genetic polymorphisms. We identified 167 SNPs that interacted with unhealthy sleep patterns and affected the risk of CKD.

A pipeline that extends the Advanced Normalization Tools (ANTs) framework was developed on 341 whole-body DXA scans of UK Biobank South Asian participants. A set of 10 measurements throughout the skeleton was automatically obtained via this process. Stature was then regressed on the automated femoral and tibia lengths and compared to published stature regressions.

Reti-CVD is a deep-learning-based cardiovascular disease (CVD) retinal biomarker. It was able to identify individuals with intermediate and high-risk for CVD in accordance with existing risk assessment tools.

Study used observational and genetic data from large consortia. Mendelian randomisation analysis identified a potentially adverse causal effect of higher systolic BP on cognitive function. Complementary MR and observational analyses identify brain structures associated with BP.

Study looked at 63,277 individuals in the UK Biobank with depressive symptoms and tryptophan intake. A modest protective effect of high dietary TLR against depression was found. NPBWR1 among serotonin genes and POLI in kynurenine pathway genes were significantly associated with depression in the low but not in the high TLR group.

Genome-wide association studies in chronic pain patients have identified hundreds of common pathogenic variants. With the advances in next-generation sequencing technologies, it is now feasible to conduct rarer variants studies in large-scale databases.

A rare group of individuals called "super-agers" thrive with their exceptional ability to maintain a healthy brain and normal cognitive function even in old age. Studying their traits, lifestyles, and environments may provide valuable insight.

There is evidence that cancer is partly caused by rare genetic variants that have not yet been identified. Using germline whole-exome sequencing data from the UK Biobank, we developed risk models for 10 cancer types. The meta-features did not improve the prediction accuracy of models based on known risk variants.

Short telomeres are associated with an increased risk of neurological and psychiatric disorders including dementia. The mechanism underlying this risk is unclear, and may involve brain structure and function. Longer telomere length was protective against certain related clinical manifestations.

Sex-specific associations between birth weight and the risk of chronic kidney disease (CKD) later in life remain controversial. Compared with normal birth weight (2.5-4.0 kg), low birth weight was associated with an 11% lower risk of CKD in men but not in women.

Accurate power and sample size estimation is crucial to the design and analysis of genetic association studies. When analyzing a binary trait via logistic regression, important covariates such as age and sex are typically included in the model. However, their effects are rarely properly considered in power or sample size computation during study planning.

Study looked at genetic risk of cardiovascular disease by age at type 2 diabetes (T2D) diagnosis. Individuals with earlier T2D diagnosis had higher CVD risk. Increased genetic risk was largely mitigated by a healthy lifestyle.

Each 10 beats per minute increase in RHR was linked with smaller ventricular structure, poorer left ventricular (LV) function and unhealthy pattern of LV remodeling. These trends are more pronounced among males. However, genetically-predicted RHR is not statistically related to heart failure.

Transcriptome-wide association studies (TWAS) have recently emerged as a popular tool to discover (putative) causal genes. In our motivating and target application, we'd like to identify causal genes for low-density lipoprotein cholesterol (LDL), which is crucial for developing new treatments.

A total of 26,354 participants from the UK Biobank study with available CVH metrics and qualified retinal imaging were included in the present analysis. CVH included 7 metrics (smoking, physical activity, diet, body mass index [BMI], total cholesterol, blood pressure [BP], blood glucose) These were summarized to classify the overall CVH as poor (0-7), intermediate (8-10) or ideal (11-14)

We multiply ascertained the BRCA1 pathogenic missense variant c.5207T > C; p.Val1736Ala (V1736A) in clinical investigation of breast and ovarian cancer families from Orkney in the Northern Isles of Scotland, UK. Oral history and birth, marriage and death registrations indicated genealogical linkage of the clinical cases to ancestors from the Isle of Westray. Twenty out of 2088 ORCADES research volunteers (~1%) carry V1736a, with a common haplotype around the variant. This allele frequency is ~480-fold higher than in UK Biobank participants.

Cases of lumbar spondylolisthesis, spinal stenosis, degenerative disc disease, and pseudarthrosis after spinal fusion were identified from the UK Biobank. Whole-genome regressions were used to test for genetic variants potentially implicated in the occurrence of each phenotype.

In the past, methods to subtype or biotype patients using brain imaging data have been developed. However, it is unclear whether and how these trained machine learning models can be successfully applied to population cohorts to study the genetic and lifestyle factors underpinning these subtypes. This work examines the generalisability of data-driven Alzheimer's disease (AD) progression models.

Introgressed Neanderthal variants make a significant contribution to trait variation (explaining 0.12% of trait variation on average) But the contribution of introgressed variants tends to be significantly depleted relative to modern human variants matched for allele frequency and linkage disequilibrium.

Identifying genotype-by-environment interaction (GEI) is challenging because the GEI analysis generally has low power. Large-scale consortium-based studies are ultimately needed to achieve adequate power for identifying GEI. We introduce Multi-Trait Analysis of Gene-Environment Interactions (MTAGEI) to test gene-environment interactions on multiple traits.

Human cortical expansion has occurred non-uniformly across the brain. We found 393 and 756 significant loci with and without adjusting for globals, respectively. Consideration of global measures is important in understanding the genetic variants underlying cortical morphology.

Genome-wide association studies (GWASs) identify genomic loci associated with complex traits. It remains a challenge to identify the genes affected by causal genetic variants in these loci. Here, we show how to combine solutions to these problems into a unified mathematical framework.

The 10-year risk of atrial fibrillation (AF) considering risk factor burden and genetic predisposition is unknown. A total of 348,904 genetically unrelated participants without AF at baseline from the UK were categorized into three groups. Optimal, borderline, or elevated risk factors were determined by body mass index, blood pressure, diabetes mellitus, alcohol consumption, smoking status and history of myocardial infarction or heart failure.

TV viewing in the elderly and in children is associated with subsequent greater decline of various cognitive functions including verbal working memory. Results of its association with subsequent risk of dementia were divided.

Obesity is a risk factor for both the development of and mortality from breast cancer in postmenopausal but not in premenopausal women. Which part of the fat mass is associated with risk remains unclear. After menopause, there was an increase in fat mass in different body segments (arms, legs, and trunk)

 ERAP2 is an aminopeptidase involved in immunological antigen presentation. Genotype data in human samples from before and after the Black Death, an epidemic due to Yersinia pestis, have marked changes in allele frequency of the single-nucleotide polymorphism (SNP) rs2549794. The T allele of this SNP showed evidence of association with respiratory infection and Crohn disease.

This study examined the association between developmental dysplasia of the hip and disease-associated loci in a Japanese cohort. A genome-wide association study (GWAS) of 238 Japanese patients with DDH and 2044 healthy individuals was performed. As a replicate, GWAS was also conducted on the UK Biobank data with 3315 cases and matched 74,038 controls.

Breastfeeding in infancy is associated with a lower risk of mortality among children, but the impact on mortality in middle and late adulthood remains unknown. We included 383,627 participants aged 40-73 from the UK Biobank (2006-2010) and followed up until 2021.

Evidence suggests potential links between circadian rhythm and atrial fibrillation (AF) Whether circadian disruption can predict the onset of AF in the general population remains largely unknown. We aim to investigate the association of accelerometer-measured circadian rest-activity rhythm (CRAR) with the risk of AF.

A link between neurodegenerative diseases and infections has been previously reported. However, it is not clear to what extent such link is caused by confounding factors. Further, studies on the impact of infections on mortality risk are rare. We analysed two data sets with different characteristics.

The classification of at-risk women using this new model highlights the opportunity to improve risk stratification and implement existing clinical risk-reduction interventions.

Atrial fibrillation (AF) is the most common arrhythmia and typically occurs in elderly patients with other cardiovascular and extracardiac diseases. Up to 15% of AF develops without any related risk factors. Recently, the role of genetic factors has been highlighted in this form of AF.

The role of systemic inflammation in promoting cardiovascular diseases has attracted attention, but its correlation with various arrhythmias remains to be clarified. We aimed to comprehensively assess the association between various indicators of. systemic inflammation and atrial fibrillation/flutter (AF), ventricular arrhythmia (VA), and bradyarrhythmi in the UK Biobank cohort. VA showed the strongest association with systemic inflammation indicators, and it was followed sequentially by AF and Bradyarr hythmia.

Mendelian randomization using GWAS summary statistics has become a popular method to infer causal relationships across complex diseases. The widespread pleiotropy observed in GWAS has made the selection of valid instrumental variables problematic. We propose a ststistical framework, MRCI, to estimate reciprocal causation between two phenotypes simultaneously.

The role of nutritional status and the risk of contracting and/or experiencing adverse outcomes from severe acute respiratory syndrome coronavirus 2 (SARS-CoV-2) infection are unclear. Preliminary studies suggest that higher n-3 PUFA intakes are protective.

There is strong evidence showing that joint analysis of multiple phenotypes in genome-wide association studies (GWAS) can increase statistical power. We previously developed the Clustering Linear Combination (CLC) method and a computationally efficient CLC method. We develop a novel method called sCLC for association studies of multiple Phenotypes and a genetic variant.

Photoreceptor cells (PRCs) are the light-detecting cells of the retina. Such cells can be non-invasively imaged using optical coherence tomography (OCT) We present the largest genome-wide association study of PRC morphology to date.

 Transcriptome-wide association studies (TWASs) aim to detect associations between genetically predicted gene expression and complex diseases or traits. Most current TWAS methods analyze one gene at a time, ignoring the correlations between multiple genes. Here, we propose a novel method, namely a COx proportional hazards model for NEtwork regression in TWAS.

Direct work with the public and exposure to disease/infections were first time demonstrated to be risk factors for both anxiety and depression. occupations involving more physical activities and dealing with unpleasant/physically aggressive people. Protective factors for anxiety only: Coordinating/leading, fluency of ideas, originality, problem sensitivity, decision latitude, and time pressure.

Relationships between insulin-like growth factor 1 (IGF-1) levels and cardiovascular disease (CVD) in the general population remain unclear. UK Biobank documented 35 803 incident CVD cases, including 4231 from CVD-related death, 27 051 from CHD, 10 014 from MI, 7661 from HF, and 6802 from stroke.

There is growing recognition that CP conditions frequently coexist at multiple body sites and may bring more burdens on patients' overall health. Whether and how multisite CP (MCP) contributes to an increased risk of dementia is largely unclear. In the current study, utilizing the UK Biobank cohort, we first investigated dementia risk in individuals (n = 354,943) with different numbers of coexisting CP sites.

Very high levels of high-density lipoprotein cholesterol (HDL-C) have been paradoxically linked to increased mortality risk. Study aimed to examine associations of HDL-C and varied sizes of the HDL particle with mortality risk stratified by hypertension.

Recent work in imaging genetics suggests high levels of genetic overlap within cortical regions for cortical thickness (CT) and surface area (SA) We model this multivariate system of genetic relationships by applying Genomic Structural Equation Modeling. We identify specific categories of genes that are disproportionately associated with pleiotropy across specific subclusters of brain regions.

There is growing interest in the role of timing of daily behaviors in improving health. Little is known about the optimal timing of physical activity to maximize health benefits. Moderate-to-vigorous intensity physical activity at any time of day is associated with lower risks for all-cause, cardiovascular disease, and cancer mortality.

Calcium plays a critical role in various physiological activities. However, the association between circulating calcium concentrations and mortality in a general healthy population remains undetermined. We examined the association of serum calcium concentrations with all-cause and cause-specific mortality using Cox proportional hazard and restricted cubic spline models.

Metabolic illnesses (MET) are detrimental to brain integrity and are common comorbidities in patients with mental illnesses, including major depressive disorder (MDD) We quantified effects of MET on standard regional brain morphometric measures from 3D brain MRI as well as diffusion MRI in a large sample of UK BioBank participants. Subjects with MET showed a higher effect size for RVI-MET than for any of the individual brain measures.

Lifestyle factors are related to health and brain function and structure, but the brain systems involved are incompletely understood. Higher combined lifestyle risk scores were associated with lower functional connectivity across the whole brain, but especially of three brain systems. Low mobile phone use, perhaps indicative of poor social communication channels, was associated with low functional connectivity.

White matter tracts form the structural basis of large-scale brain networks. We applied brain-wide tractography to diffusion images from 30,810 adults (U.K. Biobank) We found significant heritability for 90 node-level and 851 edge-level network connectivity measures.

Age-related (AR) hearing loss (HL) is a prevalent sensory deficit in the elderly population. Several studies showed that common variants increase ARHL susceptibility. Here, we demonstrate that rare-variants play a crucial role in ARHL etiology.

Study looked at the impact of genetic and socioeconomic factors on risk of type 2 diabetes (T2D) and obesity. Favorable area-level socioeconomic status was associated with an almost 50% lower T2D prevalence in those with high genetic risk.

Among 239,436 women (40-69 years) enrolled in the UK Biobank cohort who had no cancer history at baseline, we identified 35 self-reported chronic diseases at baseline. In total, 58.4% of women had at least one morbidity, and the prevalence of multi-morbidity was 25.8%. During a median 7-year follow-up, there was no association between breast cancer risk and either the number of morbidities or the identified clinically relevant morbidity patterns.

There is a paucity of data on the association between respiratory function and atrial fibrillation (AF) This study aimed to assess the relationship between forced expiratory volume (FEV1), forced vital capacity (FVC), and FEV1/FVC and AF.

Dyslipidemia is closely associated with metabolic syndrome, a known risk factor for colorectal cancer. Most previous studies did not consider cholesterol-lowering medication use at the time of lipid measurements, which could bias findings. We analyzed data from 384,862 UK Biobank participants.

Intracerebral hemorrhage (ICH) is the most devastating adverse outcome for patients on anticoagulants. We investigated whether integration of a genetic risk score into an existing risk factor-based CRS could improve risk stratification for ICH.

Study included 401,189 participants in the UK Biobank between 2006 and 2010. During a median follow-up of 12.4 years, a total of 43,273 incident cancer cases were documented. We found that exposure to greenspace at a 1000 m buffer was significantly associated with prostate cancer.

Cross-ancestry genetic correlation is an important parameter to understand the genetic relationship between two ancestry groups. Existing methods cannot properly account for ancestry-specific genetic architecture, which is diverse across ancestries. Here, we present a method to construct a genomic relationship matrix (GRM) that can correctly account for the relationship. The proposed method is further applied to anthropometric and other complex traits from the UK Biobank.

Older men on an average have lower testosterone concentrations, compared with younger men, and more age-related comorbidities. Shorter telomeres are a marker for biological age. We tested the hypothesis that testosterone concentrations are associated with leucocyte telomere length.

Middle-aged and older Europeans not diagnosed with dementia within two years of baseline were followed up and their data were analysed until 2021. The association between the nutrient quintiles measured by the web-based 24 h dietary and the risk of developing dementia was examined using a Cox proportional hazard model. A greater risk of dementia was associated with (a) no alcohol intake, (b) higher intake of total sugars and carbohydrates, (c) highest or lowest fat intake, and (d) highest protein intake.

 Proxy phenotypes based on parental diagnosis status have been used in previous studies to identify common variants associated with Alzheimer's disease. As of yet, proxy phenotypes have not been used to identify genes associated with the disease through rare variants. We show that a proxy Alzheimerâ€™s disease/dementia phenotype can capture known risk genes through rare variant aggregation.

The Korean National Health Insurance Service-Health Screening Study and the UK Biobank were evaluated. 2346 and 5314 incident AF events were recorded during the mean follow-up of 7.4 and 11.8 years. The risk of incident AF was increased by the combination of high-normal BP and IFG.

Using previously approved medications for new indications can expedite the lengthy and expensive drug development process. We describe a bioinformatics pipeline that integrates genomics and proteomics platforms to identify already-approved drugs that might be useful to treat diabetic retinopathy.

Previous research has linked having an eveningness chronotype with a higher tolerance for night shift work. On a sample of 53 211 workers in the UK Biobank (2006-2018), we focus on the effects of nightshift work on sleep duration. We find that eveningness has a strong protective effect on night workers. This protective effect is pronounced for those working the longest hours. Consistent patterns are observed with an actigraphy-derived measure of sleepduration.

DeepPheWAS is an R package for phenome-wide association studies. It creates clinically curated composite phenotypes and integrates quantitative phenotypes from primary care data. Tools are provided for efficient analysis of association with any genetic input.

COPCs are believed to share common etiological mechanisms involving central sensitization. This study employed a genome-wide polygenic risk score approach to evaluate genetic influences on 8 common COPCs. A centralized pain score (CPS) was calculated for 55,340 individuals.

Brain age is considered as an important biomarker for detecting aging-related diseases such as Alzheimer's Disease (AD) Magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) have been widely investigated with deep neural networks for brain age estimation. Most existing methods cannot make full use of multimodal MRIs due to the difference in data structure.

Cardiovascular disease (CVD), the leading cause of death globally, is associated with complicated underlying risk factors. We develop an artificial intelligence model to identify CVD using multimodal data, including clinical risk factors and fundus photographs from the Samsung Medical Center and UK Biobank.

Loss-of-Function (LoF) variants in human genes are important due to their impact on clinical phenotypes and frequent occurrence in the genomes of healthy individuals. Current approaches predict high-confidence LoF variants without identifying the specific genes or the number of copies they affect.

Adverse outcome pathways provide a powerful tool for understanding the biological signaling cascades that lead to disease outcomes following toxicity. Here we use the AOP framework combined with artificial intelligence methods to gain novel insights into genetic mechanisms that underlie toxicity-mediated adverse health outcomes. We focus on liver cancer as a case study with diverse underlying mechanisms that are clinically significant.

Alzheimer's disease and related dementias is a major public health burden-compounding over upcoming years due to longevity. Recently, clinical evidence hinted at the experience of social isolation in expediting dementia onset.

Patients with brain arteriovenous malformation (AVM) are at risk of intracranial hemorrhage (ICH) The epsilon 2 and 4 alleles within the APOE gene are well-described genetic risk factors for spontaneous, non-traumatic intraparenchymal hemorrhages.

Metabolic biomarker data quantified by nuclear magnetic resonance (NMR) spectroscopy in approximately 121,000 UK Biobank participants has recently been released as a community resource. Here we identify and characterise additional sources of unwanted technical variation influencing individual biomarkers. We developed a procedure for removing this unwantedtechnical variation, and demonstrate that it increases signal for genetic and epidemiological studies.

Sleep disturbances are increasingly recognized as adversely affecting brain health in aging. Our aim was to investigate interrelations between sleep-related symptoms, obesity, cardiometabolic disorders, brain structure and cognitive decline in a population-based aging sample.

A greater risk of cardiovascular disease is associated with low educational attainment and high adiposity. We investigated the effect of adiposity (body mass index [BMI] and waist-to-hip ratio adjusted for BMI [WHRadjBMI]) on incident CVD among individuals with varying education levels.

Sepsis is characterised by dysregulated, life-threatening immune responses. Sepsis is thought to be driven by cytokines such as interleukin 6 (IL-6) Genetic variants in IL6R known to down-regulate IL-6 signalling are associated with improved Coronavirus Disease 2019 (COVID-19) outcomes. We hypothesised that blockade of IL4R could also improve outcomes in sepsis. We performed a Mendelian randomisation (MR) analysis using single nucleotide polymorphisms (SNPs) in and nearIL6R.

Study aimed to compare the biomarker profile of pre-frail and frail adults in the UK Biobank cohort by sex. Lower concentrations of apoA1, total, LDL, and HDL cholesterol, albumin, eGFRcys, vitamin D, total bilirubin, apoB, and testosterone were identified. However, some of the associations differed by sex, such as rheumatoid factor and urate.

Penalized quasi-likelihood estimation allows to scale regularized mixed models on high-dimensional binary trait GWAS. We show through simulations that when the dimensionality of the relatedness matrix is high, penalized LMM and logistic regression with PC adjustment fail to select important predictors, and have inferior prediction accuracy.

Delta age is a biomarker of brain aging that captures differences between the chronological age and the predicted biological brain age. Using multimodal data of brain MRI, genomics, and blood-based biomarkers and metabolomics in UK Biobank, this study investigates an explainable and causal basis of high delta age.

Sex hormone-binding globulin (SHBG) levels in clinical risk stratification and intervention for coronary heart disease (CHD) remains uncertain. We aimed to examine whether circulating levels of SHBG are predictive of CHD risk in men and women. We investigated the association between SHBG and the risk of incident CHD in 128 322 men and 135 103 women.

Phenotypic associations have been reported between blood cell traits (BCTs) and a range of neurological and psychiatric disorders (NPDs) It remains unclear whether these associations have a genetic basis and, if so, to what extent genetic correlations reflect causality. We report genetic correlations and Mendelian randomization analyses between 11 NPDs and 29 BCTs.

Survival rates from colorectal cancer (CRC) are drastically higher if the disease is detected and treated earlier. Current screening guidelines involve stool-based tests and colonoscopies, whose acceptability and uptake remains low. Routinely collected blood-based biomarkers may offer a low-cost alternative or aid for detecting CRC.

Estimation of heritability is crucial for quantifying and understanding complex trait genetic architecture. Many existing approaches for heritability estimation ignore the presence of indirect genetic effects. In this work, we introduce a statistical framework to decompose heritability and genetic covariance.

In 491 606 UK Biobank participants, greater obesity was linked to significantly greater risk of incident ischaemic heart disease, atrial fibrillation (AF), heart failure (HF), all-cause mortality, and cardiovascular disease (CVD) mortality. Individuals with overweight BMI but normal WHR had weaker disease associations.

In this study we examine the instrument selection strategies currently used throughout the type 2 diabetes and HbA1c Mendelian randomization (MR) literature. We then argue for a more integrated and thorough approach, providing a framework to do this.

Previous studies have found no causal effects of education on mental health in the UK. We re-examine the relationship between education and mental health by taking a different approach. We find that higher educational attainment is associated with better adult mental health.

Cancer continues to be a major source of mortality and morbidity throughout the world. Traditional methods of detection and diagnosis such as biopsy and imaging, tend to be expensive and have risks of complications. As data becomes more abundant and machine learning continues advancing, it is natural to ask how they can help solve some of these problems.

Viral exposures significantly associated with increased risk of neurodegenerative disease. Largest effect association was between viral encephalitis exposure and Alzheimer's disease. Influenza with pneumonia was significantly associated. with five of the six neurodegnerative diseases studied. Some of these exposures were associated with an increased risk up to 15 years later.

Loss or absence of hearing is common at both extremes of human lifespan. There is increasing evidence that their genetic basis is at least partially overlapping. Both common and rare variants in genes associated with monogenic forms of hearing loss also contribute to the more polygenic basis of age-related hearing loss.

The association between biological age and lung cancer risk remains controversial. We conducted a prospective analysis in the UK Biobank study and two-sample Mendelian randomization analysis to investigate this association. PhenoAgeAccel was positively associated with the risk of overall and histological subtypes of lung cancer.

BMI-independent variation in visceral (VAT), abdominal subcutaneous (ASAT), and gluteofemoral (GFAT) fat depots in 40,032 individuals of the UK Biobank with body MRI. VATadjBMI associated with increased risk of type 2 diabetes and coronary artery disease. ASATadjB MI is largely neutral, and GFATadj BMI is associated with reduced risk. These results clarify the cardiometabolic impact of BMI-independent differences in body fat distribution.

Genome-wide association studies (GWASs) have been performed to identify host genetic factors for a range of phenotypes, including for infectious diseases. The use of population-based common control subjects from biobanks and extensive consortia is a valuable resource to increase sample sizes in the identification of associated loci with minimal additional expense.

 Electrocardiogram analysis methods using deep neural networks are becoming more efficient and accurate than traditional machine learning methods. The study of long-term ischemic heart disease prediction based on exercise electrocardiograms is still limited. The proposed model performance is better than the traditional expert feature based methods.

Pulmonary function is an indicator of well-being, and pulmonary pathologies are the third major cause of death worldwide. We analysed the UK Biobank genome-wide association summary statistics of pulmonary function for Europeans and individuals of recent African descent to identify variants associated with the trait in the two ancestries. Remarkably, we find no shared variants among Africans and Europeans.

Major depressive disorder (MDD) is associated with structural and functional brain abnormalities. This work compares the gray matter volume and resting-state functional measures in a Chinese sample of 848 MDD patients and 749 healthy controls. It found that transcriptional correlates of brain structure and function show opposite relations with gene dysregulation in postmortem cortical tissue.

Study aimed to compare the cardiovascular risk among vegetarian diets that meet existing health guidelines, those that do not, and diets that include red meat. 391,124 participants (55.5% women) from the UK Biobank prospective population-based study were included.

It has been 15 years since the advent of the genome-wide association study (GWAS) era. We predict that the emergence of large-scale biobanks will continue to expand to more diverse populations. Whole-genome sequencing will further improve our ability to investigate the causes and consequences of human genetic variation.

TREM2 is a membrane protein involved in neurodegenerative diseases and cancer. TREM2 knockout mice suffer from metabolic symptoms. We show a significant correlation between T REM2 expression levels and BMI in adipose tissues in samples from the GTEx database. This association was evident for males but not for females.

Study included 214,670 men and 214, 670 women matched by age at baseline from the UK Biobank. Baseline data were collected between 2006 and 2010, and incident dementia was ascertained using hospital inpatient or death records until January 2021. Mediation analysis was tested for 133 individual factors.

The Charlson comorbidity index (CCI) is widely used to measure multimorbidities. High waist-hip ratio (WHR) increases the risk of CCI in both males and females. Socio-economic factors, such as income and TDI, are associated with CCI.

The joint associations across genetic risk, modifiable lifestyle factors, and inflammatory bowel disease (IBD) remains unclear. During the 12-year follow-up, 707 cases with CD and 1576 cases with UC were diagnosed in the UK Biobank cohort. Adherence to a favorable lifestyle was associated with a nearly 50% lower risk of CD and UC among participants at a high genetic risk.

The predicted age difference (PAD) between an individual's predicted brain age and chronological age has been commonly viewed as a meaningful phenotype relating to aging and brain diseases. The systematic bias appears in the PAD achieved using machine learning methods.

Research-ready data increase scientific opportunity and rigour by integrating the data environment. A standard data model (C-Surv) optimised for data discovery, was developed. The model uses a four-tier nested structure based on 18 data themes selected according to user behaviour or technology.

29 164 participants in the UK Biobank who had at least one follow-up assessment and were free of IHD were included. We constructed a weighted unhealthy lifestyle score though summing five lifestyle factors. The hazard ratio of incident IHD associated with per unit increase in unhealthy lifestyle trajectory was 1.08 [95% confidence interval (CI): 0.99-1.17].

 Transcriptome-wide association studies (TWAS) have been increasingly applied to identify (putative) causal genes for complex traits and diseases. TWAS can be regarded as a two-sample two-stage least squares method for instrumental variable (IV) regression for causal inference.

Metabolic dysfunction and obesity commonly coexist with both alcoholic and nonalcoholic fatty liver disease. The association of AFLD and NAFLD with incident diseases in individuals with different metabolic phenotypes is unclear. UK Biobank study participants were screened for the presence of fatty liver at baseline.

Having children is likely associated with better cognitive function for fathers in all five domains. Mothers show worse cognitive function in some domains than childless women. The findings support previous work done on how life course contexts may link to the risk of dementia or cognitive impairment.

Evidence is limited regarding the associations of different dietary patterns with cardiovascular disease (CVD) risk among the population with diabetes. We prospectively followed 22 473 diabetic patients from the UK Biobank at the baseline. A higher healthy diet score was negatively associated with CVD, CHD, and stroke incidence.

Adverse childhood experiences may include psychological, physical, or sexual abuse; neglect; or socioeconomic factors. These experiences are linked with an increase in poor health behavior such as smoking and alcohol consumption. They may also influence epigenetic changes and metabolic changes.

Insulin-like growth factor (IGF)-1 plays an important role in Alzheimer's disease (AD) pathogenesis and increases disease risk. Previous research examining IGF-1 levels and brain neural network activity is mixed. The present study investigated the relationship between IGF- 1 levels and 21 neural networks, as measured by fMRI.

Underrepresentation of minority and disadvantaged groups has limited the use of biobank data for developing disease risk prediction models. This study proposes a transfer learning framework based on random forest models (TransRF) TransRF can incorporate models trained in a source population to improve the prediction performance in a target underrepresented population with limited sample size.

Polygenic risk scores (PRS) do not generalize across groups differing in ancestry or sample characteristics e.g., age. Quantifying performance of PRS across different groups of study participants using genome-wide association study (GWAS) summary statistics from multiple ancestry groups and sample sizes may clarify which factors are limiting PRS transferability.

Polygenic risk scores (PRS) are increasingly used to estimate the personal risk of a trait based on genetics. Most genomic cohorts are of European populations, with a strong under-representation of non-European groups. Given that PRS poorly transport across racial groups, this has the potential to exacerbate health disparities.

Polygenic risk score (PRS) has emerged as a standard approach for identifying high-risk individuals. LDpred2 outperformed the other standalone tools, whereas PRS-CS, lassosum and DBSLMM showed comparable performance. Ensemble models are generally the best choice by integrating various statistical methods.

Screening history was associated with lower CRC incidence and mortality risk. Participants benefited more substantially from screenings for CRC mortality than for CRC incidence risk. Findings emphasize the importance of CRC screening and identifying environmental factors to reduce risk.

Genetic predisposition to higher docosahexaenoic acid (DHA) was associated with cholelithiasis and cholecystitis. Higher genetically predicted levels of DHA (0.83, 0.73 to 0.95) and omega-3 were found to have a protective effect on obesity. The findings do not support the supplementation of unsaturated fatty acids for cardiovascular disease prevention.

Tinnitus is a prevalent health condition often accompanied by psychiatric comorbidities. Recent genome-wide association studies highlighted a polygenic nature of tinnitus susceptibility. We present a GWAS using the UK Biobank to investigate the genetic processes linked to the condition.

Polygenic risk score (PRS) analyses are now routinely applied across biomedical research. As PRS studies grow in size, there is an increased risk of sample overlap between the genome-wide association study (GWAS) and the "target sample"

Proton pump inhibitors (PPIs) are widely used drugs for gastric acid-related diseases and may affect the gut microbiome. We aimed to evaluate the associations of PPI use with risks of cardiovascular disease (CVD) and all-cause mortality in patients with type 2 diabetes (T2D) We documented 2971 CAD, 1827 MI, 1192 HF, and 738 stroke cases and 2297 total deaths.

 Understanding comorbidity is essential for disease prevention, treatment and prognosis. In particular, insight into which pairs of diseases are likely or unlikely to co-occur may help elucidate the potential relationships between complex diseases. Here, we introduce the use of an inter-disease interactivity network to discover/prioritizeComorbidities. We determine disease associations by accounting for the direction of effects of genetic components.

Lifestyle management is a fundamental aspect of diabetes care to prevent cardiovascular disease (CVD) However, the underlying metabolic mechanism is not well established. We aimed to identify metabolites associated with different lifestyle factors, and estimate their mediating roles.

Vitamin D-grip strength relationship is equivocal. UK Biobank participants, aged 37-73 years, with valid data on Vitamin D status and maximum grip strength were included (N = 368,890). We examined sex-specific cross-sectional associations between 25(OH)D and grip strength.

The underlying mechanisms of atrial fibrillation (AF) are largely unknown. Inflammation may underlie atrial remodelling. Autoimmune diseases, related to increased systemic inflammation, may be associated with new-onset AF.

Network-based regression approach has been developed to incorporate a biological genetic network. We use a linear combination of genotypes at SNPs or methylation values at CpG sites in a gene. We regularize them to perform gene selection based on the biological network.

There is a multitude of pathological conditions that affect human health, yet we currently lack a predictive model for most diseases. We leveraged clinical biomarker data and long-term disease outcomes in UK Biobank to build prognostic multivariate survival models for over 200 most common diseases.

Few studies have examined the neuroanatomical measures mediating environmental and genetic effects on intelligence. We investigated the brain volumes, cortical mean thicknesses, and cortical surface areas mediating the effects of the g-factor polygenic score (gPGS) and childhood adversity. Only a few regions predicted intelligence and were included in the mediation analyses.

Among 413,109 middle- and old-aged adults without cancer or CVD, all participants reported the frequency of adding salt at the table at baseline. During a median follow-up of 12 years, there were 37,091 incident CVD cases and 21,293 all-cause deaths. After adjustment for demographic, lifestyle, and cardiometabolic risk factors, the multivariable-adjusted hazard ratios (HRs) were 1.21 (95% confidence interval [CI]: 1.16-1.26) for CVD.

Red meat consumption has been found to closely related to cardiometabolic health, with sex disparity. However, the specific metabolic factors corresponding to red meat consumption in men and women have not been examined previously. We analyzed the sex-specific associations of meat consumption, with 167 metabolites using multivariable regression.

Circadian rhythm disruption (CRD) is a shared characteristic of various brain disorders. Disruption of circadian rhythm might be a risk factor for brain disorder incidents. From 7-day accelerometry data of 72,242 participants in UK Biobank we derived a circadian relative amplitude variable. Individuals with reduced relative amplitude had increasing risk of all-cause dementia.

A total of 495,942 participants from UK Biobank who completed a questionnaire on habitual glucosamine use were included at baseline. A total of 6831 dementia events were recorded during a median follow-up of 11 years. In fully adjusted models, habitual use was associated with a significantly lower risk of dementia (HR = 0.87, 95% CI: 0.82-0.93)

Medical imaging provides insights into the subclinical changes that precede serious diseases such as heart disease and dementia. Most imaging research either describes a single organ system or draws on clinical cohorts with small sample sizes. In this study, we use state-of-the-art multi-organ magnetic resonance imaging phenotypes to investigate cross-sectional relationships across the heart-brain-liver axis.

Accelerated ageing is associated with increased COVID-19 severity. The mechanisms at work here are likely immunosenescence and inflamaging. This association indicates that anti-ageing treatment may improve CO VID-19 outcome. Results within ethnic groups and that of telomere length were inconclusive.

Traditional approaches in studying the genetics of complex traits have focused on identifying specific genetic variants. Here, we evaluated whether traits could be influenced by the collective effects of variants across the entire protein coding-region of the genome or the entire genome.

Nonalcoholic fatty liver disease is common and highly heritable. Genetic studies of hepatic fat have not sufficiently addressed non-European and rare variants. In a medical biobank, we quantitate hepaticfat from clinical computed tomography (CT) scans via deep learning.

Basal cell carcinoma and squamous cell carcinomas are the most common skin cancers. They have genetic overlap with melanoma, pigmentation traits, autoimmune diseases, and blood biochemistry biomarkers. In this multi-trait genetic analysis of over 300,000 participants from Europe, Australia and the United States, we reveal 78 risk loci.

GeoSPM-based on differential geometry and random field theory. We evaluate GeoSPM across an extensive array of synthetic simulations. We demonstrate its application on large-scale data from UK Biobank.

People with type 2 diabetes from the UK Biobank and Kuwaiti cohorts were included in this cross-sectional study. Self-reported sleep, physical activity, and muscle strength were compared between the cohorts. Results: Physical activity levels (-937 (-1,097, -851) Met-min/week and grip strength (3.2 (-3.58, -2.82) kg) were lower in the Kuwaiti cohort.

There was variation in frequency of APOE alleles across ethnic groups. Per standard deviation (SD) increase in z-GRS including APOE, the odds ratio (OR) for dementia was 1.73 (95%CI 1.69-1.77)

In the recent biobank era of genetics, the problem of identical-by-descent (IBD) segment detection received renewed interest. While a new generation of efficient methods for IBD segment detection becomes available, direct comparison of these methods is difficult. We developed a comprehensive and completely open-source evaluation of the power, accuracy, and resource consumption of these IBD segments.

In an increasingly older adult population, understanding the inter-relationship between three age related conditions is important. This study aims to determine the overlap between malnutrition, frailty and sarcopenia by measuring estimates of prevalence for each individual condition.

Comorbidity among psychiatric disorders is mirrored by non-zero, positive genetic correlations from large-scale genetic studies6-10. We conducted cross-trait meta-analysis on 12 psychiatric disorders to identify pleiotropic SNPs. The meta-analytic signal was driven by schizophrenia, hampering interpretation and joint biological characterization.

Prospective cohort study included 484,268 participants from the UK Biobank without glaucoma at enrollment. Incident POAG events were recorded through assessment visits, hospital inpatient admissions, and primary care data. Higher SBP and PP were associated with an increased risk of incident POAG.

Polygenic risk scores (PRSs) are a promising approach to accurately predict an individual's risk of developing disease. The area under the receiver operating characteristic curve (AUC) of PRSs in their population are often only reported for models that are adjusted for age and sex.

Sedentary behavior time was significantly associated with a higher risk of coronary heart disease. Replacing sedentary behavior with various daily-life activities or structured exercise is associated with significant reductions in CHD risk. Sedentary behavior to strenuous sports reallocations showed the largest benefit.

Polygenic risk score (PRS) has demonstrated its great utility in biomedical research through identifying high-risk individuals for different diseases. However, the broader application of PRS to the general population is hindered by the limited transferability ofPRS developed in Europeans to non-European populations. We develop a statistical method called SDPRX that can effectively integrate genome wide association study summary statistics from different populations.

A total of 80,169 fundus images from 46,969 participants in the UK Biobank cohort met the image quality standard. Stroke events were determined by data linkage to hospital records on admissions and diagnoses, and national death registers. Each one-year increase in the retinal age gap was associated with a 4% increase in stroke.

Model-driven framework to leverage human genome-scale metabolic networks to define how genetic variants affect biochemical reaction fluxes across major human tissues. We build personalised organ-specific metabolic flux models for 524,615 individuals.

The positional Burrows-Wheeler transform has led to tremendous strides in haplotype matching on biobank-scale data. To enable fast query searches, the full-sized panel and PBWT data structures must be kept in memory. We propose a space-efficient variation of PBWT named Syllable-PBWT.

Being frail was associated with 2.68 times, 3.27 times, and 3.31 times higher risk of total respiratory diseases mortality. Adherence to a healthy lifestyle represents a potentially modifiable target for improving the harmful impact of frailty.

Previous studies have reported that maternal smoking during pregnancy and breastfeeding may affect the occurrence of hypertension. The aim of this study was to investigate the relationships among maternal smoking and breastfeeding with adult-onset hypertension and the modified impact of offspring genetic susceptibility.

Psychotropics have been associated with a lower risk of SARS-CoV-2 infection and COVID-19-related deaths. Among 168,173 participants who underwent testing for Sars-Cov-2 RNA, 30,577 (18.2%) were positive, and 14,284 (8.5%) participants used psychotropics.

Study looked at 79,161 adult participants in the UK Biobank who wore an actiwatch for 1 week. Time of sleep offset was found to be on average 36 min later on weekends than on weekdays. Younger age, more socioeconomic disadvantage, currently being in employment, being a smoker, being male and later chronotype were associated with greater differences in sleep offset.

Osteoarthritis often progresses to the end stage, in which only surgical options are available. To date, there have been no large multiancestry genetic studies of the disease. We leveraged the unique resources of 484,374 participants in the Million Veteran Program and UK Biobank.

Iiopathic pulmonary fibrosis (IPF) is a serious disease of the lung parenchyma. It has a known polygenetic risk, with at least seventeen regions of the genome implicated to date. Growing evidence suggests linked multimorbidity of IPF with neurodegenerative or affective disorders.

Myopia most often develops during school age, with the highest incidence in countries with intensive education systems. Interactions between genetic variants and educational exposure are hypothesized to confer susceptibility to myopia, but few such interactions have been identified.

Both musculoskeletal pain and sleep disturbances are major health problems worldwide. Literature suggests that the two are reciprocally related and both may be associated with changes in C-reactive protein (CRP) levels. However, the relationships among musculo- skeletal pain, sleep duration, and CRP remain unclear.

Robust Interaction Testing using Sample Splitting (RITSS) is based on sample splitting and robust test statistics. RITSS can incorporate sets of genetic variants and/or multiple environmental factors. Based on the user's choice of statistical/machine learning approaches, a screening step selects and combines potential interactions.

Lipoprotein(a) [Lp(a)] is a risk factor for atherosclerotic and valvular diseases, but its possible role in other diseases has not yet been established. We conducted phenome-wide Mendelian randomization and disease-trajectory analyses to assess any associations of circulating Lp( a) levels with a broad range of diseases.

This paper presents and compares alternative transfer learning methods that can increase the power of conditional testing via knockoffs. We apply these methods to analyze several phenotypes in the UK Biobank data set. Transfer learning helps knockoffs discover more associations in the data collected from minority populations.

Air pollution was associated with a higher risk of dementia among nonsmokers but not current smokers. Additional studies are required to confirm our findings and to explore the potential mechanisms underlying the possible effect modification by smoking status.

Little is known about the impact of daily physical activity timing on cardiovascular disease (CVD) risk. We aimed to examined the associations between chronoactivity and multiple CVD outcomes in the UK Biobank.
