High BMI is associated with many comorbidities and mortality. This study aimed to elucidate the overall clinical risk of obesity using a genome- and phenome-wide approach. Class 3 obesity was associated with 433 phenotypes.

The extent to which genetic interactions affect observed phenotypes is generally unknown. Current interaction detection approaches only consider simple interactions between top SNPs of genes. We introduce an open-source framework for increasing the power of interaction detection.

ApoA1 is the principal protein component of high-density lipoprotein (HDL) Low HDL cholesterol levels are known to be associated with greater cardiovascular risk. Recent studies have shown heightened mortality risk at very high HDL-C levels.

Hypertension appears to be one of the commonest comorbidities in COVID-19 patients. It is unclear whether the absolute level of systolic blood pressure, or the type of anti-hypertensive medication is related to this risk.

Epilepsy (EP) and congenital heart disease (CHD) are apparently unrelated diseases that display substantial mutual comorbidity. Although genetic determinants have been postulated to underlie EP and CHD, the precise genetic etiology is unknown. We performed variant and gene association analyses using whole exomes of genetically identified Europeans.

The emergence of genetic data coupled to longitudinal electronic medical records offers the possibility of phenome-wide association studies. In PheWAS, the whole phenome can be divided into numerous phenotypic categories according to the genetic architecture across phenotypes. The proposed method involves three steps. In the third step, we propose a new false discovery rate (FDR) control approach.

Gene expression is tightly regulated, with many genes exhibiting cell-specific silencing when their protein product would disrupt normal cellular function. This silencing is largely controlled by non-coding elements, and their disruption might cause human disease. We performed gene-agnostic screening to discover new molecular causes of congenital hyperinsulinism. This identified 14 de novo variants affecting a 42-bp conserved region encompassed by a regulatory element in intron 2 of the hexokinase 1 gene (HK1)

Equity is widely held to be fundamental to the ethics of healthcare. Yet no general framework for its quantification, let alone assurance, currently exists. Here we formulate epistemic equity in terms of model fidelity evaluated over learnt multidimensional representations of identity crafted to maximise diversity of the population.

Deformable image registration (DIR) can be used to track cardiac motion. Conventional DIR algorithms aim to establish a dense and non-linear correspondence between independent pairs of images. They are computationally intensive and do not consider temporal dependencies.

Sarcopenia involves the degeneration of muscle strength, muscle mass and physical performance. It remains unknown whether air pollution exposure increases the risk of sarcopenia.

The findings regarding whether the greater iron level or intake is a risk factor to Parkinson's disease (PD) or parkinsonism was not clear. We conducted a large-scale prospective cohort study using comprehensive longitudinal data from the UK Biobank. Analyses revealed that (a) iron supplementation was significantly associated with higherParkinsonism risk, and (b) greater hemoglobin was weakly and insignificantly associated with lower parkinsonist risk.

Adhesive capsulitis of the shoulder involves loss of passive range of motion with associated pain. Known risk factors include diabetes, female sex, and thyroid dysfunction. Genome-wide association study (GWAS) was conducted using the U.K. Biobank.

Chlamydia pneumoniae (C. pneumoniae) is implicated in the pathogenesis of Alzheimer's disease (AD) Chlamydial elementary and reticulate bodies have been identified in tissues from afflicted AD brain regions.

Parkinson's disease is 1.5 times more prevalent in males than females. Work has been done to identify the genetic risk factors behind Parkinson's disease on autosomes and more recently on Chromosome X. But work remains to be done on the male-specific Y chromosome.

We construct a polygenic health index as a weighted sum of polygenic risk scores for 20 major disease conditions. Individuals with higher index scores have decreased disease risk across almost all 20 diseases. Correlations between genetic disease risks are found to be mostly positive and generally mild.

The Prism Vote (PV) views the trait of an individual as a composite risk from subpopulations. Since each individual is described by a composition of subpopulation memberships, the framework enables individualized risk characterization. The advantage of PV enlarges as genetic heterogeneity and sample size increase.

Women with a family history of ovarian cancer or a pathogenic or likely pathogenic gene variant are at high risk of the disease. But very few women have these risk factors. We assessed whether a combined polygenic and clinical risk score could predict risk.

Aggregation of genome-wide common risk variants, such as polygenic risk score (PRS), can measure genetic susceptibility to cancer. Meta-analyses across cancer types in The Cancer Genome Atlas revealed that higher PRS values were associated with earlier cancer onset and lower burden of somatic alterations.

The menopause transition involves changes in oestrogen and adipose tissue distribution. These changes may influence female brain health post-menopause. It is unclear whether different types of adipose tissues play diverging roles.

Genes with moderate to low expression heritability may explain a large proportion of complex trait etiology. Such genes cannot be sufficiently captured in conventional transcriptome-wide association studies (TWASs) We introduce a method, the Summary-level Unified Method for Modeling Integrated Transcriptome (SUMMIT), to improve TWAS accuracy.

The SCN1B c.363C>G (p.Cys121Trp) variant has been identified in independent, multi-generational families with GEFS+. Although the variant is present in population databases (at very low frequency), there is strong clinical, genetic, and functional evidence to support pathogenicity.

A greater sense of meaning and purpose in life is associated with lower dementia risk. The present research examines meaning and incident dementia in the largest sample to date, the UK Biobank.

Mendelian randomization is the use of genetic variants to assess the existence of a causal relationship between a risk factor and an outcome of interest. We review methods for variable selection and estimation in cis-MR with summary-level data. We conclude by examining two case studies, assessing the effects of low-density lipoprotein-cholesterol and serum testosterone on coronary heart disease risk.

We conducted a genome-wide association study (GWAS) in 424,120 genotyped participants of the UK Biobank. Among 21,176 T2D and 402,944 non-T2D samples from UKB, stratified GWAS identified 19 and 315 genomic risk loci significantly associated with TG levels. The lead variant is located 2Kb upstream of the HLA-DQB1 gene.

Many studies have utilized physical activity for predicting mortality risk, using measures such as participant walk tests and self-reported walking pace. The rise of passive monitors to measure participant activity without requiring specific actions opens the possibility for population level analysis.

Risk of periodontal disease was higher in people with psychosis. Patients with a clinical diagnosis had the highest proportion of disease. Lifestyle factors (smoking) and comorbidities (cardiovascular, cancer or respiratory disease) were associated with disease among people with a history of psychosis.

Breast cancer (BC) is one of the most prevalent cancers worldwide but its etiology remains unclear. Obesity is recognized as a risk factor for BC, and many obesity-related genes may be involved in its occurrence and development. This study sought to construct a gene interaction network to identify potential pathogenic BC genes. The identified genes were mainly involved in energy regulation and fat-related signaling pathways.

Lifestyle risk behaviours such as smoking, physical inactivity, and unhealthy diet account for a considerable disease burden globally. These risk behaviours tend to cluster within an individual, which could have detrimental health effects. In this study, we aimed to examine the clustering effect of lifestyle risk behaviours on cardiovascular disease (CVD) and CVD risk among adults in the UK.

Type 2 diabetes (T2D) is disproportionately prevalent in bipolar disorder (BD) and is associated with cognitive deficits in psychiatrically healthy cohorts. Whether there is an interaction effect between T2D and BD on cognition remains unclear. Using the UK Biobank, we explored interactions between T1D, BD and cognition.

Genetic associations with measures of local brain folding are largely under-explored. We found 388 regional brain folding associations across 77 genetic loci. We integrated brain eQTLs to refine genes for various loci, implicated several genes involved in neurodevelopmental disorders, and highlighted global genetic correlations with neuropsychiatric phenotypes.

The prevalence of some immune-mediated diseases (IMDs) shows distinct differences between populations of different ethnicities. The aim of this study was to determine if the age at diagnosis of common IMDs differed between different ethnic groups in the UK.

A retrospective MRI dataset pooled from more than 217 sites/scanners constituted one of the largest brain MRI samples to date. The model fine-tuned for AD classification achieved 90.9% accuracy in leave-sites-out cross-validation. Predicted scores from the AD classifier showed significant correlations with illness severity.

Proportional Odds LOgistic model for NEtwork regression in Transcriptome-wide association study. It uses pointwise mutual information to represent the general relationship among the network nodes of predicted gene expression. The model can simultaneously identify the disease-related network nodes or edges.

Evidence on pancreatic cancer (PaCa) risk factors from large population-based cohort studies is limited. This study investigated the PaCa risk factors and the population attributable fraction (PAF) of modifiable risk factors in the UK Biobank cohort. The PAF suggested that eliminating smoking and obesity can contribute around a 16% reduction in PaCa cases. Preventing pancreatitis and DM could potentially reduce PaCa Cases by 1% and 6%, respectively.

Cognitive and functional measures in individuals who subsequently developed Alzheimer's disease (AD), Parkinson disease, frontotemporal dementia, progressive supranuclear palsy, dementia with Lewy bodies, or multiple system atrophy were compared against individuals without neurodegenerative diagnoses. Pre-diagnostic functional impairment and decline were observed in multiple diseases.

There has been an increasing interest in the possible role of infectious agents in the brain in the pathogenesis of dementia. We evaluated the association between seropositivity status of all viruses available in a large, population-based dataset (the UK Biobank) and dementia risk. Of the 15 viruses investigated, our results showed a statistically significant increase of dementia risk associated only with HSV1.

Alpha-1 antitrypsin deficiency associated liver disease (AATD-LD) is a rare genetic disorder and not well-recognized. We aimed to develop a tailored machine learning (ML) model to predict the disease progression. The proposed stacking ensemble ML model showed clinically meaningful accuracy.

Polygenic scores (PGS) are becoming an increasingly popular approach to predict complex disease risk. PGS hold the potential to develop insight into the molecular profiles of patients with an elevated genetic predisposition to disease. We sought to construct an atlas of associations between 125 different PGS derived using results from genome-wide association studies.

Study aimed to evaluate the association of dietary iron intake with incident dementia and brain iron deposition. Included dementia-free participants from the UK Biobank who completed at least one 24-hour dietary recall at study baseline.

Digital gait biomarkers (including walking speed) indicate functional decline and predict hospitalization and mortality. waist or lower-limb devices often used are not designed for continuous life-long use. With the almost universal uptake of smart-watches, our algorithms offer a new approach.

Multimorbidity generally refers to concurrent occurrence of multiple chronic conditions. These patients are inherently at high risk and often lead a poor quality of life due to delayed treatments. With the emergence of personalized medicine and stratified healthcare, there is a need to stratify patients right at the primary care setting.

Postpartum depression was more weakly associated with adulthood trauma and neuroticism. Depression following diagnosis of a chronic disease had weaker association with neuroticism and reported trauma in adulthood and childhood.

Previous studies found that cancer survivors had a reduced risk of dementia. However, these findings were uncertain because of survivor bias and a lack of stratification by cancer types. This current cohort study used data from the UK Biobank to explore these associations.

A discordant twin study of 120 monozygotic (MZ) and 148 dizygotic (DZ) twin pairs from the UK Biobank explored the potential causal relationships between birth weight and later-life cardiometabolic risk factors. We found no strong evidence of association in MZ twins between the within-pair differences in birth height and most cardiometric risk factors in later life.

 complex machine learning models can capture non-linear interrelations and provide opportunities to identify unexplored risk factors. Explainable artificial intelligence can improve prediction accuracy over linear models and reveal great insights into outcomes like mortality.

Study aimed to assess the relationship between different sleep patterns and tinnitus. Cross-sectional analysis using baseline data (2006-2010, n = 168,064) by logistic regressions was conducted.

Metabolic syndrome (MetS) and its components have been shown as risk factors for several solid cancers. However, current epidemiological evidence about the relevance of MetS and bladder cancer risk was limited. We conducted a prospective cohort study of 476,986 participants with undiagnosed bladder cancer based on the UK Biobank.

Copy number variations (CNVs) conferring risk for mental disorders are associated with brain changes and cognitive deficits. Whether these effects are shared or distinct across CNVs remains untested. Here we compared the effects on brain morphometry and cognitive performance across CNV with shared psychiatric liability.

It is well-known that mental health is associated with the risk of developing cardiovascular disease. The main purpose of this study was to assess capability of mental health factors along with traditional risk factors to be used in cardiovascular predictive machine learning models. We developed a combined machine learning approach using both traditional risk and psychological factors.

Obesity has been associated with increased heart failure (HF) risk. This study investigated associations between various adiposity measures and incidence of different HF subtypes.

The UK Biobank is a large prospective multicentre study which recruited over 500,000 participants in the UK aged 37-73 years at entry between 2006-2010. A total of 12,853 participants underwent a first coronary angioplasty during the study period, with 1,394 requiring RR over a median follow-up of 6.5 years. Lipoprotein(a) >80nmol/L was one of six independent predictors of time to RR (HR 1.24, p=0.006), independent of other lipids. LDL, HDL, and triglyceride levels were not significant predictors in this model.

Proton pump inhibitors (PPIs) were found to increase the risk of pancreatic cancer in a mouse model and human clinical cohorts. Serum gastrin levels were increased 8-fold (P)

Multi-Ancestry TwaS (MATS) framework jointly analyzes samples from multiple populations. It distinguishes between shared, ancestry-specific and/or subject-specific expression-trait associations. MATS amplifies power to detect shared GEx associations over ancestry-stratified TWAS.

The purpose of this study is to characterize the impact of the timing and duration of missing actigraphy data on interdaily stability (IS) and intradaily variability (IV) calculation. IV and IS were calculated for true, masked, and imputed timeseries data and used to generate Bland-Alman plots for each condition.

Air pollution has been frequently linked to a range of cardiometabolic diseases. Our results highlight clean air as an upstream approach to mitigate both initiation and progression of CMM. Older participants, males and individuals with excessive alcohol drinking and lower economic levels were more likely to experience these risks.

Deep Learning (DL) has been broadly applied to solve big data problems in biomedical fields. Recently, many DL methods have been applied to analyze genomic studies. However, genomic data usually has too small a sample size to fit a complex network.

Red wine and champagne/white wine consumption were inversely associated with waist circumference (WC) for both sexes. Alcohol consumption was associated with a lower risk of obesity incidence in women. Female and male spirit drinkers had higher WC than non-spirit drinkers.

The study included 359,489 participants without a previous diagnosis of cancer. We used the Fine-Gray regression model to predict the incident risk of liver cancer, accounting for the competing risk of all-cause death. The model had good discrimination, calibration and clinical utility.

Back pain is the leading cause of years lived with disability worldwide. Little is known regarding the biology underlying this condition. We discovered 2 genes, SOX5 and PANX3 , influencing chronic back pain.

Cancer has contributed to an increasing proportion of diabetes-related deaths. Lifestyle management is the cornerstone of both diabetes care and cancer prevention. We aimed to evaluate the associations of combined healthy lifestyles with total and site-specific cancer risks.

Caffeinated coffee drinkers had lower odds for rosacea diagnosis compared to non-coffee drinkers. We hypothesize that the vasoconstrictive effects of caffeine in regular coffee overpower the vasodilatory effects associated with hot beverages.

Theories and empirical evidence document the importance of early life environmental factors on later life cognition. Using data from the UK Biobank in conjunction with time-place-specific infant mortality rates, we assessed heterogeneous and non-linear associations. We found that the association between the infant mortality rate and later. life cognition increased once the UK achieved very low infant. mortality rates.

Mixed effects of fish oil supplementation on the risks of atrial fibrillation were observed in several large-scale randomized controlled trials. Whether this relationship would be modified by genetic AF risk, baseline cardiovascular disease (CVD) status and background oily fish consumption are unknown. We included 468 665 participants without AF at baseline from the UK Biobank cohort.

Among 502,493 participants from the UK Biobank, baseline data were extracted for 4171 factors spanning 10 different categories. Higher levels of education, body size, basal metabolic rate, fat-free mass, computer use, and cognitive functions were associated with a decreased risk of developing AD. Strong evidence was found for selective food intake and more outdoor exposures as new risk factors for AD.

A nested case-control study was conducted in East London using primary care health records. 1,055 patients with PD and 10,550 controls were included. The strongest associations were found for tremor and memory complaints. Convincing novel associations were observed for epilepsy and hearing loss with subsequent PD.

Mendelian randomization (MR) analysis can produce biased results if the genetic variant defining an instrumental variable (IV) is confounded or has a horizontal pleiotropic effect. We provide novel identification conditions for the causal effect of a treatment in the presence of unmeasured confounding by leveraging a possibly invalid IV.

Genome-wide association studies (GWASs) underlying case-control design have uncovered hundreds of genetic loci involved in tumorigenesis. However, application of GWAS in determining the genetic architecture of cancer survival remains unestablished. Here, we systematically evaluated genetic effects at the genome-wide level on cancer survival.

Polygenic risk scores quantify the individual genetic predisposition regarding a particular trait. We propose and illustrate the application of existing statistical learning methods to derive sparser models for genome-wide data with a polygenic signal. Our approach is based on three consecutive steps.

Existing methods are unable to address type I error inflation induced by increased correlation of phenotypes among closely related samples. We show through simulation studies and analysis of UK Biobank data of white British samples that the proposed method is robust and yields better calibration.

Previous studies investigating the relationship between aspirin use and subarachnoid haemorrhage (SAH) have yielded conflicting results. In this study, we aimed to clarify the association between aspirin and SAH in the general population.

Neighborhood environments may influence cancer risk. Improving neighborhood environments could inadvertently widen health inequalities if important differences are overlooked. Most notably, more greenspace near home was associated with 16% lower hazard of cancer-related hospital admission in deprived areas.

Study examined association of long and short sleep duration with risk of Parkinson's disease (PD) across RORA rs2028122 genotypes. Sleep duration exhibited a curvilinear U-shaped correlation with the risk of PD. Among GG carriers, habitual short sleepers have a higher risk ofPD compared with habitual normal sleepers.

Disease-associated single-nucleotide polymorphisms (SNPs) generally do not implicate target genes, as most disease SNPs are regulatory. Many SNP-to-gene (S2G) linking strategies have been developed to link regulatory SNPs to the genes that they regulate in cis. We developed a heritability-based framework for evaluating and combining different S2G strategies to optimize their informativeness.

Study: Modifiable risk factors are associated with aortic valve stenosis (AVS) 1602 participants developed AVS during an 8.4-year follow-up. Genetically predicted 1-SD higher levels of body mass index, body fat percentage, and serum total cholesterol were associated with higher risk of AVS.

There was a higher risk of CVD among South Asian and Black participants. Compared with White participants, the associations of BMI, triglycerides, and HbA1c with CVD were stronger in South Asians. Adiposity is an important risk factor for CVD regardless of ethnicity.

Data were from a prospective cohort of 362,094 UK Biobank participants. After a median follow-up of 9.0 years, 4149 (1.15%) individuals were diagnosed with dementia. Cox hazard regression models showed a marked increase in risk at low exposure.

Study compared a variety of global brain measures between participants with isolated hypertension to those with normal blood pressure. Isolated systolic hypertensives had larger total gray matter and smaller white matter traits when comparing these regions with participants with syStolic-diastolic hypertension.

 Genetic predisposition and unhealthy lifestyle are risk factors for nonalcoholic fatty liver disease (NAFLD) We investigated whether the genetic risk of NAFLD is modified by physical activity, muscular fitness, and/or adiposity. We found that increased physical activity and grip strength modestly attenuate genetic predisposition to elevation in ALT levels. Higher BMI markedly amplifies it.

Large-scale genome-wide association studies have identified hundreds of single-nucleotide variants (SNVs) significantly associated with coronary artery disease (CAD) These SNVs include T (control region) and m.12612A>G (ND5), found more frequently in cases (OR = 1.05), potentially related to reduced cardiorespiratory fitness in response to exercise.

Whole-exome sequencing analysis of >350,000 UK Biobank participants revealed that protein-truncating variants in four genes are negatively associated with human lifespan. Phenome-wide analyses confirm roles for these genes in cancer and clonal hematopoiesis.

The importance of quantifying the distribution and determinants of multimorbidity has prompted novel data-driven classifications of disease. Applications have included improved statistical power and refined prognoses for a range of respiratory, infectious, autoimmune, and neurological diseases.

Leukocyte telomere length (LTL) is a proposed marker of biological age. LTL is markedly longer in African and Chinese ancestries. Older age and male sex associate with shorter LTL. Age, ethnicity, sex and white cell count explain 5.5% of LTL variance.

Large-scale sequencing and genotyping data provide an opportunity to integrate external samples as controls to improve power of association tests. naively aggregating the controls could lead to inflation in Type I error rates. We propose an iECAT-Score region-based test that increases power for rare-variant tests.

Coronary artery disease (CAD) is a preeminent cause of death. Smoking is a strong risk factor for CAD. Genetic factors contribute to the development of CAD. The interplay between genetic predisposition and smoking history in CAD remains unclear.

Identifying promising drug targets for human aging using genetics has had limited success. In the present study, we combine six European-ancestry genome-wide association studies of human aging traits. The first principal component (aging-GIP1) captures both length of life and indices of mental and physical wellbeing.

Physical inactivity (PA) is an important risk factor for a wide range of diseases. Previous genome-wide association studies have identified a limited number of genetic loci associated with habitual PA. In this study, we derived 27 PA phenotypes from wrist accelerometry data obtained from 88,411 UK Biobank study participants.

Study performed individual-centric, data-driven calculations of propensity for coronary heart disease (CHD) and type 2 diabetes (T2D) Using magnetic resonance imaging-acquired body composition measurements, for sub-phenotyping of obesity and nonalcoholic fatty liver disease (NAFLD)

An increased susceptibility to COVID-19 has been suggested for individuals with neurodegenerative diseases, but data are scarce from longitudinal studies. We included 96,275 participants of the UK Biobank who had available SARS-CoV-2 test results in Public Health England. Logistic regression was applied to estimate the association between neurogenerative disease and risks of CO VID-19.

The associations of rheumatoid arthritis (RA) with risk of site-specific cancers beyond lymphohematopoietic cancer have been scarcely explored. We conducted a Mendelian randomization investigation of the associations of RA with site- specific cancers in European and East Asian populations.

Physical activity could reduce the risk of CMM incidence. Participants initially free of cardiometabolic diseases (CMDs) may benefit more from engaging in recommended physical activity. Adults should engage in WHO-recommended physical activity as early as possible to prevent CMD incidence.

Nonalcoholic fatty liver disease (NAFLD) is considered as the hepatic manifestation of metabolic syndrome. Cox proportional hazard model was used to analyze the association between NAFLD and all-cause mortality, major adverse cardiovascular events (MACEs), CVD mortality, fatal/nonfatal acute myocardial infarction (AMI), and fatal/ nonfatal stroke.

Normative modelling is becoming more popular in neuroimaging due to its ability to make predictions of deviation from a normal trajectory at the level of individual participants. So far, most normative modelling approaches used Gaussian process regression, and although suitable for smaller datasets, it does not scale well to the large cohorts currently available and being acquired.

Half of patients with a ciliopathy syndrome remain unsolved after initial analysis of whole exome sequencing (WES) data. By candidate gene curation of WES data, combined with homozygosity mapping, we detected a homozygous predicted synonymous allele in NPHP3 in two children with hepatorenal fibrocystic disease from a consanguineous family. Remarkably, the same rare variant was detected in four additional families with hepatoreal disease.

Existing methods may suffer from substantial power loss because expression of many genes tends to be consistent across tissues. Integrative Test for Associations via Cauchy Transformation (InTACT) combines information across multiple tissues. InTACT identified 227 genome-wide significant genes, of which 130 were not identified by benchmark methods.

Myocardial infarction can be determined by late enhancement cardiac magnetic resonance (CMR) imaging, which requires the injection of a potentially harmful gadolinium-based contrast agent. Emerging research in the area of myocardial strain has shown potential to identify MI using strain values.

People born in winter and early spring are at an elevated risk for schizophrenia. We used PRS analysis of the UK Biobank (UKBB) to determine whether season of birth is associated with genetic risk. We found no association between schizophrenia PRS andSeason of birth. There was no evidence that seasonality is a heritable trait.

Traditional multiple testing procedures prohibit adaptive analysis choices made by users. Goeman and Solari proposed a simultaneous inference framework that allows users such flexibility while preserving high-probability bounds.

The UK Biobank is a large-scale health resource comprising genetic, environmental, and medical information on approximately 500,000 volunteer participants. The project monitors the health and well-being of its participants. This work demonstrates how these data can be used to yield the building blocks for an interpretable risk-prediction model.

Inhalation of ambient aerosols can exacerbate or promote the development of cardiovascular and pulmonary diseases. Occupational exposure to dust, fumes and diesel exhaust particulates can also cause adverse health outcomes. An individual's job title has normally been identified as a major determinant of workplace exposure.

Birth weight has important associations with life outcomes ranging from infant mortality to cognition to adult stature. Since birth weight and such developmental outcomes may share a genetic etiology, here we compare estimates of the effect of birth weight on traits with and without controls for genotype.

A typical task arising from a Genome Wide Association Study (GWAS) is to identify single nucleotide polymorphisms (SNPs) that are likely causal variants and the affected genes. Functional genomics data from relevant tissues are believed to be helpful in selecting likely causal SNPs and interpreting implicated biological mechanisms.

The 21-point Brain Care Score (BCS) was developed to promote behavior changes and lifestyle choices. We aimed to assess the associations of the BCS with risk of incident dementia and stroke. The BCS was derived from the United Kingdom Biobank.

HapNe infers recent population size fluctuations using either IBD sharing or linkage disequilibrium. It does not require phasing and can be computed in low coverage data. HapNe shows improved accuracy in a range of simulated demographic scenarios.

A history of pregnancy loss is associated with the development of cardiovascular diseases. The association between RPL and subsequent MS is poorly understood. Women with a history of RPL have a higher prevalence of MS between the ages of 40 and 60 years.

The long-term impact of maternal smoking during pregnancy on the risk of Crohn's disease [CD] and ulcerative colitis in adult offspring remains uncertain. We conducted a prospective cohort study using UK Biobank data, including 334 083 participants recruited between 2006 and 2010, with follow-up until December 31, 2021.

Modifiable risk factor estimates are sparse for early-onset dementia incidence. This study aimed to estimate and compare the risk factor profiles of early-ONSet dementia and late-ONset dementia. It also explored the complex relationships between socioeconomic status, lifestyles, and early-ONSet dementia risk. Between 2007 and 2010, 257 345 individuals were included in the analysis of late-onsets dementia.

Stroke and dementia are major neurological disorders that contribute significantly to disease burden. There is currently no study investigating the influence of residential greenspace on the trajectory of these neurological disorders. Exposure to greenspace was measured by the percentage of total greenspace coverage within a 300-meter buffer zone surrounding the participants' residences.

 LS-imputation has been proposed for large-scale trait imputation based on a GWAS summary dataset and a large set of genotyped individuals. The current method imposes a working assumption that the imputed trait values are identically and independently distributed. Here we propose a "divide and conquer/combine" strategy to estimate and account for the covariance matrix.

There is a need for gene-environment interaction-specific methods that manipulate and use summary statistics. We introduce two tools to facilitate such analysis. We demonstrate the value and efficiency of these tools by exploring alternative methods of accounting for ancestry-related population stratification.

Hepatotoxicity is one of the most concerning sequelae of cancer. This study examined the potential supplement-drug interactions involving the hepatic system, and their associations with documented liver diseases, among patients with cancer in the UK Biobank.

Colorectal cancer (CRC) is one of the leading causes of cancer death worldwide. It is important to identify risk factors that may be used to help reduce morbidity and mortality of the disease. We used a case-control study design to explore the association between CRC, polygenic risk scores (PRS), and other factors.

Deep learning (DL) models have shown promise in detecting chronic kidney disease (CKD) from fundus photographs. Previous studies have utilized a serum creatinine-only estimated glomerular rate (eGFR) equation to measure kidney function.

Study looked at relationship between metabolomic profiles, genome-wide polygenic risk scores and risk of rheumatoid arthritis. 143 nuclear magnetic resonance-based plasma metabolic biomarkers were measured among 93 800 participants in the UK Biobank.

Oral health problem is prevalent in the elderly population which is also at high risk of Parkinson's disease (PD) However, the association between self-reported oral health and PD is still unclear. Participants were enrolled in the UK Biobank from 2006 to 2010 and those without PD at baseline were included in the study.

Left ventricular regional wall thickness (LVRWT) is an independent predictor of morbidity and mortality in cardiovascular diseases. We established a novel deep learning algorithm to calculate 12 LVRWTs accurately in 42,194 individuals from the UK Biobank.

Study aimed to examine whether younger onset age of CHD is associated with a higher risk of incident dementia. Data were obtained from the UK Biobank. Compared with participants without CHD, participants with CHD exhibited higher risks of developing all-cause dementia, Alzheimer's disease, and vascular dementia.

"successful cognitive aging" stands as a hallmark of individuals who exhibit cognitive abilities surpassing those of their age-matched counterparts. In this study, a highly selective cohort of 1060 individuals aged 65 and above was meticulously curated from a larger pool of 17,072 subjects. The selection process was guided by their striking cognitive resilience, ascertained via rigorous evaluation.

A total of 466 224 UK Biobank participants were investigated. Folate/folic acid supplementation alone was significantly associated with a higher risk of AD and VD. However, when combined with other B vitamins, these detrimental effects can be counteracted.

Greater adherence to lifestyle-based recommendations was associated with reduced risk of all cancers combined and of breast, colorectal, kidney, oesophageal, ovarian, liver, and gallbladder cancers. Our findings support compliance with the Cancer Prevention Recommendations for cancer prevention in the UK.

Developing a single-domain assay to identify individuals at high risk of future events is a priority for multi-disease and mortality prevention. We developed a disease/mortality-specific proteomic risk score based on 1461 Olink plasma proteins measured in 52,006 UK Biobank participants.

Hypertrophic cardiomyopathy (HCM) is an important cause of sudden cardiac death. There is no systematic framework for classifying morphology or assessing associated risks. We used machine learning to analyze the 3-dimensional structure of the left ventricle from cardiac magnetic resonance imaging and build a tree-based classification of HCM phenotypes.

The branched chain amino acids (BCAA) leucine, isoleucine and valine are essential nutrients that have been associated with diabetes, cancers, and cardiovascular diseases. Observational studies suggest that BCAAs exert homogeneous phenotypic effects, but these findings are inconsistent with results from experimental human and animal studies. Almost half (44% n = 52) are associated with only one BCAA.

Iron deficiency anaemia (IDA) and deferral due to hypohaemoglobinemia (Hb-deferral) are unclear. In this investigation, we aimed to quantify the value of genetic information in predicting IDA and Hb- deferral. We analysed genetic data from up to 665,460 participants of the FinnGen and Blood Service Biobank.

Study examined 34 260 men without a history of prostate cancer in the UK Biobank. Sleep characteristics were measured over 7 days using actigraphy. Sleep midpoint earlier than 4:00 am was not associated with prostate cancer risk.

Evidence regarding the association between physical activity and Parkinson's disease (PD) risk is generally limited due to the use of self-report questionnaires. We aimed to quantify the separate and combined effects of accelerometer-measured light physical activity, moderate-to-vigorous physical activity (MVPA), sedentary time and exercise timing with incident PD.

Plant-based diets are becoming increasingly popular due to favourable environmental footprints. They have been associated with lower risk of type 2 diabetes mellitus (T2DM) Here, we investigated the potential mechanisms to explain the lower T2DM risk.

Genetic risks for schizophrenia are theoretically mediated by genetic effects on brain structure. It has been unclear which genes are associated with both schizophrenia and cortical phenotypes. We accessed genome-wide association studies (GWAS) of schizophrenia and of three magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) metrics.

The role of nonalcoholic fatty liver disease (NAFLD) as a mediator in the association between various unhealthy lifestyles and major adverse cardiovascular events and all-cause death remains unclear. This study used data from the UK Biobank, with follow-up until end of 2021.

The extent to which the phenotypic effects of common and rare variants involve shared molecular mediators remains poorly understood. We developed a metric, the COmmon variant and RAre variant Convergence (CORAC) signature, to quantify the convergence for a broad range of complex traits. We found that the signature is positively correlated with effective sample size.

Cardiovascular disease (CVD) is an escalating global health crisis. Dyslipidemia stands as a critical risk factor for CVD. Vascular endothelial growth factor A ( VEGFA ) is pivotal in angiogenesis. However, the impact of genetic modulation of VEG FA on lipid levels and the subsequent risk of cardiovascular events remains unclear.

Study included 98 893 UK Biobank participants whose PA data were measured using wrist-worn accelerometers. During the follow-up period 282 incident CAs (0.39 per 1000 person-years) occurred. Total PA was inversely related to CA risk.

Low back pain (LBP) is a major public health issue that influences physical and emotional factors integral to the limbic system. This study aims to investigate the association between LBP and brain morphometry alterations as the duration of LBP increases. We found that acute LBP was associated with increased volumes of the nucleus accumbens, amygdala, hippocampus and thalamus.

Sleep and depression have a complex, bidirectional relationship, with sleep-associated alterations in brain dynamics and structure impacting a range of symptoms and cognitive abilities. Previous work describing these relationships has provided an incomplete picture. We analyze the correlations between brainwide neural signatures of sleep, cognition, and depression in task and resting-state data.

Ductal carcinoma in situ of the breast (DCIS) is a nonobligate precursor of IBC and shares several risk factors with it. We studied the association between circulating levels of TC, LDL-C, high-density lipoprotein cholesterol (HDL-C), Lipoprotein (a) (Lp-(a), IGF-1, CRP and HbA1c, with the risk of DCIS in 156801women aged 40 to 69 years and breast cancer-free at enrolment.

Amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (ALS) is a debilitating neurodegenerative disease. In patients carrying genetic mutations, elevations in neurofilament light (NfL) have been shown to precede symptom onset. The natural history of NfL in general ALS patients is less characterized.

Time spent outdoors has a small genetic component that tracked from childhood to adulthood. Accounting for the effects of time outdoors reduced the estimated causal effect of education on myopia by 40%. These results suggest about half of the relationship between education and myopia may be mediated by children not being outdoors during schooling.

Middle-aged persons with epilepsy (PWE) are under investigated regarding their mortality risk and burden of cardiovascular disease. Sudden death is the leading cause of mortality in medically refractory epilepsy.

Lung function measures are associated with cardiovascular disease (CVD) However, the added predictive values of these measures remain unclear. In the UK Biobank, 308 415 participants free of CVD with spirometry parameters were included.

Glucosamine supplementation is common but can be associated with increased intraocular pressure (IOP) This could contribute to the pathogenesis of glaucoma. Ophthalmologists should elicit any history of glucosamine use from their patients and advise them accordingly.

Genetic variants in the coding region could directly affect the structure and expression levels of genes and proteins. However, the importance of variants in non-coding region, such as microRNAs (miRNAs), remain to be elucidated. We investigated associations between 346 genetic variants in miRNA-related sequences and a wide range of clinical diagnoses.

Smoking cessation's effect on albuminuria depends on pack-years smoked, length of abstinence, body mass index (BMI) and glycosylated haemoglobin (HbA1c) UK Biobank cohort with urinary albumin concentration (UAC) in the first and second visits. Prevalence ofalbuminuria highest in ex-smokers who started smoking between the ages of 13 and 18.

Movement behaviours, including physical activity, sedentary behaviour, and sleep have been shown to be associated with several chronic diseases. We aim to describe the patterns of device-measured movement behaviours collected in the China Kadoorie Biobank study.

Dystonia is a hyperkinetic movement disorder with key motor network dysfunction. The UK Biobank encompasses > 500,000 participants, of whom 42,565 underwent brain MRI scanning. This study applied an optimized pre-processing pipeline aimed at better accounting for artifact and improving data reliability.

Study aimed to examine the association between tea and coffee consumption and the likelihood of all-cause and cause-specific mortality in patients with MetS. A total of 118,872 participants with metabolic syndrome at baseline from the UK Biobank cohort were included.

Polygenic risk score (PRS) predictions often show bias toward the population of available genome-wide association studies (GWASs) This study aimed to assess the performance differences of ancestry-specific PRS and multi-ancestry PRS to enhance the generalizability of low-density lipoprotein (LDL) cholesterol predictions in the East Asian population.

Irregular sleep-wake timing may cause circadian disruption leading to several chronic age-related diseases. We examined the relationship between sleep regularity and risk of all-cause, cardiovascular disease (CVD), and cancer mortality in 88,975 participants from the UK Biobank cohort.

BMI is a surrogate measure of adiposity. Whether cancer risk is different among adults with and without cardiovascular diseases (CVD) and/or type 2 diabetes (T2D) is unclear. The primary aim of this study was to evaluate separate and joint associations of BMI and CVD/T2d with the risk of cancer.

Study aimed to contrast associations of five diet scores with severe non-alcoholic fatty liver disease (NAFLD) incidence. In total, 162 999 UK Biobank participants were included in this prospective population-based study. The lowest risk was observed in quartile 4 for the MEDAS-14 score.

To explore the correlation and causality between multidimensional sleep traits and pan-cancer incidence and mortality among patients with cancer. The multivariable Cox regression, linear and nonlinear Mendelian randomization (MR), and survival curve analyses were conducted to assess the impacts of chronotype, sleep duration, and insomnia symptoms.

Dynamic functional networks (DFN) have considerably advanced modelling of the brain communication processes. The prevailing implementation capitalizes on system and network-level correlations between time series. This approach does not account for the continuous impact of non-dynamic dependencies within the statistical correlation.

Several prospective cohort studies have examined the relationships between circulating omega-3 and incident dementia. In the largest study to date on this topic, we confirmed the favorable relationships between DHA and risk for dementia. We also found evidence that non-DHA omega- 3 may be beneficial.

We assessed the association between exposure to various air pollutants, individually or jointly, and incident kidney stones. 453,977 participants without prior kidney stones from the UK Biobank were included. During a median follow-up of 11.9 years, 5,375 kidney stones were recorded. The association between air pollution and kidney stones was statistically significant only in participants within intermediate-high kidney stone.

Large-scale longitudinal biobank data can be leveraged to identify genetic variation contributing to human diseases progression and traits trajectories. While methods for genome-wide association studies (GWAS) of multiple correlated traits have been proposed, an efficient multiple-trait approach to model longitudinal phenotypes is not currently available. We developed a mixed-effects model to fit longitudinal outcomes where a fast algorithm for inversion was introduced.

The 16-item PHQ-ADS scale could be reduced to a 7-item scale without loss of test information. Items measuring somatic symptoms were discarded. The revised scale showed high discrimination and scalability.

More than 83% of the world's population lives under light-polluted skies. Information about health effects of outdoor light at night (LAN) is limited. We examined the association of LAN with natural cause (NC) and cardiovascular disease (CVD) mortality.

The gut microbiota is closely related to liver diseases. The dietary pattern associated with sulfur-metabolizing bacteria in stool has been found to influence intestinal health. We aimed to investigate whether consuming the sulfur microbial diet is associated with nonalcoholic fatty liver disease (NAFLD)

Genome-wide association studies is an essential tool for analyzing associations between phenotypes and single nucleotide polymorphisms (SNPs) Most of binary phenotypes in large biobanks are extremely unbalanced, which leads to inflated type I error rates for many widely used association tests. We propose a novel approach, MLN with Omnibus (MLN-O), to jointly analyse the association between phenotype and a SNP.

Ever smoking, higher cigarette consumption daily, and increased smoking intensity were associated with an increased BP risk. This association was stronger in female smokers. Not smoking, smoking cessation, and reducing smoking volume and intensity were effective measures to prevent BP.

Low handgrip strength and slow walking pace were significantly associated with a higher risk of incident PD, regardless of the individuals' genetic risk profile. A lower grip strength and an average/slow walking pace accounted for 23.8% and 19.9% of PD cases.

Whole genome sequencing (WGS) from large clinically unselected cohorts provides a unique opportunity to assess the penetrance and expressivity of rare and/or known pathogenic mitochondrial variants in population. Heteroplasmic m.3243A>G was associated with diabetes, deafness and heart failure and 12 homoplasic variants increased aspartate aminotransferase levels.

Genetic determinants of respiratory infections are understudied and poorly understood. We conducted a genome-wide association study in 19,459 hospitalised respiratory infection cases and 101,438 controls from UK Biobank. We followed-up well-imputed top signals from our Stage 1 analysis in 50,912 respiratory infection Cases and 150,442 controls from 11 cohorts.

PAT segmentations were derived from cardiovascular magnetic resonance (CMR) studies. Prevalent (present at time of imaging) and incident (first occurrence after imaging) HF were ascertained using health record linkage. PyRadiomics was utilised to extract 104 radiomics features, of which 28 were chosen after excluding highly correlated ones.

The hypothalamus plays a crucial role in the regulation of physiological, behavioral, and cognitive functions. Despite its importance, only a few small-scale neuroimaging studies have investigated its substructures. We introduce a novel, fast, and fully automated deep-learning method named HypVINN for sub-segmentation of the hypothalamus.

Biobanks often contain several phenotypes relevant to diseases such as major depressive disorder (MDD) Researchers face complex tradeoffs between shallow and deep phenotypes. Here we propose to integrate these phenotypes to combine the benefits of each. We use phenotype imputation to integrate information across hundreds of MDD-relevant phenotypes, which significantly increases genome-wide association study power.

Adherence to healthy dietary patterns can prevent the development of non-communicable diseases and affect life expectancy. Largest gains are obtained from consuming more whole grains, nuts and fruits and less sugar-sweetened beverages and processed meats.

Sociodemographic factors modulate lifestyle behaviours. Both cancer incidence and survival are socio-economically patterned. We found significant variations in adherence to individual recommendations. Education, Townsend deprivation index and ethnicity were also significant factors.

The present analysis included 23,258 individuals (mean age 63 years, 53% women) who participated in the whole body imaging sub-study of the UK Biobank. Higher visceral fat (VAT) was associated with lower LVEF and higher PWASI. Central adiposity measures (waist circumference [WC] and waist-hip ratio [WHR) showed significant inverse association with LVEf.

Study involved 207,301 participants aged between 39 and 72 years from UK biobank. 468 incident cases of all-cause dementia (165 AD, 91 VD and 26 FTD) were reported during a follow-up period of 11.4 years. Participants in the highest quintile (Q) of DII scores reported a higher risk for all- Cause dementia.

Previous studies on the relationship between chronic kidney disease (CKD) and physical activity (PA) mainly relied on subjective PA data and rarely considered the genetic risk. This study aims to thoroughly investigate this relationship by utilizing both accelerometer-measured and questionnaire-me measured PA data. Engaging in strenuous sports, other exercises, walking for pleasure, stair climbing, and heavy DIY were associated with a reduced risk of CKD.

Study looked at 336 559 participants in the UK Biobank cohort, including 157 227 cases of accelerated biological aging and 179 332 controls. Short sleepers had a 7% higher risk (OR = 1.07; 95% CI: 1.03 to 1.11), while long sleepers were 18% more likely to be accelerated. Evening chronotype was linked to higher PhenoAgeAccel risk than morning chronotype.

Phenotypes in biobanks are often missing across many individuals, limiting their utility. We propose AutoComplete, a deep learning-based imputation method to impute or 'fill-in' missing phenotypes in population-scale biobank datasets. When applied to collections of phenotypes measured across ~300,000 individuals from the UK Biobank, AutoComplete substantially improved imputation accuracy.

Adult-onset asthma (AOA) and cardiovascular diseases shared common risk factors and similar pathophysiologic resemblances. American Heart Association unveiled the life's essential 8 (LE8) to promote cardiovascular health (CVH) Study aimed to assess the overall impact of LE8 implementation on AOA prevention.

The association between dietary manganese (Mn) intake and the risk of venous thromboembolism (VTE) remains unknown. We aimed to investigate the associations of dietary Mn intake with incident VTE. BMI, waist circumference, RDW, CRP, and WBC significantly mediated the association.

Over 10% of the population in Europe and in the United States use sleep medication to manage sleep problems. In a GWAS we identified 27 genetic loci significantly associated with sleep medication. Sleep medications use was epidemiologically related to psychiatric traits in FinnGen.

Chronic airflow obstruction is a key characteristic of chronic obstructive pulmonary disease. We investigated whether isolated small airways obstruction is associated with chronic airflow obstruction later in life. We used data from 3957 participants of the multinational Burden of Obstructive Lung Disease study.

Depression is a global health issue, associated with increased risk of cardiovascular disease (CVD) and premature death. This study included 314,800 participants from the UK Biobank. Depressive symptoms were assessed using the Patient Health Questionnaire-2 (PHQ-2)

The study was based on the UK Biobank prospective cohort. MetS and its components significantly increased the risk of anxiety. This association may be partially mediated by serum inflammatory indicators.

20,111 UK Biobank cohort participants with lung function measures at baseline (2006-2010) and follow-up (2012-2014) Physical activity (International Physical Activity Questionnaire: low, moderate, high categories), grip strength (dynamometer) and cardiovascular fitness (subsample, submaximal stationary bicycle) data were collected.

Low-density lipoprotein cholesterol (LDL-C) is associated with cardio-renal diseases and mortality, but the causal nature of these associations is unclear. We aimed to determine the shape of causal relationships of LDL-C with chronic kidney disease (CKD), atherosclerotic cardiovascular disease (ASCVD) and all-cause mortality.

The current knowledge on pancreatic ductal adenocarcinoma (PDAC) risk factors is limited. The aim of this study was to analyze the exposome and its interaction with known genetic susceptibility loci, in relation to PDAC risk.

UK Biobank study contains several sources of diagnostic data, including hospital inpatient data and data on self-reported conditions. VTE cases showed little overlap between data sources, with only 6% of reported events for persons with primary-care data being identified by all 3 sources.

In 382,275 UK Biobank Europeans, we investigate how lifestyles interact with polygenic scores (PGS) of cardiometabolic risk factors. Genome-wide interaction analyses pinpoint three genetic variants ( FTO, CETP and TRIB2) The associations between lifestyles and risk factors differ between individuals grouped by the genotype of these variants.

Policy targeting one item of a person's diet does not affect their nutritional intake in a solely additive or subtractive manner. Policies tackling unhealthy diets are more likely to be adopted by governments if there is robust evidence to support them.

The association between different sedentary behaviors and hypertension risk remains unclear. We aimed to explore whether genetic susceptibility to hypertension modifies the relationship, and examine the extent to which the relationship is mediated by body mass index (BMI) and grip strength.

Both genetic and dietary factors play significant roles in the etiology of colorectal cancer (CRC) To evaluate the relationship between certain food exposures and the risk of CRC, we carried out a large-scale association analysis in the UK Biobank. The associations of 139 foods and nutrients' intake with CRC risk were assessed.

Systemic inflammatory markers have been widely used in cancer prognosis prediction. There is limited knowledge regarding their impact on breast cancer risk and their interaction with polygenic risk scores. Women in the highest tertile of neutrophil-to-lymphocyte ratio (NLR), systemic immune-inflammation index (SII), and C-reactive protein (CRP) showed an increased risk of breast cancer.

Excess energy intake can lead to metabolic dysfunction-associated steatotic liver disease (MASLD) Relationship between dietary carbohydrate intake and liver fat content remains unclear. UK Biobank participants with no pre-existing diabetes, liver disease or cardiovascular disease reported dietary intake of types of carbohydrates.

The cranial vault in humans is highly variable, clinically relevant, and heritable. Yet its genetic architecture remains poorly understood. Here, we conduct a joint multi-ancestry and admixed multivariate genome-wide association study. We present supporting evidence of regional localization for several genes.

A quarter of dementia events could have a connection with a disadvantageous social environment, especially for those genetically susceptible to dementia. The polysocial risk score (PsRS) could be effectively used in discriminating individuals at high risk of dementia.

Eleven biomarkers were found to be significantly associated with the risk of invasive breast cancer. Serum CRP, testosterone, and IGF-1 have different impacts on the transitions of different breast cancer states. Study confirms the role of chronic inflammation and endogenous hormones in breast cancer progression.

Study examined associations between educational duration and specific aspects of well-being, anxiety and mood disorders, and cardiovascular health in a sample of European Ancestry UK Biobank participants born in England and Wales. Findings were consistent across all methods for the other phenotypes.

Air pollution and type 2 diabetes (T2D) are both associated with an increased risk of ischemic heart disease (IHD) Little is known about the combined effects of multiple air pollutants on IHD risk, especially among individuals with T2D. We sought to assess the association of combined exposure to several air pollutants with incident IHD.

 relaxin-3/RXFP3 system has been implicated in the modulation of depressive- and anxiety-like behaviour in the animal literature. There is a lack of human studies investigating this signalling system. We seek to bridge this gap by leveraging the large UK Biobank study to retrospectively assess genetic risk variants linked with this neuropeptidergic system.

Lung cancer is more prevalent in female patients than in male patients. Study looked at 273,190 female individuals from the UK Biobank. Early age at menopause, a shortened reproductive life span, and early age at first birth were associated with higher risks of lung cancer.

Vitamin D status-a complex trait influenced by environmental and genetic factors-is tightly associated with skin colour and ancestry. Yet very few studies have investigated the genetic underpinnings of vitamin D levels across diverse ancestries. Here, we conduct genome-wide association studies (GWAS) of 25 hydroxyvitamin D (25OHD) in 442,435 individuals from four broad genetically-determined ancestry groups.

Nonselective beta-adrenoceptor blockers (NBBs) were demonstrated to have a significant association with PD (reporting odds ratio (ROR) = 3.13; 95% CI 2.33-4.22) In the meta-analysis of 12 studies with 12,183,809 participants, PD risk was elevated in NBBs. Among the 105,763 participants included in the cohort analysis using data from the UK Biobank, individuals who used N BBs had an increased risk of PD.

We examined more than 97,000 families from four neurodevelopmental disease cohorts and the UK Biobank. We identified within- and cross-disorder correlations between six phenotypes in parents and children, such as obsessive-compulsive disorder. Measures of sub-clinical autism features in parents are associated with several autism severity measures in children.

Previous studies have indicated a link between occupational exposures and an increased risk of chronic kidney disease (CKD) A prospective analysis of 65,069 UK Biobank participants aged 40 to 69 years without CKD at baseline (2006-2010) was performed.

Pathological placental inflammation increases the risk for several adult disorders. These mediators are also expressed under homeostatic conditions, where their contribution to adult health outcomes is unknown. We define an inflammation-related expression signature, primarily expressed in Hofbauer cells of the term placenta and use expression quantitative trait loci to create a polygenic score (PGS) predictive of its expression.

The impact of polysocial risk score (PsRS) on the development of psoriasis remains unclear. This was a prospective cohort study conducted among UK Biobank. Those with intermediate PsRS (2-4) and high PsRS (&#8805;5) had 1.20 (95% confidence interval [CI], 1.06-1.36) and 1.53 (95%) times higher risks of developing psor Sinai.

Non-alcoholic fatty liver disease (NAFLD) and inflammatory bowel disease (IBD) have shown similar worsening epidemic patterns globally. However, evidence on the relationship between NAFLD and IBD risk is lacking. We aimed to investigate the associations between long-term risk of incident IBD and NAFLd in a large prospective cohort.

A previous study of 200,000 exome-sequenced UK Biobank participants to test for association of rare coding variants with hypertension implicated two genes. A total of 42 genes had an uncorrected  p  value. The association of DNMT3A and FES with hypertension was replicated in the new sample.

Metabolic syndrome (MetS) has been associated with increased risk of cardiovascular disease, diabetes, and various cancers. Whether MetS is a risk factor for ductal carcinoma in situ of the breast (DCIS), a nonobligate precursor of IBC, remains unknown.

In 47,420 spouse-pairs from the UK Biobank, we found a weak positive phenotypic correlation between spouses for self-reported sleep duration. Timing of diurnal activity was positively correlated in contrast to the inverse correlation for chronotype. Findings support the notion that an individual's sleep may impact that of their partner.

The study identified genetically inferred effects that are generalizable across large cohorts. Reduced gray matter volume of the right anterior superior temporal gyrus had direct effects on ANX. The right posterior middle cingulate gyrus was negatively associated with "tense, sore, or aching muscles during the worst period of anxiety"

Bartter syndrome is a group of rare genetic disorders that compromise kidney function by impairing electrolyte reabsorption. Left untreated, the resulting hyponatremia, hypokalemia, and dehydration can be fatal, and there is currently no cure. Bartter syndrome type II specifically arises from mutations in KCNJ1.

Clonal haematopoiesis of indeterminate potential (CHIP) is associated with atherosclerotic cardiovascular disease and heart failure. This study aimed to test the association of CHIP with new-onset arrhythmias.

Study included 477,190 participants from UK Biobank who were free of PD at baseline (2006-2010) During a median follow-up of 12.5 years, we identified 2550 incidences of PD. Family history of AD/dementia and polygenic risk score for AD (AD-PRS) were associated with PD risk.

PGS-Depot includes 5585 high quality summary statistics curated from 1564 traits in European and East Asian populations. A standardized best-practice pipeline is used to implement 11 summary statistics-based PGS methods. Users can also submit their own summary statistics to obtain custom PGS with the available methods.

Anterior Uveitis (AU) is the inflammation of the anterior part of the eye, the iris and ciliary body. AU is strongly associated with HLA-B*27. We identify common genome-wide significant loci in Hla-B and ERAP1.

Sarcopenia has been identified as a risk factor for increased mortality in individuals with CKD. However, the impact of sarcopenia on adverse outcomes, particularly mortality, remains uncertain. Study included 323 801 participants from the UK Biobank.

Study aimed to examine the independent and combined associations between functional and structural components of social connection and mortality. Social connection was assessed using two functional and three structural measures. Cox proportional hazard models were used to examine associations with all-cause and cardiovascular disease mortality.

Patients with rheumatoid arthritis (RA) have a 2- to 10-fold increased risk of cardiovascular disease (CVD) We examined the genetic correlation, shared genetics, and potential causality between RA and CVD using linkage disequilibrium score regression, cross-trait meta-analysis, and Mendelian randomization. We observed significant genetic correlations of RA with myocardial infarction (r g :0.40 [95% CI, 0.24-0.56), angina (rG:0.42 [95%) and coronary heart diseases (rGs: 0.41)

Asthma is a risk factor for coronary heart disease (CHD) and sex modifies the risk. Previous studies may have suffered from detection bias or residual confounding. To overcome these, we applied a "triangulation approach"

The transferability and clinical value of genetic risk scores (GRSs) across populations remain limited due to an imbalance in genetic studies across ancestrally diverse populations. Here we conducted a multi-ancestry genome-wide association study of 156,319 prostate cancer cases and 788,443 controls of European, African, Asian and Hispanic men.

There is limited evidence for the causal role of these risk factors. We used hospital and general practitioner records in UK Biobank. We identified one variant (rs429358) in APOE at genome-wide significance.

Long telomere length was associated with decreased risk of incident non-alcoholic fatty liver disease (NAFLD) TL partly mediated the association between age and NAFLD (proportion mediated: 15.52%). The highest risk was found in participants with low TL and old age. A positive interaction was observed between high PRS and low TL.

The developed deep learning model accurately predicted type 2 diabetes from neck-to-knee two-point Dixon MRI scans. The ensemble over multiple Dixon MRI stations yields better performance than selecting the individually best station. Integrating clinical information about known risk factors of diabetes in the network boosts the performance across all stations.

Proprotein convertase subtilisin/kexin type 9 (PCSK9) is a key regulator of lipid homeostasis. A few earlier genome-wide association studies (GWAS) investigated genetic variants associated with circulating PCSK9 concentrations. However, uncertainty remains about some of the genetic loci discovered. We aimed to identify novel loci and validate the previously reported loci.

It has been suggested that the timing of exercise is important in the subsequent development of hypertension. We used the UK Biobank database which prospectively collates data in over 500,000 people aged between 40 and 69 years to determine the relationship between the chronoactivity pattern of exercise and the risk of incident hypertension. Cluster 1 and Cluster 2 cases with High Intensity physical activity had a lower risk of hypertension; however, Low Int intensity physical activity in Cluster 1 still reduced the risk.

Anti-inflammatory trials have shown considerable benefits for cardiovascular disease. High neutrophil counts, an easily accessible inflammation biomarker, are associated with atherosclerosis in experimental studies. This study aimed to investigate the associations between neutrophill counts and risk of nine cardiovascular endpoints.

Study determined associations of regional fat depots and fat-free mass on left ventricular function and arterial stiffness to explain obesity-related cardiac dysfunction. Participants underwent whole body magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) and dual energy X-ray absorptiometry (DXA) in an ongoing imaging study of 100,000 individuals.

Different serum lipids and lipid-modifying targets should affect the risk of cholelithiasis. Whether such effects are causal is still controversial and we aimed to answer this question. We found that serum levels of LDL-C and HDL-C were inversely associated with choleLithiasis risk and such associations were linear. But the serum level of TC was non-linearly associated with the risk.

Few studies on the risk of incident major adverse cardiac and cerebrovascular events (MACCEs) in sarcopenia have been reported. The objective was to assess the association between presarcopenia and sarc Openia and a higher risk of MACCEs. Muscle strength was measured using HGS, and muscle mass using the SMI.

Real-world retinal optical coherence tomography (OCT) scans are available in abundance in primary and secondary eye care centres. The associated electronic health records alone are often not enough to generate a high-quality dataset for clinical, statistical, and machine learning analysis. We trained a two-stage convolutional neural network to classify macula-centered 3D volumes from Topcon OCT images.

Gut microbiota imbalances have been suggested as a contributing factor to atrial fibrillation (AF), but the causal relationship is not fully understood. Mediation MR analyses were conducted for AF risk factors including type 2 diabetes, coronary artery disease (CAD), body mass index (BMI), blood lipids, blood pressure, and obstructive sleep apnea. Genus Holdemania was associated with incident AF risk in the UK Biobank.

Study included 70 830 UK Biobank participants with physical activity measured by wrist-worn accelerometers. Participants were followed for a median of 6.8 years, during which 2795 CVD events were recorded. Compared with the low abdominal adiposity and highest tertile of physical activity, abdominal obesity was associated with higher risk of incident CVD.

Migration is selective, resulting in inequalities between migrants and nonmigrants. Combination pre- and post-migration data are rarely available. We propose an alternative approach to assessing internal migration selection by integrating genetic data.

Living close to the coast and air pollution were associated with a decreased risk of prostate cancer and skin melanoma, respectively. Findings support the role of the local environment on cancer development, which is independent from genetics.

Early life events and environmental factors are associated with type 2 diabetes (T2D) development. We assessed the combined effect of birth weight andambient air pollutants, and effect of their interaction on T2D risk.

People with mental disorders have worse physical health compared with the general population. This could be attributable to receiving poorer quality healthcare. People with schizophrenia had the highest (unadjusted) risk of hospital admission for ACSCs compared with those with no mental disorder.

The relation of social deprivation with single cardiometabolic disease (CMD) was widely investigated. We analyzed 345,417 UK Biobank participants without any CMDs at recruitment. 68,338 participants developed at least one CMD, 16,225 further developed CMM, and 18,876 ultimately died from all causes (median follow up of 13.4 years) Compared to Q1 of TDI (lowest deprivation), the multivariable adjusted HR (95%CIs) of Q4 (highest deprivation) was 1.23 (1.20 ~ 1.26) for developing CMD.

Some older individuals remain unaffected despite high predicted risk of ASCVD. These individuals may carry cardioprotective genetic variants that contribute to resilience. We identified 2 independent variants in the CETP (cholesteryl ester transfer protein) gene. Carriers of the identified variants (versus noncarriers) had higher plasma high-density lipoprotein cholesterol levels.

The associations of the Mediterranean-DASH Intervention for Neurodegenerative Delay (MIND) diet with brain structural changes are unclear. Among 26,466 UK Biobank participants, a 15-point MIND score was calculated from 24-hour diet recalls from 2009 to 2012. Higher MIND adherence was associated with larger volumes of thalamus, putamen, pallidum, hippocampus, and accumbens.

Study aimed to detect the joint and interactive associations of socioeconomic status (SES) and lifestyle factors with incident dementia risk, and the underlying brain imaging alterations. Participants with high SES and most healthy lifestyle had a significantly lower risk of incident dementia.

Obesity and dyslipidemia may be associated with hippocampal alterations and may increase the risk of neurodegeneration. This study studied hippocampal anatomical and functional association with a lipid profile based on high- density lipoprotein, low-density lipop protein, and triglyceride related to dys Lipidemia in obese and nonobese adults.

Study looked at association of miscarriage and stillbirth with coronary heart disease (CHD), stroke, heart failure, atrial fibrillation, and composite outcomes. Hypertension, DM, and lipoprotein metabolism disorders mediated the association between miscarriage and various cardiovascular outcomes in later life.

ExplaiNAble BioLogical Age (ENABL Age) combines machine-learning models with explainable artificial intelligence (XAI) methods to accurately estimate biological age. ENABL Age clock was significantly correlated with chronological age.

403045 participants from UK Biobank were enrolled in this study. A cross-lagged panel model was used to investigate the longitudinal reciprocal association between RA and COPD. Causal mediation analysis was performed to explore the mediating roles of 160 systemic inflammatory biomarkers in the bidirectional association.

Clonal hematopoiesis (CH) arises when a substantial proportion of mature blood cells is derived from a single stem cell lineage. Prevalence approaches 50% in elderly participants. Smoking demonstrates a dosage-dependent impact on risk of CH.

Study involved 408,886 participants from the UK Biobank. During a median follow-up of 8.7 years, 1492 incident CP-MM were ascertained. Individuals with obesity had a hazard ratio (HR) of 1.51 (95% confidence intervals [CI]: 1.30-1.75)

Many common neurological disorders are associated with advancing chronological age. But their association with biological age (BA) remains poorly understood. We studied 325 870 participants in the UK Biobank without a diagnosed neurological condition.

Proton pump inhibitors (PPIs) are widely prescribed for gastroesophageal reflux disease and peptic ulcer disease. The association between the regular PPIs use and the risk of cardiovascular disease (CVD) outcomes remains unclear.

Joint morphology is a risk factor for hip osteoarthritis (HOA) and could explain ethnic differences in HOA prevalence. We compared the prevalence of radiographic HOA and hip morphology between the predominantly White UK Biobank (UKB) and exclusively Chinese Shanghai Changfeng (SC) cohorts.

Parkin RBR E3 ubiquitin-protein ligase (PRKN) mutations are the most common cause of young onset and autosomal recessive Parkinson's disease (PD) PRKN is located in FRA6E, which is one of the common fragile sites in the human genome, making this region prone to structural variants. Complex structural variants such as inversions of PRKN are seldom reported.

Using the UK Biobank cohort, we evaluate the association between circadian rhythm-disrupting behaviours, blood pressure (SBP, DBP) and inflammatory markers in >350,000 adults with European white British ancestry. The independent U-shaped relationship between sleep length and SBP/DBP is most prominent with a low inflammatory status. Poor sleep quality and permanent night shift work are also positively associated with SBP and DBP.

We develop and validate ancestry-specific Polygenic Risk Scores (PRSs) for Coronary Artery Disease (CAD) The CAD PRSs outperform published scores with an average Odds Ratio per Standard Deviation of 1.57. Using this risk factor to reclassify borderline or intermediate 10 year Atherosclerotic Cardiovascular Disease (ASCVD) risk improves assessments.

It remains unknown whether the dietary diversity score (DDS) could modify the association of long-term exposure to individual air pollutants with the incidence, complications, and mortality of type 2 diabetes (T2D) We included 162,579 participants from the UK Biobank who had &#8805; one 24-h dietary assessment.

UK Biobank is a prospective cohort study of 0.5 million adults aged 40-69 years recruited between 2006 and 2010. Blood pressure, plasma lipids and dysglycaemia accounted for much of the observed excess risk.

Cardiovascular risk increases during menopause, so the medical and scientific community should consider women's specific risk factors to prevent cardiovascular disease. This study aims to assess the risk factors for the incidence of major adverse cardiovascular events (MACE) exclusive to postmenopausal women.

Previous research has found an association of low bone mineral density (BMD) and regional gray matter (GM) volume loss in Alzheimer's disease. We were interested whether BMD is associated with GM volume decrease in brains of a healthy elderly population from the UK Biobank.

Body composition has a sex-specific effect on type 2 diabetes, we found. In women, higher GFATadj and ALMadj exerted a causally protective effect. In men, higher VATadj and ASATadj were found to be riskier in glycaemic traits.

The human leukocyte antigen (HLA) region on chromosome 6 is strongly associated with many immune-mediated and infection-related diseases. Traditional genetic association studies of single nucleotide polymorphisms do not perform well in this region.
