Here, we use whole-exome sequencing (WES) from 454,824 UK Biobank participants to directly call HLA alleles using the HLA-HD algorithm.

Little is known about the persistence of antibodies after the first year following SARS-CoV-2 infection. We aimed to determine the proportion of individuals that maintain detectable levels of Sars-Cov-2 antibodies over an 18-month period following infection.

Heart rate variability (HRV) is a cardiac autonomic marker with predictive value in cardiac patients. Ultra-short HRV can be measured at scale using standard and wearable ECGs, but its association with cardiovascular events in the general population is undetermined. We aimed to validate usHRV measured using &#8804; 15-s ECGs (using RMSSD, SDSD and PHF indices)

Previous studies have shown that excessive screen time is associated with an increased prevalence of dementia, Parkinson's disease (PD), and depression. This study aimed to prospectively investigate the association between different types of screen time and brain structure, as well as the incidence of these diseases.

Risk of second primary cancers is increasing after the first primary cancers (FPC) are diagnosed and treated. The underlying causal relationship remains unclear. We conducted a pan-cancer association study in the Surveillance, Epidemiology, and End Results (SEER) database.

Forearm fractures are the most common clinically recognized osteoporotic fractures with a relatively high heritability. We identified 43 loci, including 26 new fracture loci. Tall stature and low body mass index were identified as new causal risk factors. The insights from this atlas may improve fracture prediction and enable therapeutic development to prevent fractures.

Hand osteoarthritis is a common heterogeneous joint disorder with unclear molecular mechanisms and no disease-modifying drugs. We performed single-cell RNA sequencing analysis to compare the cellular composition and subpopulation-specific gene expression between cartilage with and without the disease. Both inflammatory and fibrocartilage chondrocytes showed a trend toward increased numbers of iron overload-related genes.

Study included 462,524 participants from the UK Biobank with a follow-up of 13.6 years. Participants' screen-based sedentary activities time was categorized into three groups based on recorded time. TV viewing 2-3 h/day correlated with a higher risk of all-cause dementia.

Dupuytren disease is associated with significant comorbidity and mortality. It is unclear which modifiable risk factors are most amenable for prevention. This study aimed to determine the strength of modifiablerisk factors.

Study of 2151 people with MS and 486,125 controls using data from a longitudinal cohort (UK Biobank) Exposures associated with MS were childhood obesity, smoking and earlier menarche. Autosomal polygenic risk score (PRS) was associated with disease status. Evidence of synergistic interaction between PRS and both childhood obesity and smoking.

Mild vision impairment is common in middle aged UK adults, despite widespread use of spectacles. Older adults, those from low socioeconomic and ethnic minority backgrounds were most at risk for vision problems. Optometrists should consider screening for hearing problems, particularly among older adults.

M&#233;ni&#232;re's disease was more common in participants who were older (adjusted odds ratio per 10-year increase: 1.5 [95% confidence interval:1.4-1.6]), white and female. Associations were noted with a number of diseases, and the authors hypothesize a role for the autonomic nervous system and immune system dysfunction.

The current standard measure of hearing, the pure-tone audiogram is not very cognitively demanding. We analysed data from UK Biobank that asked 40-69 year olds about their hearing, and assessed their ability on tests of speech-in-noise hearing and cognition.

Physical activity is thought to protect against obesity, but the evidence is limited. We examined the association of self-reported physical activity with measures of total and central adiposity. The study included 38,201 premenopausal and 94,592 postmenopausal healthy women aged 40 to 70 years in UK Biobank.

The built environment (BE) has emerged as one of the 'first causes' of chronic disease, capable of explaining its socio-spatial variation. There is an increasing need for objective, detailed and precise measurements of attributes of BE.

There is a general perception that smoking protects against weight gain. This may influence commencement and continuation of smoking, especially among young women. Logistic regression analyses were used to explore the association between smoking and obesity.

Cross-sectional data from the UK Biobank were used to compare 1,327 self-reported M&#233;ni&#232;re's cases with 479,500 controls. The authors used logistic regression models to investigate the relation of the disease with the components of adult height.

M&#233;ni&#232;re's disease is an unpredictable illness that impacts on mental health. The symptom triad of vertigo, tinnitus, and hearing loss all contribute to the disabling nature of the condition. To date, limited research has investigated the mental health and SWB impact of the disease.

Early puberty timing is associated with higher risks for type 2 diabetes (T2D) and cardiovascular disease in women. We characterised the range of diseases and other adverse health outcomes associated with early or late puberty timing in men and women.

Study of UK residents aged 40-69 years registered with the National Health Service. Data were collected on visual acuity, intraocular pressure (IOP), corneal biomechanics, and questionnaire from 112 690 participants.

Study used UK Biobank data to study the genetic causes of smoking behaviour and lung health. Found shared genetic causes between different phenotypes defined by extremes of FEV1.

Chronic pain and depression reporting varies across ethnic groups. Differences in health seeking behaviour between ethnic groups may impact on the results reported. Clinicians need to be aware of the cultural barriers within certain ethic groups to expressing concern over mood.

Birth weight, age at menarche and height, but not BMI, were highly significantly associated with season of birth. Individuals born in summer (June-July-August) had higher mean birth weight and later pubertal development. Those born in winter (December-January-February) showed directionally opposite differences in these outcomes.

Lung function measures are used in the diagnosis of chronic obstructive pulmonary disease. We studied genome-wide association of forced expiratory volume in 1 s (FEV1), forced vital capacity (FVC) and FEV1/FVC with 1000 Genomes Project (phase 1)-imputed genotypes.

We used linkage disequilibrium regression and polygenic profile scoring to test for shared genetic aetiology between cognitive functions and neuropsychiatric disorders and physical health. Substantial and significant genetic correlations were observed between cognitive test scores in the UK Biobank sample.

Coronary artery disease (CAD) is associated with cognitive decrements and risk of later dementia. It is not known if shared genetic factors underlie this association. We tested whether polygenic risk for CAD was associated with Cognitive ability in community-dwelling cohorts.

Several regions of the genome have shown to be associated with COPD. Study identified several associations with the risk of COPD and severity of airflow limitation. Novel regions MOCS3, IFIT3 and SERPINA12 warrant further study.

Mendelian randomisation study to test for causal effects of differences in stature and BMI on five measures of socioeconomic status. Study looked at 119,669 men and women of British ancestry, aged between 37 and 73 years. Shorter stature and higher BMI were observationally associated with several measures of lower socioeconomic status in the study.

Genome-wide association (GWA) studies have identified hundreds of common genetic variants associated with obesity and type 2 diabetes. Identifying deviations from additivity may provide new biological insights and explain some of the missing heritability for these diseases.

COPD is a leading cause of morbidity and mortality worldwide. UK Biobank cohort recruited 502 649 adults aged 40-69 years. Of 353 occupations reported by 228 614 current working participants, several showed significantly increased COPD risk.

Neuroticism is a personality trait of fundamental importance for psychological well-being and public health. It is strongly associated with major depressive disorder (MDD) and several other psychiatric conditions. Although neuroticism is heritable, attempts to identify the alleles involved in previous studies have been limited by relatively small sample sizes.

People with higher levels of neuroticism have an increased risk of several types of mental disorder. Higher neuroticism has also been associated, less consistently, with an increase in risk of various physical health outcomes. We hypothesised that these associations may, in part, be due to shared genetic influences.

M&#233;ni&#232;re's was estimated to cost between &#163;541.30 million and &# 163;608.70 million annually (equivalent to US $829.9 to $934.2 million) In the UK, the annual cost of this condition is substantial. Further research is required to develop cost-effective treatments and management strategies to reduce the economic burden.

It is unclear whether the potential benefits of physical activity differ according to level of cardiorespiratory fitness (CRF) or strength. The aim of this study was to determine whether the association between physical activity and mortality is moderated by CRF and grip strength sufficiently to inform health promotion strategies.

Analysis of the heritability of 12 complex diseases in 1,555,906 individuals from the UK Biobank. SNP heritability explains a higher proportion of estimated heritability.

The role sex determination plays in human genetic variation remains unclear. The presence of gene-by-sex (GxS) interactions implies that trait genetic architecture differs between men and women. We show that GxS interactions and genetic heterogeneity among sexes are small but common features of a range of high-level complex traits.

Little is known about the effect of copy number variants (CNVs) on lung function. CNVs represent a significant proportion of human genetic polymorphism. We measured copy number at 2788 previously characterised, common copy number variable regions in 6 independent cohorts.

About half of the variation in wellbeing measures overlaps with variation in personality traits. Studies of non-human primate pedigrees and human twins suggest that this is due to common genetic influences. We tested whether personality polygenic scores for the NEO Five-Factor Inventory (NEO-FFI) domains and for item response theory (IRT) derived extraversion and neuroticism scores predict wellbeing measures.

Experimental work has shown better visuospatial working memory (VSWM) in profoundly deaf individuals compared to those with normal hearing. Other data, including the UK Biobank resource shows poorer VSWM in individuals with poorer hearing. Using the same database, the authors investigated VSWm in individuals who reported profound deafness.

The UK Biobank combines detailed phenotyping and genotyping with tracking of long-term health outcomes in a large cohort. Results from the first 5,000 subjects are reported, including thousands of associations.

Quantitative and accurate measurements of fat and muscle in the body are important for prevention and diagnosis of diseases related to obesity and muscle degeneration. Manually segmenting muscle and fat compartments in MR body-images is laborious and time-consuming, hindering implementation in large cohorts. In the present study, the feasibility and success-rate of a Dixon-based MR scan followed by an intensity-normalised, non-rigid, multi-atlas based segmentation was investigated in a cohort of 3,000 subjects.

Caffeine is the most widely consumed psychoactive substance in the world. It presents with wide interindividual variation in metabolism. This variation may modify potential adverse or beneficial effects of caffeine on health. We conducted a genome-wide association study (GWAS) of plasma caffeine, paraxanthine, theophylline and theobromine.

In UK Biobank, OCT images were acquired between 2009 and 2010 using a commercially available "spectral domain" OCT device. Rapid, automated analysis of retinal thickness was performed using custom image segmentation software developed by the Topcon Advanced Biomedical Imaging Laboratory (TABIL)

Analysis of 113,851 UK Biobank samples showed that population structure in the UK is dominated by five principal components. Analyses of ancient Eurasians revealed that populations in the northern UK have higher levels of Steppe ancestry. UK population structure cannot be explained as a simple mixture of Celts and Saxons.

 meta-analysis of data from over 300,000 individuals for age at first birth and number of children ever born. They identify 12 significant loci that associate with these traits.

Study was conducted using the UK Biobank resource, a population-based cohort of 40- to 69-year olds. Data on tinnitus (presence, persistence, and related distress) and on sleep difficulties were analyzed using logistic regression models.

High circulating levels of the branched-chain amino acids (BCAAs) strongly associated with higher type 2 diabetes risk. Genome-wide studies of BCAA levels in 16,596 individuals revealed five genomic regions associated at genome-wide levels of significance.

Genomic analyses have suggested that the LPA gene and its associated plasma biomarker, lipoprotein(a) (Lp[a), represent a causal risk factor for coronary heart disease (CHD) This study aimed to establish the full phenotypic impact of LPAGene variation and to estimate a dose-response curve. One SD genetically lowered Lp(a), we found, was associated with a 29% lower risk of CHD.

Manual identification of signal and noise after ICA decomposition is required for efficient data denoising. We present a practical "how-to" guide to help determine whether single-subject fMRI independent components (ICs) characterise structured noise.

As genetic association studies increase in size to 100 000s of individuals, subtle biases may influence conclusions. One possible bias is 'index event bias' (IEB) that appears due to the stratification by, or enrichment for, disease status. We aimed to test the extent to which IEB influences some known trait associations.

Previous studies have suggested that modern obesogenic environments accentuate the genetic risk of obesity. However, these studies have proven controversial as to which, if any, measures of the environment accentuate genetic susceptibility to high body mass index (BMI) We used up to 120 000 adults from the UK Biobank study to test the hypothesis.

The prevalence of chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD) is increasing faster among women than among men. We analyzed 149,075 women and 100,252 men taking part in the UK Biobank. The association of airflow obstruction with smoking characteristics was assessed by sex.

Lung cancer risk prediction models have been developed, but none to date have assessed the predictive ability of lung function in a population-based cohort. We sought to develop and internally validate a model incorporating lung function using data from the UK Biobank prospective cohort study.

Physical activity has not been objectively measured in prospective cohorts with sufficiently large numbers to reliably detect associations with multiple health outcomes. Technological advances now make this possible. We describe the methods used to collect and analyse accelerometer measured physical activity in over 100,000 participants of the UK Biobank study.

 Height is a highly heritable, classic polygenic trait with approximately 700 common associated variants identified through genome-wide association studies so far. Here, we report 83 height-associated coding variants with lower minor-allele frequencies (in the range of 0.1-4.8%) and effects of up to 2 centimetres per allele. These variants overlap genes that are mutated in monogenic growth disorders.

In observational studies, abdominal adiposity has been associated with type 2 diabetes and coronary heart disease (CHD) Whether these associations represent causal relationships remains uncertain. We tested the association of a polygenic risk score for waist-to-hip ratio (WHR) adjusted for body mass index (BMI), a measure of abdominalÂ adiposity, with typeÂ 2 diabetes and CHD through the potential intermediates of blood lipids, blood pressure, and glycemic phenotypes.

Self-reported tiredness and low energy are associated with poorer physical and mental health. Twin studies have indicated that this has a heritability between 6 and 50%. In the UK Biobank sample (N=108 976), we carried out a genome-wide association study (GWAS)

The health impairments derived from both alcoholism and obesity are well known. However, reports that relate increased alcohol use with increased measures of obesity have been mixed in their findings. Here, using a large sample of adults from the UK, we report both observed and genetic correlations between BMI (kg/m2) and two measures of alcohol use.

UK Biobank study is an ongoing prospective cohort of >0.5 million UK adults aged 40-69 y. Baseline data collection included measurements of GS and adiposity indicators, including body mass index (BMI; in kg/m 2 ). Age- and sex-specific GS quintiles were used. Obesity class II was associated with a greater all-cause mortality risk.

Cross-sectional data from 119,859 white European adults, aged 37-73 y, participating in the UK Biobank. Interactions of GPRS-obesity and sleep characteristics (sleep duration, chronotype, day napping, and shift work) with effects on BMI and WC were investigated.

Mendelian randomization can test for and estimate the causal effect of an exposure on an outcome. Most IV methods assume that the function relating the exposure to the expected value of the outcome is linear. We present two novel IV methods for investigating the shape of the exposure-outcome relationship.

UK Biobank is the world's largest repository for phenotypic and genotypic information for individuals of European ancestry. We identified 3290 VTE cases and 116 868 controls through billing code-based phenotyping. We performed a phenome-wide association study for a genetic risk score of 10 VTE-associated variants. In a Mendelian randomization analysis, genetically elevated body mass index was associated with 57% higher risk of VTE.

A common missense variant in the gene encoding a component of the sulfonylurea receptor ( ABCC8  p.A1369S) promotes closure of the target channel of sulfonyLurea therapy. The variant was associated with increased BMI but lower waist-to-hip ratio adjusted for BMI.

Genotype data on &#8764;370,000 women and identify 389 independent signals that associate with age at menarche, implicating genes. Their analyses suggest causal inverse associations between puberty timing and risks for breast and endometrial cancers in women and prostate cancer in men.

UK Biobank participants were recruited and baseline measures were taken between 2007 and 2010. Self-report questionnaires were used to measure lifestyle behaviours. Six groups were defined based on BMI; 'Underweight', 'Normal weight', 'Overweight' and 'Obese'

Residential greenness was independently and consistently associated with lower adiposity. Residing in greener areas was associated with healthy weight outcomes possibly through a physical activity-related mechanism. Green allocation and design may act as upstream-level public health interventions.

Leisure screen time, including TV viewing, is associated with increased mortality risk. We estimated the all-cause mortality risk reductions associated with substituting leisure screen time with different discretionary physical activity types. Reallocations from screen time into specific activity subtypes suggested different reductions in mortality hazard.

Coronary artery disease (CAD) is the major cause of morbidity and mortality in the world. Identification of novel genetic determinants may provide new opportunities for developing innovative strategies to predict, prevent and treat CAD.

Using targeted and whole-exome sequencing, we studied 32 human and 87 rodent obesity genes in 2,548 severely obese children and 1,117 controls. We identified 52 variants contributing to obesity in 2% of cases including multiple novel variants in GNAS. Nominally significant associations were found for rare functional variants in BBS1, BBS9, GNAS, MKKS, CLOCK and ANGPTL6.

Matthew Robinson, Peter Visscher and colleagues use phenotypic data on 172,000 sibling pairs. They conclude that substantially larger sample sizes will be required to understand the full genetic architecture of this trait.

Hand grip strength is a widely used proxy of muscular fitness, a marker of frailty, and predictor of a range of morbidities and all-cause mortality. We perform a large-scale genetic discovery analysis in a combined sample of 195,180 individuals and identify 16 loci associated with grip strength.

The relationship between insomnia symptoms and cognitive performance is unclear, particularly at the population level. We conducted the largest examination of this association to date through analysis of the UK Biobank, a large population-based sample of adults aged 40-69.

Impairments in reading and in language have negative consequences on life outcomes. It is not known to what extent genetic effects influence this association. We constructed polygenic scores for difficulties with language and learning to read from genome-wide data in 6,600 children, adolescents and young adults. Polygenic risk of reading difficulties was associated with reduced income, educational attainment and self-rated health.

Sekar Kathiresan and colleagues perform a genome-wide association test for coronary artery disease (CAD) Using data from the UK Biobank, they identify 15 new loci. They implicate insulin resistance pathways and transendothelial migration.

Previous reports of altered grey and white matter structure in Major Depressive Disorder (MDD) have been inconsistent. In this study, we tested for differences in subcortical grey matter volume between depressed individuals and controls in the subset of 8590 UK Biobank Imaging study participants who had undergone depression assessments. Significant reductions were found in depressed individuals versus controls in global white matter integrity.

We estimated genotype by environment interaction (G Ã— E) on later cognitive performance and educational attainment across four unique environments. We used a novel design and statistical approach that was facilitated by the availability of datasets with the genome-wide single nucleotide polymorphisms (SNPs) There was significant G Ã— E for both fluid intelligence (p-value = 1.0E-03) and educational. attainment (p -value = 8.3E-05) in the group of individuals who were breastfed without maternal smoking.

Cognitive ability is a heritable trait with a polygenic architecture. Haplotype-based analyses are a complementary technique that take phased genotype data into account. None of the assessed haplotypes provided evidence of a statistically significant association with cognitive ability in the individual cohorts or the meta-analysis.

Hispanic/Latino Americans are a diverse and understudied population. Hypertension prevalence varies between ethnic groups, possibly due to differences in genetic, environmental, and cultural determinants. We investigated whether previously reported loci associated with BP in studies of European, African, and Asian ancestry generalize to Hispanics/Latinos.

Previous genome-wide association studies (GWAS) have identified hundreds of genetic loci to be associated with BMI and risk of obesity. In this study, we examine gene-environment interactions in 362,496 unrelated participants with Caucasian ancestry from the UK Biobank resource. 15 lifestyle factors were observed to interact with GSBMI.

For most traits and diseases the prediction R-squared (R-sq.) achieved with genetic scores remains considerably lower than the trait heritability. Modern biobanks will soon deliver unprecedentedly large biomedical data sets. Will the advent of big data close the gap between the trait. heritability and the proportion of variance that can be explained by a genomic predictor? We addressed this question using Bayesian methods and a data analysis approach.

The Trail Making Test is a widely used test of executive function. It has been thought to be strongly associated with general cognitive function. We examined the genetic architecture of the TMT and its shared genetic aetiology with other tests of cognitive function in 23 821 participants from UK Biobank.

Inadequate sleep (&#8804;6 and &#8805;9h) is more prevalent in smokers than non-smokers. We investigated the extent to which sleep duration predicted smoking behaviors and quitting intention in a population sample. Worsening sleep duration (adequate to inadequate) predicted a more than three-fold higher odds in increased cigarettes per day.

A reference panel of 1,000 individuals is adequate for a GWAS cohort of up to 10,000. Smaller panels, such as those from the 1000 Genomes Project, should be avoided. The size of the reference panel needs to scale with the GWAS sample size.

Genome-wide association studies have recently identified >400 loci that harbor DNA sequence variants that influence blood pressure (BP) Earlier studies identified 56 single nucleotide variants (SNVs) associated with BP from meta-analyses of exome chip genotype data. An additional 100 variants yielded suggestive evidence of association.

Nicotine dependence is a heritable trait with established associations with sequence variants in nicotine acetylcholine receptor genes and at other loci. We conducted a genome-wide association study (GWAS) meta-analysis of nicotine dependence, totaling 38,602 smokers across 15 studies. We reconfirmed the well-known CHRNA5-CHRNA3-CHRNB4 genes and yielded a novel association in the DNA methyltransferase gene DNMT3B.

A genetic predisposition to enhanced nitric oxide signaling is associated with reduced risks of coronary heart disease, peripheral arterial disease, and stroke. Conversely, rare variants that inactivate the NOS3 or GUCY1A3 genes were associated with a 23 mm Hg higher systolic blood pressure. Pharmacological stimulation of nitricoxide signaling may prove useful in the prevention or treatment of cardiovascular disease.

Active commuting (AC) was reported by 5.5% of participants, with the great majority using the car to commute. AC was associated with reduced sedentary time. Deprivation and distance from home to work were identified as correlates of AC behaviour. Rates of AC are very low in adults with type 2 diabetes.

Using genome-wide association meta-analysis of 606,059 parents' survival, we discover two regions associated with longevity (HLA-DQA1/DRB1 and LPA) We also validate previous suggestions that APOE, CHRNA3/5, CDKN2A/B, SH2B3 and FOXO3A influence longevity. Giving up smoking, educational attainment, openness to new experience and high-density lipoprotein (HDL) cholesterol levels are most positively genetically correlated with lifespan.

Iiopathic pulmonary fibrosis (IPF) is a chronic progressive lung disease with high mortality, uncertain cause, and few treatment options. Studies have identified a significant genetic risk associated with the development of IPF; however, mechanisms by which genetic risk factors promote IPF remain unclear. We aimed to identify genetic variants associated with IPF susceptibility and provide mechanistic insight.

Previous physical activity (PA) research in schizophrenia has relied largely upon self-report measures. Obtaining accurate measurements, and determining what may influence PA levels in schizophrenia, is essential to understand physical inactivity in this population. This study examined differences in self-reported and objectively measured PA in people with schizophrenia and the general population.

UK Biobank is a large-scale prospective epidemiological study with all data accessible to researchers worldwide. It is currently in the process of bringing back 100,000 of the original participants for brain, heart and body MRI and carotid ultrasound.

Exome-wide genetic analysis on >300,000 individuals identifies associations with plasma lipid traits. Loci significantly associated with cholesterol and triglycerides are examined together.

This large-scale genome-wide association analysis of subjects with asthma, hay fever or eczema provides insights into the shared genetic basis of these allergic diseases. The findings suggest these diseases partly co-occur because they share many genetic risk variants that dysregulate the expression of immune-related genes.

 Methods for genetic risk prediction have been widely investigated in recent years. Most available training data involves European samples, and it is currently unclear how to accurately predict disease risk in other populations. Here, we introduce a multiethnic polygenic risk score that combines trainingData from European samples and training data from the target population.

Male pattern baldness (MPB) or androgenetic alopecia is one of the most common conditions affecting men. The known genes explain little of the heritability. We present the results of a genome-wide association study including more than 70,000 men, identifying 71 independently replicated loci.

Genome-wide association studies using genotype data have had limited success in the identification of variants associated with major depressive disorder. Haplotype data provide an alternative method for detecting associations between variants in weak linkage disequilibrium with genotyped variants and a given trait of interest. A genome-wide haplotype association study for MDD was undertaken.

13 250 (3.5%) of 379 511 white European individuals in UK Biobank had developed diabetes in the first six decades of life. 1286 more cases of diabetes were in the half of the population with high genetic susceptibility to type 1 diabetes.

Genome-wide single-nucleotide polymorphism variation contributes substantially to AF risk. Risk for AF conferred by genomic variation is similar to that observed for several other cardiovascular diseases. Established AF loci only explain a moderate proportion of disease risk.

We undertook a genome-wide association study (GWAS) of parental longevity in European descent UK Biobank participants. For combined mothers' and fathers' attained age, 10 loci were associated (p -8 ), including 8 previously identified for traits including survival, Alzheimer's and cardiovascular disease.

Coronary artery disease (CAD) is a complex phenotype driven by genetic and environmental factors. Ninety-seven genetic risk loci have been identified to date, but the identification of additional susceptibility loci might be important to enhance our understanding of the genetic architecture of CAD.

Study analysed UK Biobank data from 489 079 participants. Crude diabetes prevalence was higher in men across all four ethnicities. After standardizing for age, SES, BMI and lifestyle factors, a significant sex difference in diabetes prevalence persisted.

High blood pressure (BP) is a major risk factor for cardiovascular diseases (CVDs) Both heritable and lifestyle risk factors contribute to elevated BP levels. We aimed to investigate the extent to which lifestyle factors could offset the effect of an adverse BP genetic profile.

Genome-wide association studies have identified >250 loci for body mass index (BMI) Most GWAS loci represent clusters of common, noncoding variants from which pinpointing causal genes remains challenging. Here we combined data from 718,734 individuals to discover rare and low-frequency (minor allele frequency (MAF)

To date, genetic variants in more than 60 loci have been identified as associated with BMD. We identified variants associated with TB-BMD at 80 loci, of which 36 have not been previously identified. Only variants in ESR1 and close proximity to RANKL showed a clear effect dependency on age.

Gliomas are the most common type of malignant primary brain tumor. Few risk factors have been linked to their development. Handedness has been associated with several pathologic neurological conditions such as schizophrenia, autism, and epilepsy.

By reanalyzing publicly available type 2 diabetes (T2D) genome-wide association studies (GWAS) data for 70,127 subjects, we identify seven novel associated regions. Five of the regions are driven by common variants (LYPLAL1, NEUROG3, CAMKK2, ABO, and GIP genes), one by a low-frequency (EHMT2), and one driven by a rare variant in chromosome Xq23 (rs146662075)

Much of the evidence about the effects of education comes from observational studies. We exploit the raising of the minimum school leaving age in the UK in September 1972 as a natural experiment. We found consistent evidence that remaining in school causally reduced the risk of diabetes and mortality in all specifications.

UK Biobank is a large prospective cohort comprising 502,637 men and women aged 40-69 years. History of fracture was self-reported, and details of hospital admissions for ischaemic heart disease (IHD) (ICD-10:I20-I25) were obtained through linkage to UK Hospital Episode Statistics. Cox proportional hazards models were used to investigate relationships between prior fracture and hospital admission.

Aortic valve stenosis (AS) is the most common valvular heart disease. We identify two new AS loci, on chromosome 1p21 near PALMD (rs7543130) and on chromosome 2q22 in TEX41 (rs1830321) The results implicate both cardiac developmental abnormalities and atherosclerosis-like processes in the pathogenesis of AS.

Physical activity levels and sedentary behaviours are inversely associated with colorectal cancer risk. Whether these relationships are consistent across anatomical subsites is uncertain. We investigated the associations between coloreCTal cancer and physical activity (metabolic equivalents (METs)-hours per week), and indicators of sedentary behaviour.

Medications that relax this sphincter could promote cancer. These medications were investigated in two independent datasets. None of the medications investigated were significantly associated with oesophageal cancer risk apart from &#946;2 agonists.

We used the UK Biobank resource to develop genetic predictors of height. We applied these in a Mendelian randomisation framework to estimate the causal relationship between height and cancer. We found that each genetically predicted 9 cm increase in height conferred an odds ratio of 1.10. For both risk and mortality, the effect was larger in females than in males.

Little is known about the combined associations of cardiorespiratory fitness (CRF) and hand grip strength (GS) with mortality in general adult populations. In UK Biobank, a prospective cohort of > 0.5 million adults aged 40-69 years, CRF was measured through submaximal bike tests; GS was measured using a hand-dynamometer.

Heritability is a fundamental parameter in genetics. Traditional estimates based on family or twin studies can be biased due to shared environmental or non-additive genetic variance. We applied an IBD-based approach to estimate heritability in unrelated individuals using phenotypic simulation.

Elevated intraocular pressure (IOP) is a significant risk factor for glaucoma, the leading cause of irreversible blindness worldwide. Previous studies have identified numerous genetic variants associated with IOP, but these loci only explain a fraction of IOP heritability. Here, we describe the largest genome-wide association study to date using participants of European ancestry from the UK Biobank.

We used UK Biobank data to examine the associations of four dietary patterns with frailty. We also examined whether metabolic signatures (MSs) mediate these associations. Four dietary patterns were independently associated withFrailty (all P   e.g. fatty acids, lipoproteins, acetate and glycoprotein acetyls) The MSs based on these metabolites partially mediated the association of these patterns.

Individual risk of type 2 diabetes (T2D) is modified by perturbations to the mass, distribution and function of adipose tissue. To investigate the mechanisms underlying these associations, we explored the molecular, cellular and whole-body effects of T2D-associated alleles near KLF14.

Protein-truncating variants can have profound effects on gene function. Their relevance to medical phenotypes has not been systematically assessed. We find several genes with strong pleiotropic or non-additive effects.

Nonalcoholic fatty liver disease (NAFLD) is a major cause of liver damage and has a strong genetic component. The rs4841132 G>A variant, modulating the expression of protein phosphatase 1 regulatory subunit 3B ( PPP1R3B ), has been reported to reduce the risk of NAFLD but at the same time may favor liver disease by facilitating glycogen accumulation. We assessed the impact of the variant on development of histologic steatosis and fibrosis in 1,388 European individuals.

Multiple methods have been developed to estimate narrow-sense heritability, h2, using single nucleotide polymorphisms (SNPs) in unrelated individuals. We present the most thorough and realistic comparison of these methods to date. We show that SNP-heritability can be highly sensitive to assumptions about the frequencies, effect sizes and levels of linkage disequilibrium of underlying causal variants.

Risk-taking propensity is a trait of significant public health relevance but few specific genetic factors are known. Here we perform a genome-wide association study of self-reported risk- taking propensity among 436,236 white European UK Biobank study participants. We identify genome- wide associations at 26 loci (P)

The genetic and genomic basis of sex differences in blood pressure (BP) traits remain unstudied at scale. We conducted sex-stratified and combined-sex genome-wide association studies of BP traits using the UK Biobank resource. Among associated loci, 412 were female-specific and 142 were male-specific. These sex-specific loci were enriched for hormone-related transcription factors.

Genetic correlation is a key population parameter that describes the shared genetic architecture of complex traits and diseases. It can be estimated by current state-of-art methods, i.e., linkage disequilibrium score regression (LDSC) and genomic restricted maximum likelihood (GREML) The massively reduced computing burden of LDSC compared to GREML makes it an attractive tool.

 limited knowledge exists regarding the long-term risk of mental disorders among individuals who have experienced pregnancy loss. In the UK Biobank, a total of 218,990 women without any mental disorder at baseline were enrolled between 2006 and 2010 and followed until October 2022. Incidence rates of common mental disorders were elevated among women with a history of stillbirth, miscarriage or pregnancy termination.

We assessed the causal relation of four glycemic traits and type 2 diabetes liability with 167 metabolites. Fasting glucose and 2-h glucose were not associated with any metabolite. Higher glycated hemoglobin was associated with higher free cholesterol in small low-density lipoprotein.

Heredity plays an important role in the etiology of varicose veins (VVs) However, the genetic basis underlying this condition remains poorly understood. Our aim was to replicate top association signals from genome-wide association studies (GWASs) for VVs of lower extremities.

The problem of the genetics of related phenotypes is often addressed by analyzing adjusted-model traits. Here, we adopt a joint view of adiposity traits in ~322,154 subjects. We classify 159 signals associated with body mass index (BMI), waist-to-hip ratio (WHR), or WHR adjusted for BMI (WHRadjBMI) at P.

Population studies have been limited to European ancestries. This may have overlooked possible key genes poorly captured by common European genetic variation. Here, we report 26 loci (all P)

Diabetes patients are at higher risk for mortality than the general population. Little is known about whether the excess mortality risk associated with diabetes could be mitigated or nullified via controlling for risk factors.

 summary statistics from genome-wide meta-analyses are available for hundreds of traits. Updating these to ever-increasing reference panels is very cumbersome. A much more efficient method is to directly impute the summary statistics, termed as summary statistics imputation. Its performance relative to genotype imputation and practical utility has not yet been fully investigated.

General cognitive function is a prominent and relatively stable human trait that is associated with many important life outcomes. We combine cognitive and genetic data from the CHARGE and COGENT consortia, and UK Biobank (total N = 300,486; age 16-102) and find 148 genome-wide significant independent loci.

Developal dysplasia of the hip (DDH) is the most common skeletal developmental disease. Its genetic architecture is poorly understood. We find the heritable component of DDH attributable to common genetic variants to be 55% and distributed equally across the autosomal and X-chromosomes.

A sex-specific competing risk-adjusted Cox proportional hazards model was derived in individuals with type 1 diabetes without prior CVD. Predictors included age at diabetes onset, smoking status, body mass index, systolic blood pressure, glycated haemoglobin level and estimated glomerular filtration rate.

Sarcopenia refers to age-related loss of muscle mass and function. It is related to impaired somatic and brain health, including cognitive decline and Alzheimer's disease. The relationships between sarcopenia, brain structure and cognition are poorly understood. We show that sarcopenic traits are associated with lower cognitive performance and various brain magnetic resonance imaging measures.

The effect of a healthy lifestyle on dementia associated with multimorbidity is not well understood. We utilized data from the UK Biobank cohort. A comprehensive healthy lifestyle score was generated.

Cholelithiasis is a common digestive disease that drives a myriad of adverse complications. The correlation between sarcopenia and various digestive disorders has been extensively researched. We aimed to investigate the association through prospective and Mendelian randomization (MR) analyses.

Large-scale genome-wide association studies (GWAS) strongly suggest that most traits and diseases have a polygenic component. This observation has led to an interest in "polygenic longevity scores (PLS)" that quantify the "risk" or genetic predisposition of an individual towards health. We argue that PLS are made up of variants not only robustly associated with parental lifespan, but also contribute to the genetic architecture of disease susceptibility, morbidity, and mortality.

We have undertaken a systematic Mendelian randomization (MR) study using methylation quantitative trait loci (meQTL) to assess the relationship between genetic variation, DNA methylation and 139 complex traits. Using two-sample MR, we identified 1148 associations across 61 traits where genetic variants were associated with both proximal DNAmethylation and complex trait variation.

The identification of suitable biomarkers is of crucial clinical importance for the early diagnosis of treatment-resistant schizophrenia (TRS) This study aims to comprehensively analyze the association between TRS and blood and urine biomarkers.

Most sequence variants identified hitherto in genome-wide association studies (GWAS) of atrial fibrillation are common, non-coding variants associated with risk through unknown mechanisms. We observe associations with one missense and one splice-donor variant (OR = 1.50) in RPL3L, the first ribosomal gene implicated to our knowledge.

Heavy alcohol consumption is an established risk factor for hypertension. The mechanism by which alcohol consumption impact blood pressure (BP) regulation remains unknown. We conducted a large two-stage investigation incorporating joint testing of main genetic effects and single nucleotide variant (SNV)-alcohol consumption interactions.

Low haemoglobin and anaemia are associated with poor cognition. anaemia is known to be associated with Alzheimer's disease (AD), but the mechanism of this risk is unknown. Here, we first seek to confirm the association between cognition and anemia. We then estimate the direction of causation using Mendelian randomisation.

A previous study of 200,000 exome-sequenced UK Biobank participants had implicated four genes, LDLR, PCSK9, APOC3 and IFITM5. In addition, a further 43 protein-coding genes were significant.

The negative impacts of social isolation and loneliness on health are well documented. Little is known about their possible biological determinants. In up to 452,302 UK Biobank study participants, we perform genome-wide association study analyses for loneliness.

Coffee consumption was inversely associated with gout. The urate-increasing GCKR, ABCG2, MLXIPL, and CYP1A2 alleles were associated with reduced daily coffee consumption.

Macronutrient intake is an important risk factor for metabolic diseases with significant familial aggregation. Previous studies have identified two genetic loci for macronutrients intake. Here, we expanded the genetic landscape of macronUTrient intake, identifying 12 suggestively significant loci.

We identify putative functional coding variation associated with changes in the QRS interval duration. ADAMTS6 encodes a secreted metalloprotease of currently unknown function. In vitro validation analysis shows that QRS-associated variants lead to impaired ADamTS6 secretion.

The cT1 value is a novel MRI-based quantitative metric for assessing a composite of liver inflammation and fibrosis. It has been shown to distinguish between non-alcoholic fatty liver disease (NAFL) and non- alcoholic steatohepatitis. However, these studies were conducted in patients at high risk for liver disease. This study establishes the normal reference range of cT 1 values for a large UK population.

Household income and neighbourhood fast-food outlet exposure may be related to diet and body weight. Understanding the double burden of these factors is a matter of public health importance. In a cohort of 51,361 adults aged 38-72 years in Greater London, UK, we jointly classified participants based on household income.

 meta-analysis of genome-wide association studies (GWAS) with ~16 million genetic variants in 62,892 T2D cases and 596,424 controls of European ancestry. We identify 139 common and 4 rare variants associated with T 2D, 42 of which (39 common and 3 rare variants) are independent of the known variants. 3 genes (CAMK1D, TP53INP1, and ATP5G1) with plausible regulatory mechanisms.

 genome-wide association study of 60,620 atrial fibrillation cases and 970,216 controls. We identified 142 independent risk variants at 111 loci and prioritized 151 functional candidate genes. Many of the identified risk variants fall near genes where more deleterious mutations have been reported to cause serious heart defects.

The normalized difference vegetation index (NDVI) is used to measure residential greenness. The tinnitus is defined based on self-reported. In the cross-sectional analysis including 106471 participants, higher greenness is associated with lower odds of tinnitis. A similar association is observed in the longitudinal analysis.

Lymphangioleiomyomatosis (LAM) is a rare disease of women. Decline in lung function is variable, making appropriate targeting of therapy difficult. We used unbiased serum proteomics to identify markers associated with outcome in LAM.

In genome-wide association studies (GWAS) for thousands of phenotypes in large biobanks, most binary traits have substantially fewer cases than controls. Both of the widely used approaches, the linear mixed model and the recently proposed logistic mixed model, perform poorly. Here we propose a scalable and accurate generalized mixed model association test that uses the saddlepoint approximation.

A key public health need is to identify individuals at high risk for a given disease. One important approach is to stratify individuals based on inherited DNA variation. We develop and validate genome-wide polygenic scores for five common diseases. The approach identifies 8.0% of the population at greater than threefold increased risk for coronary artery disease, atrial fibrillation, type 2 diabetes, inflammatory bowel disease, and breast cancer.

Vitamin D (25-OHD) levels are associated with higher risk of colorectal cancer (CRC) Since vitamin D is modifiable, these observations have substantial clinical and public health implications. Here, we explore causality in a large Mendelian randomisation (MR) study using an improved genetic instrument.

Clonal hematopoiesis (CH) is thought to be the origin of myeloid neoplasms (MN) Yet, our understanding of the mechanisms driving CH progression to MN and clinical risk prediction of MN remains limited. We identified 115 proteins associated with MN risk of which 30% were also associated with CH.

Study aimed to investigate the association of KB levels with incident chronic kidney disease (CKD) and death. Study was a prospective cohort study of 87,899 UK Biobank participants without baseline CKD.

Signal linkage disequilibrium profile regression is a method for detecting genome-wide directional effects of signed functional annotations on disease risk. We validate the method via simulations and application to molecular quantitative trait loci in blood, recovering known transcriptional regulators. We apply the method to expression quantitative traits in 48 Genotype-Tissue Expression tissues, identifying 651 transcription factor-tissue associations.

We characterized the prevalence and phenotypic consequences of X chromosome aneuploidy in a population of 244,848 women over 40 years of age from UK Biobank. The characteristics of women with 45,X were consistent with the characteristics of a clinically recognized Turner syndrome. Women with mosaic 45, X/46,XX were less short and had a normal reproductive lifespan and birth rate.

Red Blood Cell Distribution Width (RDW) predicts incident coronary artery disease (CAD) plus all-cause and cardiovascular mortality. But its predictive value for other common diseases in healthy volunteers is less clear. We aimed to determine the shorter and longer term associations between RDW and incident common conditions in participants free of baseline disease, followed for 9 years.

There is considerable debate regarding the role that 25-hydroxyvitamin D [25(OH)D] concentrations play in cancer risk or mortality. Using data from the UK Biobank, we evaluate whether genetically predicted 25( OH)D concentrations are associated with overall cancer susceptibility and cancer mortality.

High blood pressure is a highly heritable and modifiable risk factor for cardiovascular disease. We report the largest genetic association study of blood pressure traits to date in over 1 million people of European ancestry. We identify 535 novel blood pressure loci that offer new insights into blood pressure regulation.

Uterine leiomyomas (ULs) are benign tumors that are a major burden to women's health. A genome-wide association study on 15,453 UL cases and 392,628 controls was performed. The likely predisposition genes could be grouped to two biological processes.

We previously developed a tool that identified individuals who later developed esophageal adenocarcinoma with an area under the curve of 0.80. In this study, we collected data from 329,463 individuals in the UK Biobank cohort who were tested for genetic susceptibility to the disease. We found that after inclusion of this genetic information, the area of the curve for identification of individuals who developed the disease remained at 0. 80.

The normal menstrual cycle requires a delicate interplay between the hypothalamus, pituitary and ovary. Its length is an important indicator of female reproductive health. Menstrual cycle length has been shown to be partially controlled by genetic factors.

The Human Connectome Projects in Development are two large-scale brain imaging studies. HCP-D is enrolling 1300+ healthy children, adolescents, and young adults (ages 5-21) and H CP-A is enrolled 1200+ healthy adults (age 36-100+) Each study collects longitudinal data in a subset of individuals at particular age ranges. The result will be a large, rich, multi-modal and freely available set of consistently acquired data.

We conducted the first genome-wide association studies (GWAS) of eudaimonic well-being and linked it to a GWAS of hedonicWell-being. Loci regulating expression showed significant enrichment in the brain cortex, brain cerebellum, frontal cortex, as well as the cerebellar hemisphere for eud Aimonia. No significant enrichment was observed for Hedonic Well-being although brain tissues were top ranked.

We expanded GWAS discovery for type 2 diabetes (T2D) by combining data from 898,130 European-descent individuals. With these data, we (i) extend the inventory of T2D-risk variants. (ii) enrich discovery of lower-frequency risk alleles (80 index variants with minor allele frequency  2)

The genetic architecture of brain structure and function is largely unknown. We carried out genome-wide association studies of 3,144 functional and structural brain imaging phenotypes from UK Biobank (discovery dataset 8,428 subjects) We show that many of these phenotypes are heritable.

Genome-wide association studies for corneal and refractive astigmatism were performed in individuals of European ancestry (N = 86,335 and 88,005 respectively) Genetic correlation between the two traits was calculated using LD Score regression. The study identified four genome-wide significant loci (P)

Inclusion of a genetic risk score (GRS) did not appreciably improve discrimination of two previously validated models. Following recalibration the discrimination did not change, but good calibration for models incorporating the GRS was recovered.

White matter hyperintensities (WMH), also known as white matter lesions, are localised white matter areas that appear hyperintense on MRI scans. WMH commonly occur in the ageing population and are often associated with several factors such as cognitive disorders, cardiovascular risk factors, cerebrovascular and neurodegenerative diseases. Our proposed Bayesian spline method models the spatio-temporal distribution of WMH with respect to a parametric factor of interest, in this case age.

Osteoarthritis has a highly negative impact on quality of life because of the associated pain and loss of joint function. Here we describe the largest meta-analysis so far of osteoarth arthritis of the hip and the knee in samples from Iceland and the UK Biobank. We found 23 independent associations at 22 loci.

The effectiveness of a cardiovascular magnetic resonance (CMR) scan depends on the ability of the operator to correctly tune the acquisition parameters to the subject being scanned. In the clinical practice, a quality control step is performed by visual assessment of the acquired images. We propose a fast, fully automated, and learning-based quality control pipeline for CMR images.

Benign prostatic hyperplasia and associated lower urinary tract symptoms (BPH/LUTS) are common conditions affecting the majority of elderly males. We found 23 genome-wide significant variants, located at 14 loci. 15 of the variants reported here also associate with serum levels of prostate specific antigen.

The human default mode network (DMN) is implicated in several unique mental capacities. In this study, we tested whether brain-wide interregional communication in the DMN can be derived from population variability. Subregions most critical for cortical network interplay were adjacent to regions most predictive of fornix fibers.

Painful temporomandibular disorders (TMDs) are the leading cause of chronic orofacial pain. A single-nucleotide polymorphism on chromosome 3 (rs13078961) was significantly associated with TMD in males only. This effect is male-specific and may contribute to the lower rates of painful T MD in men.

Coffee, tea and alcohol consumption might be shaped by individual differences in bitter taste perception but inconsistent observational findings provide little insight regarding causality. We conducted Mendelian randomization analyses using genetic variants associated with the perception of bitter substances. A standard deviation (SD) higher in genetically predicted bitterness of caffeine was associated with increased coffee intake.

Congenital heart defects (CHD) are structural defects of the heart affecting approximately 1% of newborns. While genetic factors are known to play an important role in the development of CHD, the specific genetics remain unknown for the majority of patients. We performed a genome wide association study (GWAS) of CHDs in general and specific CHD subgroups.

Residential greenness was associated with higher bone mineral density and decreased risk of incident osteoporosis. PM 2.5 and NO 2 were identified as the primary mediators. Compared with individuals exposed to low NDVI levels and high genetic risk, those exposed to high NDVI Levels and low genetic risk had a 56% (95% CI 51% to 61%) lower risk of osteop orosis.

There's a lack of extensive studies exploring the linkage of traffic noise with cardio-metabolic risk factors such as obesity. The role of diet in the associations remains unknown. The aim is to prospectively examine the link between road traffic noise and obesity by focusing on the impact of meat.

Study aims to examine associations of daily step count with all-cause mortality and incident cardiovascular disease (CVD) by sedentary time levels. Compared with the referent 2200 steps/day (5th percentile), the optimal dose (nadir of the curve) for all- Cause mortality ranged between 9000 and 10 500 steps/ day for high (HR (95% CI)=0.61 to 0.73) and low (0.69 to0.92) sedentary times.

The occurrence of immune-mediated diseases (IMDs) in amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (ALS) patients is widely reported. Whether IMDs and ALS is a simple coexistence or if there exists causal relationships between the two has been a subject of great interest to researchers.

Short sleep duration was associated with increased risk of developing type 2 diabetes (T2D) This association persisted even among participants who maintained a healthy diet. To validate these findings, further longitudinal studies are needed.

Device-measured PA reveals novel joint associations with diet on health outcomes. Results emphasize the crucial role of PA in addition to a healthy diet for reducing chronic diseases and mortality risk.

Resting heart rate (RHR) is associated with cardiovascular disease (CVD) and mortality. Study aimed to identify genetic loci associated with RHR, develop a genome-wide polygenic risk score (PRS) for RHR and assess associations between the RHR PRS and CVD outcomes.

Short-term exposure to air pollutants increases the risk of migraine. But the long-term impacts of exposure to multiple pollutants on migraine have not been established. The aim of this large prospective cohort study was to explore these links.

Study aimed to explore the association between birthweight and the risk of dementia, cognitive function, and brain structure. We included 275,648 participants from the UK Biobank, categorizing birthweight into quartiles. Lower birthweight was associated with worse performance in cognitive tasks.

Welch's t test has an inflated Type I error rate, is systematically biased and is prone to produce extremely low p values. A likelihood ratio test based on logistic regression models performs better still.

The relationship between age at diagnosis of hyperlipidemia and dementia remains unclear. We examined data on a sample of 489,642 participants in the United Kingdom. Younger age of diagnosis ofHyperLipidemia (per 10-year decrease) was significantly associated with higher risks of all-cause dementia.

Study comprised 212,600 UK Biobank participants recruited over 2007 and 2010 at the baseline. Residential greenness was modeled as the normalized difference vegetation index (NDVI) from high spatial resolution (0.50 m) color infrared imagery. The proportion of the association between greenness and AL mediated by the physical activity was 3.2%.

UK Biobank participants were followed from 2006 to 2010 (baseline) to December 31st, 2022. Over a median follow-up period of 13.65 years, we documented 9177 incidents of osteoporosis. Per interquartile (IQR) increase in greenness and natural environment at a 300 m buffer was associated with a 4% lower risk.

Based on a cohort of 83,290 participants from the UK Biobank, we assessed the associations between each of the 168 metabolites with the risks of overall cancer and 20 specific types of cancer. We identified 13 metabolic biomarkers associated with overall cancer, and found that they mediated the effects of traditional factors. The accuracies of prediction models improved when we added 13 identified metabolites in models.

Transformer-based models typically demand a considerable amount of training data to achieve satisfactory performance. Dual-stream Transformer can simultaneously acquire local and global features in the image and construct relation between the two kinds of features via self-attention.

Disturbances in habitual sleep have been associated with multiple age-associated diseases. The biological mechanisms underpinning these associations remain largely unclear. We assessed the possible involvement of the circulating immune system by determining the associations between sleep traits and white blood cell counts using multivariable-adjusted linear regression and Mendelian randomization.

Dyslipidemia has long been implicated in elevating mortality risk. Study aimed to explore the causal effects of lipid traits on both all-cause and cause-specific mortality. Higher lipoprotein(a) was associated with an increased risk of all- Cause mortality.

Study aimed to investigate the association of social isolation, loneliness, and their trajectory with the risk of developing type 2 diabetes mellitus (T2DM) across genetic risk. We included 439,337 participants enrolled in the UK Biobank study who were followed up until May 31, 2021.

Skin aging is a natural process that occurs over time but can be accelerated by sun exposure. Measuring skin age in a large population can provide insight into the extent of skin damage from sun exposure and skin cancer risk. Understanding the genetics of skin aging, within and across sexes (males and females), could improve our understanding of the genetic drivers of both skin aging and skin Cancer.

The growing prevalence of osteoporosis (OP) in an aging global population presents a significant public health concern. Tobacco smoke negatively affects bone turnover, leading to reduced bone mass and heightened OP and fracture risk. The impact of early-life tobacco smoke exposure on later-life OP risk remains unclear.

This study was a retrospective case-control study using the UK Biobank. A total of 2,576 individuals with a history of cruciate ligament surgery were identified. 290 (11.25%) of these people underwent total knee arthroplasty (TKA) Physically demanding work and obesity were associated with higher odds of TKA.

The association of diabetes onset age and duration with incident arrhythmias remains unclear. We included 457,151 participants from the UK Biobank study. We documented 23,518 AF, 9079 bradyarrhythmia, 9280 conduction system diseases. Compared with non-diabetes, the risks of AF increased by 19%, 25%, and 36%.

Mendelian randomization was used to estimate the causal effects of certain cancers on health care costs and quality-adjusted life-years (QALYs) Using data from the UK Biobank cohort, it was possible to simulate the cost-effectiveness of an anticancer intervention. Genetic liability to prostate cancer and breast cancer had material causal impacts on either or both health care cost and QALYS.

The relationships between sleep duration and aging-associated diseases are intricate. Leukocyte telomere length (LTL) is a biomarker of aging, while the association of sleepduration and LTL is unclear. Compared with participants sleeping 7-8 h, those sleep longer than 8 h had shorter LTL in middle-aged and young-old adults.

1 in 4000 individuals from the Middle East and South Asia are homozygous for a common hypomorphic PTCRA variant. They had normal circulating naive &#945;&#946; T cell counts but high &# 947;& #948; T cells. autoimmune conditions were more frequent in these patients compared with the general population.

Physical activity is a protective factor against brain atrophy, while loss of brain volume could also be a determinant of physical activity. We aimed to explore the bidirectional association ofphysical activity with brain structures in middle-aged and older adults from the UK Biobank.

Amblyopia is a common neurodevelopmental condition and leading cause of childhood visual impairment. We investigated whether children with amblyopia have increased risk of cardiometabolic disorders in adult life. This was a cross-sectional and longitudinal analysis of 126,399 United Kingdom Biobank cohort participants.

Skeletal muscle may mutually interact with gastrointestinal disease through metabolic homeostasis and nutritional status and therefore may be a marker for early risk detection. We conducted a prospective cohort analysis including 393,606 participants (mean age 56.0 years, 53.9% female)

 Associations of biological aging with the development and mortality of cardiometabolic multimorbidity (CMM) remain unclear. We conducted a multistate analysis in 341,159 adults of the UK Biobank. Over a median follow-up of 8.84 years, biologically older participants demonstrated robust higher risks.

In healthcare, direct pooling of data is often not allowed by data custodians. Federated learning offers a promising solution to this problem. Combining training data from multiple sources increases sample size and reduces confounding.

Study aimed to evaluate racial differences in the incidence of stroke. East Asians tended to have a lower body mass index (23.7 vs. 26.4 kg/m 2)

The leukodystrophy megalencephalic leukoencephalopathy with subcortical cysts (MLC) is characterized by infantile-onset macrocephaly and chronic edema of the brain white matter. Classic MLC is caused by bi-allelic recessive pathogenic variants in MLC1 or GLIALCAM (also called HEPACAM) Rare patients with heterozygous dominant variants in GPRC5B and classic MLC were recently described.

Thiazide diuretics, widely used in hypertension, cause a variety of adverse reactions, including hyperglycemia, hyperuricemia, and electrolyte abnormalities. We aimed to identify genetic variants that interact with thiazide-use to increase the risk of these adverse reactions.

Mendelian randomization may give biased causal estimates if the instrument affects the outcome not solely via the exposure of interest. We demonstrate use of a global randomization test as a falsification test for the exclusion restriction assumption. We conducted proof-of-principle analyses in UK Biobank using CRP as the exposure and coronary heart disease (CHD) as the outcome.

As the brain ages, it almost invariably accumulates vascular pathology. This differentially affects the cerebral white matter. A white matter specific brain age was developed to evaluate the overall white matter health. Diabetes was most strongly associated with an increased WMBAG.

Data on cardiovascular outcomes according to objectively measured physical activity (PA) in patients with atrial fibrillation (AF) are scarce. This study explored the associations between PA derived from wrist-worn accelerometers and the risk of death, incident heart failure (HF), and incident stroke.

Optic neuritis (ON) is associated with numerous immune-mediated inflammatory diseases. 50% of ON patients are ultimately diagnosed with multiple sclerosis (MS) Differentiating MS-ON from non-MS-ON acutely is challenging but important.

We conducted a cohort study among female participants in the UK Biobank. Use of statins was significantly associated with increased risks of cervical cancer and polycystic ovarian syndrome. However, we observed no significant association between use of statin and risk of ovarian cancer, endometrial cancer, ovarian cyst, or cervical polyp.

Polygenic risk scores (PRSs) have proven to be as strong as or stronger than established clinical risk factors for many cardiovascular phenotypes. This study developed and validated 1 of the first aortic stenosis PRSs.

Having a history of maternal smoking, longer exposure to SHS, and living with smokers in the household were each associated with an increased risk of developing dementia. Individuals who were simultaneously exposed to maternal smoking and SHS had a particularly higher dementia risk.

Total testosterone (TT) and sex hormone-binding globulin (SHBG) may have beneficial effects on lung function, but these findings might be spurious due to confounding and reverse causation. We used multivariable Mendelian randomisation (MVMR) to investigate the independent causal effects of TT and SHBG. We found a strong beneficial effect of TT on FVC and FEV 1 in both males and females, but a moderate detrimental effect of SHBG in males only. These findings suggest that testosterone improves lung function in females, while SHBG has an opposite independent effect in males.

Major depression (MD) is more common amongst women than men. MD episodes have been associated with fluctuations in reproductive hormones amongst women. We examined associations between depression, stratified by sex and including perinatal depression (PND), and blood biomarkers, using UK Biobank data.

The roles of serum lipids on digestive system cancer (DSC) risk were still inconclusive. In this study, we systematically assessed indicative effects of signature lipidomic biomarkers on DSC risk. The diagnoses of DSCs were coded using International Classification of Diseases (ICD-10) codes.

The interplay between cardiovascular health metrics (CVHMs) and microvascular disease (MVD) in relation to the risk of incident coronary heart disease (CHD) among individuals with type 2 diabetes mellitus (T2DM) remains to be evaluated. We included 19,664 participants with T2DM from the UK Biobank.

Study involved 23,785 patients with diabetes without any pre-existing cardiovascular disease. Sleep behaviour traits examined encompassed sleep duration, chronotype, insomnia, snoring and daytime sleepiness. Short and long sleep durations consistently exhibited an elevated risk of AF compared to optimal sleep duration.

Triglyceride ( TG) and atherogenic index of plasma (AIP) have been acknowledged to be risk factors for vascular insults, but their impacts on the brain system remain elusive. We investigated associations of TG and AIP with brain structure, leveraging the UK Biobank database.

Few studies have reported polyunsaturated fatty acids (PUFA) as significant predictors of cardiovascular disease. Little is known about the relationship between PUFA levels and chronic kidney disease (CKD) This study explored this relationship among individuals with and without CKD.

Study was conducted among 171 094 UK Biobank participants. Participants were followed up until 1 March 2023 for type 2 diabetes incidence. Participants with a proinflammatory diet and always adding salt to foods had the highest risk.

Cardiometabolic multimorbidity (CMM) has high prevalence and poor prognosis. Mendelian randomization (MR) is a key method for identifying the causal factors of CMM. MR requires knowledge of the effects of SNPs on CMM, which remain unknown.

We present whole-exome sequencing analyses of depression with seven different definitions based on survey, questionnaire, and electronic health records in 320,356 UK Biobank participants. We showed that the burden of rare damaging coding variants in loss-of-function intolerant genes is significantly associated with risk of depression.

Cine cardiac magnetic resonance (CMR) imaging is considered the gold standard for cardiac function evaluation. Cine CMR acquisition is inherently slow and in recent decades considerable effort has been put into accelerating scan times without compromising image quality. We present a fully-automated, quality-controlled integrated framework for reconstruction, segmentation and downstream analysis.

Computer-vision models have been transformative in this space, enabling the automated quantification of muscle health and the processing of large datasets. People with BP (chronic>acute) have higher IMF and lower aCSA than people reporting no pain. The differences were not localized but broadly distributed across the lumbar spine.

Glaucoma is the leading cause of irreversible blindness worldwide. The vertical cup-to-disc ratio (VCDR) is a key structural indicator for the disease. However, manual assessment of fundus images is both time-consuming and subject to variability based on clinician expertise and interpretation.

Study aimed to investigate the potential causal relationship between domain-specific sedentary behaviors and hypertension risk in European populations. Data were collected from 261,829 hypertension-free participants in the UK Biobank. Individuals who spent >3 h per day watching television had significantly higher risk of developing hypertension.

The incidence of early-onset colorectal cancer (EOCRC) is high. We found two novel risk loci for EOCRC at 1p34.1 and 4p15.33. We identified a deleterious coding variant (rs36053993, G396D) at polyposis-associated DNA repair gene MUTYH.

Clinical decision support systems (CDSSs) play a critical role in enhancing the efficiency of mental health care delivery and promoting patient engagement. This study introduces a CDSS incorporating symptom profiling and drug recommendation formental health care. Among the UK Biobank cohort, we analyzed 157,348 participants for symptom profiling.

COPD affects estimated 164 million people worldwide. Early detection and intervention strategies are essential to reduce the burden of COPD. Current screening approaches are limited in their ability to accurately predict risk. Machine learning (ML) models offer promise for improved accuracy.

Polygenic scores (PGS) are quantitative metrics for predicting phenotypic values, such as human height or disease status. Some PGS methods require only summary statistics of a relevant genome-wide association study (GWAS) for their score. Joint-Lassosum (JLS) is an effective approach for enhancing portability and reducing predictive bias.

Cancer risk is influenced by inherited mutations, DNA replication errors, and environmental factors. influence of genetic variation in immunosurveillance on cancer risk is not well understood. heterozygosity at the  human leukocyte antigen (HLA) -II loci is associated with reduced lung cancer risk in smokers.

Study was a prospective cohort study based on the UK Biobank, with a median follow-up of 12.47 years. Results indicated that MSDP elevated the risk of all-cause mortality and mortality due to neoplasms.

Little evidence supports genetic personalization of fried food intake recommendations for the management of obesity. We included 27 427 participants who had dietary data assessed by a validated 24 h dietary recall and available anthropometric information from the UK Biobank study. Fried food intake was associated with a higher abdominal obesity risk among participants with a lower genetic risk.

Myelinated axons form long-range connections that enable rapid communication between distant brain regions. How genetics governs the strength and organization of these connections remains unclear. We perform genome-wide association studies of 206 structural connectivity measures.

The effect of influenza vaccination (FluVac) on the risk of neurodegenerative diseases has not been well evaluated in prospective populations. We aimed to assess the association between FluVac and risk of dementia and Parkinson's disease (PD) in people aged 60 years or older through a prospective population-based cohort from the UK Biobank.

SUGAR is a unified unsupervised deep-learning framework for both rigid and non-rigid registration. It incorporates a U-Net-based spherical graph attention network and leverages the Euler angle representation for deformation. SUGAR achieves remarkable sub-second processing times, offering a notable speed-up of approximately 12,000 times.

Irritable bowel syndrome (IBS) is one of the most common functional gastrointestinal disorders. Few studies have evaluated mortality risks among individuals with IBS. We explored the association between IBS and all-cause and cause-specific mortality in the UK Biobank. We found that earlier during follow-up, having diagnosed IBS was associated with lower mortality risk.

Study involved 179,565 participants from UK Biobank, tracking incident atrial fibrillation (AF) cases. Iron intake was categorized into low, moderate, and high groups based on dietary surveys conducted from 2009 to 2012. High iron intake was associated with increased risk of AF.

Type 2 Diabetes (T2D) is influenced by genetic, environmental, and ageing factors. Ageing pathways exacerbate metabolic diseases. Study aimed to examine both clinical and genetic factors of T2D in older adults.

Light at night, which may cause circadian disruption, is a potential pancreatic cancer risk factor. Evidence from related exposures such as poor sleep health and shift work remains inconclusive and sparsely investigated.

A low-inflammatory diet is associated with a lower risk of death and could prolong survival time. CMDs may partially mediate the IDI-mortality association. A favorable lifestyle beyond diet may augment the positive effect of a low- inflammatory diet on longevity.

A total of 176,352 participants from the UK Biobank with at least one web-based dietary questionnaire (Oxford WebQ) for assessment of sugar intake were included in this study. Mean follow-up lasted 10.9 years (standard deviation 2.0), with 12,355 incident cases of CVD. FS intake showed a J-shaped relationship with CVD risk, reaching the lowest HR (HR-nadir) at 9 %E.

We conducted a European-only and transancestral genome-wide association meta-analysis in 72,147 stroke patients and 823,869 controls. Using Mendelian randomization, we further show that genetic variation in the nitric oxide synthase-nitric oxide pathway in part affects stroke risk via variation in blood pressure. Ann Neurol 2018;84:934-939.

Loss of function variants in NOTCH1 cause left ventricular outflow tract obstructive defects (LVOTO) The risk conferred by rare and noncoding variants in NotCH1 for LVOTO remains largely uncharacterized. In a cohort of 49 families affected by hypoplastic left heart syndrome, a severe form of LVOTO, we discovered predicted loss of function NOTCh1 variants in 6% of individuals.
