Copy number variants (CNVs) have been shown to increase risk for physical anomalies, developmental, psychiatric and medical disorders. As most studies have been performed on children and young people, these effects of CNVs in middle-aged and older people are not well established. The UK Biobank recruited half a million adults who provided a variety of physical measurements.

Polygenic risk scores (PRSs) could improve screening and prevention strategies. The lifetime risk of overall breast cancer in the top centile of the PRSs was 32.6%. Compared with women in the middle quintile, the highest 1% of risk had 4.37- and 2.78-fold risks.

Erectile dysfunction (ED) is a common condition affecting more than 20% of men over 60 years. Little is known about its genetic architecture. Mendelian randomization provides evidence that genetic risk of type 2 diabetes mellitus is a cause of ED.

We show via simulations with real genotypes that the method, functionally informed novel discovery of risk loci (FINDOR), correctly controls the false-positive rate at null loci. We applied FINDOR to 27 independent complex traits and diseases from the interim UK Biobank release (average N = 130K) Averaged across traits, we attained a 13% increase in genome-wide significant loci detected (including a 20% increase for disease traits)

Osteoporosis is a common aging-related disease diagnosed primarily using bone mineral density (BMD) We assessed genetic determinants of BMD as estimated by heel quantitative ultrasound in 426,824 individuals. We identified 13 bone fracture loci, all associated with estimated BMD (eBMD), in ~1.2 million individuals.

For binary traits, the logistic model has not yielded clear improvements over the linear model. We introduce the quasi-Laplace approximation to solve the integral and avoid MCMC sampling. B-LORE also enables meta-analysis by approximating the likelihood functions of individual studies by multivariate normal distributions.

High adiposity is associated with higher risks for a variety of adverse health outcomes, including higher rates of age-adjusted mortality and increased morbidity. This has important implications for the management of healthcare systems. We studied the association between various measures of adiposity and inpatient hospital costs.

Out-of-Core Matrices Analyzer (OCMA) is a disk-based tool that can nimbly perform eigen and Singular Value Decomposition (SVD) analyses. By integrating memory mapping (mmap) and the latest matrix factorization libraries, our tool is fast and memory-efficient.

Suicide accounts for nearly 800,000 deaths per year worldwide with rates of both deaths and attempts rising. Family studies have estimated substantial heritability of suicidal behavior, but collecting the sample sizes necessary for successful genetic studies has remained a challenge. We utilized two different approaches to characterize the contribution of common genetic variation to suicide attempt.

Gout was present in 6768 (4.1%) men and 574 (0.3%) women, with an odds ratio (95% confidence interval) for men 13.42 (12.32-14.62) compared with women. In men, experiment-wide association with gout was observed for 21 of the 30 serum urate-associated SNPs tested. Evidence for gene-sex interaction was seen for ABCG2 (rs2231142) and PDZK1 (rs1471633)

Osteoarthritis is the most common musculoskeletal disease and the leading cause of disability globally. We discovered 64 signals, 52 of them novel, more than doubling the number of established disease loci. Ten of the likely effector genes, including TGFB1 (transforming growth factor beta 1), FGF18 (fibroblast growth factor 18), CTSK (cathepsin K), and IL11 (interleukin 11), are approved or in clinical trials.

Body mass and body fat composition are of clinical interest due to their links to cardiovascular- and metabolic diseases. Fat stored in the trunk has been suggested to be more pathogenic compared to fat stored in other compartments. In this study, we perform genome-wide association studies for the proportion of body fat distributed to the arms, legs and trunk.

Lifestyle factors, e.g. physical activity, moderate the manifestation of genetic susceptibility to obesity. Study uses UK Biobank data to investigate interaction between polygenic scores (PGS) and lifestyle and psychosocial factors.

Little is known about the genetic architecture of healthy thinness. Here, we characterise the heritability of thinness which we found was comparable to that of severe obesity. In a genome-wide association analysis, we identified 10 loci previously associated with obesity.

Phenotypic correlations among partners for traits such as longevity or late-onset disease have been found to be comparable to those in first-degree relatives. How these correlations arise in late life is poorly understood. Here we introduce a novel paradigm to establish the presence of indirect assortment on factors correlated across generations.

Higher genetically predicted BMI increases the risk of being diagnosed with or dying from any cancer. These data suggest that increased overall weight may causally increase overall cancer incidence and mortality among Europeans.

Negative selection can cause rare variants to have larger per-allele effect sizes than common variants. We estimate &#945; for 25 UK Biobank diseases and complex traits. Despite larger rare variant effect sizes, rare variants (MAF) remain common.

Microbiome-wide association studies have highlighted associations between the gut microbiome and complex traits, including type 2 diabetes (T2D) and obesity. We leveraged information from 952 normoglycemic individuals for whom genome-wide genotyping, gut metagenomic sequence and fecal short-chain fatty acid (SCFA) levels were available. We found that the host-genetic-driven increase in gut production of the SCFA butyrate was associated with improved insulin response after an oral glucose-tolerance test.

Body-fat distribution is a risk factor for adverse cardiovascular health consequences. We analyzed the association of body- fat distribution, assessed by waist-to-hip ratio adjusted for body mass index, with 228,985 predicted coding and splice site variants.

With the availability of large-scale biobanks, genome-wide scale phenome-wide association studies are being instrumental in discovering novel genetic variants associated with clinical phenotypes. Because the binary phenotypes in biobank-based studies are mostly unbalanced in their case-control ratios, very few methods can provide well-calibrated tests for associations. We propose two meta-analysis strategies that can efficiently combine association results with such unbalanced phenotypes, using the saddlepoint approximation-based score test method.

UK Biobank is an open access, population-based study of > 500,000 adults aged 40-69 years at recruitment in 2006-2010. From 17,198 participants recruited in Edinburgh, we identified those with &#8805; 1 dementia code in their linked primary care, hospital admissions or mortality data.

Self-reported tiredness or low energy, often referred to as fatigue, has been linked to low levels of circulating 25-hydroxyvitamin D (25OHD), a biomarker of vitamin D status. Although it is uncertain if the association is causal, fatigue is a common indication for testing, and correcting, low 25OHD-levels. We used two-sample Mendelian randomization to test for genetic evidence of a causal association.

Genome-wide association studies have reported 56 independently associated colorectal cancer (CRC) risk variants. Most of these variants are non-coding and believed to exert their effects by modulating gene expression. In this study, we used reference datasets from colon and whole blood transcriptomes to test CRC association with genetically determined expression levels.

Cross-sectional study utilized the United Kingdom Biobank. The primary outcomes were the effect of age, the presence of metabolic syndrome, the time of day, and the month of the year.

The beneficial effects of exercise on reducing the risk of cardiovascular disease are established. However, the potential interaction between genetic risk for type 2 diabetes and physical activity on cardiovascular outcomes remains elusive. We aimed to investigate the effect of type. 2 diabetes genetic risk-physical activity interaction on cardiovascular. outcomes in individuals with diabetes.

The prevalence of cardiometabolic multimorbidity (CMDs) has increased rapidly in recent years. The association between CMDs and cardiovascular incidence in middle-aged adults remains unclear. The data were derived from the UK Biobank, and a total of 71,923 participants aged 40-55 years old without CVD were included in the main analyses.

Bayesian network-based Mendelian randomization (BNMR) is a Bayesian causal learning and inference framework using individual-level data. BNMR employs the random graph forest, an ensemble Bayesian network structural learning process, to prioritize candidate genetic variants and select appropriate instrumental variables. Simulations demonstrate BN MR can efficiently reduce the false-positive discoveries in variant selection.

A requisite property for interpretability and generalizability of CCA/PLS associations is stability of their feature patterns. We found that when sample size is relatively small, but comparable to typical studies, associations are highly unstable and inaccurate. We further developed a power calculator to provide sample sizes required for stability.

Analysis included 110,692 participants aged 39-71 years at baseline (2006-2010) Incident chronic diseases were identified using inpatient records, or death registers until January 2021. chronological age-adjusted age gap (CAAG) was significantly associated with the incidence of 25 out of 50 chronic diseases. Greater CAAG was associated with increased risk of eight cardiometabolic disorders.

Osteoporosis is the most common metabolic bone disease globally. Recent studies have linked higher white matter hyperintensities (WMH) to reduced BMD, increasing the risk of fractures and falls in older adults. However, limited evidence exists regarding the dose-response relationship between WMH and bone health in a larger and younger population.

64 268 adults aged 37 to 73 years who had no IBS diagnosis at baseline were enrolled between 2006 and 2010 and followed up to 2022. The five healthy lifestyle behaviours studied were never smoking, optimal sleep, high level of vigorous physical activity, high dietary quality and moderate alcohol intake.

Study aimed to examine the association of liver enzymes with type 2 diabetes (T2D) risk. Liver enzymes were non-linearly associated with T2D risk in different populations, including China, the UK, and the US. Elevated ALT and GGT levels, within a certain range, could increase T1D risk.

Coeliac disease (CeD) has been associated with a broad range of diseases in observational data. We conducted a phenome-wide Mendelian randomization analysis (MR-PheWAS) to investigate the comorbidities of CeD. Genetic liability to CeD was associated with higher risk of several autoimmune diseases.

Air pollution is associated with lower lung function, and both are associated with premature mortality and cardiovascular disease. Evidence remains scarce on the potential mediating effect of impaired lung function on the association between air pollution and mortality or CVD. We used data from UK Biobank (n&#8764;200 000 individuals) with 8-year follow-up to mortality and incident CVA.

The association of pre-diabetes and type 2 diabetes (T2D) with incident lung cancer is uncertain, and the incident risk across the glycemic spectrum is unclear. We aimed to explore the associations of glycosylated hemoglobin (HbA1c), pre-Diabetes, and T2D with incident Lung cancer in a large prospective cohort.

Protein quantitative trait loci (pQTLs) are an invaluable source of information for drug target development. Using Olink proteomics data for 1,463 proteins measured in over 54,000 samples of the UK Biobank, we identified 4,248 associations with 2,821 ratios between protein levels.

Analysis included 110,354 APOE4 carriers and 220,708 age- and sex-matched controls aged 40-73 years at baseline (between 2006-2010) Incident dementia was ascertained using hospital inpatient, or death records until January 2021. For only 2 risk factors (mother's history of dementia, low C-reactive protein), their associations with incident all-cause dementia were stronger in APoe4 carriers. For 20 risk factors including multimorbidity risk score, unhealthy lifestyle habits, and particulate matter air pollutants, their associations were stronger with incident dementia.

Both internalizing disorders and alcohol use have dramatic, wide-spread implications for global health. Previous work has established common phenotypic comorbidity among these disorders, as well as shared genetic variation underlying them both. We examined patterns of genetic correlations between similar traits within additional Finnish and East Asian ancestry groups.

Niacin is an essential micronutrient fortified in food staples, but its role in CVD is not well understood. Serum levels of the terminal metabolites of excess niacin, N1-methyl-2-pyridone-5-carboxamide (2PY) and 4PY, were associated with increased 3-year MACE risk in two validation cohorts.

Cataract is one of the most prevalent causes of blindness worldwide. Surgery is the primary treatment for cataracts, but it is not always an available option. Several studies have investigated how topical application of oxysterols, such as lanosterol, may break down aggregated proteins and restore lens transparency.

The risks of respiratory diseases following SARS-CoV-2 infection have not been comprehensively understood. This study aimed to investigate whether COVID-19 increases the long-term risk of respiratory illness. Respiratory outcomes diagnosed in medical records included common chronic pulmonary diseases (asthma, bronchiectasis, chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD) and lung cancer.

Assortative mating (AM), participation bias and socioeconomic status (SES) with respect to the genetics of behavioural and psychiatric traits were investigated. Cross-method meta-analysis identified AM genetic signatures for multiple alcohol-related phenotypes, bipolar disorder and schizophrenia.

Diabetes mellitus (DM) is associated with structural grey matter alterations in the brain, including changes in the somatosensory and pain processing regions. In this case-controlled biobank study, we aimed to ascertain differences in grey and white matter anatomy in people with DM compared with non-diabetic controls.

Urban living is synonymous with a higher exposure to environmental stressors such as air pollution and associated physiological stress. We found that living in areas with higher air pollutants was associated with higher CPS. Higher residential greenness was inversely associated with CPS.

The earliest ages at which metabolic perturbations occur and how these change over time are yet to be elucidated. Mechanisms through which most known Alzheimer's disease (AD) loci operate to increase AD risk remain unclear. We examined the effects of AD genetic liability on the plasma metabolome across the life course.

Study aimed to calculate relationships between long-term exposure to ambient sulfur dioxide (SO2), carbon monoxide (CO), ozone (O3), and benzene and CKD in the UK. Risk of CKD increased non-linearly with increasing SO2, high O3 days, and CO.

Mood disorders have a genetic and environmental component and interactions (GxE) on the risk of psychiatric diseases have been investigated. The same GxE interactions may affect wellbeing measures, which go beyond categorical diagnoses and reflect the health-disease continuum.

Previous studies reported leucocyte telomere length (LTL) and frailty were associated with mortality. It remains unclear whether frailty serves as a mediator in the relationship between LTL and mortality risk. This study aimed to evaluate how measuring LTL can support early monitoring and prevention of risk of mortality.

The idea of estimating the chronological age from magnetic resonance images proved to be an interesting field of research due to the relative simplicity of its interpretation. We revised our previous BrainAGE approach, originally utilising relevance vector regression (RVR), and substituted it with Gaussian process regression (GPR) We tested the performance of the new algorithms under several different conditions and investigated their validity on the ADNI and schizophrenia samples.

East Asians had a 38% lower 5-year incidence rate compared with Caucasians. East Asians consuming alcohol &#8805;3 times/week showed a higher incidence of the primary outcome. Study revealed significant racial differences in bleeding incidence, influenced by anatomical sites and lifestyle habits.

Clinical trials and Mendelian randomization studies reported null effects of high-density lipoprotein cholesterol (HDL-C) on risk of cardiovascular disease (CVD) We aimed to investigate the dose-response relationship between circulating HDL-C concentrations and CVD.

Genome-wide association statistics were obtained from the UK Biobank for multisite chronic pain. MCP was positively genetically correlated with AUD, CanUD, OUD, and PTU. The genome-wide analysis identified two SNPs pleiotropic between MCP and all SUD investigated.

Clonal hematopoiesis of indeterminate potential (CHIP) associates with increased risk of both hematological malignancy and cardiovascular disease. CHIP is known to increase the risk of myocardial infarction and heart failure. The influence of CHIP in cardiac arrhythmias, such as atrial fibrillation (AF), is less explored.

The understanding of the molecular genetic contributions to smoking is largely limited to the additive effects of individual single nucleotide polymorphisms (SNPs) The underlying genetic risk is likely to also include dominance, epistatic, and gene-environment interactions. We attempted to identify genetic interactions between SNPs and genes across the genome.

Mendelian Randomisation (MR) estimates causal effects between risk factors and complex outcomes using genetic instruments. Pleiotropic, heritable confounders, and heterogeneous causal effects violate MR assumptions and can lead to biases. We propose an approach employing a Phenome-Wide association Clustering of the MR instruments (PWC-MR) to revisit the surprisingly large apparent causal effect of body mass index (BMI) on educational attainment (EDU)

We exploited Artificial Intelligence (AI) tools to explore whether differences in clinical measurements following lifestyle interventions in overweight population could be reflected in brain morphology. We utilized an ensemble learning framework to predict Body-Mass Index (BMI) scores, which correspond to adiposity-related clinical measurements from brain MRIs.

A cohort study of 259,435 female participants in the UK Biobank was conducted to estimate hazard ratio (HR) for breast cancer according to 9 inflammation markers. Higher level of C-reactive protein (CRP), systemic immune-inflammation index (SII), CRP-to-albumin Ratio (CAR) and other markers were associated with increased breast cancer risk.

Study included 220,963 UK Biobank participants without dementia at baseline. Participants with high air pollution score and high genetic susceptibility had higher risk of dementia.

Study aimed to explore associations between different types of meat consumption and mortality risk among people with frailty. Higher consumption of unprocessed poultry (per 25 g/day increment) was associated with a lower risk of all-cause mortality. Fish consumption was not associated with all types of mortality.

Elevated lipoprotein(a) (Lp[a]) is a putative causal risk factor for atherosclerotic cardiovascular disease (ASCVD) There are conflicting data as to whether Lp(a), may increase cardiovascular risk only in the presence of concomitant inflammation. This cohort study uses data from 3 cohorts, 1 population-based cohort and 2 randomized clinical trials.

How physical activity (PA) and different sleep traits and overall sleep pattern interact in the development of Parkinson's disease (PD) remain unknown. To prospectively investigate the joint associations of PA and sleep pattern with risk of PD.

 models with polygenic risk scores and clinical factors to predict risk of different cancers have been developed. These models have been limited by the polygenicrisk score-derivation methods and the incomplete selection of clinical variables. We used UK Biobank to train the best risk scores for 8 cancers and select relevant clinical variables from 733 baseline traits.

Genomic instability can lead to the sequestration of DNA in aberrant extranuclear structures called micronuclei (MN) MN are a hallmark of ageing and diseases associated with genomic instability. Here we analyse 997 mouse mutant lines, revealing 145 genes whose loss significantly increases or decreases MN formation. We found that mice null for Dscc1 showed the most significant increase in MN.

Study obtained UK Biobank data from 82,829 individuals with wrist-worn accelerometer data aged 40 to 79 years. Interdaily stability (a measure of regularity, hazard ratio [HR] per SD increase 1.25, 95% confidence interval [CI] 1.05-1.48) and diurnal amplitude (HR 0.79, CI 0.65-0.96) were associated with risk of AD. Several measures were additionally predictive of longitudinal cognitive test performance. These findings suggest 24-h rhythm integrity, as measured by affordable, non-invasive wearable devices, may serve as a scalable early marker of neurodegenerative disease.

 mitochondrial dysfunction in the pathogenesis of chronic kidney disease (CKD) and acute kidney injury (AKI) Little is known regarding the impact of common mitochondrial genetic variation on kidney health. We evaluated associations of inherited mitochondrial DNA (mtDNA) variation with risk of CKD and AKI in a large population-based cohort.

Study included participants from the UK Biobank recruited from 2006 to 2010. During a mean follow-up of 12.61 years, 13 789 participants were first diagnosed with heart failure. There was a nonlinear (J-shaped) trend between outdoor light time and heart failure risk.

Female reproductive factors may influence the development of chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD) through the female hormonal environment. Study aimed to assess whether age at menarche, number of children, infertility, miscarriage, stillbirth and age at natural menopause were associated with the risk of COPD.

Polygenic risk score (PRS) is useful for capturing an individual's genetic susceptibility. We explored the potential of integrating disease-related RFPRSs with disease PRS to enhance disease prediction performance. RFDiseasemetaPRS showed better performance for Nagelkerke's pseudo-R2, odds ratio (OR) per 1 SD and net reclassification improvement (NRI) values.

Parkinson's disease is the world's fastest-growing neurological disorder. Current diagnostic methods are expensive and have limited availability. A desirable screening should be diagnostically accurate even before the onset of symptoms.

Sleep disturbances are implicated as risk factors of both stroke and dementia. We analyzed 502,383 UK Biobank participants with self-reported sleep measurements. Almost all sleep measures were associated with dementia risk but not with SVD markers.

Knee OA was defined using International Classification of Diseases manual 10 codes. Central mechanisms were proxied using multisite chronic pain (MCP) and peripheral mechanisms using body mass index (BMI) Odds ratios (ORs) and 95% confidence intervals (CIs) were estimated, and proportional risk contribution (PRC) was estimated.

Maternal and fetal genetic variants associated with higher birthweight predict larger cortical surface area. The relative dominance of the maternal vs. fetal variants in these associations show striking variations across birth years. The birth-year patterns vary as a function of the epigenetic status near genes differentially methylated in individuals exposed (or not) to famine during the Dutch Winter of 1944/1945.

Sex-specific associations of sex hormone-binding globulin (SHBG) and bioavailable testosterone (BAT) with NAFLD remain indeterminate. We aimed to explore observational and genetically determined relationships between each hormone andNAFLD. We included 187 395 men and 170 193 women from the UK Biobank.

GFAP, NEFL, GDF15 and LTBP2 consistently associated most with incident all-cause dementia (ACD), Alzheimer's disease (AD) and vascular dementia (VaD) Individuals with higher GFAP levels were 2.32 times more likely to develop dementia.

Evidence exists for a causal association between 25-hydroxyvitamin D (25(OH)D) serum levels, and multiple sclerosis (MS) The role of variation in vitamin D receptor (VDR) binding in MS is unknown. We leveraged previously identified variants associated with allele imbalance in VDR binding.

Chronic kidney disease (CKD) is highly prevalent among Indigenous Australians. The rate of end-stage renal disease is up to 20 times greater in this population compared to non-Indigenous populations. Despite the identification of numerous genetic loci associated with kidney disease through GWAS, the Indigenous population such as Tiwi remains severely underrepresented.

NMR profiling of blood by nuclear magnetic resonance (NMR) is invaluable to clinical biomarker discovery. Preanalytical variation in the method of blood collection strongly influences metabolite composition within and between biobanks. In the healthy control cohort, the fluoride oxalate collection tube prevented fluctuation in glucose and lactate levels for 24 hours at either 4 &#176;C or room temperature.

Familial partial lipodystrophy (FPLD) is a heterogenous group of syndromes associated with a high prevalence of cardiometabolic diseases. Prior work has proposed DEXA-derived fat mass ratio (FMR) as a biomarker of FPLD. Participants with high FMR were at higher risk for type 2 diabetes, metabolic dysfunction-associated liver disease or steatohepatitis.

Resting-state fMRI (rs-fMRI) can be used to identify biomarkers of these conditions and study patterns of abnormal connectivity. In this work, we estimate mental health quality for individual participants using static functional network connectivity (sFNC) data.

High-potassium intake is associated with a lower risk of cardiovascular disease. However, the association between potassium intake and the development of chronic kidney disease (CKD) remains unclear. The main predictor was spot urine potassium-to-creatinine ratio.

Previous studies have demonstrated effects of rare coding variants on common, clinically relevant phenotypes. This study attempted to identify pairs of variants likely to be occurring as compound heterozygotes using 200,000 exome-sequenced subjects from the UK Biobank.

Chinese and British patients with diabetes mellitus were more likely to have low-level PA compared with the general population. Female, rural-distributed, employed, never-smoking Chinese diabetics, and male, urban-distribution, retired/unemployed, quit-smoking British diabeticics were morelikely to have PA.

Peripheral vertigo is often comorbid with psychiatric disorders. No longitudinal study has quantified the association between peripheral vertigo and risk of psychiatric disorder. It remains unknown how the white matter integrity of frontal-limbic network relates to the putative vertigo-psychiatric disorder link.

Study aimed to investigate the association between long-term use of antibiotics during childhood and the risk of type 2 diabetes mellitus (T2DM) Using a prospective cohort from the UK Biobank.

The total heritability, including common and rare variants, recovered pedigree-based estimates for 11 traits. RARity can estimate gene-level h2RV and reveal 11, previously unreported, gene-phenotype relationships.

Gout is a chronic disorder characterized by the accumulation of uric acid in the body, leading to recurrent episodes of joint inflammation and pain. There remains a lack of studies investigating the association between long-term exposure to ambient air pollution and the incidence of gout. We conducted a prospective cohort study involving participants aged 38-70 from the UK Biobank.

Habitual use of fish oil supplements showed a 24% lower dementia risk among older diabetic patients. Such inverse association was not modified by the APOE &#949;4 genotype. consumption of both oily fish and non-oily fish had no significant association with dementia risk.

Recent studies have shown that incorporating functional annotation can improve the predictive performance of polygenic risk scores (PRSs) PRS methods that employ a Bayesian framework with shrinkage can account for such sparsity. We propose a PRS method, PRSbils, which utilizes the functional annotation information with a bilevel continuous shrinkage prior.

Automated online and App-based cognitive assessment tasks are becoming increasingly popular in large-scale cohorts and biobanks. The summary scores that such tasks generate typically conflate the cognitive processes that are the intended focus of assessment with basic visuo-motor speeds and testing device latencies. This lack of precision presents a fundamental limitation when studying brain-behaviour associations.

The detrimental health effects of smoking are well-known, but the impact of regular nicotine use without exposure to the other constituents of tobacco is less clear. Given the increasing daily use of alternative nicotine delivery systems, such as e-cigarettes, it is increasingly important to understand and separate the effects of nicotine use from tobacco smoke exposure.

Adverse childhood experiences (ACEs) have been linked with increased risk of diabetes and obesity during adulthood. A comprehensive assessment on the associations between childhood maltreatment and all major endocrine diseases is currently lacking. We constructed a cohort including 151,659 participants with self-reported data on childhood malt treatment.

The precise roles of chromatin organization at osteoporosis risk loci remain largely elusive. Here, we combined chromatin interaction conformation (Hi-C) profiling and self-transcribing active regulatory region sequencing (STARR-seq) to qualify enhancer activities of prioritized SNPs.

High cognitive reserve is associated with reduced risk of dementia and may delay dementia onset. Genetic risk for dementia may be mitigated by high cognitive reserve. Our findings underscore the importance of enhancing cognitive reserve in dementia prevention.

Anxiety/stress-related disorders have been associated with multiple diseases. A comprehensive assessment of the structure and interplay of subsequent associated diseases and their genetic underpinnings is lacking. By combining findings from the comorbidity network and disease trajectory analyses, we identify five robust disease clusters to be associated with a prior diagnosis.

Evidence suggests that infections may play a major role in Alzheimer's disease (AD) mechanism is unclear, as multiple pathways may be involved. One possibility is that infections could contribute to neurodegeneration directly by promoting neuronal death. We explored relationships between history of infections and brain hippocampal volume (HV) in a subsample of UK Biobank participants.

Cardiac arrhythmias are considered an early clinical stage for cardiovascular diseases. Whether napping frequency is associated with incident arrhythias remains unknown. Usually napping was significantly associated with higher risks of AF/Af and bradyarrhythmia.

Migraine is a common neurological disorder that affects more than one billion people worldwide. Recent genome-wide association studies have identified 123 genetic loci associated with migraine risk. The biological mechanisms underlying migraine and its relationships with other complex diseases remain unclear.

 generalized linkage disequilibrium score regression (g-LDSC) requires only genome-wide association studies (GWASs) summary-level data to estimate functional enrichment. Results typically implicate tissue or cell-type-specific biological pathways in disease pathogenesis.

Multiple evidence has suggested the complex interplay between Parkinson's disease (PD) and systemic inflammation marked by C-reactive protein (CRP) and interleukin 6 (IL-6) But the direction of the effect remains controversial. Here, we aimed to explore the link between CRP and IL-6 and the risk of PD. A higher level of CRP at baseline was associated with a lower risk ofPD.

Little is known about the relationship between body composition and fat distribution with depression risk. We included 330,131 participants without depression at baseline in the UK Biobank. High levels of body composition measures were associated with an increased Depression risk.

Oestrone, predominantly made in fat, is the main circulating oestrogen. It is important for target tissue oestradiol production in women after menopause. Study looked at associations between genetic loci and endometrial cancer.

Ozone exposure was associated with higher levels of arterial stiffness. In contrast, fish oil consumption showed a protective association. The association between ozone exposure and stiffness was partially mediated by some biomarkers. In the general population,Fish oil consumption might provide protection against ozone-related AS.

APOL1 variants G1 and G2 are common in populations with recent African ancestry. They are associated with protection from African sleeping sickness. However homozygosity or compound heterozygosity for these variants is associated with chronic kidney disease (CKD)

Hypobetalipoproteinemia (HBL) is a lipid disorder characterized by permanent, inherited low levels (below the 5th percentile) of low-density lipoprotein-cholesterol. HBL is associated with a markedly increased risk of hepatic complications.

The rationale for oophorectomy during female cystectomy is not adequately supported. The co-occurrence and timing of bladder cancer (BC) and ovarian cancer (OC) in females harboring OC germline mutations remain unclear. We used genetic and phenotypic data from the UK Biobank.

We explore relation between age at menarche, parity and age at natural menopause with 249 metabolic traits in over 65,000 UK Biobank women. Older age is related to a less atherogenic metabolic profile in multivariable regression and Mendelian randomization.

A total of 75,293 patients with diagnosed hypertension from the UK Biobank study were included, matched with 256,619 nonhypertensive controls, and followed up until May 31, 2021. Seven risk factors were measured to define joint risk factor control, including blood pressure, body mass index, low-density lipoprotein cholesterol, hemoglobin A 1c , albuminuria, smoking, and physical activity.

Intracerebral hemorrhage (ICH) is a serious complication of brain arteriovenous malformation (AVM) Apolipoprotein E (APOE) &#949;4 is a well-known genetic risk factor for ICH among persons without AVM. cerebral amyloid angiopathy is a vasculopathy frequently observed in APOE &#999;4 carriers that may increase the risk of ICH.

Cross-sectional study analyzed data from a UK Biobank cohort of individuals aged 45 to 80 years. Participants included individuals with a lifetime exposure to depression and matched healthy controls without indications of psychosis, mental illness, behavior disorder, and disease of the nervous system. Across all depression criteria, individuals with lifetime depression displayed regionally consistent decreases in fALFF, LCOR, and GCOR.

The potential impact of renal function-related cardiovascular remodeling on associated cardiovascular risk has not been previously investigated. Using multiple Cox models, we found lower renal function was independently related to increased risks of various cardiovascular events and mortalities.

The appropriateness of hypertension thresholds for triggering action to prevent cardiovascular and renal complications among non-White populations in the UK is subject to question. Our objective was to establish ethnicity-specific systolic blood pressure (SBP) cutoffs for ethnic minority populations and assess the efficacy of these cutoffs in predicting adverse outcomes.

Study used data on White British participants from the prospective cohort UK Biobank. Genome-wide interaction analysis was performed to test interactions between dietary factors and variants. A total of 324 variants were identified that interacted with diet consumption at the suggestive threshold (P)

Three prospective cohorts analyzed data from adults with diabetes from the Incident, Development, and Prognosis of Diabetic Kidney Disease (INDEED) study (2016-17 to 2020) in China. National Health Nutrition Examination Survey (NHANES) in the USA and UK Biobank (UKB, 2006-10 to 2022) in UK.

An increasing body of evidence indicates an association between consuming sugar or its alternatives and cardiometabolic diseases. This prospective, population-based cohort study analyzed data from the UK Biobank. During a median (IQR) follow-up of 10.5 (10.4-11.2) years, 4459 cases of incident CKD occurred.

Atrial fibrillation (AF) is the most common sustained arrhythmia and is associated with significant morbidity and mortality. Hearing impairment has been linked to several cardiovascular diseases. The association between hearing disorders, genetic predisposition, and new-onset AF remains largely unknown.

The prevalence of chronic kidney disease (CKD) is high. Identification of cases with CKD is important to tailor early interventions. The objective of this study was to identify blood metabolites associated with prevalent and incident severe CKD.

Single-cell and spatial transcriptomics analysis of human knee articular cartilage tissue to present a comprehensive transcriptome landscape and osteoarthritis (OA)-critical cell populations. We identified 33 cell population-specific marker genes that define 11 chondrocyte populations.

GAUDI is a penalized-regression-based method specifically designed for admixed individuals. GAUDI explicitly models ancestry-differential effects while borrowing information across segments with shared ancestry in admixed genomes. We show that GAUDi improves PRS prediction of white blood cell count and C-reactive protein in African Americans by > 64% compared to alternative methods.

A total of 328,606 participants (54% women) were included using data from the UK Biobank. An unhealthy lifestyle was significantly associated with an increased CAD risk. Lifestyle factors explained 41% (95% CI = 38%-45%) of CAD, while genetic variants for BMI explained only 10%. Risks of CAD were increased with poorer HLS independent of obesity-related PGSs.

Much remains unknown regarding the associations of adversities in childhood and adulthood with incident cardiovascular diseases (CVD) We aimed to examine whether these associations can be mitigated by adopting a healthy lifestyle later in life. We included 136,073 men and women free of diagnosed CVD at baseline.

The establishment of 3&#697;aQTLs comprehensive database provides an opportunity to help explore the functional interpretation from the genome-wide association study (GWAS) data of psychiatric disorders. The GWAS datasets of five psychiatric disorders were collected from the open platform of Psychiatric Genomics Consortium (PGC, https://www.med.unc.edu/pgc/) and iPSYCH. For schizophrenia (SCZ), HLA-A showed associated with psychiatric disorders in all 12 brain regions, such as cerebellar hemisphere.

Study comprised a total of 61,115 participants without a prior T2DM from the UK Biobank database. Four trajectory groups of dietary iron intake were characterized by the GBTM: trajectory group 1, 2, 3 and 4. Trajectory group 3 was significantly associated with a 38% decreased risk of T2 DM.

Previous studies on physical activity (PA) and pelvic organ prolapse (POP) were largely limited to self-reported PA in athletes, soldiers, and women in postpartum. We aimed to investigate the association of accelerometer-measured PA and sedentary behavior with the risk of POP in middle-aged and elderly women.

Study included 460,234 participants aged 40 to 69 years, who were initially free of T2D. MSAB and breastfeeding were collected by questionnaire. Alternative health eating index(AHEI) and dietary inflammation index(DII) were calculated.

Giant cell arteritis (GCA) is an age-related vasculitis. Previous studies have identified an association between GCA and hematologic malignancies. How the presence of somatic mutations that drive the development of HMs may influence clinical outcomes in GCA is not well understood.

The study identified 4093 common genetic variants, involving 1248 gene loci, that contributed to blood-cancer pleiotropism. Pleiotropic gene candidates are frequently linked to transcriptional programs that regulate hematopoiesis. Eosinophil count is inversely associated with cancer risk.

The role of sex-specific risk factors during midlife, including hormone replacement therapy (HRT) and their interaction with other major risk factors for Alzheimer's Disease, such as apolipoprotein E (APOE)-e4 genotype and age, remains unclear. Women from the UK Biobank with no self-reported neurological conditions were included (N = 207,595 women, mean age = 56.25 years, standard deviation = 8.01 years)

In this study we use aggregated weighted scores of environmental effects to study environmental influences on well-being and happiness. We find that the PES-S explains about &#8764;12% of the variance in happiness. These predictive values did not change during the COVID-19 pandemic (N = 3214)

Hearing loss and tinnitus have been proposed as potential indicators of impaired mental health and brain morphological changes. We conducted a community-based cohort study including 129 610 participants aged 40-69 years at recruitment to the UK Biobank.

Myocardial infarction is a leading cause of death globally but is notoriously difficult to predict. We aimed to identify biomarkers of an imminent first myocardialinfarction and design relevant prediction models. Brain natriuretic peptide was most consistently associated with the risk.

Study aimed to examine the associations between air pollutants and the risk of incident musculoskeletal diseases. PM 2.5 and PM2.5-10 exhibited the most significant effect on elevated risk. Individuals with extreme BMI or lower socioeconomic status had a higher risk.

Air pollution (AP) and impaired lipid metabolism contribute to type 2 diabetes (T2D) Little is known about the detailed associations of AP to lipidomic markers. We aimed to examine the associations between long-term AP exposure, plasma metabolomic markers, and incident T2D. We identified six PCS representing distinct metabolic patterns.

 Creativity is known to be heritable and exhibits familial aggregation with psychiatric disorders. The complex nature of their relationship has not been well-established. We demonstrate that using an expanded and validated machine learning (ML)-based phenotyping of occupational creativity can allow us to further understand the trait of creativity.

Study included 307 304 British participants from the United Kingdom Biobank. Over a median follow-up duration of 13.67 years, a total of 2476 initial IS events were detected.

Regular participation in aerobic physical activity is associated with a reduced risk of dementia. It is currently unclear whether this association is due to the total volume or intensity of physical activity. The study analyzed 386,486 adults from the UK Biobank.

There is limited information on modifiable risk factors for young-onset dementia (YOD) This prospective cohort study used data from the UK Biobank, with baseline assessment between 2006 and 2010. During 2 891 409 person-years of follow-up, 485 incident YOD cases (251 of 485 men [51.8%]) were observed. 15 factors were significantly associated with a higher YOD risk. These factors should be incorporated in future dementia prevention initiatives.

It remained unclear whether central blood pressures (BP) was more closely associated with cardiovascular disease (CVD) than brachial BP in different age groups. Study included 34 289 adults without baseline CVD from the UK Biobank dataset.

Cerebral amyloid angiopathy (CAA) is a common cause of spontaneous intracerebral hemorrhage in older patients. The association between CAA and other subtypes of intracranial hemorrhage remains poorly understood. To determine whether CAA is an independent risk factor for isolated nontraumatic subdural hemorrhage, data were analyzed from October 2022 to October 2023.

Recent studies have indicated that the number of individuals living with pain has risen in recent years. Nearly half of all adults in some countries living with some form of pain. Researchers have focused on differences in pain across different sociodemographic groups. However, studies fail to consider the confounding role of early life characteristics.

Ovarian cancer (OC) is commonly diagnosed among older women who have comorbidities. We analysed OC and OC subtype-specific genetic risk scores (OC-GRS) for an association with 889 diseases and 43 other traits. Mendelian randomizaiton analysis provided robust evidence for the association of OC with higher risk of "secondary malignant neoplasm"

Large differences between estimated glomerular filtration rate (eGFR) based on cystatin C and creatinine occur commonly. We developed 2 prediction models comprising 375,175 participants. Strong predictors of lower eGFRcys were older age, male sex, South Asian ethnicity, current smoker, history of thyroid dysfunction.

Study aims to investigate the effect of Ramadan fasting on the metabolic profile and risk of chronic diseases. Ramadan fasting was associated with changes in 14 metabolites independent of changes in body composition. The metabolic scores for lung cancer, colorectal cancer, and breast cancer were lower after Ramadan.

Mouth ulcers are the most common ulcerative condition and encompass several clinical diagnoses, including recurrent aphthous stomatitis (RAS) Despite previous evidence for heritability, it is not clear which specific genetic loci are implicated in RAS. This study finds 97 variants which alter the odds of developing non-specific mouth ulcers.

Schizophrenia is a debilitating and heritable mental disorder associated with lower reproductive success. The prevalence of schizophrenia is stable over populations and time, resulting in an evolutionary puzzle. One possibility is that increased genetic liability for schizophrenia, in the absence of the disorder itself, may confer some reproductive advantage. We assessed the correlation and causal effect of genetic liability with number of children, age at first birth and number of sexual partners.

Sleep is an essential state of decreased activity and alertness. molecular factors regulating sleep duration remain unknown. We identify 78 loci for self-reported habitual sleep duration (p)

We perform genetic fine-mapping for blood cell traits in the UK Biobank to identify putative causal variants. These variants are enriched in genes encoding proteins in trait-relevant biological pathways and in accessible chromatin of hematopoietic progenitors. We explore patterns of developmental enhancer activity, predict molecular mechanisms, and identify likely target genes.

Comorbidity between coronary heart disease (CHD) and depression is evident. It is unclear whether the two diseases have shared underlying mechanisms. We showed family history of heart disease was associated with a 20% increase in depression risk.

The extent to which genetic risk factors are shared between childhood-onset (COA) and adult-onsets (AOA) asthma has not been estimated. On the basis of data from the UK Biobank study (n = 447,628), we found that the variance in disease liability explained by common variants is higher for COA. Variants associated with obesity and smoking had a stronger contribution to the risk of AOA.

The PERIOD2 (PER2) gene is a core molecular component of the circadian clock. A missense variant of PER2 common in European populations has been shown to associate with later chronotype. Later chronotype is associated with longer intrinsic circadian period.

Obesity is known to be heritable and highly polygenic. The majority of inherited susceptibility is related to the cumulative effect of many common DNA variants. We derive and validate a new polygenic predictor comprised of 2.1 million common variants to quantify this susceptibility.

Sleep is an essential human function but its regulation is poorly understood. Using accelerometer data from 85,670 UK Biobank participants, we perform a genome-wide association study of sleep traits.

Insulin resistance, broadly defined as the reduced ability of insulin to exert its biological action, has been associated with depression and cognitive dysfunction in observational studies. It is unclear whether these associations are causal and whether they might be underpinned by other shared factors. To address this knowledge gap, we capitalized on the stability of genetic biomarkers through the lifetime.

Arterial stiffness index (ASI) is independently associated with blood pressure (BP) and coronary artery disease (CAD) epidemiologically. It is unknown whether these associations represent causal relationships. Here, we assess whether genetic predisposition to increased ASI is associated with elevated BP and CAD risk.

Chronic kidney disease (CKD) is a growing health burden currently affecting 10-15% of adults worldwide. Estimated glomerular filtration rate (eGFR) as a marker of kidney function is commonly used to diagnose CKD. We analyze eGFR data from the Nord-Tr&#248;ndelag Health Study and Michigan Genomics Initiative and perform a GWAS meta-analysis.

Only roughly 1% of the adult population has atypically reversed, rightward hemispheric language dominance. The genetic-developmental program that underlies leftward language laterality is unknown, as are the causes of atypical variation.

Recent studies have highlighted the role of gene networks in disease biology. To formally assess this, we constructed a broad set of pathway, network, and pathway+network annotations. We applied stratified LD score regression to 42 diseases and complex traits to identify enriched annotations.

Mitral valve prolapse (MVP) is a common heart valve disease. MVP is characterized by excess extracellular matrix secretion and cellular disorganization. We show that genes at risk loci are involved in biological functions relevant to actin filament organization, cytoskeleton biology, and cardiac development.

Genome-wide association studies (GWAS) for type 2 diabetes have uncovered >400 risk loci, primarily in populations of European and Asian ancestry. Here, we aimed to discover additionaltype 2 diabetes risk loco (including African-specific variants) and fine-map association signals by performing genetic analysis in African populations. We identified 21 with shared causal variants in African and non-African populations.

Genome-wide association studies (GWASs) are valuable for understanding human biology. But associated loci typically contain multiple associated variants and genes. Algorithms that prioritize likely causal genes and variants for a given phenotype can provide biological interpretations.

Bone area is one measure of bone size that is easily derived from dual-energy X-ray absorptiometry (DXA) scans. In a GWA study of DXA bone area of the hip and lumbar spine, we find thirteen independent association signals at twelve loci that replicate in samples of European and East Asian descent. The strongest DXA area association is with rs11614913[T] in the microRNA MIR196A2 gene.

The human brain demonstrates structural and functional asymmetries which have implications for ageing and mental and neurological disease development. We used a set of magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) metrics derived from structural and diffusion MRI data in N=48,040 UK Biobank participants to evaluate age-related differences in brain asymmetry.

Polygenic risk score (PRS) models have transformed the field of genetics. However, the impact of genotype-environment interaction (GxE) on the performance and applicability of PRS models remains a crucial aspect to be explored. We propose novel GxEPRS models that incorporate additive and interaction genetic effects.

Recurrent pericarditis is a treatment challenge and often a debilitating condition. Drugs inhibiting interleukin 1 cytokines are a promising new treatment option, but their use is based on scarce biological evidence and clinical trials of modest sizes. The contributions of innate and adaptive immune processes to the pathophysiology are incompletely understood.

We showed an association between atrial fibrillation and rare loss-of-function (LOF) variants in the cardiac splicing regulator RBM20. We demonstrated altered splicing of sarcomere genes and differential expression in key cardiac genes. Our results implicate alternative splicing as a novel proarrhythmic mechanism in the atria.

 association of candidate single nucleotide variants (SNVs) related to mechanisms of COVID-19 complications has been seldom analysed. Our aim was to test and validate the effect of candidate SNVs on severity. We identified 14 novel SNVs and confirmed eight previously related to severity in the CARGENCORS data. In the meta-analysis, five SNVs were significantly associated to severity.

The relationship between type 2 diabetes mellitus (T2DM) and gallstone disease (GSD) has been incompletely understood. We aimed to investigate their phenotypic and genetic associations and evaluate the biological mechanisms underlying these associations. A unidirectional phenotypal association was observed, where individuals with T2DM exhibited a higher GSD risk.

Study used UK Biobank data from 2006 to 2021 (n = 23 685; participant age 40-71 years, 63.5% male) Models showed low-to-moderate discrimination performance on external validation. Most models had low calibration with overprediction of the observed risk.

Adipose stem and precursor cells (ASPCs) are an understudied, yet crucial adipose cell type. We found that the SAT ASPC proportions significantly decrease with age in an obesity-dependent way. We identified 76 genes that are differentially expressed by age in SAT and functionally enriched for developmental processes.

It is unclear whether the atherogenic index of plasma (AIP) is associated with major adverse cardiovascular events (MACEs) in the general population. A total of 361,644 participants (aged 56.19 +/- 8.09 years; 44.79% male) free of a history of MACEs at baseline from the UK Biobank data were included in the analysis.

Insulin resistance has been reported to increase the risk of breast, prostate and colorectal cancer. The role of insulin resistance and its interaction with genetic risk in the development of lung cancer remains controversial. We aimed to explore the association between a novel metabolic score for insulin resistance (METS-IR) and lung cancer risk.

Study looked at 84,254 women enrolled in the UK Biobank between 2006 and 2010. There were 2300 cases of type 2 diabetes during an average follow-up of 4.49 years. We found a significant increase in T2D risk across RRS categories.

Psychiatric disorders have been associated with higher risk for future dementia. Understanding how pre-dementia psychiatric disorders (PDPD) relate to established dementia genetic risks has implications for dementia prevention.

Lipoprotein(a) (Lp[a) has been established as a significant factor in cardiovascular disease. Its connection to CKD risk remains a topic of debate. Existing evidence indicates diverse risks of kidney disease among individuals with various renal function indicators, even when within the normal range.

 genome-wide association study meta-analysis of thyroid function in up to 271,040 individuals of European ancestry. Loci explained 14.1%, 6.0%, 9.5% and 1.1% of the total variation in TSH, FT4, total T3 and free T3 concentrations. Polygenic risk score and Mendelian randomization analyses showed the effects of genetically determined variation in thyroid function on various clinical outcomes.

Adherence to a healthy lifestyle may be a low-cost and effective strategy to decrease frailty-induced health risks across different social environments. We included 15 594 frail participants at baseline from the UK Biobank study.

Age-related macular degeneration is the leading cause of central vision loss in the elderly. One-third of the genetic contribution to this disease remains unexplained. We analyzed targeted sequencing data from two independent cohorts.

Physical activity (PA) is recognized as a key bone mass determinant across life. However, athlete studies suggest that it may be less effective in women and older individuals. This has not been explored within the general population. We aimed to address this knowledge gap using data from the UK Biobank Study.

Cardiovascular risk burden is associated with dementia risk and neurodegeneration-related brain structure. The role of genetics and incident cardiovascular disease (CVD) remains unclear. This study examined the association of overall cardiovascular risk burden with the risk of major dementia subtypes.

UK population-based prospective cohort study, involving 385,275 UK Biobank participants. During a median 12.52-year follow-up, 2,131 participants incident PD. Analysis showed that fish oil supplement users had a lower PD risk.

The majority of participants exhibited either vitamin D deficiency (18.3%) or insufficiency (34.0%). Vitamin D deficiency was less prevalent among users of vitamin D (6.9%) or multivitamin preparations (9.5%) than among nonusers (21.5%).

Multiple sclerosis cases and controls were identified in UK Biobank, a longitudinal cohort study of 500,000 British adults. Plasma proteins were assayed in 50,000 participants using the Olink proximity extension assay. Higher levels of plasma proteins involved in coagulation were associated with lower T2 lesion burden and preserved brain volume.

A dataset of 96,487 participants from UK Biobank was included with 1830 cases of incident AOA during an average follow-up of 9.68 years. Participants with the highest intake of total sugar, free sugar, and fiber intake showed a 17% and 22% increased risk of AOA. Substitution of 5 % energy from free sugars with 5% energy from non-free sugars was associated with a significantly lower risk. This study highlights the critical role of carbohydrate types in AOA prevention.

People with atrial fibrillation had an increased future risk of all-cause dementia, Alzheimer's disease, vascular dementia. The applicability of our findings to diverse ethnicities might require careful consideration and the behind biological mechanisms need to be further revealed. Atrial fibillation screening and prevention strategies should take into account to prevent and delay the onset of dementia.

Elevated hemoglobin A1C (AOR = 2.01 [1.35, 2.88]) was associated with increased dementia incidence. Indicators of liver dysfunction: elevated gamma glutamyltransferase and albumin. Both low and high concentrations of insulin-like growth factor 1 were found to be risk factors.

The evidence regarding the relationship between different types of beverages and cardiovascular health in individuals with type 2 diabetes (T2D) is scarce. We analyzed the associations of individual beverage intake with risks of CVD and ischemic heart disease (IHD) in 7315 participants with T2D.

GIFT (gene-based integrative fine-mapping through conditional TWAS) narrows down the set size of putatively causal genes by 32.16-91.32%. The genes identified by GIFT highlight the importance of vessel regulation in determining blood pressures and lipid metabolism for regulating lipid levels.

 Accelerated brain aging (ABA) intricately links with age-associated neurodegenerative and neuropsychiatric diseases. This investigation leveraged data from the UK Biobank for a comprehensive analysis. Subpopulations of accelerated brain aging and resilient brain aging were delineated based on the error between actual age and predicted brain age.

The number of identified potential drug targets is often prohibitively large to experimentally evaluate in wet lab experiments. In this review, we discuss principles of genetically guided drug development. We present a range of biomedical resources which can be used to annotate and prioritise disease-associated proteins identified by these studies.

Prior observational studies suggest an association between intra-pancreatic fat deposition (IPFD) and pancreatic ductal adenocarcinoma (PDAC) However, the causal relationship is unclear. In the observational study, we use UK Biobank data (N = 29,463, median follow-up: 4.5 years) and find that high IPFD (>10%) is associated with PDAC risk.

Genome-wide association studies (GWASs) have achieved remarkable success in associating thousands of genetic variants with complex traits. The presence of linkage disequilibrium (LD) makes it challenging to identify the causal variants. Many fine-mapping methods have been proposed to assign well-calibrated probabilities of causality.

A leading theory argues that vascular risk may drive adverse cardiac remodelling. This leads to chronic cerebral hypoperfusion and subsequent brain structural damage. This study tests that prediction in a large sample of the UK Biobank (N = 11,962)

Study was to test associations between documented, prevalent genetic variation (single nucleotide polymorphism, SNP) in DNA repair genes, cognitive function, and brain structure. SNPs in base excision repair (BER) genes of the bifunctional DNA glycosylases were considered. Statistically significant associations with cognition were detected for 12 out of the 13 SNPs analyzed.

Vascular brain injury (VBI) may be an under-recognised contributor to mobility impairment. We examined associations between MRI VBI biomarkers and impaired mobility. In ARIC, imbalance was associated with four of five VBI measures.

The human retina is a multilayered tissue that offers a unique window into systemic health. We conducted genotypic and phenotypic analyses of retinal layer thicknesses using macular OCT images from 44,823 UK Biobank participants. We identified multiple inherited genetic loci and acquired systemic cardio-metabolic-pulmonary conditions associated with thinner retinal layers.

Study aimed to identify the most predictive factors for the development of type 2 diabetes. HbA1c emerged as the foremost predictor, followed by BMI, waist circumference, blood glucose, family history of diabetes, gamma-glutamyl transferase, waist-hip ratio, HDL cholesterol.

A total of 422,531 participants from the UK biobank were included in this study. Longitudinal associations of grip strength and walking pace with the risk of incident PD were investigated.

Sarcopenic obesity (SO) is an age-related disease characterized by excessive adiposity and low muscle mass or function. Although obesity and sarcopenia are heritable conditions, the genetic determinants of SO have not been fully understood. We conducted a large-scale exome-wide association analysis of SO.

Type 2 diabetes (T2D) is known as one of the important risk factors for the severity and mortality of COVID-19. Here, we evaluate the impact of T2D and its genetic susceptibility on the severity of the disease. We also observed that the mortality rate for SARS-CoV-2-infected patients was approximately 2 to 7 times higher.

Artificial intelligence (AI), especially GPT-4, offers new opportunities. Traditional risk prediction methods such as the Framingham and American College of Cardiology/American Heart Association (ACC/AHA) have been widely used in the practice.

The protective role of estrogen in the development of dementia remains uncertain. We investigated the role of lifetime cumulative exposure to estrogen in dementia in the UK Biobank. Reproductive characteristics, including estrogen length and history of surgery, were used as exposure variables.

Predicting post-operative complications and revision surgery is critical for surgical planning and patient counseling. Due to the relatively small number of cases of ASD surgery, machine learning applications have been limited. We present the novel application of advanced models (CNN, LLM, GWAS) using complex data types (radiographs, clinical notes, genomics) for ASD outcome prediction.

The All of Us Research Program seeks to enroll 1 million diverse participants who share multiple sources of data. It is important to understand the phenomic profiles of its participants to conduct research in this cohort. The estimates of prevalence of diseases in the US general population were obtained from the Global Burden of Diseases study.

A genetic contribution to refractive error has been confirmed by the discovery of more than 150 associated variants. Environmental factors such as education and time outdoors also demonstrate strong associations. Currently however, the extent of gene-environment or gene-gene interactions in myopia is unknown.

A sub-sample of 91,648 UK Biobank participants reported moderate-to-vigorous PA (MVPA), lifestyle activities, TV viewing, computer use and sleep. Sleeping either more or less than 7 h/day at baseline was associated with lower PA at follow-up. An exception was 'walking/standing at work' in women.

The human genetic basis of tuberculosis (TB) has long remained elusive. We report a study of this variant in the UK Biobank cohort. The frequency of P1104A homozygotes was much higher in patients with TB (6/620, 1%) than in controls (228/114,473, 0.2%)

Colorectal cancer (CRC) is a leading cause of cancer-related death worldwide. It has a strong heritable basis. We report a genome-wide association analysis of 34,627 CRC cases and 71,379 controls of European ancestry that identifies SNPs at 31 new CRC risk loci.

CADM2 has been associated with a range of behavioural and metabolic traits. We assessed genetic variants in the CADM2 locus for association with phenotypes in the UK Biobank, IMPROVE, PROCARDIS and SCARFSHEEP studies. A wide range of metabolic phenotypes were meta-analysed.

Streptococcus pneumoniae is a common nasopharyngeal colonizer. It can cause life-threatening invasive diseases such as empyema, bacteremia and meningitis. Genetic variation of host and pathogen is known to play a role in invasive pneumococcal disease.

The genomics era has brought useful tools to dissect the genetic architecture of complex traits. Here we propose a multivariate reaction norm model (MRNM) to tackle genotype-covariate (G-C) correlation and interaction problems. We apply MRNM to the UK Biobank data in analysis of body mass index.

Neuroticism is a stable personality trait associated with self-harm and suicidal ideation. It is correlated with coping styles, but its value as an independent predictor of these outcomes is disputed.

Growth differentiation factor 15 (GDF-15) may explain the potential cardioprotective and anti-cancer properties of metformin. We conducted a Mendelian randomisation study to examine the role of GDF- 15 in risk of coronary artery disease (CAD) and breast and colorectal cancer.

Statin use was associated with 39% lower risk of liver cancer in the PCCIU (adjusted OR 0.61, 95% CI 0.43-0.87) We found a consistent inverse relationship between statin use and risk of primary liver cancer which was only seen for HCC but not IBDC.

Diffusion weighted magnetic resonance imaging data enables a range of promising imaging phenotypes probing structural connections. The reliability and biological sensitivity and specificity of diffusion data depend on processing pipeline. A state-of-the-art framework for data processing facilitates cross-study harmonisation.

Study aimed to identify an efficient polygenic predictor for BC based on best available evidence. Four different genetic risk scores were compared in two population-based biobank cohorts. metaGRS2 combined on the effects of more than 900 SNPs provided best predictive ability for breast cancer.

Polygenic risk scores (PRS) are designed to serve as single summary measures that are easy to construct. They have been used for stratification and prediction of disease risk. This study was conducted using data from 30,702 unrelated, genotyped patients of recent European descent.

Anorexia nervosa is a complex and serious illness affecting 0.9-4% of women and 0.3% of men. Mortality rates are higher than those in other psychiatric disorders and outcomes are unacceptably poor. Here we combine data from the Anorexia Nervosa Genetics Initiative (ANGI)8,9 and the Eating Disorders Working Group of the Psychiatric Genomics Consortium (PGC-ED) and conduct a genome-wide association study of 16,992 cases and 55,525 controls. We identified eight significant loci.

Genome-wide association studies (GWAS) have identified thousands of variants associated with complex traits. Most of these variants overlap with expression QTLs, indicating their potential involvement in regulation of gene expression. Using independent association summary statistics, we find that the majority of these loci were missed by GWAS due to power issues.

Knee pain is one of the most common musculoskeletal complaints that brings people to medical attention. Approximately 50% of individuals over the age of 50 report an experience of knee pain within the past 12 months. We identified two loci in or near GDF5 and COL27A1 that are associated with knee pain.

Inferring the full genealogical history of a set of DNA sequences is a core problem in evolutionary biology. However, current methods are limited, and the most accurate techniques are able to process no more than a hundred samples.

A total of 5596 participants of the UK Biobank were included for whom cardiovascular magnetic resonance imaging and genetic data were available. Major exclusion criteria included nonwhite ethnicity, major cardiovascular disease, and body mass index >30 or  2 . A genetic risk score to estimate genetically predicted SBP (gSBP) was constructed based on 107 previously established genetic variants.

Transposable elements (TE) comprise roughly half of the human genome. They have been widely hypothesized to contribute to the evolution of gene regulation. The contribution of TE to the genetic architecture of diseases remains unknown.

Gastroesophageal reflux disease (GERD) is caused by gastric acid entering the esophagus. We conduct a large GERD GWAS meta-analysis (80,265 cases, 305,011 controls) identifying 25 independent genome-wide significant loci for GERD. Several of the implicated genes are existing or putative drug targets.

 Understanding genetic architecture of plasma lipidome could provide better insights into lipid metabolism and its link to cardiovascular diseases. Here, we perform genome-wide association analyses of 141 lipid species and 25 CVD related phenotypes.

We aimed to investigate associations between common infections and neuroimaging markers of dementia risk. Interactions between serology measures and apolipoprotein E (APOE) genotype were tested. Findings were meta-analyzed across cohorts. Seropositivity to John Cunningham virus associated with smaller brain volumes in basic models.

UK Biobank cohort included 109,301 adults with obesity free of baseline CVD. MHO was associated with a 42% reduced risk of CVD compared with MUO. A significant interaction effect between PA and metabolic status on CVD risk was found.

Liver disease is linked to series of extrahepatic multisystem manifestations. Little is known about the associations between liver and eye diseases, especially cataract, the global leading cause of blindness. We aimed to investigate whether severe liver diseases were associated with an increased risk of the cataracts.

Sleep duration, chronotype/morningness, napping, sleeplessness/insomnia, and getting up from bed were examined. Study found decreased risk of terminated healthspan for healthy sleep behaviors such as 'sleep duration 7-8h/d'

The modifying effect of prediabetic status on the association of social isolation and loneliness with the risk of type 2 diabetes mellitus (T2DM) remains uncertain. We aimed to explore whether predi diabetic status modifies the association with incident T2DM.

Polygenic risk scores (PRSs) predict individuals' genetic risk of developing complex diseases. To date, large GWASs exist primarily for the European population. The quality of PRS prediction declines when applied to other ethnicities.

Previous observational studies established a positive relationship between snoring and stroke. We aimed to investigate the causal effect of snoring on stroke. Based on 82,339 unrelated individuals with genotyping data of Asian descent from the China Kadoorie Biobank.

Gastrointestinal (GI) cancers account for a significant incidence and mortality rates of cancers globally. We aimed to investigate the association between the phenomic features and GI cancers in a large cohort study. We included 502,369 subjects aged 37-73 years in the UK Biobank recruited since 2006.

NHS Health Check is a preventive programme in the UK designed to screen for cardiovascular risk and to aid in primary disease prevention. Despite its widespread implementation, the effectiveness of the NHS Health Check for longer-term disease prevention is unclear. In this study, we measured the rate of new diagnoses in UK Biobank participants who underwent the NHS health check compared with those who did not.

Depression has been linked to an increased risk of cardiovascular and respiratory diseases. However, its impact on cardiac and lung function remains unclear, especially when accounting for potential gene-environment interactions. We developed a novel polygenic and gene- Environment interaction risk score (PGIRS) for non-depressed individuals.

Study included 274,160 participants from the UK Biobank. Of the 249 metabolites examined, 143 were significantly associated with incident ACD, 130 with AD, and 140 with VaD. Lipoprotein lipid concentrations, linoleic acid, sphingomyelin, glucose, and branched-chain amino acids ranked top in importance.

The relationship between feelings of tense, as a significant emotional distress, and dementia remains unclear. This study aimed to evaluate the association between feeling of tense and dementia. During a median follow-up of 12.7 years among 482,360 participants, 7331 dementia cases were identified.

Cow's milk is frequently included in the human diet, but the relationship between milk intake and type 2 diabetes (T2D) remains controversial. Using data from the Hispanic Community Health Study/Study of Latinos, we show that in both sexes, higher milk intake is associated with lower risk of T2D.

Plasma proteins are promising biomarkers and potential drug targets in lung cancer. We performed proteome-wide Mendelian randomization meta-analysis (PW-MR- meta) based on lung cancer genome-wide association studies. 270 plasma proteins were identified using PW-MR meta- analysis, including 39 robust causal proteins.

Tinnitus is a heritable, highly prevalent auditory disorder treated by multiple medical specialties. Previous GWAS indicated high genetic correlations between tinnitus and hearing loss. We present a GWAS meta-analysis, triple previous sample sizes, and expand to non-European ancestries.

Angiopoietin-like protein-3 (ANGPTL3) could reduce lipoprotein-lipid levels and atherosclerotic cardiovascular disease (ASCVD) risk. Mendelian randomisation was used to determine whether genetic variations could causally influence triglyceride and apolipoprotein B (apoB) levels as well as coronary artery disease.

The association between Metabolic Syndrome (MetS), its components, and the risk of osteoarthritis (OA) has been a topic of conflicting evidence in different studies. The aim of this present study is to investigate the link between MetS and OA using data from the UK Biobank.

Study included UK Biobank participants who responded to questions concerning five components of life satisfaction at baseline. Overall life satisfaction was inversely associated with all-cause mortality. Health satisfaction showed the strongest association with mortality.

Air pollutants are important contributors to cardiovascular diseases, but associations between long-term exposure to air pollutants and the risk of abdominal aortic aneurysm (AAA) are still unknown. This study investigated the combined effects and interactions between air pollutants exposure and genetic predisposition.

Previous studies have shown that excessive alcohol consumption is associated with poor sleep. This study included 383,357 UKB participants (mean [SD] age, 57.0 [8.0] years; 46% male) who consumed a mean (SD) of 9.0 (10.0) standard drinks per week. Light-moderate-heavy alcohol consumption was linearly linked to snoring and the evening chronotype but nonlinearly associated with insomnia, sleep duration, and napping.

This work aims to investigate how smoking exerts effect on the development of inflammatory bowel disease (IBD) A prospective cohort study and a Mendelian randomization study are first conducted to evaluate the association between smoking behaviors, smoking-related DNA methylation and the risks of Crohn's disease and ulcerative colitis. Compared to never smoking, current and previous smoking habits are associated with increased CD and UC.

The current atherosclerotic cardiovascular disease risk prediction models used in clinical practice performed better in the non-inflammatory bowel disease (IBD) cohort compared with IBD. This suggests the need for a more specific risk prediction model tailored to the IBD population.

Study investigated the potential causal association of lipoprotein (a) levels with pulse wave velocity (PWV) Genetic variants associated with Lp(a) were retrieved from the UK Biobank GWAS (N = 290,497)

Obesity and diabetes are associated inversely with low-grade prostate cancer risk. Free testosterone was associated most strongly positively in normal weight men and men with diabetes. The inverse association with obesity was stronger for high-FT.

Previous falls are a well-documented risk factor for subsequent fracture. The relationship between self-reported falls and fracture risk was estimated in an international meta-analysis of individual-level data from 46 prospective cohorts. Previous falls should be considered as an additional risk factor in future iterations of FRAX to improve fracture risk prediction.

Prioritizing disease-critical cell types by integrating genome-wide association studies (GWAS) with functional data is a fundamental goal. Single-cell chromatin accessibility (scATAC) and gene expression (scRNA-seq) have characterized cell types at high resolution. Studies integrating GWAS with scATAC-seq have shown promise.

Lifestyle factors after a cancer diagnosis could influence the survival of cancer survivors. A healthy lifestyle score (HLS) was defined based on five common lifestyle factors that related to cancer survival. Never smoking, light alcohol consumption, adequate physical activity and optimal BMI were significantly associated with a lower risk of all-cause mortality.
