The Black Death pandemic (1346-1353) devastated European populations. What has remained less understood is the effect of the pandemic on human mobility and genetic diversity at the local scale. We report 275 ancient genomes from later medieval and postmedieval Cambridgeshire of individuals buried before and after the Black Death.

We investigated phenotypic leucocyte telomere length (LTL), genetically predicted LTL (gTL), and lung cancer risk among 371 890 participants, including 2829 incident cases, from the UK Biobank. Mendelian Randomization analyses supported causal associations between longer telomeres and lung cancers. The associations were prominent among never smokers.

Clonal haematopoiesis of indeterminate potential (CHIP) and atrial fibrillation (AF) are age-related conditions. This study investigated the potential role of CHIP in the development and progression of AF.

 Epidemiological studies have shown a positive relationship between birthweight and breast cancer. We re-explored the association between them in the UK Biobank cohort. Age of menarche and age at menopause as two potential mediators.

Little is known about the effects of night shifts and their interactions with genetic factors on chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD) In this study, we aim to investigate relationships between long-term night shift work exposure and COPD risk.

The Dietary Approaches to Stop Hypertension (DASH) diet score lowers blood pressure (BP) We examined interactions between genotype and the DASH diet score in relation to systolic BP. The highest narrow sense heritability accounted by single nucleotide polymorphisms potentially interacting with the Dash diet score was for gene ST20 at 15q25.1.

Premorbid constipation is associated with a 2.28-fold higher risk of depression. Participants with constipation were more likely to report depressive symptoms than people without. Gastroenterologists and primary care physicians should pay more attention to the depressive symptoms of constipation patients.

Uric acid-lowering agents such as xanthine oxidase inhibitors have potential cardioprotective effects. Studies on their use in preventing cardiovascular diseases are lacking. We investigated the genetically proxied effects of reducing uric acid on ischemic cardiovascular diseases in a lipid-level-stratified population.

The UK Biobank identified genetic loci that influence humoral immune response to multiple infections. An insertion-deletion variant thought to affect NFKB1 expression was mapped as the likely causal variant. The deletion allele was associated with an increased risk of infection from diverse pathogens but had a protective effect against allergic disease.

UK Biobank has made general practitioner (GP) data (censoring date 2016-2017) available for approximately 45% of the cohort. Hospital inpatient and death registry (referred to as "HES/Death") data are available cohort-wide through 2018-2022 depending on whether the data comes from England, Wales or Scotland.

Women with diabetes are at higher risk of cardiovascular diseases (CVD) than men with diabetes. However, the sex difference in the association between the degree of risk factor control and the risk of CVD in patients with diabetes is unclear.

Steatotic liver disease (SLD) prevails as the most common chronic liver disease yet lack approved treatments due to incomplete understanding of pathogenesis. Recently, elevated hepatic and circulating interleukin 32 (IL-32) levels were found in individuals with severe SLD. We demonstrate in vitro that incubation with IL-32&#946; protein leads to an increase in intracellular triglyceride synthesis.

Previous studies have shown that respiratory diseases are associated with an increased risk of rheumatoid arthritis (RA) However, whether there is a correlation between chronic rhinosinusitis (CRS) and RA is not known. This is the first study to reveal an association between CRS and RA.

Oily fish intake and FOS use were reported by 38 % and 31 % of participants, respectively. Increasing oily fish intake was associated with a higher likelihood of Fos use ( P   n -3 PUFA (OR 6.7 (95 % CI 6.3, 7.1)

Long-term exposure to air pollution has been found to contribute to the development of cognitive decline. We aimed to assess the association between various air pollutants and cognitive impairment and dementia. We also explore the modification effects of lifestyle and genetic predisposition.

Previously observational studies did not draw a clear conclusion on the association between fatty liver diseases and bone mineral density (BMD) Our large-scale studies revealed that MAFLD and hepatic steatosis had no causal effect on BMD, while some metabolic factors were correlated with BMD. The findings have important implications for understanding the relationship between. fatty liver disease and BMD and may help direct the clinical management of.MAFLD patients with osteoporosis.

A total of 369,065 individuals were included in the present study based on the UK Biobank. During a median follow-up period of 12.04 years, a total of 4901 incident RA cases were documented. MetS (hazard ratio [HR] 1.22, 95% CI 1.14-1.30) and 4 of its 5 components (elevated waist circumference [WC] and elevated triglyceride [ TG] level) were associated with an increased risk of RA.

Clonal hematopoiesis (CH) can be caused by single gene mutations or mosaic chromosomal alterations. CH is associated with a significantly increased risk of hematologic malignancies. Improved prognostication of transformation risk is urgently needed for routine clinical practice.

Cross-sectional analysis was performed in 618 consecutive ADPKD patients assessed and followed-up for over a decade. A total of 123 patients (19.9%) had reached kidney failure by the study date. A PKD1-T genotype had the strongest influence on the probability of reduced baseline kidney function.

Maternal circulating cortisol levels in pregnancy are associated with lower offspring birth weight. However, it is possible that the associations are due to residual confounding. We performed two-sample Mendelian Randomisation using a single genetic variant. We also tested the genetic variant's effect on pregnancy cortisol.

Green space, blue space, and the natural environment (GBN) are associated with lower risk of psychiatric disorders in middle-aged and older adults. The elderly, men, and those living with some comorbid conditions may derive greater benefits associated with exposure to GBN.

Inflammatory Bowel Disease (IBD) and Parkinson's disease (PD) are both chronic, progressive disorders. We conducted a prospective cohort study using the Cox proportional hazards model. The results show that IBD had no effect on the risk of PD.

White matter hyperintensities (WMH) increase the risk of stroke and cognitive impairment. This study aims to determine the cross-sectional and longitudinal associations between adiposity and WMH.

Migraine is one of the most common diseases that significantly impairs the quality of life. This condition has a pronounced genetic component. Genes responsible for the development of monogenic forms of hemiplegic migraine have already been identified. The search for genetic associations with common migraine and its subtypes continues.

Non-alcoholic fatty liver disease (NAFLD) has rapidly become the most common liver disease worldwide. Modern lifestyles have been linked to this rise in prevalence. We investigated how shift working patterns and chronotype were associated with hepatic fat fraction and NAFLD in 282,303 UK Biobank participants.

Lin and Sullivan propose a method to provide an optimal test statistic adjusted for the correlation. PASTRY outperformed the standard method on both simulated and real datasets in terms of the power symmetry.

Femoral neck width (FNW) derived from DXA scans may provide a useful adjunct to hip fracture prediction. Genome-wide association study (GWAS) identified 71 independent FNW SNPs. FNW and FN-BMD SNPs were used to generate genetic instruments for multivariable Mendelian randomization. Greater genetically determined FNW increased risk of all hip fractures.

In neuroimaging, predicted brain age is widely used to analyze different diseases. Age is an important variable to describe the expected brain's anatomy status across the normal aging trajectory. The deviation from that normative aging trajectory may provide some insights into neurological diseases.

Despite advances in defining somatic mutations that cause myeloid malignancies, a significant heritable component for these cancers remains largely unexplained. We identify inherited predisposition genes for these blood cancers. CTR9, which encodes a key component of the PAF1 transcription elongation complex, is among the significant genes identified.

Remnant cholesterol (RC) has been associated with atherosclerotic cardiovascular disease, but its relationship with hypertension remains unclear. This prospective cohort study aimed to investigate the association between RC and subsequent hypertension risk. Data from the UK Biobank, comprising 295,062 participants initially free of hypertension, were analyzed.

Echocardiographic studies indicate South Asian people have smaller ventricular volumes, lower mass and more concentric remodelling than White European people. But there are no data using cardiac MRI (CMR) to compare cardiac structure and function in the two groups.

Poor glycemic control with elevated levels of hemoglobin A1c (HbA1c) is associated with increased risk of cognitive impairment. We found that for every 6.75 mmol/mol increase in HbA 1c, there was an increase of 0.49 (95% CI = 0.24, 0.74;  p -value = 1.30 Ã— 10 -4 ) years in adjusted BAG. Subgroup analyses by sex and age revealed significant causal effects of Hb a1c onadjusted BAG among men aged 60-73.

A comprehensive overview of the associations between air pollution and the risk of gastrointestinal (GI) diseases has been lacking. We aimed to examine the relationships of long-term exposure to ambient particulate matter (PM) with aerodynamic diameter &#8804;2.5 &#956;m (PM 2.5) and nitrogen dioxide (NO 2 ) and nitrogen oxides (NO x) A total of 465,703 participants free of GI diseases in the UK Biobank were included at baseline.

We present a novel methodology to explore disease subtypes using our open-sourced BiomedSciAI toolkit. Of a 12,073-patient cohort, a subgroup of 440 IBD patients was discovered with an increased risk of a subsequent GI surgery.

 encryption properties of encG-reg are based on the random matrix theory by masking the original genotypic matrix without sacrificing precision of individual-level genotype data. We observed that the relatives estimated using enc G-reg was equivalently accurate with the estimation by KING, which is a widely used software.

A total of 6860 patients with type 2 diabetes were included in this study. Chronotype, sleep duration, insomnia, daytime sleepiness, and snoring were collected as a questionnaire. Restricted cubic splines were used to validate linear associations between sleep scores CVD events.

COVID-19 patients are at a higher risk of developing digestive diseases. The risks of GERD were increased stepwise with the severity of the acute phase of the infection. Even after 1-year follow-up, GERD and GI dysfunction continued to pose risks to patients.

Multiple sclerosis (MS) is a neuro-inflammatory and neurodegenerative disease that is most prevalent in Northern Europe. It is known that inherited risk for MS is located within or in close proximity to immune-related genes, but it is unknown when, where and how this genetic risk originated. This study highlights the critical importance of the Neolithic period and Bronze Age as determinants of modern immune responses.

We applied colocalization between T2D and 20 related metabolic traits, across 243 loci, to obtain inferences of shared casual variants. Network-based unsupervised hierarchical clustering was performed on variant-trait associations. Partitioned polygenic risk scores (PRSs) were generated for each cluster.

Apolipoproteins (APOs) have emerged as significant players in lipid metabolism that affects the risk of chronic disease. The impact of circulating APO concentrations on premature death remains undetermined. This study aimed to investigate associations of serum APOs with all-cause, cardiovascular disease (CVD)-related, and cancer-related mortality.

Diabetes (regardless of type) and obesity are associated with a range of musculoskeletal disorders. The causal mechanisms driving these associations are unknown for many upper limb pathologies. We used genetic techniques to test the causal link between glycemia, obesity and musculated conditions. We found evidence that long-term high glycaemia has a causal role in the aetiology of upper limb conditions.

The association between vitamin D and dementia risk in those with prediabetes remains uncertain. We aimed to evaluate the association of serum 25-hydroxyvitamin D (25OHD) with incident dementia among older adults withprediabetes.

Insulin resistance is a well-established risk factor for metabolic disease. The ratio of triglycerides to high-density lipoprotein cholesterol (TG:HDL-C) is a surrogate marker of IR. We conducted a genome-wide association study of the TG:HDl-C ratio.

The Holocene (beginning around 12,000 years ago) encompassed some of the most significant changes in human evolution. We modelled the selection landscape during the transition from hunting and gathering, to farming and pastoralism across West Eurasia. We identify key selection signals related to metabolism, including that selection at the FADS cluster began earlier than previously reported.

The varicella-zoster virus (VZV) infects over 95% of the population. VZV reactivation causes herpes zoster (HZ), known as shingles. We analyzed the immune signature and risk profile in HZ patients.

A total of 189,003 UK Biobank participants with at least one 24-h dietary assessment were included. All food items were categorised into three groups, including healthy plant foods, less healthy plant food, and animal foods. The Townsend deprivation index was used as the indicator of socioeconomic deprivation level. Cox proportional hazard models were used to estimate the hazard ratios of PDIs for all-cause and cause-specific mortality.

Non-alcoholic fatty liver disease (NAFLD) has emerged as the most prevalent chronic liver disease worldwide. Hepatic steatosis detection has remained largely based on surrogate serum biomarkers, elastography or biopsy. We used a total of 2959 participants from the UK biobank cohort and established the association of dual-energy X-ray absorptiometry (DXA)-derived body composition parameters.

Morphometric image analysis enables the quantification of differences in the shape and size of organs between individuals. We have applied morphometric methods to the study of the liver by constructing surface meshes from abdominal MRI images in 33,434 participants in the UK Biobank. The presence of type-2 diabetes accelerates age-related changes in the liver.

Physical activity (PA) is associated with mortality and cardiovascular disease (CVD) However, the effect of circadian PA trajectories remains ambiguous. This study aimed to explore ideal circadian PA patterns to reduce mortality and CVD, and potential mediators. 502,400 participants from UK Biobank were recruited between 2006 and 2010.

Study aimed to examine rheumatoid arthritis (RA) risk associated with hormonal and reproductive factors in women from the large cohort of the UK Biobank. Age at menarche >14 years was associated with a greater RA risk.

We assessed a total of 27,590 PD cases, 6701 PD proxies, and 3,106,080 controls from three data sets: 23andMe, Inc., UK Biobank, and AMP-PD. Based on well-known PD genes, 834 variants of interest were selected from the ClinVar annotated 23 andMe dataset. We performed a meta-analysis using summary statistics of all three studies.

We developed and validated a convolutional neural network (CNN)-based biological brain age prediction model. We used a multicohort dataset of cognitively healthy individuals (age range = 32.0-95.7 years) comprising 17,296 MRIs for training and evaluation. Salience maps of predictions reveal that periventricular, temporal, and insular regions are the most important for age prediction.

Psychiatric disorders are complex, heritable and highly polygenic. Current theoretical and empirical accounts have conceptualized them as disorders of brain connectivity. However, the extent to which these findings reflect common genetic factors remains unclear. Here we performed a multivariate genome-wide association analysis of functional magnetic resonance imaging-based functional brain connectivity in a sample of 30,701 individuals.

Irritable bowel syndrome (IBS) interacts with psychopathology in a complex way. Little is known about the underlying brain, biochemical, and genetic mechanisms. Study included 171,104 participants from the UK Biobank who underwent a thorough assessment.

Gene-SGAN is a multi-view, weakly-supervised deep clustering method. It dissects disease heterogeneity by jointly considering phenotypic and genetic data. It conferring genetic correlations to the disease subtypes and associated endophenotypic signatures. The method is broadly applicable to disease subtyping and endophenotype discovery.

Little is known about the role that combined sleep behaviors play in the association with chronic liver disease (CLD) risk. We included 408,560 participants initially free of CLD from the UK Biobank. A healthy sleep pattern was defined by early chronotype, sleep duration of 7-8 h/day, no insomnia, no snoring, and no excessive daytime sleepiness.

Study looked at associations of ideal cardiovascular health metrics (ICVHMs) with all-cause mortality among former and current smokers. Compared with never smokers, among former smokers, the multivariable-adjusted hazard ratio (HR) for all- Cause mortality was 1.82 (95%CI 1.71-1.92) for participants who had &#8804;2 ICVHm. Among current smokers,. the HRs for mortality were 2.74 (2.60-2.89) and 2.18 (1.78- 2.67)

Brain iron deposition is common in dementia, but whether serum iron is a causal risk factor is unknown. We aimed to determine whether genetic predisposition to higher serum iron status biomarkers increased risk of dementia and atrophy of grey matter. We analysed UK Biobank participants clustered into European, African and South Asian groups.

Antipsychotics (APs) are among the most widely prescribed medications. Previous studies on their effects on dementia risk are controversial and scarce. We aimed to examine the relationships of APs exposure with the risk of dementia.

Copy-number variations (CNVs) have been associated with rare and debilitating genomic disorders. We found that CNVs increased disease risk and caused earlier onset. 16% of these associations are indirect, acting by increasing body mass index (BMI) Signals mapped to 45 unique, non-overlapping regions, nine of which were linked to known GDs.

This contribution describes a linkage framework to assign individual-level environmental exposures to population-based cohorts using high-resolution spatio-temporal exposure maps. Framework can be used to address current limitations of exposure assessment for the analysis of health risks associated with environmental stressors.

Study aims to examine the associations of lifestyle transition with the risk of dementia and hippocampal volume. During a median follow-up period of 8.6 years, 120 (0.7 %) dementia events were documented. Among participants with healthy baseline lifestyles, the improvement group had a lower risk of incident dementia. Similar results were observed among participants with intermediate baseline lifestyles regarding dementia risk.

Alzheimer's disease (AD) genes and brain volumes begin among middle-aged and older adults. We tested whether genetic risk score for AD (AD-GRS) had age-dependent associations with 38 regional brain magnetic resonance imaging volumes. Trends began by age 45 for the nucleus accumbens and thalamus.

Type 2 diabetes (T2D) has been linked with site-specific upper gastrointestinal (UGI) cancers during the past decades. Study aimed to determine the association between T2D, glycaemic traits (random blood glucose and HbA1c) and UGI cancer.

Study included 14,543 individuals with T2D from the UK Biobank. A linear inverse association between the weighted lifestyle score and PAD was observed. A favorable lifestyle was associated with lower risk of PAD.

Ischemic heart disease (IHD) has a unique manifestation on electrocardiographic (ECG) However, the genetic relationships between IHD and ECG remain unclear. We took 12-lead ECG as phenotypes to conduct genome-wide association studies (GWAS) for 41,960 samples from UK-Biobank.

Polygenic scores (PGSs) provide an individual level estimate of genetic risk for any given disease. Most PGSs have been derived from genome wide association studies (GWASs) conducted in populations of White European ancestry. This is especially relevant for cardiometabolic diseases which disproportionately affect people of non-European ancestry.

We sought to explore the short- and long-term effects of chronic viral infection on cardiovascular disease (CVD) Based on UK Biobank data, exposed group was identified as individuals who had chronic virus infection-related hospitalization (IRH) Unexposed group was randomly selected, matched by 5-year age interval, sex, and Charlson comorbidity index. Chronic viral IRH was associated with increased risk of CVD.

Basal cell carcinoma (BCC) is one of the most common malignancies worldwide. Yet its genetic determinants are incompletely defined. We identify 122 BCC-associated loci, of which 36 were novel. We also identify an association of the well-known pigment gene SLC45A2.

Study of eight sleep-related traits among 450,000 participants from UK Biobank. 22 new genes associated with chronotype, daytime sleepiness, daytime napping, snoring and sleep apnoea. 20 of these genes were confirmed to be significantly associated with sleep disorders.

Zinc supplementation may help reduce the risk of all-cause dementia and Alzheimer's disease in middle-aged or older adults, especially among those with cataracts. No significant associations with incident dementia were observed for other antioxidant supplementation.

UK Biobank participants were included (median age = 57 years; 54.7% women) Data were collected 2006-2010, with follow-up collected in 2021. Usual walking pace was self-defined as slow, steady, average, or brisk.

Paracetamol may increase the risk of liver cancer, but epidemiological evidence remains unclear. This prospective study included 464,244 participants free of cancer diagnosis from the UK Biobank. The number needed to harm (NNH) was calculated at 10 years of follow-up.

Polygenic risk score (PRS) has proved useful in predicting the risk of cardiovascular diseases (CVD) based on the genotypes of an individual. The usefulness of PRS to predict CVD risk among type 2 diabetes (T2D) patients remains unclear. We built a meta-PRS CVD based on candidate PRSs developed from state-of-the-art PRS methods.

Human humoral immune responses to SARS-CoV-2 vaccines exhibit substantial inter-individual variability. We conducted a genome-wide association study (GWAS) on the anti-spike IgG serostatus of UK Biobank participants. The HLA-DRB1 &#8727; 13:02 allele (MAF = 4.0%, OR = 0.75, p = 2.34e-16) demonstrated the most statistically significant protective effect against IgG Seronegativity.

High hemoglobin A1c (HbA1c) is associated with increases in the risk of cardiovascular disease among individuals with elevated genetic susceptibility. We aimed to investigate the association between HbA 1c and atrial fibrillation (AF), coronary artery disease (CAD), and ischemic stroke.

Cardiac arrhythmia, a common cardiovascular disease, is closely related to genetic polymorphisms. However, associations between polymorphisms in KCNH2 and various arrhythmias remain inadequately explored. We explored the associations between 85 KC NH2 genetic variations and 16 cardiac arrh rhythmias in a UK Biobank.

Study looked at the relationship between fructose consumption and serum sex hormone-binding globulin (SHBG), (free) testosterone, and risk of hyperandrogenism in a population-based cohort. fructose intake from SSB (&#8805;10 g/day) was associated with lower SHBG in men and women and with higher free testosterone levels. Carriers of the rs2304681 A allele were characterized by higher circulating SHBG and lower serum free testosterone (women)

Dupuytren's disease (DD) is a highly heritable fibrotic disorder of the hand with incompletely understood etiology. A number of genetic loci, including Wnt signaling members, have been previously identified. We identified 85 genome-wide significant single nucleotide polymorphisms in 56 loci of which 11 were novel.

Human same-sex sexual behavior (SSB) is heritable and leads to fewer offspring. How SSB-associated alleles have persisted and whether they will remain in human populations are of interest. Using the UK Biobank, we address these questions separately for bisexual behavior (BSB) and exclusive SSB. We discover that male BSB is genetically positively correlated with the number of offspring.

Study included 66,068 and 226 participants with prediabetes from the UK Biobank (UKB) and Chinese Ocular Imaging Project (COIP) in Guangzhou, China. Frailty was evaluated using the Fried phenotype, which includes weight loss, fatigue, low grip strength, low physical activity, and slow walking pace. Pre-frailty and frailty were significantly associated with a higher risk of microvascular diseases.

Smoking may influence measured IOP through an effect on corneal biomechanics. But it is unclear whether this factor translates into an increased risk for glaucoma. This study aimed to examine the association of cigarette smoking with cornea biomechanical properties and glau coma-related traits.

Genome-wide association studies (GWAS) have successfully revealed many disease-associated genetic variants. For a case-control study, adequate power of an association test can be achieved with a large sample size. To account for the batch effect, we propose an approach by integrating External Controls into the Association Test by Regression Calibration (iECAT-RC)

Lung function is associated with cardiovascular mortality, but the relationships with atherosclerosis are unclear. The population-based Swedish CArdioPulmonary BioImage study measured lung function, emphysema, coronary CT angiography, coronary calcium, carotid plaques and ankle-brachial index in 29,593 men and women aged 50-64 years. Lower lung function was not associated with coronary Atherosclerosis in 14,524 never-smokers.

Neurological demyelination and brain damage accumulated in white matter appear as hyperintense areas on T2-weighted MRI scans. Modeling binary images at the population level plays an important role in understanding aging and inflammatory diseases. We propose a scalable hierarchical Bayesian spatial model.

Study included 374,125 participants free of gastrointestinal disorders at baseline. Of them, 19,719 (5.27%) with T2D were followed-up by linking to multiple medical records to record gastrointestinal disease diagnoses. Compared with nondiabetes, participants with T1D had an increased risk of gastritis, duodenitis, peptic ulcer and diverticular disease.

Study included 329,359 participants from the UK Biobank. During a median follow-up of 13.57 years, 2,238 participants developed PD. In summer, time spent outdoors was associated with a reduced PD risk compared with &#8804; 2.0 h/day (HR = 0.84, 95% CI, 0.74-0.95)

Study included individuals without cancer or cardiovascular disease (CVD) at baseline from the UK Biobank. 93 357 (23.40%) had obesity, and 305 615 (76.60%) did not. During a median (IQR) follow-up of 12.73 (12.01-13.43) years, a total of 22 872 incident deaths were recorded. Compared with participants with obesity with an index of 2 or greater for social isolation, the multivariable adjusted hazard ratios (HRs) for all-cause mortality were 0.85 (95% CI, 0.79-0.91)

PRS methods combine the estimated effects of single nucleotide polymorphisms (SNPs) to predict genetic risks for common diseases. Some methods require external individual-level GWAS dataset for parameter tuning. PRStuning predicts the PRS performance with different parameters, and then selects the best-performing parameters.

This study aimed to investigate the association between quantitative retinal vascular measurements and the risk of all-cause and premature mortality. We employed the Retina-based Microvascular Health Assessment System to assess fundus images for image quality. After adjusting for demographic, health, and lifestyle factors and genetic risk score, 18 and 10 retina vascular measurements were significantly associated with all- Cause and Premature mortality.

ApoB, low-density lipoprotein cholesterol (LDL-C), and triglycerides (TG) are associated with coronary artery disease (CAD) Trial evidence for the association of intensive LDL-C lowering and TG lowering with mortality is less definitive. This genetic association study used a population-based cohort of individuals of European ancestry from the UK Biobank.

Fine-mapping in genome-wide association studies attempts to identify causal SNPs from a set of candidate SNPs in a local genomic region of interest. Here, we present multi-ancestry sum of the single effects model (MESuSiE) to improve the accuracy and resolution of fine- mapping by leveraging association information across ancestries. In the real data, MESu SiE improves fine-Mapping resolution by 19.0% to 72.0%.

Little is known about the association between the overall sleep patterns and urologic cancers. We established a healthy sleep score according to five sleep traits. Compared with the participants with a poor sleep pattern (score of 0-2), the multivariable-adjusted hazard ratio and 95% confidence interval were 0.85 (0.75 to 0.96) for urologal cancers, and 0.91 (1.12) for RCC.

The age at onset (AAO) of Parkinson's disease (PD) is a major determinant of clinical heterogeneity. To investigate the risk factors with the AAO of PD, a total of 3156 patients with PD from the UK Biobank were included in this study. We evaluated the effects of polygenic risk scores (PRS), nongenetic risk factors, and their interaction.

Research using the UK Biobank demonstrates effects of body weight on the risk of several neurological and psychiatric disorders. The higher risks may be partially explained by brain structure, food intake and inflammation.

Drug repurposing (DR) intends to identify new uses for approved medications outside their original indication. Computational methods for finding DR candidates usually rely on prior biological and chemical information. We propose a simple and effective systematic screening approach to measure medication impact on hospitalization risk based on large-scale observational data.

Alcohol consumption is a risk factor for hyperuricaemia and gout. Multiple single-nucleotide polymorphisms (SNPs) have been identified as associated with both alcohol consumption and serum urate or gout in separate genome-wide association studies. This study aimed to identify and characterise interactions between these shared signals of genetic association and alcohol consumption.

Deep learning (DL) model used to predict an individual's elevated 10-year ASCVD risk score based on retinal images and limited demographic data. Study used 89,894 retinal fundus images from 44,176 UK Biobank participants (96% non-Hispanic White, 5% diabetic)

Dementia is a multifactorial syndrome attributable to a combination of vascular risk factors, lifestyle factors and neurodegeneration. Little is known about the relative contribution of all these factors and their combined effects on cognition among the older population. We examined the association of four domains of risk factors with cognition in older adults.

Study aimed to investigate the associations between dietary VC and VE with the incident risk of AAD. During a median follow-up of 12.5 years, 962 incident AAD events were documented. In subgroup analyses, the associations were more pronounced in participants who were over 60 years old, participants with smoking history, hypertension or hyperlipidemia.

Individual patterns of fat accumulation can determine cardiometabolic risk profile. To investigate risk stratification using personalized fat z-scores in persons with a body mass index of 30-40 kg/m 2 from the UK Biobank imaging study.

Cognitive reserve (CR) contributes to preserving cognition when facing brain aging and damage. CR has been linked to dementia risk in late life. However, the association between CR and cognitive changes and brain imaging measures, especially in midlife, is unclear.

Rare predicted loss-of-function (pLOF) variants were aggregated for 17,035 protein-coding genes using 55,558 distinct transcript-specific variant sets. These sets were tested for their association with 728 circulating proteins and 188 quantitative phenotypes across 406,921 individuals in the UK Biobank. The transcript- specific approach resulted in larger estimated effects of pLOF variants decreasing serum cis-protein levels.

Long-term exposure to PM 10 and PM 2.5 increases the risk of IBS, especially PM2.5 . We suggest restricting the ambient PM standards to reduce the impact of PM exposure on IBS. Individuals under 60 years old were more vulnerable to PM exposure.

Study included 363,494 participants with measured serum creatinine and cystatin C levels. A higher eGFR diff was associated with a lower risk of AF. These findings may have implications for the management of patients at risk of incident AF.

 periodontitis is a ubiquitous severe gum disease affecting the teeth and surrounding alveolar bone. We investigated the association between very severe periodonitis and early biomarkers of age-related macular degeneration in individuals with no eye disease. Among 36 897 participants included in the analysis, 1571 (4.3%) reported very severeperiodontitis.

There is increasing attention on the associations between body weight and several neurological and psychiatric disorders. We aimed to understand the effects of body mass index (BMI), BMI change and BMI-metabolic health status on the incidence of these disorders. Associations of body weight with six disorders were analysed.

17,031 participants from UK Biobank with type 2 diabetes who were free of depression were included. During a median follow-up of 12.3 years, we documented 2875 incident composite CVD cases. The presence of depressive symptoms had higher risks of composite CVB among individuals with type2 diabetes.

Precision medicine models often perform better for populations of European ancestry. As a result, prediction models may misrepresent or provide less accurate treatment recommendations for underrepresented populations. This study introduces an adaptable machine learning toolkit that integrates multiple existing methodologies.

Dietary patterns characterised by protein, polyunsaturated fatty acids, and vitamin D reduce the odds of malnutrition in cancer survivors. However, it is unclear whether these dietary patterns also improve prognosis. Study prospectively examined associations between dietary patterns and the risk of all-cause and cancer mortality in adult cancer survivors from the UK Biobank cohort.

The relationships of social isolation and loneliness with acute kidney injury (AKI) risk remained uncertain. 450,868 participants without prior AKI were included from the UK Biobank. Loneliness was assessed by asking about "Do you often feel lonely?". The study outcome was incident AKI.

Posttraumatic stress disorder (PTSD) has been reported to be a risk factor for several physical and somatic symptoms. The genetics of PTSD and its potential association with medical outcomes remain unclear. This study examined disease categories and laboratory tests from electronic health records (EHRs) that are associated with PTSD polygenic scores.

Lipoprotein(a) is recognized as a causal factor for coronary heart disease (CHD) But its atherogenicity relative to that of low-density lipoprotein (LDL) on a per-particle basis is indeterminate. Authors addressed this issue in a genetic analysis based on the fact that Lp(a), LDL both contain 1 apolipoprotein B (apoB) per particle.

Coagulation factor XI (FXI) is a novel target for antithrombotic therapy addressed by various therapeutic modalities currently in clinical development. We analyzed the association of 2 common genetic variants, which alter levels of FXI, with a range of human phenotypes. We combined variants into a genetic score standardized to a 30% increase in relative activated partial thromboplastin time.

The risk of posttraumatic stress disorder (PTSD) following trauma is heritable, but robust common variants have yet to be identified. In a multi-ethnic cohort including over 30,000 PTSD cases and 170,000 controls we conduct a genome-wide association study of PTSD. We demonstrate SNP-based heritability estimates of 5-20%, varying by sex.

M Mosaic loss of chromosome Y (mLOY) is frequently observed in the leukocytes of ageing men. The genetic architecture and biological mechanisms underlying mLOY are not fully understood. In a cohort of 95,380 Japanese men, we identify 50 independent genetic markers in 46 loci associated with mLOY at a genome-wide significant level.

We test 32.5 million variants for association with ten measures of the QRS complex in 12 leads, using 405,732 electrocardiograms from 81,192 Icelanders. We identify 190 associations at 130 loci, the majority of which have not been reported before. Assessment of genes expressed in the heart yields an additional 13 rare QRS coding variants.

Uterine leiomyomata (UL) are the most common neoplasms of the female reproductive tract. They are the primary cause for hysterectomy, leading to considerable morbidity and high economic burden.

The United Kingdom Biobank included 68 550 participants aged 40 to 69 years who underwent nonmydriatic retinal imaging, BP, and arterial stiffness index assessment. Greater arteriolar tortuosity was associated with higher systolic BP (relative increase, 1.2%; 95% CI, 0.9; 1.4% per 10 mmHg), higher mean arterial pressure, and higher pulse pressure. Associations were in the same direction but marginally weaker for venular Tortuosity and diameter.

SARS-CoV-2 infection may induce prolonged inflammation within the central nervous system. The mechanisms through which symptomatology emerges remain poorly understood. To address this gap, our study capitalized on longitudinal UK Biobank neuroimaging data.

Spinal stenosis is a common condition among older individuals, with significant morbidity attached. Little is known about its risk factors but degenerative conditions, such as osteoarthritis (OA), have been identified for their mechanistic role. This study aims to explore causal relationships between anthropometric risk factors, OA, and spinal stenosis.

UK Biobank metrics were examined for variation in white blood cell count. Variation increased with age, increased with weight up to 80 kg then decreased. Female range was greater than male.

This longitudinal study used diet-wide association studies (DWAS) to investigate the association between diverse dietary food and nutrient intakes and the onset of type 2 diabetes mellitus (T2DM) Out of 502,505 participants from the UK Biobank, 119,040 with dietary data free of T2DM at the baseline were included.

People with type 2 diabetes mellitus (T2DM) are more vulnerable to social disconnection compared with the general population. Social isolation and loneliness were measured using self-report questionnaires. Loneliness (yes vs no) was associated with a greater risk for a composite of incident MI or stroke.

Bone marrow adipose tissue (BMAT) represents > 10% fat mass in healthy humans. It can be measured by magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) as the bone marrow fat fraction (BMFF) Human MRI studies have identified several diseases associated with BMFF.

Anxiety disorders are common, complex psychiatric disorders with twin heritabilities of 30-60%. We conducted a genome-wide association study of Lifetime Anxiety Disorder and Current Anxiety Symptoms. We conclude that common genetic variation accounts for a substantive proportion of the genetic architecture underlying anxiety.

Research on the relationship between blue light exposure and diabetes development is limited. The present study aimed to investigate whether it is affected by sleep duration, physical activity, outdoor activity time, and genetic susceptibility.

Meaning in life is an aspect of eudaimonic well-being associated with lower dementia risk. This research examines whether this protective association extends to Parkinson's disease (PD) Participants from the UK Biobank reported on their meaning in life.

The impact of residential greenness on incident idiopathic pulmonary fibrosis (IPF) is unknown. 469,348 participants in the UK Biobank were included and followed until December 2020. After a median follow-up of 11.85 years, 1574 IPF cases were identified.

Rare variants are believed to play a substantial role in the genetic architecture of mental disorders, particularly in coding regions. However, limited evidence supports the impact of rare variants on anxiety. We used whole-exome sequencing data from 200,643 participants in the UK Biobank.

Metabolic dysfunction-associated steatotic liver disease (MASLD) affects many populations. Relationship between creatinine to cystatin C ratio (CCR) and MASLD remains unclear. Study included 368,634 participants from the UK Biobank for cross-sectional and prospective analyses.

There is a lack of literature concerning the effects of visceral adipose on the development of first cardiometabolic disease (FCMD) and its progression to CMM. 423,934 participants from the UK Biobank with different baseline disease conditions were included in the analysis. Visceral adiposity was estimated by calculating the visceral adiposity index (VAI)

The American Heart Association's Life's Simple 7 became the Life's Essential 8 after the addition of sleep duration. The authors tested the hypothesis that suboptimal sleep duration is associated with poorer neuroimaging brain health profiles in asymptomatic middle-aged adults.

It is unclear whether diet-associated inflammation is related to the development of anxiety disorders. In the UK Biobank Study of 96,679 participants, baseline E-DII scores were calculated from the average intake of at least two 24 h dietary recalls. Consuming a pro-inflammatory diet was significantly associated with a higher risk of total anxiety disorders (HR Q4vsQ1  = 1.12, 95% CI =1.00-1.25)

Right ventricular ejection fraction (RVEF) and end-diastolic volume (RVEDV) are not readily assessed through traditional modalities. We trained a deep learning-ECG model to predict RV dilation, RV dysfunction, and numerical RVEDV and RVEF from a 12-lead ECG paired with reference-standard cardiac magnetic resonance imaging volumetric measurements in UK Biobank. Over a median follow-up of 2.3 years, predicted RVEf was associated with adjusted transplant-free survival (hazard ratio, 1.40 for each 10% decrease)

A total of 251,825 participants free of CKD from the UK Biobank were included. Cardiovascular health was scored using LE8 and categorized as low, moderate, and high. Cox proportional hazard models were employed to evaluate the associations of LE8 scores with new-onset CKD.

The impact of CYP2C19 genotype on clopidogrel outcomes is one of the most well established pharmacogenetic interactions. However, there is a scarcity of large-scale real-world data on the extent of this pharmacogenetics effect. This study utilizes the UK Biobank dataset, including 10 365 patients treated with clop idogrel.

Identifying causal variants from genome-wide association studies (GWAS) is challenging due to widespread linkage disequilibrium. Functional annotations of the genome may help to prioritize variants that are biologically relevant. Classical fine-mapping methods conducting an exhaustive search of variant-level causal configurations have a high computational cost.

Over 90 independent risk variants have been identified for Parkinson's disease using genome-wide association studies. Most studies have been performed in just one population at a time. Here we performed a large-scale multi-ancestry meta-analysis with 49,049 cases and 18,785 proxy cases.

Adverse childhood experiences (ACEs) and anxiety-depression co-morbidity are attracting widespread attention. Previous studies have shown the relationship between individual psychiatric disorders and ACEs. This study will analyze the correlation between anxiety- Depressed co-Morbidity and different levels ofACEs.

Elevated lipoprotein(a) [Lp(a)] is a genetic driver for atherosclerotic cardiovascular disease (ASCVD) We aimed to provide novel insights into the associated risk of elevated versus normal Lp( a) levels on major adverse cardiovascular events (MACE) in an incident ASCVD cohort.

Mendelian randomization (MR) is an effective approach for revealing causal risk factors that underpin complex traits and diseases. Most existing multivariable MR methods have been developed for two-sample setting or a small number of exposures. In this study, we introduce a one-sample MR method based on partial least squares and Lasso regression (MR-PL) We applied MR-PL to the datasets from UK Biobank to reveal the causal effects of 36 white matter tracts on 180 complex traits.

The Rose hypothesis predicts that genetic risk factors will be associated with individuals' risk of disease but not population disparities. We used the UK Biobank to test the Rose hypothesis for type 2 diabetes (T2D) ethnic disparities in the UK. Both genetic and socioenvironmental T2D risk factors show greater within (w) than between (b) ethnic group variation.

Hypertension (HTN) involves genetic variability in the renin-angiotensin system and influences antihypertensive response. We previously reported that angiotens inogen ( AGT ) messenger RNA (mRNA) is endogenously bound by miR-122-5p. We aimed to test the hypothesis that increased  AGT  by rs5051 C > T counterbalances AGT  decreased by rs699 A > G, and when these variants occur independently.

It has been suggested that glycoprotein acetyls (GlycA) better reflects chronic inflammation than high sensitivity C-reactive protein (hsCRP) But paediatric/life-course data are sparse. Using data from the Avon Longitudinal Study of Parents and Children and UK Biobank, we compared short- (over weeks) and long-term correlations of GlycA and hsCRP.

HDPs are related to unfavourable maternal cardiovascular disease (CVD) risk profiles later in life. We investigated whether genetic liability to pre-eclampsia and gestational hypertension is associated with CVD risk factors and occurrence of CVD events.

Individuals with a low estimated glomerular filtration rate (eGFR) are at a high risk of death. This study aimed to assess the causal relationship of low eGFR with all-cause and cause-specific mortality. Using data from 436,214 people in the United Kingdom, we applied conventional statistical analyses and those incorporating genetic data.

Environmental exposures play a crucial role in shaping children's behavioral development. However, the mechanisms by which these exposures interact with brain functional connectivity and influence behavior remain unexplored. We examined the predictive power of brain functional network connectivity (FNC) and 41 environmental exposures for 23 behaviors related to cognitive ability and mental health.

A total of 115,453 adults without prior CKD at baseline were included from UK Biobank (2006-2010) Six common lifestyle factors including smoking, body mass index, sleep, diet, physical activity and alcohol consumption were combined into an unhealthy lifestyle score. Each additional type of childhood adversity was associated with a 12% increment in the risk of developing CKD.

Physical activity (PA) has been linked with cancer incidence. This study aimed to explore the optimal PA patterns in reducing cancer incidence and the associated potential mediators. Between 2006 and 2010, 502,400 participants were recruited from the UK Biobank. Four distinct PA trajectories were identified.

Both COA and AOA have a genetically causal effect on osteoporosis, and the risk was greatly higher in AOA. Besides corticosteroids, the increased risk of osteopsorosis among asthma patients should be attributed to genetic susceptibility and other asthma medications.

Cannabis use is increasing worldwide. Previous studies have reported an association between cannabis use and a higher risk of atrial fibrillation (AF) Most were cross-sectional and generally relied on diagnostic coding to identify cannabis users.

Long-term exposures to particulate matter with an aerodynamic diameter smaller than 2.5 &#181;m were associated with increased risk of stroke. Participants with high genetic risk and exposure to high air pollutants had &#8776;45% (31%, 61%) higher risk of Stroke. Of note, we observed additive and multiplicative interactions between genetic susceptibility and air pollutants on stroke events.

The relationship between alcohol consumption and the risk of incident atrial fibrillation remains controversial. We investigated whether the relationship could be associated with the genetic predisposition to alcohol metabolism. A total of 399,329 subjects with genetic data from the UK Biobank database were identified and followed for incident AF until 2021.

Poor oral health is a modifiable risk factor that is associated with clinically observed cardiovascular disease. Relationship between oral and brain health is not well understood. Poor oral health was associated with a 9% increase in WMH volume.

It is not clear if antagonizing the GIP (glucose-dependent insulinotropic polypeptide) receptor (GIPR) for treatment of obesity is likely to increase the risk of fractures. We analyzed the association of 3 missense variants in GIPR and 2 rare variants with risk of fracture and with BMD in a large meta-analysis of up to 1.2 million participants. Burden of LoF variants was not associated with fractures, but was associated with eBMD.

Parkinson's disease is a genetically complex disorder. Multiple genes have been shown to contribute to the risk of Parkinson's disease. Currently 90 independent risk variants have been identified by genome-wide association studies.

SLC18B1 is a sister gene to the vesicular monoamine and acetylcholine transporters. It is the only known polyamine transporter, with unknown physiological role. Slc18b1 knock out mice has significantly reduced polyamine content in the brain.

We describe a comprehensive effort that merges and harmonizes a large-scale dataset of 10,477 structural brain MRI scans from 18 different studies. We use this dataset and multi-atlas-based image processing methods to obtain a hierarchical partition of the brain from larger anatomical regions to individual cortical and deep structures. We provide a web-based visualization interface to generate and present the resulting age trends.

Insulin-like growth factor-I (IGF-I) and testosterone may be related to prostate cancer risk. Acromegaly is associated with clinically high IGF-I concentrations. Klinefelter's syndrome, testicular hypofunction and hypopituitarism are associated with low testosterone concentrations.

Using genome-wide common genetic variation data, we calculate sex-specific genetic correlations amongst body fat %, fat mass, fat-free mass, physical activity, glycemic traits and 17 psychiatric traits. Two patterns emerge: (1) anorexia nervosa, schizophrenia, obsessive-compulsive disorder, and education years are negatively genetically correlated. (2) attention-deficit/hyperactivity disorder (ADHD), alcohol dependence, insomnia, and heavy smoking are positively correlated.

Uncertainty exists regarding the relation of body size and weight change with dementia risk. As populations continue to age and the global obesity epidemic shows no sign of waning, reliable quantification of such associations is important. Obesity was associated with higher risk in vascular dementia.

Mendelian randomisation approach was used to investigate the causal effect of neuroticism, education, and physical activity on job satisfaction. One standard deviation (1 SD) higher genetically determined neuroticism score (4.07 units) was associated with -0.31 units lower job satisfaction (95% confidence interval (CI): 0.38 to 0.24). Education (0.02) andphysical activity (0).08) did not show any evidence for causal association with job. satisfaction. Our study highlights the importance of considering the confounding effect of negative personality traits for studies onJob satisfaction.

Childhood maltreatment is highly prevalent and serves as a risk factor for mental and physical disorders. Self-reported childhood maltreatment appears heritable, but the specific genetic influences on this phenotype are largely unknown. Genome-wide association analysis was undertaken, using a discovery sample from the UK Biobank (UKBB) and a replication sample from Psychiatric Genomics Consortium-posttraumatic stress disorder group (PGC-PTSD) Two genome-wide significant loci were identified in the discovery dataset but were not replicated in PGC-PtsD.

Hypertension is a key risk factor for major adverse cardiovascular events. Dietary interventions are an effective approach to lower blood pressure (BP) but are not equally effective across all individuals. We investigated whether the genetics of BP could be used to identify individuals with hypertension who may receive a particular benefit from lowering sodium intake and boosting potassium levels.

Cigarette smoke contains both nicotine and carcinogens, but not all smokers develop lung cancer. We aimed to delineate the interaction between metabolizing ability of tobacco carcinogens and smoking intensity in mediating genetic susceptibility. Single-variant and gene-based associations of 43 tobacco carcinogen-metabolizing genes with lung cancer were analyzed.

One hundred and eighty-one rare candidate predisposition variants were shared in at least one cousin pair from a high-risk pedigree. A rare variant in  MDH2 was found to segregate with breast-cancer-affected relatives in one extended pedigree.

Mood disorders, including depression and anxiety, affect almost one-fifth of the world's adult population. Mutations in circadian clock genes have previously been associated with mood disorders both directly and indirectly through alterations in circadian phase. We found no significant effects on anxiety from individual circadian gene variants. Only circadian genotypes with multiple SNP variants showed significant associations with anxiety.

Recorded symptoms in cancer patients pre-diagnosis may vary between different sources of electronic health records (EHRs) We analysed primary care EHRs in UK Biobank and Clinical Practice Research Datalink populations linked to cancer registry data.

Impact of air pollution on incident chronic kidney disease (CKD) in diabetic patients is insufficiently studied. We aimed to examine exposure-response associations of PM 2.5 , PM 10 , PM 2-10 , NO 2 , and NO X with incident CKD in diabetic Patients in the UK. We also widened exposure level of PM2.5  and examined PM 2 -CKd association in diabetic. patients across the entire range of global concentration.

The relationship between the long-term joint exposure to ambient air pollution and incidence of myocardial infarction (MI) and modification by genetic susceptibility remain inconclusive. We analysed 329 189 UK Biobank participants without MI at baseline. Exposure concentrations to particulate matter (PM2.5 and PM10), nitrogen dioxide (NO2), and nitrogen oxides (NOx) were obtained.

Excessive daytime sleepiness (EDS) has been associated with cardiovascular disease and death. EDS is prevalent in individuals having short and long sleep duration. We sought to clarify the relationship between sleep duration subtypes of EDS with cardiovascular outcomes, accounting for these subtypes.

High serum urate is a prerequisite for gout and associated with metabolic disease. Genome-wide association studies have reported dozens of loci associated with urate control. Here, we employed trans-ancestral meta-analysis using data from European and East Asian populations to identify 10 new loci.

We investigated the genetic contribution to dietary intake in a sample of 335,576 individuals from the UK Biobank study. A principal component analysis applied to diet question item responses generated two components: Diet Component 1 (DC1) represented a meat-related diet and Diet Component 2 (DC2) a fish and plant-related Diet. We estimated significant genetic correlations between both DCs and schizophrenia, and several other traits.

Urinary biomarkers are associated with cardiovascular disease, but the nature of these associations is not well understood. We performed multivariable-adjusted regression models to assess associations of random spot measurements of the urine sodium-potassium ratio (UNa/UK) and urine albumin adjusted for creatinine with cardiovascular risk factors, cardiovascular disease and type 2 diabetes mellitus (T2D)

 Expression quantitative trait loci (eQTL) are genetic variants associated with gene expression. Using genome-wide genotype data, it is now possible to impute gene expression using eQTL mapping efforts. This approach can be used to analyse previously unexplored relationships between gene expression and in vivo measures of human brain structural connectivity.

Age-related macular degeneration (AMD) is a leading cause of blindness. AMD severity is primarily measured by images of the fundus of the retina. We used both genotypes and fundus images to predict whether an eye had progressed to late AMD with a modified deep convolutional neural network.

Iiopathic pulmonary fibrosis (IPF) is a complex lung disease characterized by scarring of the lung. Genome-wide association studies have reported signals of association implicating multiple pathways including host defense, telomere maintenance, signaling, and cell-cell adhesion. We conducted genome-wide analyses across three independent studies and meta-analyzed these results to generate the largest genome- wide association study of IPF to date.

 Circulating metabolite levels are biomarkers for cardiovascular disease (CVD) We studied association of rare variants and 226 serum lipoproteins, lipids and amino acids in 7,142 healthy participants. We leveraged the information from multiple metabolite measurements on the same participants to improve discovery in rare variant association analyses.

Minimal phenotyping refers to the reliance on the use of a small number of self-reported items for disease case identification. We report differences in genetic architecture between depression defined by minimalphenotyping and strictly defined major depressive disorder (MDD) The former has a lower genotype-derived heritability that cannot be explained by inclusion of milder cases.

Lipid levels are important markers for the development of cardio-metabolic diseases. Although hundreds of associated loci have been identified, contribution of genetic factors to variation in lipids is not fully understood. We performed genome-wide association analyses for four lipid traits in over 45,000 ancestrally diverse participants.

Stroke incidence in younger and middle-aged people is growing. Despite this, its associations in this subset of the stroke population are unknown. This study examined the association between self-reported walking pace and incident stroke.

Hemoglobin is the essential oxygen-carrying molecule in humans. It is regulated by cellular iron and oxygen sensing mechanisms. To search for novel variants associated with hemoglobin concentration, we performed genome-wide association studies. We found seven novel variants, six rare coding and one common, at the ACO1 locus.

Cerebrovascular disease contributes to age-related cognitive decline. We hypothesized that vascular risk factors would lead to cognitive impairment through the disruption of brain white matter network efficiency. Participants were 19 346 neurologically healthy individuals from UK Biobank that underwent diffusion MRI and cognitive testing.

We conducted genome-wide association studies (GWAS) of relative intake from the macronutrients fat, protein, carbohydrates, and sugar in over 235,000 individuals of European ancestries. We identified 21 unique, approximately independent lead SNPs.

Leveraging high-dimensional molecular datasets can help us develop mechanistic insight into associations between genetic variants and complex traits. In this study, we integrated human proteome data derived from brain tissue to evaluate whether targeted proteins putatively mediate the effects of genetic variants.

The study aimed to explore the association between early life and life-course exposure to social disadvantage and later life body mass index (BMI) We studied participants of Helsinki Birth Cohort Study born in 1934-1944 and Northern Finland Birth Cohorts born in 1966 and 1986.

Despite strong transethnic genetic correlations, the non-transferability of polygenic risk scores across populations suggests the presence of population-specific components of genetic architecture. We analyze nine complex traits in individuals of East Asian and European ancestry, restricting to common SNPs (MAF > 5%), and find that most common causal SNPs are shared by both populations.

We measured associations between genetic liability for high levels of inflammatory markers Interleukin-6 (IL-6) and C-reactive protein (CRP) We found no evidence of an association between our instruments for IL-6 and self-harm in the two-sample MR. However we found an inverse association between instruments for CRP andSelf-harm, indicating that higher levels of circulating CRP may protect against self- harm.

Obesity and its associated diseases are major health problems characterized by extensive metabolic disturbances. Understanding the causal connections between these phenotypes and variation in metabolite levels can uncover relevant biology and inform novel intervention strategies.

Lung function is highly heritable and differs between the sexes throughout life. Little is known about sex-differential genetic effects on lung function. We aimed to conduct the first genome-wide genotype-by-sex interaction study.

G Gestational diabetes Mellitus (GDM) affects 1 in 7 births and is associated with numerous adverse health outcomes for both mother and child. GDM is suspected to share a large common genetic background with type 2 diabetes (T2D) The aim of our study was to characterize different GDM polygenic risk scores (PRSs) and test their association with GDM.

Inhibitory interneurons orchestrate information flow across the cortex and are implicated in psychiatric illness. We demonstrate stereotyped negative correlation of somatostatin and parvalbumin transcripts within human and non-human primates. schizophrenia genetic risk is enriched among interneuron-linked genes.

Baseline lung function, quantified as forced expiratory volume in the first second of exhalation (FEV 1 ), is a standard diagnostic criterion used by clinicians to identify and classify lung diseases. Using whole-genome sequencing data from the National Heart, Lung, and Blood Institute Trans-Omics for Precision Medicine project, we identified a novel genetic association with FEV 1 on chromosome 12 in 867 African American children with asthma. We explored statistical and functional evidence for all variants in linkage disequilibrium with the three independent signals.

Plant-based dietary patterns may be related to better cardiovascular profiles. Whether a healthy plant-based diet index is predictive of future cardiovascular disease (CVD) across people with different genetic susceptibility remains uncertain. The risk of CVD was gradually decreased in association with higher adherence to healthful-PDI.

The American College of Cardiology/American Heart Association defines hypertension as a blood pressure &#8805;130/80 mm Hg. The 2018 European Society of Cardiologist (ESC) and 2019 National Institute for Health and Care Excellence (NICE) guidelines use a &##8705;140/90mm Hg threshold. Our objective was to study the associations between isolated diastolic hypertension (IDH) and cardiovascular disease.

We developed Neuroharmony using a total of 15,026 sMRI images. The tool was able to reduce scanner-related bias from unseen scans. It represents a significant step towards imaging-based clinical tools.

Pregnancy involves maternal brain adaptations. Little is known about how parity influences women's brain aging trajectories later in life. Findings indicate that subcortical brain modulations during pregnancy and postpartum may be traceable decades after childbirth.

Blood lipids have been associated with the development of a range of cancers, including breast, lung and colorectal cancer. For endometrial cancer, observational studies have reported inconsistent associations between blood lipids and cancer risk. To reduce biases from unmeasured confounding, we performed a bidirectional, two-sample Mendelian randomization analysis.

It remains unknown whether blood pressure pulsatility (pulse pressure [PP]) causally affects stroke risk independently of the steady pressure component (mean arterial pressure [MAP) We applied multivariable Mendelian randomization analyses to explore associations with ischemic stroke, intracerebral hemorrhage, and their subtypes. Higher genetically predicted MAP was associated with higher risk of ischeMIC stroke and intracrebral bleeding across the examined age spectrum.

Birthweight of first child was positively influenced by maternal education, with 7 years of maternal education as the reference. A causal relation between maternal education and offspring birthweight was revealed by IVW MR (estimated effect = 0.074 for one standard deviation increase in maternal education years) and by complementary MR methods. This connection was not substantially affected by paternal education or horizontal pleiotropy.

Fundus tessellation (FT) is a prevalent clinical feature associated with myopia. It has implications in the development of myopic maculopathy, which causes irreversible visual impairment. Accurate classification of FT can help predict the disease progression and prognosis.

In women but not men, we observed that elevated polygenic risk for depression was associated with reduced cerebellar GM volume. In women with current depression compared to both women with remitted depression and women who never had depression, we also observed GM reductions in ventral and medial prefrontal, insular, and medial temporal regions.

Hepatic fat content can be non-invasively estimated by controlled attenuation parameter (CAP) during transient elastography. The aim of this study was to examine the determinants and predictors of CAP values in individuals with metabolic dysfunction. We enrolled 1230 consecutive apparently healthy individuals with &#8805;3 metabolic dysfunction features.

Chronic kidney disease is a leading cause of death and disability globally. Individuals of African ancestry (AFR) or with ancestry in the Americas (AMS) are under-represented in genome-wide association studies (GWASs) of kidney function. To address this bias, we conducted a large meta-analysis of GWASs of estimated glomerular filtration rate (eGFR) in 145,732 AFR and AMS individuals. We identified 41 loci at genome- wide significance, of which two have not been previously reported in any ancestry group.

Many metabolomics studies of depression have been performed, but these have been limited by their scale. A comprehensive in silico analysis of global metabolite levels in large populations could provide robust insights into the pathological mechanisms underlying depression and candidate clinical biomarkers.

Benzene affects human health through environmental exposure in addition to occupational contact. Few studies have examined the associations between long-term exposure to low concentrations of ambient benzene and mortality risks. This prospective cohort study consists of 393,042 participants without stroke, myocardial infarction, or cancer at baseline from the UK Biobank.

Normal and pathologic neurobiological processes influence brain morphology in coordinated ways that give rise to patterns of structural covariance. The genetic underpinnings of these patterns remain largely unknown. We apply a stochastic multivariate factorization method to a diverse population of 50,699 individuals.

Researchers examined associations between a genetic risk score (GRS) associated with CRC liability and 231 circulating metabolites measured by nuclear magnetic resonance spectroscopy. The GRS for CRC was associated with up to 28% of the circulating metabolites at FDR-P. These analyses suggest that higher genetic liability to CRC can cause early alterations in systemic metabolism.

BridgePRS is a novel Bayesian polygenic risk score (PRS) method. It leverages shared genetic effects across ancestries to increase PRS portability. Simulations suggest that the performance of BridgePRS relative to PRS-CSx increases as uncertainty increases.

Primary aldosteronism (PA) is an adrenal disorder of autonomous aldosterone secretion which promotes arterial injury. We aimed to explore whether PA is causally associated with lower-extremity arterial disease (LEAD) We included 39,713 patients with diabetes and 419,312 participants without diabetes from UK Biobank.

The impact of elevated systolic blood pressure (SBP) and low-density lipoprotein cholesterol (LDL-C) on the risk of coronary heart disease (CHD) at different stages of life is unclear. We aimed to investigate whether genetically mediated SBP and LDL-C is associated with risk of CHD throughout life.

The selfish brain mechanism proposes that in some patients with impaired cerebral blood flow (CBF) or cerebrovascular function, hypertension may develop as a compensatory mechanism. We investigated whether regional fractional ALFF (fALFF) differs between 2054 hypertensives and 1724 normotensives using data from the UK Biobank dataset.

A need exists for effective and practical tools to identify individuals at increased risk of liver-related outcomes (LROs) within the general population. We externally validated the chronic liver disease (CLivD) score for LROs in the UK Biobank cohort. We also investigated the sequential combined use of CLivD and fibrosis-4 (FIB-4) scores.

 Epidemiological studies observed an association between sex hormones, including estradiol, and kidney function. We conducted a Mendelian randomization (MR) study to assess a possible causal effect ofEstradiol levels on kidney function in males and females. The two-sample MR indicated that genetically predicted estradio levels are significantly associated with eGFR in men (beta = 0.077;  p  = 5.2E-05). We identified a single locus at chromosome 14 associated with estradiola levels in men being significant in the one- sample MR.

Brain imaging and genomics are critical tools enabling characterization of the genetic basis of brain disorders. However, imaging large cohorts is expensive and may be unavailable for legacy datasets used for genome-wide association studies (GWASs) We developed an image-mediated association study (IMAS), which utilizes borrowed imaging/genomics data to conduct association mapping.

Sex differences exist in the likelihood of cognitive decline. Age at hypertension diagnosis is a unique contributor to brain structural changes associated with cerebral small vessel disease. However, whether this relationship differs between sexes remains unclear.

This study proposes the use of polygenic risk scores (PRS) as reliable proxies of COVID-19 severity across three large biobanks: the Michigan Genomics Initiative (MGI), UK Biobank (UKB), and NIH All of Us. The goal is to identify associations between pre-existing conditions and COVID19 severity.

Hip and knee arthroplasty aims to reduce joint pain and increase functional mobility in patients with osteoarthritis. The degree to which arthro plasty is associated with higher physical activity is unclear. This cross-sectional study analyzed wrist-worn accelerometer data collected from UK Biobank participants.

The association between depression and hypertension has been extensively investigated. We sought to investigate the bidirectional relationship. We first performed observational analyses using longitudinal data from the UK Biobank. We then performed genetic analyses leveraging summary statistics fromGWASs.

Physical activity (PA) and sedentary time (ST) have been shown to affect mental health outcomes in opposite directions. We used accelerometery-derived measures of PA and ST from the UK Biobank and depression, anxiety and well-being data. Genetically instrumented higher PA was associated with lower odds of depression.

Mounting evidence suggests considerable diversity in brain aging trajectories, primarily arising from the complex interplay between age, genetic, and environmental risk factors. We conducted a comprehensive association analysis between cerebral structural measures and prevalent risk factors, using data from 36,969 UK Biobank subjects aged 44-81.

Hypertension (a major risk factor for cardiovascular disease) is highly prevalent in Africa. Most hypertension-related genome-wide association studies (GWASs) focus on non-African populations. AWI-Gen study GWAS meta-analysis for blood pressure (BP)-related traits (systolic and diastolic BP, pulse pressure, mean-arterial pressure and hypertension) from three sub-Saharan African geographic regions (N = 10,775)

Angiopoietin-like protein (ANGPTL)3 regulates plasma lipids by inhibiting LPL and endothelial lipase (EL) ANGPTL3 inactivation lowers LDL-C independently of the classical LDLR-mediated pathway.

Cardiometabolic morbidity and medications have been linked with adverse outcomes from coronavirus disease 2019 (COVID-19) We studied 7,099 participants from the UK Biobank who had been tested for CO VID-19 in hospital. Age, sex, ethnicity, body mass index (BMI), diabetes, hypertension, hypercholesterolaemia, ACEi/ARB use, prior myocardial infarction (MI), and smoking were considered. Black, Asian, and Minority ethnic (BAME) ethnicity, male sex, and higher BMI were independently associated with a positive result.

Humans display reproducible sex differences in cognition and behavior. However, the consistency, causes and consequences of sex differences are poorly characterized and hotly debated. Recent studies in mice have established highly consistent sex biases in regional gray matter volume. Here, we directly test translatability of rodent findings to humans.

Using genetic scores for fasting plasma glucose (FPG GS) and type 2 diabetes (T2D GS), we investigated whether the fasting, 1-hour and 2-hour glucose thresholds from the WHO 2013 criteria for gestational diabetes (GDM) have different implications for genetic susceptibility to raised fasting glucose. We looked at women from the Hyperglycemia and Adverse Pregnancy Outcome (HAPO) and Atlantic Diabetes in Pregnancy (DIP) studies. In HAPO and DIP, the mean FPG GS was higher than controls.

A polygenic score (PGS) or polygenic risk score (PRS) is an estimate of an individual's genetic liability to a trait or disease. It is calculated according to their genotype profile and relevant genome-wide association study (GWAS) data. PRSs are exploited to assess shared etiology between phenotypes, to evaluate the clinical utility of genetic data for complex disease.

Existing methods for fitting variance components do not scale well to large-scale datasets of genetic variation. We present a method for variance components analysis that is accurate and efficient. We observe enrichment of heritability in FANTOM5 enhancers in asthma, eczema, thyroid and autoimmune disorders.

Genetic risk scores, known as polygenic risk scores (PRSs), aggregate risk information from the most important genetic variants into a single score that describes an individual's genetic predisposition to a given disease. This article reviews recent developments in the predictive utility of PRSs.

Tissue characterisation with cardiovascular magnetic resonance (CMR) parametric mapping has the potential to detect and quantify both focal and diffuse alterations in myocardial structure. Native T 1 mapping in particular has shown promise as a useful biomarker to support diagnostic, therapeutic and prognostic decision-making.

Most loci identified by GWASs have been found in populations of European ancestry (EUR) In trans-ethnic meta-analyses for 15 hematological traits in 746,667 participants, including 184,535 non-EUR individuals, we identified 5,552 trait-variant associations at p  -9.

It has been known since 1904 that, in humans, diverse cognitive traits are positively intercorrelated. This forms the basis for the general factor of intelligence (g) We directly test whether there is a partial genetic basis for individual differences in g using data from seven different cognitive tests.

Major depression has been linked to changes in white matter architecture. It remains unclear whether risk factors for depression are directly associated with these alterations. We reexamined white matter fiber tracts in individuals with depressive symptoms.

Inflammatory endotypes ( e.g.  T2-high (eosinophilic)) may play a key role in asthma exacerbations. We aimed to assess whether genetic susceptibility underlies asthma exacerbation risk. In the UK Biobank, we identified 11 604 cases and 37 890 controls. While no variants reached genome-wide significance (p -8 ) in the primary analysis, 116 signals were suggestively significant. In GERA, two single nucleotide polymorphisms (rs34643691 and rs149721630) replicated.

Binge and heavy binge drinking significantly increase the risk of alcohol-related cirrhosis. Higher genetic predisposition further amplifies the risk. Diabetes consistently elevates ARC risk across all drinking and PRS categories.

CKD is determined by an interplay of monogenic, polygenic, and environmental risks. Autosomal dominant polycystic kidney disease (ADPKD) and COL4A-associated nephropathy represent the most common monogenic kidney diseases. By combining SNP array, exome/genome sequence, and electronic health record data, we demonstrate that the genome-wide polygenic score significantly predicts CKD among ADPKD monogenic variant carriers.

BioMOBS is a workflow consisting of two data visualization tools integrated with an open-source molecular information database to perform clinically relevant analyses. The central visualisation tool, where data-driven and literature-based findings can be integrated, is available within the github link as well.

Hospital admissions account for a large share of the healthcare costs incurred by people with asthma. We assessed the hospital care use and costs associated with asthma severity using the UK Biobank cohort and linked healthcare data.
