A substantial body of evidence points to the heritability of dietary preferences. We identified one SNP on chromosome 18 that is associated with vegetarianism at the genome-wide significant level. Four genes are associated with rs72884519: TMEM241, RIOK3, NPC1, and RMC1.

High-throughput proteomics platforms measure thousands of proteins in plasma combined with genomic and phenotypic information. We performed association studies of Olink Explore 3072 data generated by the UK Biobank Pharma Proteomics Project on plasma samples from more than 50,000 participants. We found modest correlation between the two platforms.

Gut hormone ghrelin is an early marker of future risk of developing gastrointestinal cancer. We conducted a genome-wide association study (GWAS) to investigate the possible causal association. The study found associations between multiple genetic variants within +/-200kb of the GHRL gene and plasma ghrel in.

There are several established biomarkers for coronary heart disease (CHD) It is of high interest to determine how a combined polygenic risk score (PRS) of CHD-associated biomarkers can further improve genetic prediction. We developed CHDBioPRS, combining BioPRS with PRS ofCHD in the UK Biobank and tested it on FinnGen.

Male-pattern baldness (MPB) is related to dysregulation of androgens such as testosterone. A previously observed relationship between MPB and skin cancer may be due to greater exposure to ultraviolet radiation or indicate a role for androgenic pathways in the pathogenesis of skin cancers.

Ensemble machine learning could support the development of highly parsimonious prediction models that maintain the performance of more complex models. The main limitation of this study is that the models have not been validated outside of UK and US cohorts.

Despite the known benefits of data-driven approaches, the lack of approaches for identifying functional neuroimaging patterns that capture both individual variations and inter-subject correspondence limits the clinical utility of rsfMRI and its application to single-subject analyses. Here, we identify replicable multi-spatial-scale canonical intrinsic connectivity network (ICN) templates via the use of multi-model-order independent component analysis (ICA) We also study the feasibility of estimating subject-specific ICNs via spatially constrained ICA.

Kidney stone disease affects approximately 10% of individuals in their lifetime and is frequently recurrent. The disease is linked to obesity, but the mechanisms mediating this association are uncertain. Using conventional and genetic epidemiological techniques, we demonstrate that general and central adiposity are independently associated with kidney stone disease.

Ultra-processed food (UPF) is a popular supplement in the UK and other developed countries. Whether UPF intake is associated with chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD) remains unclear. We aimed to examine the association between UPF consumption and COPD incidence and explore the potential mediating effects of COPD-related biomarkers.

Vasomotor symptoms (VMS) can often significantly impact women's quality of life at menopause. Previous genetic studies implicate the TACR3 gene locus that encodes NK3R. We investigated the genetic basis of VMS by analysing health records. Using genomics we demonstrate changes in genetic associations with HRT use.

NAFLD and metabolic dysfunction-associated fatty liver disease (MAFLD) are important risk factors of chronic kidney disease (CKD) Whether adherence to a healthy lifestyle can modify these effects remain unknown. This study aimed to evaluate the modification effects of healthy lifestyle on the associations among NAFLD, MAFLd, and the risk of CKD.

Colorectal cancer (CRC) risk varies widely in the population at average risk without a family history. There are no established routines for translating this variation into personalized starting ages of screening. This cohort study included participants in the UK Biobank study recruited in England, Wales, and Scotland.

Hearing loss is a modifiable risk factor for dementia. However, it is unknown whether risk differs by sex. Women with hearing loss show greater risk of dementia and brain atrophy. Men with poor hearing did not have increased risk.

Calcium channel blocker (CCB) use has been associated with an increased risk of glaucoma in exploratory studies. This population-based cross-sectional study included UK Biobank participants with complete data from 2006-2010. The primary outcome measures included glau coma status, corneal-compensated IOP, and 2 OCT-derived inner retinal thickness parameters. After adjustment for key sociodemographic, medical, anthropometric, and lifestyle factors, use of CCBs (but not other antihypertensive agents) was associated with greater odds of glauxcoma.

This retrospective cohort study analyzed all available MAS cases from medical centers in the US and Europe. Prevalence of MAS ranged from 1 in 170 503 in Geisinger MyCode to 1 in 39 149 in UK Biobank. Brain neoplasms (4 of 12) and schwannomas (3 of 12, 25%) were the most common malignant and benign neural tumors.

Population-based prospective observational study used summary-level data mainly from the UK Biobank and FinnGen. Mendelian randomization analysis was conducted using the inverse variance-weighted method. Genetically predicted high liver MRI PDFF was associated with increased risks of malignant liver neoplasm.

Intermittent non-exercise physical activity was associated with lower mortality and MACE. Compared with bouts of less than 1 min, mortality risk was lower for bouts of 1 min to less than 3 min (hazard ratio [HR] 0.66 [0.53-0.81])

The objective was to assess whether presarcopenia and sarcopenia are associated with an increase in fracture risk. A total of 387,025 participants (women 54.4%; median age 58.0 years) were included. 18,300 (4.7%) participants were diagnosed with at least one incident fracture. Presarcopenic (subgroups 1 and 2) and sarc Openic status were significantly associated with a higher risk of fracture.

Long non-coding RNAs (lncRNAs) are known to perform important regulatory functions in lipid metabolism. Large-scale whole-genome sequencing studies and new statistical methods for variant set tests now provide an opportunity to assess more associations between rare variants in lncRNA genes and complex traits across the genome.

Mitochondria carry their own circular genome and disruption of the mitochondrial genome is associated with various aging-related diseases. Unlike the nuclear genome, mitochondrial DNA (mtDNA) can be present at 1000 s to 10,000 s copies in somatic cells. mtDNA variants may exist in a state of heteroplasmy, where only a fraction of the DNA molecules harbors a particular variant.

We applied structural equation modeling to conduct a genome-wide association study (GWAS) of the general factor measured by a neuroticism questionnaire administered to &#8764;380,000 participants in the UK Biobank. Enriched gene sets pointed to an underlying biological basis associated with brain development, synaptic function and behaviors in mice indicative of fear and anxiety.

A total of 492,998 individuals free of IBD recruited from 2006 to 2010 in the UK Biobank were included in our study. During a median follow-up of 12.5 years, we documented 2954 incident IBD cases (915 Crohn's disease [CD] and 2039 ulcerative colitis) After adjustment for important confounders, body mass index (HR) highest quintile vs. lowest quintile [Q1] = 1.18, 95% confidence interval [CI] 1.04-1.32; P-trend = 0.006.

Study included 381 179 participants without coronary heart disease, stroke, atrial fibrillation, or heart failure at baseline. Over a median follow-up of 12.1 years, 41 910 participants developed FCVD, 7302 further developed CVM, and 20 707 died. Findings suggest that improving sleep behaviors might be helpful for the primary and secondary prevention of cardiovascular diseases.

In 391,652 UK Biobank participants recruited in 2006-2010, 22,413 deaths occurred. Compared to slow walkers, brisk SRWP was associated with reduced cancer (smallest reduction), CVD, and other (largest) causes of death.

Using whole-genome data of 3955 of Darwin's finches on the Gal&#225;pagos Island of Daphne Major, we identified six loci of large effect that explain 45% of the variation in the highly heritable beak size of Geospiza fortis. The major locus is a supergene comprising four genes. Abrupt changes in allele frequencies at the loci accompanied a strong change in beakSize caused by natural selection during a drought.

Cardiometabolic disease is the leading cause of death worldwide. Proteins are crucial components in biological pathways dysregulated in disease states. Identifying genetic components that influence circulating protein levels may lead to the discovery of biomarkers for early stages of disease.

There is no acceptable maximum wall thickness (MWT) threshold for diagnosing apical hypertrophic cardiomyopathy. A normal myocardium naturally tapers apically; a fixed diagnostic threshold fails to account for this. Using cardiac magnetic resonance, "relative" ApHCM has been described with typical electrocardiographic features.

Autoimmune conditions have been reported among patients with cysteine-altering  NOTCH3 variants and CADASIL. This study aimed to investigate the occurrence of autoimmune illnesses and markers of inflammation in such populations. Cases were identified who had a NotCH3  cy Steine-Altering variant from the Geisinger MyCode &#174; Community Health Initiative. A similar analysis was conducted using data from the UK Biobank ( n ~450,000)

A total of 203,348 participants from UK Biobank with consumption data on three beverages were included. Low and moderate intake of pure fruit/vegetable juices showed a significantly inverse association with VAT mass in men and women.

eHEART was derived using landmark Cox models for incident CVD with repeated measures of conventional CVD risk predictors. Using 119,137 individuals from UK Biobank, we modelled the implications of initiating guideline-recommended statin therapy using eHEART with age- and sex-specific prioritisation thresholds.

Oral contraceptives (OC) and menopausal hormone therapy (MHT) contain exogenous sex hormones. However, their effect on the development of rheumatoid arthritis (RA) is still debated. The current literature suggests that they may exert opposite effects on the risk of RA.

Pathogenic or likely pathogenic (P/LP) germline TP53 variants are the primary cause of Li-Fraumeni syndrome (LFS), a hereditary cancer predisposition disorder characterized by early-onset cancers. The TP53 p.R181H variant was the most frequently identified (9 of 109 individuals, 8%). A total of 110 cancers, including 47 hematologic cancers, were reported in 71 individuals.

Dementia is a debilitating syndrome characterized by the gradual loss of memory and cognitive function. We investigated data from 502,357 individuals from the UK Biobank cohort via Structural Equation Modelling. Our model demonstrated that higher education was associated with better cognitive performance.

Frailty is commonly considered as a syndrome of old individuals, but recent studies show that it can affect younger adults, too. Whether and how frailty differs in younger adults compared to old is however unknown. To this end, we analyzed the prevalence, characteristics, and risk factors of early-life (aged   METHODS: We analyzed individuals in the UK Biobank and Swedish Screening Across the Lifespan Twin study.

BMI was found to be a stronger risk factor in women compared to men for psoriatic arthropathy and gout. The effect on osteoarthritis was stronger in premenopausal compared to postmenopausal women. The nonlinearity for gout was also more extreme in men compared to women.

Sleep duration has been linked to a wide range of negative health outcomes and to reduced life expectancy. In a cross-population meta-analysis, we identify 84 independent loci for short sleep and 1 for long sleep. We estimate SNP-based heritability for both sleep traits in each ancestry based on population derived linkage disequilibrium scores.

Males presented higher ASCVD risk than females (8.63% vs. 2.65%) in the UK Biobank population. PM 2.5 , PM 10 , NO 2 , and NO x each were associated with an increased ASCvd risk >7.5% in the adjusted logistic models. No association was observed in both sexes between ASCVDrisk and PM 2-10.

Excessive salt consumption is known to increase the risk of hypertension and cardiovascular disease. But the association between salt intake and incident type 2 diabetes has not been extensively researched. In this study, we aimed to investigate the relationships between the frequency of adding salt to foods and incident Type 2 diabetes.

High-density lipoprotein cholesterol, HDL-C, was found to increase the risk of chronic kidney disease (CKD) and estimated glomerular filtration rate (eGFR) The shared genetic basis was largely explained by 29 pleiotropic loci and 36 shared gene-tissue pairs. Mendelian randomization revealed an independent causal relationship of genetically predicted HDL- C with CKD.

Lp(a) is a highly atherogenic lipoprotein subfraction that may contribute to polygenic risk of coronary artery disease (CAD) The extent of this contribution is unknown. The aim of this study was to estimate the contribution of Lp( a) to polygenic risk of CAD.

Plant-based dietary patterns may affect colorectal cancer (CRC) related outcomes. We aimed to examine the association of plant-based diet quality with risks of CRC incidence and mortality. We found a joint association of genetic risk and PDIs with incident CRC.

Study included 485 936 UK Biobank participants free of baseline VTE. Incident VTE cases were defined by ICD-9 and 10 codes with data from the nationwide inpatient data set. Eleven gastrointestinal diseases (nine non-neoplastic and two neoplastic) were associated with an increased risk of incident VTE after Bonferroni corrections.

UK cardiovascular disease (CVD) incidence and mortality have declined in recent decades. But socioeconomic inequalities persist. A new CVD model was developed to project health outcomes and the impact of guideline-recommended statin treatment.

Study examined age-specific effects of 14 risk factors on CVD and mortality in different age groups. Metabolic factors had the highest PAF in each age group, with hypertension (14.04%) and abdominal obesity (9.58%) prominent. Low income contributed most among middle-aged and elderly groups (3.74%) and less education accounted for 4.46% of the PAF.

Rates of cerebrovascular disease increase after menopause, which is often attributed to the absence of hormones. We examined the relationship between lifetime hormone exposure (LHE) and cerebral small vessel disease in more than 9,000 postmenopausal women in the UK-Biobank. Women with higher LHE Endo  showed smaller WMHV.

There are many ways in which selection bias might impact COVID-19 research. Here we focus on selection for receiving a polymerase-chain-reaction (PCR) SARS-CoV-2 test. We construct four distinct time-periods between March 2020 and March 2021, representing distinct periods of testing pressures and lockdown restrictions.

Accurate information on PGx allele frequencies improves the implementation of PGx. We applied the Pharmacogenomics Clinical Annotation Tool (PharmCAT) on an integrated 200K UK Biobank genetic dataset (N = 200,044) Based on PharmCAT results, we estimated PGx frequencies for 17 pharmacogenes in five biogeographic groups.

Study aimed to calculate risk and worldwide prevalence of diabetes in patients with autoimmune hepatitis (AIH), primary biliary cholangitis (PBC) and primary sclerosing cholangsitis (PSC) Case-control study using data from the United Kingdom Biobank. Risk of T1D and T2D significantly increased compared with matched controls.

Stress and depression have a reciprocal relationship, but the neural underpinnings of this reciprocity are unclear. We investigated neuroimaging phenotypes that facilitate the reciprocity between stress and depressive symptoms. 22 195 participants (52.0% females) from the population-based UK Biobank study completed two visits.

Little is known about whether the association between genetic susceptibility to high waist-to-hip ratio (WHR) and incident coronary heart disease (CHD) is modified by adherence to a healthy lifestyle. This study included 282,316 white British individuals from the UK Biobank study.

Autozygosity is associated with rare Mendelian disorders and clinically relevant quantitative traits. We investigated associations between the fraction of the genome in runs of homozygosity (F ROH ) and common diseases in Genes & Health, UK Biobank, and 23andMe. We found experiment-wide significant associations between F ROH and twelve common diseases.

Polygenic scores (PGS) for coronary heart disease (CHD) are constructed using GWAS summary statistics for CHD. Pleiotropy is pervasive in biology and disease-associated variants often share etiologic pathways with multiple traits. Using lasso regression models, we developed two multi-PGS for ChD. In the Mayo Clinic Biobank, a 1 SD increase in multiPGSCHD was associated with a 1.66-fold (95% CI: 1.60-1.71) and 1.70-fold increased odds of CHD, respectively.

Racial minority status increased dementia risk by 24% (HR = 1.24, 95% CI: 1.07-1.45,  P  = 0.005), an association attenuated by socio-economic status (SES) Total race-dementia effect was mediated through both SES and Life's Essential 8 lifestyle sub-score (LE8 LIFESTYLE ), combining diet, smoking, physical activity, and sleep factors.

This study aimed to investigate the association between serum 25-hydroxyvitamin D (25(OH)D) levels and dementia, mild cognitive impairment (MCI), and delirium. 443,427 participants with a mean (standard deviation) age of 56.8 (8.0) years were included in this study. Based on Cox regression models, serum 25( OH)D concentrations were inversely associated with the risk of dementia.

Polygenic risk scores (PRSs) increasingly predict complex traits. Suboptimal performance in non-European populations raise concerns about clinical applications and health inequities. We developed CT-SLEB, a powerful and scalable method to calculate PRSs.

Type 2 diabetes disproportionately affects individuals of non-White ethnicity. Early disease detection and prediction are essential and require tools that can be deployed on a large scale. We aimed to tackle this problem by developing questionnaire-based prediction models for type 2 diabetes prevalence and incidence.

Many studies have reported on the associations between the amount of physical activity (PA) and the transitions of cardiometabolic multimorbidity (CMM) The evidence for PA intensity has not been fully evaluated. This study aimed to explore the impact of PA intensity on the dynamic progression of CMM.

Cine magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) is the current gold standard for the assessment of cardiac anatomy and function. However, it typically only acquires a set of two-dimensional slices of the underlying three-dimensional (3D) anatomy of the heart. In this paper, we propose a novel fully automatic surface reconstruction pipeline capable of reconstructing multi-class 3D cardiac anatomy meshes from raw cine MRI acquisitions.

Both air pollution and physical inactivity contribute to the increased risk of incident chronic kidney disease (CKD) The detrimental effects of air pollution exposure could be augmented by an elevated intake of air pollutants during exercise. We analyzed 367,978 participants who were CKD-free at baseline (2006-2010) based on the UK Biobank.

Walking pace is associated with various health-related outcomes. The aim of this study was to investigate the association between self-reported walking pace and the incidences of diabetic microvascular complications. A total of 14 518 participants with T2D in the UK Biobank were included.

The role of fatty acids (FAs) in primary prevention of coronary artery disease (CAD) is highly debated. Here, we report the prospective associations of circulating FAs and genetic predisposition with CAD development in 101,367 U.K. Biobank participants.

Gilbert syndrome (GS) is genotypically predetermined by UGT1A1*28 homozygosity in Europeans. GS is phenotypically defined by hyperbilirubinemia using total bilirubin (TB) cutoff &#8805;1mg/dL (17 &#956;mol/L) The prevalence of illnesses associated with GS has never been studied prospectively. UK Biobank with apparently healthy liver participants (middle-aged, n=138,125) were analyzed.

Male-pattern hair loss (MPHL) is common and highly heritable. While genome-wide association studies (GWAS) have generated insights into the contribution of common variants to MPHL etiology, the relevance of rare variants remains unclear. We perform gene-based and single-variant analyses in exome-sequencing data.

Some evidence suggests gene-treatment interactions might cause persistent symptoms in individuals receiving levothyroxine (LT4) treatment. We investigated if single-nucleotide variations (SNVs) were associated with outcomes indicative of local tissue hypothyroidism in LT4-treated patients and controls.

Alzheimer's disease (AD) and cardiovascular traits might share underlying causes. We sought to identify clusters of cardiovascular traits that share genetic factors with AD. The clustering of body mass index (BMI) with weight but not height indicates that weight defines BMI-AD pleiotropy.

Common genetic variants associated with lung cancer have been well studied in the past decade. Only 12.3% heritability has been explained by these variants. In this study, we investigate the contribution of rare variants (RVs)

The concept of biological age has emerged as a measurement that reflects physiological and functional decline with ageing. Here we aimed to develop a deep neural network (DNN) model that predicts biological age from optical coherence tomography (OCT) The DNN model predicted age with a mean absolute error of 3.27 years and showed a strong correlation of 0.85 with chronological age.

Personalized prediction of chronic diseases is crucial for reducing the disease burden. Previous studies on chronic diseases have not adequately considered the relationship between chronic diseases. We developed a multitask learning Cox (MTL-Cox) model for personalized prediction of nine typical chronic diseases on the UK Biobank dataset.

A low resting heart rate (RHR) implies a more efficient heart function and a lower risk of cardiovascular disease. However, observational studies have reported a U-shaped association between RHR and atrial fibrillation (AF) In contrast, Mendelian randomization (MR) studies have found an inverse causal association. The aim is to investigate the causal association using linear and non-linear MR (NLMR)

Abnormally short and long sleep are associated with premature mortality. We calculated Sleep Regularity Index (SRI) scores from > 10 million hours of accelerometer data. Higher sleep regularity was associated with a 20%-48% lower risk of all-cause mortality.

Study looked at long-term associations between coronavirus disease 2019 (COVID-19) and diabetes complications and mortality, in patients with diabetes. Compared with uninfected participants, patients with CO VID-19 infection with diabetes were consistently associated with higher risks of cardiovascular diseases.

Little is known about milder forms of SARS-CoV-2 infection. We sought to explore the association between ethnic background and the probability of testing, testing positive, hospitalisation, COVID-19 mortality and vaccination uptake.

Social isolation and loneliness pose significant public health challenges globally. The objective of this study is to investigate the association between social isolation, loneliness, and the risk of type 2 diabetes mellitus (T2DM) 423,503 UK adults from the UK Biobank and 13,800 Chinese adults from China Health and Retirement Longitudinal Study were analyzed.

We assessed several genomic data science tools. Tools were compared in terms of data storage technology, query speed, scalability, annotation, data manipulation, visualization, data output representation, and availability. tools that leverage sophisticated data structures are noted as the most suitable for large-scale projects.

Inflammation is linked with chronic pain but the extent to which this relationship is associated with biopsychosocial factors is not known. We investigated relationships between blood C-reactive protein (CRP) and regional chronic pain conditions adjusting for a large range of potential confounders.

Fatty acid amide hydrolase (FAAH) is an enzyme that degrades anandamide, an endocannabinoid that modulates mesolimbic dopamine release. FAAH's specific role in subjective well-being remains underexplored. We found that the A-allele of FAAH gene (rs324420) was associated with lowerWell-being scores.

Autoimmune disorders (ADs) occur when self-attacking autoantibodies are produced due to failure in the self-tolerance mechanisms. ADs are polygenic disorders and associations with genes both in the human leukocyte antigen (HLA) region and outside of it have been described. For the first time, we performed a comparative polygenic risk score (PRS) for 11 different ADs.

Using genome-wide imputed genetic data, we aimed to classify 158,951 unrelated individuals from the UK Biobank as either concordant or deviating from two well-measured phenotypes. Stratifying individuals misaligned to a genetic predictor based on common variants may be important for follow-up studies.

Previous work identified rare variants in DSTYK associated with human congenital anomalies of the kidney and urinary tract (CAKUT) Here, we present a series of mouse and human studies to clarify the association, penetrance, and expressivity of DSTyK variants.

A cohort of 93,095 UK Biobank participants (mean age 62 years) without a history of type 2 diabetes wore a wrist-worn accelerometer for 1 week. We converted accelerometer information to estimate metabolic equivalent of task (MET), summing MET h of total physical activity completed within three intra-day time segments (morning, afternoon and evening) We quantified physical activity consistency as the SD of participants' dailytotal physical activity.

Tobacco smoking is the most important risk factor for bladder cancer. Previous studies have identified the N-acetyltransferase (NAT2) gene in association with bladder cancer risk. NAT2 gene encodes an enzyme that metabolizes aromatic amines, carcinogens commonly found in tobacco smoke.

UK Biobank recruited over 500,000 women and men between 2006 and 2010. Over 12.5 years of follow-up, there were 4,908 MI events in women and 10,517 in men. A unit higher log-transformed O/T ratio was associated with a lower risk of MI in men, but not women.

Metformin shows beneficial effects on cardiometabolic health in diabetic individuals. However, the beneficial effects in the general population, especially in non-diabetic individuals are unclear. We aim to estimate the effects of perturbation of seven metformin targets.

Atrial fibrillation (AF) is the most common sustained arrhythmia in adults. Investigations of risk factor profiles for AF according to age and genetic risk groups are essential to promote individualized strategies.

Eighty IMDs (involving allergic/atopic diseases, autoimmune diseases, immunodeficiency diseases, etc) were identified in the UK Biobank. During a median of 12.0 years of follow-up, 2244 cases out of 500 371 subjects developed HPV-associated diseases. Overall, participants with IMDs had a higher risk of HPV- associated diseases.

Study included 161,127 White European UK Biobank participants who were free of diabetes at baseline. Anthropometric measures included height, weight, BMI, A Body Shape Index, waist circumference, waist to hip ratio. All markers except height and hip index were positively associated with type 2 diabetes.

The association of serum sex hormone-binding globulin (SHBG) concentrations with dementia risk remains uncertain. We examined associations of serum SHBG levels with incidence of all-cause dementia and its subtypes in middle-aged to older women from the large UK Biobank cohort study.

Medial temporal lobe (MTL) atrophy is correlated with risk and severity of Alzheimer disease (AD) pathology and cognitive decline. Increasing evidence suggest that oestrogens affect the aging of MTL structures. Here we investigate the relationship between reproductive hormone exposure, polygenic scores for AD risk and oestradiol concentration, MTL anatomy and cognitive performance.

Study included 4,293 and 1,157 adults with rheumatoid arthritis. Medians (25th-75th percentiles) of serum 25(OH)D and omega-3 % were 45.8 (31.4-62.9) nmol/L and 4.1 % (3.3 %-5.1%) During 52,612 person-years of follow-up, 502 all-cause deaths occurred.

The associations between intensity of stair climbing and atherosclerotic cardiovascular disease (ASCVD) are not fully understood. This prospective study used data of 458,860 adult participants from the UK Biobank. Participants who stopped stair climbing between baseline and resurvey had a higher risk of ASCVD compared with those who never climbed stairs.

 Concurrence between ovarian reserve and spontaneous miscarriage was observed. It may be attributed to shared genetic risk loci enriched in antigen processing and presentation and autoimmune disease pathways. Risk of early spontaneous miscarriage 1.57 times higher in the group with AMH.

Time spent on screen-based sedentary activities is significantly associated with dementia risk. Whether the associations vary by family history of dementia is currently unknown. We examined independent associations of TV viewing and computer use with dementia and assess the modifying effect of FHx.

Regular aspirin use was associated with an 11.2% reduction in the risk of developing new liver diseases. The risk of metabolic dysfunction-associated steatotic liver disease (ICD-10 K76.0) and MRI-diagnosed steatosis was significantly lower among aspirin users. No increased risk of gastrointestinal bleeding or ulcers was observed.

Study looked at 454,712 UK Biobank participants with exome sequence and clinical data. Participants had a self-reported family history of breast or colorectal cancer and a pathogenic/likely pathogenic variant in the major genes responsible for hereditary breast cancer or Lynch syndrome. Women with pathogenic BRCA1 or BRCa2 variant had increased risk of breast cancer.

Study sought to examine whether younger onset age of HF is associated with a higher risk of incident dementia. Compared with 442,791 participants without HF, those with HF had a higherrisk of all-cause dementia (HR: 1.14)

In cross-platform analyses of 174 metabolites, we identify 499 associations (P) We identified 499 associations between 174 metabolites and a range of human health conditions.

Study examined gray and white matter associations of four different PLEs in subjects of the UK Biobank study with neuroimaging data. Individuals that reported having experienced auditory hallucinations had smaller volumes of the caudate, putamen, and accumbens. People who indicated they had ever believed in unreal conspiracies had a larger volume of the left amygdala.

Previous Mendelian randomization (MR) studies on 25-hydroxyvitamin D (25(OH)D) and cancer have typically adopted a handful of variants and found no relationship. Using a larger set of variants associated with 25( OH)D (74 SNPs, up from 6 previously), we perform a unified MR analysis to re-evaluate the relationship. Our findings are broadly consistent with previous MR studies indicating no relationship, apart from ovarian cancers.

Bardet-Biedl Syndrome (BBS) is a pleiotropic genetic disease caused by the dysfunction of primary cilia. The immune system of patients with ciliopathies has not been investigated. The impairment of processes typically associated with cilia may have influence on the hematopoietic compartment and immunity.

Germline de novo copy number variants (CNVs) are known causes of autism spectrum disorder (ASD) The contribution of mosaic (early-developmental) copy number variant (mCNVs), has not been explored. In this study, we assessed the contribution of mCNVs to ASD by assessing genotype array intensity data from 12,077 probands with ASD and 5,500 unaffected siblings.

Adiposity is a strong risk factor for cancer incidence and mortality. Most of the evidence available has focused on body mass index (BMI) as a marker of adiposity. There is limited evidence on relationships of cancer with other adiposity markers, and if these associations are linear or not. The aim of this study was to investigate the associations of six adiposity marker with incidence and death from 24 cancers.

Red wine drinking, consumption with food and spreading alcohol intake over 3-4 days were associated with lower risk of mortality and vascular events among regular alcohol drinkers. If replicated and validated, these findings have the potential to influence policy and practice advice on less harmful patterns of alcohol consumption.

Donor and recipient size matching during heart transplant can be assessed using weight or predicted heart mass (PHM) ratios. Of 53,648 adult patients in the United Network of Organ Sharing database between 1996 and 2016, 6528 (12.2%) died within the first year. undersized matches by any metric were associated with increased 1-year mortality.

In social neuroscience, many experiments have sought to first define and then locate 'perspective taking', 'empathy', and other psychological concepts to specific brain circuits. We explored coherent representations of structural co-variation at population scale within a recent social brain atlas, by translating autoencoder neural networks from deep learning.

Biallelic Parkin (PRKN) mutations cause autosomal recessive Parkinson's disease (PD) The role of monoallelic PRKN mutations as a risk factor for PD remains unclear. We investigated the role of single heterozygous PR KN mutations in three large independent case-control cohorts totalling 10 858 PD cases and 8328 controls.

Admixed populations are routinely excluded from genomic studies due to concerns over population structure. We present a statistical framework and software package, Tractor, to facilitate the inclusion of admixed individuals in association studies. We test Tractor with simulated and empirical two-way admixed African-European cohorts.

We evaluate the genetic basis of 35 blood and urine laboratory measurements in the UK Biobank (n = 363,228 individuals) We identify 5,794 independent loci associated with at least one trait (p  0.1 s.d.) protein-altering, human leukocyte antigen (HLA) and copy number variant (CNV) associations. We discover 51 causal relationships, including previously known agonistic effects of urate on gout and cystatin C on stroke.

Distribution entropy (DistEn) is a recently introduced complexity measure that is designed specifically for shorter duration heartbeat recordings. We hypothesized that reduced DistEn predicted increased mortality in a large population cohort. The prognostic value of DistEn was examined in 7631 middle-older-aged UK Biobank participants who had 2-minute resting ECGs conducted.

Lung cancer is the leading cause of cancer-related death globally. An improved risk stratification strategy can increase efficiency of low-dose CT (LDCT) screening. The age reaching the LDCT screening recommendation threshold can vary by 4 to 8 years, depending on the individual's genetic background.

Left ventricular noncompaction (LVNC) may represent a distinct pathology or a secondary phenotype associated with other cardiac diseases. We performed rare variant association analysis with 840 LVNC cases and 125,748 gnomAD population controls. We observed substantial genetic overlap indicating that LVNC often represents a phenotypic variation of DCM or HCM. In contrast, truncating variants in MYH7, ACTN2, and PRDM16 were uniquely associated with LVNC.

Several polygenic risk scores (PRS) have been developed for cardiovascular risk prediction. This study assesses the clinical utility of including four PRS, along with conventional risk factors, to predict risk of ischemic heart disease (IHD), myocardial infarction (MI), and first MI event on or before age 50.

In epidemiological studies, the exposure is often a coarsened approximation to some latent continuous trait. Genetically driven variation in the outcome can exist within categories of the exposure measurement. We propose a framework to clarify this violation.

Insulin-like growth factor-1 (IGF1) has been implicated in mitogenic and anti-apoptotic mechanisms that promote susceptibility to cancer development and growth. Previous epidemiological studies have described phenotypic associations between higher circulating levels of IGF1 in adults with higher risks for breast, prostate, ovarian, colorectal, melanoma and lung cancers. We perform a genome-wide association study in 428,525 white European ancestry individuals.

Machine learning models could be used to predict risks at different stages of management. ML models predicted the risk of death of 0.906 at diagnosis, 0.818, at hospital admission and 0.721 at ICU admission.

The Trans-Omics for Precision Medicine (TOPMed) programme seeks to elucidate the genetic architecture and biology of heart, lung, blood and sleep disorders. The initial phases of the programme focused on whole-genome sequencing of individuals with rich phenotypic data and diverse backgrounds. In the first 53,831 TOPMed samples, we detected more than 400 million single-nucleotide and insertion or deletion variants.

Metabolite levels in urine may provide insights into genetic mechanisms shaping related pathways. We investigate the cumulative contribution of rare, exonic genetic variants on urine levels of 1487 metabolites and 53,714 metabolite ratios among 4864 GCKD study participants. We report the detection of 128 significant associations involving 30 unique genes, 16 of which are known to underlie inborn errors of metabolism.

Genome-wide association studies have discovered numerous genomic loci associated with Alzheimer's disease (AD) Yet the causal genes and variants are incompletely identified. We performed an updated genome-wide AD meta-analysis, which identified 37 risk loci.

Genetic connections of a person can be traced using identity by descent (IBD) segments. On average, one UK individual shares IBD segments with 14,000 UK Biobank participants, which we refer to as "relatives" Using these segments, approximately 80% of a people's genome can be imputed.

We performed a multivariate gene-by-environment genome-wide interaction study (GEWIS) of suicidality in 123,633 individuals. PTSD was identified as a primary driving environment for GxE at risk loci. GEWIS points to extracellular matrix biology and synaptic plasticity as biological interactors with the effects of potentially modifiable lifetime traumatic experiences on genetic risk for suicide.

Study used genotype data on 166,281 Icelanders and 408,595 individuals from the UK Biobank. 25,205 BCC cases and 683,058 controls were tested. Rare germline loss-of-function variants in PTPN14 conferred substantial risks of BCC. Findings highlight future prospects for new discoveries on carcinogenesis.

Bell's palsy is the most common cause of unilateral facial paralysis. Previous studies have implicated post-viral inflammation and resulting compression of the facial nerve. A genetic component in the etiology and an autosomal dominant inheritance has been proposed.

Risky behaviors, such as substance use and unprotected sex, are associated with various physical and mental health problems. Recent genome-wide association studies indicated that variation in the cell adhesion molecule 2 (CADM2) gene plays a role in risky behaviors and self-control. In this phenome-wide scan for risky behavior, it was tested if underlying common vulnerability could be (partly) explained by pleiotropic effects of this gene.

Bayesian methods have been developed using individual-level GWAS data to estimate multiple genetic architecture parameters including selection signature. We present a method (SBayesS) that only requires GWAS summary statistics. We estimate that, on average across traits, about 1% of human genome sequence are mutational targets.

Most genome-wide association study (GWAS) analyses test the association between single-nucleotide polymorphisms (SNPs) and a single trait or outcome. While valuable second-step analyses of these associations are common, single-step multivariate analyses of GWAS data are rarely performed.

Tumor mutational burden (TMB) is an emerging biomarker of response to immunotherapy in solid tumors. The extent to which variation in TMB between patients is attributable to germline genetic variation remains elusive. Using 7,004 unrelated patients of European descent across 33 cancer types, we show that pan-cancer TMB is polygenic.

Keratoconus is characterised by reduced rigidity of the cornea. It can lead to severe visual morbidity in children and young adults. It is a common indication for corneal transplantation worldwide.

Macular Telangiectasia Type 2 (MacTel) is a rare degenerative retinal disease with complex genetic architecture. We performed a genome-wide association study on 1,067 MacTel patients and 3,799 controls. We identified eight novel genome- wide significant loci (p)

There is limited prospective evidence on the association between meat consumption and many common, non-cancerous health outcomes. We examined associations of meat intake with risk of 25 common conditions (other than cancer) We used data from 474,985 middle-aged adults recruited into the UK Biobank study.

More than 150 million women worldwide use oral contraceptives. Women with inherited thrombophilia are at an increased risk for venous thromboembolism. The polygenic risk score could be used to identify women who are at high risk.

Dilated cardiomyopathy (DCM) is a life-threatening heart disease and a common cause of heart failure due to systolic dysfunction and subsequent left or biventricular dilatation. As a complex disease, the exact genetic risk factors are largely unknown and many patients remain without a molecular diagnosis.

We identify 35 modifiable factors for age gap (p  -4  ), where pulmonary functions, body mass, hand grip strength, basal metabolic rate, estimated glomerular filtration rate, and C-reactive protein show the most significant associations. We identify CST3 as an essential gene for biological aging, which is highly expressed in the brain and is associated with immune and metabolic traits.

Viral encephalitis increases later-life risk of Alzheimer's disease (AD) by a factor of 31. West Nile virus (WNV) was significantly associated with deaths from AD in 50 US states.

Accurate polygenic scores (PGSs) facilitate the genetic prediction of complex traits and aid in the development of personalized medicine. We develop a statistical method called multi-trait assisted PGS (mtPGS) which can construct accurate PGSs for a target trait of interest.

Using 2D CNNs on high-resolution medical volumes is very computationally demanding, especially for large datasets like UK Biobank, which aims to scan 100,000 subjects. Using our approach, one training epoch with 20,324 subjects takes 20-50 s using a single GPU, which is two orders of magnitude faster than a small 3D CNN.

Clonal hematopoiesis of indeterminate potential (CHIP) is associated with an increased risk of cardiovascular diseases. We identified CHIP using whole-exome sequencing data of blood DNA. We developed predicted gene expression scores for 26 inflammasome-related genes and assessed how they modify CHIP-associated CVD risk.

When polygenic risk score (PRS) is derived from summary statistics, independence between discovery and test sets cannot be monitored. We compared two types of PRS studies derived from raw genetic data and the summary statistics for IGAP.

Glucagon-like peptide 1 receptor (GLP1R) is a major drug target. Several agonists are prescribed in individuals with type 2 diabetes and obesity. The impact of genetic variability of GLP1r on receptor function and its association with metabolic traits are unclear.

Major depressive disorder (MDD) has a significant impact on global burden of disease. Complications in clinical management can occur when response to pharmacological modalities is considered inadequate and symptoms persist. We aim to investigate inflammation, proxied by C-reactive protein (CRP) levels, and body mass index (BMI) as putative causal risk factors for depression and subsequent treatment resistance.

Major depressive disorder (MDD), bipolar disorder (BD), and schizophrenia (SCZ) are associated with an increased risk of cardiovascular diseases, including venous thromboembolism (VTE) Genetic studies have increasingly provided evidence of the shared genetic risk of psychiatric and cardiometabolic illnesses. This study aimed to determine whether a genetic predisposition to MDD, BD, or SCZ is associated with a risk of VTE.

Metabolites' connection to sarcopenia through inflammation and mitochondrial dysfunction is presumed, but their impact remains unclear due to limitations in conventional observational studies. We conducted a Mendelian randomization (MR) analysis to elucidate the association of serum metabolites with sarc Openia and its related traits, i.e., appendicular lean mass and grip strength. Fourteen genetically predicted serum metabolites were associated with the risk of sarc openia.

The cerebellum and the brainstem are two brain structures involved in pain processing and modulation that have also been associated with migraine pathophysiology. The aim of this study was to investigate possible associations between the morphology of the cerebellums and migraine. The analyses were based on data from 712 individuals with migraine and 45,681 healthy controls.

An overall significant effect of GSD on CVD was found in meta-analysis. A positive shared genetic basis was observed for GSD with stroke and CAD. The shared genetic architecture was largely explained by the multiple pleiotropic loci identified in cross-phenotype association study.

Smoking may increase headache risk, individuals may smoke to alleviate headaches, or smoking and headache may share common risk factors. Mendelian randomization is a method that uses genetic variants as instruments for making causal inferences about an exposure and an outcome. There was evidence for weak causal effects of smoking initiation and lifetime smoking (but not smoking heaviness) on likelihood of experiencing headache.

Study followed 455,804 participants from the United Kingdom Biobank cohort who were free of lung cancer at baseline. Compared with participants without CVD, those with CVD had HRs of 1.49 for NSCLC, 1.80 for lung squamous cell carcinoma (LUSC) and 1.25 for lung adenocarcinoma (LUAD) CVD was associated with lung cancer risk across each genetic risk level.

Sedentary behavior is associated with cardiometabolic disease and mortality, but its association with dementia is unclear. A retrospective study of prospectively collected data from the UK Biobank included 49 841 adults aged 60 years or older without a diagnosis of dementia at the time of wearing the wrist accelerometer.

Diets rich in plant-based foods are associated with lower risks of non-alcoholic fatty liver disease (NAFLD) While the prospective evidence is limited, we aimed to examine longitudinal associations of plant- based diets and genetic susceptibility with NAFLD risk.

Few studies have investigated associations between adiposity and reproductive factors using causal methods. We used genetic data from UK Biobank (273,238 women) and other consortia for eight reproductive factors. We found a higher childhood body size leads to an earlier age at menarche.

Left ventricular systolic dysfunction (LSVD) is a heterogeneous condition with several factors influencing prognosis. Better phenotyping of asymptomatic individuals can inform preventative strategies.

Metabolic profiling is increasingly employed in clinical care. However, there is little evidence on the benefit of metabolic profiling as compared with established atherosclerotic cardiovascular disease (CVD) risk scores. UK Biobank is a prospective study of 0.5 million participants, aged 40-69 at recruitment.

The social determinants of ethnic disparities in risk of SARS-CoV-2 infection during the first wave of the pandemic in the UK remain unclear. In May 2020, a total of 20 195 adults were recruited from the general population into the UK Biobank Sars-Cov-2 Serology Study.

Human exposome has emerged as a significant contributor to the overall risk of developing major diseases, such as cardiovascular disease (CVD) and diabetes. We developed and evaluate a novel and fair machine learning (ML) model for CVD and type 2 diabetes (T2D) risk prediction based on a set of readily available exposomes.

Denture use may potentially increase the risk of cardiometabolic diseases (CMDs), but the casual relevance and strength of the associations are currently unknown. In observational analysis, denture use was associated with 14-25% higher risks of various CMDs.

CYP2C19 is a key enzyme involved in the metabolism of several drugs, including SSRIs. Variations in the gene are associated with differential metabolic activity, and thus differential SSRI exposure. We analysed data from the UK Biobank, a large, deeply phenotyped prospective study.

The prevalence of type 2 diabetes is increasing rapidly, particularly among younger age groups. Estimates suggest that people with diabetes die, on average, 6 years earlier than people without diabetes.

Mosaic chromosomal alterations (mCAs) are common in cancers and can arise decades before diagnosis. Using mCA clone size estimates from the blood of approximately 500,000 UK Biobank participants, we estimate mutation rates and fitness consequences of acquired gain, loss and copy-neutral loss of heterozygosity events.

Lifestyle factors have been acknowledged to be modifiable targets that can be used to counter the increasing prevalence of depression. This study aims to investigate combining an extensive range of lifestyle factors, including alcohol consumption, diet, physical activity, sleep, smoking and sedentary behavior.

Femoral neck width (FNW), diameter of the femoral head (DFH) and hip axis length (HAL) were derived automatically from left hip DXA scans. Correlations were calculated between geometric parameters, age, height, and weight. Greater FNW and HAL were independently related to an increased risk of radiographic HOA.

A prospective cohort with a total of 317,552 participants without NCDs at recruitment was obtained from UK Biobank. Cox proportional hazards models were used to examine associations of lifestyle score (HLS), polygenic risk score (PRS) for longevity. Quitting smoking showed the largest benefits among various lifestyles.

Using data from the UK Biobank, we reveal the roles of selection and mutation in shaping the genetic diversity of mosaic chromosomal alterations in healthy blood.

Uticaria is characterized by inappropriate mast cell degranulation leading to the development of wheals and/or angioedema. Twin and family studies indicate that there is a substantial heritable component to urticaria risk. Genome-wide significant associations were identified at 6 independent loci. Genes with expected or established roles in mast cell biology were associated with the 4 other genome-wide association signals.

Study included 214,945 participants over the age of 60 who had available information on glucosamine use and did not have dementia at baseline in the UK Biobank. The primary outcome was incident vascular dementia, incident Alzheimer's disease, and incident frontotemporal dementia. Overall, habitual glucosamines use was significantly associated with a lower risk of vascular dementia.

Ultra-processed food (UPF) consumption has aroused concern about its potential health effects. This study evaluates the association of UPF consumption with mortality. Those with the highest quartile of UpF consumption had higher risks of all-cause mortality.

A data-driven transdiagnostic approach could provide a new perspective on the neurobiology of AUD and NUD. Three biotypes-primary NUD, mixed NUD/AUD with depression and anxiety, and mixed AUD/NUD-were identified. Cerebellar FC features were important in distinguishing the 3 biotypes.

Using data from 91,532 participants in the UK Biobank, we evaluated the associations of metabolites measured using nuclear magnetic resonance testing with the risk of CKD. We found that 90 out of 142 lipid biomarkers were significantly associated with incident CKD and that several amino acids, fatty acids, and inflammatory biomarker were associated with CKD risk. These findings advance our knowledge about mechanistic pathways that may contribute to the development of CKd.

Lipid traits are known essential mediators of cardiovascular disease. Few approaches have taken advantage of their shared genetic effects. We apply a Bayesian multivariate size estimator, mash, to GWAS of four lipid traits.

Heart failure is a major health problem and early diagnosis is important. Atherosclerosis is the main cause of HF and carotid intima-media thickness (IMT) is a recognized early measure of atherosclerosis. This study aimed to investigate whether increased IMT is associated with changes in cardiac structure and function in middle-aged participants of the UK Biobank Study.

Clonal hematopoiesis (CH) can differ in frequency and cellular fitness by CH type. Co-occurring CH raises questions as to their origin, selection, and impact. We integrate sequence and genotype array data in up to 482,378 UK Biobank participants.

The relationship between coffee consumption and diabetes-related vascular complications remains unclear. This study assessed the relationships of coffee consumption with major cardiovascular disease (CVD) and microvascular disease (MVD) in never-smokers with type 2 diabetes mellitus (T2DM)

Women with an early menopause are at higher risk of stroke compared with women with a later one. We analyzed data of the UK Biobank and EPIC-CVD study. Over a median follow-up of 12.6 years, 6770 women experienced a stroke. We found no statistically significant association between genetically proxied age at menopausal and risk of any type of stroke.

Cardiac output, systemic vascular resistance, and aortic distensibility were measured from cardiac magnetic resonance imaging in 31 112 (distensibility in 21 178) participants (46.3% male, mean age+/-SD 63+/-7 years) Participants with higher blood pressure had higher cardiac output (higher by 17.9+/-26.6% in hypertensive compared with those with optimal blood pressure)

Conventional measurements of fasting and postprandial blood glucose levels investigated in genome-wide association studies (GWAS) cannot capture the effects of DNA variability on 'around the clock' glucoregulatory processes. Here we show that GWAS meta-analysis of glucose measurements under nonstandardized conditions (random glucose (RG) in 476,326 individuals enables locus discovery and innovative pathophysiological observations.

In 176,249 dementia-free UK Biobank participants aged &#8805;60 years at baseline, Cox proportional-hazards models were used to investigate the association between MetS and incident dementia. MetS was defined as the presence of elevated waist circumference, triglycerides, blood pressure, blood glucose, and reduced high-density lipoprotein cholesterol. Over 15 years of follow-up, 5255 participants developed dementia.

Ankylosing spondylitis (AS) and carriage of the HLA-B27 gene are reportedly associated with increased mortality. We evaluated this hypothesis, using data from both a 35-year AS follow-up study and UK Biobank data.

The role of genetic background underlying the disparity of relative risk of smoking and lung cancer between European populations and East Asians remains unclear. To assess the role of ethnic differences in genetic factors associated with smoking-related risk of lung cancer, we constructed ethnic-specific polygenic risk scores (PRSs)

Early menarche, early menopause, short reproductive lifespan, early age at first birth, multiparity, and use of oral contraceptives (OCs) and hormone replacement therapy (HRT) were associated with shorter LTL.

AMPK is a pharmacological target of metformin. We investigated the effect of AMPK on the risk of psoriasis and its comorbidities and mortality among participants in the UK Biobank. The AMPK genetic risk score was associated with a 12.4% increase in the risk in men.

Genomic discovery and characterization of risk loci for type 2 diabetes (T2D) have been conducted primarily in individuals of European ancestry. We conducted a multiethnic genome-wide association study of T2D among 53,102 cases and 193,679 control subjects from African, Hispanic, Asian, Native Hawaiian, and European population groups. In individuals of African ancestry, we discovered a risk variant in the  TGFB1 gene (rs11466334, risk allele frequency (RAF) = 6.8%, odds ratio [OR] = 1.27, p = 2.06 Ã— 10 -8 ), which replicated in independent studies. We also identified amultiethnic risk variant of the BACE2 gene

Deep neural networks trained to predict morbidity risk from wearable sensor data can provide a high-quality and cheap alternative for BAA determination. The GeroSense BAA model was trained and validated using steps per minute recordings from 103,830 one-week long and 2,599 of up to 2 years-long longitudinal samples.

Liver function tests (LFTs) measure a series of complex traits that are affected by genetic and environmental factors. Previous studies demonstrated that there exist significant differences in LFTs across individuals, which may be the results of the unique genetic profile of each individual. We performed a genome-wide association study (GWAS) to evaluate the influence of single nucleotide polymorphisms (SNPs) in L FTs.

We conducted a genome-wide association study of the preference for whole versus skimmed milk. Mendelian randomization indicated that whole-milk preference significantly decreased the risk of inflammatory bowel disease ( &#946; =-1.735, P =0.048) Of the two subtypes, whole-Milk preference was associated with a lower risk of Crohn disease. But there was no significant effect on therisk of ulcerative colitis.

Angiotensin-converting enzyme (ACE) inhibitors and/or in combination with calcium channel blockers (CCBs) are generally recommended as the first-line antihypertensive therapy for people with hypertension and kidney dysfunction. We used published genetic variants in genes regulating target proteins of these drugs. We then applied a meta-analysis of the largest available genome-wide association studies of kidney function.

Genome-wide association meta-analysis (GWAMA) is an effective approach to enlarge sample sizes and empower the discovery of novel associations. Independent replication has been used as a gold-standard for validating genetic associations. We demonstrate using simulations that MAMBA is more powerful and robust than existing methods, and produces more accurate genetic effects estimates.

Deriving reliable information about the structural and functional architecture of the brain in vivo is critical for the clinical and basic neurosciences. Diffusion magnetic resonance imaging (dMRI) is a fertile imaging technique for probing and visualising brain tissue microstructure in vivo. We introduce Fast qualitY conTrol meThod foR derIved diffUsion Metrics (YTTRIUM) to evaluate diffusion map quality and mean diffusion metrics.

Homocysteine (Hcy) is a toxic amino acid and hyperhomocysteinemia (HHcy) was reported to be associated with both cerebrovascular disease and neurodegenerative disease. We extracted the genetic variants (SNPs) associated with plasma Hcy level from a large genome-wide association study (GWAS) meta-analysis.

Since pancreatic islets are central to type 2 diabetes (T2D), we profiled 15,298 islet cells by using combinatorial barcoding snATAC-seq. We cataloged 228,873 accessible chromatin sites and identified transcription factors underlying lineage- and state-specific regulation.

Genome-wide association studies (GWAS) and family-based studies have revealed partly overlapping genetic architectures between various psychiatric disorders. Given clinical overlap between disorders, our knowledge of the genetic architectures underlying specific symptom profiles and risk factors is limited. Here, we aimed to derive distinct profiles relevant to mental health in healthy individuals.

Serpin family A member 1 ( SERPINA1 ) Z allele is present in approximately one in 25 individuals of European ancestry. Z allele homozygosity (Pi*ZZ) is the most common cause of alpha 1-antitrypsin deficiency and is a proven risk factor for cirrhosis. In UK Biobank, we identified 1,493 cases of Cirrhosis, 12,603 Z allele heterozygotes, and 129 Zallee homozygotes among 312,671 unrelated white British participants.

Multiple sclerosis (MS) can be divided into four phenotypes based on clinical evolution. The pathophysiological boundaries of these phenotypes are unclear, limiting treatment stratification. Machine learning can identify groups with similar features using multidimensional data.

Dysregulation of the urea cycle has been detected in colorectal cancer (CRC) However, the impact of the UC's end product, urea, on CRC development remains unclear. We investigated the association between serum urea and CRC risk based on the data of 348 872 participants cancer-free at recruitment from the UK Biobank. Lower urea levels were associated with a higher CRC risk.

Short anagen hair (SAH) is a rare paediatric hair disorder. It is characterized by a short anagen phase, an inability to grow long scalp hair and a negative psychological impact. The genetic basis of SAH is currently unknown.

There were 398,146 participants without diabetes and 30,952 patients with diabetes from the UK Biobank cohort included in this study. After a median 12.90 years follow-up, 14,710 participants developed incident diabetes (58.83 +/- 7.52 years, 56.10% male) After multivariate adjustment, serum albumin was inversely associated with incident diabetes: hazard ratio (HR) per 10 g/l increase 0.88 [0.82;0.94].

A total of 285 009 participants free of CVD at baseline from the UK Biobank were included in this analysis. Four major cardiovascular admission events were identified: chronic ischaemic heart disease (CIHD), cerebrovascular disease, atrial fibrillation and heart failure. We observed significant associations between air pollution and both first admission and readmission for CVDs.

There is insufficient evidence to show that the guidelines' recommendations of physical activity are associated with long-term benefits in individuals with hypertension. MPA was inversely associated with risks of major adverse cardiovascular events and all-cause mortality. Modest amounts of LPA or VPA were likely to be more beneficial than higher amounts of either.

Body mass index (BMI) is an easily obtained adiposity surrogate. There is controversy regarding the BMI associated with the lowest mortality risk. Study used incident deaths from the UK Biobank (UKB; 2006-2022)

Genome-Wide Association Study of standard lipid measures using two approaches. 90 variants meet significance threshold only in the meta-analysis. 64 variants are significant only in pooled analysis. 20% of variants in each of those groups are most prevalent in non-European, non-Asian ancestry individuals.

Depression is often present concurrently with coronary artery disease (CAD), a disease with which it shares many risk factors. The manner in which depression mediates and moderates the association between traits (including biomarkers, anthropometric indicators, lifestyle behaviors, etc.) and CAD is largely unknown.

Elevated blood pressure (BP) is a modifiable risk factor associated with cognitive impairment and cerebrovascular diseases. However, the causal effect of BP on white matter brain aging remains unclear.

A 1 standard deviation higher genetically predicted plasma cortisol was associated with greater odds of hypertension. There was no evidence of association with type 2 diabetes, osteoporosis, depression and schizophrenia. The association with hypertension was attenuated upon adjustment for waist circumference, suggesting potential mediation through central obesity.

Lower eGFR, an indication of poor kidney function, was associated with higher RCC risk when measured up to 5 years prior to diagnosis. Markers of kidney function provided limited improvements in R CC risk discrimination beyond established risk factors.

About 416,258 participants without a prior CKD diagnosis enrolled in the UK Biobank between 2006 and 2010. At baseline, 33,156 (8.0%) participants were diagnosed with FGIDs, including 21,060 (5.1%) cases of IBS, dyspepsia, and other FIDs. During a mean follow-up period of 12.1 years, 11,001 (2.6%) participants developed CKD.

Sugar consumption was assessed in 186,622 UK Biobank participants with at least one web-based dietary questionnaire. Over a mean follow-up of 10.6 (standard deviation 1.1) years, 1498 incident dementia cases occurred. The intake of FS and intrinsic sugar was significantly associated with dementia risk.

Personality has recently emerged as a critical determinant for multiple health outcomes. However, evidence is less established for brain health, and the underlying mechanisms remain unclear. Five personality traits, including warmth, diligence, nervousness, sociability and curiosity, were constructed.

Sex hormones have been identified as cardiovascular risk factors. Relationship between sex hormones and the risk of arrhythmias in men has not yet been well studied in the prospective cohort study.

Study aimed to identify clustering of lifestyle risk behaviours and their 4 +/- year changes among UK adults with CVD. Smoking, high alcohol intake, poor fruit and vegetable consumption, physical inactivity, poor sleep balance ( 8 h/night) and prolonged sitting were assessed. Three latent classes emerged: LC1, LC2 and LC3.

Polygenic risk score (PRS) models are based on the evaluation of the additive effects attributable to common variants. In contrast, burden tests are often used to identify an enrichment of rare deleterious variants in specific genes. We applied our framework on UK Biobank dataset with genotyping and exome data and considered 28 blood biomarkers levels as target phenotypes.

Green and blue spaces were inversely associated with the hazard of NAFLD. The beneficial effects of approximately 25-52 % of green space exposure and about 5-35 % of blue space exposure were mediated by the reduction of PM 2.5 , NO 2 and NO x.

Leukocyte telomere length (LTL) is associated with a wide variety of diseases, including cancer. Findings regarding the association between LTL and the risk for lung cancer have been inconclusive and inconsistent across previous observational studies. This prospective cohort study included data from 425,146 participants.

Carriers of the 1q21.1 distal and 15q11.2 BP1-BP2 copy number variants exhibit regional and global brain differences compared with noncarriers. Intraindividual variability measures can be used to test for regional differences beyond global differences in brain structure.

The Positional Burrows-Wheeler Transform (PBWT) is a data structure that enables finding maximal haplotype matches in h sequences containing w variation sites in O(hw) time. The original PBWT data structure does not allow for queries over Biobank panels that consist of several millions of haplotypes.

The authors aimed to determine the risk of mortality and composite cardiomyopathy-related outcomes associated with predicted deleterious variants. They used whole exome sequencing data from the UK Biobank. CMP-G+ individuals had higher risk for all-cause mortality.

The data used in the study were obtained from the UK Biobank, a database that contains information collected from 502 389 participants between March 2006 and October 2010. Based on domestic and international guidelines for lung cancer screening and high-quality research literature, high-risk population identification criteria were determined. Cox proportional hazards regression was performed to identify 10 independent variables as predictors of lung cancer, including age, body mass index (BMI), education, income, physical activity, smoking status, alcohol consumption frequency, fresh fruit intake, family history of cancer, and tobacco exposure.

Physical activity (PA) and telomeres both contribute to healthy aging and longevity. To investigate the optimal dosage of various PA for longevity and the role of telomere length in PA and mortality, we analyzed 333,865 adults from the UK Biobank.

The Brain Health Index (BHI) is an automated approach to quantifying brain integrity. Normative values derived from generally healthy individuals provide a vital baseline for understanding neurodegenerative change. The scale and quality of the UK Biobank imaging cohort allows for derivation of such values.

Genetic studies of platelet reactivity (PR) phenotypes may identify novel antiplatelet drug targets. Such studies have been limited by small sample sizes (n)

Hidradenitis suppurativa (HS) is a common and severely morbid chronic inflammatory skin disease that is reported to be highly heritable. Few genome-wide association studies have been performed for HS, which have not identified significant risk loci. This genetic association study recruited 753 patients with HS in the HS Program for Research and Care Excellence.

Cancer meQTLs near known cancer genes were analyzed for association with cancer risk in the UKBioBank and prognosis in The Cancer Genome Atlas (TCGA) In TAD boundary regions, the density of cancer meQ TLs was higher near inactive TADs. Risk and survival-associated me QTLs tended to affect cancer genes involved in DNA damage repair and cellular adhesion.

We used 24 h PA time series from 96,351 UK Biobank participants aged between 42 and 79 years at accelerometry in 2013-2015. Four distinct fPCs accounted for 96% of the variation of the accelerometry data. Using a loading score of zero (i.e., average overall PA during the day) as the reference, a fPC1 score of + 2 was inversely associated with mortality.

Many sequence variants have additive effects on blood lipid levels and, through that, on the risk of coronary artery disease (CAD) We show that variants also have non-additive effects and interact to affect lipid levels as well as affecting variance and correlations. Variance and correlation effects are often signatures of epistasis or gene-environmental interactions.

Study of 140 214 unrelated UK Biobank (UKB) participants found that each of them carries a median of 7 variants previously reported as pathogenic or likely pathogenic. We focused on 967 diagnostic-grade gene (DGG) variants for rare bleeding, thrombotic, and platelet disorders. By association analysis, we estimated effect sizes for platelet count and volume.

Reaction time variability (RTV) has been proposed as an endophenotype for many neuropsychiatric disorders. There have been no large-scale genome-wide association studies (GWAS) of RTV and little is known about its genetic underpinnings. We used data from the UK Biobank to conduct a GWAS in participants of white British ancestry (n = 404,302) as well as a trans-ancestry GWAS meta-analysis.

Study aims to examine the association between the rest-activity rhythm (RAR) and the incidence of type 2 diabetes (T2D) 97 503 participants without diabetes in the UK Biobank cohort were recruited.

Daily-life gait speed, quantity and quality, derived from wrist-worn sensors, are significant predictors of injurious falls in older people. Digital gait biomarkers could potentially be used to identify fall risk in screening programs and integrated into fall prevention strategies.

Vigorous physical activity is a time-efficient way to achieve recommended physical activity (PA) for cancer prevention. But structured longer bouts of VPA (via traditional exercise) are unappealing or inaccessible to many individuals. This was a prospective cohort analysis of 22 398 self-reported nonexercising adults.

Longer leukocyte telomere length (LTL) is associated with a lower risk of adverse cardiovascular outcomes. The extent to which variation in LTL is. associated with intermediary cardiovascular phenotypes is unclear. Longer LTL was independently associated. with a pattern of positive cardiac remodeling (higher left ventricular mass, larger. global ventricular size and volume, and higher ventricular and atrial stroke volumes)

Inadequate representation of non-European ancestry populations in genome-wide association studies (GWAS) has limited opportunities to isolate functional variants. Fine-mapping in multi-ancestry populations should improve the efficiency of prioritizing variants for functional interrogation. Significant overlap in genetic causal variants across populations suggests generalizability of genetic mechanisms underpinning obesity-related traits.

Primary open-angle glaucoma (POAG) genetics could enable timely screening and promote individualized disease risk prognostication. This was a cross-sectional, population-based study conducted from 2006 to 2010.

Genetic factors are not included in prediction models for coronary heart disease (CHD) The authors assessed whether the risks due to monogenic familial hypercholesterolemia (FH) and family history (FamHx) are independent of and additive to the polygenic risk score (PRS)

Childhood adversity and lifestyle have been associated with frailty in later life. Not much is known about factors that may explain these associations. This study aims to investigate the association of childhood adversity and frailty, and the mediating role of unhealthy lifestyle in the association.

Germline pathogenic loss-of-function (pLOF) variants in DICER1 are associated with a predisposition for a variety of solid neoplasms, including pleuropulmonary blastoma and Sertoli-Leydig cell tumor (SLCT) Some patients with SLCT have no pLOF variants detected by germline or tumor testing.

Prioritizing genes for translation to therapeutics for common diseases has been challenging. We find 98 BEST genes for a variety of indications. Drugs targeting those genes are 3.8-fold more likely to be approved than non-BEST genes.

Nonalcoholic fatty liver disease (NAFLD) is a leading cause of chronic liver disease. NAFLD results from environmental exposures acting on a susceptible polygenic background. This study performed the largest multiethnic investigation of exonic variation associated with NAFLd and correlated metabolic traits and diseases.

Atherosclerotic cardiovascular disease (ASCVD) is considered the leading cause of mortality worldwide. Arterial stiffness, measured by arterial stiffness index (ASI), could be a main predictor in target damage of organs. Uncertainty remains regarding the contribution of ASI to estimated ASCVD risk.

Mendelian Randomization is a popular method to estimate causal effects in genomic studies. Recently, there has been much research in instrumental variable (IV) selection. In this paper, we focus on IV selection and adopt nonparametric variable selection approaches.

Genome-wide association studies (GWAS) are not fully comprehensive, as current strategies typically test only the additive model, exclude the X chromosome, and use only one reference panel. We implement an extensive GWAS strategy, GUIDANCE, which improves genotype imputation by using multiple reference panels.

 GWASs for atopic dermatitis have identified 25 reproducible loci. We attempt to prioritize the candidate causal genes at these loci using extensive molecular resources compiled into a bioinformatics pipeline. At eight loci, we were able to prioritize a single candidate gene.

Previous studies have investigated whether milk consumption has a role in preventing the development of cognitive impairment, but the results were inconsistent. This study aimed to examine the associations between different types of milk consumption and the risk of dementia. Of 307,271 participants included in the study, 3789 (1.2%) incident all-cause dementia cases were observed over a median follow-up of 12.3 years.

Protein-truncating variants (PTVs) affecting dyslipidemia risk may point to therapeutic targets for cardiometabolic disease. Our objective was to identify PTVs that were associated with both lipid levels and the risk of coronary artery disease (CAD) or type 2 diabetes (T2D)

There is no consensus about which single nucleotide polymorphisms must be investigated when properly assessing association between ABO locus and VT risk. Compared with the O1 haplotype, the A2 haplotype is associated with a modest increase in VT risk (odds ratio, &#8764;1.2) The A1 and B haplotypes are associated with an &# 8764; 1.8-fold increased risk, whereas the O2 tends to be slightly protective.

In this community-based cohort study, we investigated the relationship between combinations of modifiable lifestyle risk factors and infectious disease mortality. Participants were 468,569 men and women (56.5 +/- 8.1, 54.6% women) residing in the United Kingdom. Meeting public health guidelines or best practice recommendations was inversely associated with mortality.

Previous studies have failed to definitively establish a causal relationship between serum 25-hydroxyvitamin D (25OHD) concentrations and the onset of rosacea. This cross-sectional population-based cohort study utilizing 370,209 individuals from the UK Biobank.

Osteocytes are master regulators of the skeleton. We mapped the transcriptome of osteocytes from different skeletal sites, across age and sexes in mice to reveal genes and molecular programs that control this complex cellular-network. We showed osteocyte transcriptome signature genes are enriched for human orthologs that cause monogenic skeletal disorders.

Autism has previously been characterized by both structural and functional differences in brain connectivity. We introduce a technique of deriving symmetric similarity matrices from regional histograms of grey matter volumes estimated from T1-weighted MRIs. We then validated the technique by inputting the similarity matrix into a convolutional neural network (CNN) to classify between participants with autism and age-, motion-, and intracranial-volume-matched controls.

Multiple independently associated SNPs within a linkage disequilibrium region are a common phenomenon. Conditional analysis has been successful in identifying secondary signals. 'quasi-adaptive' method was applied to GWAS on free thyroxine (FT4), inflammatory bowel disease (IBD) and human height.

A polygenic risk score (PRS) derived from variants most associated with schizophrenia was increased 5-fold in individuals who experienced complications during pregnancy or birth. Follow-up gene expression analysis showed that the genes mapping to the most associated genetic variants are highly expressed in placental tissues. If confirmed, these findings will have major implications in our understanding of the joint effect of genes and environment in the pathogenesis of schizophrenia.
