Quantile regression provides a natural framework for modelling such heterogeneity. We propose a new method for inference on heterogeneous quantile treatment effects. Our estimator combines an &#8467;1-penalised regression adjustment with a quantile-specific bias correction scheme.

Advanced diffusion approaches allow for estimation of intra-axonal water fraction (AWF), describing a key structural characteristic of brain tissue. AWF can be interpreted as an indirect measure or proxy of neurite density and has a potential as useful clinical biomarker. Voxel-wise analysis revealed age-related differences in AWF-based brain asymmetry.

Telomere length (TL) is a biomarker of genomic aging. The evidence on the association between TL and air pollution was inconsistent. We aimed to evaluate the association of ambient air pollution with TL and further assess the modification effect of genetic susceptibility.

Among older adults, total and hospitalized infection may be associated with incidence of all-cause and Alzheimer's disease (AD) dementias, with variation by cardiovascular health (CVH) We used Cox proportional hazards (PH) models to examine the relationships between International Classification of Diseases-10th revision (ICD-10)-specific viral and bacterial infectious agents.

Short telomere length may be targeted by increased physical activity to reduce the risk of multiple aging-related diseases, including coronary heart disease. Data were from the UK Biobank participants with well-calibrated accelerometer data for at least 6.5 days (n = 54,180). Relative mean LTL at baseline (5-6 years prior to aPA assessment) was measured in T/S ratio, using a multiplex quantitative polymerase chain reaction (qPCR) technology.

Study included 18,092 individuals with type 2 diabetes from the UK Biobank. During a median follow-up of 12.1 years, 672 individuals (3.7%) were diagnosed with neuropathy. Any level of physical activity was associated with a lower risk of neuropathy and nephropathy but not retinopathy.

Almost one-third of participants reported sleeping shorter (24.7%) than age-corrected recommended sleep durations. The incidence of shorter or longer sleep increased with social deprivation and varied with ethnicity. Snoring, waking during the night, finding it difficult to get up in the morning and sleeping in the daytime were subject to similar effects.

Using UK Biobank (UKB) survey data, 472 397 participants who had not previously been diagnosed with cancer and whose self-reported sex was consistent with their genetic sex were studied. Information on prevalence of previous chronic lung diseases, general demographic characteristics and the prevalence of lung cancer was collected using baseline questionnaires and national health system data.

Higher ALAN exposure was associated with increased risk of mental disorders. The associations were stronger in participants with high iron deposition in left hippocampus, left accumbens and left pallidum.

Kidney dysfunction is associated with increased inflammation. Kidney function markers and C-reactive protein (CRP) were evaluated in the UK Biobank. Potassium was associated with endometrioid and clear cell tumors.

Systemic inflammation has been implicated in the etiology of selected neurodegenerative disorders, but its role in the development of amyotrophic lateral sclerosis is untested. We quantified the relationship of C-reactive protein (CRP), an acute-phase reactant and marker of systemic inflammation, with subsequent ALS occurrence.

74% of 245 genome-wide significant genetic associations with age at natural menopause show a form of age-specific effect. DNA damage response processes only act to shape ovarian reserve and depletion for women of early ANM. Genetically mediated delays in ANM were associated with increased relative risk of breast cancer and leiomyoma at all ages.

Sex steroid hormone fluctuations may underlie both reproductive disorders and sex differences in lifetime depression prevalence. Previous studies report high comorbidity among reproductive disorders. This study sought to assess whether this latent factor shares a common genetic architecture with female depression, including perinatal depression.

Study included 437,932 participants from the UK Biobank with a median follow-up period of over 10 years. Participants exposed to PM 2.5 levels of &#8805;10 &#956;g/m 3 had a higher risk of developing all-cause dementia (HR = 1.1; 95% CI: 1.05-1.28) On the other hand, participants exposed to NOx levels of&#8705;50 &#976;g-m 3  had a significantly higher risk.

The associations between hip/knee osteoarthritis (OA) and various psychiatry disorders remain unclear. Based on the community-based prospective data of UK Biobank, we constructed two matched cohorts to assess the bidirectional associations between OA and five common psychiatry disorders. Using GWAS summary statistics, we identified several shared genes and pathways, particularly the biological process related to HDAC histones. The findings of shared genetic architectures between knee Oa and depression/stress-related disorder provided possible targets for further mechanistic exploration and intervention development.

Current understanding of determinants for COVID-19-related cardiovascular and thromboembolic (CVE) complications primarily covers clinical aspects with limited knowledge on genetics and lifestyles. Here, we analysed a prospective cohort of 106,005 participants from UK Biobank with confirmed SARS-CoV-2 infection. We show that higher polygenic risk scores, indicating individual's hereditary risk, were linearly associated with increased risks.

Long-term exposures to PM 2.5 , PM 10 , NO 2 , and NO x were associated with increased BD risk. Associations were still observed and even stronger at pollutant concentrations lower than WHO air quality guideline. These findings could help inform policy makers regarding ambient air quality standards and BD management.

The association between serum calcium and COPD risk remains unclear. We included 386,844 participants with serum calcium measurements and without airway obstruction at the baseline from UK Biobank. Compared to participants with normal serum calcium, a 14% higher risk of COPD was observed in hypercalcemic participants.

We aimed to test the associations of sugar-sweetened beverages (SSB) with the risk of nonalcoholic fatty liver disease (NAFLD) Data for 136 277 UK Biobank participants who completed the dietary questionnaire and did not have a history of liver disease were included. Excessive consumption of ASBs was associated with an increased risk of incident hospitalized NAFLD.

A genome-wide meta-analysis of 100 studies in up to 835,465 individuals reveals 493 independent genetic variants in 352 loci, including 68 genetic variants outside previously identified resting heart rate associated loci. We prioritize 670 genes and in silico annotations point to their enrichment in cardiomyocytes and provide insights in their ECG signature. We do not find evidence for a linear or non-linear genetic association between resting heart rates and all-cause mortality.

Obesity is associated with type 2 diabetes mellitus and chronic low-grade inflammation. Although chronic inflammatory conditions and diabetes are associated with anaemia, less is known about associations of obesity and body shape, independent of each other, with erythrocyte and reticulocyte parameters.

Obesity contributes substantially to the global burden of disease and has a significant heritable component. We identified genes in which rare heterozygous loss-of-function increases adult BMI in women ( DIDO1, PTPRG,  and  SLC12A5 ) and in men ( SLTM ), with effect sizes up to &#8764;8 kg/m 2 . This is complemented by analyses implicating rare variants in OBSCN and MADD for recalled childhood adiposity.

Immune dysregulation has been widely observed in patients with psychiatric disorders. This study aims to examine the association between HLA alleles and depression and anxiety. HLA-A*02:07 Ã— cigarette smoking was associated with depression score. Sex stratification analysis revealed significant sex-based differences in the interaction effects of certain HLA.

Many diseases show patterns of co-occurrence, possibly driven by systemic dysregulation of underlying processes affecting multiple traits. We have developed a method (treeLFA) for identifying such multimorbidities from routine health-care data. We also show that treeLFA improves upon existing methods like latent Dirichlet allocation.

Study included 175 543 employed or self-employed workers who participated in the UK Biobank baseline survey (2006-2010) During a median (IQR) follow-up of 9.06 (8.35-9.75) years, 3956 workers (2.3%) developed depression and 2838 (1.7%) developed anxiety. Individuals who reported engaging in shift work, or shift workers, had a higher risk of depression.

Cross-sectional study jointly modeled parental and offspring polygenic scores (PGSs) across 9 traits to test for the association of genetic nurture with lifetime broad depression and neuroticism. A broad depression phenotype was measured in 38 702 offspring from 20 905 independent nuclear families.

Vitamin D deficiency is commonly associated with sarcopenia. The latest International Clinical Practice Guidelines for Sarcopenia do not recommend vitamin D supplementation. It remains unclear whether such suboptimal levels can maintain optimal health. Randomized clinical trials are required to verify the potential causality.

Previous research has shown associations between eczema and psoriasis and anxiety and depression. We investigated whether associations are consistent across different settings of ascertainment for depression and anxiety. We analysed 230,047 people with linked Biobank and primary care data.

Little is known about the association between pure fruit/vegetable juices and AD. This prospective cohort study of the UK Biobank included 206,606 participants aged 39-72 years free of dementia at baseline between 2006 and 2010. The consumption of SSBs and ASBs was associated with a higher risk of AD. However, participants who drank > 1-2 units/d of pure fruit and veg juices had a lower risk.

The evidence regarding the association between leucocyte telomere length (LTL) and brain health is sparse and inconclusive. LTL in the peripheral blood was measured by the quantitative polymerase chain reaction (qPCR) assay from 439 961 individuals in the UK Biobank recruited between 2006 and 2010.

The healthy aging index (HAI) has been recently developed as a surrogate measure of biological age. We aimed to quantify the association between the HAI and mortality in a population of UK adults. 387,794 middle-aged and older participants were followed up for a median of 8.9 years (IQR 8.3-9.5) A total of 14,112 all-cause deaths were documented.

The burden of depression and anxiety in the world is rising. Identification of individuals at increased risk of developing these conditions would help to target them for prevention and ultimately reduce the healthcare burden. If deployed in a digital solution, it would allow individuals to track their risk, as well as provide some pointers to how to decrease it.

Major histocompatibility (MHC) molecules are capable of presenting neoantigens resulting from somatic mutations on cell surfaces, potentially directing immune responses against cancer. This led to the hypothesis that cancer driver mutations may occur in gaps in MHC capacity. If this is correct, it has important implications for understanding oncogenesis.

Human same-sex sexual behaviour (SSB) is heritable, confers no obvious direct reproductive or survival benefit and can divert mating effort from reproductive opportunities. This presents a Darwinian paradox: why has SSB been maintained despite apparent selection against it? We show that genetic effects associated with SSB may confer a mating advantage.

There is considerable interest in GIPR agonism to enhance the insulinotropic and extrapancreatic effects of GIP, thereby improving glycemic and weight control in type 2 diabetes (T2D) and obesity. Recent genetic epidemiological evidence has implicated higher GIPr-mediated GIP levels in raising coronary artery disease (CAD) risk. We aimed to quantitatively assess whether the association between higher G IP levels and CAD risk is mediated via G IPR or is instead the result of linkage disequilibrium.

A large volume of clinical genomics data has become available due to rapid advances in sequencing technologies. Current resources providing disease-phenotype associations are not comprehensive. We developed a semi-automatic way to collect ICD-10-phenotypes associations from existing resources.

The prevalence of non-alcoholic fatty liver disease (NAFLD) is rapidly increasing worldwide due to the ongoing obesity epidemic. Currently the NALFD diagnosis requires non-readily available imaging technologies or liver biopsy. Here we utilized the large UK Biobank (UKB) to accurately estimate the NAFLD status in UKB based on common serum traits and anthropometric measures.

Osteoarthritis affects over 300 million people worldwide. We identify 100 independently associated risk variants across 11 osteoarth arthritis phenotypes, 52 of which have not been associated with the disease before. We provide evidence for genetic correlation with phenotypes related to pain, the main disease symptom.

Evidence from observational studies suggests a positive association between serum thyroid-stimulating hormone (TSH) levels and differentiated thyroid carcinoma. Using Mendelian randomization (MR) methodology, this study aimed to investigate the causal role of TSH in both benign thyroid nodules and thyroid cancer. We observed evidence of an inverse association between TSH levels and both thyroid cancer and benign nodular thyroid disease.

Tea drinkers were 16% (95% confidence interval: 8-23) less likely to develop dementia compared with non-drinkers. Moderate consumption (1-6 cups/day) exerted significant protective effects.

Albuminuria was associated with worse performance on tasks of verbal-numeric reasoning. Interaction between kidney function markers and a polygenic risk score for general cognitive function was assessed.

Healthy lifestyle factors included no/moderate alcohol consumption, no smoking, physical activity, and a healthy diet. Over the follow-up (median: 12.1 years), 6206 participants developed gout. Compared to low genetic risk, the hazard ratios (HRs) and 95% confidence intervals (CIs) of gout was 1.44 for middle and 1.77 for high genetic risk.

 TOP-LD is an online tool to explore LD inferred with high-coverage (&#8764;30Ã—) WGS data from 15,578 individuals in the NHLBI Trans-Omics for Precision Medicine (TOPMed) program. It offers 2.6- to 9.1-fold increase in variant coverage compared to HaploReg 4.0 or LDlink. In addition, TOP- LD includes tens of thousands of structural variants (SVs)

UK Biobank is a prospective cohort study of around half-a-million general population participants, recruited between 2006 and 2010. From 2014 to date, magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) has been pursued in a participant sub-sample, with the aim to scan around n  = 100k. This sub- sample is studied widely and therefore understanding its relative characteristics is important for future reports.

The association between severe mental illness (SMI) and cardiovascular and metabolic disease (CMD) is poorly understood. PCSK9 is expressed in systems critical to both SMI and CMD and influences lipid homeostasis and brain function. We used genetic data from white British ancestry individuals of UK Biobank.

Genotype imputation is an integral tool in genome-wide association studies. In principle, combining all sequenced whole genomes into a single large panel would provide the best imputation performance. Here, we describe a method that allows imputation results generated using different reference panels to be combined into a consensus imputed dataset.

Nuclear magnetic resonance (NMR) profiling was undertaken on baseline plasma samples in 65,684 UK Biobank participants without diabetes and not taking lipid-lowering medication. 90 metabolic biomarkers showed independent associations with T2D risk among 50,519 participants.

 Epistasis has recently emerged as one of the intrinsic mechanisms that could explain part of this missing heritability. We conducted epistasis analysis for genome-wide body mass index (BMI) associated SNPs in Alzheimer's Disease Neuroimaging Initiative (ADNI) and followed up top significant interacting SNPs for replication.

Resting-state functional magnetic resonance imaging (rs-fMRI) has been successfully employed to understand the organisation of the human brain. The brain is parcellated into regions of interest (ROIs) and modelled as a graph where each ROI represents a node and association measures between ROI-specific blood-oxygen-level-dependent (BOLD) time series are edges.

A common G risk allele in the melatonin receptor 1B (MTNR1B, rs10830963) gene has been associated with altered melatonin signaling and secretion. Given that melatonin possesses anticancerogenic properties, we hypothesized that breast and prostate cancer risks vary by the genotype. A total of 216 702 participants from the UK Biobank without cancer at baseline were included.

Cohort studies report inconsistent associations between body mass index (BMI) and all-cause incident dementia. Evidence on fat distribution and body composition measures is scarce. Few studies estimated the association between early life adiposity and dementia risk.

Many risk factors have emerged for novel 2019 coronavirus disease (COVID-19) It is relatively unknown how these factors collectively predict infection risk, as well as risk for a severe infection. Among aged adults (69.3 +/- 8.6 years) in UK Biobank, data was downloaded for 4510 participants.

Study aimed to systematically examine the women-specific temporal pattern (trajectory) of the disease network. UK Biobank study, 502,650 participants entered the cohort from 2006 to 2010, and were followed up until 2019.

 gene Ã— environment (GÃ—E) research deploys a limited toolkit on the genetic side to study the gene-environment interplay. In this article, we develop a genetic summary measure better suited for GÃ—E research: variance polygenic scores (vPGSs)

Whether driving and computer use are associated with the risk of dementia in older adults is an important research question. Participants of a longitudinal cohort study that included European middle- and old-aged adults at the baseline (2006-2010) who had not been diagnosed with dementia before 5 years after the baseline were followed up.

Several candidate genes have been proposed to explain variation in well-being. These candidate gene and candidate gene-by-environment interaction studies have been surrounded by controversy. In the present study, we review the existing candidate gene literature for well- Being. We find no support for any of the candidate genes.

Aberrant sleep parameters are associated with the risk of nonalcoholic fatty liver disease (NAFLD) However, existing information is inconsistent among studies and involves reverse causation. We aimed to investigate the observational associations and causations between sleep traits and NAFLD.

We present the results of a GWAS of food liking conducted on 161,625 participants from the UK-Biobank. Liking was assessed over 139 specific foods using a 9-point scale. Genetic correlations coupled with structural equation modelling identified a multi-level hierarchical map of food-liking.

The role of fish oil in the prognosis of hypertensive patients is unknown. This study investigated the associations of. fish oil supplementation with the progression of cardiometabolic multimorbidity (CMM) and. mortality among patients with hypertension.

We assigned 329,908 UK Biobank participants into six subgroups based on a self-organizing map of 51 biochemical measures. The subgroup with the most favorable metabolic traits was chosen as the reference. Multimorbidity was enriched in metabolically favorable subgroups despite lower disease burden overall.

Lifestyle intervention is important for the treatment of liver diseases. A higher overall lifestyle score was associated with a significantly lower SLD risk (P trend) In European individuals, a healthy lifestyle is associated. with a lower risk of incident SLD.

UK Biobank study included 479,650 participants with data available for supplement use and without HF at baseline. In multivariable analysis, the HR of glucosamine users for HF was 0.87 (95% CI, 0.81 to 0.94). The inverse associations were stronger in males and participants with unfavorable lifestyle.

Single nucleotide polymorphisms (SNPs) could be potentially useful to construct polygenic risk scores (PRSs) for kidney disease. Increased albuminuria indicates underlying glomerular pathology and is associated with worse renal disease outcomes. Many SNPs are associated with UACR or renal injury, suggesting a role in kidney dysfunction.

A study was conducted from 53,363 healthy participants in the UK Biobank survey to determine predicted ASI. Stiffness index was applied on 49,452 hypertensives without CV diseases to discriminate determinants of positive stiffness index from negative index.

Study used a novel clustering algorithm to identify robust subtypes of type 2 diabetes. Five distinct T2D clusters were identified in the UK Biobank and validated in the All of Us cohort. With a median follow-up of 11.69 years, risks of incident CVD events varied considerably between the clusters.

Study examined associations of in utero tobacco smoke exposure, age of smoking initiation, and their interaction with genetic risk levels with cancer incidence in 393,081 participants from the UK Biobank. The relative risk of incident cancer increased with earlier smoking initiation.

Many complex diseases share common genetic determinants and are comorbid in a population. We hypothesized that the co-occurrences of diseases and their overlapping genetic etiology can be exploited to simultaneously improve multiple diseases' polygenic risk scores (PRS) This hypothesis was tested using a multi-task learning (MTL) approach based on an explainable neural network architecture.

White matter hyperintensities (WMHs) are a major risk factor for stroke and dementia. It has been debated how much risk is accounted for by conventional cardiovascular risk factors (CVRFs) Only 32% of the variance in WMH volume was explained by measures of CVRFs, sex, and age.

Uticaria is a skin disorder characterized by outbreaks of raised pruritic wheals. We found nine sequence variants at nine loci associating with urticaria. The variants are at genes participating in type 2 immune responses and/or mast cell biology.

Study included 114,289 cancer-free participants with at least two dietary assessments. The derived-DP was characterized by a higher intake of beer and cider, processed meat, high sugar beverages, red meat, and artificial sweetener. A higher obesity-related DP Z-score was linearly associated with an increased risk of overall cancer.

Long-term exposure to PM2.5 (per 5-&#956;g/m3 increase) was significantly associated with AST (0.596% increase, 95% CI, 0.414 to 0.778%) Significant modification effects by alcohol consumption were found (P-interaction)

Previous studies suggest that air pollution can increase the risk of incident chronic kidney disease (CKD) However, the association between end-stage kidney disease and co-exposure to relatively low-level air pollutants remains unclear. A prospective cohort was designed based on UK Biobank from 1 January 2010 to 12 November 2021.

Statins are widely used for cardiovascular disease prevention but their effects on cognition remain unclear. We used participants from the UK biobank aged 40-69 without neurological and psychiatric disorders. Statin use was associated with lower cognitive performance at baseline.

Previous studies have linked higher body mass index (BMI) to lower subjective well-being in adult European ancestry populations. However, our understanding of these relationships across different populations is limited. Here, we investigated the association between BMI and well being in people of (a) East Asian and (b) European ancestry.

 quantification of visceral adipose tissue (VAT) has become increasingly important in risk assessment for cardiovascular and metabolic diseases. Differences exist in the accuracy of various modalities, with a lack of up-to-date comparison with three-dimensional whole volume assessment. We evaluated the correlation of various commonly used modalities and techniques namely body impedance analysis (BIA), dual-energy x-ray absorptiometry (DXA) as well as single slice CT.

Data were obtained from the UK Biobank, comprising 497,503 adults. At baseline, 70.5% of participants reported drinking &#8805;1 cups/d coffee. After adjusting for potential confounders, we identified a nonlinear J-shaped association between coffee consumption and HF risk.

Study looked at relationship of variety and duration of different sedentary behaviors with the risk of dementia. 173,829 older participants without prior dementia in the UK Biobank were enrolled. During a median follow-up of 12.4 years, 4965 participants developed new-onset dementia.

The World Health Organization proposed the concept of intrinsic capacity (IC) as central for healthy ageing. Little research has investigated the interaction and joint associations of IC with cardiovascular disease (CVD) incidence and CVD mortality in middle and older-aged adults.

The relevance of race and ethnicity to genetics and medicine has long been a matter of debate. Race and ethnicity can be used to stratify pharmacogenomic risk in the US and UK populations and should not be discounted when making treatment decisions.

Pancreatitis patients were identified through national hospital and mortality records across the United Kingdom. Genotyped data that included 35 SNPs were assessed for independent associations with SAP. Male sex and older age increased odds of developing SAP.

Circadian rhythms are crucial for regulating physiological and behavioral processes. Pineal hormone melatonin is often used to measure circadian amplitude but its collection is costly and time-consuming. Wearable activity data are promising alternative.

 Shape reconstruction from sparse point clouds/images is a challenging and relevant task required for a variety of applications in computer vision and medical image analysis. We propose a deep learning architecture, coined Mesh Reconstruction Network (MR-Net), which tackles this problem. MR-Net enables accurate 3D mesh reconstruction in real-time despite missing data.

Model-X knockoffs is a general procedure that can leverage any feature importance measure to produce a variable selection algorithm. This article introduces a derandomization method by aggregating the selection results across multiple runs of the knockoffs algorithm. When applied to the base procedure of Janson and Su, we prove that derandomized knockoffs controls both the per family error rate and the k family-wise error rate.

Diseases were identified using questionnaires, nurses' interviews, or inpatient data. Mortality register data were used to identify mortality up to January 2021. 37 diseases including cancers and heart diseases were associated with an increased risk of mortality independent of other diseases (hazard ratio ranged from 1.09 to 7.77)

With the increasing size and number of genome-wide association studies, individual single nucleotide polymorphisms are increasingly found to associate with multiple traits. Many different mechanisms could result in proposed genetic IVs for an exposure of interest being associated with multiple non-exposure traits, some of which could bias MR results. We highlight the pros and cons of relying on sensitivity analyses without considering particular pleiotropic paths.

Patients with established Parkinson's disease display differences in blood biomarkers of immune function. These may be useful biomarkers to predict PD and inform pathogenesis. We examined the relationship between incident PD and baseline leukocyte differential count in UK Biobank. Lower lymphocyte count was associated with increased risk of PD diagnosis.

Study population included 499,830 UK Biobank participants without schizophrenia and bipolar disorder at baseline. Type 1 and type 2 diabetes and depression were identified using self-reported diagnoses. Mortality was identified from death records using the primary cause of death.

UK Biobank participants (46.9% men, mean age 55 years) with data on early markers of CVD risk (n=12 706) were followed longitudinally (2014-2020; mean 8.4 years) Two DPs (DP1, DP2) were derived using reduced rank regression. DP1 was positively correlated with saturated fat, monounsaturated fat, and polyunsaturated fat. DP2 (characterized by higher butter and high-fat cheese, lower nuts and seeds intake) was associated with slightly higher odds of elevated CVB risk.

Job attainment is an important component of socioeconomic status (SES) There is a paucity of genomic research on an individual's job attainment. By incorporating O*NET occupational information into the UK Biobank database, we performed GWAS analyses of six major job attainment characteristics.

Little is known about the links between long-term exposure to air pollution and risk of incident microvascular disease (retinopathy, peripheral neuropathy, and chronic kidney disease) This study included 396 014 UK residents free of microv vascular disease and macrovascular diseases at baseline. Annual means of PM 2.5 , PM 2-10 , PM 10 , NO 2 , and NO  x   were assessed by land use regression models.

Study included 373,026 individuals of European ancestry without prevalent CHD/stroke from UK Biobank data. TV viewing and computer use were assessed through touch-screen questionnaires. Compared with &#8805;4h/day of TV viewing, the hazard ratio of CHD was 0.84. CHD hazards were higher for medium and high genetic risk.

Hypertrophic cardiomyopathy (HCM) is the most common genetic cardiovascular disorder. There is substantial interest in the use of real-world data, such as electronic health records, to better understand disease mechanisms and discover new treatment strategies. We identified two novel, non-sarcomeric genetic variants in KMT2C and PARD3B that were associated with HCM diagnosis.

Genetic fine-mapping revealed both shared and distinct causal variation between COA and AOA in the class I region. Both gene expression levels and amino acid variation contributed to risk. The HLA-DQA1*03:01 allele accounted entirely for the most significant association with AOA. A convergence of genomic, transcription, and protein coding evidence implicates the Hla-D QA2 and HLA DQA2 genes in AOA and the HLA C protein coding variation in COA.

Quantitative susceptibility mapping (QSM) is an emerging magnetic resonance imaging technique that measures tissue magnetic susceptibility. We present an open resource of QSM-based imaging measures of multiple brain structures in 35,273 individuals from the UK Biobank.

Parents pass on both their genes and environment to offspring, prompting debate about the relative importance of nature versus nurture in the inheritance of complex traits. Advances in molecular genetics now make it possible to quantify an individual's genetic predisposition to a trait via his or her 'polygenic score'

 venous thromboembolism (VTE) is associated with increased mortality. The combined effects of adopting multiple healthy lifestyles have not been firmly demonstrated. This study was to evaluate the association of combined healthy lifestyles and genetic risk factors with VTE.

No population-based cohort study investigated a potential inverse association between long-term low-dose acetylsalicylic acid (ASA) use and all-cause dementia. Strongest protective effect of ASA was observed in participants with coronary heart disease (CHD) in both cohorts.

This study was conducted in people with gout from the UK Biobank. Logistic regression was used to examine the association between self-reported physician-diagnosed hypertension, diabetes, hypercholesterolemia and ischaemic heart disease. High eGFR associated with urate raising allele at rs2231142. The SNP in ADH1B that protects from alcohol excess showed a negative association with IHD.

Moderate alcohol consumption is widespread but its impact on brain structure and function is contentious. Relationship between alcohol intake and structural and functional neuroimaging indices remain unclear. 25,378 UK Biobank participants underwent multi-modal MRI 9.6 +/- 1.1 years after study baseline. Alcohol use was self-reported at baseline (2006-10)

Enlargement of the aorta is an important risk factor for aortic aneurysm and dissection. We identified lead variants across 41 loci, including genes related to cardiovascular development. A polygenic score significantly predicted prevalent risk of thoracic aortesm and need for surgical intervention.

High consumption of dietary fibre was associated with a lower risk of IBD, Crohn's disease (CD) and ulcerative colitis (UC) The findings support current recommendations to increase the intake of Dietary fibre.

UK Biobank cohort study participants provided a full week of accelerometer-based physical activity data. Physical activity concentrated within 1 to 2 days was associated with similarly lower risk of cardiovascular outcomes to more evenly distributed activity. Findings were consistent at the median threshold of 230.4 minutes or more of MVPA per week.

The iron overload disorder hemochromatosis is primarily caused by the homozygous  HFE  p.C282Y variant. The scale of excess related musculoskeletal morbidity is uncertain. A total of 451,143 European ancestry participants (40 to 70 years at baseline) were followed in hospital records (mean 11.5-years) Cox proportional hazards models estimated HFE and p.H63D associations with incident outcomes.

Mediterranean-style, Dietary Approaches to Stop Hypertension (DASH) and plant-based diets were scored. Greatest ultra-processed food consumption was associated with a significant increase in AF risk.

Study looked at relationship between body fat distribution and risk of cardiometabolic and microvascular events among individuals with prediabetes or diabetes with normal body mass index (BMI) Participants with central obesity defined by WHR had 27%-54% higher risk of incident all-cause mortality, cardiovascular mortality, myocardial infarction and stroke.

Low birth weight, being thinner and changing to have a thinner body size in childhood are associated with higher risks of developing multimorbidity and many chronic conditions in adulthood. Early monitoring and maintaining a normal body size could have life-course benefits for preventing chronic diseases.

Polyneuropathy was significantly associated with all-cause and cardiovascular mortality. Metabolic parameters HbA 1c , waist circumference, BMI and the inflammatory parameter C-reactive protein showed significant mediation effects. Adherence to a favorable lifestyle was associated with a lower risk of death.

Study included data from 43 930 participants of the large UK Biobank cohort. Using official ICD10 diagnosis, we selected 712 participants with migraine, 1 853 with depression and 23 942 healthy controls. We estimated mean volumetric difference between the groups using generalized linear regression models.

Data suggest that various dietary interventions slow kidney disease progression and improve clinical outcomes for those with chronic kidney disease (CKD) However, the association between plant protein intake and incident CKD has been uncertain. Using the UK Biobank Study data, we found that participants with a higher plantprotein intake had a lower risk of developing CKD.

Meat-free diets may be associated with a higher risk of hip fracture, but prospective evidence is limited. In the UK Biobank, occasional meat-eaters, pescatarians, and vegetarians were compared to regular meat- eaters. Among 413,914 women, 3503 hip fractures were observed. After adjustment for confounders, vegetarians (HR (95% CI): 1.50 (1.18, 1.91)) had a greater risk.

Evidence linking glucose metabolism status with brain macro- and microstructure is limited and inconsistent. This study enrolled 29 251 participants from the UK Biobank. Glucose metabolism status was classified into normal glucose metabolism (NGM), prediabetes, type 2 diabetes (T2D) with HbA1c.

Lipoproteins are well-established risk factors for cardiovascular disease (CVD) mortality. But conventional measurements failed to identify lipoprotein particle sizes. This study aimed to investigate associations of lipop protein subclasses categorized by particle sizes with risk of all-cause and CVD mortality in individuals with type 2 diabetes.

Low-to-moderate nut consumption was associated with a 17% lower risk of depression during a 5.3-year follow-up compared with no nut consumption. This protective association is enhanced in the absence of other known risk factors for depression.

A total of 35,550 participants (55.6% females) with a mean age 56.8 +/- 8.04 years were included in the study. Participants were stratified into 7 different body composition groups based on BMI and WC. Individuals in the Overweight/High WC, Mild obesity/ high WC and Severe obesity/high WC groups were associated with an increase in the retinal age gap, compared with those in the Normal Weight/Normal WC group.

Both unhealthy lifestyle factors and ambient air pollution have been closely linked with the risk of atrial fibrillation (AF) We retrieved 250,898 participants without AF at baseline from UK Biobank. Participants with moderate and high CVH showed a decreased risk of incident AF compared to those with low CVH.

Neuroticism is a major risk factor for neurodegenerative disorders, such as Alzheimer's disease and related dementias. This study investigates whether neuroticism is associated with white matter hyperintensities.

Mood and other mental health status may be associated with the development of dementia. A comprehensive mood index that reflects the overall mood status and dementia risk is lacking. We examined the relationship between mood index, sleep duration and dementia in 429,761 participants.

A total of 166,377 UK Biobank participants without dementia at baseline were analyzed. Brain structural anatomy and tissue-specific volumes were measured using brain MRI. The incidence of all-cause dementia increased by 4.6% for each additional unit of DII. DII displayed a "J-shaped" non-linear association with Alzheimer's dementia.

Of 436,990 participants included in the study who were cancer-free at baseline, 21.6% (99,965) were multi-morbid (&#8805; 2 diseases) Over a median follow-up time of 10.9 [IQR 10.0-11.7] years, 9,019 prostate, 7,994 breast, 5,241 colorectal, and 3,591 lung cancers were diagnosed.

Study looked at data from 48,515 participants with prediabetes and 24,393 participants with diabetes from the UK Biobank. Annual pollution data were collected for fine particulate matter (PM 2.5), inhalable particulates (PM 10), nitrogen dioxide (NO 2 ), and nitrogen dioxides (NO x ) during 2006-2021. Reducing air pollution levels would significantly benefit this vulnerable population by reducing the incidence of mental disorders.

Study included 250,312 women aged 40-69 years between 2006 and 2010 from the UK Biobank cohort. We found no overall association between diabetes and BCa risk. However, there was a significantly increased risk of BCa in the short time window after T2D diagnosis.

Few investigations have been performed between tobacco smoking, alcohol, and arterial stiffness. 98 039 individuals of the UK Biobank cohort were included (45 457 men and 52 582 women) ASI levels were higher in men than in women (9.91 vs. 8.71 m/s)

Evidence concerning intakes of protein or sources of dairy protein and risks of colorectal, breast, and prostate cancers is inconclusive. Using a subsample of UK Biobank participants, we estimated intakes of total protein, protein from total dairy products, milk, and cheese, and dietary calcium in 114,217 participants. After a median of 9.4 years of follow-up, 1193 coloreCTal, 2024 female breast and 2422 prostate cancer cases were identified.

The UK Biobank is a national prospective cohort study that recruited 502,505 participants aged 40-69 years between 2006 and 2010. During a median follow-up of 8.9 years, 27,394 (6.3%) developed CVD. The frequency of depressive symptoms increased the risk of CVD according to low, moderate, high, and very high frequency.

The study retrieved data from 402,042 participants who were free of IPF at baseline in the UK Biobank. The annual mean concentration of ambient SO 2 was estimated for each participant based on their residential addresses. The results indicated that each 1 &#956;g/m 3 increase in ambient SO2 was associated with a hazard ratio (HR) (95% confidence interval [CI]) of 1.67.

Cognitive ability is a strong predictor of occupational achievement, quality of life and physical health. Little is known about how these factors combine and interact to explain variation in cognition. We modelled the relationship between common genetic variation, grey matter volume, early life adversity and education and cognitive ability in a UK Biobank sample of N = 5237 individuals.

Exclusive use of cars was associated with a relatively higher risk of CHD across all strata of genetic susceptibility. There was, in general, no strong evidence of interactions between genetic susceptibility and categories of overall, non-commuting and commuting transport.

We conducted a prospective analysis of 281,280 UK Biobank participants. Compared with workers who never/rarely worked night shifts, those who worked some night shifts or usual/permanent night shifts were 1.12 and 1.27 times more likely to develop NAFLD, respectively. Those with a longer duration, a higher frequency, more consecutive night shifts and a longer length per shift all showed higher risks of incidentNAFLD.

Grip strength is commonly used to identify weakness. We aimed to investigate if total and central adiposity are causally associated with grip strength. We explored whether associations varied by age, by examining age-stratified associations.

Diet is considered as one of the most important modifiable factors influencing human health. Efforts to identify foods or dietary patterns associated with health outcomes often suffer from biases, confounding, and reverse causation. Applying Mendelian randomization in this context may provide evidence to strengthen causality in nutrition research.

Multicollinearity can hinder inference in environmental health research. An alternative approach to address this problem is the use of principal component analysis. This combines and projects a group of correlated variables onto a new orthogonal space. The study was conducted in a cohort of 379,690 individuals in the UK.

We identified 53/c loci affecting hearing loss risk, including common coding variants in COL9A3 and TMPRSS3. Through exome sequencing of 108,415 cases and 329,581 controls, we observed rare coding associations with 11 Mendelian hearing loss genes. Our results suggest a shared etiology between Mendelians and common hearing loss in adults.

Study involved 493,774 participants from the UK Biobank. 4701 incident CM cases were documented among participants with none cardiometabolic disease at baseline. Compared with the fourth quartile (Q4), the multivariable adjusted HR (95% CI) value of Q1 of HGS for developing CM was 1.46 (1.34-1.60) HGS was also associated with the risk of all-cause mortality.

We identified genetic variants associated with lipid species putatively in the mechanistic pathway for coronary artery disease (CAD) We quantified 596 lipid species in serum from 4,492 individuals from the Busselton Health Study. We identified 134 lipid endophenotypes for CAD associated with 186 genomic loci.

In this paper, we propose a new approach for variable selection using a collection of Bayesian neural networks. Motivated by fine-mapping applications in statistical genetics, we refer to our framework as an "ensemble of single-effect neural networks"

The extent of shared and distinct neural mechanisms underlying major depressive disorder (MDD), anxiety, and stress-related disorders is still unclear. We compared the neural signatures of these disorders in 5,405 UK Biobank patients and 21,727 healthy controls. Found the greatest case-control differences in resting-state functional connectivity and cortical thickness in MDD.

Study looked at 462,619 participants in the UK Biobank cohort. Social isolation was associated with a 1.26-fold increased risk of dementia. 75% of this relationship was attributable to depressive symptoms.

Children with obesity typically have larger left ventricular heart dimensions during adulthood. Whether this is due to a persistent effect of adiposity extending into adulthood is challenging to disentangle due to confounding factors throughout the lifecourse. Strong evidence of a genetically predicted effect of childhood body size on all measures of adulthood heart structure was identified.

Hernias are characterized by protrusion of an organ or tissue through its surrounding cavity and often require surgical repair. In this study we identify 65,492 cases for five hernia types in the UK Biobank and perform genome-wide association study scans for these five types and two combined groups.

We conducted the largest genome-wide association study (GWAS) of circulating PUFA to date including a sample of 114,999 individuals. We used Mendelian randomization to investigate the involvement of PUFA on a wide range of CVDs in up to 1,153,768 individuals of European ancestry. Higher genetically predicted DHA (and total omega-3 fatty acids) concentration was related to higher risk of some cardiovascular endpoints, but these findings did not pass our criteria for multiple testing correction.

Many rare monogenic diseases are known to be caused by deleterious variants in thousands of genes. The same variants can also be found in people without the associated clinical phenotypes. We used UK Biobank to investigate phenotypes associated with rare protein-truncating and missense variants in 599 monoallelic DDG2P genes.

Growth differentiation factor 15 (GDF-15) levels have been revealed as a robust biomarker for metformin use. We conducted Mendelian randomization (MR) analysis to explore the association between G DF-15 and gallstone disease. Four genetic variants associated with GDF- 15 levels were selected as instrumental variables from a genome-wide association meta-analysis including 21,758 individuals.

 Reduced glomerular filtration rate (GFR) can progress to kidney failure. Risk factors include genetics and diabetes mellitus (DM), but little is known about their interaction. We conducted genome-wide association meta-analyses for estimated GFR based on serum creatinine (eGFR), separately for individuals with or without DM.

Sleep, physical activity and sedentary behavior have been found to be associated with dementia risk. However, findings are inconsistent and their joint relationship remains unclear. This study aimed to investigate independent and joint associations of these three modifiable behaviors with dementia risks. A total of 431,924 participants without dementia from UK Biobank were included.

Study used data from 425 043 participants from the UK Biobank. An 80-variant LDL-C weighted genetic score was generated. We found that the genetically increased LDL- C effect on CVD events was sex specific. We also observed attenuated risks for ischemic heart disease and heart failure.

We used genotyping data and exome sequencing data of unrelated European individuals in the UK Biobank. We found that genetically proxied inhibition of the HMGCR gene mimicking long-term statin treatment associated with higher risk of cataract. Clinical trials with longer follow-up are needed to confirm these findings.

Recurrent copy-number variations (CNVs) at chromosome 16p11.2 are associated with neurodevelopmental diseases, skeletal system abnormalities, anemia, and genitourinary defects. Among the 40 protein-coding genes encompassed within the rearrangement, some have roles in leukocyte biology and immunodeficiency.

The UK Biobank is a major open access resource. We present a protocol to efficiently integrate the main dataset and record-level data files. We use an R package named "ukbpheno" to process the data.

Hormone-related cancers, including cancers of the breast, prostate, ovaries, uterine, and thyroid, globally contribute to the majority of cancer incidence. We show that considering hormone-sensitive cancers as a single disease in the UK Biobank reveals shared genetic aetiology.

Mendelian randomization (MR) has emerged as one of the foremost methods to efficiently interrogate diverse hypotheses using large-scale, observational data from biobanks. Most approaches implicitly assume that any putative causal effect is linear. We propose PolyMR, an MR-based method that provides a polynomial approximation of an (arbitrary) causal function between an exposure and an outcome.

 Depression and psychosis are often comorbid; they also have overlapping genetic and environmental risk factors, including trauma and area-level exposures. The present study aimed to advance understanding of this comorbridity via a network approach. It identified bridge nodes that connect clusters of lifetime depression and psychosis symptoms.

Arterial stiffness (AS), measured by arterial stiffness index (ASI), is a determinant in cardiovascular (CV) diseases. High serum uric acid (SUA) level is a known risk factor for CV disease. Authors investigated the relationship between SUA and ASI in the middle-age UK Biobank population study.

Physical inactivity increases the risk of chronic disease and mortality. The high prevalence of physical inactivity in the UK is likely to increase financial pressure on the National Health Service. We assessed the associations between objectively measured physical activity levels and future inpatient days and costs in UK Biobank study.

Associations of sex steroids and their binding proteins with body shape are unclear. waist and hip circumference are correlated strongly with body size. We defined body shape using "a body shape index" (ABSI) and hip index (HI) We examined associations in multivariable generalised linear models for the UK Biobank cohort.

Alzheimer's disease (AD) is the most common form of dementia and the leading risk factor, after age, is possession of the apolipoprotein E epsilon 4 allele (APOE4) Approximately 50% of AD patients carry one or two copies of APOE4 but the mechanisms by which it confers risk are still unknown.

Genetic ancestry (GA) is more strongly associated with creatinine levels among healthy individuals than self-identified ethnicity. Black ethnicity shows a positive effect on participant serum creat inine levels. African ancestry has the highest association. GA (9.06%) explains significantly more of the variation in creatinin levels than ethnicity.

New therapies may help to prevent osteoporotic fractures other than increasing bone mineral density (BMD) Because fracture risk has an important genetic component, we aim to identify loci increasing fracture risk that do not decrease BMD. We found that only three loci affecting fracture risk exhibited genetic effects not mediated by BMD: SOST, CPED1-WNT16, and RSPO3.

Food-based dietary patterns (DPs) can help target specific combinations of foods that are associated with disease risk. Most high-income countries including the UK are far from reaching the dietary intakes which are recommended for good health.

Machine learning (ML) holds promise for precision psychiatry, but its predictive performance is unclear. We assessed whether ML provided added value over logistic regression for prediction of schizophrenia. We compared models built using polygenic risk scores (PRS) or clinical/demographic factors.

The intestinal hormone, glucose-dependent insulinotropic polypeptide (GIP), is involved in important physiological functions. While mutations leading to physiological changes can be identified in large-scale sequencing, no systematic investigation of GIP missense variants has been performed. Here, we identified 168 naturally occurring variants in the human GIP genes.

The inherited basis of fat distribution in the general population is not fully understood. We study up to 38,965 UK Biobank participants with MRI-derived visceral (VAT), abdominal subcutaneous (ASAT), and gluteofemoral (GFAT) adipose tissue volumes. We identify 250 independent common variants (39 newly-identified) associated with at least one trait.

Patients with germline pathogenic variants (GPV) in cancer predisposition genes are at increased risk of pancreatic ductal adenocarcinoma (PDAC) The genes most frequently found to harbor GPV in unselected PDAC cases are ATM, BRCA1 ,  BRCa2 ,  CDKN2A ,  CHEK2 , and  PALB2. GPV prevalence and gene-specific associations have not been extensively studied in the general population.

Exploring multimorbidity relationships among diseases is of great importance for understanding their shared mechanisms, precise diagnosis and treatment. Here, we present a graph convolutional network (GCN) model, named MorbidGCN, for multimor bidity prediction by integrating population phenotypes and disease network. With Morbid GCN, 9742 and 14 010 novel multimorbridities are identified in the UKB and HuDiNe data sets, respectively.

The Mediterranean diet is associated with better global cognition in older adults, slower cognitive decline and lower risk of dementia. Little is known about the relative contribution of each component of the Mediterranean diet to dementia risk. We aimed to examine whether Mediterranean diet components are associated with all-cause dementia risk in the UK BioBank cohort.

Neural network training and validation rely on the availability of large high-quality datasets. In many cases only incomplete datasets are available, particularly in health care applications. GapNet is an alternative deep-learning training approach that can use highly incomplete datasets without overfitting or introducing artefacts.

Neuroimaging techniques have been increasingly used to understand the neural biology of aging brains. We develop computationally efficient algorithms to estimate the parameters of new random effects. We further apply this method to the UK Biobank data to investigate the effects of tobacco smoking on the white matter integrity of the entire brain.

We analysed data from the Genomics England 100,000 Genomes Project and from a cohort of 1313 individuals with albinism aiming to gain insights into the genetic architecture of this archetypal rare disorder. We investigated the contribution of protein-coding and regulatory variants both rare and common.

Gene-environment interactions represent the modification of genetic effects by environmental exposures. These often induce differential phenotypic variance across genotypes. These variance-quantitative trait loci can be prioritized in a two-stage interaction detection strategy.

Myalgic encephalomyelitis/chronic fatigue syndrome (ME/CFS) is a disease with a variety of symptoms such as post-exertional malaise, fatigue, and pain. An increasing number of studies have implicated the involvement of the immune system in ME/C FS. Genetic association studies are being performed to identify potential risk variants.

Air pollutants exposure and venous thromboembolism (VTE) remains controversial. In this study, a total of 389,659 participants from the UK Biobank who were free of VTE in 2010 were included. During a median follow-up period of 8.25 years, 4986 VTEs were determined from hospital admission records.

Hematopoietic mosaic loss of Y chromosome (mLOY) is associated with increased risk of mortality and age-related diseases in men. Here, we show that male mice reconstituted with bone marrow cells lacking the Y chromosome display increased mortality. Cardiac macrophages lacking Y chromosome exhibited polarization toward a more fibrotic phenotype.

The more deprivation status the individuals were in, the higher daily smoking frequency or risk to be ever smokers. Income, education, health, living environment, and crime deprivation were positively associated with the risk of smoking behaviors. Employment deprivation was negatively correlated with smoking behaviors (all P)

The relevance between circulating metabolites and vascular events remains controversial. We sought to investigate the prospective associations of plasma metabolomics with risks of incident stroke, ischemic stroke (IS), hemorrhagic stroke (HS), and myocardial infarction (MI) Within the UK Biobank cohort, 249 circulating metabolites were measured in 90 438 participants without baseline vascular diseases.

Cerebellar volume is highly heritable and associated with neurodevelopmental and neurodegenerative disorders. Understanding the genetic architecture of cerebellarVolume may improve our insight into these disorders. A genome-wide associations study was performed in a sample of 27,486 individuals from UK Biobank.

Long-term exposure to PM2.5 or NO2, even at relatively low levels, is associated with a higher risk of dementia. Air pollution may additively interact with the genetic susceptibility on dementia risk.

Modern GWAS studies use an enormous sample size and ultra-high density SNP genotypes. These conditions reduce the mapping resolution of marginal association tests. Multi-locus Bayesian Variable Selection (BVS) offers a one-stop solution for powerful mapping of risk variants.

UK Biobank ocular assessment included 68,550 participants aged 40-70 years. Those with diabetes had significantly more tortuous venules and wider arteriolar diameters compared with those without. Associations between venular tortuosity and cardiometabolic risk factors differed according to diabetes status.

Familial hemiplegic migraine (FHM) is a severe neurogenetic disorder. More than 80% of referred diagnostic cases of HM are negative for exonic mutations in these known FHM genes. Dysfunction in T-type calcium channels, including Cav3.3, has been implicated in a range of neurological conditions.

In recent work, Wang et al introduced the "Sum of Single Effects" (SuSiE) model. It provides a simple and efficient approach to fine-mapping genetic variants from individual-level data. Here we present new methods for fitting the SuSiE model to summary data. We also present a new refinement procedure that improves model fits in some data sets.

Analysis of whole-genome sequencing of 150,119 individuals from the UK Biobank. High-quality variants include 585,040,410 single-nucleotide polymorphisms. Depletion rank analysis shows that coding exons represent a small fraction of regions in the genome subject to strong sequence conservation.

Reducing Associations by Linking Genes and omics Results web app provides multi-layered omics information based on results from GWAS, transcriptomic, epigenomic and eQTL studies. With a focus on asthma datasets, the integrated omics results it contains facilitate the formulation of hypotheses related to airways disease-associated genes.

 Prediction models are commonly used to estimate risk for cardiovascular diseases. However, performance may vary substantially across relevant subgroups of the population. Here we investigated heterogeneity of accuracy and fairness metrics across a variety of subgroups for risk prediction.

Eosinophils play important roles in the release of cytokine mediators in response to inflammation. We have analyzed 200,000 whole-exome sequences from the UK Biobank cohort. A total of 220 genes in 55 distinct genomic regions were found to be associated with eosinophile count. Seven genes are driven by rare variants, independent of common variants.

The discrepancy between an individual's biological and chronological age of the brain ("brain age gap") can be assessed by applying machine learning techniques to Magnetic Resonance Imaging (MRI) data. We examined the links between brain age gap and a broad range of cognitive, affective, socioeconomic, lifestyle, and physical health variables in up to 335 adults of the Berlin Aging Study II.

Mitochondrial dysfunction, which can be approximated by blood mitochondrial DNA copy number (mtDNA-CN), has been implicated in the pathogenesis of type 2 diabetes mellitus. We assessed the association between blood mt DNA-CN and incident type 2 Diabetes using multivariable-adjusted regression analyses and bi-directional MR. We also assessed the potentially causal relationship between blood. mtDNA- CN and type 2abetes and BMI using bi- directional two-sample MR.

The cell adhesion molecule 2 (CADM2) gene has appeared among the top associations in a wide range of genome-wide association studies (GWASs) This study aims to examine how widespread the role of CADM2 is in behavioural traits.

Genome-wide variance quantitative trait loci (vQTL) analysis complements genome-wide association study (GWAS) VQTLs have potential to identify novel variants associated with the trait and explain additional trait variance.

Alcohol's impact on telomere length, a proposed marker of biological aging, is unclear. We performed the largest observational study to date (in n = 245,354 UK Biobank participants) and compared findings with Mendelian randomization (MR) estimates. Higher genetically-predicted AUD (inverse variance-weighted (IVW) &#946; =. -0.06, 95% confidence interval (CI): - 0.10 to 0.02, p = 0.001) was associated with shorter telomeres.

Maternal obesity causes early metabolic disorder in the offspring. Interleukin-6 induced bronchial and microvascular smooth muscle cell (SMC) hyperproliferation and increased airway and pulmonary vascular resistance. Key anti-proliferative transcription factor FoxO1 was inactivated via nuclear exclusion.

Inter-individual variation in fat distribution is increasingly recognized as clinically important but is not routinely assessed in clinical practice. We report a deep learning model trained on an individual's body shape outline that enables accurate estimation of specific fat depots of interest.

We developed a novel interpretable biological heart age estimation model using cardiovascular magnetic resonance radiomics measures of ventricular shape and myocardial character. We included 29,996 UK Biobank participants without cardiovascular disease. We subtracted actual age from model estimated heart age to calculate a "heart age delta", which we considered as a measure of  heart aging.

Polygenic risk scores (PRS) are proposed for use in clinical and research settings for risk stratification. There are limited investigations on how different PRS diverge from each other in risk prediction of individuals. We compared two recently published PRS for each of three conditions, breast cancer, hypertension and dementia.

Joint deafferentation after post-ankle sprain ligament healing can disrupt sensory input from the ankle and induce maladaptive neuroplasticity, especially in the cerebellum. Study aimed to determine whether the regional homogeneity of intrinsic cerebellar activity differs between patients with ankle instability and healthy controls.

 increasing evidence has shown adverse effects of loneliness on cardiometabolic health. The neuromodulator and hormone oxytocin has traditionally been linked with social cognition and behaviour. Recent implications of the Oxytocin system in energy metabolism suggests that oxytoc in may represent a mechanism bridging mental and somatic traits.

The APOE-&#949;4 allele is known to predispose to amyloid deposition and consequently is strongly associated with Alzheimer's disease (AD) risk. We found no significant associations of SNPs in the APOE locus with AD in the sample of 5,390 individuals. However, we identified a novel genome-wide significant locus associated to AD, mapping to DAB1.

Metformin use has been associated with reduced incidence of dementia in diabetic individuals. However, the causality between the two in the general population is unclear. This study uses Mendelian randomisation to investigate the causal effect of metformin targets on Alzheimer's disease.

To date, little is known about the pleiotropic genetic variants among depression, cognition, and memory. The current research aimed to identify the potential pleiotsropic single nucleotide polymorphisms (SNPs)

UK Biobank participants reported their intake of commonly consumed foods. Serum IGF-I concentrations were measured in blood samples collected at recruitment. Compared to never consumers, participants who reported consuming oily fish or non-oily fish &#8805; 2 times/week had 1.25 nmol/L (95% confidence interval:1.19-1.31)

 Frailty, a prevalent clinical syndrome in aging adults, is characterized by poor health outcomes. While the relevance of the syndrome is gaining awareness, much remains unclear about its underlying biology. Further elucidation of the genetic determinants and possible underlying mechanisms may help improve patients' outcomes allowing healthy aging.

To date, no study has explored the extent to which genetic susceptibility modifies the effects of air pollutants on the risk of atrial fibrillation (AF) This study included 401,251 participants without AF at baseline from UK Biobank. Participants exposed to high air pollutants levels and high genetic risk had approximately 149.2% (PM 2.5 ) and 181.7% ( PM 10 ) higher risk of AF.

Comorbid conditions can be driven by underlying pleiotropic and causal mechanisms that can provide insights into shared molecular and biological processes contributing to disease risk. Endometriosis is a chronic condition affecting one in nine women of reproductive age.

Using data from the UK Biobank, we showed that pain spreads from proximal to distal sites. We developed a biopsychosocial model that predicted the number of coexisting pain sites. Key risk factors included sleeplessness, feeling 'fed-up', tiredness, stressful life events and a body mass index >30.

The risk of developing severe obesity for SAS individuals was almost twofold higher for individuals with high aPRS than for those with intermediate aPRs. Risk of developing coronary artery disease (CAD), obesity, and type 2 diabetes (T2D) in the South Asian (SAS) individuals in the UK Biobank.

Study analysed data of 459 840 participants from the UK Biobank. Those scored 2-3, 4 and 5-7 all had around the two-time risk of all-cause dementia. Diabetes duration and insulin use moderated the association.

Only 3% of participants who are homozygous for rs887829-T have a recorded diagnosis of Gilbert syndrome. Carriers of this genotype have modest increases in the odds of developing biliary pathology and pityriasis rosea. Evidence suggests that bilirubin has no likely causal role in protection from cardiovascular disease, chronic obstructive pulmonary disease, or other key healthcare outcomes.

The study looked at the association between periodontal disease and the development of inflammatory arthritides in the general population. The study included 489 125 participants from the UK Biobank without a previous history of RA, AS and PsA.

Happiness and eudaimonic well-being are negatively related to depressive symptoms. Genetic variants play a role in this association, reflected in substantial genetic correlations. Pure happiness and pure meaning became genetically unrelated to traits strongly associated with depressive symptoms, including loneliness, and psychiatric disorders. For other traits, including ADHD, educational attainment, and smoking, the genetic correlations changed substantially.

The higher score of psychological distress was associated with an increased risk of lung cancer. 16.8% (95% CI: 13.0%-20.6%) of the distress-lung cancer association was mediated by smoking. Compared with never smokers with no distress, participants with heavy smoking had the highest risk.

No CMR analysis tool exists to automatically analyse large (unstructured) clinical CMR datasets. We develop and validate a robust AI tool for start-to-end automatic quantification of cardiac function from SAX cine CMR in large clinical databases.

On average, educated people are healthier, wealthier and have higher life expectancy. Previous studies have used a range of natural experiments to provide causal evidence. Here we compare two natural experiments: a policy reform, raising the school leaving age in the UK in 1972; and Mendelian randomization.

We fine mapped the leukocyte antigen (HLA) region in 13,770 Parkinson's disease (PD) patients, 20,214 proxy-cases, and 490,861 controls of European origin. Four HLA types were associated with PD after correction for multiple comparisons. Haplotype analyses followed by amino acid analysis and conditional analyses suggested that the association is protective.

Early onset of menopause is associated with increased risk of hypertension. Whether this association is causal or due to residual confounding and/or reverse causation remains undetermined. We aimed to evaluate the observational and causal association between age at natural menopresa (ANM) and blood pressure traits.

35% to 78% of asthmatics do not respond to leukotriene inhibitors. European individuals with early-onset (&#8804;18y) carrying at least one copy of rs2660845 have increased odd of exacerbation under montelukast treatment. These findings support a precision medicine approach for the treatment of asthma.

A total of 28,919 participants from the UK Biobank study with available glycemic status and qualified retinal imaging data were included in the present analysis. Glycemic status included type 2 diabetes mellitus (T2D) disease status and glycemic indicators of plasma glycated hemoglobin (HbA1c) and glucose. Retinal age gap was defined as the difference between the retina-predicted age and chronological age.

Previous studies have suggested that vitamin D (VD) was associated with psychiatric diseases. Here, we examined associations of VD traits with depression and anxiety traits. Our study results suggested that VD was negatively associated with anxiety and depression.

It remains unknown whether a low-inflammatory diet could modify the chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD) and lung cancer risk related to smoking. An inflammatory diet index (IDI) was developed based on C-reactive protein levels and was a weighted sum of 34 food groups. Replacing each standard deviation unit (&#8776;1080.426 g day -1 ) of pro- inflammatory foods with anti-inflammatory foods was associated with a 30% lower COPD risk.

Premorbid data for total cholesterol, high-density and low-density lipoprotein cholesterol, triglyceride, glycated haemoglobin A1c and creatinine were collected retrospectively. Data were fitted using linear mixed effects models with linear b-splines to identify inflection points. In specialist amyotrophic lateral sclerosis clinic cases, models indicated decreasing levels of total cholesterol prior to an inflection point in the years before symptom onset.

Proton-pump inhibitors (PPIs) are used to suppress gastric acid secretion in several gastrointestinal conditions. Long-term use may be associated with different adverse effects, including migraine. We analyzed the association between treatment with PPIs and migraine prevalence.

There is a lack of studies on the association between specific physical activity (PA) types and dementia. We examined the association of LTPA, OPA, and sedentary lifestyle with dementia risk and cognitive decline using the UK-Biobank study.

Vitamin D has been known to be associated with asthma, particularly in children. The evidence among adults is limited and inconclusive. This study aimed to investigate the association between serum, vitamin D concentrations, and the incidence of adult-onset asthma. It also investigated the modified effect caused by sleep patterns and genetic risks.

Ongoing increases in the size of human genotype and phenotype collections offer the promise of improved understanding of the genetics of complex diseases. Here we show that advances in phenotype prediction can be applied to improve the power of genome-wide association studies.

An elastic net-based Cox model (ML4H EN-COX ) trained and evaluated in 173,274 UK Biobank participants selected 51 predictors from 13,782 candidates. Beyond most traditional risk factors, the model selected a polygenic score, waist circumference, socioeconomic deprivation, and several hematologic indices.

We found that the genetic variation that supports longer life is significantly associated with the lower risk of COVID-19 infection and hospitalization. We find that lower B-cell CD19 levels are indicative of an increased risk and decreased life expectancy. Interventions that target these factors to reduce biological age may reduce the risk.

This two-sample Mendelian randomization study aimed to examine the potential causal association of telomere length (TL) with the risk of osteoarthritis (OA) The summary-level data for OA was derived from the United Kingdom Biobank cohort, including 50,508 individuals of European descent.

Pharmacogenomic studies have revealed associations between rs1967309 in the adenylyl cyclase type 9 ( ADCY9 ) gene and clinical responses to dalcetrapib. Here, we characterized selective signals at the locus associated with the pharmacogenomic response in human populations. We show that the region exhibits signatures of positive selection in several populations.

Little is known on the gender-specific effect and potential role of non-linear associations between metabolic syndrome (MetS) components and liver cancer risk. We evaluated these associations based on the UK Biobank cohort.

Vertigo is the leading symptom of vestibular disorders and a major risk factor for falls. In a genome-wide association study of vertigo, we uncovered an association with six common sequence variants. None of the six vertigo variants were associated with hearing loss and only one was associated with age-related hearing impairment.

Deep learning demonstrates great promise for automated analysis of CMR. However, existing limitations are holding back the introduction of deep learning tools in the clinical environment. This study aimed to develop a framework for automated detection and quality-controlled selection of standard cine sequences images.

Recovering the 3D motion of the heart from cine cardiac magnetic resonance (CMR) imaging enables the assessment of regional myocardial function. 3D cardiac motion estimation is challenging because the acquired cine CMR images are usually 2D slices which limit the accurate estimation of through-plane motion. We propose a novel multi-view motion estimation network (MulViMotion) which integrates 2D cine cMR images acquired in short-axis and long-axis planes. We extensively evaluate the proposed method on 2D C MR images from 580 subjects of the UK Biobank study.

C-reactive protein (CRP) is a routinely measured blood biomarker for inflammation. Elevated levels of circulating CRP are associated with response to infection, risk for a number of complex common diseases, and psychosocial stress. CRP serum levels are significantly associated with ethnicity in an age and sex adjusted model. BMI, smoking, and socioeconomic deprivation all have high relative effects on CRP.

Growth differentiation factor-15 (GDF15) is a stress response cytokine that is elevated in several cardiometabolic diseases and has attracted interest as a potential therapeutic target. We conducted a broad study into the phenotypic and genetic correlates of GDF15 concentration in up to 14,099 individuals. Assessment of 772 traits across 6610 participants in FINRISK identified associations with a range of phenotypes.

Lateralization is a fundamental characteristic of many behaviors and the organization of the brain. Atypical lateralization has been linked to various brain-related disorders such as autism and schizophrenia. Right-handedness is one of the most prominent markers of human behavioural lateralization, yet its neurobiological basis remains to be determined.

Aortic dimensions and distensibility are key risk factors for aortic aneurysms and dissections, as well as for other cardiovascular and cerebrovascular diseases. We identify 102 loci (including 27 novel associations) tagging genes related to cardiovascular development, extracellular matrix production and smooth muscle cell contraction.

The aim of this study was to investigate the causal effects of T2DM liability and glycated haemoglobin (HbA1c) levels on various cardiovascular disease outcomes. We selected 243 variants as genetic instruments for T2 DM liability and 536 variants for HbA 1c. Linear Mendelian randomization analyses were performed to estimate the associations of genetically-predicted T1D liability and Hb1c levels with 12 cardiovascular outcomes.

Using UK Biobank data, we analysed clinical phenotypic and genetic information in the largest dystonia cohort reported to date. Phenotypic patterns highlighted a predominance of psychiatric symptoms (anxiety and depression), excess pain and sleep disturbance. Cognitive impairment was limited to prospective memory and fluid intelligence.

Study investigates the association of common serum laboratory tests with the risk of incident dementia. Among 407,190 participants from the UK Biobank (median follow-up of 9.19 years), we investigated the linear and nonlinear effects of 30 laboratory measures. Dementia incidence was associated with low vitamin D concentration.

Drug target Mendelian randomization (MR) studies use DNA sequence variants in or near a gene encoding a drug target to anticipate the effect of drug action on the same target. Here we apply MR to prioritize drug targets for their causal relevance for coronary heart disease (CHD) The targets are further prioritized using independent replication, co-localization and protein expression profiles.

Autoimmune diseases share a general mechanism of auto-antigens harming tissues. Genetic as well as environmental factors contribute to their etiology at varying degrees. Associated genomic loci and variants have been identified in numerous genome-wide association studies.

Cardiac magnetic resonance (CMR) imaging is a valuable modality in the diagnosis and characterization of cardiovascular diseases. However, in clinical practice, it is commonly acquired as a collection of separated and independent 2D image planes. This paper presents a completely automated pipeline for generating patient-specific 3D biventricular heart models from MR slices.

Respiratory infections contribute to significant morbidity and mortality. Genetic determinants of respiratory infections are understudied and remain poorly understood. We conducted a genome-wide association study in 19,459 hospitalised respiratory infection cases and 101,438 controls from UK Biobank. We followed-up well-imputed top signals in 50,912 cases and 150,442 controls.

Nomograms are important clinical tools applied widely in both developing and aging populations. They are generally constructed as normative models identifying cases as outliers to a distribution of healthy controls. Hippocampal volume (HV) is a key endophenotype for many brain disorders.
