Long-term blood pressure variability (BPV) is a risk factor for cardiovascular diseases, dementia, and stroke. This study aims to explore its genetic factors and provide more evidence on the mechanisms and further pathological study of BPV.

Population biobanks recruit many individuals who can be affected by rare diseases. Major challenges include suboptimal phenotype mapping and limited statistical power. We identified 420 rare diseases affecting 23,575 individuals in the UK Biobank.

 kidney-specific gene  UMOD encodes for uromodulin, the most abundant protein excreted in normal urine. Rare large-effect variants in UMOD cause autosomal dominant tubulointerstitial kidney disease (ADTKD) Common low-impact variants strongly associate with kidney function and the risk of chronic kidney disease.

Alzheimer's disease (AD) has no proven causal and modifiable risk factors, or effective interventions. We report a phenome-wide association study (PheWAS) of genetic liability for AD in 334,968 participants of the UK Biobank study, stratified by age. We also examined the effects of AD genetic liability on previously implicated risk factors.

Interleukin 6 (IL-6) signaling is being investigated as a therapeutic target for atherosclerotic cardiovascular disease (CVD) Changes in circulating high-sensitivity C-reactive protein (hsCRP) are used as a marker of IL-6 signaling. It is not known whether there is effect heterogeneity in relation to baseline hsCRP levels or other cardiovascular risk factors.

Study used data from RNA-sequencing experiments and whole-body MRI scans of 200 participants in the EPIC-Potsdam cohort. The analysis identified 625 genes associated with adiposity, of which 531 encode a known protein and 487 are novel candidate genes for obesity.

We used data from UK biobank (N = 342,846) to evaluate joint effect of breastfeeding and maternal smoke during pregnancy (MSDP) on seven adult offspring mental health outcomes. Sex, age, 10 principle components of population structure, smoking, alcohol use, and Townsend deprivation index were examined as covariates. At MSDP grouping level, coefficients (odds ratio [OR]) for association of breastfed as a baby with self-reported anxiety (category variable) were 0.87 (95%CI, (0.82-0.93), P = 1.74 Ã— 10-5) in the MSDP group.

Recent studies are questioning the role of common candidate genes in the development of depressive disorders. We hypothesize that 5-HTTLPR exerts its effect on depressive disorders in interaction with other genetic variants. We identified a region in the DPF1 gene that displayed a genome-wide significant (p = 3.31 Ã— 10 -7 ) interaction effect with the biallelic version of 5- HTTLPR on lifetime depression.

Metabolomic data of 110,655 people in the UK Biobank study were measured with nuclear magnetic resonance technique. A total of 38 metabolites, including lipids and lipoproteins, ketone bodies, glycolysis-related metabolites, and amino acids, were found to be significantly associated with incident dementia. Adding selected metabolites (n=24) to the conventional dementia risk prediction model significantly improved the prediction for incident dementia and reclassification ability.

We tested the hypothesis that individuals with high ELPRS have a low prevalence of MetS. Participants were from five cohorts of middle-aged to older adults. MetS prevalence (22-30%) was higher in the older cohorts.

The 2021 European Society of Cardiology (ESC) guideline on cardiovascular disease (CVD) prevention categorizes moderate and severe chronic kidney disease as high and very-high CVD risk status. We developed and validated an 'Add-on' to incorporate CKD measures into these algorithms, using a validated approach.

High general cognitive ability (GCA) is associated with lower risk of neurodegenerative disorders. neural mechanisms are unknown. GCA could be associated with more cortical tissue, from young age, or less cortical atrophy in adulthood.

There is limited evidence exploring the relationship between diet and the risk of COVID-19. This study aimed to assess the associations between consumption of ultra-processed foods (UPF) and risk of infection. 41,012 participants from the UK Biobank study with at least 2 of up to 5 times 24-h dietary assessments were included.

Brown and beige adipose tissue are protective against metabolic diseases. PR domain-containing 16 (PRDM16) is an attractive target for improving metabolic health. We identify CUL2-APPBP2 as the ubiquitin E3 ligase that determines PRDM16 protein stability.

The modern sedentary lifestyle is negatively influencing human health. Current guidelines recommend at least 150 min of moderate activity per week. While accelerometers are the most common tools to measure activity, current activity classification methods require calibration studies.

The association between metabolic obesity phenotypes and incident lung cancer (LC) remains unclear. During a median follow-up of 9.1 years, 3654 incident LC patients were confirmed among 450,482 individuals. MHO and MHOW individuals had a 24% and 18% lower risk of developing LC, respectively.

Study examined associations between sugar-sweetened beverages (SSBs) and the incidence of CMM in patients with a single cardiometabolic disease. Consumption of SSBs and ASBs was associated with a higher risk of the disease. In contrast, intake of pure fruit/vegetable juices was inversely associated with the risk of C MM.

Public greenspace was strongly associated with lower mortality risks. The protective associations were especially pronounced among those with lower individual-level socioeconomic status or living in places with area-level deprivation. Exploratory mediation analysis detected benefits in pathways through reducing air pollution, relieving social isolation and depression.

Prostate cancer is highly heritable, with >250 common variants associated in genome-wide association studies. It commonly presents with non-specific lower urinary tract symptoms that are frequently associated with benign conditions.

The association between coronary artery disease (CAD) and posttraumatic stress disorder (PTSD) contributes to the high morbidity and mortality observed for these conditions. To understand the dynamics underlying PTSD-CAD comorbidity, we investigated large-scale genome-wide association statistics. We observed a genetic correlation of CAD with PTSD case-control and quantitative outcomes.

Phenome-wide association studies identified numerous loci associated with traits and diseases. To help interpret these associations, we constructed a network map of colocalized genes and phenotypes. The majority of links were observed in a single tissue.

Schizophrenia is a highly heritable psychiatric disorder characterized by widespread functional and structural brain abnormalities. Previous association studies between MRI and polygenic risk were mostly ROI-based single modality analyses. We identified a PRS-associated brain pattern with smaller gray matter volume and decreased functional activation in frontotemporal cortex.

Gene-environment correlations affect associations between genetic variants and complex traits in genome-wide association studies (GWASs) Controlling for geographic regions significantly decreased the heritability for socioeconomic status (SES)-related traits. For most traits, controlling for regions significantly reduced genetic correlations with educational attainment and income.

Sedentary behavior (SB) is associated with cardiometabolic disease and mortality, but its association with dementia is currently unclear. This study investigates whether SB is linked with incident dementia regardless of engagement in physical activity (PA) A total of 146,651 participants from the UK Biobank who were 60 years or older and did not have a diagnosis of dementia were included.

We use genetics to assess a latent, broad non-cognitive skills dimension. On average across cohorts and designs, indirect genetic effects explain 36-40% of population polygenic score associations. We identify potential causes of higher sibling- and trio-based estimates including population stratification and assortative mating.

Whether a genetic predisposition to psychiatric disorders is associated with coronavirus disease 2019 (COVID-19) is unknown. Our analytic sample consisted of 287,123 white British participants in UK Biobank who were alive on 31 January 2020. We performed a genome-wide association study (GWAS) analysis for each psychiatric disorder.

Natural killer (NK) cells represent a critical component of the innate immune system's response against cancer and viral infections. To distinguish healthy host cells from infected or tumor cells, killer immunoglobulin receptors (KIR) on NK cells bind and recognize Human Leukocyte Antigen (HLA) complexes. Just like the HLAs they bind, KIR receptors exhibit high allelic diversity in the human population. Here we provide a method to identify KIR allele variants from whole exome sequencing data.

An elevated risk of CVD was constantly observed among cancer patients, compared to their matched unexposed individuals. Such excess risk was most pronounced (hazard ratio [HR] = 5.28, 95% confidence interval [CI] 4.90-5.69) within 3 months after a cancer diagnosis.

Study was performed on a subset of participants from the UK Biobank between 2006 and 2010. Exposure to air pollutants, especially PM 2.5 and PM 10, was positively associated with LBW. A negative correlation was observed between the BW and PM2.5.

Coeliac disease (CeD) is characterized by gliadin-induced intestinal inflammation appearing in genetically susceptible individuals, such as HLA-DQ2.5 carriers. CeD has been associated with increased morbidity and mortality, but the causes are unknown. We compared the overall and cause-specific mortality and morbidity of 3,001 patients with CeD, 2,020 with CD and 4,399 with UC.

Gestational diabetes mellitus (GDM) is a common complication of pregnancy that adversely affects maternal and offspring health. Risk factors, such as BMI and age, have been associated with increased risks of gestational diabetes. Here we develop a polygenic risk score for GDM.

Myelofibrosis is a rare myeloproliferative neoplasm (MPN) with high risk for progression to acute myeloid leukemia. We identify 6 germline susceptibility loci, 4 of which overlap with previously identified MPN loci. We also describe recurrent 9p24.1 large mCAs that selectively retained JAK2V617F mutations.

The association between body mass index (BMI) and Alzheimer's disease (AD) remains controversial. Genetic and environmental factors are now considered contributors to AD risk. Little is known about the potential interaction between genetic risk and BMI onAD risk.

Mendelian randomization (MR) and multivariable regression was used to examine nonlinear effects of sleep duration on stillbirth, miscarriage, gestational diabetes, hypertensive disorders of pregnancy, perinatal depression, preterm birth and low/high offspring birthweight. Shorter and longer duration increased stillbirth and low offspring birth weight; shorter duration increased perinata depression.

The evidence of relationship between dietary intake of folate, vitamin B6 and vitamin B12 and cardiovascular diseases (CVD) in UK populations is limited. We aimed to analyze the association of dietary intake. with CVD events [stroke, myocardial infarction (MI)] and CVD mortality.

Immune system dysregulation plays a vital role in the pathogenesis of neurodegenerative diseases. The associations of immune-mediated diseases with incident dementia are unclear and need to be clarified in prospective studies with a large population and long follow-up.

Genome-wide association studies do not always replicate well across populations, limiting the generalizability of polygenic risk scores. Despite higher incidence and mortality rates of prostate cancer in men of African descent, much of what is known about cancer genetics comes from populations of European descent.

UK Biobank is a large volunteer cohort (over 500,000 participants recruited aged 40-69) We compared participants with and without a history of infections for changes in cognitive function during follow-up. No evidence of an association was found between infection site, setting or frequency and cognitive decline except for small associations on the visual memory test.

The direction of the association between discretionary screen time (DST) and sleep in the adult population is largely unknown. We examined the bidirectional associations of DST and sleep patterns in a longitudinal sample of adults in the general population. A high DST at baseline is associated with poor sleep over a nearly 7 year follow-up period.

Comorbidity in heart diseases, including cardiac dysfunction (CD) and cognitive impairment, such as Alzheimer's disease and dementia (AD/D) might be due to a pleiotropic effect of genetic variants shared between CD and AD/D. Validation of disease-disease associations through health care records and genomic evidence can determine whether health conditions share risk factors.

Genome-wide survival association analysis can identify variants associated with ages of onset, disease progression and lifespan. We propose an efficient and accurate frailty model approach for genome-wide association analysis of censored time-to-event (TTE) phenotypes.

We analyzed 420,964 cancer-free participants from UK Biobank cohort. Observational analyses showed higher CRP concentration was associated with increased risk of overall cancer. No association were observed for genetically-predicted CRP and cancer risks.

Copy number variation (CNV) is a form of rare genetic variation that has been implicated in the etiology of psychiatric disorders. No large-scale investigation of CNV in PTSD has been performed. The 15q11.2 BP1-BP2 microdeletion region was significantly associated with PTSD. No individual significant genes interrupted by CNV were identified.

Several biobanks, including UK Biobank (UKBB), are generating large-scale sequencing data. An existing method, SAIGE-GENE, performs well when testing variants with minor allele frequency (MAF &#8804; 1%) But inflation is observed in variance component set-based tests when restricting to variants with MAF &# 8804; 0.1%.

Machine learning was used to develop a novel dementia prediction model by leveraging a rich-phenotypic variable space of 366 features. 425,159 non-demented participants were enrolled from 22 recruitment centres across the UK between March 1, 2006 and October 31, 2010. The model can achieve high discriminative accuracy in dementia and even better in AD.

Grip strength and walking pace have been linked to cognitive dysfunction. A 5 kg increment of absolute grip strength was associated with lower risks of all-cause dementia. A slow walking pace demonstrated consistent associations with increased risks.

Research suggests that diet influences cognitive function and the risk for neurodegenerative disease. The present study aimed to determine whether a recently developed diet score was associated with fluid intelligence. It also investigated whether associations were modified by individual genetic disposition.

 mitochondrial DNA copy number (mtDNA-CN) reflects mitochondrial function and has been associated with various aging-related diseases. We examined 415,422 exomes of self-reported White ancestry individuals from the UK Biobank. A survey across nine variant sets tested enrichment of putatively causal variants and identified 14 genes at experiment-wide significance.

BLM-s (BCL-2-like molecule, small transcript isoform) mediates apoptosis of postmitotic immature neurons during embryonic cortical development. Global depletion of Blm-s is associated with depression- and anxiety-related behaviors in adult mutant mice with intact learning and memory capacity.

There is limited understanding of how genetic factors contributed to altered neuroanatomy during human evolution. Here, we analyze neuroimaging and genetic data from up to 30,000 people in the UK Biobank. We show that previously reported signals of recent polygenic selection for cortical anatomy are not replicable in a more ancestrally homogeneous sample.

Being part of social groups constitutes a backbone for communal life and confers many benefits for the physical and mental health. We used structural and functional analyses to explore how social participation is reflected in the human brain.

PCSK9 inhibitors might lower lipoprotein(a), but whether this effect contributes to reductions in cardiovascular risk remains unknown. We aimed to assess whether genetically proxied PCSK9 inhibition influences lipop protein(a) and whether any such effect could mediate its effects on coronary artery disease (CAD) and ischemic stroke (IS)

Hemoglobin (Hb) concentration in the blood reflects a major functional iron (i.e., heme iron) in the body. Hb may serve as a surrogate of the nutritional status of iron. Iron overnutrition has been implicated with a higher risk of developing metabolic and cardiovascular diseases.

The impact of different coffee preparations on cardiovascular outcomes and survival is largely unknown. The aim of this study was to evaluate associations between coffee subtypes on incident outcomes. Decaffeinated, ground, and instant coffee, particularly at 2-3 cups/day, were associated with significant reductions in incident CVD and mortality.

Cardiometabolic multimorbidity (CMM) has risen as a global issue of public health. This study aimed to estimate the association between use of fish oil and mortality among patients with CMM. Use of fishoil was associated with a 17% lower risk of all-cause mortality.

Obstructive sleep apnea (OSA) may differentially affect specific molecular pathways and processes in the pathogenesis of coronary artery disease (CAD) We calculated pathway-specific polygenic risk scores for CAD based on 6.6 million common variants evaluated in the CARDIoGRAMplusC4D genome-wide association study.

Evidence is limited regarding the associations between vitamin D status and microvascular complications in individuals with type 2 diabetes (T2D) Vitamin D deficiency or insufficiency is particularly common. In this study we aimed to investigate the associations of serum 25-hydroxyvitamin D [25(OH)D] and vitamin D receptor (VDR) polymorphisms with risk of diabetic microv vascular complications.

Ambient air pollution has been widely linked with morbidity and mortality of stroke. We investigated the effects of ambient air pollution on progression trajectory from healthy status to incident stroke, poststroke cardiovascular diseases, and subsequent death.

The combined effect of coffee and tea consumption on asthma has rarely been studied. We examined associations between the self-reported intake of tea and coffee and the risk of incident asthma. Cox proportional hazards models were used to estimate the associations between coffee/tea consumption and incident adult-onset asthma.

The cardioprotective diet was reported to be associated with several chronic cardiometabolic diseases through an anti-inflammation effect. However, the association between the diet and the risk of inflammatory bowel disease (IBD) was unclear and deserved to be further explored. We calculated the cardiop rotective diet score based on the consumptions of seven common food groups using validated food frequency questionnaire data in the UK Biobank.

Childhood-onset asthma (COA) has become a major and growing problem worldwide. Understanding the influence of early-life experiences such as breastfeeding on COA is of great importance for early prevention. We investigated the impact of breastfeeding on asthma in children under 12 years of age in the UK Biobank cohort. In the full cohort, it was identified that breastfeeding had a protective effect onCOA.

Magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) of the brain could be a key diagnostic and research tool for understanding the neuropsychiatric complications of COVID-19. For maximum impact, multi-modal MRI protocols will be needed to measure the effects of SARS-CoV-2 infection on the brain by diverse potentially pathogenic mechanisms. Here we describe the development of such a protocol, based upon the UK Biobank, and its validation with a travelling heads study.

The association between habitual glucosamine use and incident gout has not been examined in previous studies. A total of 436,594 participants (55.4% female) without prior gout at baseline who completed a questionnaire on supplementation use were enrolled. Incident gout was recorded from self-report, death register, primary care, and hospital admission data.

Study looked at macular retinal nerve fibre layer (mRNFL) and ganglion cell-inner plexiform layer (GC-IPL) thicknesses. Results suggest ethnic differences in layer thickness are likely driven by differences in total retinal thickness.

Urban agriculture has been shown to contribute to healthy lifestyle behaviors, such as increased fruit and vegetable intake and greater exposure to greenspaces. There is plenty of evidence linking these lifestyle behaviors to better health and wellbeing. Most evidence relates to assessing one behavior at a time. This research aims to examine the association of the interactions between various lifestyle behaviors and exposures related to urban agriculture.

Large data sets may contain associations that are statistically significant and yet misleading. This paper develops a method based on model-X knockoffs to find conditional associations. The effectiveness of this approach is demonstrated by simulations and applications to the UK Biobank data.

CYP2D6 and CYP2C19 enzymes are essential in the metabolism of antidepressants and antipsychotics. Genetic variation in these genes may increase risk of adverse drug reactions.

Predicting high-risk patients who require active intervention is challenging, especially in people with preserved kidney function. A predictive risk score for CKD (Reti-CKD score) was derived from a deep learning algorithm using retinal photographs.

The study included 20,047 study participants with T2D and complete data on spirometry at recruitment from the UK Biobank cohort. 4,521 patients showed comorbid PRISm at baseline. Over a median follow-up of 11.52 to 11.87 years, patients with T1D with PRism showed higher risks.

Examine the association of physical activity (PA) with glaucoma and related traits. To assess whether genetic predisposition to glau coma modified these associations. To probe causal relationships using Mendelian randomization (MR)

Trans-ethnic genome-wide association studies have revealed that many loci identified in European populations can be reproducible in non-European populations. How to leverage such shared information more efficiently in association analysis is less investigated for traits in underrepresented populations. We propose a statistical framework, trans-ethnic genetic risk score informed gene-based association mixed model (GAMM)

The benefit of using individual risk prediction tools to identify high-risk individuals for breast cancer (BC) screening is uncertain, despite the personalized approach of risk-based screening. Risk predictors assessed include the Gail model, BC family history, BC polygenic risk score (PRS), and presence of loss-of-function variants in BC predisposition genes.

The association between cardiovascular disease (CVD) risk and socio-economic status (SES) remains poorly studied. The purpose of this study was to investigate the relationship between SES and estimated 10-year atherosclerotic cardiovascular disease risk among the general UK Biobank population. The findings from this study showed that men had higher estimated 10 year risk than women.

Ultra-processed food (UPF) intake has been associated with multiple health outcomes. Data on the association between UPF intake and venous thromboembolism (VTE) risk are lacking. We conducted a prospective cohort study to examine the association.

A decade ago, we proposed an index of physiological dysregulation based on Mahalanobis distance. We assessed pairwise correlations among systems, difference with age, prediction of mortality and age-related diseases. Different physiological systems showed distinct dysregulation processes.

Automated image analytics to compute quantitative imaging biomarkers of cardiac function are desperately needed. A hybrid and robust algorithm is proposed to improve the accuracy of automatic left and right ventricle segmentation. The proposed architecture outperformed the state-of-the-art for cardiac MRI segmentation from UK Biobank.

The Li and Stephens (LS) hidden Markov model (HMM) models the process of reconstructing a haplotype as a mosaic copy of haplotypes in a reference panel. For small panels, the probabilistic parameterization of LS enables modeling the uncertainties of such mosaics. LS becomes inefficient when sample size is large, because of its linear time complexity.

Study looked at hypertension-related cardiovascular magnetic resonance (CMR) phenotypes in the UK Biobank. Hypertension was associated with concentric left ventricular (LV) hypertrophy, poorer LV function, larger left atrial (LA) volumes, lower LA ejection fraction, and lower aortic distensibility. Increasing time since diagnosis of hypertension linked to adverse remodelling.

Research on the effect of oral contraceptive (OC) use on the risk of depression shows inconsistent findings, especially in adult OC users. One possible reason for this inconsistency is the omission of women who discontinue OCs due to adverse mood effects, leading to healthy user bias. To address this issue, we aim to estimate the risk. of depression that is associated with the initiation of OCs as well as the effect. of OC use on lifetime risk of. depression.

Previous studies identified a number of diseases were associated with 2019 coronavirus disease (COVID-19) However, the associations between these diseases related viral infections and CO VID-19 remains unknown now. In this study, we utilized single nucleotide polymorphisms (SNPs) related to COVID- 19 from genome-wide association study.

Asthma, type 2 diabetes (T2D), and anthropometric measures are correlated complex traits that all have a major genetic component. We found several genome-wide significant variants in and around the JAZF1 gene that are associated with asthma, T2D, or height. We also observed an association in this region with WC when adjusted for BMI.

Metabolomics allowed for leveraging the future of diagnosis and management of 'healthily obese' and 'unhealthily lean' individuals. The groups carrying obesity-related metabolites were at higher risk of mortality and morbidity.

Study of individual pairs of genes to complex traits has been challenging. Findings from model systems do not always translate to humans. Study identifies distinct gene pairs that modulate plasma and cellular lipid levels primarily via AEs.

Glycemia has been found as one important risk factor of depression. The biological mechanism underlying this relationship remained largely unknown. This analysis was derived from a cohort of 33,151 participants in the UK Biobank who provided brain magnetic resonance imaging data.

Pancreatic cancer has the poorest 5-year survival rate of any major solid tumor. Population screening is impractical because pancreatic cancer is rare with a lifetime risk of 1.7%. accurate risk stratification could enable health care providers to focus early detection strategies to at-risk individuals.

Previous research suggested an association between air pollution and shortened telomere length (TL), a biomarker of oxidative stress and inflammation. To comprehensively evaluate the association, we studied 471,808 participants from UK Biobank. Among participants with lower household income, lower educational attainment, and higher BMI, a stronger association was found.

Poor oral health is associated with a higher risk of incident dementia. Dentures may predict accelerated cognitive decline and are associated with regional cortical surface area changes. Improvement of oral health care could be beneficial for the prevention of dementia.

Beverage consumption was found to be associated with cardiovascular disease and mortality in the general population. However, it is unclear whether this association still exists in individuals with inflammatory bowel disease (IBD) To investigate, we included 1981 participants with IBD in the UK Biobank. Outcomes of interest were overall cardiovascular Disease and all-cause mortality.

Using structural magnetic resonance imaging from the UK Biobank (n = 33,293), we examined the relationships between smoking status, dosage, and abstinence with total and 166 regional brain gray matter volumes (GMV) Smoking was associated with lower total and regional GMV, with the extent depending on the frequency of smoking and on whether smoking had ceased. The smaller GMV in smokers was most evident in the thalamus.

Thinness and anorexia nervosa are both characterised by persistent low weight. Both conditions are heritable and share genomics with BMI, but are not genetically correlated with each other. Based on their pattern of genetic associations with other traits, we explored differences between thinness andAnorexia Nervosa on a genomic level.

Cross-sectional study included cancer survivors (n = 2415) from the UK Biobank. Eighteen percent of participants were malnourished, 5% had low muscle mass and 6.5% had sarcopenia. Three dietary patterns were identified: 'high oily fish and nuts', 'low oily fish' and 'meat and dairy'

The influence of genetic factors on survival following a diagnosis of hepatocellular carcinoma (HCC) remains unclear. To assess whether genetic polymorphisms influencing the susceptibility to develop HCC are also associated with HCC prognosis. Five HCC susceptibility loci were investigated: rs738409 (PNPLA3), rs58542926 (TM6SF2), rs72613567 (HSD17B13) and rs2242652 (TERT)

Polygenic risk scores may improve VTE prediction but have not yet been evaluated in patients with cancer. Guidelines recommend thromboprophylaxis for patients at high risk of venous thromboembolism.

A prospective cohort study included 21 193 individuals with CHD from the UK Biobank. Sleep 7-8 h/day, never/rarely insomnia, and no frequent daytime sleepiness were each significantly associated with a 12-22% lower risk of heart failure.

The literature has reported the potential involvement of inflammation in cognitive performance as well as Alzheimer's Disease, but not consistently. This study was designed to investigate the relationship between a systematic inflammatory biomarker measure, concurrent and later cognitive performance, and future dementia risk.

Non-alcoholic fatty liver disease (NAFLD) and alcoholic liver disease are among the most common liver diseases worldwide. It is unclear whether Omega-3 supplementation can prevent the development of liver disease, particularly in individuals at an increased (genetic) risk. In this UK Biobank cohort study, we established a multivariate cox proportional hazards model.

We build polygenic scores and examine performance as a function of training set size, genetic ancestral background, and training method. We show that predictor performance is most strongly dependent on size of training data, with smaller gains from algorithmic improvements. We find that LASSO generally performs as well as the best methods.

Drugs targeting genes linked to disease via evidence from human genetics have increased odds of approval. Approaches to prioritize such genes include genome-wide association studies (GWASs), rare variant burden tests in exome sequencing studies (Exome), or integration of a GWAS with expression/protein quantitative trait loci (eQTL/pQTL-GWAS) We compare gene-prioritization approaches on 30 clinically relevant traits and benchmark their ability to recover drug targets.

The human genome contains hundreds of thousands of regions harboring copy-number variants (CNV) Only larger CNVs have been ascertainable from SNP-array data generated by large biobanks. We developed a computational approach leveraging haplotype sharing in biobank cohorts to more sensitively detect CNVs.

Cardiometabolic multimorbidity (CMM) is becoming increasingly common in patients with hypertension. It is well established that healthy lifestyle plays a key role in the prevention of hypertension. However, the association between combined lifestyle factors and CMM is uncertain.

Kidney function is usually estimated from serum creatinine level. An alternative glomerular filtration marker (cystatin C level) associates more closely with future risk of cardiovascular disease (CVD) and mortality.

Higher urate levels are associated with higher systolic blood pressure (SBP) in adults, and in pregnancy with lower offspring birthweight. Mendelian randomization analyses suggest a causal effect of higher urate on higher SBP. If urate reduces birthweight, it might confound the effect of SBP on birth weight.

A total of 422,955 subjects who did not have osteoporosis at baseline in the UK Biobank were included from 2006 to 2010. After confounder adjustment, the results showed a remarkable increase in the risk of osteop orosis with each 10 unit increase in exposure to air pollution. Exposure to PM 2.5 , NO 2  and NOx was associated with an increase in osteopOrosis risk.

Alcohol drinking and obesity are associated with an increased risk of cirrhosis and hepatocellular carcinoma (HCC) Genetic variants, such as I148M in the patatin-like phospholipase domain-containing protein 3 (PNPLA3) gene, may play an important role in modulating cirrhotic risk. This prospective cohort study analyzed 414 209 participants enrolled in the UK Biobank study from March 2006 to December 2010.

In the UK Biobank Study cohort, 114 583 volunteers were included at baseline from March to June 2006 to July 2010. Habitual distance visual acuity was examined using the logarithm of the minimum angle of resolution. Depression was identified based on Patient Health Questionnaire (PHQ) or through an interview-based psychiatric diagnosis. Subgroup participants completed multimodal magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) of the brain and PHQ evaluation during the imaging visit after 2014.

Glaucoma is a leading cause of blindness. Current medications work by lowering intraocular pressure (IOP) Most treatments do not directly target the pathological changes leading to increased IOP.

Blood leukocyte counts are easily accessible markers of immune function. Their association with the risk of AD is unknown. Study included 101 582 participants with a median age of 58 years. Of these, 1588 individuals developed AD.

Physical activity is correlated with, and effectively treats various forms of psychopathology. However, whether biological correlates of physical activity and psychopathology are shared remains unclear. Here, we examined the extent to which the neural and genetic architecture ofphysical activity and mental health are shared.

Metabolic dysfunction-associated fatty liver disease (MAFLD) is recently recognized as a condition featured with metabolic dysfunctions in liver. It has been supposed that MAFLD might contribute to the development of IBD, but evidence from prospective cohort studies is lacking and inconclusive.

Lipid metabolism plays a central role in the development of atherosclerotic cardiovascular disease. Sex differences in the levels of 141 lipid species were observed. 121 lipid species showed significant age-sex interactions. Most of the cholesteryl esters, ceramides, lysophospholipids, and glycerides were higher in 45- to 50-year-old men.

The aim of this study is to explore the relationship between birth weight and adult bone mass. We found that higher birth weight could increase the adult bone area (lumbar spine)

The current state-of-the-art imputation quality metric, denoted as standard Rsq, is poorly calibrated for lower-frequency variants. We propose MagicalRsq, a machine-learning-based method that integrates variant-level imputation and population genetics statistics.

Incident all-cause heart failure was prospectively ascertained via hospital inpatient and death records, followed up to May 31, 2021.

Genome-wide association studies (GWAS) on diverse ancestry groups are lacking, resulting in deficits of genetic discoveries and polygenic scores. We conducted GWAS for 76 phenotypes in Korean biobank data, namely the Korean Genome and Epidemiology Study. Our analysis discovered 2,242 associated loci, including 122 novel associations.

Arterial stiffness, measured by arterial stiffness index (ASI), can be considered as a major denominator in cardiovascular diseases. This study investigates among UK Biobank participants without cardiovascular diseases, the hypothesis that K-means cluster analysis can be used to identify homogeneous phenotyping subgroups of participants.

We aim to explore the potential interaction effects of mitochondrial function and human behavior on the risks of anxiety and depression. Brain imaging outcomes are important for Alzheimer's disease detection. Prediction based on both genetic and demographic risk factors can facilitate prevention and treatment of AD. Existing studies have identified numerous significantly AD-associated SNPs.

Resting heart rate (RHR) has been linked with an increased risk of dementia. This study aims to investigate the relationships of RHR with different dementia types, cognitive function, and brain structural abnormalities.

From 2006 to 2010, 254,575 women and 214,891 men were included from the UK Biobank. Cox regression estimated overall and sex-specific hazard ratios (HRs) for apolipoprotein A (ApoA), ApoB, HDL, LDL, total cholesterol, triglycerides, lipoprotein A, and various lipid ratios, by quarters and standard deviation (SD) higher.

Calcification of large arteries is a high-risk factor in the development of cardiovascular diseases. Due to the lack of routine monitoring, the pathology remains severely under-diagnosed. We have developed a set of machine learning methods to quantitate levels of abdominal aortic calcification.

Study investigated whether a healthy lifestyle is associated with lower CRC risk, regardless of genetic risk. We recruited 390,365 participants without cancer at baseline (2006-2010) from the UK Biobank. A healthy lifestyle score was constructed using 16 factors of six dimensions.

FS in beverages were significantly associated with depression risk in an ascending approximately linear way with the lowest HR at 4%.

Several genes have been proposed as causal for maturity-onset diabetes of the young (MODY) Scoring systems to annotate mutation pathogenicity have been widely used. However, statistical evidence for being a highly penetrant MODY gene has not been well-established.

There is increasing evidence suggesting a shared genetic basis between IPF and other diseases. We identified 12 candidate genes across 13 genomic regions using local genetic correlation. Two TFs showed significant enrichment in both partitioned heritability and cell-type-specific DEGs.

Brain imaging-derived phenotypes (IDPs) and psychiatric disorders have been reported. Whether the relationships are causal is uncertain. We identified nine IDPs for which there was evidence of a causal influence on risk of schizophrenia, anorexia nervosa and bipolar disorder.

Occupational exposures may play a key role in severe acute respiratory syndrome coronavirus 2 (SARS-CoV-2) infection risk. We used a job-exposure matrix linked to the UK Biobank to measure occupational characteristics.

 Observational studies have suggested a potential non-linear association between sleep duration and hyperuricemia. However, the causal nature and sex-specific differences are poorly understood. We aimed to determine the shape of sex- specific causal associations. Genetically predicted short sleep duration is a potential causal risk factor for hyperurICemia for females but has little effect on males. Long sleep duration does not appear to be causally associated with hyperurica.

Metabolic syndrome may contribute to the rising incidence of multiple gastrointestinal (GI) cancers. The association between nonalcoholic fatty liver disease (NAFLD) and risk of non-liver GI cancers is unexplored. We prospectively examined the associations of NAFLD risk with GI cancers among 319,290 participants in the UK Biobank (2006-2019)

A higher PRS was associated with increased odds of type 2 diabetes in all ancestries.

Research into idiopathic pulmonary fibrosis (IPF) has been limited by the rarity of the disease itself. Global biobanking efforts can dramatically alter the future of IPF research.

A total of 305,969 participants from the UK Biobank Cohort - an open access cohort of 500,000 participants recruited in the United Kingdom between 2006 and 2010 - were included in the study. For every 10dB increase in road traffic noise, there was a 4% increase in T2D risk.

White, South Asian and Black UK Biobank participants recruited from 2006-2010 and followed up until 2020. During follow-up, 5,972 people (2.03%) developed dementia. Risk of dementia was higher in Black participants than White participants. Association between each risk factor and dementia was similar in each ethnic group.

Previous studies have suggested that gene-environment interactions (GEIs) between a common variant and an environmental factor can influence multiple correlated phenotypes simultaneously. Methods to test the GEI for rare variants with multiple phenotypes are, however, lacking. We propose four multiphenotype GEI tests for rare variant.

Common single-nucleotide polymorphisms (SNPs) are predicted to collectively explain 40-50% of phenotypic variation in human height. Identifying the specific variants and associated regions requires huge sample sizes. We show that 12,111 independent SNPs that are significantly associated with height account for nearly all of the common SNP-based heritability.

Overweight and obesity are well-established risk factors for COVID-19 severity. Less is known about the role of sedentary behaviors such as television (TV) viewing. We analyzed 329,751 UK Biobank participants to investigate the independent and combined associations of BMI and self-reported TV viewing time.

Few studies have examined the long-term association between stair climbing and the incidence of type 2 diabetes (T2D) We included 451,699 adults without T2D at baseline in the UK Biobank and followed up to 2021.

TL-PRS uses gradient descent to fine-tune the baseline PRS model from an ancestry group with large sample GWASs to the dataset of target ancestry. In our application of constructing PRS for seven quantitative and two dichotomous traits for 10,285 individuals of South Asian ancestry and 8,168 individuals of African ancestry in UK Biobank we obtained 25% average relative improvement for South Asian samples.

The modification of physical activity (PA) on the metabolic status in relation to atrial fibrillation (AF) in obesity remains unknown. We aimed to investigate the independent and joint associations of metabolic status and PA with the risk of AF in obese population. MHO was significantly associated with a 35% reduced AF risk compared with MUO.

We develop a framework to infer the effect of potential, hidden mediators influencing complex traits. This framework can be used to place boundaries on unexplained risk factors contributing tocomplex traits.

Physically-demanding occupations may increase rotator cuff disease (RCD) risk and need for surgery. We linked a job-exposure matrix (JEM) to the UK Biobank cohort study to measure physical occupational exposures. Of 277 808 people reporting jobs, 1997 (0.7%) had an inpatient RCD surgery.

South Asians have a two- to fivefold higher risk of developing type 2 diabetes than those of white European descent. Greater central adiposity and storage of fat in deeper or ectopic depots are potential contributing mechanisms. We summarised imaging data on SAT, VAT and liver fat from eight published and three previously unpublished datasets.

Cloud computing makes access to supercomputers affordable. Deep learning software libraries make programming statistical algorithms easy. Fitting this half-million-variate model takes less than 45 minutes and reconfirms known associations.

The coronavirus disease 2019 (COVID-19) pandemic has demonstrated the value of real-world data for public health research. Common data models (CDMs) are critical for enabling these studies to be performed efficiently. We converted UK Biobank data to OMOP CDM v. 5.3.

Evidence concerning the associations of ambient air pollution exposure with bone mineral density and osteoporosis has been mixed. We conducted a cross-sectional and prospective analysis of the associations between air pollution and osteoarthritis using data from the UK Biobank study. Among the 341,311 participants at baseline, higher pollution exposure was associated with lower eBMD levels and increased odds of osteop orosis.

The multiple comorbidities & dimensions of chronic pain present a formidable challenge in disentangling its aetiology. We performed genome-wide association studies of 8 chronic pain types using UK Biobank data. Across 5,942 significant genetic correlations, 570 trait pairs could be explained by a causal association (|GCP| >0.6; 5% false discovery rate)

Hyperopia was significantly associated with an increased risk of incident CSD. This was independent of genetic predisposition to hyperopia. This emphasises the importance of regular vision screening and correction of hyperopia to reduce the risk of CSD regardless of genetic risk.

Habitual coffee consumption is an addictive behavior with unknown genetic variations. We performed exome-wide association studies to identify rare risk variants. A total of 34,761 qualifying variants were imported into SKAT.

Perivascular spaces (PVS) are emerging markers of cerebral small vessel disease (CSVD) Research on their determinants has been hampered by conflicting results from small single studies using heterogeneous rating methods. We aimed to identify determinants of PVS burden in a pooled analysis of multiple cohort studies using 1 harmonized PVS rating method.

A longer duration of hypertension (HTN) has been suggested to be associated with a greater risk of cardiovascular disease (CVD) Whether such an association is similar for mortality risk, and whether HTN duration is associated with CVD/mortality beyond blood pressure (BP) control levels are yet to be assessed. We aimed to examine the associations of HTN. duration and the combination of HTn duration and systolic blood pressure. with risks of CVD and all-cause mortality.

Pathogenic variants in HNF1A, HNF4A, and GCK account for >80% of monogenic diabetes. We show that one in 1,500 individuals harbor a pathogenic variant in one of these genes. The penetrance of diabetes for these variants was substantially lower in the clinically unselected individuals compared to clinically referred probands.

 Meta-analyses of randomized controlled trials (RCTs) have demonstrated the efficacy of vitamin D supplementation for reduced cancer mortality, all-cause mortality, and respiratory tract infections. However, whether and to what extent this translates into effectiveness in real-world practice is unknown.

Recent studies have shown that obesity is associated with asthma in adults. The relationship between childhood obesity and childhood asthma remains to be clarified. In the present study, we investigated the shared genetic components between body mass index (BMI, n = 39620) in children and Childhood asthma. The findings shed light on childhood asthma pathogenic mechanisms and prevention.

Non-alcoholic fatty liver disease (NAFLD) is a complex disease linked to several chronic diseases. We aimed at identifying genetic variants associated with NAFLD and evaluating their functional consequences. We performed a genome-wide meta-analysis of 4 cohorts of electronic health record-documented NAFLd in participants of European ancestry (8,434 cases and 770,180 controls)

Developing functional insight into the causal molecular drivers of immunological disease is a critical challenge in genomic medicine. We systematically apply Mendelian randomization (MR), genetic colocalization, immune-cell-type enrichment, and phenome-wide association methods to investigate the effects of genetically predicted gene expression on ten immune-associated diseases and four cancer outcomes.

The discovery of human obesity-associated genes can reveal new mechanisms to target for weight loss therapy. We uncovered a large number of rare homozygous gene variants by exome sequencing of severely obese children. We identified 4 genes, not previously linked to human obesity, that regulate adiposity (itpr, dachsous, calpA, and sdk)

Clinical classification is essential for estimating disease prevalence but is difficult, often requiring complex investigations. The widespread availability of population level genetic data makes novel genetic stratification techniques a highly attractive alternative.

Cardiorespiratory fitness (CRF) and physical activity (PA) are well-established predictors of morbidity and all-cause mortality. CRF is not routinely measured and PA not routinely prescribed as part of standard healthcare. We leverage genetic data in the UK Biobank to strengthen the case for CRF as a vital sign.

Disease heterogeneity is a significant obstacle to understanding pathological processes and delivering precision diagnostics and treatment. Clustering methods have gained popularity for stratifying patients into subpopulations of brain diseases using imaging data. Unsupervised clustering approaches are often confounded by anatomical and functional variations not related to a disease or pathology of interest.

Illumina developed a more efficient and scalable version of our mobile element locator tool (MELT) We then used MELT to perform MEI discovery in 57,919 human genomes and exomes. This led to the discovery of 104,350 nonredundant MEIs. We leveraged this collection to examine potentially active L1 source elements.

 orbital telorism is a distinctive craniofacial trait that also serves as a clinically informative measure. Heritability estimates were 76% (standard error = 12%) with a family-based method. Genome-wide association studies in 34 130 Europeans identified 56 significantly associated genomic loci.

Vitamin D status of the UK African-Caribbean population remains under-researched. Over one third of the population were deficient ( 50 nmol/L) Winter blood draw, not consuming oily fish and not using vitamin D supplements predicted increased odds of vitamin D deficiency.

We examined data collected from 7,152 participants of the United Kingdom Biobank study. Consistent weekly attendance at a sports club or gym was associated with connectivity of the sensorimotor functional network with the lateral visual and cerebellar networks. Visiting friends and family across the two timepoints was also associated with larger volumes of the occipital lobe.

Maternal blood pressure (BP) during pregnancy is associated with increased future risk of offspring cardiometabolic disease. It is unclear whether this association represents a causal relationship through intrauterine mechanisms. We used a Mendelian randomization framework to examine the relationship between unweighted maternal genetic scores for systolic BP and diastolic BP. We found little evidence to support the notion that maternal BP is a major causal risk factor.

Hypertension is a leading contributor to the global burden of disease and to mortality. The combined effects of sleep factors on the risk of hypertension are unclear. We aimed to evaluate whether this association is independent of genetic risk. A total of 170,378 participants were included in the UK Biobank study.

Based on up to 352,277 European ancestry participants in the UK Biobank, we constructed polygenic risk scores for 15 physiological and biochemical quantitative traits. We identified a total of 185 polygenic prediction variability quantitative trait loci for 11 traits.

Hip fracture is the clinically most important fracture, but the genetic architecture of hip fracture is unclear. Here, we perform a large-scale hip fracture genome-wide association study meta-analysis and Mendelian randomization study. The results show that five genetic signals associate with hip fractures.

We used logistic regression to investigate the joint associations of physical activity level (high: &#8805;3000 MET-min/week) and TV viewing time with COVID-19 mortality risk in UK Biobank. Additional models were performed with adjustment for body mass index (BMI) and waist circumference.

Mosaic chromosomal alterations (mCAs) detected from blood-derived DNA are large structural alterations of clonal haematopoietic origin. We aimed to investigate whether mCAs contribute to the risk of lung cancer and modify the effect of polygenic risk score on lung cancer risk prediction.

It remains unknown whether higher dietary intake of antioxidant vitamins could reduce the harmful effects of air pollution on incident diabetes mellitus. Antioxidant vitamin intake was measured using a 24-h food intake questionnaire. Exposure to fine particles (PM 2.5, PM 10, NO 2 ) was estimated using land use regression models at participants' residences.

Mitral annular disjunction is the atrial displacement of the mural mitral valve leaflet hinge point within the atrioventricular junction. Said to be associated with malignant ventricular arrhythmias and sudden death.

 Theory for liability-scale models of the underlying genetic basis of complex disease provides an important way to interpret, compare, and understand results. liability models facilitate an understanding and comparison of the relative importance of genetic and environmental risk factors that shape different clinically important disease outcomes.

Depression and anxiety are two major categories of mental disorders that are highly prevalent in the general population. We calculate genetic risk scores for depression, anxiety and mental disorders based on 37/44 single-nucleotide polymorphisms (SNPs) of Major Depressive Disorder (MDD) and 9/10 SNPs of anxiety. People with pre-frailty and frailty suffered higher risks ofmental disorders than the non-frail group.

Pathogenic and likely pathogenic variants associated with arrhythmogenic right ventricular cardiomyopathy (ARVC) are recommended to be reported as secondary findings in genome sequencing studies. This provides opportunities for early diagnosis, but also fuels uncertainty in variant carriers (G+) We assessed the prevalence and disease expression of G+ in the general population.

Regular use of non-steroidal anti-inflammatory drugs (NSAIDs) was associated with the lower risk of colorectal cancer (CRC) Whether regular use of NSAIDs could attenuate the effect of genetic risk and environmental risk factors on CRC is unknown.

Candidate gene studies have identified genetic variants associated with clinical outcomes following aneurysmal subarachnoid haemorrhage (aSAH) No genome-wide association studies have been performed to date.

Evidence on the association between air pollution and dementia is accumulating but still inconclusive. The potential effect modification by genetics is unclear. We investigated the joint effects of air pollution exposure and genetic risk on incident dementia.

Study included cancer-free UK Biobank participants aged 40-69 years. Alcohol consumption was categorised based on current UK guidelines into four groups. Risk of obesity-related cancer increased with higher adiposity in a dose-response manner.

Diet is a modifiable risk factor for common chronic diseases and mental health disorders. Diet indices enable a holistic estimation of diet and account for the intercorrelations between food and nutrients. We identified seven independent single-nucleotide polymorphisms (SNPs) associated with DASH.

Diabetic kidney disease (DKD) affects about 40% of patients with diabetes. It is incurable and usually leads to end-stage renal disease (ESRD) The genetics of DKD have not yet been extensively studied.

Different populations may exhibit differences in dietary intakes, which may result in heterogeneities in diet-disease associations. We compared intakes of major food groups overall, by sex, and by socio-economic status (SES) between participants in the China Kadoorie Biobank (CKB) and the UK Biobanks (UKB)

QT interval length is an important risk factor for adverse cardiovascular outcomes. The genetic architecture of QT interval remains incompletely understood. We conducted a genome-wide association study of 76,995 ancestrally diverse Kaiser Permanente members.

COVID-19 cases were defined using health record linkage. Each case was propensity score-matched to two uninfected controls on age, sex, deprivation, body mass index, ethnicity, diabetes, prevalent ischaemic heart disease, smoking, hypertension and high cholesterol.

Nonalcoholic fatty liver (NAFL) and its sequelae are growing health problems. We performed a genome-wide association study of NAFL, cirrhosis and hepatocellular carcinoma. We found rare, protective, predicted loss-of-function variants in MTARC1 and GPAM, underscoring them as potential drug targets.

Low vitamin D status is associated with increased mortality, but randomized trials on severely deficient participants are lacking. UK Biobank, a large-scale, prospective cohort from England, Scotland, and Wales with participants recruited between March 2006 and July 2010. All-cause and cause-specific mortality were recorded up to June 2020.

Intracranial volume, measured through magnetic resonance imaging and/or estimated from head circumference, is heritable and correlates with cognitive traits and several neurological disorders. Parkinson's disease cases have greater and attention deficit hyperactivity disorder cases smaller intracranialvolume than controls.

Study examined the effect of air pollutants exposure on CKD in the European population. 458,968 participants from the UK Biobank were included in this study. The associations between air pollutants and CKD were modest and marginal in the high genetic risk population.

Vigorous physical activity (VPA) is a time-efficient way to achieve recommended physical activity levels. There is a very limited understanding of the minimal and optimal amounts of vigorous physical activity in relation to mortality and disease incidence.

The interplay between physical activity (PA) volume and intensity is poorly understood. This study aimed to investigate the role of PA intensity, over and above volume, in relation to incident CVD. Data were from 88 412 UK Biobank middle-aged adults (58% women) without prevalent CVD who wore accelerometers for 7 days.

Ultra-processed food (UPF) consumption has been linked to increased incidence and prevalence of chronic diseases, including inflammatory bowel diseases. We aimed to investigate the association between UPF consumption and IBD incidence, prevalence, and I BD-relevant outcomes. We performed a cross-sectional and prospective cohort study in 187 854 individuals included in the national UK Biobank.

Heavy drinking was well associated with an increased risk of hepatocellular carcinoma (HCC) The effect of low-to-moderate drinking on HCC remains under debate.

From 2013 to 2015, 106,053 UK Biobank participants took part in a 7-day accelerometer test. Glaucoma patients spent 4.7% less time on MVPA in multivariable models. Compared with those with normal body mass index, the decreased MVPA time was more pronounced in participants with overweight and obesity.

Study included 33,236 participants (aged 40-72) with type 2 diabetes from the UK Biobank. Favorable CVH metrics consisted of non-smoker, regular physical activity, a healthy diet, non-overweight, untreated resting blood pressure   3 mg/L.

Circulating levels of amino acids were associated with blood pressure (BP) in observational studies. The causation of such associations has been hypothesized but is difficult to prove in human studies. Here, we aimed to use two-sample Mendelian randomization analyses to evaluate the potential causal associations.

Metabolic profile in middle-to-older age can predict cancer incidence, in particular risk of obesity-related cancer, hematologic malignancies, and liver cancer. Elevated values from liver tests are strong predictors for later risk of Liver cancer.

Previous studies showed that gestational diabetes mellitus (GDM) can be a risk factor for subsequent atherosclerotic cardiovascular disease. There is a paucity of information regarding diverse cardiovascular outcomes in elderly women after GDM. We examined whether women with GDM have an increased risk for long-term overall cardiovascular outcomes.

End-stage renal disease is associated with a high risk of cardiovascular events. It is unknown whether mild-to-moderate kidney dysfunction is causally related to coronary heart disease (CHD) and stroke. Using a genetic risk score of 218 variants for estimated glomerular filtration rate (eGFR), we conducted Mendelian randomization analyses involving 413 718 participants.

T2D diagnosed at a younger age was associated with larger reductions in brain volume. After adjustment for glycated haemoglobin (HbA1c) and other covariates, only T1D diagnosed.

Researchers have identified an association between lifestyle factors and colorectal cancer (CRC) risk. 392,252 individuals were sampled from the UK Biobank. Healthy sleep scores were inversely associated with CRC events.

We used data from the UK biobank of 204,646 adults aged 37-73 free of dementia at baseline. Genetic risk for dementia including APOE &#949;4 status and polygenic risk score (PRS) categorized as low, intermediate, and high. CMDs including ischemic heart disease (IHD), stroke, and type 2 diabetes (T2D) were confirmed by touchscreen questionnaires.

Air pollution is associated with different progressions and outcomes of T2D. Exposures to particulate matter with a diameter &#8804; 10 &#956;m (PM10), PM2.5, nitrogen oxides (NOx), and NO2 for each transition stage were estimated at each participant's residential addresses using data from the UK's Department for Environment, Food and Rural Affairs.

A decreased estimated glomerular filtration rate (eGFR) leading to chronic kidney disease is a significant public health problem. Kidney function is a heritable trait, and recent application of genome-wide association studies (GWAS) successfully identified multiple eGFR-associated genetic loci. We improved our recently developed quasi-adaptive method estimating SNP-specific alpha levels for the conditional analysis.

Pancreatic ductal adenocarcinoma (PDAC) is a component of familial melanoma. It is unclear what role this gene or other genes play in its etiology. We analyzed 189 cancer predisposition genes using parametric rare-variant association (RVA) tests and nonparametric permutation tests.

The aim of this study was to examine the associations of fine particulate matter (PM2.5) and physical activity (PA) with age-related cataract and its subtypes. A total of 291,627 participants enrolled in the UK Biobank cohort during 2006-2010 was included.

Contactin-5 (CNTN5) is a candidate risk gene for autism spectrum disorder (ASD) Previous attempts to associate CNTN 5 CNVs with ASD-susceptibility were limited by insufficient statistical power. We aim to clarify the putative association between CNTn5 CNVs and ASD-risk using large-scale case-control analyses.

Multiple human pathogens establish chronic, sometimes life-long infections. These infections can trigger some degree of local or systemic immune response. There remains an incomplete understanding of the potential contribution of persistent infections and human genetic variation on chronic low-grade inflammation. We searched for potential associations between seropositivity for 13 persistent pathogens and the plasma levels of the inflammatory biomarker C-reactive protein (CRP)

Despite the increasing popularity of supplement use among the cancer community, the current evidence on its effect on mortality in large studies is inconclusive. This study examined the association of dietary supplement use with mortality risk in a large population-based cohort.

Self-reported trauma exposure has consistently been found to be a risk factor for major depressive disorder (MDD) To date, most studies have examined gene-environment interactions with trauma exposure using genome-wide variants (single-nucleotide variations [SNVs) or polygenic scores. The current study used available cross-sectional genomic and trauma exposure data from UK Biobank.

There is a link between factors related to ovulation and reproductive function and endometrial cancer (EC) risk. It is not clear whether these relationships are causal, and whether the risk factors act independently of each other. The aim of this study was to investigate putative causal relationships between the number of live births and EC risk.

Hypertension remains the major cardiovascular disease risk factor globally. variability in measured blood pressure may result in suboptimal management. Blood pressure polygenic risk score may augment identification of individuals at heightened cardiovascular risk. Whether it may also guide antihypertensive initiation or intensification requires further study.

Study was a prospective cohort study in the UK Biobank. Snoring, daytime sleepiness, insomnia, and short/long duration, individually or jointly, were all associated with the risk of glaucoma.

Aims: To identify metabolites associated with a healthy lifestyle and explore the possible mechanisms of lifestyle in coronary artery disease (CAD) The nuclear magnetic resonance metabolomics platform was applied to perform metabolomic profiling of baseline plasma samples from a subset of 121 733 UK Biobank participants.

Physical activity (PA) is recommended in the management of non-alcoholic fatty liver disease (NAFLD) Using data from the UK Biobank population-cohort, this study examined associations between habitual PA and hepatic fibro-inflammation.

In UK Biobank, a total of 308,534 dementia-free participants with valid lung function measures (forced expiratory volume in 1 s [FEV1] and forced vital capacity [FVC]) were included. Restrictive impairment (hazard ratio [HR], 1.42; 95% confidence interval [CI] 1.27-1.60) and obstructive impairment were associated with higher risk of all-cause dementia.

Study aimed to investigate the association between residential greenness and dementia incidence. The effects of particulate air pollution on mediating dementia were also determined. Results indicated that there were 4929 ACD, 2132 AD, and 1184 VD incidents.

Information theory-based measures of variable dependency have been implemented into a software package, MIST. The design of the software and its potential uses are described, and a demonstration is presented in the discovery of modifier alleles of the ApoE gene in affecting Alzheimer's disease.

Spinal cord cross-sectional area (CSA) is a relevant biomarker to assess spinal cord atrophy in neurodegenerative diseases. However, the considerable inter-subject variability among healthy participants currently limits its usage. Previous studies explored factors contributing to the variability, yet the normalization models required manual intervention and used vertebral levels as a reference.

Previous studies have shown anti-cancer and anti-inflammatory benefits of glucosamine. This study was performed to prospectively evaluate the association between glucosamines and the mortality of multiple cancers. A total of 453,645 participants aged 38-73 who had no cancer at baseline were recruited between 2006 and 2010.

PM 2.5 , smoking, and genetic factors are associated with lung cancer. Relationship between PM 2. 5 , smoking and subtypes of lung cancer remains unclear. It is unclear whether genetic risk modifies the impact of PM2.5 and smoking.

Preeclampsia and gestational hypertensive disorders (GHD) are common complications of pregnancy. High BMI, advanced age, and pre-existing conditions are known risk factors for GHD. This study demonstrates that a risk score developed with machine learning from the case-control genetics dataset can be used as an early screening test.

Study aims to describe the grading methods and baseline characteristics for UK Biobank participants who underwent retinal imaging in 2009-2010. Captured retinal features included those associated with age-related macular degeneration (AMD), glaucoma and retinopathy.

Metabolic traits are heritable phenotypes widely-used in assessing the risk of various diseases. We conduct a genome-wide association analysis (GWAS) of nine metabolic traits in 125,872 Korean subjects.

Adults with congenital heart disease (CHD) face increased risk of various comorbid diseases. Previous work on lung dysfunction in this population has mainly focused on restrictive lung disease, in patients with severe CHD phenotypes. We examined the association of mild CHD with chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD) in the UK Biobank.

Study examined the interplay of apolipoprotein B (apoB) and LDL particle size, approximated by the LDL-cholesterol (LDL-C)/apoB ratio, on the risk of new-onset coronary heart disease (CHD) For all 3 cohorts, CHD risk was higher for higher levels of apoB.

Comparing with the general population, the pain in depression patients has more complex biological mechanism. We aim to explore the etiological mechanism of pain in depressed patients from the perspective of genetics. Utilizing the UK Biobank samples with self-reported depression status, we conducted genome-wide association studies of seven pain traits.

Large epidemiological studies such as the UK Biobank (UKBB) or German National Cohort (NAKO) provide unprecedented health-related data of the general population. As part of these studies, Magnetic Resonance Imaging (MRI) is performed in a subset of participants allowing for phenotypical and functional characterization of different organ systems.

Low serum 25(OH)D3 (vD) is an environmental risk factor for multiple sclerosis (MS) Lower vD levels during early disease may be associated with long-term disability. We developed a vD-weighted genetic risk score (GRS) and validated this in 373,357 UK Biobank participants without MS.

Identical genetic variations can have different phenotypic effects depending on their parent of origin. Studies focusing on parent-of-origin effects have been limited in terms of sample size due to the lack of parental genomes or known genealogies. We propose a probabilistic approach that does not require parental genomes nor prior knowledge of genealogy. We combine this with robust haplotype inference and haploid imputation to infer the parent- of-origin for 26,393 UK Biobank individuals.

Of the 1.3 billion smokers globally, 80% live in low- and middle-income countries. The number of deaths due to tobacco use is expected to double in the next decade according to the World Health Organization.

UK Biobank participants (n = 359,153) without diabetes at baseline were included. Exposure to air pollution, including PM2.5, PMcoarse, PM10, and NO2, was estimated from land use regression models. Compared with a low PA level, the HRs for the risk of T2D among individuals with moderate and high PA were 0.82 and 0.73.

Previous genetic MPB prediction models were limited by sparse marker coverage, small sample size, and/or data dependency in the different analytical steps. We selected 117 SNP predictors within 85 distinct loci from a list of 270 previously MPB-associated SNPs in 55,573 males of the UK Biobank Study. Based on these 117 SNPs with and without age as additional predictor, we trained, by use of different methods, prediction models.

 Milk consumption is a modifiable lifestyle factor that has been associated with several cancer types in observational studies. Limited evidence exists regarding the causality of these relationships. Using a genetic variant (rs4988235) near the lactase gene (LCT) locus that proxies milk consumption, we conducted a comprehensive survey to assess potential causal relationships.

 Globally, more than 1.9 billion adults are overweight. Obesity is a major risk factor for diabetes mellitus, coronary heart disease, and cardiovascular disease. Information on genome-wide genetic variants has been used to estimate the genome- wide polygenic score (GPS)

Study of brain asymmetry has focused on pairwise comparisons between homologous regions. By pooling information on left-right shifts underlying whole-brain structure, we deconvolved signatures. Classically asymmetric regions turned out to belong to more than one asymmetry pattern.

Asthma is a heterogeneous, complex syndrome, and identifying asthma endotypes has been challenging. We hypothesize that distinct endotypes of asthma arise in disparate genetic variation and life-time environmental exposure backgrounds. We computationally discover 22 distinct comorbid disease patterns among individuals with asthma.

Study of 291,305 unrelated White British UK Biobank participants enrolled from 2006 to 2010. Case-control sample of 9499 prevalent CAD cases and an equal number of randomly selected controls was used for tuning and integrating of the polygenic risk scores. A separate cohort of 272,307 individuals was used to examine the risk prediction performance of pooled cohort equations.

Atrial fibrillation (AF) is the most common cardiac arrhythmia. It is associated with a higher risk of important adverse health outcomes such as stroke and death. AF is linked to distinct electro-anatomic alterations. The main tool for AF diagnosis is the Electrocardiogram (ECG)

Hearing impairment was recently identified as the most prominent risk factor for dementia. However, the mechanisms underlying the link between hearing impairment and dementia are still unclear. We investigated the association of hearing performance with cognitive function, brain structure and cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) proteins.

Integrating polygenic risk scores with QCancer-10 modestly improves risk prediction. The added benefit, cost effectiveness, and acceptability of polygenicrisk scores should be carefully evaluated in a real life screening setting.

Schizophrenia (SCZ) and bipolar disorder (BD) are severe psychiatric conditions that can involve symptoms of psychosis and cognitive dysfunction. The 2 conditions share symptomatology and genetic etiology. We examined how genetic liability to SCZ and BD shapes normative variations in brain connectivity.
