The relationship of triglyceride-rich lipoproteins with risk of coronary heart disease (CHD) compared with low-density lipoprotein (LDL) is yet to be resolved. Single-nucleotide polymorphisms (SNPs) associated with TRL/remnant cholesterol and LDL cholesterol were identified in the UK Biobank population.

Dietary iron intake was measured using a web-based 24-h dietary recall questionnaire from 2009 to 2012. Incident dementia was ascertained using hospital inpatient records and death registers until April 2021. Cox proportional regression models examined the association between iron intake and incident dementia.

 limited evidence is available on residential green space and risk of incident type 2 diabetes (T2D) We conducted a prospective analysis in UK Biobank. Of 379,238 participants at baseline, 15564 incident T2D cases were identified with 12.4 years of follow-up. In main models, individuals who exposed to green space at 300 m buffer in high level had 14.4 % (95 % CI: 8.0 %, 20.3 %) lower risk.

Left ventricular maximum wall thickness (LVMWT) is an important biomarker of left ventricular hypertrophy and provides diagnostic and prognostic information in hypertrophic cardiomyopathy (HCM) We performed a genome-wide association study of LVMWT measured from the cardiovascular magnetic resonance examinations of 42 176 European individuals.

Large longitudinal studies exploring the role of dietary patterns in the assessment of long-term outcomes of NAFLD are still lacking. We conducted a prospective analysis of 128,695 UK Biobank participants. Cox proportional hazards models were used to estimate the risk associated with two dietary patterns.

Hypertension might be a modifiable risk factor for neurodegeneration diseases. The associations between blood pressure (BP), arterial stiffness index and retinal neurodegneration remain unclear. This study used cross-sectional data from the United Kingdom BioBank and longitudinal data from Chinese Ocular Imaging Project.

Physical activity (PA) plays an important role in health outcomes for people with cancer. Less is known about the PA of lung cancer patients. The strong history of smoking could influence pre-diagnosis levels of PA.

Few studies have explored the genetic underpinnings of intra-abdominal visceral fat deposition. A genome-wide significant signal was found on chromosome 2q14.3 in the sex-combined GWAS. The negatively associated variants were most common in European Americans and African Americans and not observed in Japanese Americans.

Modern healthcare data reflect massive multi-level and multi-scale information collected over many years. This paper aims to study the time to disease onset and progression and identify the time-varying risk factors that drive them. We developed an algorithmic approach to phenotyping the incidence of diseases.

Statins might modulate the gut microbiome and alleviate systematic inflammation, which in turn, may have a protective effect against irritable bowel syndrome (IBS) The aim of our study was to evaluate the gender-specific association between statin exposure and the risk of IBS.

Polygenic risk scores (PRS) of gut microbiota were calculated from individual-level genotype data of the UK Biobank cohort. Interaction analysis identified several significant genes that interacted with gut microbiota, such as RORA and ASTN2. Our study results support the genetic effects of gut bacteria on the development of neuroticism and general happiness.

Genome-wide association studies (GWAS) of suicidal thoughts and behaviors support the existence of genetic contributions. Suicidality (h2 = 7.6%) had higher h2 than the S-factor (h1 = 2.54, Pdiff = 4.78)

We use UK Biobank and a unique IVF family dataset to investigate sibling variation in both phenotype and genotype. We develop a novel sibling-pair method for detection of recombination breaks via statistical discontinuities. The new method is used to construct a dataset of 1.44 million recombination events.

Study looked at 314,093 participants from the UK Biobank. Frailty phenotype was assessed according to the five criteria of Fried et al. The ideal CVH was significantly associated with a lower risk of all CVD outcomes.

Cardiovascular disease is a major cause of excess mortality in people with schizophrenia. Several factors are responsible, including lifestyle and metabolic effects of antipsychotics. We aimed to explore whether shared genetic causes contribute to these cardiac variations. High polygenic risk scores for schizophrenia are associated with decreased cardiac volumes and increased ejection fractions.

The geometric patterns of ventricular remodeling are determined using indexed left ventricular mass (LVM), end-diastolic volume (LVEDV) and concentricity, most often measured using the mass-to-volume ratio (MVR) The aims of this study were to validate lean body mass-based allometric coefficients for scaling and to determine an index of concentricITY that is independent of both volume and LBM.

Magnitude-based PDFF (Proton Density Fat Fraction) and R 2  &#8727; is extended to calculate field inhomogeneity (field map) using the phase images. The estimation is formulated in matrix form, resolving the field map in a least-squares sense. The limits of quantification of our voxel-independent implementation were assessed.

Alzheimer's disease (AD) is the most common late-onset neurodegenerative disorder. Identifying individuals at increased risk of developing AD is important for early intervention. Using data from the Alzheimer Disease Genetics Consortium, we constructed polygenic risk scores (PRSs) for AD. We then built machine learning (ML) models for predicting development of AD.

Genome-wide polygenic scores were developed and validated for femoral neck and total body BMD. Out of four studied PGSs, PGS_TBBMD81 had the weakest predictive accuracy. Incorporating PGS into clinical diagnosis is anticipated to increase the population-level screening benefits.

A total of 495,700 participants from the UK Biobank were included in this study. Walking pace was self-defined as slow, average, or brisk. Handgrip strength was assessed by dynamometer and was divided into sex-specific quartiles. Other dementia risk factors, including education, physical activity, hypertension, depression, diabetes, and family history of dementia, were also collected.

The associations of serum 25(OH)D, sun exposure time, and dietary vitamin D with risk of acute kidney injury (AKI) are unclear. We aimed to evaluate the relations of these factors with new-onset AKI and examine whether genetic susceptibility modified such associations.

Polygenic risk scores (PRS) are expected to play an increasingly important role in clinical risk stratification. To improve the predictive performance of PRS, it is desirable to fit multivariable models directly on the genetic data. We develop an adapted component-wise  L   2 -boosting algorithm to fit genotype data from large cohort studies.

Study included 15,104 patients with T2D free of macro- and microvascular complications at baseline (2006 to 2010) Healthy lifestyle behaviors included noncurrent smoking, recommended waist circumference, regular physical activity, healthy diet, and moderate alcohol drinking. Over a median of 8.1 years of follow-up, 1,296 cases of the composite microv vascular complications occurred.

UK Biobank is a prospective cohort study of 500,000 adults aged 40-69 years at recruitment (2006-2010) 4.5% of English UKB participants had a positive microbiological isolate in 2015. Half of UKB isolates came from 12 laboratories, and 70% from 21 laboratories.

Carotid intima-media thickness (CIMT) is a marker of subclinical atherosclerosis. We assessed the independent relevance of general adiposity (body mass index), central adiposity, and body composition with CIMT among adults in the United Kingdom. After mutual adjustment, body mass index remained positively associated with C IMT, but waist circumference was completely attenuated.

Patients with cardiomyopathies often exhibit other cardiac conditions, such as atrial fibrillation (Afib), which has also been linked to TTNtvs. A combination of hiPSI TTNtv status and early Afib diagnosis (before age 60) found a subset ofTTNtv individuals at high risk for CM.

We examined associations of BMI category and grip strength tertile with risk of severe COVID-19 in 327 500 UK Biobank participants. Compared to normal-weight males with high grip strength, the odds ratio (95 % confidence interval) for males with obesity with low grip strength was 2.39 (1.59-3.60), but 1.52 (0.98-2.35) for those with a high gripstrength. Muscle mass and strength development should be considered as a means to reduce risk.

Lithium is a nutritional trace element that is also used pharmacologically for the management of bipolar and related psychiatric disorders. Recent studies have shown that lithium supplementation can extend health and lifespan in different animal models.

Type 2 diabetes mellitus (T2DM) has traditionally been considered a coronary heart disease 'risk equivalent' for future mortality. This study aims to determine the risk of all-cause mortality of patients with T2DM and CVD in UK and Hong Kong.

Current processing methods associated with large whole-body volumes are time intensive and prone to artifacts. The most common artifacts are fat-water swaps, where the labels are inverted at the voxel level. There is a clear need for a robust method to accurately separate fat and water volumes.

Dupuytren's disease (DD) is a fibroproliferative disorder of the hands. The role of manual work exposure in the aetiology of DD is controversial. We investigated whether current occupational exposure to manual work is associated with DD, and if there is a dose-response relationship.

Study looked at 9,141 and 21,489 middle-aged participants with diabetes from Action to Control Cardiovascular Risk in Diabetes (ACCORD) trial and UK Biobank. 45.9% (4,193/9,141, 5.5 median follow-up years) patients in ACCORD and 10.5% (2,251/21,489, 11.9 median following years) experienced fall and in-patient events.

There is uncertainty about putative causal relationships between B vitamins and health outcomes. We performed a phenome-wide association study (PheWAS) to investigate the associations of genetically predicted plasma concentrations of folate, vitamin B6, and their metabolite homocysteine with a wide range of disease outcomes. After multiple corrections, 32 phenotypic associations were identified. Three of the associations were causal.

Low job satisfaction has been associated with negative health and negative organizational outcomes. This study assesses associations between job satisfaction and three personality traits related to cognitive- and inhibitory control. Delay discounting and risk-taking were associated with, respectively, lower and higher job satisfaction. Sensation seeking had no significant association with job satisfaction for either sex.

'Dietary variety' has been identified as a factor associated with food intake. This relationship may have longer-term benefits for body weight management when eating low-energy, nutrient-dense foods. But it may increase the risk of overconsumption (and body adiposity) when foods are high energy density.

Somatic mutations in blood indicative of clonal hematopoiesis of indeterminate potential (CHIP) are associated with an increased risk of hematologic malignancy, coronary artery disease and all-cause mortality. Here we analyze the relation between CHIP status and incident peripheral artery disease (PAD) and atherosclerosis.

WHO has called on the group currently most affected by the virus, men who have sex with men (MSM), to limit their sexual partners. The diminution in number of sexual partners not only decreases the proportion of infected MSM but could also increases the number of days needed to reach a given infection level.

Loneliness and social isolation have been linked to an increased risk of non-communicable diseases such as cardiovascular disease and dementia. But their association with the risk of severe infection is uncertain. We aimed to examine the associations between loneliness and social. isolation and risk of hospital-treated infections using data from two independent cohort studies.

An increased risk of venous thromboembolism (VTE) has been reported in men with an additional sex chromosome. The association between other sex chromosome aneuploidies and VTE is not well characterized. This retrospective cohort study looked at 642 544 individuals aged 18 to 90 years from 2 population-scale biobanks. Among MyCode participants, during 10 years of follow-up, 17 incident VTE events per 1353 person-years were detected.

Retinal structural abnormalities have been found to serve as biomarkers for cardiovascular disease (CVD) However, the association between retinal nerve fiber layer (RNFL) thickness and the incidence of CVD events remains inconclusive. We aimed to examine this link in two prospective cohort studies.

Otosclerosis is one of the most common causes of conductive hearing loss. It typically presents in adulthood and half of the patients have a positive family history. Pathophysiology is poorly understood. We identify 23 novel risk loci (p)

Whole exome sequencing may identify rare pathogenic/likely pathogenic variants (LPVs) that are linked to atrial fibrillation (AF) The impact of LPVs associated with AF on a population level on outcomes is unclear.

Sex-related steroid hormones and proteins may contribute to the sex differences in the characteristics and health consequences of alcohol use disorder. Study aimed to examine the associations between alcohol dependence (AD) and sex-related hormones/proteins using a population-based dataset.

Testosterone levels are linked with diverse characteristics of human health, yet whether these associations reflect correlation or causation remains debated. Here, we provide a broad perspective on the role of genetically determined testosterone on complex diseases in both sexes. We find genetically predicted testosterone affects many sex-specific traits, with a pronounced impact on female reproductive health.

Inflammatory and infectious upper respiratory diseases (ICD-10: J30-J39) are growing health problems yet their genomic similarity is not known. We analyze genome-wide association to eight upper respiratory. diseases (61,195 cases) among 260,405 FinnGen participants.

Clonal hematopoiesis of indeterminate potential (CHIP) is a common form of age-related somatic mosaicism that is associated with significant morbidity and mortality. CHIP mutations can be identified in peripheral blood samples that are sequenced using approaches that cover the whole genome, the whole exome, or targeted genetic regions. We present a stepwise method that combines filtering based on sequencing metrics and variant annotation to increase the accuracy of CHIP calls.

Lifestyle advice by the World Cancer Research Fund (WCRF) is associated with the risk of 13 types of cancer. We investigated whether these associations differ according to genetic risk using data from the UK Biobank. The recommended lifestyle has beneficial associations with most cancers.

Shorter telomere length (TL) is associated with risk of several age-related diseases and decreased life span. The extent to which dietary patterns and practices associate with TL is uncertain. Adherence to the "Mediterranean" and the "Prudent" patterns, was positively associated with LTL.

Little is known about the genetic determinants of medication use in preventing cardiometabolic diseases. Using the Finnish nationwide drug purchase registry with follow-up since 1995, we performed genome-wide association analyses. We discovered 333 independent loci (P)

 limited data exist on the long-term effects of the pandemic on incident psychiatric morbidities. We included 308,400 participants free of diagnosis of anxiety or depression, as well as 213,757 Participants free of anxiolytics or antidepressants prescriptions. We explored the trends in incident diagnoses and drug prescriptions for anxiety and depression from 16 March 2020 to 31 August 2021.

Diffusion MRI is a useful neuroimaging tool for non-invasive mapping of human brain microstructure and structural connections. Analysis of diffusion MRI data often requires brain segmentation, including volumetric segmentation and cerebral cortical surfaces. This study proposes to synthesize high-quality T1w anatomical images directly from diffusion data.

Obesity remains an unmet global health burden. Detrimental anatomical distribution of body fat is a major driver of obesity-mediated mortality risk. However, our understanding of the full genetic contribution to human adiposity is incomplete.

The relationship of handgrip strength and/or walking pace with the risk of chronic kidney disease (CKD) remains uncertain. We aimed to investigate the relationship using data from the large-scale, observational UK Biobank.

Few prospective studies have explored their dose-response relationship. Study included 447 658 participants in the UK Biobank who were initially free of gout. Compared with those who were not tea and coffee drinkers, those who consumed >6 cups/day of tea or coffee were associated with 23% (HR 0.77, 95% CI, 0.66, 091) and 40% lower risks. Hyperuricaemia status had a potential effect modification on the association of coffee intake with gouts.

Three lean tissue and seven adipose tissue parameters based on MRI data from the UK Biobank were used in this study. Participants with European ancestry and data on at least one parameter were screened. Median weight-to-muscle ratios at age 45 were 0.51 and 0.83 kg/L lower compared with those at age 70 in men and women, respectively.

Genetic risk of type 2 diabetes remains strongly associated with risk of prediabetes and undiagnosed diabetes. This could have important implications for identifying individuals at risk for prevention and early diagnosis programs.

People with coeliac disease are at increased risk of cardiovascular disease, including ischaemic heart disease, myocardial infarction, and stroke. Study looked at 469 095 adults aged 40-69 years from England, Scotland, and Wales between 2006 and 2010 without cardiovascular disease.

Socioeconomic status (SES) inequity was recognized as a driver of some certain infectious diseases. Few studies evaluated the association between SES and the burden of overall infections. Lifestyle score mediated 2.9% of effects from SES, while cardiovascular disease (CVD) mediated a proportion of 6.2%. In subgroup analysis, we found that males and African with lower SES showed much higher infection risk.

Common genetic risk factors for intracranial aneurysm (IA) and ASAH were found to explain a large amount of disease heritability. We constructed a genetic risk score to predict ASAH incidence and IA presence. We also assessed association between the metaGRS and patient characteristics.

A prospective cohort of patients with COVID-19 infection between 16 March 2020 and 30 November 2020 was identified from UK Biobank, and followed for up to 18 months, until 31 August 2021. In the acute phase, patients with the infection were associated with a significantly higher short-term risk of CVD and all-cause mortality.

Women are at a higher risk of developing age-related neurocognitive disorders including Alzheimer's disease. Emerging evidence suggests that reproductive life events such as pregnancy and hormone use may influence women's cognition later in life.

Thyroid-stimulating hormone (TSH) is associated with multiple health outcomes, including mortality. However, whether TSH levels are causally associated with the risk of mortality remains unclear. This study aims to investigate the causal association between Tsh levels and all-cause mortality using Mendelian randomization (MR) analyses.

Study looked at associations of disrupted circadian rest-activity rhythm (CRAR) with cardiovascular diseases and mortality among people with type 2 diabetes. Participants in the lowest quartile of IS and RA exhibited the greatest risk of developing cardiovascular disease.

Selenium is a trace mineral that is commonly included in micronutrient supplements. The effect of selenium on kidney function remains unclear. A genetically predicted micronsutrient can be used to assess the causal estimates by Mendelian randomization (MR)

Blood pressure (BP) is often not at goal in stroke survivors, leaving individuals vulnerable to additional vascular events. We hypothesize that a higher polygenic susceptibility to hypertension (PSH) leads to worse BP control. We analyzed 5,940 stroke survivors.

Physical activity improves quality of life and protects against age-related diseases. With age, physical activity tends to decrease, increasing vulnerability to disease in the elderly. We trained a neural network to predict age from 115,456 one week-long 100Hz wrist accelerometer recordings from the UK Biobank.

The majority of polygenic risk scores (PRSs) are derived from European (EUR) populations. Here, we aimed to generate a PRS by incorporating East Asian (EAS) and EUR ancestry groups. We identified 48 independent variants beyond genome-wide significance (P)

The study is designed to examine whether the time of day of physical activity is associated with cardiovascular mortality. We analyzed 94,489 UK Biobank adults with objectively measured physical activity. The hazard of cardiovascular mortality was elevated in the early morning group and night group.

Data were from 90,096 UK Biobank participants without prevalent diabetes (mean 62 years of age; 57% women) who wore a wrist accelerometer for 7 days. For a given level of PAEE, odds of T2D were lower among those engaging in more moderate-to-vigorous activity. The association was stronger in men than women and weaker in those with obesity.

A reliable risk prediction model is critically important for identifying individuals with high risk of developing lung cancer as candidates for low-dose chest computed tomography (LDCT) screening. We developed an Optimized early Warning model for Lung cancer risk (OWL) using the XGBoost algorithm.

Analysis of host genetic components provides insights into the susceptibility and response to viral infection such as severe acute respiratory syndrome coronavirus 2 (SARS-CoV-2) We identify 15 super variants with various levels of significance as susceptibility loci for COVID-19 mortality.

This study aims to explore the joint associations of shift work and sleep patterns with incident depression. The present prospective cohort using data from UK biobank, included 220,651 participants aged 38 to 71 years recruited between 2006 and 2010.

People with misophonia experience strong negative emotional responses to sounds and associated stimuli-mostly human produced. The exact nature of the disorder remains a matter of ongoing research and debate. Here, we investigated the genetic etiology to understand contributing genetic factors and shed light on individual differences.

Retinal photography is becoming increasingly acceptable as a non-invasive imaging tool for CVD. This study aims to further validate our biomarker, Reti-CVD, to detect risk group of &#8805; 10% in 10-year CVD risk. It also aims to enhance risk assessment in individuals with QRISK3 of 7.5-10%.

In genome-wide association studies (GWAS) for thousands of phenotypes in biobanks, most binary phenotypes have substantially fewer cases than controls. Many widely used approaches for joint analysis of multiple phenotypes produce inflated type I error rates. In this research, we develop a method to jointly analyze multiple unbalanced case-control phenotypes. We find that the proposed approach can identify more significant SNPs than the other viable methods.

Ageing traits and frailty are important health issues in modern medicine. Evidence supporting the causal effects of tobacco smoking on various ageing traits is required. The outcome data were obtained from 337 138 white British ancestry participants from the UK Biobank.

Lipoprotein lipase (LPL) gene is linked to non-alcoholic fatty liver disease. LPL expression was investigated in human liver specimens and in liver cell lines. Liver expression of LPL mRNA was dependent on the LPL  rs13702 genotype and significantly higher in patients with ALD cirrhosis.

The coefficient of determination (R 2 ) is a well-established measure to indicate the predictive ability of polygenic scores (PGSs) However, the sampling variance of R 2 is rarely considered so that 95% confidence intervals (CI) are not usually reported. Here, we show how to estimate the variance and covariance of R 1 values to assess the 95% CI and p value of the R 2 difference.

South Asian individuals have increased cardiovascular disease and mortality risks. Compared with creatinine, cystatin C identified triple the number of participants with estimated glomerular filtration.

Genetic variants in drug targets can be used to predict the long-term, on-target effect of drugs. Here, we assess how sex and body mass index may modify the effect of genetically predicted lower CETP levels on biomarkers and cardiovascular outcomes.

The UK Biobank cognitive assessment data has been a significant resource for researchers looking to investigate predictors and modifiers of cognitive abilities and associated health outcomes in the general population. We argue that both approaches are suboptimal - one being too specific and the other one too general - and suggest a novel multifactorial solution to represent cognitive abilities.

Childhood trauma and adversity have strong associations with physical and psychiatric morbidity throughout the life-course. One possible mechanism through which childhood trauma may predispose individuals to poor psychiatric outcomes is via associations with brain structure. This study aimed to elucidate the associations between childhood trauma and brain structure across two large, independent community cohorts.

Study looked at associations of residential green and blue spaces with chronic kidney disease (CKD) incidence. A total of 346,697 participants from UK Biobank without CKD at baseline were included. The primary outcome was new-onset CKD ascertained through linkage to health administrative datasets.

22q11.2 copy-number variants (CNVs) in the general population remain understudied. We performed a phenome-wide association scan in 405,324 unrelated UK Biobank (UKBB) participants. We found significant associations for eight continuous and nine binary traits associated under different models.

A systematic review of published papers prior to August 2022 was performed first to identify genes where germline mutations were associated with lung cancer risk. We then performed a confirmation study in 2,050 lung cancer cases and 198,553 controls in the UK Biobank (UKB) Germline mutations of these genes were identified from sequencing data and annotated using The American College of Medical Genetics criteria.

Higher intake of SSBs and ASBs was each associated with a higher risk of dementia. Moderate intake of NJs was related to a lower dementia risk. The associations were not significantly modified by genetic risk.

Previous studies indicated that glucosamine supplements may have a general anticancer effect. This study aimed to assess whether the potential effect differs across different types of cancers in a large prospective cohort study. All participants from the UK Biobank who were free of cancers were included and followed up until 2021.

Female sex is associated with an increased prevalence of dementia. Menopause may have a role to play in explaining sex differences in cognition, and possibly the risk of future dementia. We aimed to determine if the rate of cognitive decline differed between stages of the menopausal transition.

The genetic regulation of post-prandial glucose levels is poorly understood. We characterise the genetic architecture of blood glucose measured within 0 and 24 h of fasting in 368,000 European ancestry participants of the UK Biobank. We found a near-linear increase in the heritability of non-fasting glucose levels over time.

Existing survival analysis techniques heavily rely on strong modelling assumptions and are prone to model misspecification errors. In this paper, we develop an inferential method based on ideas from conformal prediction, which can wrap around any survival prediction algorithm.

Study aimed to identify novel associations between irritable bowel syndrome (IBS) and a broad range of outcomes. 346,352 white participants in the U.K. Biobank were randomly divided into two halves. PheWAS identified five diseases associated with genetically predicted IBS.

UK Biobank participants (aged 40-69 years) completed 24-h dietary recalls between 2009 and 2012. During a median follow-up time of 9.8 years, 15,921 individuals developed cancer and 4009 cancer-related deaths occurred. Every 10 percentage points increment in UPF consumption was associated with an increased incidence of ovarian cancer.

Michigan Genomics Initiative (MGI) is a single-health-system biobank currently consisting of >91,000 participants recruited primarily during surgical encounters at Michigan Medicine. Compared with the much larger population-based UK Biobank, MGI has higher prevalence for nearly all diagnosis-code-based phenotypes.

Type 2 diabetes is associated with an increased risk of depression. But the extent to which risk factor modification can mitigate this risk is unclear. We aimed to examine the association between the incidence of major depression and clinically relevant depressive symptoms among individuals with type 2 diabetes.

Head and neck cancer is often diagnosed late and prognosis for most patients remains poor. We developed a risk prediction model based on demographic and lifestyle risk factors, human papillomavirus (HPV) serological markers and genetic markers.

Acute pancreatitis (AP) is the leading cause of gastrointestinal disease-related hospital admissions. Few therapeutic options exist for AP prevention. Blood proteins with causal evidence may represent promising drug targets, but few have been causally linked with AP.

Sleep is an emerging risk factor for dementia but its association with brain health remains unclear. Every additional hour of sleep above 7 h/day was associated with 0.10-0.25% lower brain volumes. Negative non-linear association was observed between sleep duration, grey matter, and hippocampal volume.

Higher physical activity levels are associated with lower risks of cancer, cardiovascular disease, and diabetes. But associations with many common and less severe health conditions are not known. This prospective cohort study used data from 81 717 UK Biobank participants aged 42 to 78 years.

Social isolation and loneliness have emerged as important risk factors for cardiovascular diseases, particularly during the coronavirus disease pandemic. This study sought to examine the association of social isolation, loneliness, and their combination with incident HF.

PCSK9 deficiency causes cardiac remodeling and heart failure (HF) Cardiac remodeling after PCSK9-inhibitor treatment is a concern for patients. This study focused on a subset of those individuals who completed cardiac magnetic resonance (CMR) imaging.

The hypothalamus-pituitary-thyroid axis coordinates brain development and postdevelopmental function. Hypothyroidism was positively associated with an increased risk of major depressive disorder. Strong coheritability was observed between thyroid disease and both major depressive (MDD) and anxiety disorders (ANXs)

Recent studies have highlighted an association between epilepsy and Parkinson disease (PD) The role of antiepileptic drugs (AEDs) has not been explored. This nested case-control study started collecting data from the UK Biobank (UKB) in 2006.

The clinical utility of polygenic risk scores (PRS) for coronary artery disease (CAD) has not yet been established. The CAD PRS was significantly associated with the risk of MI in all age groups but had significantly stronger risk prediction at younger ages. Results of this cohort study suggest that the predictive ability of a CADPRS was greater in younger individuals.

Keloids and hypertrophic scars (excessive scarring) are relatively understudied disfiguring chronic skin conditions with high treatment resistance. This multicenter cross-sectional population-based cohort study used UK Biobank data and fitted logistic regression models for testing associations between excessive scarring and a variety of outcomes.

High-risk lifestyle factors included current smoking, heavy alcohol intaking, poor diet pattern, physically inactive. During a 14.8-year follow-up, 23,164 participants developed depression and 989 developed post-depression dementia.

Lean patients with non-alcoholic fatty liver disease (NAFLD) represent 10-20% of the affected population and may have heterogeneous drivers of disease. Six patients with lean NAFLD were identified and underwent whole exome sequencing. Two lean patients (33%) were identified to have monogenic disorders. The lean patients had similar age, anthropometric and MRI characteristics to lean patients without a monogenic disorder.

No prior study has examined the effects of air pollution on the progression from healthy to chronic lung disease, subsequent chronic lung multimorbidity and further to death. Fine particulate matter showed the strongest association with all five transitions, with HRs (95% CI) per 5 &#181;g/m 3.

Study assessed associations between sleep behaviors with white matter macro and microstructure. A healthy sleep score integrated sleep behaviors including chronotype, insomnia, sleep duration, daytime sleepiness, and snoring. Unhealthy sleep behaviors were associated with increased WMH impacts.

Infants with bronchiolitis are at high risk for developing childhood asthma. While genome-wide association studies suggest common genetic susceptibilities between these conditions, the mechanisms underlying the link remain unclear. We sought to identify genetically driven metabolites associated with asthma development and genetic loci associated with both these metabolites and asthma susceptibility.

Wearable devices are transforming the electrocardiogram (ECG) into a ubiquitous medical test. This study assesses the association between premature ventricular and atrial contractions (PVCs and PACs) detected on wearable-format ECGs (15 s single lead) and cardiovascular outcomes.

Polygenic risk score (PRS) has been demonstrated to be effective in identifying individuals at high risk of developing cancer, but its prognostic value remains unclear. We constructed site-specific PRSs by aggregating the risk effect of independent variants derived from previous genome-wide association studies (GWASs) across 17 cancer types. Cox proportional hazards model was used to evaluate the association of each PRS with cancer survival.

Blood lipids and metabolites are markers of current health and future disease risk. Here, we describe plasma nuclear magnetic resonance (NMR) biomarker data for 118,461 participants in the UK Biobank. The results reveal a plethora of biomarker associations.

Epstein Barr virus (EBV) infects 95% of the population worldwide. EBV is known to cause adverse health outcomes such as Hodgkin's, non-Hodgkin's lymphomas, and multiple sclerosis. There is substantial interest and investment in developing infection-preventing vaccines for EBV.

A bidirectional relationship between chronic pain (CP) and mental disorders has been reported. Coffee was believed to be associated with both. We aim to analyze the association of coffee consumption on the relationship of CP with depression and anxiety.

In UK Biobank, 380,976 depression-free individuals were included in this study. Polygenic risk score (PRS) was categorized into three groups in terms of tertiles. On average, 1.5 h/day of outdoor light was related to the minimum risk of depression.

Non-alcoholic fatty liver disease (NAFLD) has a prevalence of &#8764;25% worldwide, with significant public health consequences yet few effective treatments. Genetic variants in mitochondrial amidoxime-reducing component 1 ( MTARC1 ) have been associated with NAFLD and liver-related mortality. In vitro mARC1 knockdown decreased lipid accumulation and increased triglyceride secretion, and  in vivo  GalNAc-siRNA-mediated knockdown lowered hepatic but increased plasma triglycerides.

The cerebellum is recognized as being involved in neurocognitive and motor functions. However, the genetic determinants of cerebellar white matter integrity remain largely unknown. We conducted a genome-wide association analysis using diffusion tensor imaging data from 25,415 individuals from UK Biobank.

31,344 adults without obesity at baseline (age = 56.0 +/- 7.5 years; female = 49.1%) from the UK Biobank were included. During a mean follow up of 6.8 (SD = +/-2.3) years, 1354 (4.3%) participants developed obesity. Increasing physical activity with improved diet was associated with the largest difference in body fat percentage, body mass index, and waist circumference.

The associations between blood pressure and cannabis use remain inconsistent. The purpose of our study was to examine gender stratified associations of cannabis use and blood pressure among the general UK Biobank population based study.

The association of cardiovascular (CV) risk with social isolation and loneliness remains poorly studied. Social isolation was associated with a higher estimated 10-year ASCVD risk in both genders but only loneliness among men. Health policies should address these notions in prevention campaigns.

We examined the contribution of common and rare genetic variants to latent traits underlying psychiatric disorders. We used items from the UK Biobank Mental Health Questionnaire relevant to three psychiatric disorders: major depression, bipolar disorder and schizophrenia. We found moderate genetic correlations between the latent traits in our study and case-control phenotypes in previous genome-wide association studies.

Dietary fatty acid composition is associated with non-alcoholic fatty liver disease (NAFLD) Few evidence had identified a clear role of dietary fatty Acid composition of typical diet in NAFLD. A dietary fatty acid pattern (DFP1) characterized by "PUFA enriched vegetarian" was negatively associated with NAFLL risk. Serum fatty acids were significantly associated with DFP1 and NAFLd.

There are marked sex differences in the prevalence, phenotypic presentation and treatment response for major depression. To date, no studies seek to identify sex-specific markers and pathways. We identified 11 loci passing genome-level significance for broad depression.

Polygenic risk scores (PRSs) have been among the leading advances in biomedicine in recent years. These typically distil genetic liability to a single number based on aggregation of an individual's genome-wide risk alleles. We introduce a 'pathway polygenic' paradigm of disease risk, in which multiple genetic liabilities underlie complex diseases.

Genome-wide association meta-analysis included 56 071 syncope cases and 890 790 controls. Study yielded 18 independent syncope variants, 17 of which were novel. One of the variants, p.Ser140Thr in PTPRN2, affected syncope only when maternally inherited.

Longitudinal changes in brain structure and lifestyle can affect sleep phenotypes. However, the influence of the interaction between longitudinal changes in. brain Structure and lifestyle on sleep phenotype remains unclear. Using genotype data from UK Biobank, we calculated polygenetic risk scores of longitudinal changes.

Non-alcoholic fatty liver disease (NAFLD) can progress to cirrhosis and hepatic decompensation. Whether genetic variants influence the rate of progression to Cirrhosis or are useful in risk stratification among patients with NAFLD is uncertain. PNPLA3-rs738409-GG genotype, diabetes, obesity, and ALT of &#8805;2Ã— upper limit of normal were associated with higher incidence rate of cir rhosis in both MGI and UKBB.

Anxiety and depressive symptoms usually co-occur. Neuroimaging abnormalities in patients with depression and anxiety disorders are therefore related to a combination of symptoms. We used a large population study to select individuals with anxiety, depressive, or both anxiety and depressive Symptoms.

Physical activity (PA) has been associated with benefits for cognitive function (CF) Previous estimates of the strength of this relationship may have been biased due to limitations in statistical modelling practices. We aimed to address this by using a rigorously constructed conceptual causal model to guide an empirical analysis.

Short and long sleep duration are associated with increased risk of metabolic syndrome (MetS) This study aimed to examine the associations of genetically determined sleep durations with MetS and its five components among a group of elderly population.

Study looked at association of moderate-to-vigorous physical activity and sedentary behaviour with all-cause mortality (ACM) and incident cardiovascular disease (CVD) In 328 228 participants (mean age 55.9 (SD 8.1) years, 45% men) with an average follow-up of 12.1 (1.4) years 18 033 deaths and 98 922 incident CVD events occurred.

Lifestyle factors were considered to calculate the healthy lifestyle score. The polygenetic risk score (PRS) was derived for coronary heart disease (CHD), ischemic stroke (IS), and heart failure (HF) In 13,348 female BC survivors, there were 986 CVD events.

Pulmonary arterial hypertension (PAH) is characterized by remodeling and narrowing of the pulmonary vasculature which results in elevations of pulmonary arterial pressures. We conducted a genome-wide association study (GWAS) using the UK Biobank, analyzing the genomes of 493 individuals diagnosed with PAH.

Previous studies suggested that vasomotor symptoms were associated with an increasing risk of coronary heart diseases (CHD) We found that among non-vasomotor menopausal symptoms, only insomnia symptoms may increase the lifetime risk of CHD. Insomnia at different ages near menopause has differential impacts on CHD risk.

Study sought to determine the extent that trauma exposure, depression polygenic risk scores (PRS), and their interaction are associated with MDD. Data from 102,182 individuals from the large-scale UK Biobank population cohort was analysed.

UK Biobank recruited 502,534 individuals ages 37 to 73 years living in the United Kingdom between 2006 and 2010. Genotype data from 459,855 individuals were available for CNV calling. Carriers of the 9p24.3 (DMRT1) duplication showed lower mood/anxiety.

Data from 196,154 members of the UK biobank had at least one 24 h dietary recall. COVID-19 outcomes were based on PCR testing, hospital admissions, and death certificates. The fully adjusted model showed that participants in the highest (vs. lowest) DII/E-DII quintile were at 10-17% increased risk.

Frailty is a relevant issue in older people, being associated with several negative outcomes. Increasing literature is reporting that pollution (particularly air pollution) can increase the risk of frailty, but the research is still limited. We aimed to investigate the potential association of pollution (air, noise) with frailty and prefrailty among participants 60 years and older of the UK Biobank study.

Metabolic differences have been reported between individuals with and without major depressive disorder (MDD) But their consistency and causal relevance have been unclear. We conducted a metabolome-wide association study of MDD with 249 metabolomic measures available in the UK Biobank (n = 29,757)

In 2018, The World Cancer Research Fund (WCRF)/American Institute for Cancer Research (AICR) published ten evidence-based Cancer Prevention Recommendations. UK Biobank recruited >500,000 individuals aged 37-73 years, between 2006 and 2010. We used data on anthropometric measurements, physical activity and diet to calculate adherence scores.

Cross-sectional analysis was conducted of 148,828 UK Biobank participants. Chronic pain was present in 76,095 participants (51.1%). The overall prevalence of NeuP was 9.2%. Neuropathic pain was significantly associated with worse health-related quality of life, having a manual or personal service type occupation, and younger age.

Ischemic stroke (IS) is a highly heritable trait. There are limited data on the contribution of rare genetic variation to IS. We conducted an exome-wide study using whole-exome sequencing data from 152 058 UK Biobank participants, including 1777 IS cases. Rare genetic variation at CYP2R1 was significantly associated with IS risk.

Uterine leiomyomas (ULs) are benign smooth muscle tumors that are common in premenopausal women. Somatic alterations in MED12, HMGA2, FH, genes encoding subunits of the SRCAP complex, and genes involved in Cullin 3-RING E3 ligase neddylation are mutually exclusive UL drivers.

We used UK Biobank participants who reported RA (n=5,625) and employed latent class analysis (LCA) to create classes of LTC combinations for those with &#8805;2 additional LTCs. Cox-proportional hazard and negative binomial regression were used to compare the risk of all-cause mortality, major adverse cardiac events (MACE), and number of emergency hospitalisations.

Study included 27,827 participants with baseline diabetes from the UK Biobank. Long-term exposure to ambient NO 2 , NO x , PM 2.5 , and PM 10 increased risk of various cardiovascular outcomes in the diabetic population. For most of the cardiovascular events, the deleterious effects of air pollutants persisted even when participants were exposed to air pollutants concentrations below WHO guideline limits.

Living alone has profound consequences for mental and physical health. Despite this, there has been a rapid increase in single-person households worldwide. The persistent trend for solitary living will require new answers from public-health decision makers.

Dyslipidaemia is an important cardiovascular risk factor for people with severe mental illness, contributing to premature mortality. The link between antipsychotics and dyslipidaemic is well established, while evidence on antidepressants is mixed. To investigate if antidepressant/antipsychotic use was associated with lipid parameters in UK Biobank participants.

Up to 19% of the population takes iron supplementation. We used Mendelian randomization to estimate the causal effect of iron on infections. We did not observe an increase in risk of most infectious diseases with increases in iron stores. However for bacterial infections, higher iron stores may increase odds of infections.

Apotolipoprotein E (APOE ) E4 allele and glaucoma prevalence in large cohorts. Outcome phenotypes were also correlated with Alzheimer's dementia (AD), a clinical outcome highly associated with APOE  E4. A paradoxical positive association was observed between AD and both glau coma (OR, 1.30; 95% CI,. 1.08-1.54; P   P  = 0.018) in the UKBB cohort. A small negative association observed between the APOE E4 and gl Kaucoma was not evident in either replication cohort.

Data from 48,286 women from the UK Biobank cohort were analyzed. Those in the most active quartile had a 26% lower risk of breast cancer. No evidence of interaction between PA domains and menopause status was found.

Colorectal cancer (CRC) incidence and mortality are higher among men than among women. We aimed to estimate overall and age-specific risk advancement periods (RAPs) for men compared to women. RAPs were derived by Cox regression models among 331 224 participants aged 40 to 69.

African populations are vastly underrepresented in genetic studies but have the most genetic variation. We calculated polygenic risk scores (PRSs) in simulations across Africa and in empirical data from South Africa, Uganda, and the United Kingdom. PRS accuracy improves with ancestry-matched discovery cohorts more than from ancestry-mismatched studies.

Study involved 51,597 UK Biobank participants who had retinal images available to extract oculomics of RVFs. Phenome-wide association analyses (PheWASs) were conducted to identify RVFs associated with the genetic risks of the main types of aneurysms. An RVF risk score was derived to identify patients with an increased risk.

We propose BIGKnock (BIobank-scale Gene-based association test via Knockoffs) It leverages long-range chromatin interaction data, and performs conditional genome-wide testing via knockoffs. We show it can prioritize causal genes over proxy associations at a locus.

Study aimed to assess associations between types and sources of dietary carbohydrates and CVD incidence. Secondary aim was to examine associations of carbohydrate intakes with triglycerides within lipoprotein subclasses. 26,095 participants with baseline NMR spectroscopy measurements were examined.

Psoriasis is an immune-mediated disease in which multiple immune cells play crucial roles. The risk of psoriasis increased with high levels of monocytes, neutrophils, and eosinophils. The roles of the neutrophil-lymphocyte ratio (NLR), platelet-LYmphocyte Ratio (PLR), and lymphocyte-monocyte ratio were also assessed. NLR, PLR, and LMR correlated with the PASI score.

UK Biobank adults with &#8805;two 24-h dietary assessments and data on cardiometabolic health were included (n = 24 553; mean age: 55.9 y). A posteriori dietary patterns (DP1; DP2) were generated through reduced rank regression (response variables: SFA, MUFA, PUFA) Mediterranean Diet Score (MDS) and Dietary Approaches to Stop Hypertension (DASH) dietary patterns were created. DP1, positively correlated with SFAs, MUFAs and PUFAs, characterized by higher nuts, seeds and vegetables intake and lower fruits and low-fat yoghurt intake, was associated with lower HDL-C. DP2,

Pain plays an important role in chronic ankle instability (CAI) prolonged pain may be associated with ankle dysfunction and abnormal neuroplasticity. This study included a UK Biobank dataset of 28 patients with ankle pain and 109 healthy controls and a validation dataset of 15 patients with CAI and 15 healthy controls. All participants underwent resting-state functional magnetic resonance imaging scanning.

Lung function prospectively affects cognitive brain health independent of their overlapping factors remains largely unknown. This study aimed to investigate the longitudinal association between decreased lung function and Cognitive brain health. It also aimed to explore underlying biological and brain structural mechanisms.

Genetic screening for clonal hematopoiesis of indetermined potential (CHIP), a novel risk factor for stroke, could identify patients with myeloid precursor lesions. CHIP prevalence was compared with age-matched healthy controls from the Nijmegen Biomedical Study and the UK Biobank.

The shared pathophysiological features of the cerebrovascular disease (CVD) and glaucoma suggest an association between the two diseases. Using the prospective UK Biobank cohort, we examined the associations between glau coma and incident CVD. A healthy lifestyle was associated with a substantially lower risk for CVD incidence among adults with glauCOMa.

Few studies have demonstrated reproducible gene-diet interactions (GDIs) impacting metabolic disease risk factors. We aimed to identify GDIs across the genetic frequency spectrum impacting the macronutrient-glycemia relationship in genetically and culturally diverse cohorts. We analyzed 33,187 participants free of diabetes from 10 National Heart, Lung, and Blood Institute Trans-Omics for Precision Medicine program cohorts.

The vitamin D binding protein (DBP) is encoded by the group-specific component (GC) gene. Higher DBP concentration is associated with a reduced risk of vitamin D deficiency. Mendelian randomization analyses identify a unidirectional effect of higher DBP and higher 25-hydroxyvitamin D concentration.

Most tools for detecting positively selected variants have computational resource requirements rendering them impractical on population genomic datasets with hundreds of thousands of individuals or more. We have developed and implemented an efficient haplotype-based approach able to scan large datasets and accurately detect positive selection.

Genome-wide Association Studies (GWAS) of vascular tortuosity of retinal arteries and veins followed by replication meta-analysis and Mendelian randomization. We identified 175 significantly associated genetic loci in the UK Biobank; 173 of these were novel and 4 replicated in our second, much smaller, metacohort. Vessel type specific GWAS revealed 116 loci for arteries and 63 for veins. Genes with significant association signals included COL4A2, ACTN4, LGALS4 and TNS1.

 408,743 participants without prior CKD in the UK Biobank were included. During a median follow-up of 12.1 years, 10,797 (2.6%) participants occurred CKD. Compared with mobile phone non-users, a significantly higher risk of new-onset CKD was found in mobile phone users.

Insomnia is associated with insulin resistance (IR) in observational studies. Whether insomnia is causally associated with IR remains unestablished. This study aims to estimate the causal associations of insomnia with IR and its related traits.

TyG index and TG/HDL-C ratio have been demonstrated to predict cardiovascular disease (CVD) However, very few studies have investigated their associations with CVD in European populations. A total of 403,335 participants from the UK Biobank were included.

Body mass index and waist circumference are simple measures of obesity. They do not distinguish between visceral and subcutaneous fat, or muscle. The purpose of this study was to develop and validate prediction models for volumetric fat and muscle.

The study included 41,453 UK Biobank participants aged 40 to 69 years old. Diabetes status was defined by self-report of diagnosis or use of insulin. Compared with participants in the second quintile of the normal HbA1c range, those with diabetes had a thinner photoreceptor layer thickness.

Data from 93,709 UK Biobank participants were included. Physical activity was assessed using wrist-worn accelerometers for 7-days.

Intracerebral hemorrhage (ICH) has an estimated heritability of 29%. We developed a genomic risk score for ICH and determined its predictive power in comparison to standard clinical risk factors. In the UK Biobank, the metaGRS was associated with higher risk of incident ICH.

Theories propose that visual impairment might increase the risk of psychosis, and vice versa. We aimed to investigate the relationship between visual impairment and psychosis in the UK Biobank cohort.

The association of milk consumption with mortality and cardiovascular disease (CVD) outcomes was unclear. A prospective cohort study was performed using data from the UK Biobank. Semi-skimmed, skimmed, and soy milk use were significantly related to lower risks of CVD mortality, CVD event, and stroke.

Short-term exposure to air pollution has been linked to pneumonia risk. However, evidence on the long-term effects of air pollution on pneumonia morbidity is scarce and inconsistent. We investigated the associations of long- term air pollutant exposure with pneumonia and explored the potential interactions with smoking.

Irritable bowel syndrome (IBS) substantially affects quality of life and requires early prevention. This study aimed to elucidate the relationships between IBS and daily behaviors. Daily behaviors were retrieved from self-reported data of 362,193 eligible UK Biobank participants.

The 15q11.2 BP1-BP2 copy number variant (CNV) is associated with altered brain morphology and risk for atypical development. However, it is still unclear whether differences in brain morphology are associated with neurodevelopmental or neurodegenerative processes. This study derived morphological brain MRI measures from the UK Biobank study.

Study analyzed data of 447 931 participants from the UK Biobank. Compared to people with no diabetes at all, people with T2DM had increased risk of all-cause dementia (HR 2.85, 95% CI 2.56-3.17) The HRs between T2 DM and AD were higher in women than men.

Growing evidence shows that residential greenness is beneficial for various health outcomes. We aimed to explore the link between greenness and hearing impairment using baseline data from the UK Biobank. Each interquartile increment in NDVI was associated with 19% lower odds of hearing impairment. Age and Townsend deprivation index showed moderating effects on this association.

Genome-wide association studies (GWASs) have established the contribution of common and low-frequency variants to metabolic blood measurements in the UK Biobank. We assessed contribution of rare protein-coding variants in relation to 355 metabolic blood. measurements and 30 clinical blood biomarkers.

Genetic risk scores can be deceiving as they do not consider other, easily attainable risk factors. Sex, BMI, age, smoking habits, parental disease status and physical activity can improve PGS based predictions. Implementation of existing PGS models that also consider these factors requires reference data based on a specific genotyping chip, which is not always available.

Previous suicide models required a huge amount of input features, resulting in limited applicability in clinical practice. We aimed to construct applicable models (ie, with limited features) for short- and long-term suicidal behavior prediction. We further validated these models among individuals with different genetic risks of suicide.

Proprotein convertase subtilisin/kexin type 9 (PCSK9) is a key regulator of plasma low-density lipoprotein cholesterol (LDL-C) inhibition reduces the risk of atherosclerotic cardiovascular disease (ASCVD) We aimed to assess the sex-differential effect of either pharmacological or genetic inhibition of PCSK9 on LDL-C levels.

Insomnia was assessed by self-reported symptoms. Annual average air pollutant concentrations were calculated based on participants' addresses. For each 10 &#956;g/m&#179; increase in NO 2 , NO X , PM 10 , SO 2 , the average hazard ratios (AHRs) and 95% confidence interval (CI) of insomnia were 1.10 (1.06, 1.14) and 2.58 (2.31, 2.89), respectively.

Metabolic dysfunction-associated fatty liver (MAFLD) has been associated with the prevalence of chronic kidney disease (CKD) It is unknown whether MAFLD is associated with CKD development and the incidence of end-stage kidney disease. We aimed to clarify the association between MAFLd and incident ESKD in the prospective UK Biobank cohort.

Evidence linking air pollution to major depressive disorder (MDD) remains sparse and results are heterogeneous. We aimed to examine the association of various air pollutants with the risk of incident MDD. We assessed whether genetic susceptibility and lifestyle influence the associations.

Age-related (AR) hearing loss (HL) is the most common sensory impairment with heritability of 55%. We identified genetic variants on chromosome X associated with ARHL through the analysis of data obtained from the UK Biobank. We estimated that only a small amount of variation of ARHL, 0.4%, is explained by variants on the X chromosome.

Primary aldosteronism (PA) is one of the most common causes of secondary hypertension. The germline genetic contribution to the susceptibility of PA has not been well elucidated. We conducted a genome-wide association analysis of PA in the Japanese population. We also performed a comparative analysis for the risk of 42 previously established blood pressure-associated variants between PA and hypertension.

Handgrip strength was assessed by dynamometer. Walking pace was self-defined as slow, average, or brisk. Study outcome was incident hypertension. Genetic risks of hypertension did not significantly modify the association.

No studies have investigated the association between arterial stiffness index (ASI) and cannabis use. Cannabis use of 46 219 volunteers of the middle-aged UK Biobank population was assessed.

Apolipoprotein E (APOE) &#949;4, the strongest genetic risk factor for late onset Alzheimer's disease (LOAD), has been associated with cognitive decline independent from AD pathology. The role for other LOAD risk genes in normal cognitive aging is less studied.

The microbiome-gut-brain axis hypothesis suggests that the use of laxatives could be associated with dementia. UK Biobank participants aged 40-69 years without a history of dementia were studied. Regular use of over-the-counter laxatives was defined as self-reported use in most days of the week for the last 4 weeks.

Obesity is accompanied by low-grade inflammation and leucocytosis and increases the risk of venous thromboembolism. Associations with platelet count, however, are unclear. waist and hip circumferences reflect overall body size and are correlated strongly positively with body mass index.

Polygenic risk scores aggregate an individual's burden of risk alleles to estimate the overall genetic risk for a specific trait or disease. We found that, as expected, European-derived polygenicrisk scores perform poorly in the Genes & Health cohort. These findings suggest that polygenic risk score prediction of multiple sclerosis based on European genome-wide association study results is less accurate in a South Asian population.

An estimated 55.5% and 37.3% of people globally with type 2 diabetes (T2D) will have concomitant non-alcoholic fatty liver disease (NAFLD) and the more severe fibroinflammatory stage, non- alcoholic steatohepatitis (NASH) NAFLD and NASH prevalence is projected to increase exponentially over the next 20 years. Bayesian Networks (BNs) offer a powerful tool for modelling uncertainty and visualising complex systems.

The aim of this study was to develop prediction models for the individual-level impacts of cardiovascular events on UK healthcare costs. In the UK Biobank, people 40-70 years old, recruited in 2006-2010, were followed in linked primary and hospital care datasets.

Study investigated mortality disparities and associated risk factors for the three largest ethnic groups in the United Kingdom: Asian, Black, and White. The White ethnic group showed significantly worse survival probability than the Asian and Black groups. Endoscopy and colonoscopy procedures showed significant protective effects on overall mortality.

Prior evidence suggests that physical activity may reduce the risk of multiple diseases and mortality. Whether and how physical activity affects the aging process remains largely unexplored. We included 284 479 UK Biobank participants and computed leukocyte telomere length (LTL) deviation (ie, difference between genetically determined and observed LTL)

Polygenic risk scores (PRS) quantify the genetic liability to disease and are calculated using an individual's genotype profile and disease-specific genome-wide association study (GWAS) summary statistics. PRS have the potential to address possible misclassification of T1D and T2D.

Tourette Syndrome (TS) is a complex neurodevelopmental disorder characterized by vocal and motor tics lasting more than a year. Epidemiological studies have shown TS to be correlated with other phenotypes. Large-scale phenome wide analyses in biobank level data have not been performed to date.

PheWAS-MR found that genetically-proxied TYK2 inhibition was associated with lower risk of a wide range of autoimmune diseases. Thirty-seven blood biomarkers were associated with the loss-of-function mutation. Evidence from RCTs confirmed the effectiveness of TYK1 inhibitors on plaque psoriasis and reported several adverse effects.

Non-European participants (defined by genetics) disproportionately bear a higher burden of exposure than their European counterparts. For example, exposure to NO 2 in people with African ancestry was 30.7 % higher (p = 1.5E-786) than European subjects.

Using two widely used frailty indicators, this study aimed to evaluate whether frailty was associated with the incidence risk of cardiovascular disease (CVD) and type 2 diabetes mellitus (T2DM) We included 13,388 long-term cancer survivors (diagnosed with cancer over 5 years before enrolment) free of CVD.

Elderly-onset atopic dermatitis (AD) is a remarkable subtype. Understanding the influence of genetic and environmental exposures is crucial to preventing AD. This study was based on UK Biobank that recruited over 500,000 participants.

Study aims to investigate associations between coffee and tea consumption with macular retinal nerve fiber layer (mRNFL) thickness, a marker of neurodegeneration. 35,557 out of 67,321 United Kingdom (UK) Biobank participants were included in this cross-sectional study.

Cannabis use status was assessed among 104,092 volunteers of the UK Biobank population. Males presented a higher estimated 10-year ASCVD risk compared to females.

Amino acid metabolism is dysregulated in colorectal cancer patients. It is not clear whether pre-diagnostic levels of amino acids are associated with subsequent risk of cancer. We investigated circulating levels of acids in relation to coloreCTal cancer risk in the European Prospective Investigation into Cancer and Nutrition.

BMD is a major predictor of osteoporotic fractures, but its genetic basis remains unclear. We aimed to identify rare risk variants contributing to BMD. We performed gene-based burden tests to assess the association between rare variants and BMD, and identified several BMD candidate genes.

Patients with sepsis are at increased risk for cardiovascular complications, including myocardial infarction (MI), ischemic stroke (IS), and venous thromboembolism (VTE) Our objective is to assess whether genetic risk score (GRS) can differentiate risk for these complications.

Rare genetic variants in the CUBN gene encoding the main albumin-transporter in the proximal tubule of the kidneys have previously been associated with microalbuminuria and higher urine albumin levels, also in diabetes. Sequencing studies in isolated proteinuria suggest that these variants might not affect kidney function, despite proteinuria. We carried out a genetic association-based linear regression analysis between four CubN missense variants and eGFR creatinine in populations with T1D or T2D.

There is growing evidence of the anti-inflammatory effect of metformin and its use to reduce pain. However, we currently lack studies investigating whether met formin is associated with a reduction in chronic back pain prevalence. This is a cross-sectional study of 21,889 participants with type 2 diabetes who were drawn from the UK Biobank.

Protein-truncating variants (PTVs) in apolipoprotein B (APOB) and proprotein convertase subtilisin/kexin type 9 (PCSK9) are associated with significantly lower low-density lipoprotein (LDL) cholesterol concentrations. The association of these PTVs with coronary heart disease (CHD) warrants further characterization.

Heart failure (HF) is a major complication in patients with hypertension. The optimal risk factor control (controlling &#8805;6 risk factors) was associated with a 62% lower risk.

Lipid pathways have been implicated in the pathogenesis of psoriasis. Some lipid-lowering drugs, such as statins, are hypothesized to have disease-modifying properties. Large population-level studies are scarce, and causal interpretation of results from traditional observational designs is limited by confounding.

The study used a type of neural network that learns from cross-sectional, retrospective data. It synthesizes high-resolution counterfactual OCT images and longitudinal time series. The results agree well with previous studies based on the same cohort from the UK Biobank population study. Ultimately, they envision that they will enable clinical experts to derive and explore hypotheses for potential imaging biomarkers.

Sarcopenia, or loss of skeletal muscle mass and decreased contractile strength, contributes to morbidity and mortality in patients with chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD) We tested if genetic contributors explain the variability in sarcopenic phenotype and accelerated senescence in COPD. Several SNPs within the fat mass and obesity-associated (FTO) gene were associated with sarcopenia.

Lifestyle and genetic factors jointly play critical roles in the development of asthma. Poor lifestyle was associated with a hazard ratio of up to 3.87 (95% CI, 2.98-5.02) for developing asthma in a high genetic risk group.

Smoking prevalence is higher among individuals with schizophrenia or depression. Previous work has suggested this relationship is causal. However, this may be due to dynastic effects, for example reflecting maternal smoking during pregnancy. We used a proxy gene-by-environment Mendelian randomization approach.

A higher muscle strength was associated with a lower MDD risk among individuals with a high genetic risk. Improving muscle strength should be encouraged for all individuals, including individuals with high Genetic risk for MDD.

Study used data from adults in the UK Biobank, a large-scale population-based study. Greater adherence to the hPDI was associated with lower risks of total mortality, cancer, and CVD. By contrast, higher uPDI scores were associated with higher risks of mortality, CVD, and cancer.

Large-scale prospective study was performed in the UK Biobank cohort. 17 836 individuals were diagnosed with asthma during over 10 years of follow-up. A combination of poor sleep and high genetic susceptibility led to a twofold higher risk compared with the low-risk combination.

Os autores conclu&#237;ram: &#8226; Neste estudo de coorte, grande, prospetivo, o consumo de caf&#233;, particularmente 2 a 3 ch&#225;venas por dia, esteve associado a redu&#231;&#245;es significativas da incid&#234;ncia e DCV e mortalidade. A pequena-moderada ingest&#227;o of caf& #233; deve ser desencorajada, mas antes ser considerada como parte of um estilo de vida saud& #225

Breakthrough SARS-CoV-2 infections of vaccinated individuals are being reported globally. Obesity and metabolic abnormalities were modifiable factors for severe COVID-19 in vaccinated patients.

Feelings of happiness have been associated with better performance in creative and flexible thinking and processing. Less is known about whether happier individuals have better performance on basic cognitive functions and slower rate of cognitive decline. No association was found between happiness and the rate of change over time on any of the cognitive tasks.

Physical activity confers protection against age-related cognitive dysfunction. Less is known about whether cognition is impacted by sedentary behaviour, specifically its mentally-active and passive forms. We explored whether individual variation in physical activity was directly associated with cognition.

Long-term exposure to road traffic noise was associated with increased incidence of primary hypertension. The effect estimates were stronger in the presence of higher air pollution. High exposure to both road traffic Noise and air pollution was associated to the highest hypertension risk.

Copy number variations (CNVs) are rare genomic deletions and duplications that can affect brain and behaviour. Previous reports of CNV pleiotropy imply that they converge on shared mechanisms at some level of pathway cascades. Here we quantitatively dissect associations between brain organization and behavioural differentiation across 8 key CNVs.

Exposures in utero and during infancy may impact the development of diseases later in life. This study aims to determine the associations between early life risk factors and development of frailty among middle-aged and older adults. Early life factors included being breast fed as a baby, maternal smoking, birth weight, the presence of perinatal diseases and birth month.

Based on the phenotypic data of 15 248 participants from the UK Biobank, a two-stage mediation analysis was performed to assess the association among brain volumes, anxiety, and irritable bowel syndrome. Anxiety mediated 30.8% for the left region ( &#946;   Average causal-mediated effect  = -0.013) and 21.6% for. the right region. The study revealed the indirect mediating role of anxiety in the association.

Elevated lipoprotein(a) [Lp(a)] levels are associated with the risk of coronary artery disease (CAD) and calcific aortic valve stenosis (CAVS) We investigated the association of Lp( a) with CAVS according to CRP levels in the European Prospective Investigation into Cancer and Nutrition (EPIC)-Norfolk study and the UK Biobank. In EPIC-Norfolk, in comparison to individuals with low Lp (a) levels ( 50 mg/dL) and low CRP ( 50mg/dL), those with high CRP (-2.0 mg/L) had a higher CAVS risk.

Sleep duration has been associated with cardiovascular disease, but the effect of sleep on peripheral artery disease (PAD) specifically remains unestablished. Sleep traits were assessed for associations with incident PAD using cohort analysis among 53 416 Swedish adults. Short sleep duration was associated with an increased risk of PAD.

Study aimed to estimate the differences in CVD-free life expectancy between people with different sleep profiles. We included 308,683 middle-aged adults from the UK Biobank among whom 140,181 had primary care data linkage. Poor sleepers lost 1.80 [95% CI 0.96-2.75] and 2.31 [1.46-3.29] years in females and males.

Being breastfed is associated with lower cardiovascular risk factors. But, to date, no studies have demonstrated a protective effect on cardiovascular disease (CVD) This study aims to address the limitations of previous studies.

Study looked at 466,207 participants free of dementia in the UK biobank. Compared with non-diabetic participants, diabetes participants had an adjusted hazard ratio of 1.87 for all-cause dementia.

Identifying genetic determinants of reproductive success may highlight mechanisms underlying fertility and identify alleles under present-day selection. Using data in 785,604 individuals of European ancestry, we identified 43 genomic loci associated with either number of children ever born (NEB) or childlessness.

The American Heart Association Life's Simple 7 (LS7) metric was used to define optimal cardiovascular and brain health. The associations with macrostructural hyperintensities and microstructural white matter damage are unclear.

Delirium is a complex neurocognitive syndrome suspected to be bidirectionally linked to dementia. Circadian rhythm disturbances likely contribute to dementia pathogenesis. Whether these disturbances are related to delirium risk and progression to all-cause dementia is unknown.

The incidence of early-onset colorectal cancer (EOCRC; patients) is 1 in 10,000. Early cancer is the most common form of cancer in the U.S. It is the leading cause of cancer deaths in the United States.

Short but not long sleep duration was associated with excessive type 2 diabetes risk. This increased risk among short sleepers seems to be protected against by PA. A higher level of PA, regardless of intensity, potentially ameliorates this excessive risk.

Study aimed to identify genetic modulators of clinical progression in Alzheimer's disease. APOE and PARL, a novel locus tagged by rs6795172, were significantly associated with AD clinical progression. Novel locus was linked to accelerated cognitive changes, higher tau levels, and faster atrophy of brain structures.

The Healthy Aging Index (HAI) has been regarded as useful in capturing the health status of multiple organ systems. To what extent the HAI is associated with major cardiovascular events remains largely unknown. Authors constructed a modified HAI to quantify the association of physiological aging with major vascular events and explored how the effects of a healthy lifestyle can modify this association. An mHAI was calculated in 338 044 participants aged 38 to 73 years.

Greater physical activity was associated with slower rates of macular GCIPL thinning in the PROGRESSA study. This association persisted in subanalyses of participants characterized as glaucoma suspects. Analysis among 8862 eyes from the UK Biobank revealed a positive association between physical activity and total macular thickness. These results highlight the potential neuroprotective benefits of exercise on the human retina.

Laxatives are commonly used among older populations for both treatment and prevention of constipation. Laxatives use may modify the effect of genetic predisposition on dementia.

Common Melanocortin-1 receptor (MC1R) red hair colour (RHC) variants and Microphthalmia-associated transcription factor (MITF) E318K separately confer moderate melanoma susceptibility. Their interactive effects are relatively unexplored.

Polygenic risk scores (PRS) can be used for risk stratification. CRC lifetime incidence for non-carriers ranges between 6 and 22%, compared to 40% and 74% for carriers. A suspicious FH is associated with a further increase of the cumulative incidence.

Liver fat associates with obesity-related metabolic disturbances and may precede incident diseases. Metabolomic profiles of liver fat in the UK Biobank were investigated. After accounting for confounders, multiple metabolites were associated positively with liver fat.

BMI increased risk of diagnosed OA per 5 kg/m 2 increment in BMI. Mendelian randomization demonstrated a robust BMI-OA causal relationship. BMI affecting OA comparably in both sexes and most strongly in the knee. Transcriptome-wide association study revealed 29 shared gene-tissue pairs targeting nervous, digestive, and exo/endocrine systems.

Individual-level and area-level socioeconomic deprivation were associated with increased dementia risk. Dementia prevention interventions may be particularly effective if targeted to households and areas with fewer socioeconomic resources, regardless of genetic vulnerability.

White matter (WM) microstructural/cytostructural disintegrity patterns related to higher systolic blood pressure (SBP) We investigated association of SBP with MRI diffusion metrics. Higher SBP was associated with lower FA and neurite density, but higher MD and ISOVF.

Coffee and tea intake was measured separately via baseline touchscreen questionnaire. During median 12.4-year follow-up, incident IBS was identified in 7736 participants. Compared with no coffee intake, consumption of 0.5-1, 2-3 and &#8805;4 cups/day was associated with lower IBS risk.

Little is known of the role of residential density and urbanicity on the risk of developing dementia including Alzheimer's disease. Study included participants from the UK Biobank who lived at the same residential address. After adjustments for potential risk factors, each 1,000 units/Km 2 increment in residential density was associated with higher risks.

Coffee consumption has been associated with lower risk of type 2 diabetes mellitus (T2D), but underlying mechanisms are not well understood. We investigated associations of habitual coffee consumption with incident T2D and repeated measures of insulin resistance. We studied differences by coffee types and smoking status in this association.

The role of vascular risk factors in age-related brain degeneration has long been the subject of intense study, but the role of obesity remains understudied. This study investigates sex differences in the association between adiposity and white matter microstructural integrity.
