In recent years, significant progress has been achieved in comprehending the impact of alcohol consumption on adverse health outcomes. However, the quality of evidence remains limited. Our objective was to conduct a prospective study examining the relationship between different types of alcoholic beverages and the risk of all-cause mortality, cardiovascular disease (CVD), and chronic kidney disease (KD)

 reduced kidney function is a risk factor of cardiovascular and all-cause mortality. It is unclear whether integrating multiple measured markers may improve mortality risk prediction. We conducted an exploratory factor analysis (EFA) of serum creatinine- and cystatin C-based estimated glomerular filtration rate.

The relationship between physical frailty, age-related conditions, and the incidence of degenerative valvular heart disease (VHD) remains unclear. This study aimed to investigate the potential association between frailty and the development of VHD. Participants from the UK Biobank were categorized into three groups based on the frailty phenotype.

Artificial sweeteners are widely popular worldwide as substitutes for sugar or caloric sweeteners. There are still several important unknowns and controversies regarding their associations with cardiovascular disease (CVD) We aimed to assess the association and subgroup variability between artificial sweeteners and CVD and CVA mortality in the UK Biobank cohort.

The independent role of body fat distribution and fat-free mass in heart failure (HF) risk is unclear. We investigated the role of different body composition compartments in risk of HF. Overall, HF risk was more strongly associated with central adiposity (waist circumference) than general adiposity.

Shift work was associated with higher risk of dementia (HR 1.29, 95 % CI 1.10-1.52), anxiety, depression and sleep disorders. Shift work was correlated with decreasing volume of various brain regions. Increased immune response and glucose levels are common pathways linking shift work to these disorders.

Using large-scale factor analysis, we distill hundreds of variables (diagnoses, assessments and survey items) into 35 latent constructs. We use data from unrelated individuals with predominantly estimated European genetic ancestry in UK Biobank. These factors recapitulate known disease classifications, disentangle elements of socioeconomic status and highlight the relevance of psychiatric constructs to health.

Metabolic status, metabolic transitions, and genetic susceptibility collectively impact cardiovascular outcomes and all-cause mortality across diverse body mass index (BMI) categories. We included a total of 481,576 participants at baseline.

The associations between specific types of sugary beverages and major chronic respiratory diseases remain relatively unexplored. This study aimed to investigate the associations of sugar-sweetened beverages (SSBs) with chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD) and asthma. The study included 210,339 participants from the UK Biobank.

Dementia is an important disease burden among the elderly, and its occurrence may be profoundly affected by environmental factors. Evidence of the relationship between air pollution and dementia is emerging, but the extent to which this can be offset by lifestyle factors remains ambiguous.

Cognitive impairment is a major determinant of functional outcomes in schizophrenia. Understanding of the biological mechanisms underpinning cognitive dysfunction in the disorder remains incomplete. We identify latent cognitive factors capturing genetic liabilities to 12 cognitive traits measured in the UK Biobank.

Vitamin D deficiency has been linked to various chronic pain conditions. However, randomized trials of vitamin D supplementation have had mixed results. We undertake a Mendelian randomization investigation in UK Biobank.

Mental health conditions are characterized by higher-order transdiagnostic factor structures. However, the phenotypic and genetic structures of various psychopathology diagnoses may differ, raising questions about the validity and utility of these factors. Here we study the phenotypes and genetic factor structures of ten psychiatric conditions.

Study included 11,997 patients with CHD from the UK Biobank. During a median follow up of 12.5 years, we documented 3366 recurrent cardiovascular events, 1068 myocardial infarction, 1829 heart failure events, 703 strokes, and 934 cardiovascular deaths. biomarkers including renal function and inflammation collectively explained 47.6%-87.7% of the associations.

DNA methylation has been implicated in the pathogenesis of numerous complex diseases. The exact methylation sites that play key roles in these processes remain elusive. One strategy to identify putative causal CpG sites and enhance disease etiology understanding is to conduct methylome-wide association studies.

It remains largely unknown whether individualised longitudinal changes of brain imaging features can be predicted based only on the baseline brain images. We explore this possibility using longitudinal data of multiple modalities from UK Biobank brain imaging, with around 3,500 subjects. Our study contributes a new theoretical framework for longitudinal brain imaging studies.

Study included 73,729 adults from the UK Biobank who wore an Axivity AX3 accelerometer on their dominant wrist for at least 3 days. High sedentary time was associated with higher risk of CVD mortality only among participants with low MVPA (HR 1.96; 95% CI 1.23 to 3.14).

Disease susceptibility of chronic axonal polyneuropathy is not fully explained by clinical risk factors. We determined the contribution of common genetic variants in chronic axonic polyneurpathy in the general population. Chronic axonalpolyneurophy was present in 2,357 of the 458,567 participants and 54.3% of the total population was female.

Type 2 diabetes mellitus (T2DM) and spinal degenerative disorders (SDD) are common diseases that frequently coexist. Traditional observational studies and recent Mendelian randomization (MR) studies have demonstrated conflicting evidence on the association between T2DM and SDD.

Age-related chronic inflammatory lung diseases impose a threat on public health, including idiopathic pulmonary fibrosis (IPF) and chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD) However, their etiology and potential targets have not been clarified. We performed genome-wide meta-analysis for IPF with the largest sample size (2883 cases and 741,929 controls) and leveraged the summary statistics of COPD (17,547 cases and 617,598 controls) The mediation effect was assessed using leukocyte telomere length (LTL) and single-cell transcriptome analysis was performed.

High-quality diets have been increasingly acknowledged as a promising candidate to counter the growing prevalence of mental health disorders. This study aims to investigate the prospective associations of adhering to the EAT-Lancet reference diet with incident depression, anxiety and their co-occurrence in 180,446 UK Biobank participants.

Haplotype estimation, or phasing, has gained significant traction in large-scale projects. Statistical methods excel in resolving common variants, but they still struggle at rare variants due to the lack of statistical information. In this study we introduce SAPPHIRE, a new method that leverages whole-genome sequencing data to enhance the precision of haplotype calls produced by statistical phasing.

No study has examined the joint association of diet and physical activity (PA) with type 2 diabetes (T2D) and hypertension. The aim of this study is to examine the joint associations of PA and diet with incidence of type T2D and hypertension, as a combined outcome and separately.

Evidence on weight transitions across life stages and cardiovascular diseases (CVDs) is limited. We aimed to explore weight transition patterns from birth to childhood to midlife and risk of incident CVDs. A total of 193,905 participants from the UK Biobank were included. Weight at birth, childhood, and midlife were collected at baseline (2006-2010) CVD outcomes were collected in 2022.

Study looked at polygenic risk scores (PRS) for SA in 334,706 UK Biobank participants. Found 246 (63.07%) behaviour-related and 200 (10.41%) physiological factors significantly associated with SA. Mendelian randomization analyses supported a potential causal effect of liability to 58 factors on SA.

Metabolic disorders exhibit strong inflammatory underpinnings and vice versa. This study aimed to investigate the association between metabolic health status, genetic predisposition, and the risk of inflammatory bowel disease (IBD)

Physical activity has proven effective in preventing atherosclerotic cardiovascular disease. But its role in preventing degenerative valvular heart disease (VHD) remains uncertain. Study aimed to explore the dose-response association between moderate to vigorous physical activity (MVPA) volume and the risk of degenerative VHD among middle-aged adults.

Iron plays a fundamental role in multiple brain disorders. The genetic underpinnings of brain iron and its implications for these disorders are still lacking. We find 36 genes linked to brain iron, with 29 not being previously reported. 16 of these genes can be replicated in an independent dataset with 3,039 subjects.

Study looked at the association between estimated 24-hour urinary sodium excretion and the occurrence of pancreatic cancer in the UK Biobank's large prospective cohort. Over a median follow-up period of 13.8 years, 1,765 cases of Pancreatic cancer were detected.

Few large studies have investigated predictors of increased motion in the first instance. Poorer values in most health traits predicted lower odds of complete imaging data. The largest association was for history of traumatic brain injury.

CKD increases the risk of cardiovascular disease (CVD) and is more prevalent in older adults. Retinal age gap, a biomarker of aging based on fundus images, has been previously developed and validated. This study aimed to investigate the association of retina age gap with CKD and subsequent CVD complications.

Healthy lifestyles were assessed in two large-scale surveys in the US and UK. The prevalence of periodontal diseases was the primary outcome in both surveys. The presence of at least 2-3 healthy behaviours was associated with lower odds of overall and severe periodontitis.

Every 0.5-diopter increase in MSE was associated with a 6% higher risk of depressive disorders. Hyperopia participants at a higher risk than non-hyperopia participants. MVPA and sleep time significantly correlated with depressive disorders, with odds ratios of 0.79 and 1.14 (P)

Limited epidemiologic data has suggested direct associations between hair pigment, race, and incidence of alopecia areata (AA) Here, we examine the relationship between natural hair color, race and the lifetime risk of AA. We included UK Biobank patients of all races and self-reported hair color.

A total of 260,836 participants from the UK Biobank were included. LE8 scores were determined by 8 metrics (physical activity, diet, nicotine exposure, sleep, body mass index, blood pressure, blood glucose, and blood lipids) Cox proportional hazards models were used to calculate the risk of IBD.

Light at night disrupts circadian rhythms, and circadian disruption is a risk factor for type 2 diabetes. Whether personal light exposure predicts diabetes risk has not been demonstrated in a large prospective cohort. UK Biobank participants wore light sensors for one week, recording day and night light exposure. Circadian amplitude and phase were modeled from weekly light data.

There is growing interest in the intersection of frailty and heart failure (HF) Large-sample longitudinal studies in the general population are lacking. This prospective cohort study included 340,541 participants free of HF at baseline in the UK Biobank. Frailty status was associated with a higher risk of incident HF independent of genetic risk. A younger population may be more susceptible to HF when exposed to frailty.

We studied the association of very low serum Lipoprotein(a) [Lp(a)] concentrations with new-onset type 2 diabetes (T2D) and non-alcoholic liver disease (NAFLD) in the UK Biobank. Using an extended biomarker dataset, we identified 47,362 participants with very low Lp( a) concentrations.

Computational variant effect predictors offer a scalable and increasingly reliable means of interpreting human genetic variation. Concerns of circularity and bias have limited previous methods for evaluating and comparing predictors. Population-level cohorts of genotyped and phenotyped participants can facilitate an unbiased benchmarking of available methods.

White individuals experience a higher risk of atrial fibrillation (AF) while exhibiting a lower AF-related stroke risk compared to other ethnic groups. It is possible that these observations stem from phenomena unique to the United States. The United Kingdom provides socialized medicine, which ostensibly promotes equitable health care access.

Fecal metabolites effectively discriminate inflammatory bowel disease (IBD) and show differential associations with diet. Metabolomics and AI-based models, including explainable AI (XAI), play crucial roles in understanding IBD.

Liver fat content increased the risk of non-alcohol liver cirrhosis, hepatocellular and Intrahepatic bile ducts and gallbladder cancers. Excess liver fat appears to be causally linked to liver Cirrhosis and cancers in a dose dependent manner.

The extent to which modifiable lifestyle factors offset the determined genetic risk of obesity and obesity-related morbidities remains unknown. The polygenic score for body mass index was calculated to quantify inherited susceptibility to obesity in 338,645 UK Biobank European participants. We observed significant interaction between high genetic risk and poor lifestyles.

The role of fasting plasma glucose (FPG), glycated hemoglobin (HbA1c), and triglyceride-glucose index (TyG index) in predicting all-cause and cause-specific mortalities remains elusive. This study included 384,420 adults from the Shanghai cohort and the UK Biobank (UKB) cohort.

It is unclear whether lifestyle factors affect bone mineral density (BMD) during different inflammatory states. This study investigated the effects of coffee consumption, vitamin D (VD) intake, smoking, and alcohol consumption on heel BMD in adults. Coffee was negatively associated with adult heel B MD in low inflammatory states, while there was no association between coffee and adult heel bMD in high inflammatory state. Coffee may reverse the adverse effects of inflammation on BMD when the patient is in a highly inflammatory state, thus acting as a protective agent.

Pubertal timing varies considerably and is associated with later health outcomes. We identified several genes harboring rare loss-of-function variants in ~200,000 women. Shared signals with menopause timing at genes involved in DNA damage response suggest that the ovarian reserve might signal centrally to trigger puberty.

Oral health problems were self-reported at baseline. Symptoms of depression and anxiety were assessed using the Mental Health Questionnaire (PHQ-4) in a cross-sectional study. Periodontal disease was consistently associated with an increased risk of depression, anxiety and their comorbidity.

Stratified medicine holds great promise to tailor treatment to the needs of individual patients. While genetics holds great potential to aid patient stratification, it remains a major challenge to operationalize complex genetic risk factor profiles. Contemporary approaches to this problem rely on polygenic risk scores (PRS)

Metabolic dysfunction-associated steatotic liver disease (MASLD) poses a considerable health risk. This study aimed to explore the relationship between reticulocyte count and MASLD.

Ageing hallmarks, characterising features of cellular ageing, have a role in the pathophysiology of many age-related diseases. We examined whether obesity is associated with an increased risk of developing such hallmark- related diseases.

The Mediterranean-DASH Intervention for Neurodegenerative Delay (MIND) diet is emerging as a promising candidate for preventive measures against inflammatory bowel disease (IBD) There is currently no direct evidence from population-based studies. This study aims to bridge the gap in understanding of the association of the MIND diet with IBD risk.

Floods have been the most common type of disaster and are expected to increase in frequency and intensity due to climate change. We collected data from 364 841 participants from the UK Biobank project. The risks associated with flooding exposure could last for several years, with the highest cumulative effect observed over 0-4 years.

Accurate measurement and classification of sleep/wake and sleep stages is important in clinical studies for sleep disorder diagnoses. We developed a self-supervised deep neural network for sleep stage classification using concurrent laboratory-based polysomnography and accelerometry. The sleep classifier was deployed in the UK Biobank with ~100,000 participants to study the association of sleep duration and sleep efficiency with all-cause mortality.

Study included 114,165 participants who completed at least two 24-h dietary recalls and were initially free of CVD from the UK Biobank. Incidence of total CVD, ischemic heart disease (IHD), atrial fibrillation (AF), heart failure (HF), and stroke were identified via electronic health records. Compared with participants with the lowest adherence to PHD, HRs for total Cvd, IHD, AF, HF, and stroke among those with the highest adherence were 0.79 and 0.88.

In a subset of females, postmenopausal status has been linked to accelerated aging. A complex interplay between reproductive-related factors, mental disorders, and genetics may influence brain function and accelerate the rate of aging.

UK Biobank participants reported on six life events that occurred within the past two years. Serious illness, injury, or assault to yourself, marital separation/divorce, and financial difficulties were associated with a higher risk of dementia. Death of a spouse/partner or close relative were mostly unrelated to dementia risk.

We included 262,368 women without prevalent T2DM from the UK biobank. Cox proportional hazards regression models were employed. During a mean follow-up of 12.2 years, 8,996 T2 DM cases were identified.

Studies have shown a link between myocardial infarction and shift work, but evidence is still lacking. We analysed data from the UK Biobank with >500 000 participants and an average 12-year follow-up duration. Night shift workers had a higher risk of myocardials infarctions compared to day workers.

MetaboAge and MetaboHealth are metabolomics-based biomarkers of biological age trained on chronological age and mortality risk. Lifestyle factors contribute to the extent chronological and biological age differ. associations between current smoking, sleeping &#8805;8 hours/day, higher BMI, and larger waist circumference were associated with higher MetaboAge.

BIA and dual-energy X-ray absorptiometry (DXA) serves as common modalities for body composition assessment. This study aimed to evaluate the agreement between BIA and DXA measures in UK Biobank.

The association between dietary magnesium (Mg) intake and the risk of atherosclerotic cardiovascular disease (ASCVD) remains uncertain. We aimed to examine the associations of dietary Mg intake with therisk of ASCVD events and mortality in individuals with and without type 2 diabetes. There were significantly negative associations between sufficient dietary MG intake (equal to or greater than the recommended daily intake) and risk ofASCVD incidence.

Our retinal image-based deep learning (DL) cardiac biological age (BioAge) model could facilitate fast, accurate, noninvasive screening for cardiovascular disease (CVD) in novel community settings.

In most Proteome-Wide Association Studies (PWAS), variants near the protein-coding gene are used to predict protein levels. However, proteins can be regulated through variants outside of the cis region. An intermediate GWAS step to identify protein quantitative trait loci (pQTL) allows for the inclusion of trans SNPs in protein-level prediction models.

 Investigating the genetic underpinnings of human aging is essential for unraveling the etiology of and developing actionable therapies for chronic diseases. We characterize the genetic architecture of the biological age gap across nine human organ systems in 377,028 participants of European ancestry from the UK Biobank.

Stroke stands as a major global health issue, causing high death and disability rates. The effectiveness of existing stroke risk assessment methods is questionable due to inconsistent and varying biomarkers. This study introduces an automatic deep learning-based system for predicting stroke risk.

Mendelian randomization (MR) studies support an effect of self-reported insomnia, but not others, on glycated haemoglobin (HbA1c) To explore potential effects, we used MR methods to assess effects of accelerometer-derived sleep traits. We found no causal effect of any accelerometers- derived sleep trait on HbA 1c or glucose.

Microdeletions on chromosome Xq23 disrupt the brain-expressed transient receptor potential (TRP) channel 5 (TRPC5) Male TRPC5 deletion carriers exhibited food seeking, obesity, anxiety, and autism. Women carrying TR PC5 deletions had severe postpartum depression.

Sarcopenia index (SI) based on serum creatinine and cystatin C. SI can predict clinical outcomes and discriminate between sarcopenia in a range of chronic and acute conditions. SI has not yet been tested in a large real-world general population dataset.

The phenotypic impact of compound heterozygous (CH) variation has not been investigated at the population scale. We phased rare variants (MAF &#8764;0.001%) in the UK Biobank (UKBB) exome-sequencing data to characterize recessive effects in 175,587 individuals. Genetic phase contributes to disease risk for gene-trait pairs: ATP2C2-COPD, FLG-asthma, and USH2A-visual impairment.

Stroke continues to be a leading cause of death and disability worldwide. Traditional stroke risk calculators are biased and imprecise. Novel stroke predictors need to be identified.

Cross-sectional study used data from the UK Biobank. Participants aged 40-69 years were recruited between the year 2006 and 2010. Annual average concentrations of NO X , NO 2 , PM 2.5 and PM 10 were estimated. Compared with the low group, the high group's APEX levels were associated with increased WMH volumes.

One-carbon metabolism coenzymes may influence brain aging in cognitively unimpaired adults. Increased B6 and B12 estimated intake linked with less functional connectivity in most networks, including the posterior portion of the Default Mode Network. Conversely, higher folate was related to more connectivity in similar networks.

Dysanapsis refers to a mismatch between airway tree caliber and lung size arising early in life. It is evident by early adulthood and associated with chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD) risk. We performed a genome-wide association study (GWAS) of CT-assessed dysanapsi in 11,951 adults. Higher dysanapscis genetic risk score was associated with obstructive spirometry.

Metabolic abnormalities are implicated in the etiology of neurodegenerative diseases. Their role in the development of amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (ALS) remains a subject of controversy. We aimed to identify the association between metabolic syndrome and the risk of ALS.

Gout is a nutrition-related, highly prevalent inflammatory arthritis with undesirable effects. The relationships between circulating fatty acids (FAs) and gout remain poorly understood. We included 268 174 participants with plasma FAs measured using nuclear magnetic resonance at the baseline (2006-2010) from the UK Biobank.

There is growing evidence that inflammation impairs erythrocyte structure and function. We assessed the impact of mild systemic inflammation on ery Throcyte fragility in three different settings. In mice challenged with a live attenuated bacterial strain to induce low-grade systemic inflammation, a significant increase in osmotic fragility was observed. Taken together, we conclude that mild systemic. inflammation increases ery throat fragility and may contribute to haemolysis.

High ultraprocessed food (UPF) consumption has been linked with increased mortality risk in the general population. But whether UPFs harm participants with a history of cancer remains unclear. This study aimed to evaluate the association of UPF consumption with mortality among participants.

Gout is associated with a significant burden of cardiovascular disease. The aim of this study was to evaluate the impact of a favorable lifestyle on incident cardiovascular events in patients with gout.

In this study, we aimed to compare imaging-based features of brain function with individual characteristics such as age, gender, and total intracranial volume. We developed a machine learning framework based on rsfMRI features in a dataset of 20,000 healthy individuals.

C-reactive protein/albumin ratio (CAR) seems to mirror disease severity and prognosis in several acute disorders particularly in elderly patients. Less is known about if CAR is superior to CRP in the general population. Cox regression analyses were conducted to assess all-cause and cardiovascular mortality.

MAFLD was associated with an increased risk of vascular dementia but a reduced risk of Alzheimer's disease. Differing risks emerged among MAFLD subtypes, with the diabetes subtype increasing risk of all-cause dementia.

VNTRs often appear unresolved ("dark") in variation databases due to their repetitive nature. One particularly complex and medically relevant VNTR is the KIV-2 VN TR located in the cardiovascular disease gene LPA which encompasses up to 70% of the coding sequence. We apply the approach to six protein-coding VNtrs in 2504 samples from the 1000 Genomes Project.

Atrial fibrillation (AF) has a substantial genetic component. Rare pLOF variants in 6 genes (TTN, RPL3L, PKP2, CTNNA3, KDM5B, and C10orf71) were associated with AF. Carriers with high PRS had a substantial 10-year risk of AF.

Coffee consumption is globally widespread and has become a lifestyle habit. This study investigated coffee consumption and liver-related survival in a large cohort of 455,870 individuals with UK biobank. Moderate coffee consumption was associated with lower all-cause mortality across the entire cohort.

Intelligence quotient is a vital index to evaluate the ability of an individual to think rationally, learn from experience and deal with the environment effectively. Few efforts have been paid to explore the potential associations of intelligence quotient traits with the tissue proteins from the brain, CSF and plasma.

Lumbar MRI findings may have stronger connections to LBP in specific subgroups of people. Genetically-predicted propensity to pain modifies the LDD-LBP association, with the strongest association present in people with the highest genetic propensity toPain.

Long-term exposure to high-level ambient PM 2.5 was associated with increased risks of brain disorders. The associations remain uncertain when the exposure is lower than current air quality standards in numerous countries. The brain-relevant epidemiological assessment suggests that each country should update the standard for ambient PM2.5 following the WHO Air Quality Guidelines 2021.

The electrocardiogram (ECG) can capture obesity-related cardiac changes. We trained an AI-ECG model to predict body mass index (BMI) from the ECG alone. The top tertile of delta-BMI showed increased risk of future cardiometabolic disease.

Both genetic and lifestyle factors contribute to myocardial infarction (MI) and stroke, including ischaemic stroke (IS) and intracerebral haemorrhage (ICH) We explored how and the extent to which a healthy lifestyle could counteract the genetic risk of those diseases, respectively.

We merge historical data on infant mortality rates to 370,000 individual records in the UK Biobank using information on local area and year of birth. We find no association between the polygenic index and heart disease in areas with the lowest infant mortality rate. But we find a strong positive relationship in areas characterized by high infant mortality.

There is a growing interest in using machine learning (ML) models to perform automatic diagnosis of psychiatric conditions. Generalising the prediction of ML models to completely independent data can lead to sharp decrease in performance. We assess the potential of multi-task learning (MTL) to improve accuracy by characterising multiple related conditions with a single model.

A cohort of 271,075 participants from the UK Biobank underwent analysis. Lifestyles were classified as unhealthy (0-1 score), general (2-3 score), and healthy (4-5 score) Air pollution was divided into three levels (high, moderate, and low) Cox proportional hazard regression analysis was performed to examine the links between lifestyle, air pollution, and all-cause mortality before and after adjustment for potential confounders.

The association of cardiovascular health levels, as measured by the Life's Essential 8 score, with cardiovascular disease (CVD) incidence and mortality among individuals with type 2 diabetes (T2D) has not been fully elucidated. This cohort study included 15,118 participants with T2D from the UK Biobank who were free of CVD and cancer at baseline. Compared to participants with low cardiovascular health, those with high cardiovascular health had a 52 %, 50 %, 47 %, 67 %, and 51 % lower risk.

There is a lack of comprehensive understanding of the temporal dynamics and neuroimaging biomarkers linked to accelerated (ABA) and resilient brain aging (RBA) This study addressed this gap by utilizing a large-scale UK Biobank (UKB) cohort.

Psoriatic disease (PsD) is closely associated with cardiovascular diseases. The Life's Essential 8 (LE8) score is a new metric for assessing cardiovascular health. A higher score indicates better CVH. However, the longitudinal association between LE8 score and the risk of PsD remains uncertain.

Interaction-LD score (i-LDSC) regression is an extension of the original LDSC framework that accounts for interactions between genetic variants. For each of the 25 traits analyzed in the UK Biobank and BioBank Japan, i-L DSC detects additional variation contributed by genetic interactions.

Inflammation has been linked to nonalcoholic fatty liver disease (NAFLD) Most studies have focused on a single indicator, leading to inconsistent results. This study aimed to thoroughly investigate the potential associations between different systemic inflammatory indicators and NAFLD in the UK Biobank cohort.

This study explores the role that place of birth and place of residence have in variation in cognition in adulthood in the UK. We find, consistent with studies in the US, that place effects at both time points contribute modest variation.

Frailty is a common geriatric syndrome associated with reduced reserves and increased vulnerability to stressors among older adults. Vitamin D deficiency has been implicated in frailty, as it is essential for maintaining musculoskeletal functions. The relationship between dynamic changes in vitamin D levels and frailty over time has not been extensively studied.

Data of 356,894 participants without cancer at baseline in the UK Biobank were analyzed. Sleep score was evaluated using five sleep traits (sleep duration, chronotype, insomnia, snoring, and excessive daytime sleepiness) Circulating liver function biomarkers were measured. Cox proportional hazard model was performed to investigate the independent and joint associations of sleep and liver function.

There is limited evidence of the longitudinal associations between frailty, genetic predisposition to CKD, and the risk of CKD in the general population. This study aimed to examine such associations among participants in the UK Biobank. The study underscores the importance of frailty screening and intervention as a potential strategy to prevent CKD.

Social disconnection has been associated with poor cardiometabolic health. This study sought to investigate the associations of social isolation and loneliness with diabetic microvascular complications (DMC) among individuals with type 2 diabetes mellitus.

The Multimorbidity-Adjusted Disability Score (MADS) integrates disease trajectory methodologies with advanced techniques for assessing interdependencies among concurrent diseases. This approach is designed to better assess the clinical burden of clusters of interrelated diseases and enhance our ability to anticipate disease progression.

The Merovingian period (5th to 8th cc AD) was a time of demographic, socioeconomic, cultural, and political realignment in Western Europe. Here, we report the whole-genome shotgun sequence data of 30 human skeletal remains from a coastal LateMerovingian site of Koksijde. We find two distinct ancestries, one shared with Early Medieval England and the Netherlands, while the other, minor component, reflecting likely continental Gaulish ancestry.

Recent evidence has linked childhood maltreatment with cardiovascular disease risk. This prospective analysis included 151,741 participants from the UK Biobank. Childhood maltreatment, including five types, was measured using the Childhood Trauma Screener (CTS) Incident arrhythmias were documented through linked hospital admission and death registry.

Study included 34,454 participants (53.4% females) aged 40-73 years from the UK Biobank. Brain volumes were measured using magnetic resonance imaging between 2014 and 2019. Strongest mediator for the association between greenspace buffered at 1000 m and total brain volume was smoking.

The incidence rate of infections was 29.3/1000 person-y in patients with T2D. Compared with those with 25(OH)D of 50.0-74.9 nmol/L, the multivariable-adjusted IRRs and 95% CIs of total infections, pneumonia, gastrointestinal infections, and sepsis were 1.44 and 1.41, respectively.

We identified a genetic subtype (C4) of type 2 diabetes (T2D) benefitting from intensive glycemia treatment in the ACCORD trial. We characterized the population of patients that met the C4 criteria in the UKBiobank cohort. C4 individuals were less likely to develop T2D, were slightly older and had lower HbA1c values.

Malnutrition, sarcopenia and frailty are distinct, albeit interrelated, conditions associated with adverse outcomes in adults with cancer. Whether they relate to multimorbidity, which affects up to 90% of people with cancer, is unknown. This study investigated the relationship between multimorbridity with malnutrition, sarc Openia and (pre-)frailty.

Run-of-homozygosity (ROH) segments, contiguous homozygous regions in a genome were traditionally linked to families and inbred populations. ROH-DICE identified over 1 million ROH diplotypes that span over 100 single nucleotide polymorphisms and are shared by more than 100 UK Biobank participants.

Residential greenness is defined as the area-weighted mean of greenness coverage based on the land used data from the Generalized Land Use Database for England (GLUD) 2005 in the UK Biobank. PM 10 partially mediated the relationship between greenness and allergic rhinitis incidence with a mediation effect of 26.9%.

The relationship between branched-chain amino acids (BCAAs) and sarcopenia is incompletely understood. We conducted a community-based study involving > 100,000 United Kingdom adults. We assessed the potential role of muscle mass in mediating the relationship between BCAAs and muscle strength.

Smoking is a recognized risk factor for chronic kidney disease (CKD) The relationship between the time smoking is initiated after awakening each day and CKD remains largely unstudied. This study examined the association between this timing and the risk of CKD.

Polygenic scores (PGS) from genome-wide association studies are increasingly utilized. However, independent method evaluation is lacking, and method comparisons are often limited. Here, we evaluate polygenic scores derived via seven methods in five biobank studies. We found that no single method consistently outperformed all others.

VAT volume is associated with poorer brain health in midlife. This relationship is greatest in men and those at younger ages. Greater VAT was associated with lower TBV, GMV and THV.

There is growing evidence of an association between inflammatory bowel disease (IBD) and psychiatric disorders. This study aimed to examine the association between IBD and the risk of incident psychiatric disorders and investigate whether and how blood biomarkers mediate this association.

Polygenic risk scores (PRSs) enable early prediction of disease risk. Evaluating PRS performance for binary traits commonly relies on the area under the receiver operating characteristic curve (AUC) However, the widely used DeLong's method for comparative significance tests suffer from limitations, including computational time.

Few studies have evaluated the benefits of colorectal cancer (CRC) screening integrating both non-genetic and genetic risk factors. We applied the integrated model to calculate 10-year CRC risk for 430,908 participants in the UK Biobank.

Pilonidal sinus disease is a highly morbid condition characterized by the formation of chronic sinus tracts throughout the sacrococcygeal region. Despite its commonality and strong association with family history, there is no prior investigation of genetic risk factors for pilonidal Sinus disease.

Cholesteryl ester transfer protein (CETP) inhibitors, initially developed for treating hyperlipidemia, have shown promise in reducing the risk of new-onset diabetes. Given their oral administration, they could complement existing oral medications like sodium-glucose cotransporter 2 (SGLT2) inhibitors.

Polygenic risk scores (PRSs) likely predict risk and prognosis of glaucoma. We compared the PRS performance for primary open-angle glau coma (POAG), defined using International Classification of Diseases (ICD) codes. We identified POAG cases in Mount Sinai BioMe and Mass General Brigham (MGB) biobank using ICD codes.

High frequency of playing computer games was associated with decreased risk of incident dementia. Individuals with high frequency of games had better performance in prospective memory. Genetically determined computer gaming was associated to a low risk of dementia. Computer gaming could modulate cognitive function and may be a promising target for dementia prevention.

Metabolic syndrome (MetS) has been linked to dementia. In this study, we examined the association of MetS with neuroimaging and cognition in dementia-free adults. MetS was associated with lower total brain, gray matter, and hippocampal volumes. Study participants with MetS performed poorer on cognitive tests.

Irritable bowel syndrome (IBS) patients exhibit significantly lower levels of serum selenium (Se) compared to healthy controls. This study integrates a prospective cohort analysis and animal experiments to investigate Se deficiency as a potential risk factor for IBS.

Previous research has indicated a potential connection between psychological stress and how individuals perceive their own age. The current study explores the relationship between negative emotions and self-perceived age. After adjusted for covariates, participants with irritability, nervous feelings, worrier/anxious feelings or fed-up feelings are more likely to be rated as "about your age" or "older than you are"

Obese adults are often reported to have smaller brain volumes than their non-obese peers. Whether this represents evidence of accelerations in obesity-driven atrophy or is instead a legacy of developmental differences established earlier in the lifespan remains unclear. This study aimed to investigate whether early-life differences in adiposity explain differences in numerous adult brain traits commonly attributed to mid-life obesity.

Cardiovascular health (CVH) has been associated with cognitive decline and dementia. We investigated the association of CVH, assessed using Life's Essential 8 (LE8), with neuroimaging-based brain age and brain-predicted age difference (brain-PAD)

Study used data from four cohorts in the International Collaboration for a Life Course Approach to Reproductive Health and Chronic Disease Events. Histories of infertility, miscarriage, and stillbirth were self-reported. Compared to women without stillbirth, a history of recurrent stillbirths was associated with 64% higher risk of dementia.

Mfge8 is a major exosome (EV) protein known to mediate inflammation and atherosclerosis in type 2 diabetes mellitus (T2DM) in animal studies. The pathophysiological role of this protein in obesity, T2DM, and cardiovascular disease is less investigated in humans. We found a rare Asian Indian population-specific missense variant (rs371227978; Arg148His) in the MFGE8 gene associated with increased circulating M fge8 and T2 DM. We also evaluated the exposure of Mfge 8-enriched human EVs in zebrafish (ZF) for their impact on cardiometabolic organ system.

Study conducted a prospective follow-up of 112,196 NAFLD participants diagnosed at baseline from the UK Biobank cohort study. Five sleep behaviors were collected to measure a healthy sleep score. Five genetic variants were used to construct a polygenic risk score.

Using data from the UK Biobank, we identified independent LEAP2 gene single nucleotide polymorphisms (SNPs) We examined their associations with obesity traits and serum insulin-like growth factor-1 (IGF-1) concentration.

Frailty is a phenotype of decreased physiological reserves and diminished ability to respond to stressors. Epidemiological evidence connecting frailty to non-alcoholic fatty liver disease (NAFLD) and cirrhosis risks remain sparse. We aimed to assess the longitudinal associations of frailty with the risks of severe NAFLD and Cirrhosis in middle-aged to older adults.

The Graded Incomplete Letters Test (GILT) is an optimised psychophysical variation of a test used to diagnose cortical visual impairment. It measures thresholds for recognising letters under levels of increasing visual degradation (decreasing "completeness") in a similar fashion to ophthalmic tests.

The evidence about the associations of leukocyte telomere length (LTL) and intermediary cardiovascular phenotypes with adverse cardiovascular outcomes is inconclusive. This study assessed these relationships with cardiovascular imaging, electrocardiography, and the risks of sudden cardiac death (SCD), coronary events, and heart failure admission.

Previous preclinical evidence indicates a protective role of quercetin against inflammatory bowel disease (IBD) However, there is no evidence from human populations, resulting in knowledge gaps. We aimed to prospectively evaluate the associations between dietary quercETin intake and IBD in humans and  in vivo animal models.

Physical activity (PA) has been shown to reduce diabetes mortality, but largely based on imprecise self-reported data. We perform a prospective cohort study of 19,624 individuals with type 2 diabetes (T2D) from the UK Biobank with a median follow-up of 6.9 years. We observe L-shaped associations of longer duration of PA, regardless of PA intensity, with risks of all-cause and cancer mortality.

Polygenic scores (PGS) have emerged as the tool of choice for genomic prediction in a wide range of fields. We show that PGS performance varies broadly across contexts and biobanks. Contexts such as age, sex and income can impact PGS accuracy.

IL-6 is a crucial cytokine in inflammatory responses. Recent evidence has linked elevated IL-6 levels to changes in brain structure and cognitive decline. This study utilized a longitudinal cohort from the UK Biobank to analyze the correlation between IL- 6 expression levels, cognitive performance, and brain volumes.

Spirometry was conducted at baseline and a second visit after 5-7 years. The primary outcomes were annual changes in the per cent-predicted forced expiratory volume in 1 s.

Hospital-treated infectious diseases were associated with an increased risk of PD. The greatest PD risk was observed in neurological/eye infection. A dose-response relationship between infection burden and incident PD was revealed.

Study examined associations between residential environments and late-onset schizophrenia and its interaction with genetic risk factors in UK Biobank. Within 300 m buffer surrounding the residential addresses, per interquartile increase in greenspace (31.5%) and total natural environment (34.4%) were associated with an 11% lower risk of late-ONSet schizophrenia. Domestic garden and blue space did not show significant protective effects on late-ONS.

Familial hypercholesterolemia (FH) is a significantly underdiagnosed monogenic disorder. Improved detection could reduce the large number of cardiovascular events attributable to poor case finding. We aimed to assess whether machine learning algorithms outperform clinical diagnostic criteria and recommended screening criteria.

Hospital-treated infectious diseases were associated with a greater risk of T2D. Bacterial infection with sepsis had the strongest risk. The risk showed specificity according to types, sites, severity of infection and period since infection occurred.

Air pollutants are important exogenous stimulants to eye diseases. Long-term exposure to air pollutants was associated with an increased risk of POAG. Stratification analyses revealed stronger effects in Black people and the elderly.

We study the feasibility of combining privacy preserving synthetic data sets in place of the original data for collaborative learning on real-world health data from the UK Biobank. Data sharing can especially help parties whose data contain underrepresented groups to perform better-adjusted analysis for said groups.

Chronological age (CAge), biological age (BAge), and accelerated age (AAge) are all important for aging-related diseases. CAge is a known risk factor for benign prostatic hyperplasia (BPH); However, the evidence of association of BAge and AAge with BPH is limited. This study aimed to evaluate the association of CAge, Bage, and AA ge with B PH in a large prospective cohort.

Previous research has not investigated the persistent cutaneous immune-related adverse events (cirAEs) related to long COVID. This multinational study utilizes large national claims-based cohorts, using ICD-10 code diagnosis, focusing on patients aged &#8805;20 years from three countries: South Korean, Japanese, and the British cohorts. An increased risk of cirAEs was observed (HR, 1.10; 95% CI,. 1.06-1.14) in Korean cohort, while a similar association was observed in Japanese and UK cohorts.

Cognitive decline is among the most common non-motor symptoms in Parkinson's disease. The underlying genetic background was still less studied. We identified significant association between locus rs75819919 (DPP6) and accelerated cognitive decline.

We consider problems where many, somewhat redundant, hypotheses are tested and we are interested in reporting the most precise rejections. Assuring FDR control on the reported findings with these adaptive searches is, however, often impossible. To design a multiple comparison procedure that allows for an adaptive choice of resolution with FDR control, we leverage e-values and linear programming.

Study included 22 989 patients with type 2 diabetes from the UK Biobank. New-onset atrial fibrillation was ascertained from hospital admission records. During median of 12.3 years of follow-up, 844 all-cause dementia, 342 Alzheimer's disease and 246 vascular dementia cases occurred.

A healthy brain underpins cognitive and physical well-being, and mitigates cognitive decline, neurodegenerative diseases, and mental health disorders. We introduce a novel approach to forecasting a brain health index (BHI) by deploying three distinct models, each capitalizing on different modalities for training and testing.

Genome-wide association studies (GWAS) are often underpowered due to small effect sizes. We propose redefining case-control outcomes into ordinal case-subthreshold-asymptomatic variables. Overall, the ordinal model improves statistical power in GWAS consistent with increasing the sample size by approximately 10%.

Synthetic surrogate (SynSurr) analysis makes GWAS on imputed phenotypes robust to imputation errors. Rather than replacing missing values, SynSurr jointly analyzes the original and imputed traits. We show thatsynSurr estimates the same genetic effect as standard GWAS.

Liver fibrosis, typically a silent condition, is antecedent to cirrhosis. The objective of this study was to test the hypothesis that elevated Fibrosis-4 (FIB-4) index is associated with an increased risk of hemorrhagic stroke. Among 452,994 participants (mean age, 57 years; 54% women), approximately 2% had FIB- 4 index >2.67.

Unhealthy sleep behaviors are associated with higher risks of osteoporosis (OP), while prospective evidence is limited. This study aimed to quantify the attributable burden of OP incidence reduction due to unhealthy sleep behaviors.

Three trans-ancestry PRSs achieved moderately improved predictive performance in EAS compared to EUR populations. Among these models, PRS183 demonstrated the optimal discriminatory ability in both EAS and EUR validation datasets, particularly for individuals at risk of colorectal neoplasms.

Incretin-based therapies are highly successful in combatting obesity and type 2 diabetes. Yet both activation and inhibition of the glucose-dependent insulinotropic polypeptide receptor (GIPR) in combination with glucagon-like peptide-1 receptor (GLP-1R) activation have resulted in similar clinical outcomes. This underlines the importance of a better understanding of the GIP system.

Study explores the independent and joint associations of accelerometer-measured physical activity and genetic predisposition with incident coronary artery disease. UK Biobank population-based cohort recruited over 500,000 individuals aged 40 to 69 between 2006 and 2010. During a median follow-up of 6.8 years, 1,382 cases of coronary arteries disease developed.

It's unclear if excess visceral adipose tissue (VAT) mass in individuals with prediabetes can be countered by adherence to a Mediterranean lifestyle (MEDLIFE) We aimed to examine VAT mass, MEDLIFE adherence, and their impact on type 2 diabetes (T2D) and diabetic microvascular complications (DMC)

Canine and human osteosarcoma are similar in clinical presentation and tumor genomics. We prioritized association testing of 5985 human SNPs mapping to candidate osteosArcoma risk regions detected in Irish wolfhounds. Fourteen SNPs were associated with human osteoarthritis risk after adjustment.

Type 2 diabetes (T2D) is a major risk factor for heart failure (HF) and has elevated incidence among individuals with HF. Since genetics and HF can independently influence T2D, collider bias may occur when T2d (i.e., collider) is controlled for by design or analysis. We conducted a genome-wide association study (GWAS) of diabetes-related HF with correction forCollider bias.

Polygenic scores (PGSs) offer the ability to predict genetic risk for complex diseases. To produce risk estimates relevant to clinical and public health decision-making, it is important to account for varying effects due to age and sex. We develop a novel framework to estimate country-, age-, and sex-specific estimates of cumulative incidence stratified by PGS for 18 high-burden diseases.

Most medicines with drug-gene interactions (DGIs) are prescribed in primary care. This study aimed to estimate the prevalence of potential and actionable DGIs. Antidepressants, weak opioids and statins were most commonly identified.

Fish oil has been considered to have an anti-inflammatory effect and has been proven to play a beneficial role in the incidence of numerous diseases. The association between fish oil supplementation and the risk of systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE) is still unknown. This study aimed at evaluating the correlation between fishOil use and incident SLE in a large population-based prospective cohort.

Previous studies suggest a role for inflammation in hepatocarcinogenesis. No study has comprehensively evaluated associations between circulating inflammatory proteins and risk of hepatocellular carcinoma (HCC) We conducted a nested case-control study with 56 pairs of incident HCC cases and controls.

Mitochondrial dysfunction is a hallmark of liver diseases. The effects of functional variants such as protein truncating variants (PTVs) in MT-related genes have not been extensively explored. We extracted 60,928 PTVs across 2466MT-related nucleus genes.

The cognitive impairment patterns and the association with Alzheimer's disease (AD) in mental disorders remain poorly understood. We analyzed data from 486,297 UK Biobank participants, categorizing them by mental disorder history to identify the risk of AD and the cognitive impairment characteristics. Causation was further assessed using Mendelian randomization (MR). AD risk was higher in individuals with bipolar disorder (BD) and obsessive-compulsive disorder (OCD)

People with type 1 diabetes (T1D) carry a markedly increased risk of stroke. We used whole-exome or whole-genome sequencing of 1,051 individuals with T1D. We identified a rare missense variant on SREBF1 significantly associated with stroke. Due to the rarity of the identified genetic variants, future replication is required.

Coronary artery disease (CAD) exists on a spectrum of disease represented by a combination of risk factors and pathogenic processes. An in silico score for CAD built using machine learning and clinical data in electronic health records captures disease progression, severity and underdiagnosis.

Hypothyroidism is a common endocrine disorder whose prevalence increases with age. The disease manifests itself when the thyroid gland fails to produce sufficient thyroid hormones. We used GWAS compilation from Open Targets and tuned protocols focusing on genes and coding regions. We propose that the integration of established association methods enhances interpretability and clinical utility.

Bayesian Linear Programming can efficiently convert any posterior distribution over signals into credible regions for signals. Applying BLiP to existing state-of-the-art analyses of UK Biobank data increased power by 30%-120% in just a few minutes of additional computation.

BMI shows heterogeneous body mass index (BMI) sensitivity. We performed stratification based on BMI to optimize predictions for BMI-related diseases. Polygenic risk scores from low-BMI discovery outperformed PRSs from high BMI. T2D predictions showed 37% improvements over unstratified-matched-population prediction.

Susceptibility to metabolic syndrome (MetS) is dependent on genetics, environment, and gene-by-environment interactions. We derived a continuous metric, the metabolic health score (MHS), based on standard clinical parameters. In human UK Biobank, the MHS associated with MetS status and was predictive of future disease incidence.

Small airways obstruction (SAO) has been associated with occupational exposures. We used data from UK Biobank participants with SAO. A greater mortality risk was associated with exposure to VGDF.

Chronic kidney disease (CKD) is a complex disorder that has become a high prevalence global health problem. Autosomal genetic variation only explains some of the predisposition to kidney disease. Variations in the mitochondrial genome (mtDNA) and nuclear-encoded mitochondrial genes (NEMG) are implicated in susceptibility to CKD. We investigated the association of variation in both mtDNA and NEMG with CKD (and related traits)

Cross-sectional study of 201,466 European participants from UK Biobank. Found 42.8% of the association between genetic predisposition to obesity and phenotypic obesity was explained by lifestyle. Significant difference between men and women was found in central obesity.

Cohort studies linking greenspace exposure to a lower risk of obesity-related cancer (ORC) are scarce. Existing evidence on site-specific cancers has predominantly relied on non-specific greenspace measures. We examined associations of total greenspace, private residential gardens, and other greenspace types with the risk of being diagnosed with ORC.

Complicated associations between multiplexed environmental factors and aging are poorly understood. Air pollution presented a relatively large contribution in most cases. Particulate matter contributed the most to variance in aging. Noise and green space showed considerable contribution to brain volumes.

Low total kidney volume (TKV) is a risk factor for chronic kidney disease (CKD) However, evaluations of nonlinear relationships, incident events, causal inference, and prognostic utility beyond traditional biomarkers are lacking. TKV, height-adjusted TKv, and body surface area- adjusted TKVs of 34,595 White British ancestry participants were derived from the UK Biobank.

Multiple sclerosis (MS) is a chronic inflammatory disease affecting the central nervous system. Previous studies have indicated that albumin may exert influence on the inflammatory process and confer beneficial effects in neurodegenerative disorders. Here, we aimed to explore the link between albumin and the risk of MS.

Exome-wide analyses converged on RAB32 as a novel PD gene identifying c.213C > G/p.S71R as a high-risk variant. This variant was confirmed in all cases via Sanger sequencing and segregated with PD in three families. Functional analyses showed that RAB 32 S71R increases LRRK2 kinase activity, as indicated by increased autophosphorylation of L RRK2 S1292.

Frailty Index (FI) is a common measure of frailty, which has been advocated as a routine clinical test. The genetic and phenotypic relationships of FI with cardiovascular indicators (CIs) and behavioral characteristics (BCs) are unclear. The model developed by integrating easily collected CIs and BCs data in predicting FI has the potential to monitor disease risk.

Cross-sectional evidence suggests a possible link between frailty and atrial fibrillation (AF) Study aimed to determine whether the frailty phenotype is longitudinally associated with incident arrhythmias.

Head and neck cancer (HNC) incidence is on the rise, often diagnosed at late stage. Risk prediction tools have a potential role in prevention and early detection. Demographics and risk behaviors are strong predictors of HNC.

We analyzed data from UK biobank prospective study (n = 421,650, median 12.5 years follow-up) to examine disparities of mortality risk associated with air pollution. Fine particulate matter (PM 2.5 ), PM 10  and nitrogen dioxide (NO 2 ) were measured and assigned to each participants' address. In disadvantaged communities, air pollutants explained larger proportions of deaths and such disparities persisted over past decades.

Previous investigations into multiple sclerosis (MS) risk factors predominantly relied on retrospective studies. We aimed to evaluate the impact of genetic and early life factors on MS diagnosis by employing a time-to-event analysis in a prospective cohort. Tobacco smoking and infectious mononucleosis diagnosis were also considered.

Cystatin C (Cyst-C) concentrations were significantly and positively associated with the risks of kidney cancer, lung cancer, leukemia, mesothelial and soft tissue cancer, multiple myeloma, non-Hodgkin lymphoma and liver cancer. Only in men, higher Cyst- C concentrations (per SD increment) were associated with higher risks of head and neck cancer.

Study included 87,039 participants from the UK Biobank who had 7-day accelerometry data. Low rest-activity rhythm amplitude was associated with a higher risk of ASCVD.

Coronary artery disease (CAD) is the leading cause of death among adults worldwide. Accurate risk stratification can support optimal lifetime prevention. Current methods lack the ability to incorporate new information throughout the life course.

The human brain has been implicated in the pathogenesis of several complex diseases. genome-wide association studies have taken it a step further and revealed brain cell-type-specific functions for disease loci. Mendelian randomization studies usually include all instrumental variables from GWAS, which hampers the understanding of cell-specific causality.

Study included 407,027 participants from the UK Biobank. Sleep index of each participant was retrieved from seven sleep behaviors. Compared with participants in low. sleep quality group, those in medium and high sleep. quality group decreased 0.727 (95%CI, 0.653 to 0.801) and 1.056 (95%.CI, 1.494 to 1.592) years of PhenoAgeaccel, respectively. There was interaction between the genetic risk and sleep quality.

The current understandings of the relationship between air pollution (AP), greenspace exposure and Parkinson's Disease (PD) remain inconclusive. We engaged 441,462 participants from the UK Biobank who were not diagnosed with PD.

Low lung function is associated with an increased risk of age-related diseases. Relationship between AMD and low lung function remains unclear. We conducted a prospective cohort analysis of 409 230 UK Biobank participants with completed lung function after excluding individuals with AMD.

There are 90 independent genome-wide significant genetic risk variants for Parkinson's disease (PD) There are currently only five nominated loci for PD progression. The biology of PD progression is likely to be of central importance.

Glucosamine is a dietary supplement commonly used to support joint health. There has been interest in exploring other effects of glucosamine on health outcomes due to its ant-inflammation effect. This study compared the risks of major adverse liver outcomes (MALOs) between regular users and non-users.

Study involved 444,343 participants, with 4,458 cases of KSD identified during an average follow-up period of 12.6 years. Higher 25(OH)D levels were not associated with developing kidney stones in general population model 3 (HR = 0.88 [95% CI 0.77-1.01] Women over 60 years old were associated with a lower risk of kidney stone disease.

The contribution of gene-environment interactions (GxE) to complex trait variation can provide insights into disease mechanisms and explain sources of heritability. We introduce a method to estimate the proportion of trait variance explained by GxE and additive genetic effects across the genome. We show that our method is accurate in simulations and computationally efficient for biobank-scale datasets.

The World Health Organization recently released a novel metric for healthy aging: intrinsic capacity (IC) The relationship between IC and the incidence of dementia, and its subtypes, is unknown. This cohort study involved 366,406 participants from the UK Biobank between 2006 and 2010.

Alzheimer's disease is the largest contributor to dementia at the population level. We investigated whether a neurobiological model of DMN effective connectivity could predict a future dementia diagnosis at the single-participant level. Dysconnectivity predicted both future dementia incidence and time to diagnosis.

Heart failure (HF) risk is greater in rural versus urban regions in the United States (US) Whether this excess risk applies to countries with universal healthcare is unclear and the underlying biological mechanisms are unknown. In the prospective United Kingdom (UK) Biobank, we investigated urban-rural regional differences in HF risk.

Atrial fibrillation (AF) is associated with an elevated risk of cognitive impairment and dementia. Understanding the cognitive sequelae and brain structural changes associated with AF is vital for addressing ensuing health care needs. We investigated neuropsychological and multimodal neuroimaging data of 1335 individuals with AF and 2683 matched controls.

The association of diet with atopic dermatitis (AD) remains poorly understood and could help explain heterogeneity in disease course. This cross-sectional study examined 24-hour urine sodium excretion, which was estimated using a single spot urine sample collected between March 31, 2006, and October 1, 2010. Multivariable logistic regression models adjusted for age, sex, race and ethnicity, Townsend Deprivation Index, and education were used.

Pulmonary function is associated with the development of chronic liver disease. Evidence of the association between pulmonary function and cirrhosis risk is still lacking. This study aimed to investigate the longitudinal associations of pulmonary function with the developing of cirrhotic disease.

Fracture prediction is essential in managing patients with osteoporosis. We aimed to identify the most relevant clinical fracture risk factors in contemporary populations. We used traditional and machine learning survival models to predict risks of vertebral, hip and any fractures.

Telomere length is a putative biomarker of aging and is associated with multiple age-related diseases. We identified 18 robust rare-variant genes for LTL, most of which estimated effects on LTL were significant. Three novel genes (ASXL1, CFAP58, and TET2) were identified.

High LE8 score was associated with reduced risk of MCI and dementia. It was also linked to brain MRI indices. LE8 combined age and sex had good performance for predicting all-cause dementia.

Metabolic dysfunction-associated steatotic liver disease (MASLD) is currently the most common chronic liver disease worldwide. MASLD is strongly associated with metabolic comorbidities, including dyslipidemia. Isolated hypertriglyceridemia is the second strongest independent predictor of MASLD/MASH.

Cardiovascular diseases (CVDs) are responsible for a large proportion of premature deaths in low- and middle-income countries. Early CVD detection and intervention is critical in these populations. Many existing CVD risk scores require a physical examination or lab measurements, which can be challenging in such health systems due to limited accessibility. We investigated the potential to use photoplethysmography (PPG), a sensing technology available on most smartphones that can potentially enable large-scale screening at low cost.

Cardiorespiratory fitness (CRF) has wide effects on metabolic, cardiovascular, pulmonary and neurological health. Despite the wide effects, challenges in the feasibility and reproducibility of CRF measurements have impeded its use for clinical decision-making. Here we link proteomic profiles to CRF in 14,145 individuals across four international cohorts.

Residential greenness is considered beneficial to human health. Its association with respiratory function has been found in previous studies. We conducted a prospective cohort study based on participants of the UK Biobank.

Long-term exposure to air pollutants during circadian syndrome was associated with subsequent CVD and death. CVD, particularly CHD, significantly mediated the associations of PM 2.5 , NO 2 , NO x and air pollution score with death.

Loneliness and social isolation are linked to higher risk of developing chronic kidney disease (CKD) American Heart Association has highlighted importance of considering social determinants of health in conjunction with traditional risk factors in patients with diabetes.

A total of 416 220 participants from the UK Biobank were included in this prospective cohort study. Fried phenotype was adopted to evaluate frailty, which included 5 aspects. More than 800 infectious diseases were identified based on electronic health records.

Evaluate sex differences in cardiovascular disease (CVD) risk prediction. Use of sex-specific risk thresholds should be considered in any re-evaluation of CVD risk calculators. At current risk thresholds, PCE and QRISK3 work less well for women than men but sensitivity was improved in women using a 5% 10-year risk threshold.

Dyslipoproteinemia often involves simultaneous derangements of multiple lipid traits. We aimed to evaluate the phenotypic and genetic characteristics of combined lipid disturbances in a general population-based cohort. Incident coronary artery disease risk was estimated for each subtype using Cox proportional hazards models.

Young women have a slower progressive loss of kidney function than age-matched men. Sex advantage diminishes after menopause, suggesting a role for female hormones in the development of kidney diseases.

The GSA-MiXeR analytical tool for gene set analysis (GSA) fits a model for the heritability of individual genes. It prioritizes gene sets with greater biological specificity compared to standard GSA approaches. Such biologically relevant gene sets are more likely to provide insights into the pathobiology of complex diseases.

Multiomics analyses have identified multiple potential biomarkers of the incidence and prevalence of complex diseases. However, it is not known which type of biomarker is optimal for clinical purposes. Here, we make a systematic comparison of 90 million genetic variants, 1453 proteins, and 325 metabolites from 500,000 individuals with complex diseases from the UK Biobank. Only five proteins per disease resulted in median (min-max) areas under the receiver operating characteristic curves for incidence.

Adhering to a Mediterranean Diet is generally considered an effective intervention in individuals at risk for type 2 diabetes mellitus (T2DM) Little is known about its effect with respect to the different specific manifestations of T2DM. We examined the association between the MED and the incidence of these microvascular complications in a prospective cohort of 33,441 participants.

Cannabis use status was assessed by questionnaire and categorized as heavy, moderate, low, and never. Data were analyzed from inception of study inclusion to December 2020. Among 121 895 participants, 2375 total deaths occurred, including 1411 deaths from CVD and 440 from cancer.

The mechanisms underlying alcohol-induced breast carcinogenesis are not fully understood but may involve hormonal changes. Cross-sectional associations were investigated between self-reported alcohol intake and serum or plasma concentrations of estradiol, estrone, progesterone, testosterone, androstenedione.

Multiple sclerosis (MS) is a debilitating autoimmune condition primarily affecting young adults. The link between diet and MS lacks substantial evidence due to limited large-scale studies. We exploited the UK Biobank resources to explore the nexus between diet, lifestyle, and MS risk.

Cancer risk models exist, but utility on a population level for risk stratification across cancer types has not been fully explored. We aimed to close this gap by evaluating pan-cancer risk models built on electronic health records across the Danish population with validation in the UK Biobank. The models were validated on cancer incidence between 2015 and 2018 across Denmark.

Study aims to assess CVD risk associated with the dietary contribution of food groups that consider both plant or animal origin and food processing categories. Data from the UK Biobank participants (40-69 y) who completed at least two 24-h dietary recalls between 2009 and 2012. Every 10 percentage points increase in plant-sourced non-UPF consumption was associated with a 7% lower risk of CVD.

Long-term exposure to air pollution is linked to increased incidence risks of atrial and ventricular arrhythmias. The associations of air pollutants with various arrhythmia subtypes were assessed. Females, older individuals, overweight or obese individuals, and those with low education attainment, low income, or cardiometabolic morbidities had higher HRs associated with pollutants.

The EAT-Lancet Commission in 2019 advocated a plant-centric diet for health and environmental benefits. The relation to metabolic dysfunction-associated steatotic liver disease (MASLD) is unclear. We analyzed data from 105,752 UK Biobank participants with detailed dietary and metabolomic information.

Exposome-wide association study on neurodegenerative disease and neuropsychiatry disorders using data of participants from the UK Biobank. The significantly associated exposures fell into six primary exposome categories. The joint effects of identified risk factors demonstrated higher risks for common disorders of CNS.

Retirement significantly increases biological age for those induced to retire by the State Pension eligibility by 0.871-2.503 years, depending on sex and specific biological age measurement. This study provides novel empirical evidence contributing to the question of what social factors make people old.

Early-onset colorectal cancer (EOCRC) exhibits differential clinical, pathological, and molecular features. The potential differential effects of blood glucose on EOCRC compared to LOCRC have not been investigated. Study analyzed 374,568 participants from UK Biobank cohort and 172,809 participants from Kailuan cohort.

Chronic rhinosinusitis (CRS) is a prevalent upper respiratory condition. Previous studies indicate a correlation between air pollution and CRS, but the role of genetic predisposition in this relationship remains largely unexplored. We hypothesized that higher air pollution exposure would lead to the development of CRS and that genetic susceptibility might modify this association.

Efficient data exchange and health care interoperability are impeded by medical records in nonstandardized or unstructured natural language format. Advanced language models, such as large language models (LLMs), may help overcome current challenges in information exchange.

Varying case definitions of COPD have heterogenous genetic risk profiles. Overlapping risk loci were found in/near the genes ZEB2, FAM136B, CHRNA3, and CHRNA4. Mediation analysis to estimate the effects of lead genotyped variants mediated by smoking found significant indirect effects.

Daily behavior patterns were significantly different in patients before CeVD. Although SB time was not associated with CeVD risk, MVPA time, both total min/d (HR), 0.998 [95% CI, 0.997-0.999] and guideline threshold adherence (#8805;150 min/wk) was associated with decreased risk. Comorbid burden had a significant partial mediation effect on the relationship.

Study looked at cardiovascular disease risks associated with metabolic dysfunction-associated steatotic liver disease (MASLD) MASLD is associated with increased CVD risk in IBD patients, with greater risk as number of CMRFs increased.

Aging triggers intricate physiological changes, particularly in whole-body fat-free mass (FFM) and handgrip strength. Cross-sectional analysis of the UK Biobank involved 45,984 individuals aged 40-70 years with a complete dataset. In older men and women, higher physical activity beneficially affect both FFM.

Study: Relationship between oxidative balance score (OBS) and IBD. Results: There is a significant negative correlation between OBS and the occurrence of IBD, ulcerative colitis (UC), and Crohn's disease (CD)

High salt intake may play a critical role in the etiology of psoriasis. Yet, evidence on the association of high salt intake with risk of Psoriasis is limited. We conducted a prospective cohort study of 433,788 participants from the UK Biobank. In the multivariable-adjusted model, a higher frequency of adding salt to foods was significantly associated with an increased risk of psOriasis.

Comorbid hypothyroidism (HT) exacerbates kidney, cardiac, neurological and other complications of T2D. The current HT standard of care (SOC) screening is infrequent, delaying HT diagnosis and treatment. We present a first-to-date machine learning algorithm (MLA) clinical decision tool to classify patients as low vs. high risk for developing HT.

Diabetic vascular complications share common pathophysiological mechanisms. Relationship between diabetes-related macrovascular complications (MacroVCs) and incident diabetic microvascular complication remains unclear. We aimed to investigate the impact of MacroVCs on the risk of microv vascular complications.

The relationship between rheumatoid arthritis (RA) and early onset atherosclerosis is well depicted. Glycoprotein acetyls (GlycA), a novel biomarker of inflammation, may play a role in the manifestation of these two inflammatory conditions. The present study examined a potential mediating role of GlycA within the RA-atherosclerosis relationship.

A 5 kg reduction in HGS was associated with increased risk for all-cause mortality. HGS could serve as a practical indicator of vascular health in patients with pre-diabetes and diabetes.

Genome-wide associations study (GWAS) was carried out to identify genetic variants that contribute specifically to social isolation behavior. 17 loci were identified at genome-wide significance, contributing to a 4% SNP-based heritability estimate. Linkage disequilibrium (LD) score correlation demonstrated genetic correlations with autism spectrum disorder (ASD), schizophrenia, major depressive disorder (MDD), educational attainment, extraversion, and loneliness.

Polygenic risk scores (PRS) are rapidly emerging as a way to measure disease risk. Understanding the interplay of PRS with environmental factors is critical for interpreting and applying PRS. We develop an efficient method for simultaneously modeling gene-environment correlations and interactions using PRS in case control studies.

The association of coffee and tea consumption with osteoporosis is highly controversial. Few studies have focused on the combined effects of the two beverages. A prospective cohort study involving 487,594 participants aged 38-73 years from the UK Biobank was conducted.

Epilepsies are associated with differences in cortical thickness (TH) and surface area (SA) We investigated the extent to which these phenotypes share genetic influences. Despite absent genome-wide genetic correlations, there was a substantial genetic overlap between SA and genetic generalized epilepsy.

Hormonal and reproductive factors have been associated with upper gastrointestinal cancers in women but there is little available data on men. We included 219,425 men enrolled in the UK Biobank in 2006-2010. During 8 years of follow-up, 309 oesophageal 210 gastric cancers occurred. There was some evidence that male pattern baldness was associated with gastric cancer risk.

Baseline data from 19,327 individuals with type 2 diabetes in the UK Biobank were analysed. The mean age at baseline was 60.2 years, and median follow-up was 13.9 years. Diabetes duration was significantly longer among those with younger-onset diabetes.

By 2023, >900 new cases of each of 'wet' (neovascular) and 'dry' age-related macular degeneration, >1200 cases of primary open angle glaucoma and almost 15 000 cases of cataracts are expected to have accrued. These predicted incident case numbers generate good or substantial statistical power for a range of nested case-control studies of potential genetic, lifestyle and environmental determinants of disease.

Frontal fibrosing alopecia (FFA) is an increasingly prevalent form of follicular lichen planus, causing irreversible hair loss predominantly in postmenopausal individuals. CYP1B1, which is important for hormone metabolism, was implicated with the substitution of serine for asparagine at position 453 (c.1358A>G, p.Asn453Ser) exhibiting a protective effect against FFA.
