The Lancet Commission identified 12 risk factors as priorities for prevention of dementia. APOE e4/e4 genotype and family history of Alzheimer's disease strongly associated with dementia outcomes. It is unclear how robust these relationships are across dementia subtypes and analytic scenarios.

Most polygenic score (PGS) approaches do not incorporate non-additive effects. Here, we present GenoBoost, a flexible PGS framework capable of considering both additive and non- additive effects, specifically focusing on genetic dominance. We reveal that Genoboost improves prediction for autoimmune diseases.

Early identification of people at risk of cancer-related malnutrition, low muscle mass (LMM) and sarcopenia is crucial to mitigate the impact of adverse outcomes. This study investigated risk factors associated with LMM, malnutrition and (probable-) sarc Openia in people with or without a history of cancer.

Study evaluated associations between glycaemic control, glycated haemaglobin (HbA1c) levels, and major depressive disorder (MDD) in individuals with type 2 diabetes. In 11,837 T2D cases (6.9 years median follow-up), pre-T2D MDD was associated with a 0.92 increase in HbA 1c (95% CI: [0.00, 1.84]). Poorer control was observed in MDD diagnosed post-T1D, highlighting the importance of depression screening.

The plasma proteome can mediate poor oral health problems (POHP)'s link to incident dementia. We screened 37,269 UK Biobank participants 50-74 years old (2006-2010) for prevalent POHP. We further tested against 1463 plasma proteins and incident dementia over up to 15 years of follow-up.

Study aimed to investigate effects of smoking, physical activity, alcohol consumption, diet and sleep duration on all-cause, cancer and non-cancer mortality of cancer survivors in UK biobank. During a median follow-up of 12.7 years, 5652 deaths were documented from 34,184 cancer survivors. Specific cancer types showed notable benefits from adherence to healthy lifestyle.

The relationships between ABO blood genotypes and dementia are modified by gender and APOE status. We used data from the UK Biobank, a population-based cohort study of 487,425 individuals.

Study looked at the interplay between genetics, educational attainment and coronary artery disease (CAD) risk. Found strong associations between the 'genetic education score' with 'modifiable' risk factors including smoking and BMI.

Genome-wide association studies (GWAS) of psychiatric phenotypes have tended to focus on categorical diagnoses. To understand the biology of mental illness it may be more useful to study traits which cut across traditional boundaries. We report the results of a GWAS of mood instability as a trait in a large population cohort (UK Biobank, n = 363,705)

Study explores interaction between obesity and cortical morphometry in children, young adults, adults, and older adults. Findings reveal pattern of lower cortical thickness in fronto-temporal brain regions associated with obesity across all age cohorts.

Study looked at the link between polyunsaturated fatty acids (PUFA) and cancers. None of the six PUFAs showed association with overall cancer risk or mortality. Only colorectal cancer showed evidence for a causal association for higher AA levels.

Study aimed to investigate the association of dietary diversity score (DDS), as reflected by five dietary categories, with biological age acceleration. After adjusting for multiple variables, DDS was inversely associated with KDMAccel. Meat and protein alternatives had a positive association.

Fibrotic diseases affect multiple organs and are associated with morbidity and mortality. We developed machine learning models to quantify T1 time, a marker of interstitial fibrosis, in the liver, pancreas, heart and kidney among 43,881 UK Biobank participants. Individuals with a high burden of fibrosis in &#8805;3 organs had a 3-fold increase in mortality compared to those with a low burden.

Age-related mosaic chromosomal alterations (mCAs) detected from genotyping of blood-derived DNA are structural somatic variants that indicate clonal hematopoiesis. Study aimed to investigate whether mCAs contribute to the risk of cirrhosis and modify the effect of a polygenic risk score.

Atrial fibrillation (AF) is a common arrhythmia with high morbidity and mortality implications. Several studies have described a paradoxical inverse relationship between serum cholesterol and the risk of AF. It remains unknown whether remnant cholesterol (RC) is associated with AF incidence.

Socioeconomic deprivation is associated with many illnesses including increased fracture incidence in older people. The effect of deprivation on total bone health status has not been well defined. We examined the relationship between socioeconomic deprivation and poor bone health and falls and we found a significant association.

It remains unknown how the patterns of change of social isolation and loneliness are associated with the onset of cardiovascular disease (CVD) and mortality. We aimed to investigate the longitudinal association of changes in social isolation. The study included 18,258 participants aged 38-73 years.

There are effective treatments to reduce hip fractures. Identification of patients at high risk of hip fracture is important to inform efficient intervention strategies. We developed a protein-based risk score in the Cardiovascular Health Study using an aptamer-based proteomic platform.

About 2.4% of the human mitochondrial DNA (mtDNA) genome exhibits common homoplasmic genetic variation. 45.1% of individuals from 1526 mother-offspring pairs harbor a mixed population of mtDNA (heteroplasmy)

In observational studies, instrumental variable (IV) methods are commonly applied when there are unmeasured covariates. In Mendelian randomization, constructing an allele score using many single nucleotide polymorphisms is often implemented. However, estimating biased causal effects by including some invalid IVs poses some risks.

Physical frailty and genetic factors are both risk factors for increased dementia. The joint effect remains unclear. This study aimed to investigated the long-term relationship between physical frailty, genetic risk, and dementia incidence.

Major depressive disorder (MDD) is considerably heterogeneous in terms of comorbidities. We analyzed 77,519 participants and 6,266,189 single-nucleotide polymorphisms (SNPs) of the UK Biobank database. At SNP-level, only the high-multimorbidity Cluster 6 revealed a genome-wide significant SNP.

The rise in asthma has been linked to different environmental and lifestyle factors including dietary habits. Whether dietary salt contributes to asthma incidence, remains controversial. We aimed to investigate the impact of higher salt intake on asthma incidence in humans and to evaluate underlying mechanisms.

Evidence has shown that women are frailer than men in all age groups and across different populations. Female-specific reproductive factors may be related to risk of frailty in women. Study involved 189 898 women from the UK Biobank.

This research aims to explore associations between the frequency of 13 food groups intake (or four diet groups) and infectious diseases. 487849 participants from the UK Biobank were enrolled, and 75209 participants were diagnosed with infectious disease. Consuming fish 2.0-2.9 times (  OR  = 0.8221; 95% CI: 0.7955-0.8496), cheese &#8805;5.0 times, fruit 3.0 -3.9 servings, and vegetables 2. 0-2,9 servings per week were associated with a lower risk of infection.

Long-term air pollution exposure is a major health concern, yet its associations with thyroid dysfunction (hyperthyroidism and hypothyroidism) and biological aging remain unclear. A prospective cohort study was conducted on 432,340 participants with available data on air pollutants from the UK Biobank. All air pollutants were observed to be significantly associated with an increased risk of incident hypothy thyroidism. Individuals with higher pollutant levels and biologically older generally had a higher risk of thyroid dysfunction.

Polymyalgia rheumatica (PMR) is an age-related inflammatory disease of unknown cause. We aimed to identify potentially modifiable risk factors and therapeutic targets for preventing or treating PMR. We meta-analysed genetic association data from 8,156 cases of PMR and 416,495 controls of European ancestry.

Small airways obstruction (SAO) is common in general populations. It has been associated with respiratory symptoms, cardiometabolic diseases, and progression to COPD over time. Whether SAO predicts mortality is largely unknown.

The genetic architecture of complex human traits and diseases is affected by large number of possibly interacting genes. detecting epistatic interactions can be challenging. Some studies have sought to avoid this problem by only testing interactions between SNPs with R-sq.

Soy amino acids, glutamate and aspartate, may lower androgens. No large randomized controlled trials testing their health effects exist. Glutamate was not associated with IHD, blood pressure, or diabetes after correction for multiple comparisons.

Study aimed to explore how single air pollutants and air pollution mixture could affect cognitive function and the incidence of dementia. Also to determine whether pulmonary function (PF) could play a mediating role in the relationship. Mixed air pollution may impact cognitive function, with PF potentially mediating this relationship.

BMI was higher among physically inactive and highly sedentary individuals. BMI difference was 38% lower among physically active individuals and those with low sedentary time. Study provides evidence that combined categories of PA and sedentary behaviors modify extent to which genetic predisposition to obesity results in higher BMI.

Polygenic Risk Scores (PRS) combine genotype information across many single-nucleotide polymorphisms. PRS might have a major impact on public health, possibly allowing for screening campaigns to identify high-genetic risk individuals for a given disease. The "Clumping+Thresholding" (C+T) approach is the most common method to derive PRS.

Genotype data include errors that may influence conclusions reached by downstream statistical analyses. We propose a genotype error model that considers both genotype errors and uncalled deletions. We applied our model to SNVs in 77 sequenced White British parent-offspring trios in the UK Biobank.

Green space is an emerging factor with promising prospects for bolstering human well-being. The incidence of delirium increases significantly with age and is fatal. To date, there is no research elucidating the enduring implications of green spaces on the occurrence ofDelirium. We explored the relationship between residential greenness and the incidence of Delirium in a large community sample.

The molecular pathology of stress-related disorders remains elusive. Genes and exons within the mPFC carried most disease signals replicated across two independent cohorts. Pathways pointed to immune function, neuronal and synaptic regulation, and stress hormones.

Long-term changes in frailty were associated with the risk of incident T2DM, irrespective of baseline frailty status. Preventing the worsening of frailty may reduce T2 DM risk.

Kidney cancer is a prevalent malignancy with an increasing incidence worldwide. Blood cell indices and inflammation-related markers have shown huge potential as biomarkers for predicting cancer incidences, but that is not clear in kidney cancer. Our study aims to investigate the correlations of blood cell indices with kidney cancer risk.

Ten-year risk equations for incident heart failure (HF) are available for the general population, but not for patients with established atherosclerotic cardiovascular disease (ASCVD) Study aimed to develop and validate 10-yearrisk equations for HF in patients with known ASCVD.

Obesity is associated with chronic low-grade inflammation, which is linked to cancer development. Abdominal obesity has unusually been associated inversely with cutaneous malignant melanoma. Leucocytes participate in inflammation and are higher in obesity, but prospective associations of leucocytes with CMM are unclear.

Glaucoma is a progressive neurodegenerative disease characterized by the gradual degeneration of retinal ganglion cells. The advent of optical coherence tomography (OCT) has marked a transformative era in ophthalmology, offering detailed visualization of the macula and optic nerve head (ONH) regions.

Study analyzed data from 89,400 UK Biobank participants without Parkinson's disease. Participants were categorized into three groups: inactive, regularly active, and engaged in the weekend warrior (WW) pattern. Relationship between these exercise patterns and Parkinson's risk was assessed using a multifactorial Cox model.

Stroke increases the likelihood of social isolation and stroke survivors are at high risk of cognitive decline. We assessed the association between social engagement and cognitive function in a sample of stroke survivors.

The UK Biobank recruited over 500,000 British participants aged 40-69 in 2006-2010. Coronary artery disease (CAD) is the most common cause of death in the UKB cohort. We identified geographical variations in age-standardized rates of CAD between assessment centers.

Cross-sectional studies have demonstrated strong associations between physical frailty and depression. Here, we analyze data of 352,277 participants from UK Biobank with 12.25-year follow-up. Pre-frail and frail individuals account for 20.58% and 13.16% of depression cases.

Human leukocyte antigen (HLA) types are drivers of autoimmune disease, although with limited penetrance. Sarcopenia is characterized by chronic inflammation plus loss of muscle mass and strength. We tested whether autoimmune diagnoses are associated with sarcopenia in autoimmune disease-free older people.

Linkage-Disequilibrium Eigenvalue Regression for Gene-Environment interactions (LDER-GE) improves the accuracy of estimating the phenotypic variance component explained by genome-wide GE interactions. LDER-GE leverages the complete Linkage Disequilibrium (LD) matrix, as opposed to only the diagonal squared LD matrix utilized by LDSC.

M Mosaic loss of the Y chromosome (mLOY) in peripheral leukocytes is a somatic event in which a fraction of leukocyte have lost the entire Y chromosome. The frequency of mLOY increases with age and may reflect poor genomic maintenance as well as clonal imbalances in normal immune function. We investigated the relationship between mLOY and incident cancer in a large sample of 207,603 cancer-free men from the UK Biobank.

Sleep problems are prevalent but impact of sleep patterns on digestive diseases remains uncertain. 410,586 participants from UK Biobank with complete sleep information were included in the analysis. Compared to participants scoring 0-1, those scoring 5 showed a 28% reduced risk of any digestive disease.

Age-related hearing loss is the most common form of permanent hearing loss. It is associated with various health traits, including Alzheimer's disease, cognitive decline, and depression. Past genome-wide association studies identified multiple genomic loci involved in common adult-onset health traits.

Heterozygous familial hypercholesterolemia (FH) is among the most common genetic conditions worldwide that affects &#8776; 1 in 300 individuals. FH is characterized by increased levels of low-density lipoprotein cholesterol (LDL-C) and increased risk of coronary artery disease (CAD) FH variability in expression is incompletely explained by known risk factors.

Iron overload is observed in neurodegenerative diseases, especially Alzheimer's disease and Parkinson's disease. Homozygotes for the iron-overload (haemochromatosis) causing HFE p.C282Y variant have increased risk of dementia and PD. We studied brain iron estimated by R2* and quantitative susceptibility mapping in 8 subcortical regions.

Time of year of birth affects the amount of daylight, nutrients, and viral load that an individual is exposed to within this key developmental period. Summer births were associated with probable recurrent Major Depressive Disorder.

Alcohol consumption has been associated with the occurrence of many health conditions. We analyzed UK Biobank data to explore associations of various conditions to type and amount of alcohol consumed. We observed increased condition prevalence with increasing amounts of alcohol. Beer consumers showed higher prevalence for most conditions.

Study aimed to identify candidate loci and genes related to sleep disturbances in depressed individuals. Sleep related traits included chronotype, insomnia, snoring and daytime dozing.GWAS detected 15 loci significantly associated with chronotype.

Cadence thresholds have been widely used to categorize physical activity intensity in health-related research. We examined the convergent validity of two cadence-based intensity classification approaches against a machine-learning-basedintensity schema in 84,315 participants.

Anti-M&#252;llerian hormone (AMH) is required for sexual differentiation in the fetus, and in adult females AMH is produced by growing ovarian follicles. AMH levels are correlated with ovarian reserve, declining towards menopause when the oocyte pool is exhausted. We carried out a genome-wide meta-analysis in 3344 pre-menopausal women from five cohorts.

Flavonoid intakes were estimated from &#8805;2 dietary assessments among 113,097 study participants. 2628 incident cases of T2D were identified during 12 years of follow-up. A higher FDS (compared to lower [Q4 vs. Q1] was associated with a 26% lower T 2D risk.

Large-scale cardiac magnetic resonance imaging data paired with genetic data provides a unique opportunity to assess the genetic contributions to left atrial structure and function. We use deep learning and surface reconstruction models to measure left. atrial minimum volume, maximum volume, stroke volume, and. emptying fraction in 40,558 UK Biobank participants.

Creatinine-cystatin C ratio (CCR) has been demonstrated as an objective marker of sarcopenia in clinical conditions. CCR has not been evaluated as an osteoporosis marker in individuals with normal renal function. We selected 271,831 participants withnormal renal function from UK Biobank cohort.

Stacked Neural Network Polygenic Risk Score (SNPRS) synthesises outputs from multiple neural network models. SNPRS captures a broader array of genetic variants enabling a more nuanced interpretation of the combined effects of these variants.

The COVID-19 pandemic exposed a global deficiency of systematic, data-driven guidance to identify high-risk individuals. Here, we illustrate the utility of routinely recorded medical history to predict the risk for 1883 diseases. We developed a neural network to learn from health records of 502,460 UK Biobank.

Study investigated associations between systemic medication use and diabetic retinopathy. Found significant associations between the use of short-acting insulins, medium-actingins and sulfonylureas with increased odds of incident DR. In contrast, fibrates and Cox-2 inhibitors were associated with decreased odds of DR.

Accurate estimation of population allele frequency (AF) is crucial for gene discovery and genetic diagnostics. determining AF for frameshift-inducing small insertions and deletions (indels) faces challenges. We developed CRAFTS-indels, an algorithm that combines AF of distinct indels within a given region and provides "regional AF"

Genetic biomarkers are very much needed for both research and treatment. To date, useful and valid biomarkers have been scant owing to the inaccessibility and complexity of human brain tissue. Genome-wide association studies of common diseases have matured over the last decade, generating the knowledge base for increasingly informative individual-level genetic risk prediction.

Anorexia nervosa (AN) occurs nine times more often in females than in males. AN displays high genetic correlations with anthropometric and metabolic traits. Given sex differences in body composition, we investigated the possible metabolic underpinnings of female propensity for AN.

Liver cirrhosis is the third most common cause of premature death in the UK. Iron overload is now increasingly associated with obesity, type-2 diabetes and non-alcoholic fatty liver disease. This study shows that population studies including measurement of liver iron concentration are feasible.

Very low-depth sequencing has been proposed as a cost-effective approach to capture low-frequency and rare variation in complex trait association studies. We show that imputed 1Ã— WGS recapitulates 95.2% of variants found by imputed GWAS with an average minor allele concordance of 97%.

Subjective well-being (SWB) is an important measure for mental health status. Previous research has shown that physical activity can affect an individual's well- Being. In this study, we aim to evaluate the potential interactions between mitochondrial genes and physical activity (PA)

We aggregated coding variant data for 81,412 type 2 diabetes cases and 370,832 controls of diverse ancestry. We identified 40 coding variant association signals.

We develop a Bayesian mixed linear model that estimates single-nucleotide polymorphism (SNP)-based heritability. We apply the method to 28 complex traits in the UK Biobank data (N = 126,752) We show that on average, 6% of SNPs have nonzero effects, which in total explain 22% of phenotypic variance.

Study aimed to research the associations between accumulated social risks and sleep disorders. Research includes 239,165 individuals with sleep disorders and social determinants of health data from the UK Biobank cohort. Higher PsRS scores were associated with worse sleep status. Emotional stress and not in paid employment were found to have significant contributions for sleep disorder.

Major depressive disorder (MDD) is a common illness accompanied by considerable morbidity, mortality, costs, and heightened risk of suicide. We conducted a genome-wide association meta-analysis based in 135,458 cases and 344,901 controls and identified 44 independent and significant loci.

Hypertension (HTN) and Type 2 Diabetes (T2D) often coexist, therefore understanding the relationship between both diseases is imperative to guide targeted prevention/therapy. This study aims to explore the relationship. between HTN and T2D using genome-wide association study (GWAS) analysis and biochemical data.

Proton pump inhibitors (PPIs) and histamine-2 receptor antagonists (H2RAs) are commonly used. PPIs have been shown to promote liver cancer in rats. Only one study has examined the association in humans.

Study included 23,129 participants with T2D at baseline from the UK Biobank. After 13.6 years of follow-up, a total of 1,123 severe NAFLD cases occurred. High levels of PM2.5, NO2, and NOX were associated with an elevated risk of severe NAflD. A lower LE8 score was negatively associated with the risk of NAFLd.

Lipid-lowering drugs and antihypertensive drugs are commonly combined for cardiovascular disease (CVD) The relationship of combined medications with CVD remains controversial. We aimed to explore the associations of genetically proxied medications of lipid- Lowering and Anti-Hypertensive Drugs with risk of CVD and other clinical outcomes.

Identifying the imaging method that best predicts all-cause mortality, cardiovascular adverse events and heart failure risk is crucial for tailoring optimal management. Potential prognostic markers include left ventricular myocardial mass, ejection fraction and stroke work. A new measurement called global longitudinal active strain density (GLASED) was also used.

Hepatic steatosis is an early histological subtype of both NAFLD and ALD. Excessive alcohol consumption is widely known to lead to hepatic Steatosis and subsequent liver damage. We simulated a target trial to estimate the effects of several hypothetical interventions, including changes in the amount of alcohol consumption or the types of alcoholic beverages consumed. The findings could inform decisions about alcohol-related policymaking and clinical care.

Previous observational studies have indicated associations of physical activity (PA) and air pollution with mortality. Still, the trade-off between the harmful effects of air pollution exposure and the protective effects of PA remains controversial and unclear. This study aimed to investigate the joint association of air. pollution and PA with mortality risks.

The difference in genetic regulation of gene expression between brain and blood is important for discovering genes for brain-related traits and disorders. Here, we estimate the correlation of genetic effects at the top-associated cis-expression or -DNA methylation (DNAm) quantitative trait loci. We identify 61 genes and 167 DNAm sites associated with four brain- related phenotypes.

We present a catalogue of human protein-coding variation, derived from exome sequencing of 983,578 individuals across diverse populations. 23% of the Regeneron Genetics Center Million Exome (RGC-ME) data come from individuals of African, East Asian, Indigenous American, Middle Eastern and South Asian ancestry. The catalogue includes more than 10.4 million missense and 1.1 million predicted loss-of-function (pLOF) variants.

Rare HTRA1 variants are linked to ischemic stroke in the UK Biobank and BioBank Japan. variants causing loss of protease function are associated with stroke, coronary artery disease and skeletal traits. A common variant modulating circulatingHTRA1 mRNA and protein levels enhances the risk of stroke. Findings identify two mechanisms as potential targets for therapeutic interventions.

 null mutations within the filaggrin ( FLG ) gene are established genetic risk factors for atopic dermatitis. Studies of FLG have typically used sequencing or bespoke genotyping. Large-scale population cohorts with genome-wide imputed data offer powerful genetic analysis opportunities.

Childhood trauma was known to increase risks of social isolation, loneliness and self-injurious thoughts and behaviors in adulthood. The aim of this study was to examine the protect and risk factors of social health, self- injurious thought and behaviors between adults with or without childhood trauma.

The association of sleep traits (insomnia, sleep duration, chronotype, daytime sleepiness, and snoring) with benign prostatic hyperplasia (BPH) is unclear. This research aimed to examine the effects ofSleep traits on BPH risk. A total of 170 241 men aged 38 to 73 years were included in the study.

Race-based equations may reclassify ventilatory impairment for 12.5 million persons, medical impairment ratings for 8.16 million, occupational eligibility for 2.28 million, grading of chronic obstructive pulmonary disease, and military disability compensation. Annual disability payments may increase by more than $1 billion among Black veterans.

Concerns have been raised about the increasing prevalence of both spontaneous and induced abortions worldwide. We aimed to examine the associations between abortion and all-cause and cause-specific premature mortality. Women aged 39 to 71 years with prior pregnancies were derived from the UK Biobank.

Psoriasis is an inflammatory skin disease with an estimated heritability of around 70%. Previous GWASs have detected several risk loci for psoriasis. This study included 925,649 individuals (22,659 cases and 902,990 controls)

Study enrolled UK Biobank participants between 2006 and 2010. Coffee intake of 2-3 cups/day (HR 0.973, 95% CI 0.949-0.998) or tea intake of 4-6 cups/ day (HR0.962) linked with lowest risk of incident cataract.

A total of 422 316 participants (mean age, 56 years; 54% women) were included for analyses. During a median follow-up of 11.9 years, there were 24 774 AF events documented. Participants in higher RC quartiles had a lower risk of incident AF.

A total of 330,716 participants from UK Biobank was included between 2006 and 2010. During a median follow-up period of 12.4 years, 37,897 death cases were recorded. The SHS was inversely associated with the risks of all-cause, CVD and cancer mortality in a dose-dependent manner (P for trend)

Insulin resistance (IR) significantly contributes to cardiovascular disease (CVD) development. Triglyceride glucose (TyG) index and triglyceride glucose-body mass index ( TyG-BMI) are recognised as convenient proxies for IR. However, their relationship with sudden cardiac arrest (SCA) remains unclear.

The relationship between non-alcoholic fatty liver disease (NAFLD) and hypertension remains highly controversial. There are ongoing debates on whether NAFLD induces hypertension or vice versa. We employed cross-lagged panel models to investigate the temporal relationship between hepatic steatosis and blood pressure.

Hypertension increases the risk of cardiovascular diseases (CVD) such as stroke, heart attack, heart failure, and kidney disease. Previous studies have utilized statistical and machine learning techniques to develop hypertension prediction models. Only a few have included genetic liabilities and evaluated their predictive values.

Study included 20 634 UK Biobank participants free of CVD and cancer at baseline with two or more assessments of depressive symptoms during 2006-2016. Incident CVD, cancer and mortality were followed up until 2021 through linked registries. Six depressive symptoms trajectories were identified.

Stroke is a life-threatening condition that causes a major medical burden globally. Exposure to tobacco in early life, including smoking during adolescence and maternal smoking during pregnancy, can affect adolescent development and lead to several negative outcomes. The association between early-life tobacco exposure and stroke is not known.

There is limited evidence linking metabolic syndrome (MetS) with kidney cancer risk. This study aimed to investigate the association between MetS and its components and the risk of kidney cancer.

Lifestyle are closely related to migraine. There is a lack of studies investigating the association between Healthy lifestyle or Life's Essential 8 (LE8) and the risk of migraine. The objective of this research was to investigate the relationship between Healthy. lifestyle scores and Life's essential 8 scores, and migraine.

Telomeres form repeated DNA sequences at the ends of chromosomes, which shorten with each cell division. Factors modulating telomere attrition and the health consequences thereof are not fully understood. We leveraged data from 326,363 unrelated UK Biobank participants of European ancestry. Smoking cessation and high educational attainment associate with longer LTL.

More negative SER was nonlinearly associated with greater Euclidian (largely horizontal) OD-fovea distance. In myopia, these parameters varied more strongly with SER as myopia increased. These changes also suggest that the posterior pole stretches predominantly in the temporal horizontal direction.

The ERLIN1 p.Ile291Val single-nucleotide polymorphism (rs2862954) is associated with protection from steatotic liver disease (SLD) The protective effect of this variant was enhanced in patients with alcoholic liver disease. Strikingly, the protective effects of ERLin1. p.ile 291Val were not apparent in individuals carrying the TM6SF2 p.Glu167Lys variant.

 2021 European Society of Cardiology prevention guidelines recommend the use of (lifetime) risk prediction models to aid decisions regarding initiation of prevention. We aimed to update and systematically recalibrate the LIFEtime-perspective CardioVascular Disease (LIFE-CVD) model to four European risk regions.

Leveraging data from two prospective cohorts in China, we identified incident Omicron infections between January 2023 and April 2023. Participants with a self-reported history or self-rated symptoms of depression or anxiety were considered the exposed group, whereas the others were considered unexposed. No association was found between any pre-existing depression or Anxiety and the overall risk of infection.

About 60% of known trait-associated loci are in linkage disequilibrium with a cis-eQTL. For most traits, tissue-shared eQTLs underlie a greater proportion of trait associations. We propose new variant and gene associations for several complex traits.

Estimating linkage disequilibrium (LD) is essential for a wide range of summary statistics-based association methods for genome-wide association studies. Large genetic datasets enable more accurate and comprehensive LD estimates, but increase the computational burden of LD estimation. Here, we describe emeraLD, a computational tool that leverages sparsity and haplotype structure to estimate LD up to 2 orders of magnitude faster than current tools.

New-onset diabetes mellitus after transplantation (NODAT) is a complication following solid organ transplantation. We investigated whether single nucleotide polymorphisms (SNPs) within 158 immune- or inflammation-related genes contribute to NODAT in SOT recipients. Only SP110 rs2114592C>T remained associated with NODat in the STCS replication sample.

Intraocular pressure (IOP) is currently the sole modifiable risk factor for primary open-angle glaucoma (POAG), one of the leading causes of blindness worldwide. Both IOP and POAG are highly heritable2. We identified 101 statistically independent genome-wide-significant SNPs for IOP, 85 of which have not been previously reported. Gene-based tests implicated an additional 22 genes associated with IOP.

The prevalence of the so-called diseases of affluence, such as type 2 diabetes or hypertension, has increased dramatically in the last two generations. The sudden increase in disease incidence suggests a major role for environmental risk factors. Obesity constitutes a case example of a modern trait shaped by contemporary environment.

It remains unclear how to meaningfully classify people living with multiple long-term conditions. This paper aims to identify clusters of MLTCs in different age groups and associated risks of adverse health outcomes and service use.

There is growing evidence supporting that vascular abnormalities contribute to multiple sclerosis (MS) We hypothesized that retinal vascular curve tortuosity is associated with MS, which this study aims to address.

Polygenic risk scores (PRS) quantify an individual's genetic predisposition for different traits. A crucial challenge in clinical practice is the generalizability and transferability of PRS models to populations with different ancestries. The R2$$R^2$$ is a commonly used measure to evaluate prediction accuracy.

Inter-individual variation in blood pressure (BP) arises in part from sequence variants within enhancers modulating the expression of causal genes. We propose these genes, active in tissues relevant to BP physiology, can be identified from tissue-level epigenomic data and genotypes of BP-phenotyped individuals.

We aimed to develop a proteomic aging clock for all-cause mortality risk as a proxy of biological age. Data were from the UK Biobank Pharma Proteomics Project, including 53,021 participants aged between 39 and 70 years.

Pancreatic cancer is the deadliest malignancy due to late diagnosis. Aberrant alterations in the blood proteome might serve as biomarkers to facilitate early detection of PC.

Previous studies have found that both physical inactivity and poor sleep are deleteriously associated with severe mental illness (SMI) The aim of current study was to investigate the joint association of physical activity (PA) and sleep with late-onset SMI (schizophrenia and bipolar disorder) risk.

Genome-wide association studies have predominantly focused on populations of European and Asian ancestry. This study presents the largest GWAS for urinary albumin-to-creatinine ratio (UACR) in SSA individuals. Two genome-wide significant (P  -8 ) UACR-associated loci were identified.

We investigated associations of 1463 plasma proteins with incidence of 19 cancers and 9 cancer subsites in UK Biobank participants. We identify 618 protein-cancer associations, of which 107 persist for cases diagnosed more than seven years after blood draw. CD74 and TNFRSF1B with NHL, ADAM8 with leukemia, and SFTPA2 with lung cancer.

Mental health is influenced by inclination to sleep at specific times (chronotype) and actual sleep timing (behavior) Chronotype and timing of actual sleep are, however, often misaligned. Study aims to determine how chronotype, sleep timing, and the alignment between the two impact mental health.

Mendelian randomisation analyses of two prospective population-based cohorts. Evidence for a harmful effect of reducing BMI at low BMI levels was only present in some analyses, and where present, only below 20 kg/m 2. The association between genetically predicted BMI and mortality at high BMI level was stronger in women than in men.

Previous studies have explored the association of drinking with gout risk. We found that light alcohol consumption was linked to a slight decrease in gout incidence among female individuals. There was no significant association in male individuals.

The relationship between biological age acceleration (BAA) and cardiac size, cardiac function, and heart failure (HF) is not well-defined. A significant correlation was found between increased BAA and deleterious changes in cardiac structure. Mendelian randomization analysis suggests a likely causal link between BAA, vital cardiac metrics, and HF risk.

High prevalence of conversion from amnestic mild cognitive impairment (aMCI) to Alzheimer's disease (AD) makes early prevention of AD extremely critical. Neuroticism, a heritable personality trait associated with mental health, has been considered a risk factor for conversion from aMCI to AD. Whether the neuroticism genetic risk could predict the conversion of aMCi and its underlying neural mechanisms is unclear.

Step count is an intuitive measure of physical activity frequently quantified in health-related studies. However, accurate step counting is difficult in the free-living environment. This study aims to describe the development and validation of step count derived from a wrist-worn accelerometer and assess its association with cardiovascular and all-cause mortality.

Multi-copy 47S ribosomal DNA (rDNA) codes for rRNA components of the ribosome. Analysis in White British individuals reveals that rDNA CN associates with altered counts of specific blood cell subtypes, such as neutrophils.

Human aging is marked by the emergence of a tapestry of clonal expansions in dividing tissues. Clonal hematopoiesis (CH) often stems from somatic mutations in a set of established genes. However, the majority of clones lack known drivers. Here we infer gene-level positive selection in whole blood exomes from 200,618 individuals in UK Biobank.

Consumption of fibre, fruits and vegetables has been linked with lower colorectal cancer (CRC) risk. A genome-wide gene-environment (G Ã— E) analysis was performed to test whether genetic variants modify these associations. We identified 2 loci associated with fibre and fruit intake that also modify the association of these dietary factors with CRC risk. Potential mechanisms include chronic inflammatory intestinal disorders, and gut function.

Currently, the relationship between household size and incident dementia, along with the underlying neurobiological mechanisms, remains unclear. This prospective cohort study was based on UK Biobank participants aged &#8805; 50 years without a history of dementia. Smaller household size was associated with an increased risk of all-cause dementia.

Being breastfed has established benefits for infant health, but its long-term effects on adult diseases, including cancer, remain underexplored. We examined associations between being breastfed in infancy and the risks of common cancers.

We mapped diagnosis (ICD code) data to standardized phecodes from 3 EHR-linked biobanks. We conducted 4 common analyses comparing unweighted and weighted results. For AOU and MGI, estimated phecode prevalences decreased after weighting. Weighting had a limited impact on dimensionality estimation.

Inflammatory bowel disease (IBD) and Parkinson's disease (PD) are chronic disorders that have been suggested to share common pathophysiological processes. LRRK2 has been implicated as playing a role in both diseases. Exploring the genetic basis of the IBD-PD comorbidity through studying high-impact rare genetic variants can facilitate the identification of novel shared genetic factors.

Long-term exposure to ambient air pollution is closely related to the risk of mortality. It is still unknown whether lifestyle and genetic susceptibility could modify the association. This population-based prospective cohort study involved 461,112 participants from the UK Biobank. Each interquartile range (IQR) increase in PM 2.5 , NO 2  and NO x was associated with 7 %, 6 % and 5 % higher risk of all-cause mortality.

Kidney stone disease (KSD) has been associated with genetic risk factors. An association between physical activity and KSD risk also has been hypothesized. We conducted a comprehensive prospective cohort study utilizing participants from the UK Biobank to assess the intensity of PA using accelerometers.

A growing body of evidence suggests that the difference between predicted and chronological age-referred to as brain-predicted age difference (brain-PAD)-is related to various neurological and neuropsychiatric disease states. We tested the models on a separate dataset consisting of motion-free and motion-corrupted T1-weighted MRI scans from the same participants, the quality of which were rated by neuroradiologists.

Peripheral glial fibrillary acidic protein (GFAP) and neurofilament light chain (NfL) are sensitive markers of neuroinflammation and neuronal damage. Previous studies have shown that peripheral GFAP and NfL levels are elevated in the pre-clinical phase of Alzheimer's disease (AD) and dementia.

Polygenic score (PGS) is a valuable method for assessing the estimated genetic liability to a given outcome or genetic variability contributing to a quantitative trait. While polygenic risk scores are widely used for complex traits, their application in uncovering shared genetic predisposition between phenotypes remains limited. We developed an R package, comorbidPGS, which facilitates a systematic evaluation of shared genetic effects among (cor)related phenotypes.

The relationship between sarcopenia and the long-term risk of atrial fibrillation (AF) remains unclear. This study recruited a large prospective Caucasian cohort from the UK Biobank. There were 24,007 cases of new-onset AF over a median follow up of 12.56 years.

The reason for higher incidence of atrial fibrillation (AF) in Europe compared with East Asia is unclear. We aimed to investigate the association between modifiable lifestyle factors and lifetime risk of AF in Europe and East Asia.

This article revisits the classical concept of network modularity. We establish asymptotic distributional results in the large-network limit for networks exhibiting nodal community structure. We provide confirmatory simulation studies and real data analysis pertaining to the network neuroscience study of psychosis, specifically schizophrenia.

Study examined the association between consumption of ultraprocessed foods and leucocyte telomere length (LTL) LTL exhibited a decrease of 0.005 (95% CI: -0.007, 0.002) with 1 UPF serving increase.

CCIs of each cancer were identified by NicheNet analysis of single-cell RNA sequencing data from breast, colon, liver, lung, and ovarian cancers. These CCIs were used to construct a shared multi-cellular tumor model (shared-MCTM) representing common CCIs across cancers. A gene signature was identified from the shared-M CTM and tested on the mRNA and protein level in two large independent cohorts.

Previous studies on the associations between serum urate levels and neurodegenerative outcomes have yielded inconclusive results, and the causality remains unclear. This prospective study included 382,182 participants (45.7% men) from the UK Biobank cohort. During a median follow-up period of 12 years, we documented 5,400 ADRD cases, 2,553 PD cases, and 1,531 neuro degenerative deaths.

Existing imaging genetics studies have been mostly limited in scope by using imaging-derived phenotypes defined by human experts. We propose a new approach, image-based genome-wide association study (iGWAS), for identifying genetic factors associated with phenotypes discovered from medical images. Using retinal fundus photos, our model extracts a 128-dimensional vector representing features of the retina as phenotypes.

Lung function measurements included forced vital capacity (FVC) and forced expiratory volume in 1 s (FEV1) Study outcome was microvascular diseases, a composite outcome including chronic kidney diseases, retinopathy and peripheral neuropathy. FVC was inversely associated with the risk of new-onset microv vascular diseases in participants with diabetes.

Healthier lifestyle decreased the risk of mental disorders (MDs) such as depression and anxiety. Research on the effects of a comprehensive healthy lifestyle on their progression is lacking. 385,704 individuals without baseline MDs from the UK Biobank cohort were included.

Joint analysis of multiple correlated phenotypes for genome-wide association studies (GWAS) can identify pleiotropic loci. constructing a network based on associations between phenotypes and genotypes provides a new insight.

Personality traits, especially neuroticism, can influence susceptibility to dementia. Social contact mitigates stress and risk of dementia, but extent to which social contact can mitigate excess risk associated with neuroticism remains unclear. We aim to investigate whether active social contact is associated with lower neuroticism-associated excess risk.

Air pollution has been linked to multiple psychiatric disorders, but little is known on its long-term association with schizophrenia. The interaction between air pollution and genetic susceptibility on incident schizophrenia has never been reported. This population-based prospective cohort study included 437,802 middle-aged and elderly individuals free of schizophrenia at baseline.

The association between tea consumption and venous thromboembolism (VTE) remains unknown. A total of 190,189 participants with complete dietary information and free of VTE at baseline in the UK Biobank were included. During a median follow-up of 12.1 years, 4,485 (2.4%) participants developed incident VTE. Genetic variation in caffeine metabolism did not significantly modify the association.

Genetic susceptibility is involved in developing TKA-related SSI. Previously reported models for predicting SSI were constructed using nongenetic risk factors without incorporating genetic risk factors. We performed a genome-wide association study (GWAS) using the UK Biobank database. We identified 4 novel variants that were significantly associated with susceptibility to SSI following TKA.

Depressive disorders have increased in global prevalence, making improved management of these disorders a public health priority. Prior research has linked circadian clock genes to depression, either through direct interactions with mood-related pathways in the brain or by modulating the phase of circadian rhythms. Using machine learning and statistical techniques, we explored associations between 157,347 SNP variants from 51 circadian-related genes and depression scores.

Polygenic Risk Scores (PRS) based on results from genome-wide association studies offer the prospect of risk stratification for many common and complex diseases. We developed a PRS for alcohol-associated cirrhosis by comparing single-nucleotide polymorphisms among patients with ALC versus drinkers without ALC.

Few prospective studies have investigated the joint effect of lifestyle factors and genetic susceptibility on the risk of irritable bowel syndrome (IBS) This study aims to evaluate the associations of lifestyle and genetic factors with incident IBS in the UK Biobank. An overall healthy lifestyle was defined using six modifiable lifestyle factors.

The independent effect of waist-to-height ratio (WHtR) and body fat percentage (BF%) on ischemic cardiovascular disease (CVD) remains uncertain. This study aimed to investigate the independent associations of WHtR and BF% withIschemic CVD.

Study aimed to explore the effect of genetically predicted lifelong lowering blood pressure (BP) through different antihypertensive medications on frailty. Among 298,618 UK Biobank participants, one-sample MR analysis observed that genetically proxied BB use (0.76; 95% CI, 0.65-0.90; p = 0.001) and CCB use was significantly associated with lower risk of pre-frailty.

Dyslipidaemias is the leading risk factor of several major cardiovascular diseases (CVDs) There is still a lack of sufficient evidence supporting a causal role of lipoprotein subspecies in CVDs. In this study, we comprehensively investigated several lipoproteins and their subspecies, as well as other metabolites.

Clonal hematopoiesis (CH) is a phenomenon of clonal expansion of stem cells. It is driven by somatic mutations affecting certain genes. CH has been linked to the development of hematologic malignancies, cardiovascular diseases, and other conditions.

Study aimed to examine the longitudinal associations of CA with incident all-cause dementia. Each additional CA was associated with a 15.5% (95% CI: 8.8%-22.5%) higher risk of dementia.

Insufficient and deficient vitamin D may be associated with chronic musculoskeletal pain. Study findings are conflicting, and few account for important confounding factors. Data collected at the baseline assessments of 349,221 UK Biobank participants.

Standard methods of heart chamber volume estimation in cardiovascular magnetic resonance (CMR) typically utilize simple geometric formulae based on a limited number of slices. We aimed to evaluate whether an automated deep learning neural network prediction of 3D anatomy of all four chambers would show stronger associations with cardiovascular risk factors and disease.

Study included 360,271 individuals in UK Biobank. After a median follow-up of 12.52 years, we found higher total physical activity (TPA) level and higher sleep scores were related to reduced risk of cancer.

Abdominal aortic aneurysm (AAA) is an important cause of cardiovascular mortality. The authors aimed to explore the associations between sleep patterns and genetic susceptibility to AAA. They included 344,855 UK Biobank study participants free of AAA at baseline.

22,496 participants with T2D from the UK Biobank were included. SO was defined as the combination of obesity (body mass index &#8805;30 kg/m 2 ) and sarcopenia (grip strength) 1946 (8.7%) participants developed HF during a median follow-up of 12.0 years.

Toxoplasma gondii is an opportunistic pathogen affecting about 1/3 of world population. While often asymptomatic, it can lead to severe toxoplasmosis in immunocompromised patients. We found a significant association between the SAG1 seropositivity at baseline and the incidence of schizophrenia.

Excessive dietary sodium intake has known adverse effects on intravascular fluid volume and systemic blood pressure. This study aimed to assess the association of urinary sodium excretion, a biomarker of dietary intake, with glaucoma.

The eye is a well-established model of brain structure and function. Yet region-specific structural correlations between the retina and the brain remain underexplored. We aimed to explore relationships between retinal layer thicknesses and brain magnetic resonance image (MRI)-derived phenotypes in UK Biobank.

Study looked at associations of accelerometer-measured intensity-specific physical activity with mortality risk among population with cardiometabolic disease. Participants were recruited from the United Kingdom (UK) across 22 assessment centers from 2006 to 2010.

What distinguishes vulnerability and resilience to posttraumatic stress disorder (PTSD) remains unclear. Levering traumatic experiences reporting, genetic data, and electronic health records (EHR), we investigated and predicted the clinical comorbidities (co-phenome) of PTSD vulnerability and resilient in the UK Biobank and All of Us Research Program.

Mantis-ML 2.0 is a framework integrating AstraZeneca's Biological Insights Knowledge Graph and numerous tabular datasets. We use graph neural networks, capturing the graph's holistic structure, and train them on hundreds of balanced datasets. The enhanced models demonstrate a 6.9% average classification power boost.

There is limited evidence suggesting that osteoporosis might exacerbate depressive symptoms. More studies demonstrate that depression negatively affects bone density and increases fracture risk. We found that genetically predicted MDD was associated with a higher risk of fracture and  vice versa. The shared genetic components (such as SGIP1 ) between the diseases could be a potential therapeutic strategy for both MDD and bone loss.

The leucine-rich repeat-containing G-protein-coupled receptor 6 (LGR6) was recently identified as the cognate receptor for the proresolving mediator maresin 1 (MaR1) We investigated the functional impact of a genetic variant in the gene encoding for LGR6, which is predicted to lead to a frameshift mutation in one of the receptor isoforms, on both receptor expression and immune cell responses.

Researchers have endeavored to address this issue by pursuing the harmonization of MRIs. Most existing image-based harmonization methods for MRI are tailored for 2D slices. We aim to resolve inconsistencies between slices by introducing a pseudo-warping field. This field is created randomly and utilized to transform a slice into an artificially warped subsequent slice.

Evidence suggests Toxoplasma gondii is associated with a variety of neuropsychiatric and behavioral conditions. This research aims to explore the potential correlation between T. Gondii antibody positivity and neuroPsychiatric disorders through a comprehensive prospective cohort study. The study sample consisted mostly of white British individuals aged 40 to 69.

Liver fibrosis was associated with an increased risk of hospitalization or death from heart failure. Genetic polymorphisms associated with liver fibrosis were not positively associated with elevated heart failure risk.

The impact of early-life tobacco exposure on dementia has remained unknown. Early-life smoking accelerated dementia onset and was genetically correlated to AD. MSDP and smoking in adolescence altered many brain regions, including the hippocampus.

Comorbid anxiety occurs often in MS and is associated with disability progression. Polygenic scores offer a possible means of anxiety risk prediction but often have not been validated outside the original discovery population. We aimed to investigate the association between the Generalized Anxiety Disorder 2-item scale polygenic score with anxiety in MS.

The relationship between 24-hour rest-activity rhythms (RARs) and risk for dementia or mild cognitive impairment (MCI) remains an area of growing interest. More studies are required to fully explore the link between disrupted RARs and dementia or MCI in middle-aged and older adults.

Flood data were retrieved from the Dartmouth Flood Observatory and linked with health data from 499,487 UK Biobank participants. Risk of all-cause mortality increased by 6.7% for every unit increase in flood index after confounders had been controlled for. Participants with higher levels of education and household income had a higher estimated risk of death from most causes.

We used data from UK Biobank, The Tr&#248;ndelag Health Study (HUNT), and Michigan Genomics Initiative (MGI) One genome-wide significant (P &#8804; 5E-08) locus was associated with the susceptibility to upper UTI, located near TSN in the female-only analysis.

Study looked at 163 748 UK Biobank participants in England with linked primary care EHRs. 29% of the sample self-reported having insomnia symptoms, while only 6% had a Read code for insomnia symptoms in their primary care records.

Polygenic scores (PGS) enable the prediction of genetic predisposition for a wide range of traits and diseases. Present approaches for calculating PGS from genotypes are often inefficient and labor-intensive, limiting transferability into clinical applications. We present 'Imputation Server PGS', an extension of the Michigan Imputation server designed to automate a standardized calculation of polygenic scores.

Glucagon and glucagon-like peptide-1 (GLP-1) are derived from the same precursor; proglucagon. Dual agonists of their receptors are currently being explored for the treatment of obesity and metabolic dysfunction-associated steatotic liver disease (MASLD) Elevated levels of endogenous glucagon (hyperglucagonaemia) have been linked with hyperglycaemia in individuals with type 2 diabetes.

Existing risk assessment tools are mostly limited to a single outcome of interest. This study tests the feasibility of producing multiple disease risk estimates with at least 70% discrimination.

The non-genetic factors predisposing to trigger finger (TF) have mostly been characterised in small studies from individual institutions. We identified 2250 individuals with medical and surgical diagnostic codes for TF, and 398,495 controls. TF was found to be significantly associated with age (OR 1.04, 95% CI 1.03-1.04) and female sex.

Within-person (non-directional) variability had a SNP-based heritability of 2-5% for height, sitting height, body mass index (BMI) and weight. A variant tracking the Alzheimer's risk APOE-E4.4 allele (rs429358) was significantly associated with weight loss. Findings help elucidate the genetic influence on trait-change within an individual and highlight disease risks.

Study examined how plasma proteome indicators may explain the link between poor cardiovascular health (CVH) and dementia risk. Study involved 28,974 UK Biobank participants aged 50-74y at baseline (2006-2010) who were followed-up for dementia.

A higher prevalence of cardiovascular risk factors has previously been shown to be associated with adverse social determinants of health (SDoH) We investigated associations of apoA1, apoB, and apolipoprotein A1 with the level of education and household income and their joint impact on CAD mortality in participants of the UK Biobank.

Is childhood adversity associated with biological aging, and if so, does sex modify the association, and do lifestyle and mental health mediate the association? A lifespan analysis is conducted using data on 142 872 participants from the UK Biobank. Childhood adversity is assessed through the online mental health questionnaire.

Walking pace is associated with risks of major chronic diseases including cancer, cardiovascular disease (CVD) and diabetes mellitus type 2 (T2DM) in the general population. Brisk walking pace was linked to reduced risks of these diseases in individuals with hypertension, partially mediated by low-grade inflammation.

Steroid sulphatase (STS) cleaves sulphate groups from steroid hormones. In animals, STS inhibition or deletion of the associated gene, enhances memory/neuroprotection and alters hippocampal neurochemistry. Little is known about the consequences of constitutive STS deficiency on memory-related processes in humans.

It remains unclear whether there are associations between sunlight exposure and brain structural markers. Stratification analyses were performed based on sex, age, and diseases (hypertension, stroke, diabetes) Prolonged natural sunlight exposure was associated with the volumes of total brain.

Age at first sexual intercourse (AFS) and lifetime number of sexual partners (NSP) may influence the pathogenesis of uterine leiomyoma (UL) through their associations with hormonal concentrations and uterine infections. Four specific genomic regions were identified as contributing significant local genetic correlations to AFS and UL, including one genomic region further identified for NSP and UL.

ShaPRS is a method that leverages pleiotropy between traits or shared genetic effects across ancestries. The method uses genome-wide summary statistics from two diseases or ancestries to improve the genetic effect estimate and standard error.

Despite growing evidence that apolipoprotein B (apoB) is the most accurate marker of atherosclerotic cardiovascular disease (ASCVD) risk, its adoption in clinical practice has been low. This investigation sought to determine whether low-density lipoprotein cholesterol (LDL-C), non-high-density Lipo-C, and triglycerides are sufficient for routine cardiovascular care. A sample of 293 876 UK Biobank adults (age: 40-73 years, 42% men) was included.

Diffusion tensor image analysis along the perivascular space (DTI-ALPS) has been suggested as a method to index the health of the glymphatic system. In small-scale studies the index has been shown to correlate with age, cognitive health, and sleep, and is higher in females than males.

Some studies have suggested an association between metabolic syndrome and kidney stones. Whether some individual characteristics and clustering of metabolic syndrome traits increase the risk of kidney stones has not been examined in a large-scale prospective cohort.

Genome-wide association study on head size identified 67 genetic loci. 17 variants affect specific brain areas, but most have widespread effects. Gene set enrichment is observed for various cancers and signaling pathways.

Trinucleotide repeats in the androgen receptor have been proposed to influence testosterone signaling in men, but the clinical relevance of these trin nucleotide repeats remains controversial. We quantified CAG and GGC repeat lengths in the AR gene of European-ancestry male participants in UK Biobank. Both repeat lengths were shown to be positively associated with circulating total testosterone level and bone mineral density.

Early-life tobacco exposure serves as a non-negligible risk factor for aging-related diseases. Compared with those without in utero exposure, participants with in. utero tobacco exposure had an increase in Klemera-Doubal biological age (KDM-BA) and PhenoAge acceleration of 0.26 and 0.49 years, respectively, but a decrease in telomere length of 5.34% among 276,259 participants.

Circulating metabolites are potential candidates for biomarker and therapeutic target identification. Genetically increased &#937;-3 unsaturated fatty acids abundance, as well as genetically decreased &##8-catalyzed N-acetyl-amino acids, and hypotaurine were negatively associated with the risk of bipolar disorder.

Eosinophils exhibit anti-tumor cytotoxic responses in the tumor microenvironment. They may contribute to tumor immunosurveillance. We analyzed data from 443,542 adults aged 38-73 in the UK Biobank.

The data of 307,023 participants recruited between 2006 and 2010 were extracted from the UK Biobank study. Healthy diet scores were calculated based on self-reported dietary data at baseline. Over a median 6.2-year follow-up, 3,276 participants developed CRC. The mediating effect of adiposity on CRC risk was significant in men but not in women.

Nuclear magnetic resonance (NMR)-based plasma fatty acids are objective biomarkers of many diseases. We explored the associations of NMR-based Plasma fatty acids with the risk of hepatocellular carcinoma (HCC) and chronic liver disease (CLD) mortality in 252,398 UK Biobank participants.

Elevated estimated glomerular filtration rate (eGFR) based on creatinine and cystatin C associated with risk of cardiovascular diseases. 372,060 participants free of CVD and CKD in the UK Biobank were included. Thresholds for high eGFR varied with age and sex.

To investigate the associations of physical activity (PA), low-level air pollution, and interaction on cardiovascular diseases (CVD) incidence based on the UK Biobank. PA was measured by the International Physical Activity Questionnaire and five air pollutants were estimated using Land Use Regression. All association estimates were based on Cox regression.

Lifestyles are associated with all-cause mortality, yet limited research has explored the association in the elderly population with multimorbidity. This prospective study included 29,451 and 173,503 older adults aged 60 and over from Chinese Longitudinal Healthy Longevity Survey and UK Biobank. For participants with two or more conditions, adopting a healthy lifestyle was associated with a 27%-41% and 22%-42% reduction in mortality risk.

COVID-19 vaccination (at least one dose) was associated with reduced short-term risks of hospitalizations from stroke, heart failure, non-CO VID-19 pneumonia, and dementia. The results for two-dose vaccination were similar. Taken together, this study provides further support to the safety and benefits of COVID- 19 vaccination.

Study aimed to quantify the relationship between the incidence of OSA and sleep patterns and genetic susceptibility. 355,133 white British participants enrolled in the UK Biobank between 2006 and 2010 with follow-up data until September 2021 were recruited.

Age-related cognitive decline is accelerated by vascular risk factors for cerebral small vessel disease. We used data from the UK Biobank to assess cognitive tests (executive function, processing speed, and memory) We found a significant sex-by-time interaction over a 5-year period. High low-density lipoprotein, low education, and high blood pressure had a greater effect on the rate of cognitive decline in the executive function for females.

Red blood cell distribution width (RDW) to albumin concentration (RAR) has emerged as a reliable prognostic marker for mortality in patients with various diseases. Whether RAR is associated with mortality in the general population remains unknown. This population-based prospective cohort study used data from participants in the 1998-2018 US National Health and Nutrition Examination Survey (NHANES) and from the UK Biobank.

Elevated lipoprotein (a) is associated with premature atherosclerotic cardiovascular disease. Fewer than 0.5% of individuals undergo Lp(a) testing, limiting the evaluation and use of novel targeted therapeutics currently under development. We describe the development of a machine learning model for targeted screening.

Cross-sectional analysis used ordinary least squares regression within the UK Biobank database. 26 820 participants aged 53-86 years, categorised into two cohorts: Cohort 1 and Cohort 2. Cognitive performance scores were evaluated against sleep parameters and health and lifestyle factors.

The role of plant-based diets, particularly their quality, is poorly known. The consumption of healthy plant foods was associated with lower frailty risk. The hPDI was directly, and the uPDI inversely, associated with higher risk of low physical activity and weak hand grip.

Study sought to examine whether younger onset age of OSA is associated with a higher risk of incident dementia. Study excluded 445,023 participants due to baseline dementia diagnoses, incomplete covariate information, or pre-OSA onset dementia.

Study aimed to explore relationships between orofacial pain and sleep using the UK Biobank dataset. Participants experiencing pain all over the body showed a significant association with an unhealthy sleep pattern (OR = 1.18, P)

Ankle-foot sprains are the most common musculoskeletal injuries, which can impair balance and theoretically increase the risk of falls. There is a lack of evidence supporting the direct association between ankle-foot Sprains and the future risk of fall.

APOC3, ANGPTL3, and ANGPTl4 are circulating proteins that are actively pursued as pharmacological targets to treat dyslipidaemia and reduce the risk of atherosclerotic cardiovascular disease. Here, we used human genetic data to compare the predicted therapeutic and adverse effects of these proteins. Genetically lowering circulating AngPTL4 levels reduced the odds of coronary artery disease (CAD) and Type 2 diabetes.

 Depression is heritable, differs by sex, and has environmental risk factors such as cigarette smoking. The effect of single nucleotide polymorphisms (SNPs) on depression through cigarette smoking and the role of sex is unclear. We used counterfactual-based mediation analysis to test the indirect or mediated effect of SNPs on broad depression through the log of pack-years of cigarette smoking, adjusting for age, sex, current smoking status, and genetic ancestry (via principal components) In the UK Biobank, we found SNPs in two genes [ LOC105378800 ,  GRM5 ] with an indirect effect.

Study aimed to examine the association between past/current sleep duration and macro-/micro-structural brain outcomes. 40 436 dementia-free participants (age 40-70 years) underwent a baseline assessment followed by a brain magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) scan 9 years later. Past (baseline) and current (MRI scans) sleep duration (hours/day) were recorded.

Automated segmentation is a challenging task in medical image analysis. Most current supervised learning based algorithms suffer from insufficient manual annotations. We propose a hybrid framework to learn polygon vertices, region masks, and their boundaries in a weakly/semi-supervised manner.

This study analyzed the intima-media thickness(cIMT)indicators obtained through ultrasound examination in patients with Type 2 Diabetes Mellitus(T2DM)and their relationship with age. The study established a significant connection between cIMT and both grip strength and walking speed.

Biobanks typically rely on volunteer-based sampling. This results in large samples (power) at the cost of representativeness (bias) The problem of volunteer bias is debated. We show that volunteering biases associations in UK Biobank (UKB) and estimate inverse probability (IP) weights that correct for volunteer bias in UKB.

We report the largest genome-wide association study (GWAS) on nine serum amino acids in the UK Biobank participants (117 944, European descent) We identified 34 genomic loci for circulatory levels of alanine. Every standard deviation increase in valine is associated with 35% higher risk of type 2 diabetes.

The aim of this article is to propose a novel method for estimating trans-ancestry genetic correlations in genome-wide association studies. These correlations describe how genetic architecture of complex traits varies among populations. Our new estimator corrects for biases arising from prediction errors in high-dimensional weak GWAS signals.

Regular use of fish oil supplements had different roles in the transitions from healthy status to atrial fibrillation, to major adverse cardiovascular events, and then to death. For people without cardiovascular disease, hazard ratios were 1.13 (95% confidence interval 1.10 to 1.17) and 1.05 (1.00 to1.11) for transition to stroke.

Aging is often associated with cognitive decline. Understanding neural factors that distinguish adults in midlife with superior cognitive abilities (Positive-Agers) may offer insight into how the aging brain achieves resilience. Optimal Labeling with Bayesian Optimization (OLBO) algorithm used an unsupervised approach.

In a recent publication, we applied a novel model to address phenotypic heterogeneity in genetic research on alcohol misuse. We stratified individuals based on their patterns of alcohol use behaviours and comorbid psychopathology. In this Commentary, we provide further descriptions of the subtypes of alcohol misuse that emerged from the empirical mixture modelling approach.

Inflammatory bowel disease is a common digestive disorder and diabetes can lead to intestinal dysfunction. Patients with inflammatory bowel disease in combination with diabetes present a higher rate of hospitalization and consumption of medical resources. We studied 313,008 participants from the UK Biobank, including 5891 patients with type 2 diabetes.

We aimed to unravel the mechanisms connecting adiposity to type 2 diabetes. We used MR-Clust to cluster independent genetic variants associated with body fat percentage (388 variants) and BMI (540 variants) We identified five clusters of adiposity-increasing alleles associated with higher type 2 Diabetes risk. We then characterized each cluster based on various biomarkers, metabolites and MRI-based measures of fat distribution.

Brain age gap (BAG) is a potential biomarker of brain health. BAG was significantly increased in Alzheimer&#8242;s disease, anxiety disorders, bipolar disorder and post-traumatic stress disorder.

Cardiovascular diseases (CVDs) are the leading cause of mortality worldwide. Cardiac image and mesh are two primary modalities to present the shape and structure of the heart. To obtain efficient and explainable biomarkers for CVD prediction and diagnosis, it is needed to jointly consider both.

Electronic health records (EHRs) permit large cohorts to be followed across the lifespan and include a wide range of diagnostic information. We studied relationships between schizophrenia, mania/bipolar disorder, depression, anxiety and subsequent risk of dementia.

The relationship between socioeconomic status (SES) inequity and incident age-related macular degeneration (AMD) remains unclear. We aim to investigate whether low SES increases the risk of AMD and to explore the effect of a healthy lifestyle on this association. This prospective cohort study included 316,663 UK Biobank individuals.

There is a lack of comprehensive data regarding the association of depression and anxiety for the subsequent risk of thyroid disease. Depression and anxiety were measured through self-reported Patient Health Questionnaire-4 (PHQ-4) at baseline. thyroid disease was diagnosed by corresponding hospital data documented through International Classification of Diseases (ICD)-10 codes.

The existing diagnostic methods for Alzheimer's disease (AD) require considerable time and expense from patients. We propose a mobile device-targeted AD diagnosis network, which uses retinal fundus images. The proposed model adopts MobileNetV3-Large as a backbone for efficient computation.

 miR-137 is a microRNA involved in brain development, regulating neurogenesis and neuronal maturation. Genome-wide association studies have implicated mi R-137 in schizophrenia risk but do not explain its involvement in brain function and underlying biology. Polygenic risk for schizophrenia mediated by miR -137 targets is associated with working memory, although other evidence points to emotion processing.

MS-GWAS associations are significantly enriched in regulatory regions of microglia and peripheral immune cell subtypes. Cell-specific polygenic risk scores were developed to examine the cumulative impact of the susceptibility genes on MS risk and clinical phenotypes.

Growth hormone insensitivity (GHI) encompasses growth restriction, normal/elevated growth hormone (GH), and low insulin-like growth factor I (IGF1) "Nonclassical" GHI is poorly characterized and is rarely caused by heterozygous dominant-negative (DN) variants located in the intracellular or transmembrane domains of the GH receptor. We sought to determine the molecular mechanisms underpinning the growth restriction in 2 GHI cases.

Lifestyle modification is an effective measure for diabetes prevention in people with prediabetes, but its associations with the long-term risks of cardiovascular disease (CVD), cancer, and mortality remain largely uncertain. We aimed to investigate the associations of combined healthy lifestyle factors with these health outcomes among participants withprediabetes. We documented a total of 18 333 incident diabetes, 10 829 incident CVD, 6926 incident cancer and 9877 deaths.

The iron overload condition hereditary hemochromatosis (HH) can cause liver cirrhosis and cancer, diabetes, and arthritis. Males homozygous for the p.C282Y missense mutation in the Homeostatin Iron Regulator (HFE) gene have greatest risk. Only a minority develop these conditions.

Mendelian randomization (MR) study investigated the causal effect of metabolically different adiposity subtypes on osteoarthritis. Greater metabolically unfavorable and metabolically neutral adiposity were associated with higher odds of the disease. The nonlinear MR analyses suggested a nonlinear relationship between metabolically favorable adiposity and osteoartritis.

Population-based prospective cohort study used data from the UK Biobank for 2013 to 2015. Participants were adults 40 to 79 years old in England, Scotland, and Wales. More daily steps were associated with a lower risk of all-cause, CVD, and cancer mortality. Peak-30 cadence was consistently associated with lower risks across all outcomes, beyond the benefit of total daily steps.

Nonalcoholic fatty liver disease (NAFLD) is prevalent worldwide. NAFLD is associated with elevated serum triglycerides (TG), low-density lipoprotein cholesterol (LDL), and reduced high-density cholesterol (HDL) We identified credible genes in these pathways and characterized missense variants in these for effects on serum traits.

Lichen planus (LP) is known to affect the skin, skin appendages and mucosae. We examined conditions associated with LP in two unrelated cohorts. Dermatological and digestive disorders were overrepresented in LP individuals.

Eczema is a chronic inflammatory skin disease. Hard water is formed when minerals are dissolved in water from filtration through sedimentary rocks. Several studies have reported a higher prevalence of eczema in areas with hard water. But this association has not been explored in adults.

Vitamin D deficiency or insufficiency is particularly common in people with type 2 diabetes (T2D) Study included 15,103 individuals with T2D who were initially free of CVD. 65.7% of participants had a vitamin D concentration below 50 nmol/L.

Asthma is a heterogeneous common respiratory disease that remains poorly understood. The established genetic associations fail to explain the high estimated heritability. Robust association analyses incorporating different genetic ancestries and whole-genome sequencing data may identify novel genetic associations.

 Pharmacogenetic variants impact dihydropyridine calcium-channel blockers (dCCBs; e.g., amlodipine) treatment efficacy. Evidence on clinical outcomes in routine primary care is limited. We aimed to estimate associations between reported pharmacogenetic. variants and incident adverse events in a community-based cohort prescribed dCCB.

COVID-19 vaccination has been associated with increased venous thromboembolism (VTE) risk. It is unknown whether genetic predisposition to VTE is associated with an increased risk of thrombosis following vaccination.

Step-based recommendations may be appropriate for dementia-prevention guidelines. However, the association of step count and intensity with dementia incidence is unknown. UK Biobank prospective population-based cohort study with 6.9 years of follow-up.

The risk of venous thromboembolism (VTE) in ambulatory COVID-19 is controversial. This population-based cohort study included participants with SARS-CoV-2 infection that was confirmed by a positive polymerase chain test reaction result. Older age, male sex, and obesity were clinical risk factors for post-CO VID-19 VTE. factor V Leiden thrombophilia was additionally associated with double the risk, comparable with the risk of 10-year aging.
