High-density lipoprotein cholesterol (HDL-C) and low- density lipop protein cholesterol (LDL-L) were examined. HDL-C/LDl-C ratio of 0.4-0.6 was correlated with lower MI risk, all-cause mortality, haemorrhagic stroke and ischaemic stroke.

Modern tractography algorithms are based on segmentation maps of white matter (WM), gray matter (GM), and cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) These maps are generally estimated from a T1-weighted (T1w) image and then registered in diffusion weighted images (DWI) space. Diffusion-based segmentation would, thus, potentially allow not to have higher quality anatomical priors injected in the tractography process.

Air pollutants are considered as non-negligible risk factors of idiopathic pulmonary fibrosis (IPF) However, the relationship between long-term air pollution and the incidence of IPF is unknown. Our objective was to explore the associations of air pollutants with IPF risk and further assess the modification effect of genetic susceptibility.

Increasing evidence suggests that sleep is important for fat metabolism. This study investigated the linear and nonlinear causal association between sleep duration and VAT. For each 1-hour increase in genetically predicted sleep duration, the reduction in predicted VAT mass was 0.11 kg (P = 8.18E-16)

Common variants of the apolipoprotein E (APOE) gene, homozygous in approximately 3% of the world's population, are associated with Alzheimer's disease, atherosclerosis and anti-tumour immunity. Mice bearing the APOE2 or APOE4 variant exhibited rapid disease progression and poor survival outcomes relative to mice bearing the most prevalent APOE3 allele.

Few studies have compared approaches within the same dataset. We used baseline data from 495,465 participants (age 38-73 years) to characterise MLTC. The prevalence of MLTC was 44% (BC), 33% (CC), 6% (BI) and 2% (CI)

Using data from 26 239 UK Biobank participants free from dementia and stroke, we assessed the associations of metabolic subgroups. Participants characterized by high triglycerides and liver enzymes showed the most adverse brain outcomes compared to the healthy reference subgroup with high-density lipoprotein cholesterol.

There is little direct evidence for their associations with preclinical changes in brain structure. We investigated the association of genetic dementia risk and healthy lifestyle with brain morphometry. We used data from up to 25,894 UK Biobank participants.

Study looked at the association of polygenic risk score (PRS) and bladder cancer (BC) risk and whether this PRS can be offset by a healthy lifestyle. Overall, a negative interaction was observed between the PRS and the HLS (P = 0.02). A 7% higher and 28% lower BC risk per 1-standard deviation (SD) increment in PRS.

High levels of cystatin C, urate, and microalbuminuria were found significantly associated with severe COVID-19. Findings might point to new directions for clinicians and policymakers in optimizing risk-stratification among patients.

Genome-wide association studies (GWASs) have successfully identified many genetic variants and risk loci for complex traits and common diseases. However, these identified variants, in general, can explain only a small to moderate proportion of the heritability. We propose a new and orthogonal approach by integrating individual-level omics data with GWASs. We applied the method to the UK Biobank subcohort of n = 90,000 individuals with both GWAS and metabolomics data.

Quadile integral linear model (QUAIL) used to estimate genetic effects on trait variability. QUAIL identified 11 vQTLs for body mass index (BMI) that have not been previously reported. Findings showed substantial enrichment for interactions with physical activities and sedentary behavior.

Canada's Food Guide (CFG) was profoundly revised in 2019. The extent to which adherence to recommendations on healthy food choices reduces the risk of cardiovascular disease (CVD) is unknown. The aim of this study was to examine how greater adherence to the 2019 CFG's recommendations onhealthy food choices influences the risk.

Regular use of paracetamol, but not ibuprofen, was associated with a significantly higher risk of incident T2DM among middle aged UK adults.

Cortical morphology changes with ageing and age-related neurodegenerative diseases. Previous studies suggest that the age effect is more pronounced in the frontal lobe. However, our knowledge of structural complexity changes in male and female brains is still limited.

17q12 microdeletion and microduplication syndromes present as overlapping, multisystem disorders. We assessed the disease phenotypes of individuals with 17q12 CNV in a population-based cohort. Microdeletions were strongly associated with diabetes (p=2Ã—10 -7 ) but microduPLications were not.

Some adults, aged 80 years or older, are "super-agers" that exhibit cognitive performance like younger adults. It is unknown if there are adults in mid-life with similar superior cognitive performance ("positive-aging") versus cognitive decline over time.

National Institute for Health and Care Excellence 2021 guidelines on chronic kidney disease (CKD) recommend the use of the Kidney Failure Risk Equation (KFRE) The equation to calculate estimated glomerular filtration rate (eGFR) has also been updated.

MOSTest is well powered to discover genomic effects distributed across multiple phenotypes. Applied to cortical brain MRI morphology measures, MOSTest has resulted in a drastic improvement in power to discover loci when compared to established approaches.

The relation of vitamin D status with the risk of chronic kidney diseases (CKD) remains uncertain. We aimed to examine the association of serum 25-hydroxyvitamin D (25OHD) with new-onset CKD in participants with and without diabetes.

The associations of native T1 with incident events were evaluated in 42,308 UK Biobank participants over 3.17 +/- 1.53 years of prospective follow-up. Higher myocardial T1 was associated with greater odds of a range of prevalent conditions (eg, any CVD, brain disease, heart failure, nonischemic cardiomyopathies, AF, stroke, and diabetes) The strongest relationships were with heart failure (OR: 1.41 [95% CI:1.26-1.57]; P = 1.60 Ã— 10 -9)

Long-term exposure to air pollution was associated with risks of non-alcoholic fatty liver disease (NAFLD) and cirrhosis among the UK population. PM 2.5, PM 10, NO 2 and NO x exposures contributed to the excess risk of NAFLD associated with air pollution score. Alcohol consumption was an effect modifier for the association.

The low-density lipoprotein receptor (LDLR) controls cellular delivery of cholesterol and clears LDL from the bloodstream, protecting against atherosclerotic heart disease. We sought to identify regulators of the LDLR beyond the targets of current therapies and known causes of familial hypercholesterolemia. Cold shock domain-containing protein E1 (CSDE1) enhanced hepatic  LDLR messenger RNA (mRNA) decay via its 3' untranslated region.

Previous studies have suggested a potential association between sleep and telomere length (TL), but its genetic basis remains unclear. In the UK Biobank cohort, the association between TL and insomnia was observed in the female samples. There was no evidence for causal association between insomnia and TL in individuals of European ancestry.

Fatigue is common following aneurysmal subarachnoid haemorrhage (aSAH) Little is known about its frequency, prognosis and impact on employment. The aim of this study was to assess the frequency of fatigue and its relationship to employment in the long term.

It is well established that decreased kidney function can increase blood pressure (BP), but it is unproven whether moderately elevated BP causes chronic kidney disease (CKD) or glomerular hyperfiltration. 311 119 White British UK Biobank participants were included in logistic regression analyses to estimate the odds of CKD.

We perform GWAS of 16 metabolites clustered at the intersection of amino acid catabolism, glycolysis, and ketone body metabolism in a subset of UK Biobank. Among the 213 lead GWAS hits, we find a strong enrichment for genes encoding pathway-relevant enzymes and transporters. These outlier variants often reflect biology local to the traits.

The relationship between fish oil supplementation and incident dementia in a large population-based cohort study has not yet well studied. A total of 211,094 community-dwelling older persons over 60 years from the UK Biobank cohorts enrolled between 2006 and 2010 that reported regularly taking fish oil and had no dementia at baseline.

NPC is closely associated with genetic factors and Epstein-Barr virus infection. Individuals with a family history suffer elevated NPC risk. This study provides the potential for risk stratification of individuals with an NPC family history.

Population-based studies have suggested an increased risk of acute arterial events (AAEs) in patients with inflammatory bowel disease (IBD) We aimed to assess the risk of incident AAEs and premature A AEs, adjusted for diet, physical activity, and inflammation biomarkers, in participants with IBD.

Accelerated aging makes adults more vulnerable to chronic diseases and death. Whether childhood adversity is associated with accelerated aging processes, and to what extent lifestyle mediates the association, remain unknown. A retrospective cohort analysis was conducted using data from adult participants in the UK Biobank baseline survey (2006-2010) and online mental health survey (2016)

Study analyzed data from the UK Biobank Mental Health Survey from January 1 to June 1, 2021. In the discovery data set, 162 variables (66%) were associated with psychotic experiences. Of these, 148 (91%) were replicated. The findings underscore the need for systematic approaches and triangulation of evidence.

Cholesteryl ester transfer protein inhibition (CETP) has been shown to increase levels of high-density lipoprotein cholesterol (HDL-C) Current LDL-C target attainment is low, and novel phase 3 trials are underway to investigate whether CETP inhibitors result in reduction of cardiovascular disease risk in high-risk patients.

Hypoxia-inducible factor prolyl hydroxylase inhibitors (HIF-PHIs) are currently under clinical development for treating anemia in chronic kidney disease (CKD) It is important to monitor their cardiovascular safety. Genetic variants can be used as predictors to help inform the potential risk of adverse effects associated with drug treatments.

The evidence linking chronic kidney disease (CKD) to spontaneous intracerebral hemorrhage (ICH) is inconclusive owing to possible confounding by comorbidities. A 3-stage study that combined observational and genetic analyses was conducted. CKD was found to be independently associated with higher risk of ICH. Mendelian randomization analyses suggest that this association was causal.

Prolyl hydroxylase (PHD) inhibitors are in clinical development for anaemia in chronic kidney disease. Epidemiological studies have reported conflicting results regarding safety of long-term therapeutic haemoglobin (Hgb) rises through PHD inhibition. Genetic variation in genes encoding PHDs can be used as partial proxies to investigate the potential effects of Hgb rises.

In mice, GPR146 (G-protein-coupled receptor 146) deficiency reduces plasma lipids and protects against atherosclerosis. Whether these findings translate to humans is unknown.

Nonlinear association between serum 25-hydroxyvitamin D [25(OH)D] concentration and all-cause mortality has been widely reported for the general population. This association has not been quantified for individuals with inflammatory bowel disease (IBD) We identified 2690 females and 2532 males with diagnosed IBD at baseline in the UK Biobank.

 type 2 diabetes (T2D) is associated with an increased risk of peripheral artery disease (PAD) However, whether the two diseases share a genetic basis and whether the relationship is causal remain unclear. We explored the genetic correlation and putative causal relationship between T2D and PAD in both Europeans and East Asians.

Among exome-sequenced participants in the UK Biobank, we identified 7194 migraine cases with the remaining 193,433 participants classified as controls. We investigated rare variants in 10 genes previously reported to be implicated in conditions with migraine as a prominent part of the phenotype. We found no evidence for association of these genes or variants with the common form of migraine.

 regional vulnerability index (RVI) was used to measure individual's brain-wide similarity to the expected SMI patterns derived from meta-analytical studies. UKBB participants with MDD had significantly higher RVI-MDD (Cohen's d = 0.20, p = 1 Ã— 10 -23  ) than nonpsychiatric controls.

Higher tea intake was modestly associated with lower all-cause mortality risk among those who drank 2 or more cups per day. Findings were similar regardless of whether participants also drank coffee.

Monogenic disorders are estimated to account for 10%-12% of patients with kidney failure. We report the unexpected finding of an unusual uromodulin (UMOD) variant in multiple pedigrees within the British population. We demonstrate a shared haplotype indicative of an ancestral variant.

Study included 321,672 participants free of HF at baseline from the UK Biobank. During a median follow-up of 12.0 years, 8212 cases of HF were uncovered. Compared with participants with low PA, the hazard ratios (HRs) were 0.69 and 0.61 for moderate and high PA, respectively.

Early identification of individuals at risk of sudden cardiac death (SCD) remains a major challenge. The ECG is a simple, common test, with potential for large-scale application. We developed and tested the predictive value of a novel index quantifying T-wave morphologic variations.

Little is known regarding the potential relationship between clonal hematopoiesis (CH) of indeterminate potential (CHIP) and risk of prostate cancer. We evaluated the association of age-related CHIP with overall and aggressive prostate cancer risk in two large whole-exome sequencing studies.

Job satisfaction plays an important role for the life quality and health of working individuals. Neurotic and stress disorders, eating disorders and other mental health disorders were strongly associated with lower job satisfaction. Neuroticism was strongly linked to job satisfaction but was not associated with job tenure.

Study aimed to investigate the associations between ultra-processed food (UPF) consumption and the risk of cardiovascular disease and all-cause mortality in the UK Biobank Cohort. 60 298 participants aged 40 years or older were evaluated.

Newborn screening (NBS) dramatically improves outcomes in severe childhood disorders. In many genetic diseases, however, outcomes remain poor because NBS has lagged behind drug development. Rapid whole-genome sequencing (rWGS) is attractive for comprehensive NBS because it concomitantly examines almost all genetic diseases.

End-stage knee osteoarthritis (OA) is a highly debilitating disease for which total knee arthroplasty (TKA) is an effective treatment option. Although a genetic component to OA in general has been described, evaluation of the genetic contribution to end-stage OA of the knee is limited. We present a genome-wide association study involving patients undergoing TKA for primary knee OA to characterize the genetic features of severe disease on a population level.

Traditional classification systems of metabolic-associated fatty liver disease (MAFLD) do not account for the high rate of extrahepatic complications. To create a new classification of MAFLD using metabolic parameters to identify risks of complications more accurately.

Night shift workers had a higher hypertension risk than day shift workers, which increased with increasing frequency of night shift work. Night shift work was associated with increased hypertension risk, which was modified by the genetic risk for hypertension.

Mendelian randomization (MR) is a form of instrumental variable analysis used to investigate causality using observational data. We used MR and data from UK Biobank in a proof-of-principle study to investigate confounding due to reverse causation. We focus on the association between alcohol consumption (exposure) and outcomes including educational attainment and physical and mental health.

Genetic liability to RA was associated with an increased risk of CAD and ICH. The heightened cardiovascular risk should be actively monitored and managed in RA patients.

Lifestyle factors are similarly associated with risk of heart failure (HF) for individuals with different metabolic or genetic risk status. Healthy lifestyle factors included avoidance of smoking, no obesity, regular physical activity, and healthy diet.

The etiology of adhesive capsulitis involves inflammation, thickening, and fibrosis of the shoulder capsule. The underlying genetic factors are poorly understood. The purpose of this study was to identify genetic variants associated with adhesive Capsulitis using the UK Biobank (UKB) cohort. It was also to compare them with variants associated. with Dupuytren disease investigating a common etiology between the 2 fibrotic disorders.

Iiopathic pulmonary fibrosis (IPF) is an incurable lung disease characterised by progressive scarring leading to alveolar stiffness, reduced lung capacity and impeded gas transfer. We aimed to identify genetic variants associated with declining lung capacity or declining gas transfer after diagnosis of IPF.

Exome-sequencing studies of population biobanks provide an opportunity to systematically evaluate the impact of rare coding variations. We find that the discovery of genetic associations is tightly linked to frequency and is correlated with metrics of deleteriousness and natural selection.

Psychologic wellbeing can impact cardiovascular health. We aimed to evaluate the joint association of multiple psychologic wellbeing factors with cardiovascular diseases (CVD) and examine whether this association was modified by genetic susceptibility. In the UK Biobank, 126,255 participants free of CVD at baseline were included.

Both genetics and ambient air pollutants contribute to depression. The degree to which genetic susceptibility modifies the effect of air pollution on depression remains unknown. 490,780 participants who were free of depression at baseline in the UK Biobank study were recruited from 2006 to 2010. PM 2.5 , PM 10 , NO 2 and NO x exposure were significantly positively associated with the risk of depression.

Study combined a retrospective longitudinal analysis of suspect and early manifest primary open angle glaucoma cases with 2 replication cohorts from the UK Biobank and the Canadian Longitudinal Study of Ageing. A lower BMI conferred a faster rate of visual field progression.

Sex differences related to immune responses can influence atopic manifestations in childhood asthma. While genome-wide association studies have investigated a sex-specific genetic architecture of the immune response, gene-by-sex interactions have not been extensively analysed for atopy-related markers.

This study investigated the association between a healthy lifestyle with all-cause, cause-specific mortality, and cancer incidence among individuals with metabolic syndrome. Healthy lifestyle scores were created based on MetS management guidelines, including never/quitting smoking, moderate drinking, good sleep, healthy diet, sufficient exercise, social support, and less sedentary behaviour.

The germline variant HSD3B1[1245A/C] affects outcomes of castration-resistant prostate cancer and is associated with estrogen receptor positivity in postmenopausal breast cancer. Like breast cancer, endometrial cancer is another malignancy with hormone-dependent and hormone-independent subtypes. We hypothesized that adrenal-restrictive HSD1B1 genotype would associate with cancer subtype.

Mental health and cognitive achievement are partly heritable, highly polygenic, and associated with brain variations in structure and function. The underlying neural mechanisms remain unclear. We investigated the association between genetic predispositions to various mental health and Cognitive traits and a large set of structural and functional brain measures from the UK Biobank.

An increasing proportion of people have a body mass index (BMI) classified as overweight or obese. published studies disagree whether this will be beneficial or detrimental to health. We applied and evaluated two intergenerational instrumental variable methods to estimate the average causal effect of BMI on mortality.

Vitamin C is an antioxidant with a potential role in the prevention of digestive system cancers. There is yet no consensus whether vitamin C has a causal role in these cancers. The aim of this study was to utilize Mendelian randomization to decipher the potential causal associations of vitamin C.

Neuroticism is a transdiagnostic feature of psychiatric disorders displaying prominent sex differences. We performed genome-wide association studies of neuroticism separately in males and females to identify sex-specific genetic and transcriptomic profiles. Male- and female-specific neuroticism polygenic scores were most significantly associated with mood disorders. We identified several molecular pathways that can partially explain the known sex differences in neurotic symptoms and their psychiatric comorbidities.

Gene panels with a series of strict variant filtering rules are often used for clinical analysis of exomes and genomes. Panel sizes vary, affecting the test's sensitivity and specificity. We investigated background rate of candidate variants in a population setting using gene panels developed to diagnose a range of heterogeneous monogenic diseases.

Alzheimer's disease (AD) is the most frequently occurring type of dementia. Prolonged sleep duration may be one of the clinical predictors of a higher risk of AD.

For the first time, benign prostatic hyperplasia and prostate cancer are genetically related. Diagnoses of these two diseases were significantly correlated. BPH and PCa share common inherited genetics. This finding may have implications in disease etiology and risk stratification.

A major challenge of genome-wide association studies (GWASs) is to translate phenotypic associations into biological insights. We integrate a large GWAS on blood lipids involving 1.6 million individuals from five ancestries with a wide array of functional genomic datasets to discover regulatory mechanisms underlying lipid associations.

Dual sensory impairment is affecting over 10% of older adults worldwide. The long-term effect of dual sensory impairment on the risk of mortality remains controversial. We aim to investigate the impact of single or/and dual-sensory-impairment on mortality in a large population-based sample in the UK.

We apply our Bayesian grouped mixture of regressions model (GMRM) in the UK and Estonian Biobanks. We obtain the highest genomic prediction accuracy reported to date across 21 heritable traits. We then extend our GMRM prediction model to provide mixed-linear model association (MLMA) SNP marker estimates for genome-wide association (GWAS) discovery.

Males had on average steeper FC than females. Compared with whites, non-white individuals showed flatter FC. Ocular factors (visual acuity, refractive status, and CPRT) showed a graded inverse association with FC.

Exome-wide association study was conducted to detect rare variants. We detected 730,572 variants with MAF  Bonferroni adjusted  = 0.015. TMIE and ZIC2 were reported to be associated with several mental traits.

Lactase persistence (LP) is the most strongly selected monogenic trait to have evolved over the past 10,000 years. Lactase non-persistent individuals consumed milk when it became available but, under conditions of famine and/or increased pathogen exposure, this was disadvantageous, driving LP selection in prehistoric Europe.

Oesophageal adenocarcinoma (EA), with Barrett's oesophagus (BE) as a precursor, is the most prevalent EC subtype in the Western world. Study aims to contribute to better understand the genetic causes of BE/EA.

Elevated blood pressure (BP) is a prevalent modifiable risk factor for cardiovascular diseases and contributes to cognitive decline in late life. Here, we aim to delineate neurobiological correlates of BP at an individual level using machine learning and functional connectivity.

Psychiatric disorders and neuroticism are closely associated with central nervous system. Proper functioning depends on efficient protein renewal. This study aims to systematically analyze the association between anxiety / depression / neuroticism and each of the 439 proteins. Six common candidate proteins were associated with all three traits.

Previous studies stratified patients with major depressive disorder (MDD) based on clinical characteristics. This study used this approach in individuals with lifetime MDD who reported low wellbeing, a group of high clinical relevance.

Study includes 319,832 participants who were free of diabetes, cardiovascular disease and cancer at baseline in the UK Biobank study. The PsRS was calculated by counting the 12 social determinants of health from three social risk domains that had a statistically significant association with incident type 2 diabetes after Bonferroni correction.

 trigger finger and carpal tunnel syndrome are the two most common non-traumatic connective tissue disorders of the hand. Both conditions frequently co-occur, often in patients with rheumatoid arthritis. We aimed to identify a specific genetic locus associated with both diseases. We identified five independent loci, including one locus, DIRC3, that was co-localised with carpal Tunnel syndrome.

The fat-to-muscle mass ratio (FMR) has been proposed as a useful indicator to assess disease risk independent of overall obesity. Little is known about the association between FMR and dementia risk. We aimed to investigate sex-specific associations between total and regional F MR and incident dementia.

Population genetic structure is an important confounder in genome-wide association studies (GWASs) This may ultimately result in a biased polygenic risk score (PRS) prediction, especially when applied to another population. We aimed to investigate whether using a reference population (1000G) for computation of the PCs adjusted for in the discovery cohort improves PRS performance.

Obesity is associated with increased risk of depression, but the extent to which this association is symptom-specific is unknown. We examined associations of overweight and obesity with individual depressive symptoms. We pooled data from 15 population-based cohorts comprising 57,532 individuals aged 18 to 100 years at study entry.

The association between dyslipidemia and psoriasis has been studied widely. However, which individual indicators of serum lipids determine an increasing risk of incident Psoriasis is still underappreciated in prospective cohorts. On the basis of UK Biobank, we investigate the causal relationship between four serum Lipids and incident Psorsiasis by Cox proportional hazard model and Mendelian randomization analysis.

Habitual coffee consumption has been associated with multiple health benefits. A comprehensive analysis of disease trajectory and comorbidity networks in relation to coffee consumption is, however, currently lacking. We aimed to examine the health outcomes associated with habitual coffee consumption.

Recent genome-wide association studies of mood instability (MOOD) have found significant positive genetic correlation with major depression and weak correlations with other psychiatric disorders. We investigated the polygenic overlap between MOOD and psychiatric disorders beyond genetic correlation to better characterize putative shared genetic determinants.

Study aims to explore associations between HbA1c levels and risks of incident CVD in patients with gout. We included a total of 6,685 patients (mean age 59.7; 8.1% females) for analyses. During a mean follow-up of 7.3 years, there were 1,095 CVD events documented with an incidence of 2.26 events per 100 person-years (95% confidence interval [CI]: 2.13-2.40)

A total of 345,217 unrelated participants of white British descent were included in analyses. Genetic risk for T2D was estimated as a genome-wide polygenic risk score. A favorable lifestyle was defined in terms of four modifiable lifestyle components. metabolic health status was determined according to the presence of metabolic syndrome components.

We assess contributions to autoimmune disease of genes whose regulation is driven by enhancer regions (enhancer-related) and genes that regulate other genes in  trans (candidate master-regulator) We link these genes to SNPs using several SNP-to-gene (S2G) strategies and apply heritability analyses to draw three conclusions.

Genome-wide association study (GWAS) and meta-analysis association statistics highlighted one susceptibility locus, Tubulointerstitial Nephritis Antigen (TINAG), with genome-wide significance for dermatophytosis. The top SNP was a missense variant within TINAG, position chr6:54308557, alleles A > G, minor allele frequency (MAF) 0.014.

Polygenic risk scores (PRSs) derived from genotype data and family history of disease provide valuable information for predicting disease risk. But PRSs perform poorly when applied to diverse populations. Here, we explore methods for combining both types of information in UK Biobank data. We evaluated PRS, FH, and PRS-FH using liability-scale  R   2.

The associations between visceral adipose tissue (VAT) and bone mineral density (BMD) or fracture have been controversial and the causality of the associations remains to be assessed. This study aimed to explore the associations of VAT^ (predicted value of VAT mass) with BMD and fracture risk in men and women.

Study used UK Biobank, a large progressive cohort study of the UK population. The Asian ethnic group shows the greatest average number of comorbidities, followed by the Black and then White groups. Comorbidity prevalence varies significantly among the ethnic groups for almost all disease categories, with diabetes and hypertension showing the largest differences across groups. Diabetes and hypertension both show ethnic-specific com orbidities that may contribute to observed disease prevalence disparities.

Diet and genetic predisposition to adiposity are independent predictors of body composition. Study examined association of three diet quality indices and a polygenic risk score (PRS) with trunk fat, total fat mass, lean mass and bone mineral content.

A health-conscious lifestyle may protect against breast cancer in situ. Many studies lack information on screening participation. We evaluated the association between prediagnostic lifestyle and risk of breast cancer. Lifestyle was inversely associated with risk in women not reporting dietary changes.

The ageing process includes the development of debilitating musculoskeletal (MSK) conditions, including chronic back pain (CBP) and rheumatoid arthritis (RA) The mechanisms involved in the genetic-epidemiological relationships between these MSK phenotypes are controversial and limited.

The direct effects of general adiposity and central adiposity on circulating lipoproteins, lipids, and metabolites are unknown. We used new metabolic data from UK Biobank ( N =109,532, a five-fold higher N over previous studies) Higher BMI decreased apolipoprotein B and low-density lipoprotein cholesterol (LDL-C) whilst BMI increased triglycerides only before WHR-adjustment.

Current global diabetes prevention programmes appear to be glucocentric, and do not fully acknowledge the ramifications of cardiorenal risk factors in smokers and ex-smokers. More holistic approach is needed to prevent vascular complications in people with prediabetes and diabetes before and after quitting.

Genome-wide association (GWA) analyses were performed utilizing data from the Kaiser Permanente Research Board (KPRB) and the UK Biobank. There were a total of 3,872 combined cases of chondromalacia from the KPRB and the British cohorts. Genetic markers in  ARHGAP15 and  MAGEC2 appear to be associated with the condition.

Hypertrophic cardiomyopathy (HCM) is a leading cause of sudden cardiac death in young people. Rare genetic variants are well-established contributors to HCM risk, but common genetic variants have recently been implicated in disease pathogenesis. This cohort study assessed the relative and joint contributions of rare genetic variants and a common variant (polygenic) score to risk of HCM. Both rare and common variant predictors were then evaluated in the context of relevant clinical risk factors.

Previous studies have shown lower cardiovascular risk with higher high-density lipoprotein cholesterol (HDL-C) levels. However, recent data in the general population have shown increased risk of adverse outcomes at very high HDL-C concentrations. This prospective, multicenter, cohort study recruited patients with CAD from the UK Biobank (UKB) and the Emory Cardiovascular Biobanks (EmCAB), respectively.

Study used large-scale data of UK Biobank and ESTHER study. Used three major former smoking traits: pack-years, smoking duration and time since smoking cessation. This score was robustly associated with higher risks of mortality.

The mechanisms linking APOE to AD-particularly the apoE protein's role in AD pathogenesis-remain poorly understood. This study combined case-control, family-based, population-based and longitudinal AD-related cohorts. Two missense variants were associated with a 2-fold to 3-fold decreased AD risk. The large risk reductions reported here suggest that protein chemistry and functional assays of these variants should be pursued.

Pathogenic variants associated with inherited cardiomyopathy are recognized as important and clinically actionable when identified. This was a genetic association study of participants in Atherosclerosis in Risk Communities (ARIC) and the UK Biobank. Incidence of all-cause mortality, heart failure, and atrial fibrillation were determined. Cardiac magnetic resonance imaging, echocardiography, and electrocardiogram measures were assessed.

A total of 501 379 participants from UK biobank who completed the questionnaire on the frequency of adding salt to foods at baseline. During a median of 9.0 years of follow-up, 18 474 premature deaths were documented. The multivariable hazard ratios [95% confidence interval (CI)] of all-cause premature mortality were 1.00 (reference), 1.02 (0.99, 1.06), and 1.28 (1.20,1.35) (P-trend)

PM 2.5 and NO 2 were positively associated with COVID-19 hospitalisations and deaths in minimally adjusted models, but not in fully adjusted models. No associations for PM 10 were found. In analyses with additional adjustment for pre-existing chronic disease, effect estimates were not substantially attenuated.

Wellbeing, an important component of mental health, is influenced by genetic and environmental factors. Previous association studies between brain structure and wellbeing have typically focused on volumetric measures and employed small cohorts. We explored the relationships between wellbeing and brain morphometrics (volume, thickness and surface area) at both phenotypic and genetic levels.

Autoimmune and allergic diseases are outcomes of the dysregulation of the immune system. Study aimed to elucidate differences or shared components in genetic backgrounds between autoimmune and allergic disease. Multi-trait GWAS meta-analysis newly identified six allergic disease-associated loci.

Postexercise heart rate recovery (HRR) is an important indicator of cardiac autonomic function and abnormal HRR is associated with adverse outcomes. We hypothesized that deep learning on resting electrocardiogram (ECG) tracings may identify individuals with impaired HRR. We trained a deep learning model to infer HRR based on resting ECG waveforms among UK Biobank participants.

Review aims to summarize key methods for estimating years of life lost (YLL) We used data from UK Biobank and multimorbidity as our example. For the YPLL and GBD method, the analytical procedures allow only to quantify average YLL.

 xSqueezeIt (XSI) allows for a file size reduction of 4-20Ã— compared with compressed BCF. It has potential for 'compressive genomics' on the UK Biobank whole-genome sequencing genotypes. The XSI file format specifications, API and command line tool are released under open-source license.

A higher polygenic resilience score was associated with a lower risk for PD. Although no single locus reached genome-wide significance, MAGMA gene-based analyses nominated TBCA as a putative gene. Subsequent functional enrichment analysis highlighted histone methylation as a potential pathway harboring resilience alleles.

Millions of women worldwide use exogenous hormones as oral contraceptives or hormone replacement therapy. Still, time-dependent and long-term consequences of these hormones on stroke risk remains unclear. We examined the association between self-reported oral contraceptive use and stroke risk in 257 194 women from the UK Biobank.

Gastrointestinal (GI) cancer risk has been associated with metabolic syndrome (MetS), a surrogate indicator for unhealthy lifestyles, and a number of genetic loci. The combined effect of MetS and genetic variants on GI cancer risk is uncertain.

The interplay between pain of different chronicity and cardiovascular disease is incompletely understood. We aimed to investigate the association between different levels of chronic or nonchronic pain and risk of CVD. Participants in the UK Biobank who reported pain at baseline were divided into three groups.

Previous studies had limited power to assess the associations of circulating insulin-like growth factors (IGFs) and IGF-binding proteins (IGFBPs) with clinically relevant prostate cancer as a primary endpoint. We aimed to investigate associations of IGF-I, IGF-II, IGFBP-1, IGF BP-2 and IGFBP3 concentrations with overall, aggressive and early-onset prostate cancer.

There is growing recognition that chronic liver conditions influence brain health. We evaluated the association between liver fibrosis and incident dementia in a cohort study. Liver fibrosis in middle age was associated with an increased risk of incident dementia, independent of shared risk factors.

The complex relationship between life course traumas and cardiovascular disease (CVD) and the underpinning pathways are poorly understood. Using data from 104,939 participants from the UK Biobank, we demonstrate that subgroups of childhood, adulthood, and lifetime traum as were associated with CVD. Formal mediation analyses suggested that phenotypic aging partially mediated the above associations.

Intracranial volume (ICV) is frequently used in volumetric magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) studies. Findings of associations between ICV and age have varied, potentially due to differences in ICV estimation methods. We found both positive and negative cross-sectional associations with age, depending on dataset and ICv estimation method. Longitudinal ICV reductions were found for all ICV estimating methods.

Current epidemiologic evidence indicates that smoking is associated with a lower endometrial cancer risk. However, it is unknown if this association is causal or confounded. We conducted complementary observational and Mendelian randomization (MR) analyses. In the observational analysis, lifetime amount of smoking and ever having smoked regularly were associated with lower risk.

Progressive eGFR-decline can lead to kidney failure, necessitating dialysis or transplantation. Hundreds of loci from genome-wide association studies (GWAS) for eG FR help explain population cross section variability. We provide a large data resource and prioritized genes for kidney function decline.

There is a paucity of data regarding the phenotype of dilated cardiomyopathy (DCM) gene variants. We aimed to determine the frequency and penetrance of DCM-associated putative pathogenic gene variants in a general adult population. UK Biobank participants had undergone whole exome sequencing, ECG, and cardiovascular magnetic resonance imaging.

UK Biobank cohort included 61,958 participants aged 40 to 70 years from April 2007 to December 2016. Healthy behaviors examined were: never smoking, high level of physical activity, high diet quality, moderate alcohol intake, and optimal sleep.

Cataract surgery was associated with decreased risk of all-cause dementia. Cataract was negatively associated with cortical volumes, aging-related subcortical volumes, and fractional anisotropy of white matter fibers.

We assessed the associations of vegetarian and non-vegetarian diets with risks of all cancer, colorectal cancer, postmenopausal breast cancer, and prostate cancer. We conducted a prospective analysis of 472,377 UK Biobank participants who were free from cancer at recruitment. Compared with regular meat-eaters, being a low meat-eater, fish-eaters, or vegetarians were all associated with a lower risk of cancer.

Right ventricular (RV) structure and function influence morbidity and mortality from coronary artery disease (CAD), dilated cardiomyopathy (DCM), pulmonary hypertension and heart failure. Little is known about the genetic basis of RV measurements. We identify 25 unique loci associated with at least one RV phenotype at P.

Congenital heart diseases often involve maldevelopment of the evolutionarily recent right heart chamber. We fine-tuned deep learning models to recognize the right atrium, right ventricle and pulmonary artery, measuring right heart structures in 40,000 individuals. Genome-wide association studies identified 130 distinct loci associated with at least one right heart measurement.

Consumption of meals bought from out-of-home sources is a suggested risk factor for obesity. Consumption of fast-food/caf&#233; meals was not consistently associated with BMI or percent body fat.

Coffee consumption has been associated with several adverse pregnancy outcomes. We investigated whether there is a causal relationship between coffee consumption and miscarriage, stillbirth, birthweight, gestational age and pre-term birth using Mendelian randomization.

ASD is diagnosed three to four times more frequently in males than in females. Sex differences in common inherited genetic risk for ASD are less studied, particularly within families. Using both epidemiologic and genetic approaches, our findings strongly support an FPE against ASD's common inherited influences.

Mood disorder was associated with onset of cardiometabolic multimorbidity (CMM) However, the impact of mood disorder on the transition from single CMD to CMM was poorly understood. A total of 95,351 participants with one CMD, with median age of 59 (range 40 to 71) years were enrolled at baseline.

 Depression and anxiety are the leading mental health problems worldwide. Handgrip strength (HGS) was inversely associated with incident depression and anxiety. HGS is a simple, non-invasive, and inexpensive measure. It could be easily used to stratify patients.

The current study aims to investigate the combined association of walking pace and grip strength with incident type 2 diabetes (T2D) A total of 205 738 participants (mean age 56.6 +/- 8.1 years, 115 139 [56.0%] women) without diagnosed or unknown diabetes at baseline from the UK Biobank study were included in this prospective study.

There is inconsistent evidence for the causal role of serum insulin-like growth factor-1 (IGF-1) concentration in the pathogenesis of human age-related diseases such as type 2 diabetes (T2D) We investigated the association between IGF-1 and T2D using Mendelian randomization (MR) analyses in the UK Biobank.

We conducted a multiancestry whole-genome sequencing analysis of blood pressure among 51 456 Trans-Omics for Precision Medicine and Centers for Common Disease Genomics program participants. Two blood pressure signals achieved genome-wide significance in meta-analyses of stage-1 and stage-2 single variant findings. Among them, a rare intergenic variant at novel locus was associated with lower systolic blood pressure.

Haplotypes can be estimated from unphased genotype data via statistical methods. We show that genotype error inflates the observed switch error rate and that the relative bias increases with sample size. We propose an alternate definition of phase error that counts two consecutive switch errors as a single error.

Phenome-wide association study used health data from participants in 3 cohorts. Germline variants in 23 hereditary cancer genes were aggregated for association analyses. All 38 established gene-cancer associations were replicated, and 19 new associations were identified.

Keratoconus can be a debilitating corneal ectasia in which the cornea thins, bulges, and steepens into a conical shape. Early features include myopia and irregular astigmatism, which affect vision and can be treated with contact lenses, collagen cross-linking, or, in advanced cases, cornea transplant. However, obtaining very large keratoconuus data sets for a genome-wide association study is problematic.

Recent work has found increasing evidence of mitigated, incompletely penetrant phenotypes in heterozygous carriers of recessive Mendelian disease variants. We leveraged whole-exome imputation within the full UK Biobank cohort to extend such analyses to 3,475 rare variants. Testing these variants for association with 58 quantitative traits yielded 102 significant associations involving variants previously implicated in 34 different diseases.

PRKN mutations are the most common recessive cause of Parkinson's disease and are a promising target for gene and cell replacement therapies. Identification of biallelic PRKN patients at the population scale remains a challenge, as roughly half are copy number variants and many single nucleotide polymorphisms are of unclear significance.

UK Biobank participants (n = 36,260) aged (40-70) years were included and stratified by sex and four age groups (age &#8804; 45, 46-55, 56-65 and > 65 years) Multi-level regression analyses were used to assess the association between mean arterial pressure, systolic BP, diastolic BP and brain volumes. Interaction effects between body mass index (BMI), antihypertensive medication and BP in predicting brain volumes and WMLs were also investigated.

Study examined association of BMI and waist-to-hip ratio (WHR) with CVD risk using genetic scores of the obesity measurements as proxies. High BMI or higher WHR genetic scores were associated with an increase in CVA risk.

IBD may be associated with an increased risk of overall cancer and cancer-specific mortality. digestive cancers, nonmelanoma and male genital cancers were observed in IBD patients.

Recent evidence suggests periodontitis (PD) causes hypertension, which is a precursor to development of other systemic diseases. The aim of this study was to examine the effect of hypertension and PD on the risk of subsequent systemic disease. The study included 244,393 UK Biobank participants who were free of systemic disease other than hypertension at baseline.

Exercise boosts neurogenesis in the mouse hippocampus. Increased levels of the selenium transport protein selenoprotein P (SEPP1) in the serum of exercised animals may contribute to the impact of exercise. Selenium supplementation in the diet had the same effect as exercise in reducing some cognitive impairments associated with aging.

Study included 118,153 UK Biobank participants with data on statin use and corneal-compensated IOP. After excluding participants with neurodegenerative diseases, 41,638 participants with macular retinal nerve fiber layer thickness (mRNFL) were available for analysis. Statin use was weakly associated with thinner mRNFL.

 Associations of liver, metabolic, and inflammatory biomarkers in blood with body shape are unclear. waist circumference (WC) and hip circumference (HC) are dependent on overall body size, resulting in bias. Study confirms associations with waist and hip size, independent of BMI, for metabolic biomarkers but only with waist size for inflammatory biomarker.

Statins lower low-density lipoprotein cholesterol and are widely used for the prevention of atherosclerotic cardiovascular disease. Whether statin-induced low- density lipop protein reduction increases risk of intracerebral haemorrhage has been debated for almost two decades. Using genomic data from randomized trials, we derived a polygenic score from 35 single nucleotide polymorphisms of on-statinLow-density Lipoprotein response.

Cardiometabolic disease (CMD) increases the risk of mortality, but the extent to which this can be offset by adherence to a healthy lifestyle is unknown. We aimed to investigate whether and to what extent a combination of healthy lifestyle was associated with lower risk of total mortality.

Socioeconomic status (SES) correlates with brain structure, a relation of interest given the long-observed relations of SES to cognitive abilities and health. In an unprecedently large study, here, we assess genetic and environmental contributions to SES differences in neuroanatomy.

Polygenic risk scores (PRSs) quantify the contribution of multiple genetic loci to an individual's likelihood of a complex trait or disease. Existing PRSs estimate this likelihood with common genetic variants, excluding the impact of rare variants. We report on a method to identify rare variants associated with outlier gene expression and integrate their impact into PRS predictions.

Asthma is the most common chronic condition in children and the third leading cause of hospitalization in pediatrics. A polygenic risk score (PRS) with predictive value across ancestries has not been evaluated for this important trait. This study aimed to train and validate a PRS relying on genetic determinants for asthma.

Low vitamin D status is often associated with systemic low-grade inflammation as reflected by elevated C-reactive protein (CRP) levels. We investigated the causality and direction of the association between Vitamin D status and CRP using linear and non-linear Mendelian randomization (MR) analyses.

There is growing evidence for the inherited basis of susceptibility to childhood acute lymphoblastic leukemia (ALL) Genome-wide association studies have identified non-coding ALL risk variants at the ARID5B gene locus. The exact functional effects and the molecular mechanism linking ARID 5B to B-cell ALL leukemogenesis remain largely unknown.

We propose a simple framework - meta-matching - to translate predictive models from large-scale datasets to new unseen non-brain-imaging phenotypes in small-scale studies. Using the UK Biobank (N = 36,848) and Human Connectome Project (HCP) datasets, we demonstrate that meta- matching can greatly boost the prediction of new phenotypes.

Common adrenal-permissive missense-encoding variant HSD3B1(1245C) that enables androgen synthesis from adrenal precursors was investigated. The outcomes were identification as a COVID case among all subjects, COVID positivity among COVID-tested subjects, and mortality.

Study looked at 127 496 participants who completed a psychological wellbeing questionnaire and did not have type 2 diabetes at baseline. Moderate to extreme unhappiness, presence of broad depression, and a neuroticism score &#8805;3 were all significantly associated with an increased risk of diabetes.

The association between vitamin E and cancer risk has been widely investigated by observational studies, but the findings remain inconclusive. We aimed to evaluate the causal effect of circulating vitamin E on the risk of ten common cancers, including bladder, breast, colorectal, esophagus, lung, oral and pharynx, ovarian, pancreatic, prostate, and kidney cancer.

Cancer patients treated with capecitabine and oxaliplatin (XELOX) often develop hand-foot syndrome (HFS) or palmar-plantar erythrodysesthesia. We found that 68% of patients from COIN and COIN-B with grade 2-3 HFS responded to treatment as compared to 58% with grade 0-1 HFS. HFS was also associated with improved overall survival.

 PKP2 (PKP2 tv) variants cause arrhythmogenic right ventricular cardiomyopathy (ARVC) yet display varied penetrance and expressivity. We determined the prevalence of an ARVC phenotype and other cardiovascular traits based on clinical and procedural data. Atrial fibrillation was over-represented in the UKB cohort in those with PKP1 tv.

Method based on inverse probability weighting, extended natural effect model method and weight-based imputation strategies were used. Simulation experiments of three scenarios were carried out to compare the performance of different methods in estimating direct and indirect effects in different situations. The regression method is more suitable for continuous mediator, and the inverse probabilities weighting method is for binary mediator.

Low vitamin D status is associated with a higher risk for cardiovascular diseases (CVDs) Although most existing linear Mendelian randomization (MR) studies reported a null effect of vitamin D on CVD risk, a non-linear effect cannot be excluded. Our aim was to apply the non- linear MR design to investigate the association of serum 25-hydroxyvitamin D [25(OH)D] concentration.

Blood copper may have causal association with prostate cancer, malignant and unknown neoplasms of the brain and nervous system, hypertension, and dysphagia. Considering that copper is modifiable, exploring whether regulation of copper levels can be used to optimize health outcomes might have public health importance.

Review of current state of genetic risk models for kidney cancer. 39 models predicting the development of kidney cancer were identified. 31 of the models were validated in the UK Biobank cohort. Models containing a larger number of genetic variants performed better.

In UK Biobank, 661 men died from prostate cancer over a mean follow-up of 11.6 years. BMI, body fat percentage and WC were strongly associated with imaging estimates of total and central adiposity. The hazard ratios (HR) for prostate cancer death were 1.07 (95% confidence interval = 0.97-1.17) per 5 kg/m2 higher BMI.

We identify four broad factors (neurodevelopmental, compulsive, psychotic and internalizing) that underlie genetic correlations among the disorders. Despite moderate-to-high genetic correlations across all 11 disorders, we find little utility of a single dimension of genetic risk across psychiatric disorders.

Polygenic risk scores (PRSs) aggregate the effects of genetic variants across the genome and are used to predict risk of complex diseases, such as obesity. Current PRSs only include common variants (minor allele frequency (MAF) &#8805;1%), whereas the contribution of rare variants to predict disease remains unknown. Here, we examine whether augmenting the standard common variant PRS with a rare variantPRS improves prediction of obesity. We used genome-wide genotyped and imputed data on 451,145 European-ancestry participants.

We analyzed data on 4,657 plasma proteins from 7,213 European American and 1,871 African American individuals. Elastic Net produced powerful models for protein prediction in both populations. An application of proteome-wide association studies to serum urate and gout implicated several proteins.

Previous research suggests that inflammation may lead to structural brain changes via activation of microglia and/or astrocytic dysfunction in a range of neuropsychiatric disorders. This study used multistage linked analyses, including mendelian randomization (MR), gene expression correlation, and connectivity analyses. In the UK Biobank sample, genetically predicted levels of IL-6 were associated with GMV in the middle temporal cortex.

The host genetic background for hepatocellular carcinoma (HCC) is incompletely understood. We aimed to determine if four germline genetic polymorphisms, previously associated with progressive alcohol-related and nonalcoholic fatty liver disease, are also associated with HCC. Four HCC case-control data sets were constructed. The frequency of each variant was compared between HCC cases and cirrhosis controls.

Glomerular hematuria can have a genetic basis, including Alport syndrome and IgA nephropathy. We used summary statistics to identify genetic variants associated with the condition in White British UK Biobank participants. A strongly associated locus on chromosome 2 was identified.

Late-life depression (LLD) is characterized by considerable heterogeneity in clinical manifestation. This study characterized LLD into 2 dimensions with distinct neuroanatomical, cognitive, clinical, and genetic profiles. The 2 dimensions demonstrated significant single-nucleotide variant-based heritability of 18% to 27% within the general population.

Nonalcoholic fatty liver disease (NAFLD) is an emerging cause of liver-related events (LREs) We assessed the ability of a composite score based on clinical features, metabolic comorbidities, and genetic variants to predict LREs.

Little is known about gene-gene (G Ã— G) interactions that may influence the risk of non-small cell lung cancer (NSCLC) We analyzed 58 billion G Ã— G interactions from 340,958 single-nucleotide polymorphisms (SNPs) The top interactions were further tested by demographically adjusted logistic regression models. We used the selected interactions to build lung cancer screening models of NSCLC, separately, for never and ever smokers.

Serum lipids are modifiable, routinely collected blood test features associated with cardiovascular health. We examined the association of commonly collected serum lipid measures with intraocular pressure. Higher levels of TC, HDL-C, and LDL-C were associated independently with higher IOPcc in both cohorts.

Arterial stiffness (AS), measured by arterial stiffness index (ASI), can be considered as a major denominator in cardiovascular (CV) diseases. According to European consensus, AS is defined as ASI > 10 m/s. The purpose of this study was to investigate the determinants of ASI among UK Biobank normotensive and healthy participants.

 Epidemiological studies reveal that marijuana increases the risk of cardiovascular disease (CVD) Little is known about the mechanism. We found that marijuana smoking activated inflammatory cytokines implicated in CVD. Genistein is a CB1 antagonist that attenuates &#916; 9 -THC-induced atherosclerosis.

Sleep duration, psychiatric disorders and dementias are closely interconnected in older adults. However, the underlying genetic mechanisms and brain structural changes are unknown. Using data from the UK Biobank for participants primarily of European ancestry aged 38-73 years, including 94% white people, we identified a nonlinear association between sleep and cognition.

Using older adults aged 60 years and over in the UK Biobank, we examined the association between leukocyte telomere length and osteosarcopenia. Telomere shortening is linked to oxidative stress and inflammation, both of which are linked to bone and muscle loss. Longer telomeres was associated with a lower risk of slow walking pace, but not low grip strength or low bone density.

ExPheWas (exphewas.ca) is a gene-based phenome-wide association study browser and platform. It enables the conduct of gene- based Mendelian randomization. Interactive visualizations are provided through a browser to facilitate data exploration.

Personality is a strong determinant for several health-related behaviours and has been linked to the development of cardiovascular diseases. However, the reports of personality's mediating role have been inconsistent with no data available from large population-based cohorts. Study aimed to create proxies for the Big Five personality traits, extraversion, agreeableness, conscientiousness, openness and neuroticism.

Cardiometabolic risk (CMR) factors are associated with accelerated brain aging and increased risk for sex-dimorphic illnesses. It is unknown how CMRs interact with sex and apolipoprotein E-&#1013;4 (APOE4), a known genetic risk factor for AD, to influence brain age across different life stages. We investigated whether associations between white matter Brain Age Gap (BAG) and body mass index (BMI), waist-to-hip ratio (WHR), body fat percentage (BF%), and APOE4 status varied between males and females.

We report the largest genome-wide association study (GWAS) on C-reactive protein (CRP), a marker of systemic inflammation. We identify 266 independent loci, of which 211 are not previously reported. 27 clinical outcomes associated with genetically determined CRP.

High vitamin D status has been suggested to have beneficial effects on the brain. We examined the association between 25(OH)D concentrations with neuroimaging outcomes. Vitamin D deficiency was associated with an increased risk of dementia and stroke, with the strongest associations for those with 25( OH)D.

Coronary artery disease (CAD) remains the leading cause of death despite scientific advances. Elucidating shared CAD/pneumonia pathways may reveal novel insights regarding CAD pathways. We performed genome-wide pleiotropy analyses of CAD and pneumonia.

Study looked at 466 788 participants of the UK Biobank. The outcome was all-cause dementia incidence and mortality. Grip strength was assessed using a Jamar J00105 hydraulic hand dynamometer.

Chronic multisite musculoskeletal pain (CMP) is common and highly morbid. Vulnerability factors for CMP are poorly understood. Previous studies have shown that both small hippocampal brain volume and genetic risk alleles in a key stress system gene, FKBP5, increase vulnerability for chronic pain.

Little is known about how the effect of genes can be modulated by the environment, creating a gene-environment interaction. MRNMs provide unbiased polygenic-covariate interaction estimates for a quantitative trait. Of the 17 selected covariates, 11 significantly modulate deviations in depressive symptoms through the modelled interactions. No single interaction explains a large proportion of phenotypic variation.

Sleep quality (duration) is associated with health-related quality of life (HRQoL) Most studies have been small-sized and targeted at young and middle-aged adults. Few studies have explored the path mechanism of sleep disorders leading to impaired HRQOL.

There is inconsistent evidence on whether genetic risk for dementia modifies the association between hypertension and dementia. In 198,965 dementia-free participants aged &#8805;60 years, Cox proportional-hazards models were used to investigate the association. Hypertension was associated with a 19% increased risk of dementia.

Genetic variants associated with caffeine metabolism were leveraged in the two-sample Mendelian randomization framework. Genetically predicted higher plasma caffeine levels were associated with a non-significant lower risk of Alzheimer's disease. No overall association was found.

Mildly elevated bilirubin might mitigate cardiometabolic risk factors including adiposity, dyslipidemia, and high blood pressure (BP) We investigated the cross-sectional relationship between (total) bilirUBin and baseline risk factors in 467,519 UK Biobank study participants.

Ataxia-telangiectasia mutated (ATM) gene has been widely studied in oncology. Independent effects of ATM missense variants and protein-truncating variants (PTVs) on neoplasms have not been heavily studied. Whole-exome sequencing data and clinical health records of 394,694 UK Biobank European participants were used in this analysis.

Mice with experimental nerve damage can display long-lasting neuropathic pain behavior. We show that 4 months and later after nerve injury, male but not female mice displayed telomere length (TL) reduction and p53-mediated cellular senescence in the spinal cord.

Schizophrenia and bipolar disorder are neurodevelopmental disorders with overlapping symptoms and a shared genetic background. Deviations in intracranial volume (ICV) - a marker for neurodevelopment - differ between schizophrenia and bipolar Disorder. We investigated whether genetic risk for schizophrenia andipolar disorder is related to ICV in the general population by using UK Biobank data.

Sleep has been associated with aging and relevant health outcomes, but the causal relationship remains inconclusive. We investigated the associations of sleep behaviors with biological ages (BAs) among 363,886 middle and elderly adults from UK Biobank. A one-unit increase in sleep index was associated with 0.104- and 0.119-year decreases in KDM-biological AA and PhenoAge.

Diastole is the sequence of physiological events that occur in the heart during ventricular filling and principally depends on myocardial relaxation and chamber stiffness. Abnormal diastolic function is related to many cardiovascular disease processes and is predictive of health outcomes. Here, we use machine-learning cardiac motion analysis to measure diastolics functional traits in 39,559 participants of the UK Biobank.

With age, the prevalence of diseases such as fatty liver disease, cirrhosis, and type two diabetes increases. Approaches to both predict abdominal age and identify risk factors for accelerated abdominal age may ultimately lead to advances that will delay the onset of these diseases.

 Depression is assessed in various ways in research, with large population studies often relying on minimal phenotyping. We studied 39,300 UK Biobank imaging participants (20,701 female; aged 44.6 to 82.3 years, M = 64.1, SD = 7.5)

Noninvasive assessment of histological features of nonalcoholic fatty liver disease (NAFLD) has been an intensive research area over the last decade. We aimed to develop a simple noninvasive score using routine laboratory tests to identify those at high risk for NAFLD. The final predictive model, designated as Fibrotic NASH Index, combined aspartate aminotransferase, high-density lipoprotein cholesterol, and hemoglobin A1c.

Non-alcoholic fatty liver disease (NAFLD) is the leading cause of liver disorders. We found that rare mutations in a gene called autophagy-related 7 (ATG7) increase the risk of developing severe liver disease in individuals with dysmetabolism.

Physical activity, body mass index (BMI), body fat percentage, waist circumference, and waist to hip ratio changes were categorized on the basis of public health and clinical guidelines. Among 29,610 participants, 545 deaths and 2970 CVD events occurred. Increases in physical activity to meet guidelines lowered all-cause mortality and CVD risk equal to that of those who continually met guidelines.

A rare genetic variant (p.Thr95Ile) in the manganese transporter SLC30A10 is associated with elevated plasma alanine transaminase (ALT) Heterozygotes also had higher corrected T1 on liver MRI, a marker of hepatic inflammation. These data support that the variant may increase the risk of liver disease.

Over 400 variants in the cystic fibrosis (CF) transmembrane conductance regulator (CFTR) are CF-causing. CFTR modulators target variants to improve lung function, but marked variability in response exists. Alternative epithelial ion channel/transporters such as SLC26A9 could compensate for CFTR dysfunction.

Studies suggest that adiposity in childhood may reduce the risk of breast cancer in later life. The biological mechanism underlying this effect is unclear but is likely to be independent of body size in adulthood. Using a Mendelian randomization framework, we investigate 18 hypothesised mediators of the protective effect of childhood adiposity.

Rare sequence variation in genes underlying cardiac repolarization and common polygenic variation influence QT interval duration. Current clinical genetic testing of individuals with unexplained QT prolongation is restricted to examination of monogenic rare variants. Recent emergence of large-scale biorepositories with sequence data enables examination of the joint contribution of rare and common variations.

Intraocular pressure (IOP) is a highly heritable risk factor for primary open-angle glaucoma (POAG) GAS7 is quite close to a cannabis receptor at chromosome 17p31.3. CB1, GPR18, and cannabis are associated with cannabis IOP reduction in mice.

Depression and obesity are complex global health problems. Recent studies suggest that a genetic predisposition to obesity might be accentuated in people with depression. Here, we tested the hypothesis that depression accentuates genetic susceptibility to obesity.

South Asians are at high risk of developing type 2 diabetes (T2D) We identify 21 novel genetic loci for significant association with T2D. A polygenic risk score based on South Asian-derived summary statistics shows a 4-fold higher risk between the top and bottom quartile.

No reference standards currently exist to quantify individual differences in neuroimaging metrics over time. We assemble an interactive open resource to benchmark brain morphology derived from any current or future sample of MRI data. We aggregated 123,984 MRI scans, across more than 100 primary studies, from 101,457 human participants between 115 days post-conception to 100 years of age.

Magnetic Resonance Imaging (MRI) technology has been increasingly used in neuroscience studies. Reproducibility of statistically significant findings generated by MRI-based studies has been heavily debated. Most currently available reproducibility measures depend on thresholds for the test statistics. It is crucial to elucidate the relationship between overall study reproducibilities and sample size in an experimental design.

UK Biobank has recruited more than 500 000 volunteers from the United Kingdom. Ongoing medical imaging of 100 000 participants with 70 000 follow-up sessions will yield up to 170 000 MRI scans, enabling image analysis of body composition, organs, and muscle.

The storage amount of liver glycogen could affect the liver fibrosis assessment made by MRI-based methods. We conducted an association study of the glycogen metabolism genes based on the PDFF data of 11,129 participants in the UK Biobank. The effect of SNPs in these genes on non-alcoholic fatty liver disease was estimated by a meta-analysis of the available NAFLD case-control studies.

Clonal hematopoiesis of indeterminate potential (CHIP) predisposes both hematologic malignancy and CAD. TERT (which encodes telomerase reverse transcriptase) is the most significantly associated germline locus for CHIP in genome-wide association studies.

The link between hearing impairment and air pollution has not been established. We investigated the association between air pollution and hearing impairment in British adults aged 37-73 years. We found that exposure to PM 10 , NO X , and NO 2 was associated with hearing impairment.

Gene set findings implicate both early brain development and neurodegenerative processes in the rates of brain changes. Global genetic overlap with depression, schizophrenia, cognitive functioning, insomnia, height, body mass index and smoking. Identifying variants involved in structural brain changes may help to determine biological pathways underlying optimal and dysfunctional brain development.

Multiplex Serology platform measures quantitative antibody responses against 45 antigens from 20 infectious agents. Antibody responses included human herpes, hepatitis, polyoma, papilloma, and retroviruses. Assayed a random subset of 9695 UK Biobank participants.

Urban greenspace provides opportunities for outdoor exercise and may increase physical activity, with accompanying health benefits. Areas suitable for walking are also associated with increased physical activity. interactions with greenspace are poorly understood. We investigated associations of walkability and green walkability with physical activity in an urban adult cohort.

Paediatric GCT samples were obtained from a Children's Oncology Group study and state biobank programs in California and Michigan. Mendelian randomisation was used to look at the association between genetically predicted LTL and GCTs and TERT variants.

Atrial fibrillation (AF) is a cardiac arrhythmia associated with an elevated risk of stroke, heart failure, and mortality. Lipoprotein(a) (Lp[a]) is a recognized risk factor for atherosclerotic cardiovascular disease (ASCVD), which itself increases AF risk. It remains unknown whether Lp(a), a known ASCVD risk factor, is a causal mediator of AF independent of ASCVD. We found that each 50 nmol/L (23 mg/dL) increase in Lp (a) was associated with increased risk of incident AF.

Spontaneous coronary artery dissection (SCAD) is an increasingly recognized nonatherosclerotic cause of acute myocardial infarction. To assess which genes contribute to the development of SCAD, whole-exome sequencing was performed among individuals with SCAD. Rare disruptive variants were found within 10 collagen genes.

We conducted an exome-wide association study to identify rare risk variants contributing to MDD. 120,033 participants with MDD polygenic risk scores (PRS) were included. 34,761 qualifying variants were imported into the SKAT R-package to perform single variants, gene-based burden and robust burden tests with minor allele frequency (MAF)

Late-onset Alzheimer's disease (LOAD) is significantly more frequent in Hispanics than in non-Hispanic Whites. Ancestry may explain these differences across ethnic groups. We tested the association between Local Ancestry (LA) and LOAD ("admixture mapping") to identify LOAD-associated ancestral blocks.

Socioeconomic status (SES) anchors individuals in their social network layers. It remains obscure how distinct facets of SES are reflected in the architecture of the central nervous system. Individuals with higher SES showed a pattern of increased region volumes in the left brain.

Study was conducted using electronic health care records on 1 016 277 individuals from primary care practices in East London. Individuals with a diagnosis of PD were compared with controls without PD.

Primary open angle glaucoma (POAG) is a common cause of blindness. We assessed associations of cardiopulmonary conditions and markers with POAG. We constructed a POAG polygenic risk score using genome-wide association study statistics.

Monogenic familial hypercholesterolaemia (FH) is an autosomal dominant disorder characterised by elevated low-density lipoprotein cholesterol (LDL-C) concentrations. Some mutation-negative patients have a polygenic cause for elevated LDL-C due to a burden of common LDL- C-raising alleles. People of White British (WB) ancestry have a 12-single nucleotide polymorphism (SNP) score. This score has yet to be evaluated in people of South Asian (SA), and Black and Caribbean (BC) ethnicities.

Caffeine-neuropathology correlations and interactions with lifestyle and genetic factors impacting caffeine metabolism and response were also tested. Caffeine intake was inconsistently associated with clinical dementia; potentially explained by cohort differences in underlying dementia etiology. Lewy bodies may link caffeine to lower risk in some persons.

Infection with SARS-CoV-2 virus impacts disadvantaged groups most. Lifestyle factors are also associated with adverse COVID-19 outcomes. We explored effect modification of socioeconomic-status (SES) on associations between lifestyle and outcomes.

PXS was associated with higher levels of clinical risk factors including BMI, systolic blood pressure, blood glucose, triglycerides, and HbA1c. In addition to predicting incident T2D, PXS and PGS were significantly and positively associated with the incidence of all 7 other chronic diseases.

 individuals with supranormal left ventricular ejection fraction (snLVEF; LVEF >70%) have increased mortality. This study aimed to determine the relationship of both snLVEf genetic risk and phenotype with survival and underdiagnosed heart failure (HF) Of 486 754 participants, the median age was 58 years, 20 069 died, and 10 088 had diagnosed HF.

Common diagnostic next-generation sequencing strategies are not optimized to identify inherited variants in genes associated with dominant neurodevelopmental disorders. Heterozygote parents are mildly or not affected, suggesting variable expressivity.

An early age at onset of major depression (AAO-MD) has been associated with more severe illness, psychosis, and suicidality. This study sought to investigate the genetic components underlying AAO- MD. We found a small but significant SNP-heritability (~6%) for the AAO -MD phenotype.

Few studies have derived dietary patterns based on intake of discretionary foods and beverages and examined associations with genetic risk and obesity. Data from 11,735 adults from the UK Biobank cohort study were used. A dietary pattern high in high-SFA and low-fiber discretionary food and beverages was associated with higher risk of obesity.

Women's reproductive factors include their age at menarche and menopause, the age at which they start and stop having children and the number of children they have. Studies that have linked these factors with disease risk have largely investigated individual reproductive factors and have not considered the genetic correlation and total interplay that may occur between them. This study aimed to investigate the relationships between eight female reproductive factors.

Polygenic risk score (PRS) prediction across more than 1,500 traits using genetic and phenotype data in the UK Biobank. We report 813 sparse PRS models with significant (p)

In a genome-wide association study of CTS, we found 53 sequence variants at 50 loci associated with the syndrome. We conclude that at least 22 genes mediate CTS risk and highlight the role of 19 CTS variants in the biology of the extracellular matrix. Anthropometric traits including height and BMI are genetically correlated with CTS.

Post-translational modifications diversify protein functions and dynamically coordinate their signalling networks. Their genetic regulation or influence on complex traits is not fully understood. We compare the genetic regulation of the same PTM of two proteins - glycosylation of transferrin and immunoglobulin G.

 Depression is linked to dementia but whether it is a risk factor or an early sign of a developing dementia remains unclear. Neuroinflammation is increasingly recognised in both depression and Alzheimer's Disease. We hypothesised that recurrent depression has adverse effects on performance in cognitive tests.

Diffusion tensor imaging (DTI) assumes that diffusion measured at typical b-values (approximately 1000 s/mm 2 ) is Gaussian. Diffusion kurtosis imaging (DKI) is an extension of DTI that measures non-Gaussian diffusion (kurtosis) to better capture microenvironmental processes by incorporating additional data at a higher b-value. Using diffusion data (b-values of 1000 and 2000 s/ mm 2 ) from 700 UK Biobank participants aged 46-80, we establish a pattern of lower k Kurtosis alongside higher diffusivity among older adults.

This study included 391,366 participants of European ancestry initially free from pre-existing hypertension in the UK Biobank. Exposure to ambient air pollutants, including particulate matter (PM 2.5, PM 2. 5-10 , and PM 10 ), nitrogen dioxide (NO 2 ) and nitrogen oxides (NO X), was estimated. The associations between air pollutants and the incidence of hypertension were investigated.

Study looked at 13,602 European individuals with asthma diagnosed before 18 years old and 136,008 matched unexposed individuals without such an experience.
