The effects of HLA genetic variation on the expression of 2940 plasma proteins across 45,330 Europeans in the UK Biobank are examined. HLA-I and II affected proteins expressed in similar cell types but in different pathways of both adaptive and innate immunity.

Conventional GWAS for quantitative traits are based on simplified regression models modeling the conditional mean of a phenotype as a linear function of genotype. We draw attention to an alternative, lesser known approach, namely quantile regression. Quantile regression can be applied efficiently at biobank scale.

Steatotic liver disease (SLD) is characterized by excessive accumulation of lipids in the liver. It is associated with elevated risk of hepatic and cardiometabolic diseases, as well as mental disorders such as depression. Previous studies revealed global gray matter reduction in SLD.

 Selection can cause bias in a given analysis if the outcome is related to selection (conditional on the other variables in the model) We propose methods to detect selection bias in genetic studies. We examine the use of four hypothesis tests to identify induced associations between genetic variants in the selected sample. We evaluate these approaches in Monte Carlo simulations.

Maternal smoking during pregnancy (MSDP) is significantly linked to the short- or long-term health of offspring. Little research has examined whether MSDP affect the aging rate of offspring, says study.

The plasma proteome can mediate associations between periodontal disease (Pd) and brain white matter integrity (WMI) We screened 5089 UK Biobank participants aged 40-70 years for poor oral health problems (POHP) POHP was more prevalent among men (12.3% vs. 9.6%) and was associated with lower WMI on most metrics, in a sex-specific manner.

Incomplete Hippocampal Inversion (IHI), sometimes called hippocampal malrotation, is an atypical anatomical pattern of the hippocampus found in about 20% of the general population. IHI has been associated with several brain disorders (epilepsy, schizophrenia) However, these studies were based on small samples.

Ovarian cancer is characterized by late-stage diagnoses and poor prognosis. We aimed to identify factors that can inform prevention and early detection of ovarian cancer. Greater parity and ever-use of oral contraception were associated with lower ovarian cancer risk.

A favorable lifestyle (6-10 healthy factors; 46.4%) was associated with a 36% lower risk of multisystem sequelae. Risk reductions spanned all 10 organ systems, including cardiovascular, coagulation, metabolic, gastrointestinal, kidney, mental health, musculoskeletal, respiratory disorders.

Patients treated with kidney replacement therapy experience a 1.5 to 2-fold increased risk of cancer and cancer mortality. Whether this excess risk extends to people with earlier stages of chronic kidney disease is unclear. This study explored the potentially causal relationship between reduced kidney function and cancer.

Cataract is a leading cause of blindness worldwide. Little is known about sex differences in cataracts. This study aimed to explore the relationships between key health risk factors and the incidence of cataract.

A total of 72,800 participants with accelerometer data and free of mental disorders from the UK Biobank were analyzed. Participants with chronic pain had a higher rate of incident overall mental disorders. Increased sedentary behavior and reduced moderate-to-vigorous physical activity caused by chronic pain both increased the risk of mental disorder.

A growing research body supports the connection between neurodegenerative disorders, including Alzheimer's disease (AD), and traffic-related air pollution (TRAP) However, the underlying mechanisms are not well understood. A deeper investigation of TRAP effects on hippocampal volume (HV), a major biomarker of Neurodegeneration, may help clarify these mechanisms.

 Penetrance is the probability that an individual with a pathogenic genetic variant develops a specific disease. Knowing the penetrance of variants for monogenic disorders is important for counseling of individuals. Until recently, estimates of penetrance have largely relied on affected individuals and their at-risk family members being clinically referred for genetic testing.

Dysbetalipoproteinemia (DBL) is a combined dyslipidemia associated with an increased risk of atherosclerotic cardiovascular diseases. Several algorithms have been proposed to screen DBL. This work compared the diagnostic performances of nine algorithms including a new one.

Previous studies have reported inconsistent associations between platelet count (PLT) and cancer survival. We conducted a cohort study using the UK Biobank and a two-sample Mendelian randomization (MR) analysis. PLT levels were measured prior to cancer diagnosis.

Hospital-treated infectious disease was associated with a greater risk of lung cancer. The impact of lower respiratory tract infections (LRTIs) on lung cancer was the strongest.

Little is known regarding the association between clonal hematopoiesis of indeterminate potential (CHIP) and risk of neurodegenerative diseases. We conducted a community-based cohort study based on UK Biobank and used Cox regression to estimate hazard ratios (HRs) and 95% confidence intervals (CIs) Individuals with CHIP had an increased risk of any neurodegnerative disease (HR 1.10, 95% CI: 1.01-1.19)

The association between air pollutants and hepatobiliary pancreatic diseases remains inconclusive. This study analyzed up to 247,091 participants of White European ancestry (aged 37 to 73 years at recruitment) from the UK Biobank. PM 2.5 significantly increased liver disease risk.

Prescription opioid use (POU) has been shown to lead to cardiovascular disease (CVD), but its association with heart failure has not been well studied. We investigated the potential causal association between POU and HF using cohort studies and Mendelian Randomization (MR) analysis.

When combining imputed and sequenced data in a single gene-based association analysis, the problem of reconstructing genetic correlation matrices arises. To recover these correlations, we propose an efficient method based on maximising the determinant of the matrix. This method has a number of useful properties and an analytical solution for our task.

SARS-CoV-2 has resulted in a global pandemic with a rapidly developing global health and economic crisis. Variations in the disease have been observed and have been associated with the genomic sequence of either the human host or the pathogen.

Gastrointestinal (GI) disorders are highly prevalent and severely diminish life quality. It is yet unknown which dietary pattern is optimal for the prevention of GI disorders. Among 141 450 participants from UK Biobank with a median follow-up of 15 years, we comprehensively assessed 13 dietary patterns.

Over the next 10 years mental ill-health and suicidal behaviours have been predicted to increase. This paper investigated a Syndemic model of health experience in people with SMI. It was informed by physical activity levels, exposure to nature, personal resilience levels, drugs related (tobacco smoking and alcohol consumption), and sleep behaviours.

We examined the relationship between genetic risk for schizophrenia (SZ) and retinal morphological alterations. macular ganglion cell-inner plexiform layer (mGC-IPL) thickness was significantly inversely related to PRS for SZ. PRS, however, was unrelated to retinal vascular characteristics.

Most prediction models for coronary artery disease (CAD) compile biomedical and behavioural risk factors. This study explored the potential of integrating positive psychosocial factors (PPFs) into conventional and machine learning-based CAD prediction models.

In the UK Biobank, in utero tobacco exposure and age of smoking initiation were self-reported. A composite lifestyle score was calculated based on diet, physical activity, nicotine exposure, sleep duration, and BMI. Hazard ratio (HR) and absolute risk difference (ARD) were used to estimate associations of early-life smoking behaviors and genetic risk with incident T2D.

Abdominal aortic aneurysm (AAA) is a complex disease with environmental and genetic risk factors. Polygenic risk scores (PRS) based on disease-specific risk-associated single nucleotide variants (SNVs) have demonstrated effectiveness in stratifying individual-level disease risk for cardiovascular diseases. This prospective cohort study assessed associations of PRS of AAA with risk of incident AAA.

The poor nutritional characteristics and potentially harmful molecules in ultra-processed foods (UPFs) were risk factors for diabetic microvascular complications. We included a prospective cohort of UK Biobank participants with type 2 diabetes (T2D) having at least one 24-h dietary recall. Triglycerides, C-reactive protein, and body mass index collectively explained 22.0% (9.6%-43.0%) of the association.

Study aimed to assess the fatty acid (FA) composition of abdominal subcutaneous and visceral adipose tissue (ASAT and VAT) in the UK Biobank imaging cohort. We measured fractions of saturated, monounsaturated, and polyunsaturated FA (fSFA, fMUFA, and fPUFA, respectively) from multiecho MRI scans.

Arterial and venous cardiovascular conditions are genetically correlated. Interrogating underlying mechanisms may shed light on disease mechanisms. We aimed to identify (1) epidemiological and (2) causal, genetic relationships between metabolites and CAD, PAD, and VTE.

The Brain Care Score (BCS) is a tool designed to empower patients to address 12 dementia and stroke risk factors. The BCS ranges from 0 to 21, with higher scores suggesting better brain care. Every 5-point increase in baseline BCS was linked to significantly lower WMH volumes.

The human cerebellum is increasingly recognized to be involved in non-motor and higher-order cognitive functions. Yet, its ties with the entire cerebral cortex have not been holistically studied. Here, we characterized dissociable cortical-cerebellar structural covariation patterns based on regional gray matter volume (GMV) across the brain.

Analysis includes 44,796 UK Biobank participants (average age 64.1+/-7.7 years; 51.9% women) Ventricular asymmetry was expressed as the ratio of left and right ventricular (LV, RV) end-diastolic volumes.

 Retrotransposons comprise about 45% of the human genome. Their contributions to human trait variation and evolution are only beginning to be explored. We find that a sequence of SVA retrotransposon insertions in an early intron of the ASIP gene has probably shaped human pigmentation several times.

This cohort study included 40283 UK Biobank participants. Neutrophil-to-lymphocyte ratio mediated 9.3% (95% CI, 3.3%-40.4%) of the association of trunk- to-leg lean mass ratio with all-cause mortality. Central lean mass distribution may interact synergistically with aging, and poor diet quality.

Study examined associations between patterns of body composition and the risk of neurodegenerative diseases. It also explored the mediating role of cardiovascular diseases (CVDs) Among 412,691 participants (mean age 56.0 years, 55.1% female), 8,224 new cases of neuro degenerative diseases were identified over an average follow-up of 9.1 years. Patterns identified as "fat-to-lean mass," "muscle strength," "bone density," and "leg-dominant fat distribution" were associated with a lower rate.

Osteoporosis (OP) is characterized by a gradual onset and an increased susceptibility to osteoporotic fractures. Previous studies have suggested that hemoglobin (HGB) levels could be a potential diagnostic marker for OP. This prospective study aimed to investigate the association between HGB levels and OP.

Air pollution is associated with chronic respiratory diseases (CRD) and lung function. The underlying metabolic mechanisms remain largely unclear. We identified 103, 86, 85, and 90 metabolites in response to PM 2.5 , PM 10 , NO X , and NO 2 exposure. The metabolomic signatures showed significant associations with CRD risk.

Study included 2,094 patients with diabetes with no history of CKD at baseline. Based on nearly 3,000 plasma proteins, a CKD protein risk score including 11 proteins was constructed.

Primary liver cancer is globally on the rise, partially due to poor diets and sedentary lifestyles. Shifting to more plant-based diets may lower the risk. We aimed to estimate the effect of replacing total red meat, unprocessed red meat and processed red meat with legumes on primary liver cancer.

Transthyretin is a transport protein whose misfolding has been implicated in the development of cardiac amyloidosis. V142I non-carriers [n = 35,167, mean: -0.1 (0.3)] have higher adjusted transt Hyretin levels compared with the carriers. Transthy Retin levels are lower in females, decrease with increasing C-reactive protein levels, and increase with body mass index.

The 21-point Brain Care Score (BCS) is a novel tool designed to motivate individuals and care providers to take action to reduce the risk of stroke and dementia. We tested the hypothesis that a higher BCS is associated with a reduced incidence of future depression. We also examined its association with a brain health composite outcome comprising stroke, dementia, and late-life depression.

Evidence is limited and inconsistent regarding vitamin D and heart failure (HF) risk in people with type 2 diabetes (T2D) Vitamin D insufficiency or deficiency is common among people with T2D. This study aimed to investigate the associations of serum 25-hydroxyvitamin D (25[OH]D) with HF risk among individuals with T1D.

Genome-wide association studies for subsequent major adverse cardiovascular events (MACE) and subsequent arterial ischemic stroke (AIS) were performed. Two variants were significantly associated with subsequent cardiovascular events. These associations suggest that inflammation is a contributing factor to subsequent MACE outcomes after incident AIS.

Previous studies underscore the protective role of physical activity (PA) in bone health. But the relationship between different PA categories and osteoporosis risk remains less explored. Understanding the relationships helps tailor health recommendations and policies.

In 41,931 individuals from the United Kingdom Biobank Pharma Proteomics Project, we integrated measurements of 3,000 plasma proteins with clinical information to derive sparse prediction models for 218 common and rare diseases. The predictive performance of sparse models including as few as 5 to 20 proteins was superior to the performance of models developed using basic clinical information.

Data from 432,497 participants in UK Biobank, who were free of PD at baseline, were analyzed. Physical activity levels were assessed by measuring the duration of walking for pleasure, light and heavy do-it-yourself activities, strenuous sports, and other exercises.

The aim of this study was to examine the effects of habitual iron supplementation on the risk of CKD in individuals with different hypertensive statuses and antihypertension treatment statuses. We included a total of 427,939 participants in the UK Biobank study, who were free of CKd and with complete data on blood pressure at baseline.

285,213 dementia-free UK Biobank participants were enrolled between 2006 and 2010. Over a median follow-up of 13.8 years, 1887 dementia cases were documented. Current shift workers had significantly higher dementia risk than non-shift workers. This excess risk was eliminated in shift workers with 8 h of sleep.

Study aimed to explore association of five early life factors with incidence of depression and anxiety in adults aged 40-69 years. We used data from the UK biobank, 5,02,394 participants aged 40 to 69 years were recruited between 2006 and 2010. Increased risk of depression was found to be significantly associated with non-breastfeeding, maternal smoking around birth, birth weight, being born in a multiple birth, and adoption.

Less childhood education is a potentially modifiable risk factor for developing incident dementia. It is not known if education in later life is protective. We sought to add to previous work by testing the association between adult education and brain volume as well as exploring the impact of continuing adult education versus intermittent participation.

Primary diabetes care and diabetic retinopathy (DR) screening persist as major public health challenges due to a shortage of trained primary care physicians. We developed an integrated image-language system (DeepDR-LLM) combining a large language model (LLM module) and image-based deep learning. The LLM module demonstrated comparable performance to PCPs and endocrinology residents.

Cardiometabolic diseases (CMDs) including type 2 diabetes, heart disease, and stroke have been linked to a higher risk of dementia. We examined whether high levels of cognitive reserve (CR) can attenuate the increased dementia risk.

Alpha-1 antitrypsin deficiency is an inherited disorder caused by AAT mutations. We analysed the association between alcohol intake and liver-related parameters in individuals with the heterozygous/homozygous Pi*Z AAT variant. In both cohorts, no/low alcohol intake was reported by >80% of individuals, while harmful consumption was rare (~1%).

Study aims to construct an atlas on known and emerging factors for hypertension through comprehensive epidemiological and genetic analyses. This study included 214,957 UK Biobank participants, hypertension-free at baseline. In our ExWAS analyses, 964 significant exposome variables were replicated.

Retinal structures offer a unique opportunity to assess brain disorders. Their relationship to brain structure and function is not well understood. We conducted a systematic cross-organ genetic architecture analysis of eye-brain connections.

A total of 210,832 participants from the UK Biobank cohort were included in this prospective cohort study. Increased absolute sugar intake was significantly associated with a higher risk of all-cause dementia. Explorative mediation analyses were conducted to explore underlying mechanisms.

Muscle fiber atrophy is considered a major feature of sarcopenia. The greater muscle fiber cross-sectional area (CSA) is associated with greater skeletal muscle mass and strength. Fifty-seven single-nucleotide polymorphisms (SNPs) were identified as having an association with muscle fiber size.

Low-grade inflammation (LGI) mainly acted as the mediator of the association of obesity and inflammatory diet with numerous chronic diseases, including neuropsychiatric diseases. The evidence about the effect of LGI on brain structure is limited but important, especially in the context of accelerating aging.

Mothers exhibit widely distributed higher gray matter density. No brain changes were observed in fathers. Parents reported a higher sense of life's meaning compared to childless counterparts. Gray matter changes did not mediate the relationship between motherhood and well-being.

Study was conducted with 357,554 UK Biobank participants. CRMM was defined as coexistence of two or three cardio-renal-metabolic diseases. Smoking status, diet, and social connection played pivotal roles in specific disease transitions. A healthy lifestyle may have a protective effect throughout the longitudinal progression of CRMM.

The associations between sugary beverages and genetic predisposition to depression risk remain unclear. We used data from the UK Biobank of 180 599 individuals aged 39-72 years who were depression-free at baseline. Higher consumption of SSBs and ASBs was associated with an increased risk of depression. In contrast, moderate consumption of NJs was inversely associated with a lower risk.

Metabolic dysfunction-associated fatty liver disease (MAFLD) is a significant health problem. Dietary intervention plays an important role in patients with MAFLD.

Study looked at associations of individual and area-level socioeconomic status (SES) with incident cardiovascular diseases (CVD) alone, cancer alone, and comorbid CVD and cancer. We used the American Heart Association's Life's Simple 7 (smoking, body weight, physical activity, diet, blood pressure, blood glucose, and total cholesterol) to calculate the cardiovascular health score.

Endometrial cancer (EC) is one of the gynecologic malignancy cancer with increasing incidence and mortality rates. This study explores the associations between biological age accelerations (BAA) and risk of incident EC.

Among 84,421 UK Biobank participants (mean age: 62 years) who were free of diabetes at the time of providing accelerometer data in 2013-2015. There were 2,058 incident diabetes cases over 622,080 person-years of follow-up. Irregular sleep duration was associated with higher diabetes risk, particularly in individuals with a lower diabetes PRS and longer sleep duration.

The role of serum branched-chain amino acids (BCAAs) in long-term liver cirrhosis complication events remains unclear. We aimed to evaluate the associations between serum BCAAs and the risk of liver-related events. Serum total BCAA and isoleucine concentrations might reduce the risk. by raising therisk of (type 2 diabetes mellitus) T2DM.

Chronic respiratory diseases (CRDs) are among the top three causes of human mortality. Relationship between modifiable environmental risk factor of noise and risk of mortality in CRDs is unclear. We investigated the longitudinal association between environmental noise exposure and cause-specific mortality in individuals with CRDs.

Proton pump inhibitors (PPIs) have raised wide concerns. The association of PPIs with influenza is unexplored, while that with pneumonia or COVID-19 remains controversial. The current study included 160,923 eligible participants at baseline who completed questionnaires on medication use.

Proposed method generalizes Steiger's method from using a single SNP to multiple SNPs as IVs. It is especially useful in transcriptome-wide association studies (TWASs) with typically small sample sizes for gene expression (or another molecular trait) data. It can be applied to GWAS summary data with a reference panel.

Genome-Wide Association Studies (GWAS) over-represent European ancestries, neglecting all other ancestry groups and low-income nations. polygenic risk scores (PRS) more accurately predict complex traits in Europeans than African Ancestries groups.

CSF1R -related disorder is a devastating neurodegenerative disorder. There is evidence that it is significantly underdiagnosed or misdiagnosed. We leveraged the large data set of the UK Biobank to determine the prevalence of mutations in the UK population and identify clinical phenotypes.

Study aimed to explore the associations of 30 dietary micronutrients intakes with risk of alcoholic liver disease (ALD) Case-control study was conducted within the UK Biobank cohort, with 231 incident ALD cases and 1386 controls. Creatinine (enzymatic) in urine, aspartate aminotransferase, and insulin-like growth factor 1 were the top 3 biomarkers with the highest number of significant mediation effects.

Genome-wide association studies have identified more than 200 risk loci associated with colorectal cancer. The functional mechanism of this region has not been fully elucidated. Here we employed an RNA interfering-based on-chip approach to screen for the genes essential for cell proliferation in the CRC risk locus 19q13.2. We found that RPS19 exhibited the most significant effect among the identified genes.

Previous studies have shown that inflammatory bowel disease (IBD) is associated with osteoporosis (OP) and bone mineral density (BMD) This study wanted to explore the genetic and causal relationship between IBD and OP. The study indicates that IBD may increase the risk of OP.

Study included 298,984 UK Biobank participants without cardiometabolic diseases (CMDs) at baseline. Compared to former smokers, current smokers had higher risk at all transitions, with hazard ratio (95% confidence interval) = 1.59 (1.55 &#8764; 1.63)

Study included 222 824 participants free from CVD and CKD at baseline from the UK Biobank. During a mean follow-up of 14.1 years, 24 088 incident CVD events, 8605 CKD events and 15 813 deaths were documented. Elevated KB levels were associated with an increased risk of all-cause mortality across the glycaemic spectrum.

High levels of circulating IGF-1, HbA1c, and alanine aminotransferase were associated with lower ovarian cancer risk. These results suggest metabolism of glucose/amino acid and insulin/IGF-1 signaling pathway may be contributing to ovarian carcinogenesis.

Plasma low-density lipoprotein (LDL)-cholesterol is positively associated with coronary artery disease risk. Biliary cholesterol promotes gallstone formation. Different plasma LDL-cholesterol lowering pathways may have distinct effects on biliary cholesterol.

The coronavirus disease 2019 (COVID-19) pandemic has resulted in more than 692 million cases worldwide and nearly 7 million deaths (August 2023) EFCAB4B is a gene that encodes for two proteins (CRACR2A and Rab46) that play important roles in endothelial and T-cell secretion.

Group 1 show continuously decreasing GMV associated with higher neurocognitive performances than the other two groups during adolescence. Group 2 exhibit a slower rate of GMV decrease and lower neuroc cognitive performances compared with Group 1, which was associated with epigenetic differences and greater environmental burden. Using the UK Biobank, we show these differences may be attenuated in mid-to-late adulthood.

Exome sequencing of 40 IMDs in 350,770 UK Biobank participants identified 162 unique genes in 35 IMDs, among which 124 were novel genes. 91 genes exerted significant effects on longitudinal outcomes. Mendelian randomization identified five causal genes, of which four were approved drug targets.

Dyslipidemia is a well-known risk factor for cardiovascular disease, the leading cause of mortality worldwide. Although habitual intake of fish oil is associated with cardioprotective effects through triglyceride reduction, the interactions ofFish oil with the genetic predisposition to dysregulated lipids remain elusive.

Sleep quality was negatively correlated with childhood trauma, anxiety symptoms, and self-harm attempt. Multiple avenues of intervention, such as the provision of professional psychological interventions and timely monitoring, should be used to improve sleep quality and mental health.

Postoperative complications affect up to 15% of surgical patients. Combining deep neural networks and genomics with the already established clinical predictors may hold promise for improvement. Models were generated for atrial fibrillation, venous thromboembolism and pneumonia.

Lynch syndrome (LS) is an inherited cancer predisposition syndrome caused by genetic variants affecting DNA mismatch repair (MMR) genes. 830 carriers of pathogenic or likely pathogenic ( path_MMR ) MMR gene variants were identified in 454 756 UK Biobank (UKB) participants using whole-exome sequence. Nelson-Aalen survival analysis was used to estimate cumulative incidence of colorectal, endometrial and breast cancer (BC)

Both adverse childhood experiences (ACEs) and lifestyle factors have been associated with risk of cardiovascular diseases (CVDs) in later life. We aimed to determine whether and to what extent adopting to a healthy lifestyle in adulthood can offset the risk of CVDs in individuals according to their ACEs.

Sodium intake reduction is crucial for cardiovascular health, but its lasting impact on dementia remains unclear. We included 458,577 UK Biobank participants without dementia at baseline. Over a mean follow-up of 13.6 years, 7886 (1.7%) developed all-cause dementia.

Irritable bowel syndrome (IBS) is often comorbid with somatic pain and psychological disorders. Dysregulated signaling of brain-derived neurotrophic factor (BDNF) and its receptor, tropomyosin-related kinase B (TrkB), has been implicated in somatic-psychological symptoms in individuals with IBS. We investigated the association of 10 single-nucleotide polymorphisms (SNPs) in the regulatory 3' untranslated region of TrkB.

 Ideal cardiovascular health (CVH) has been associated with reduced cardiovascular disease risk and mortality. In this prospective cohort study, we investigated the relationship between CVH and subsequent arrhythmias risk, including atrial fibrillation/flutter.

Much of disease information is collected as time-to-event outcomes in interval-censored form. Conventional tools for genetic association analysis are often not available for this type of data. The proposed tests are applied to the UK Biobank to search for genes associated with fracture risk while accounting for death as a competing outcome.

Research on the association between dietary adherence and cancer risk is limited. Here we show significant negative associations of MedDiet and MINDDiet adherence with overall cancer risk. These associations remain robust across 14 and 13 specific cancers, respectively.

Study used data from UK Biobank aged 37 to 73 years. Light physical activity (LPA), moderate-to-vigorous activity (MVPA), sleep duration, and total sedentary behavior (TSB) were measured by accelerometers. Longer SSB time (HR = 1.18, 95%CI: 1.06-1.32) could increase depression risk. Replacing 1h/day TSB, SSB, and LSB with MVPA brought greatest risk reductions.

The link between nonalcoholic fatty liver disease and type 2 diabetes has not been fully established. Hepatic steatosis mediated approximately 69.514% of the total effect between obesity and follow-up T2D. Findings contribute to determining the sequential relationship between NAFLD and T 2D in the causal pathway.

Vitamin D users have a slightly higher prevalence of hypercalcemia, possibly due to co-supplementation with calcium, but without a higher atherosclerosis prevalence or risk of kidney stones. High 25(OH)D levels in routine care were not associated with any adverse outcome.

Little is known about the genetic background of metabolic dysfunction-associated steatotic liver disease (MASLD) Compared to non-alcoholic fatty liver disease, MASLD presents significantly distinct diagnostic criteria, and epidemiological and clinical features. Autosomal genetic variants associated with NAFLD were compared with the MASLD GWAS results.

Chronic pain is associated with development of cardiovascular disease. We analysed data from participants enrolled in the UK Biobank study. The number of chronic pain sites was directly related to increased arterial stiffness index.

Tobacco smoking is a major risk factor for various diseases worldwide. Few studies have examined the impact of smoking cessation on the likelihood of common pancreatic exocrine diseases. Study sought to determine whether smoking cessation would reduce pancreatitis and PC morbidity.

This study utilized UK Biobank data from 144 286 participants and employed whole-genome sequencing (WGS) data and time-to-event data over a 12-year follow-up period. Following genotype quality control, 6 319 822 single nucleotide polymorphisms underwent analysis, revealing 31 significant variant-level associations. Among these, 29 were novel - 15 in Fibrillin-2 ( FBN2 ) and 4 in Junctophilin-2.

Early age at menarche (AAM) has been associated with a higher risk of carotid artery intima-media thickness (cIMT) A better understanding of the relationship between AAM, modifiable cardiometabolic risk factors and subclinical atherosclerosis may contribute to improved primary prevention and cardiovascular disease treatment.

Alzheimer's disease (AD) exhibits considerable phenotypic heterogeneity, suggesting the potential existence of subtypes. AD is under substantial genetic influence, thus identifying systematic variation in genetic risk may provide insights into disease origins. We performed principal component analysis (PCA) on AD-associated variants in the UK Biobank.

High blood basophil level is associated with increased odds of endometriosis. This association was first discovered in the ENDOX cohort (basophils >0.04 x10^9/L: OR 1.65 [95%CI:1.06-2.57], P trend = 0.025) and replicated in the UKBB dataset.

Study was based on UK Biobank participants without depression/anxiety recruited between 2006 and 2010. Depression and anxiety outcomes were assessed by diagnostic interviews and nondiagnostic scales. Compared with non-statin users, statin use was associated with reduced risk of depression and anxiety.

Cardiac digital twins (CDTs) have the potential to offer individualized evaluation of cardiac function in a non-invasive manner. CDTs could be a promising approach for personalized diagnosis and treatment planning of myocardial infarction (MI) In this work, we investigate the feasibility of inferring myocardials from the electrocardiogram (ECG) within a CDT platform.

Study aimed to investigate the relationships of lipids and their fractions with CKD in patients with T2D. The 10-year predicted probabilities of CKD were evaluated via integrating MR and Cox models. Higher GRS of apolipoprotein B was associated with an increased CKD risk.

Genetic variations in single nucleotide polymorphisms (SNPs) within oxytocin pathway genes have been linked to social behavior and neurodevelopmental conditions. The neurobiological mechanisms underlying these associations remain elusive. Empirical evidence has linked the GG genotype at OXT rs4813627 with a behavioral tendency of insensitivity to others.

Lung function parameters included forced expiratory volume in 1 second (FEV1) and forced vital capacity (FVC) 340, 253 participants without prior liver diseases were included from the UK Biobank. During a media follow-up duration of 9.3 years, 7335 cases of non-alcoholic fatty liver disease (NAFLD) were documented. There was an inverse association of FEV1 and FVC with the presence of NAFLD.

Study aimed to evaluate the predictive performance of 7 established cardiovascular risk scores in cancer survivors from the UK Biobank. Participants were propensity matched on age, sex, deprivation, health behaviors, family history, and metabolic conditions. Incident cardiovascular events were tracked through health record linkage.

Vision and eye conditions are associated with increased risk for Alzheimer disease and related dementias (ADRDs) If causal, vision would be an important modifiable risk factor with viable population-level interventions. A cohort and MR study of UK Biobank participants found that cataracts were associated with an increased risk of dementia, especially vascular dementia.

Venous thromboembolism (VTE) is common among older individuals, but provoking factors are not identified in many cases. Clonal hematopoiesis of indeterminate potential (CHIP) is a precursor state to myeloid malignancies and may similarly predispose to VTE. JAK2 mutations were highly associated with both prevalent and incident VTE risk with odds ratio of 6.58 (95% CI 2.65-16.29)

Previous research on the association between serum albumin (ALB) and venous thromboembolism (VTE) has produced inconclusive results. It is still unknown whether albumin and genetic factors jointly contributed to the incidence of VTE. The present investigation was an analysis of prospectively collected data from UK Biobank.

Study aimed to investigate the association between peripheral inflammatory indicators and the risk of OA using data from the UK Biobank. Over a mean follow-up period of 12.7 years, a total of 49,509 OA events were identified. CRP, NLR, PLR, and SII were associated with an increased risk.

Weekend catch-up sleep was defined as a longer average sleep duration on weekends compared to weekdays. In multivariable-adjusted models, weekend catch- up sleep was not associated with mortality or CVD incidence. These findings do not align with previous evidence suggesting that extending sleep over the weekend may offer protective health benefits.

This study proposes the use of semiparametric log-normal shared frailty models to ana- lyze time-to-event data for individuals with similar features referred to as clusters. The results suggest the presence of frailty within the clusters and indicate cluster time dependence in the study population.

Multiorgan abnormalities were more common in individuals with type 2 diabetes (94%) than in age- and BMI-matched healthy individuals or healthy individuals with normal weight. Obesity was most closely associated with advanced liver disease, renal and visceral steatosis, and multiorgan abnormality. Pharmacological therapies with proven cardiorenal protection improved liver and vascular health unlike conventional glucose-lowering treatments.

Heart failure (HF) as a cardiovascular disease subtype is a growing global pandemic with high morbidity and mortality. Consumption of fried foods is highly prevalent in the Western dietary pattern. Western diet has been unfavorably linked with high risk of developing cardiovascular diseases.

Previous research has suggested that pathogen infections may serve as potential contributors to dementia. The study aimed to evaluate whether pathogen exposure heightens the risk of dementia. Out of the 8,144 participants, 107 eventually developed dementia, while 55 participants were diagnosed with Alzheimer's disease (AD) The highest quartile of EBV VCA p18 had a higher risk of AD compared lower quartile.

Study aimed to explore the time-varying impact of COVID-19 on acute kidney disorders, including acute kidney injury and other acute kidney diseases. 10,121 participants were matched with up to 3 historically unexposed controls by age, sex, Townsend deprivation index, and the status of hospitalization or receiving critical care.

Previous research suggests physical activity attenuates grey and white matter loss. However, there appears to be individual variability in this effect. Understanding factors that can influence the relationship between physical activity and brain volume may enable prediction of individual response.

Fifty percent of diffuse large B cell lymphoma (DLBCL) cases lack cell-surface expression of the class I major histocompatibility complex (MHC-I), thus escaping recognition by cytotoxic T cells. Loss of HLA-I, but not MHC-II, is preferentially restricted to DLBCL.

Genome-wide association study (GWAS) to identify genetic variants for stroke in an Indian population. 8 teaching hospitals in India recruited 4,088 participants, including 1,609 stroke cases. Imputed genetic variants were tested for association with stroke subtypes using single-marker and gene-based tests.

Blood pressure-lowering medications, antiplatelet drugs and statins are often prescribed to asymptomatic patients with white matter hyperintensities (WMH) A clinical trial is needed, but potential trial participants would be excluded if they already had another indication to take the medication. We used data from the UK Biobank study to determine what proportion of people with WMH were not taking these drugs.

Using longitudinal structural MRI data (4,422 observations), we tested the hypothesis that higher education translates into slower rates of brain aging. Cross-sectionally, education was modestly associated with regional cortical volume. Despite marked mean atrophy in the cortex and hippocampus, education did not influence rates of change.

QDECR is a flexible and extensible R package for group-level statistical analysis of cortical morphology. QDECR was written with large population-based epidemiological studies in mind and was designed to utilize the extensive modeling options in R.

Both genetic and lifestyle factors play an etiologic role in colorectal cancer (CRC) The risk reduction was more apparent among those with high PRS (HRhealthy vs. unhealthy HLS1) than those with low PRS.

Diabetic retinopathy (DR) is a common consequence in type 2 diabetes (T2D) and a leading cause of blindness in working-age adults. Here, we examined the polygenic architecture underlying DR by deriving and assessing a genome-wide polygenic risk score (PRS) for DR. We observed that PRS was significantly associated with DR.

New method to test for differences in allele frequency between cases of two disorders. Simulations and analytical computations confirm that CC-GWAS is well powered with effective control of type I error.

Altered expression of the complement component C4A gene is a known risk factor for schizophrenia. Altered C 4A expression in the brain may be relevant for cognitive and behavioral traits. We obtained genetic information and performance measures on seven cognitive tasks.

Genome-wide association studies have identified multiple genomic regions associated with anorexia nervosa. No genome-wide studies of other eating disorders, such as bulimia nervosa and binge-eating disorder, have been performed. We aimed to identify traits that are genetically associated with binge-type eating disorders.

We use the genomic relationship (&#960;$$\pi$$) among 417,060 individuals to investigate the phenotypic covariance between pairs of individuals for 32 traits. We find linear relationships that agree with the SNP-based heritability in unrelated pairs. We also examine the effect of assortative mating on heritability estimates.

Dercum's disease (DD) is a loose connective (adipose) tissue disease characterized by painful lipomas. In the USA, the Orphan Drug Act of 1983 defines a rare disease as affecting under 200,000 individuals. The prevalence of DD has not been systematically assessed previously.

Mendelian randomisation uses genetic variants as instrumental variables to investigate causation. Strong evidence reduced forced vital capacity (FVC) causes increased risk of coronary artery disease (OR 1.32, 95% CI 1.19-1.46) There is weak evidence that reduced lung function increases risk of ischaemic stroke. FVC could be taken into consideration when assessing cardiovascular risk.

Adiposity now accounts for more deaths in England and Scotland than smoking among people in middle- and old-age. National strategies to address adiposity should be a public health priority.

American College of Cardiology/American Heart Association blood pressure (BP) guidelines lowered the hypertension threshold from a SBP/DBP level of at least 140/90 mmHg to at least 130/80mmHg. The cardiovascular impact of isolated systolic hypertension (ISH) and isolated diastolic hypertension(IDH) under the new definition remains unclear.

Previous research points to the heritability of risk-taking behaviour. However, evidence on how genetic dispositions are translated into risky behaviour is scarce. Here, we report a genetically informed neuroimaging study of real-world risky behaviour across the domains of drinking, smoking, driving and sexual behaviour.

Cystic fibrosis (CF) carriers carrying one defective copy of a CFTR germline mutation are common in the general population. A recent study reported associations of CF carriers with risk for cancers of digestive organs and pancreatic cancer. In the current study, we assessed associations ofCFTR F508del carriers with the risk for 54 types of cancers.

Baseline UK Biobank data (2006-10) for England were linked to SARS-CoV-2 test results. Included participants were employed or self-employed at baseline, alive and aged. Of 120 075 participants, 271 had severe COVID-19. Compared with white non-essential workers, non-white non- essential workers had a higher risk.

There has been uncertainty about the safety or benefit of angiotensin-converting enzyme (ACE) inhibitors during the COVID-19 pandemic. We used Mendelian randomization using genetic determinants of serum-ACE levels to test whether decreased ACE levels increase susceptibility to SARS-CoV-2 infection.

Coeliac disease arises in genetically susceptible individuals, in particular in carriers of HLA-DQ2/DQ8 risk alleles and is associated with various comorbidities. We found 225 ICD-10 codes significantly associated with coeliac Disease. During the median follow-up of 10.7 years, coeliak disease individuals (n = 2482) had higher overall mortality.

We investigated independent associations between telomere length and risk of fracture and arthroplasty in UK Biobank participants. We studied 59,500 women and 51,895 men, mean +/- standard deviation (SD) age 56.4 +/- 8.0 years. During follow-up there were 5619 fractures; 5285 hip and 4261 knee arthro plasties.

Rheumatoid arthritis (RA) and low bone mineral density (BMD), an indicator of osteoporosis (OP), appear epidemiologically associated. Shared genetic factors may explain this association. This study aimed to investigate the presence of pleiotropy to clarify the potential genetic association between RA and OP.

The contribution of shape changes to hip osteoarthritis (HOA) remains unclear. In the present study, we used statistical shape modeling (SSM) to evaluate relationships between hip shape and HOA of different severities using UK Biobank DXA images.

There is evidence that long-term environmental exposure to particulate air pollution is associated with type-2 diabetes mellitus (T2DM) and dementia. There are many occupations that may expose workers to airborne particles. Some exposures in the workplace are very similar to environmental particulate pollution. The results of the present study do not provide clear evidence of an association between occupational exposure and T2DM or dementia.

There is limited understanding of the genetic aetiology of obstructive sleep apnoea (OSA) We aimed to identify genetic loci associated with OSA risk, and to test if OSA and its comorbidities share a common genetic background. We conducted the first large-scale genome-wide association study of OSA using the FinnGen study.

Reversible infantile respiratory chain deficiency (RIRCD) is a rare mitochondrial myopathy leading to severe metabolic disturbances in infants, which recover spontaneously after 6-months of age. RIRCD is associated with the homoplasmic m.14674T>C mitochondrial DNA mutation. Only 1/100 carriers develop the disease.

Dietary fiber intake may relate to bone health. The associations of dietary fiber intake with estimated BMD were assessed. Participants with lower genetically determined propionate production may benefit more from taking more dietary fiber.

Loss of NEMP1 homologs in Drosophila, Caenorhabditis elegans, zebrafish, and mice leads to sterility or early loss of fertility. Loss of Nemp leads to nuclear shaping defects, most prominently in the germ line.

The role of obesity and overweight in occurrence of COVID-19 is unknown. We conducted a large-scale general population study using data from a community-dwelling sample in England. There was an upward linear trend in the likelihood of CO VID-19 hospitalization with increasing BMI. Elevated risk was apparent even at modest weight gain.

Anti-TNF exposure has been linked to demyelination events. We conducted a case-control study to describe the clinical features of demyalination events following anti- TNF exposure. We compared genetic risk scores [GRS], calculated using carriage of 43 susceptibility loci for MS, in 48 cases.

Genomes from Neanderthals, Denisovans, and ancient humans have revealed protein-coding variants that may hold clues to how our species evolved over the last &#8764;600,000 years. In this study, we identify such variants in the human-specific NOTCH2NL gene family.

Caffeine, alcohol, nicotine and cannabis are commonly used psychoactive substances. While the use of these substances has been previously shown to be genetically correlated, causality between these substance use traits remains unclear. We aimed to revisit the genetic relationships among different measures of SU.

We identify genetic loci associated with phenotypic variability in thalamus volume and cortical thickness. The variance-controlling loci involved genes with a documented role in brain and mental health and were not associated with the mean anatomical volumes.

Risk variants identified so far for colorectal cancer explain only a small proportion of familial risk of this cancer, particularly in Asians. We performed a genome-wide association study (GWAS) in East Asians. Of the remaining 59 variants, 12 showed an association at P   P  -8. We identified three novel risk loci and two highly suggestive loci.

Blood lipids are causally involved in the pathogenesis of atherosclerosis, but their role in cerebral small vessel disease remains largely elusive. We explored associations of genetic determinants of blood lipid levels, lipoprotein particle components, and targets for lipid-modifying drugs. Genetic predisposition to higher HDL-C levels was associated with lower risk of small vessel stroke.

New evidence suggests that handgrip strength is associated with better cognitive performance in people with major depressive disorder (MDD) The underlying processes are unclear, although hippocampal volume (HCV) reductions and white matter hyperintensities (WMHs) have been implicated. We investigated associations between grip strength and various brain region volumes and WMHs in MDD and healthy controls.

Cell type-specific binding of transcription factors (TF) is critical to gene regulation. Assessing contribution of genetic variation in TF-binding sites to disease heritability is challenging. We investigate approaches to annotate TF binding, including directly measured chromatin data and sequence-based predictions.

Breakfast has been determined to exhibit the most heritable meal timing. Little is known about the contribution of genetic variation to food timing. Breakfast timing and skipping are not routinely measured in large cohort studies.

There are known risk factors associated with the development of heart failure (HF) It is not fully understood whether these differ by sex. Women with type 1 diabetes, type 2 diabetes, hypertension, hypercholesterolaemia, low levels of physical activity and fitness, low strength, high levels of TV viewing, sleep duration were at higher risk of HF incidence.

Study aimed to identify causal blood biomarkers linking favorable adiposity with type 2 diabetes risk for use in cardiometabolic risk assessments. Only insulin-like growth factor-binding protein (IGFBP)-3 concentration was associated with the PRS, where a 1 unit increase in PRS predicted a 0.28-SD decrease in IGFBP-3.

 Observational epidemiological studies have found an association between schizophrenia and breast cancer, but it is not known if the relationship is a causal one. We used summary statistics from very large genome-wide association studies of schizophrenia (n = 40675 cases and 64643 controls) and breast Cancer. We found that there is a small but significant genetic correlation (rG) between the 2 disorders, indicating shared genetic risk factors.

A polygenic risk score of 90 single nucleotide polymorphisms previously associated with stroke was constructed at P -5. Adherence to a healthy lifestyle was determined on the basis of four factors: non-smoker, healthy diet, body mass index  2 , and regular physical exercise.

Most expression quantitative trait locus (eQTL) studies to date have been performed in heterogeneous tissues as opposed to specific cell types. Melanocyte eQTLs are enriched in cis -regulatory signatures found in melanocytes as well as in melanoma-associated variants identified through genome-wide association studies.

Erectile dysfunction affects millions of men worldwide. Twin studies support the role of genetic risk factors underlying erectile dysfunction, but no specific genetic variants have been identified. In the discovery cohort, we identified a single locus (rs17185536-T) on chromosome 6 near the single-minded family basic helix-loop-helix transcription factor 1 ( SIM1 ) gene.

Type 2 diabetes (T2D) is a heterogeneous disease for which disease-causing pathways are incompletely understood. Unlike other biomarkers, germline genetic markers do not change with disease progression or treatment. In an effort to identify mechanistic pathways driven by established T2D genetic loci, we applied Bayesian nonnegative matrix factorization (bNMF) clustering.

 serum estradiol (E2) is more strongly associated with bone mineral density (BMD) than serum testosterone (T) Both E2 and T associate with fracture risk in men. A 1 SD (or 9.6 pg/mL) genetically instrumented decrease in serum E2 levels was associated with a 0.38 SD decrease in eBMD (P value: 9.7 Ã— 10-74)

Extreme longevity in humans has a strong genetic component, but whether this involves genetic variation in the same longevity pathways as found in model organisms is unclear. Using whole-exome sequences of a large cohort of Ashkenazi Jewish centenarians, we found most longevity-associated rare coding variants converge upon insulin/insulin-like growth factor 1 signaling and AMP-activating protein kinase signaling.

SARS-CoV-2 has resulted in a global pandemic with a rapidly developing global health and economic crisis. Variations in the disease have been observed and have been associated with the genomic sequence of either the human host or the pathogen.

The study examined the association between liver function-related indicators and gallstone disease (GSD) risk. The results were consistent when stratified by the study design, geographic background, and study quality. This study suggests liver function indicators were associated with GSD risk.

A total of 388,900 participants from the United Kingdom Biobank from 2006 to 2010 were included. For each standard deviation increase in the TyG index, TyG-BMI, TG/HDL-C, and METS-IR, the risk of EAC increased by Hazard ratios.

Fatty acid (FA) metabolism plays an important role in the development of nonalcoholic fatty liver disease (NAFLD) However, data on the relation of circulating FAs with NAFLD risk are limited. This study aimed to assess the associations between specific circulating F as and severe NA FLD risk among the general population. 116,223 participants without NAFLd and other liver diseases from the UK Biobank, were enrolled between 2006 and 2010.

Evidence on the association between cardiovascular health (CVH) and breast cancer is limited. The present study aimed to assess the association of CVH, defined by Life's Essential 8 (LE8), and genetic risk with breast cancer incidence and mortality among premenopausal and postmenopausal women. High LE8 score was associated with 22% lower risk of breast cancer.

Genome-wide association study (GWAS) was performed on two noninvasive definitions of hepatic fat content: MRI-PDFF and fatty liver index (FLI) Heritability, genetic overlap, and similarity between hepaticfat content phenotypes were analyzed. Novel MRI- PDFF genetic signals (CREB3L1 and GCM1) were replicated in the FLI GWAS.

Study aimed to investigate the hypothesis that breastfeeding reduces the risk of lung cancer-related death. Over a median follow-up duration of 11.8 years, encompassing a total of 501 859 participants, breastfeeding was found to reduce the risk. The influence of maternal smoking and breastfeeding was significant at a high genetic risk level.

A total of 448,574 participants enrolled in the UK Biobank study were included. Circulating C-reactive protein(CRP), white blood cell count(WBC), platelet count(Plt), and neutrophil/lymphocyte ratio(NLR) were measured. Dietary intake information was documented through 24-hour dietary recalls.

Sedentary behavior (SB), moderate-to-vigorous physical activity (MVPA), and white matter hyperintensity (WMH) volumes are associated with risk of neurodegenerative disease in middle-aged to older adults. Both MVPA and SB were associated with WMH volumes.

Regular mobile phone use was defined as at least 1 call per week. Weekly mobile phone usage time was self-reported as the average time of calls per week over the previous 3 months. In a median follow-up period of 12.3 years, 56,181 individuals developed incident CVD. Compared with nonregular mobile phone users, regular phone users had a significantly higher risk of CVD and increased CIMT.

Mendelian randomization (MVMR) estimates the direct effects of multiple exposures on an outcome. This study tackles the issue of highly correlated exposures commonly observed in metabolomic data. We identified two independent signal clusters for AD: glutamine and lipids, with posterior inclusion probabilities of 95.0% and 81.5%.

Intraocular pressure (IOP) is closely correlated with blood pressure (BP) Each 10-mmHg increase in diastolic BP was linked to a 0.13 ml larger white matter hyperintensity (WMH) Associations between IOP and brain volumes were more pronounced in younger individuals or those without hypertension.

Myocardial strain using cardiac magnetic resonance (CMR) is a sensitive marker for predicting adverse outcomes in many cardiac disease states. The prognostic value in the general population has not been studied conclusively. 45,700 participants were included in the study (average age 65 +/- 8 years)

Study used data from the UK Biobank, a middle-aged and elderly cohort recruited in 2006-2010. Depression was associated with a higher prevalence of modifiable risk factors. These risk factors were associated with increased mortality in the depression subsample and explained most of the excess mortality risk associated with depression.

We investigated the genetic architecture of obesity by clustering the Japanese and British populations with obesity using obesity-related factors. In Step-1, we conducted a genome-wide association study (GWAS) with body mass index (BMI) as the outcome. In step-2, we assigned participants with obesity to five clusters based on obesity- related factors.

Two independent datasets (UK Biobank and our tertiary academic institution) of good-quality retinal photographs derived from subjects with AD and controls were used to build two deep learning models. The models' performance to distinguish AD from non-AD was determined using mean accuracy, sensitivity, specificity and receiving operating curves. The self-supervised ADRET model had superior accuracy when compared with ADVAS.

Previous observational studies have investigated the association between coffee consumption and single cardiometabolic disease. This study aimed to further investigate the association of coffee consumption with the onset and progression of cardiometric multimorbidity (CMM) Coffee consumption was associated with lower risk for almost all transition phases of CMM development and consistent findings were observed with unsweetened coffee.

Study used data from the UK Biobank, a population-based cohort. Participants were current drinkers aged 60 years or older. Data were analyzed from September 2023 to May 2024. Wine preference and drinking with meals showed small protective associations with mortality, especially from cancer.

Mendelian randomization method was used to investigate the causal association between immune cell and different types of sepsis. CD16 on CD14 - CD16 + ; monocyte had horizontal pleiotropy in seps isis. There were five immunophenotypes that had reverse causal associations with the types associated with sepsi.

 periodontal disease is the sixth most common disease worldwide. It may be a contributory risk factor for cardiovascular disease (CVD) This study used non-invasive cardiac imaging, longitudinal and genetic data to characterize the association.

Previous studies on alcohol consumption and incident gout have mostly included men or combined both sexes. This prospective cohort study included 401 128 participants in the UK Biobank aged 37 to 73 years. Current drinkers showed a higher risk of gout than never drinkers among men. Beer or cider showed the strongest association per 1 pint per day.

Inflammation has been proposed as a mechanism linking cardiometabolic diseases (CMDs) to increased risk of dementia. However, whether an anti-inflammatory diet can support brain and cognitive health among people with CMDs is unclear. The UK Biobank is an ongoing community-based cohort study with baseline assessments conducted between March 13, 2006, and October 1, 2010.

Hormone therapy (HT) is associated with health outcomes in postmenopausal women. This population-based, retrospective cohort study included women registered in the UK Biobank. Ever use of HT was associated with a smaller biological aging discrepancy than never use ofHT. The association between HT and a smaller aging discrepancy was more evident in women with low SES.

Transcriptome-wide association study (TWAS) aims to identify trait-associated genes regulated by significant variants. Traditional approaches still face two main challenges: the lack of methods that can guarantee finite-sample false discovery rate (FDR) control. We propose a powerful knockoff inference method termed TWAS-GKF to identify candidate trait- associated genes.

The presence of horizontal pleiotropy in Mendelian randomization (MR) analysis has long been a concern due to its potential to induce substantial bias. In recent years, many robust MR methods have been proposed to address this. Here, we propose a novel two-stage framework called CMR, which integrates a conditional analysis of multiple genetic variants. Extensive simulation studies showcased the superior performance of the proposed CMR framework.

We examined associations between genetic instruments for smoking initiation, smoking heaviness and lifetime smoking and these phenotypes. We found evidence that smoking-related genetic instruments were associated with phenotypes not plausibly caused by smoking. This may reflect horizontal pleiotropy in these genetic risk scores.

Opioid use impacts metabolic homeostasis, although mechanisms remain elusive. We explore the OPRD1 gene (encoding delta opioid receptor, DOP) to understand its impact on type 2 diabetes. Loss-of-function variants are associated with higher adiposity and lower hyperglycemia risk. Findings align with studies of opium addicts.

Activation of the NLRP3 inflammasome has been implicated in Parkinson's disease (PD) Clinical trials targeting the NL RP3 infammasome in PD are ongoing. We analyzed common and rare variants in NLRP1 inflammaome-related genes in PD cohorts.

Common kidney stones are unlikely to be an independent and direct cause of CKD in the general population. Kidney stones did significantly associate with a higher urinary albumin-creatinine ratio. Conversely, CKD was associated with a lower risk of calcium kidney stones.

The comorbidity of Alzheimer's disease (AD) and age-related macular degeneration (AMD) has been established in clinical and genetic studies. There is growing interest in determining the shared environmental factors associated with both conditions.

A total of 373,330 participants from the UK Biobank without glaucoma at recruitment were included in this study. During a median follow-up of 13.1 (interquartile range: 12.3-13.9) years, 6,489 participants developed glau coma. After adjusting for confounding factors, loneliness and social isolation were associated with a higher risk of glauCOMa.

Mendelian randomization was applied to elucidate the causal role of serum lipids in AD. Only Proprotein Convertase Subtilisin/Kexin Type 9 (PCSK9) was significantly linked to a reduced AD risk. Beta nerve growth factor (b-NGF) might mediate approximately 12.8% of PCSK9's influence.

Social determinants of health (SDHs) are the primary drivers of preventable health inequities. Study aimed to estimate the associations of combined SDHs with life expectancy and future health risks among adults with type 2 diabetes from the UK and USA. In the UK Biobank, 3235 deaths and 2259 cancer cases were documented.

In 2020, the Lancet Commission identified 12 modifiable factors that increase population-level dementia risk. It is unclear if these risk factors co-occur among individuals in a clinically meaningful way. Using latent class analysis, we identified profiles of modifiable dementia risk factors in dementia-free adults aged 60-64 years.

Study included 396,600 participants without prior dementia and CKD from the UK Biobank. During a median follow-up of 12.5 years, new-onset CKD developed in 13,090 participants. Per 1 SD score increments in genetically predicted global cognitive function resulted in a significantly (7%) lower risk of CKD.

The association of residential environments with psoriasis risk was modified by genetic susceptibility. We observed joint effects of genetic risk and residential environments and an antagonistic additive interaction between blue spaces and genetic risk (P = 0.011) We observed that residing in natural environments and green areas increased the risk of Psoriasis.

Cardiometabolic continuum (CMC) is sequence of cardiovascular events that stem from gene-environmental interactions, unhealthy lifestyle influences, and metabolic diseases such as diabetes, and hypertension. We present a machine learning approach to model the CMC and investigate sex and population differences. Smoking habits and education had high importance and clear directionality for both sexes.

Osteoarthritis increased the likelihood of developing dementia, and had an association with regional brain atrophy. OA therapy lowered the risk of dementia in both medication group and surgery group.

The global burden of metabolic dysfunction-associated steatotic liver disease (MASLD) is growing, but its subsequent health consequences have not been thoroughly examined. A phenome-wide association study was conducted to map the associations of MASLD with 948 unique clinical outcomes.

We examined the association between hypnotic agents and cardiovascular outcomes in general individuals with insomnia. No significant association was detected between Z-meds and CHD, stroke, and cardiovascular mortality. Benzodiazepine use was significantly associated with the increased risk of CHD and HF.

Polyunsaturated fatty acids (PUFAs) have been implicated in potentially safeguarding against diabetic microvascular complication. However, the causal nature of these relationships remains ambiguous due to conflicting findings across studies. This research employs Mendelian randomization (MR) to assess the causal impact of PUFAs on diabeticMicrovascular complications.

Portability of trans-ancestral polygenic risk scores is often confounded by differences in linkage disequilibrium and genetic architecture between ancestries. Recent literature has shown that prioritizing GWAS SNPs with functional genomic evidence over strong association signals can improve model portability. We leveraged three RegulomeDB-derived functional regulatory annotations-SURF, TURf, and TLand.

Total joint arthroplasty (TJA) is an orthopedic procedure commonly used to treat damaged joints. Despite the efficacy of TJA, postoperative complications, including aseptic prosthesis loosening and infections, are common. The effects of individual genetic susceptibility and modifiable risk factors on these complications are unclear.

Urea cycle impairment and its relationship to obesity and inflammation remained elusive. We generated mice with hepatocyte-specific arginase 2 deletion (Arg2 LKO ) and revealed a mild compensated urea cycle defect. serum-based hallmarks of urea, TCA cycle, and mitochondrial derangements predict incident fibroinflammatory liver disease in 106,606 patients nearly a decade in advance.

SF-Relate is a practical and secure federated algorithm for identifying genetic relatives across data silos. We assign individuals who are likely to be related together into buckets and then test relationships only between individuals in matching buckets across parties. To guarantee privacy, we introduce an efficient algorithm based on multiparty homomorphic encryption (MHE) to allow data holders to cooperatively compute the relatedness coefficients between individuals.

Aggregated L0Learn using Summary-level data (ALL-Sum) is a fast and scalable ensemble learning method for computing PRS. It leverages a L0L2 penalized regression and ensemble learning across tuning parameters to flexibly model traits with diverse genetic architectures. All-Sum consistently outperformed popular alternative methods in terms of prediction accuracy, runtime, and memory usage.

Previous research on autism spectrum disorders (ASD) have showed important volumetric alterations in the cerebellum and brainstem. Herein, we aimed to explore the association between the cumulative genetic load (polygenic risk score, PRS) for ASD and volumetry alterations. We utilized the latest genome-wide association study of ASD by the Psychiatric Genetics Consortium.

Childhood maltreatment has been indicated in adverse health outcomes across the lifespan, including severe infection-related outcomes. We found the number of CM types was associated with the risk of severe COVID-19 outcomes in a graded manner. 50.9% of the association was explained by suboptimal socio-economic status, lifestyle, and pre-pandemic diagnosis of psychiatric disorders.

Finding an interpretable and compact representation of complex neuroimaging data is extremely useful for understanding brain behavioral mapping. Here, we implemented a data-driven approach using a three-dimensional autoencoder on two large-scale datasets. This approach provides a latent representation of high-dimensional task-fMRI data which can account for demographic characteristics.

Poor sleep score and renal function biomarker score (RFS) were associated with an increased risk of new-onset severe MASLD. Study highlights the bidirectional communication of the liver-kidney axis.

Circulating plasma proteins play key roles in human health. They can potentially be used to measure biological age, allowing risk prediction for age-related diseases, multimorbidity and mortality. We developed a proteomic age clock in the UK Biobank (n = 45,441) using 2,897 plasma proteins.

Long-term exposure to PM 2.5 , PM 10 , NO 2 , NO x , and SO 2 was significantly associated with the risk of cardiopulmonary disease in PRISm. The corresponding hazard ratios (HRs) per interquartile range (IQR) were 1.84 (1.76, 3.84) and 1.45 (132, 1.57), respectively.

Study assessed whether digital gait biomarkers from a wrist-worn device could identify people with frailty in a large sample of middle-aged and older adults. Findings indicate that measures obtained from wrist- worn wearable devices worn in everyday life can identify individuals withFrailty.

The burgeoning field of brain health research increasingly leverages artificial intelligence (AI) to analyze and interpret neuroimaging data. Medical foundation models have shown promise of superior performance with better sample efficiency. This work introduces a novel approach towards creating 3D medical foundation models.

The eXtreme Gradient Boosting (XGBoost) model was utilized to rank the importance of 11 micronutrients in cardiovascular health. Results indicated that vitamin E, calcium, vitamin C, and potassium intake were associated with a reduced risk of CVD. Subgroup analysis revealed a stronger correlation between calcium intake and CVD risk in older adults.

Little is known about the brain's role in mediating links between physical and mental health. We identify lifestyle and environmental factors that influence mental health through their selective impact on the physiology of specific organ systems and brain structure.

 increased left ventricular mass has been associated with adverse cardiovascular outcomes including incident cardiomyopathy and atrial fibrillation. The regional distribution of myocardial hypertrophy is extremely variable and genetic associations of such variability require further study. Apical and septal mass may be driven by genes distinct from total left vent cardiac mass.

We evaluated the effect of hyperuricemia on the presence and development of CKD after considering genetic background by calculating polygenic risk scores (PRSs) We observed a significant positive association between PRS and CKD and the presence of the disease.

Long-term exposure to air pollutants was positively related to the schizophrenia risk. Interactions between genetic factors and the pollutants NO 2  and NO x had an effect on schizophrenia events.

Low birth weight was associated with higher risk of MI. No significant correlation between high birth weight and MI was observed after adjustment. Improving LE8 can mitigate MI risk attributed to low birth weight.

Cancer and cardiovascular disease share common lifestyle risk factors. It remains unclear whether cardiovascular health (CVH) evaluated by Life's Essential 8 can predict cancer risk. High CVH was associated with decreased risks of overall cancer and the majority of common cancers.

Concentrating recommended physical activities into 1-2 days per week is associated with a lower incidence of NDDs. When the exercise threshold was increased to 75% of MVPA, both patterns still were associated with decreased risk of incident all-cause dementia.

 flavonoids may have potential effects on hormone-related cancers (HRCs) due to their anti-cancer properties. We aimed to examine the association of flavonoid intake with risks of HRCs and whether this association was mediated by blood biomarkers involved in biological mechanisms.

Phenome-wide Multi-Institutional Multimorbidity Explorer (PheMIME) leverages three large-scale EHR systems. It offers interactive and multifaceted visualizations for exploring multimorbidities. It is a significant advancement in medical informatics.

Watch Walk digital biomarkers were developed, validated, and applied to 92,022 participants aged 45-79 who wore a wrist sensor for at least three days. Normative data were collected for daily-life walking speed, step-time variability, step count, and 17 other gait and sleep biomarkers.

The genetic structure in Europe was mostly shaped by admixture between the Western Hunter-Gatherers, Early European Farmers and Steppe Bronze Age ancestral components. Heart rate, platelet count, bone mineral density and many other traits show stratification similar to height and pigmentation traits.

The current evidence regarding how different predictor domains contributes to predicting incident dementia remains unclear. This study aims to assess the incremental value of five predictor domains when added to a simple dementia risk prediction model. Neuroimaging markers provided the highest incremental value in predicting all-cause dementia and AD.

Telomere length (TL) has been acknowledged as biomarker of biological aging. We evaluated relationship between individual and combined early life factors and leukocytes TL in middle and late life using data from the UK Biobank. Exposure to maternal smoking, lack of breastfeeding, low birth weight, and shorter height compared to peers at age 10 were identified to be associated with shorter TL.

We used 15 HCC-associated genetic loci from two PRSs and FinnGen GWAS data to calculate a PRS-combined score and to fit the related PRS model in the UK Biobank cohort (N = 436,162) The top 20% of the PRS combined distribution had a 3.25 increased risk of HCC vs. the middle decile.

High-density lipoprotein (HDL) might lose atheroprotective functions in the presence of diabetes. We sought to examine associations of HDL cholesterol and HDL particle with risk of coronary heart disease (CHD) stratified by diabetes. HDL-C showed inverse associations with CHD among nondiabetics, whereas U-shaped associations among diabetics.

Aspirin and other non-steroidal anti-inflammatory drugs (NSAIDs) usage has been associated with pancreatic ductal adenocarcinoma (PDAC) prevention. The aim of this study is to identify if aspirin and other NSAIDs are effective in the primary prevention of PDAC in a large UK prospective cohort.

Study looked at 103,215 non-diabetic participants in the UK Biobank cohort. After adjustment, compared to the comfortable group, the participants working in non-comfortable environmental temperature had greater risk of T2D.

The heritability of Alzheimer's disease (AD) is estimated to be 58%-79%. However, known genes can only partially explain the heritability. We conducted gene-based exome-wide association study (ExWAS) of rare variants and single-variant ExWAS of common variants. We identified 11 genes predicting a higher ADRD risk, including five novel ones and six previously reported ones.

It is elusive why some heavy drinkers progress to severe alcohol-related liver disease (ALD) while others do not. This study aimed to investigate if the association between alcohol consumption and severe ALD is modified by diet. This prospective study included 303,269 UK Biobank participants.

Cardiovascular magnetic resonance (CMR) imaging shows promise in estimating pulmonary capillary wedge pressure (PCWP) non-invasively. At the population level, the prognostic role of CMR-modelled PCWP remains unknown.

The UK Biobank provides access to a large magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) data set. Fifty thousand three hundred thirty-two participants were included in the study. Total fat-free thigh muscle declined between the ages of 45 and 84 years. Intramuscular fat of the thigh continued to increase.

Copy-number variants (CNVs) have been implicated in a variety of neuropsychiatric and cognitive phenotypes. We found that deleterious CNVs are less prevalent in non-European ancestry groups than they are in European ancestry groups.

We built a reference panel with 342 million autosomal variants using 78,195 individuals from the Genomics England (GEL) dataset. The GEL-imputed UK Biobank genome-wide association analysis identified 70% of associations found by direct exome sequencing.

The language network of the human brain has core components in the inferior frontal cortex and superior/middle temporal cortex, with left-hemisphere dominance in most people. Excitatory connections between cortical regions arise and innervate according to layer-specific patterns.

Aortic diameter estimation models were built with a 1.1 million-variant polygenic score. Models were validated internally in 4394 UK Biobank participants and externally in 5469 individuals from Mass General Brigham.

The interplay between genetic and lifestyle factors in the development of bipolar disorder (BD) remains unclear. A cohort study was carried out on 365,517 participants from the UK Biobank. A favorable lifestyle was associated with a reduced risk of developing BD.

Short sleep duration, snoring, insomnia, and 'insomnia and snoring' were associated with increased risk of 0, 9, 10, and 19 diseases. These diseases were classified into three disease modules, characterized by predominant diseases related to digestive system, circulatory and endocrine systems. Genetic determinants associated with each disease module were identified by genome-wide association studies.

Childhood Emotional Support (CES) and the mechanisms of aging is pivotal for understanding its potential to lessen the incidence of age-related pathologies and promote a milieu for healthy aging. Data from the UK Biobank comprising nearly 160,000 individuals were used to explore associations.

Study included 11,949 individuals diagnosed with T2D, matched with 47,796 non-T2D control study participants from the UK Biobank cohort. Each additional risk factor controlled was associated with an average 19% lower risk of HF. Optimal control of at least six risk factors associated with a 67% lower HF risk.

We developed a computational pipeline (now provided as a resource) for measuring morphological similarity between cortical surface sulci. We constructed a sulcal phenotype network (SPN) from each magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) scan in an adult cohort.
