Carotid intima-media thickness (cIMT) is valuable for cardiovascular risk stratification. We assessed the relative importance of traditional atherosclerosis risk factors and plasma proteins in predicting cIMT measured nearly a decade later. We examined 6,136 UK Biobank participants with 1,461 proteins profiled using the proximity extension assay.

There are no reliable methods for predicting and preventing atrial fibrillation (AF) in its early stages. This study aimed to identify plasma proteins associated with AF to discover biomarkers and potential drug targets.

Analyses were performed within European ancestry participants from UK Biobank. Principal components (PC) analyses were used for the dimension reduction of 11 measures of adiposity, anthropometrics and energy expenditure. PCs were studied in relation to incident type 2 diabetes mellitus (T2D) and coronary artery disease (CAD)

It is unclear how patterns of regional genetic differentiation in the UK and Ireland might impact the protein-coding fraction of the genome. We exploit UK Biobank (UKB) and Viking Genes whole exome sequencing data. We demonstrate substantial exonic differentiation among Shetlanders, Orcadians, individuals with full or partial Ashkenazi Jewish ancestry.

Triglyceride-rich lipoproteins and remnants (TRL/remnants) have a causal, but not yet quantified, relationship with coronary heart disease (CHD): myocardial infarction plus revascularization. The authors sought to estimate TRL/Remnant per-particle atherogenicity, investigate causal relationships with inflammation, and determine whether differences in the Atherogenicity of TRL and low-density lipoprotein (LDL) impact the causal association of non-HDL-C.

Few studies have integrated the impact of individual and cumulative childhood maltreatment on multiple psychiatric symptoms. We examined seven types of psychiatric symptoms in adulthood, including depressive symptoms, anxiety symptoms, mania, post-traumatic stress disorder (PTSD), psychotic experiences, self-harm, and alcohol use disorder. Levels of C-reactive protein (CRP) and counts of leukocytes and neutrophils were positively associated with depressive symptoms. Emotional abuse and physical neglect showed the strongest average marginal effects on Psychiatric symptoms.

Older biological age, as measured by shortened telomere length, has been observed in children with autism spectrum disorders (ASD) In contrast, older parental age at birth has been related to both ASD risk and longer telomeres. Older paternal or maternal age was more strongly associated with longer TL in participants with ASD. Future studies tracking TL attrition before ASD diagnosis are warranted.

Four Asian studies (discovery) and UK Biobank (validation) were included. CMM was defined as two or more of hypertension, hyperlipidemia, diabetes mellitus, stroke, and heart disease. Two-step individual participant data (IPD) and Cox regressions explored associations between CMM and the presence and short-term incidence of four neuropsychiatric subsyndromes.

There has been limited research exploring this relationship from a genetic perspective. A substantial risk of depression and anxiety development was detected in participants exposed to the high air pollution concomitantly with high genetic risk. Some significant genes overlapped among four air pollutants, like TSN.

Deep mutational scanning enables high-throughput functional assessment of genetic variants. While phenotypic measurements from screening assays generally align with clinical outcomes, experimental noise may affect the accuracy of individual variant estimates. We developed the FUSE (functional substitution estimation) pipeline to improve the estimation of variant impacts.

 basal ganglia are subcortical brain structures involved in motor control, cognition, and emotion regulation. We used brain scans from 34,794 Europeans with replication in 4,808 white and generalization in 5,220 non-white Europeans.

Case-control study investigates UK Biobank data for 8 early-life factors and early-onset endometrial cancer risk among UK residents.

The relationship between sedentary time, physical activity, and chronic back pain remains unclear. Sedentary time was also associated with decreased grey matter volume in several brain regions, including bilateral primary somatosensory cortex.

Study used a recently developed statistical technique to investigate the relations between various elements of a subject's family background and the odds of that subject reporting a sexual history indicative of a minority sexual orientation. Subjects were 78,983 men and 92,150 women who completed relevant questionnaire items in the UK Biobank, a large-scale biomedical database of volunteers aged 40-69 years. Results showed that older brothers increased the chances of homosexuality in both men and women.

There is limited research on whether the association between sarcopenia and the risk of Alzheimer's disease (AD) is influenced by genetic susceptibility. The role of alcohol consumption as a mediator in the risk between sarc Openia and dementia remains inadequately studied.

Study tracked 478,198 participants from the UK Biobank. Data regarding individual leisure-time SB and PA were collected through a standardized questionnaire. For individuals sleeping 8 hours or less per day, substituting SB with an adequate amount of sleep or engaging in VPA emerges as an effective strategy for reducing stroke risk.

Study included 42,325 participants without osteoporosis in the UK Biobank. We used Cox regression and Mendelian randomization analysis to examine the association between plasma proteins. Of 2,919 plasma proteins, we identified 134 significantly associated with the condition. Twelve of these proteins showed significant associations with bone mineral density.

Few studies explore relationship between plant-based dietary patterns and venous thromboembolism (VTE) in different genetic backgrounds. A total of 183,510 participants who were White British ethnicity background and free of VTE at baseline in the UK Biobank were recruited. High PRS was associated with a 47% increase in VTE risk.

The application of machine learning to tasks involving volumetric biomedical imaging is constrained by the limited availability of annotated datasets of three-dimensional (3D) scans for model training. We report a deep-learning model pre-trained on 2D scans that accurately predicts disease-risk factors from 3D medical-scan modalities.

Food preferences can determine an individual's dietary patterns and therefore, may be associated with certain health risks and benefits. The Health-conscious group exhibited lower risk of heart failure (RR = 0.86, 95%CI 0.79-0.93) and chronic kidney disease. The Sweet-tooth group had greater risk of depression, diabetes, and stroke.

Biological ageing markers are useful to risk stratify morbidity and mortality more precisely than chronological age. In this study, we aimed to develop a novel deep-learning-based biological ageing marker (referred to as RetiPhenoAge hereafter) using retinal images and PhenoAge, a composite biomarker of phenotypic age. We determined the performance of this marker for the prediction of morbidity (cardiovascular disease and cancer events) and mortality.

Human brain aging is a complex process that affects various aspects of brain function and structure, increasing susceptibility to neurological and psychiatric disorders. A number of nongenetic and genetic risk factors are found to contribute to the varying rates at which the brain ages among individuals.

Previous observational studies have suggested an association between whole grain consumption and a reduced risk of death. We aimed to evaluate the association between unsweetened, sugar-sweetened, and artificially sweetened cereals and all-cause and cause-specific mortality. We conducted a prospective cohort study of 186 419 UK Biobank participants.

No evidence has linked dietary anthocyanins to the prevention potential against inflammatory bowel disease (IBD) in humans. We leveraged data from 188,044 IBD-free individuals (mean age 59 years; 55.2% females) from the prospective cohort UK Biobank.

Accelerated biological aging has been verified to be a critical risk factor for a number of age-related diseases, but its role in dementia remained unclear. This study evaluated the associations between accelerated biological aging and dementia and the moderating role of accelerated biological Aging in the genetic susceptibility to the disease.

Rare copy-number variants associated with neurodevelopmental conditions (ND-CNVs) exhibit variable expressivity of clinical, physical, behavioural outcomes. Findings from clinically ascertained cohorts suggest this variability may be partly due to additional genetic variation. We assessed impact of polygenic scores (PGS) and rare variants on ND-CNV carrier fluid intelligence (FI) scores in the UK Biobank.

Air pollution is a significant public health issue and an important risk factor for metabolic dysfunction-associated steatotic liver disease (MASLD) The mechanism by which air pollution affects MASLD remains unclear. Our study used integrated serological metabolic data of 251 metabolites from a large-scale cohort study to demonstrate that metabolic signatures play a crucial role in the elevated risk.

The association of a healthy lifestyle with type 2 diabetes (T2D) has been extensively studied. However, its impact on the dynamic trajectory, including progression, onset and prognosis, of T2D has not been investigated. Using data from the UK Biobank, 461 168 participants without diabetes or diabetes-related events were included. Results indicated that adhering to 3-4 healthy lifestyles had an inverse association with the risk of transition from baseline to diabetes.

 Transcriptome analysis was performed on livers from mice engineered for deletion of the flow-sensing PIEZO1 channel in endothelium. This revealed unique up-regulation of  Cyp7a1, which encodes the rate-limiting enzyme for bile synthesis from cholesterol in hepatocytes. Elevated portal fluid flow acting via endothelial PIEzO1 and genetically enhanced PIE ZO1 conversely suppressed  Cyp 7a1.

Brain structural alterations begin long before the presentation of brain disorders. We explored associations between 218 modifiable factors and neuroimaging markers of brain health. The identified factors related to brain health fell into six domains, including systematic diseases, lifestyle factors and personality traits.

Previous studies have found that patients with epilepsy are more likely to suffer impulsivity. We conducted a bidirectional Mendelian randomization (MR) study to explore the causal relationship between impulsivity and epilepsy with recurrent seizure. SNPs related to the lack of perseverance were associated with a decreased risk of epilepsy.

Osteopenia, osteoporosis, and fragility fractures pose a major public health concern. Population-level clinical and biopsychosocial data may uncover modifiable risk factors to target when developing whole person approaches to managing these conditions.

BMI-proteomic score (pro-BMI score) was calculated from 67 pre-identified plasma proteins associated with BMI. A higher pro-B BMI score was significantly associated with higher risks of ischemic heart disease (IHD) and heart failure (HF), but not with risk of stroke.

Study looked at associations between coffee consumption and metabolic syndrome and its components. Consuming up to two cups of coffee per day was inversely associated with metabolic syndrome. Both self-reported and genetically predicted high coffee consumption (four cups or more) were associated with central obesity.

Study included 122,494 UK Biobank participants aged &#8805;60 years without AF at baseline. Low SES and high AL were associated with an increased risk of AF. Chronic stress was also shown to partially mediate the association.

Idiopathic Pulmonary Fibrosis (IPF) is a fatal disease with scarce therapeutic alternatives. Plasma proteins with discernible causal evidence hold promise as viable drug targets for this condition.

While sex differences in right heart phenotypes have been observed, the molecular drivers remain unknown. The aim of this study was to provide insights into the structure and function of the right ventricle using common genetic variation.

Kidney failure manifests in various forms, from sudden occurrences such as Acute Kidney Injury (AKI) to progressive like Chronic Kidney Disease (CKD) Given its intricate nature, marked by overlapping comorbidities and clinical similarities, we sought to design and validate an end-to-end framework for clustering kidney failure subtypes.

Evaluating the impact of lifestyle factors and work practices on renal function has the potential to support the early prevention of chronic kidney disease (CKD) Current studies linking disrupted circadian rhythms to the development or progression of CKD are limited and show disparate findings. This study is the first to link associations between sleep quality and renal function to inflammatory status.

The impact of physical activity on the incidence of idiopathic pulmonary fibrosis (IPF) remains less well studied. This study aimed to investigate the relationship between moderate-to-vigorous physical activity (MVPA) and the risk of developing IPF. We analyzed data from a prospective cohort study within the UK Biobank.

Lifespan is influenced by complex interactions between genetic and environmental factors. Studying those factors in model organisms of a single genetic background limits their translational value for humans. We mapped lifespan determinants in 85 C. elegans recombinant inbred advanced intercross lines (RIAILs)

Genome-wide interaction scan included 33,756 colorectal cancer cases and 44,346 controls from three genetic consortia. Evidence of an interaction was observed between smoking status (ever vs. never smokers) and a locus on 3p12.1.

The lack of efficient preventive interventions against Alzheimer's disease (AD) calls for identifying efficient modifiable risk factors for AD. Mounting evidence suggests that links between AD and diabetes may be more complex than previously believed. This study emphasizes differences and similarities in the heterogeneous genetic architectures of AD and DM.

Neuroinflammation and the activation of microglial cells are among the earliest events in Alzheimer's disease. Direct observation ofmicroglia in living people is not currently possible. We indexed the heritable propensity for neuroinflammation with polygenic risk scores (PRS)

Phenotyping of major depressive disorder (MDD) can vary from study to study. In this study we examined the classification accuracy of structural and functional connectomes across different depressive phenotypes. We also separated MDD subgroups into those with and without self-reported exposure to childhood trauma (CT)

Trigeminal neuralgia (TN) is a severe facial pain disease of uncertain pathophysiology and unclear genetic background. Few candidate genes have been proposed to date. Study aimed to identify independent genetic variants in the protein-coding genes associated with TN.

The advent of biobanks with vast quantities of medical imaging creates huge opportunities for a new generation of genotype-phenotype association studies. However, disentangling biological signals from the many sources of bias and artifacts remains difficult. We show how registration, both spatial and temporal, guided by domain knowledge or learned  de novo , helps uncover biological information.

Regular laxative use was significantly associated with a higher risk of incident depression. Genetic risk of depression did not significantly modify this association. The risk increased with increasing types of laxatives used, with a HR of 1.89 for use of single laxative type.

Cognitive reserve (CR) has been linked to dementia and might be a predictor of aged-related outcomes. The association between CR and risk of other chronic diseases and mortality remains unclear. We aimed to investigate the association of CR with survival free from major chronic diseases.

Based on a prospective cohort from the UK Biobank, a total of 55,139 individuals aged 50 and above with depression were enrolled in the study, among whom 29,528 exhibited suicidal behavior. We used the Gradient Boosting Decision Tree (GBDT) algorithm with stratified 10-fold cross-validation and grid-search to construct the prediction models.

Embedding Genetic Evaluation Methods is a framework to systematically evaluate the utility of embeddings in genetic discovery. EmbedGEM focuses on comparingembeddings along two axes: heritability and disease relevance. The approach is generally applicable to multivariate traits.

Conditional testing via the knockoff framework allows one to identify -- among large number of possible explanatory variables -- those that carry unique information about an outcome of interest. This approach is particularly well suited to the analysis of genome wide association studies.

Genetic prediction holds immense promise for translating genetic discoveries into medical advances. As the high-dimensional covariance matrix of genetic variants often presents a block-diagonal structure, numerous methods account for the dependence among variants in predetermined local LD blocks.

Mendelian randomization is an epidemiological technique that can explore the potential effect of perturbing a pharmacological target. Plasma caffeine levels can be used as a biomarker to measure the pharmacological effects of caffeine. Some genetic variants that decrease caffeine metabolism associate with higher levels of plasma caffeine, but lower levels of caffeine consumption.

Previous studies found that visual impairment (VI) is associated with higher risk of cognitive impairment. The molecular basis of these conditions is unknown. We aim to compare the metabolite associations of VI and cognitive impairment and identify distinct and overlapping metabolites.

The prognostic value of personality and its association with lifestyle factors remain elusive. We identified 8794 patients with T2DM from the UK Biobank database between 2006 and 2010. The primary outcome was a composite of incident CVD, including myocardial infarction (MI), ischemic stroke (IS), atrial fibrillation (AF), and heart failure (HF)

Bilateral oophorectomy (BO) confers immediate estradiol loss. Those with early BO had four times the odds of developing AD compared to those with SM. Greater years of education were associated with reduced odds of AD for both BO and SM.

In genome-wide association studies (GWAS), it is desirable to test for interactions (GxE) between single-nucleotide polymorphisms (SNPs,G's) and environmental variables (E's) However, directly accounting for interaction is often infeasible, because E is latent. For quantitative traits (Y) that are approximately normally distributed, indirect testing on GxE can be done by testing for heteroskedasticity of Y between genotypes.

Long-term health risk assessments related to ambient fine particulate matter (PM2.5) exposure have been more limited to general population but not towards individuals suffering from multimorbidity. Cross-cohort analysis was undertaken on data from 3 population-based prospective cohorts of UK Biobank, the Taiwan MJ Cohort, and the Taiwan Biobanks.

Study evaluated 146,772 UK Biobank participants with serial smoking assessments. 37,377 (25.5%) currently smoked; 105,429 (72.0%) were former smokers; and 3,966 (2.7%) quit smoking during the study. Compared to current smokers, the adjusted risk of AF was 13% lower in former smokers.

Sleep and physical activity (PA) are thought to be interconnected with the development of rheumatoid arthritis (RA) This study aimed to quantify the longitudinal effects of sleep behaviors, PA, and genetic susceptibility on the incidence of RA.

Study identified prevalent patterns of chronic pain locations and evaluated their associations with incident dementia. Data were from 445,530 participants who were free of dementia at baseline (2006-2010) in the UK Biobank. The 3 most prevalent combinations were neck and back, back and knee, and neck and knee. Chronic back, neck, and knee pain was commonly present either individually or simultaneously.

Preserved ratio impaired spirometry (PRISm) is a new lung function impairment phenotype. PRISm has been recognized as a risk factor for various adverse outcomes. We aimed to examine the associations of this new lungfunction impairment phenotype with depression and anxiety in longitudinal studies.

High intakes of dietary flavonoids may protect against nonalcoholic fatty liver disease (NAFLD) This is the first population-based study with long-term follow-up on flavonoid consumption and incident NAFLD.

The relationship between a metabolic signature indicative of healthy lifestyle and dementia risk remains unknown. We retrieved 136 628 dementia-free participants from UK Biobank. We identified 83 metabolites that could represent healthy lifestyle behaviours using elastic net regression. The metabolic signature was associated with a lower dementia risk.

Genetic analysis of major depressive symptoms has the potential to identify clinical and etiological subtypes. There are several challenges to integrating symptom data from genetically informative cohorts, such as sample size differences.

Leveraging data from 46,165 UK Biobank participants and 2920 plasma proteins profiled at baseline, we conducted a longitudinal analysis with a median follow-up of 14.5 years. We identified 157 proteins associated with incident depression. Dysregulation of the 157 proteins is correlated with brain regions implicated in depression, including the hippocampus and middle temporal gyrus.

Recent meta-analyses estimated 14.6% and 11.2% SNP-based heritability of migraine, compared to twin-heritability estimates of 30-60%. This study aimed to investigate heritability estimates in "migraine-first" individuals.

 insulin resistance (IR) is an autonomous risk factor for cardiovascular disease (CVD) The association between estimated glucose disposal rate (eGDR), a novel indicator of IR, and incident CVD and mortality in chronic kidney disease patients without diabetes remains uncertain.

Language is supported by a distributed network of brain regions with a particular contribution from the left hemisphere. A multi-level understanding of this network requires studying its genetic architecture. We used resting-state imaging data from 29,681 participants (UK Biobank) to measure connectivity.

Glaucoma is the leading cause of irreversible blindness worldwide. Despite growing concerns about air quality and its impact on ocular health, there remains a knowledge gap regarding the long-term association between air pollution and glaucomA risk. This study investigates the relationship between exposure to ambient air pollution.

Inhibition of cholesteryl ester transfer protein (CETP) meaningfully affects the concentrations of blood lipids. Lower CETP concentrations were associated with higher total brain volume, lower risk of LBD and Parkinson's dementia.

Mitochondrial DNA (mtDNA) has an important yet often overlooked role in health and disease. Constraint models quantify the removal of deleterious variation from the population by selection. However, nuclear constraint models are not applicable to mtDNA, owing to its distinct features. Here we describe the development of a mitochondrial genome constraint model and its application to the Genome Aggregation Database.

Mendelian randomization studies using sex-combined data suggest that sex hormone-binding globulin (SHBG) and bioavailable testosterone (BioT) affect bone traits. Given significant sex differences in hormone regulation and effects, female-specific MR studies are necessary. We explored the causal relationships of SHBG, BioT, and total testosterone (TT) with forearm fracture (FAFx) risk in women.

A total of 213,604 participants without hypertension were identified at baseline from the UK Biobank between 2006 and 2010. The hazard ratio (HR) of habitual fish oil users for hypertension was 0.94. Fish oil nonusers with a high genetic risk had an increased risk of hypertension.

Light enhances or disrupts circadian rhythms, depending on the timing of exposure. Circadian disruption contributes to poor health outcomes that increase mortality risk. UK Biobank participants wore light sensors for 1 wk. Day light, night light, and circadian amplitude predicted cardiometabolic mortality with larger hazard ratios than for mortality by other causes.

Identifying causal relations between diseases allows for the study of shared pathways, biological mechanisms, and inter-disease risks. Such causal relations can facilitate the identification of potential disease precursors and candidates for drug re-purposing. Few approaches have been developed to automatically extract causal relationships between diseases from unstructured text.

Coronary artery calcification (CAC) is associated with an increased risk of mortality and cardiovascular events. None therapeutic drugs have been proven effective for CAC treatment. A total of 671 genes were found to be significantly associated with the risk of CAC.

Menopause and related metabolites are associated with mortality. The relationship between earlier menopause, premature mortality, and the role of metabolomic signatures remains underexplored. This study investigated the association between earlier. menophere and premature mortality and the mediating effect of metabolomics.

During chronic inflammation, macrophages acquire sustained inflammatory 'states' that contribute to disease. There is limited understanding of the regulatory mechanisms that drive their generation. Here we describe a systematic functional genomics approach that combines genome-wide phenotypic screening with transcriptional and cytokine profiling.

Clinical studies and meta-analyses have suggested a link between thyroid dysfunction and lens opacification. The objective of this study is to investigate the causal relationship between hyperthyroidism and the development of cataracts using the Mendelian randomization approach. The results demonstrate that there is a strong likely causal relationship.

Previous studies have suggested associations between high-level educational attainment (EA) and a lower risk of sarcopenia. This study used a two-step Mendelian randomization analysis to illustrate the causal relationship between EA and brain cortical structure. EA was associated with increased appendicular lean mass and hand grip strength.

Quantifying molecular regulations between genes/molecules causally from observed data is crucial for elucidating the molecular mechanisms underlying biological processes. Most methods for inferring gene regulatory and biological networks rely on association studies or observational causal-analysis approaches. This study introduces a novel approach that combines intervention operations and diffusion models within a do-calculus framework by deep learning.

We investigated the potential determinants of frailty in a cohort of 469,301 UK Biobank participants. The largest EWAS identified 90 modifiable factors for frailty across ten domains. Health and medical history, psychosocial factors, and physical activity were the most significant contributors.

The association between the triglyceride-glucose (TyG) index and its combination with obesity indictors in aortic aneurysm and dissection (AAD) remains unclear. This study included 387,483 baseline participants from the UK Biobank with complete data on TyG. For each standard deviation increase, the risk of AAD occurrence increased by 33%.

Rare deleterious NR5A1/SF-1 variants have been identified in individuals with various differences of sex development (DSD), primary ovarian insufficiency, and infertility. We analyzed health records and exome sequencing data from up to 420 162 individuals (227 858 women) from the UK Biobank study to assess the impact of rare (frequency) variants.

 Transcriptome-wide association studies (TWAS) have been widely used to identify thousands of likely causal genes for diseases and complex traits. Most existing TWAS methods rely on gene expression alone. We introduce a multi-omics method that integrates gene expression, DNA methylation, and splicing data to improve the identification of associated genes.

A total of 17,926 participants with prediabetes and 7798 with diabetes were enrolled from the UK Biobank between 2006 and 2010 and followed until the end of 2020. High-sugar-sweetened beverages (SSB) intake accounted for 35% of the hPDI-CVD association. Low intake of whole grain accounted for 36%. Elevated cystatin C levels explained the largest proportion of the association between uPDI and CVD risk.

Previous research has shown that use of renin-angiotensin system (RAS) blockers is linked to a lower prevalence of posttraumatic stress disorder (PTSD) We aimed to estimate the association between the use of RAS blockers and the risk of PTSD among individuals taking antihypertensive medications. The study included participants aged 40-69 from the UK Biobank.

Study included 419,835 UK Biobank participants who did not have KSD at baseline. Significant associations were found between KSD risk and air pollution score. PM2.5 and NO2 reductions may be a key mechanism for the protective impact of residential greenspace on KSD.

The protective effect of a healthy diet combined with stair climbing on cardiovascular health is unclear. We aimed to assess the independent and joint associations of dietary patterns and stair climbing with major adverse cardiovascular events (MACEs) The UK Biobank documented 9408 MACEs over a median follow-up of 13.3 years.

A BRCA2 splice acceptor variant, c.517-2A>G, is found in breast and ovarian cancer families from Shetland. The variant segregates with female cancer in diagnosed cases and is classified as pathogenic. Nine VIKING I research volunteers carry this variant, on a shared haplotype (carrier frequency 0.4%).

Patients with inflammatory bowel disease (IBD) are at increased risk of Clostridioides difficile infection (CDI) We aimed to determine if genetic risk contributes to this observed association. We carried out a genome-wide association study (GWAS) analysis in the Michigan Genomics Initiative and the United Kingdom Biobank for CDI.

Loneliness has garnered significant attention globally, with extensive exploration of its association with cardiovascular disease. A notable research gap persists concerning loneliness and its potential link to atrial fibrillation (AF) This prospective cohort study utilized data from the UK Biobank.

Walking pace is a strong predictor of health, but little is known about its causal association with rheumatoid arthritis. This study aimed to investigate the causal effect of WP on the developing RA using Mendelian randomization analysis. After adjusting for the risk factors, the associations for WP and RA did not change substantially.

Anatomical MRI templates of the brain are essential to group-level analyses and image processing pipelines. Most existing strategies for multimodal template construction either do not use all modalities of interest to inform the template construction process. Here, we present cross-sectional templates constructed from UK Biobank data.

Low grip strength (GS) is associated with higher risk of Parkinson's disease (PD) incidence. Low GS and high genetic predisposition contribute to the highest PD risk in an additive interaction. In addition to enhancing GS, interventions targeting risk factors might also reduce the excess risk.

Adiposity is positively associated with risk of some cancer sites and other health conditions in men. It is unclear if endogenous hormones play a role in these associations. We examined how body composition and common measures of adiposity are related to hormone concentrations in men from the UK Biobank study.

Cross-sectional study included 53,170 participants aged 60 years and over from the UK biobank. The primary outcomes were grip strength index and muscle mass index. The predictor variable was n-3 fatty acid intake.

The research gap on how to effectively control urate levels in the population with diabetes still remains. Diabetes was associated with a 70% 58% and 134% increased risk for all-cause dementia, Alzheimer's disease, and vascular dementia respectively.

UK Biobank participants (n = 11,780; aged 43-78 years) with accelerometer data for one or more days during the 2 weeks surrounding the Spring and Autumn daylight saving time transitions. Between-individual t-tests compared sleep duration on the Sunday of the clock changes with the Sunday before and the Sunday after.

There is a lack of comprehensive evidence on the long-term risks posed by air pollution with respect to acute kidney injury (AKI) and AKI-related death. This prospective cohort analysis included 414,885 UK Biobank (UKB) participants who did not exhibit AKI at the study's outset.

The role of diet on the risk of chronic pancreatitis (CP) is understudied. The health benefits of the Mediterranean diet (MedDiet) pattern have long been recognized, but its association with CP risk is unclear. We aimed to investigate the association between adherence to MedDiet and the incidence of CP.

Brain ageing is highly heterogeneous, as it is driven by a variety of normal and neuropathological processes. These processes may differentially affect structural and functional brain ageing across individuals. More pronounced ageing during midlife is indicative of later development of dementia.

Altered metabolism plays a role in the pathophysiology of cardiac diseases such as atrial fibrillation (AF) and heart failure (HF) We aimed to identify novel plasma metabolites and proteins associating with cardiac disease. We identified 35 metabolites and 38 druggable proteins expressed in cardiac tissue.

Malnutrition is a complication of chronic kidney disease (CKD) Whether malnutrition, assessed via the geriatric nutritional risk index (GNRI), is associated with the incidence and risk of CKD in older individuals remains unclear. We identified 6,135 and 16,662 CKD patients in the NHANES and UK Biobank.

Little is known about the shared genetics and causality of the association between serum 25-hydroxyvitamin D (25OHD) and bone mineral density (BMD) A significant local signal was discovered at 5p11-5q11.9. Protein-protein interaction analysis identified RPS9 and RPL7A as hub genes.

Mounting evidence supports the key role of the disrupted integrity of the blood-brain barrier (BBB) in stress- and inflammation-associated depression. We assumed that variations in genes regulating the expression and coding proteins constructing and maintaining this barrier have a predisposing or protecting role in the development of depressive symptoms.

Obesity is implicated in the development of multiple sclerosis (MS), but its effect on disability is less well-established. Study examined effects of various obesity measures on MS severity in 12,584 MS cases. Results showed a significant association between higher genetically-determined body mass index and increased MS severity.

Bridging the gap between genotype and phenotype in GWAS studies is challenging. A multitude of genetic variants have been associated with immune-related diseases, including cancer, yet the interpretability of most variants remains low. Here, we investigate the quantitative components in the T cell receptor (TCR) repertoire.

Type 2 diabetes mellitus (T2DM) is a major risk factor for heart failure with preserved ejection fraction and cardiac arrhythmias. Our goal is to quantify T2DM-driven abnormalities in ECG and cardiac imaging biomarkers leading to cardiovascular disease.

Previous studies identified common genetic variants associated with longevity in centenarians. The role of the rare loss-of-function (LOF) mutation burden remains largely unexplored. We investigated the burden of rare LOF mutations in Ashkenazi Jewish individuals using whole-exome sequencing data.

Study aimed to explore the association between child maltreatment and hospital-treated infectious diseases in middle-aged and older adults. Child maltreatment included five types: physical abuse, physical neglect, emotional abuse, emotional neglect, and sexual abuse. Participants reporting any maltreatment had elevated infectious diseases risk.

Liver disease activity, indicated by cT1, increases the risk of developing ALS, independent of metabolic syndrome, liver fat, or fibrosis. 15 incident ALS cases were observed during a median follow-up period of 5.6 years.

Study included 161,018 CVD-free participants from the UK Biobank. During 13 years of follow-up, 17,030 participants developed incident CVDs. A healthy lifestyle-related metabolic signature comprising 123 metabolites was established.

Deep learning models for predicting variant pathogenicity have not been thoroughly evaluated on real-world clinical phenotypes. Here, we apply state-of-the-art prediction models to hereditary breast cancer gene variants in UK Biobank participants. Model predictions for missense variants in BRCA1, BRCa2 and PALB2 were associated with breast cancer risk.

Aging is related to deterioration of bodily and neural functions, leading to various disorders and symptoms, including the development of dementia, hearing loss, or tinnitus. Understanding how these phenomena are intertwined and how aging affects those is crucial for prevention and the future development of interventions.

Structural brain aging has demonstrated strong inter-individual heterogeneity and mirroring patterns with brain development. Most of the existing research focused on the cross-sectional changes of brain aging. Genomic analyses revealed risk loci and genes contributing to accelerated brain aging and delayed brain development, providing molecular basis for elucidating the biological mechanisms.

The association between leukocyte telomere length (LTL) alteration and major adverse cardiovascular events (MACE) or mortality in patients with hypertension is still unclear. 20,034 patients with essential hypertension were enrolled from UK biobank. LTL was shorter in hypertensive patients with MACE compared to those without MACE.

Structural brain aging has demonstrated strong inter-individual heterogeneity and mirroring patterns with brain development. Most of the existing research focused on the cross-sectional changes of brain aging. Genomic analyses revealed risk loci and genes contributing to accelerated brain aging and delayed brain development, providing molecular basis for elucidating the biological mechanisms.

No study explored the association of noise exposure in the workplace and genetic susceptibility with incidence of atrial fibrillation. We included 167 577 participants without AF at baseline in UK Biobank. During a median follow-up of 11.83 years, we observed 9355 AF cases.

Study examined data of UK Biobank participants who were diagnosed with cancer. Fish oil and glucosamine use was associated with reduced risks of all-cause mortality. The protective effects of fish oil were only observed in patients with LE8 scores lower than the mean score.

The genetics of &#946;-cell function (BCF) offer valuable insights into the aetiology of type 2 diabetes (T2D) Previous studies have expanded the catalogue of BCF genetic associations through candidate gene studies. Here, we aggregate GWAS data of eight BCF traits from 26,000 individuals of European descent. We identify 55 independent genetic associations at 44 loci.

GWASs of traits affecting primary open angle glaucoma through mechanisms independent of intraocular pressure remain limited. Here, we address this gap by subtracting the genetic effects of a GWAS for intraocular Pressure from aGWAS for primary open angles. Seventeen independent genome-wide significant SNPs were associated with the intraocular pressures-independent component of glau coma.

Previous epidemiological studies on the associations between polyunsaturated fatty acids (PUFAs) and cancer incidence have been inconsistent. We investigated the associations of plasma omega-3 and omega-6 PUFAs with the incidence of overall and 19 site-specific cancers. 253,138 eligible UK Biobank participants were included in our study.

Sleep disorders and low grip strength often co-occur clinically and are geriatric symptoms that cause significant socioeconomic burden. Previous observational studies have found an association between sleep behaviors and grip strength, but the causal relationship remains unclear. Study used genetic variants from the genome-wide association study.

This cohort study aimed to analyze the relationship between nut consumption and the risk of all-cause dementia in adults from the United Kingdom. Data from participants in the UK Biobank cohort between 2007-2012 (baseline) and 2013-2023 (follow-up) were analyzed. Compared with no consumption, daily nut consumption was significantly associated with a 12% lower risk.

Evidence regarding the role of chronic low-grade inflammation in the progression of cardiometabolic diseases (CMDs) is currently limited. This prospective cohort study, utilising data from the UK Biobank, included 273,804 adults aged 40-69 years.

Cognitive decline is a public health concern affecting about 50 million individuals worldwide. Neuroticism has been associated with an increased risk of late-life cognitive decline. This study investigated the relationship between genetic predisposition to neuroticism, computed by polygenic risk score (PRS), and performance in cognitive domains.

Conditional testing via the knockoff framework allows one to identify - among a large number of possible explanatory variables - those that carry unique information. This approach is particularly well suited to the analysis of genome-wide association studies (GWAS)

Study involved 238 388 participants from the UK Biobank. Hypertensive patients who had the optimal risk factor control had a 14.6% lower stroke risk than those who controlled 2 or fewer.

Previous studies indicate a link between non-alcoholic fatty liver disease (NAFLD) and unhealthy dietary patterns or nutrient intake. However, it remains unclear whether ultra-processed foods (UPF) contribute to an increased risk of NAFLD. This study aimed to explore how ultra- Processed food consumption correlates with severe NAFLd using the UK Biobank data.

Healthy dietary patterns have been linked to a decreased risk of chronic diseases. However, it remains uncertain whether proteomic signatures can reflect proteome response to healthy diet patterns. Using data from the UK Biobank including Olink plasma proteins, we identified substantial proteomic variation.

Polygenic risk scores (PRSs) hold promise in their potential translation into clinical settings to improve disease risk prediction. For each disease, we identified the top 10% subgroup with the greatest magnitude of improvement in risk prediction accuracy attributed to PRSs in the multi-modal model.

MetaboAgeMort is developed using metabolomic profiles from 239,291 UK Biobank participants for 10-year all-cause mortality prediction. Metabo ageMort showed significant associations with all- Cause mortality, cause-specific mortality, and diverse incident diseases.

Otitis media and allergic rhinitis are prevalent conditions. Some data posit a significant association between the 2 ailments. A 2-sample Mendelian randomization study was undertaken to elucidate the causal impact of AR on otitis media. Data on AR were sourced from the Genome for Extensive Association Study.

Incidental physical activity as part of daily living may offer feasibility advantages over traditional exercise. We examined the joint associations of incidental physical activity and sedentary behaviour with major adverse cardiovascular events (MACE) risk.

The aim of this study was to scan phenotypes in adulthood associated with polygenic risk scores (PRS) for childhood cancers with well-articulated genetic architectures. SNPs were queried from the UK Biobank genotype imputation data. A total of 244,332 unrelated white British participants were included.

Polygenic scores (PGSs) for complex traits could detect lipid dysfunctions related to the traits and provide new biological insights. We constructed genome-wide PGSs (approximately 1 million genetic variants) for 50 complex traits in 7,169 Finnish individuals.

Growth differentiation factor 15 (GDF15) is a secreted protein that regulates food intake, body weight and stress responses in pre-clinical models. The physiological function of GDF15 in humans remains unclear. Here we show the absence of an overt phenotype in human G DF15 loss-of-function carriers, including stop gains, frameshifts and the fully inactivating variant C211G3.

Whole-genome sequencing (WGS) and array genotyping with imputation (IMP) are common strategies for assessing genetic variation and its association with medically relevant phenotypes. To date, there has been no systematic empirical assessment of the yield of these approaches when applied to hundreds of thousands of samples. Using data for 100 complex traits from 149,195 individuals in the UK Biobank, we systematically compare the relative yield.

Plasma levels of 2,919 proteins measured in 52,164 UK Biobank participants are associated with incident myocardial infarction, ischemic stroke or heart failure. Mendelian randomization and colocalization analyses indicated that genetically determined levels of 47 and 18 proteins, respectively, were associated with CVDs. FGF5, PROCR and FURIN showed evidence to support potential causality and are therefore promising targets for drug treatment.

Deep rare variant association testing (DeepRVAT) is a model based on set neural networks. It learns a trait-agnostic gene impairment score from rare variant annotations and phenotypes. On 34 quantitative and 63 binary traits, using whole-exome-sequencing data from UK Biobank, it yields substantial gains in gene discoveries and improved detection of individuals at high genetic risk.

Liver X receptor-&#945; regulates cellular cholesterol abundance and potently activates hepatic lipogenesis. At least 1 in 450 people in the UK Biobank carry functionally impaired mutations in LXR&# 945;, which is associated with evidence of hepatic dysfunction.

Evidence suggests an inverse correlation between smoking and Parkinson's disease (PD) This study examined the changing risk relationship using alcohol consumption as a comparative measure. Non-smokers had a heightened PD risk, and this association strengthened closer to diagnosis.

The genetic landscape of cardiometabolic risk factors has been explored extensively. However, insight in the effects of genetic variation on these risk factors over the life course is sparse. We performed genome-wide interaction studies (GWIS) to identify age-specific genetic risks.

Lifestyle, ambient air pollution with crucial outcomes in the progression of adult asthma, including asthma new-onset and asthma hospitalisation. 176,800 participants were included to assess the prospective association between baseline risk exposures and the subsequent asthma onset. For pollutants, PM 2.5 was consistently recognized as a significant risk factor for asthma onset (HR = 1.064, 95% CI: 1.034-1.094)

Fine particulate matter (PM 2.5) is suggested to pose a severe risk to the kidneys by inducing functional degradation and chronic kidney diseases (CKD) In experimental study, noticeable kidney injury, which is the initiation of kidney diseases, is observed with PM 2. 5 exposure in C57BL/6N mice. In vitro, HK-2 cells with PM2.5 -stimulation exhibit tubulopathy and increased reactive oxygen species (ROS) generation.

The study used quantitative adipose and muscle tissue measures derived from magnetic resonance imaging data from UK Biobank. Fat distribution and muscle composition of selective serotonin reuptake inhibitor (SSRI) and tricyclic antidepressant (TCA) users were compared with sex-, age-, and BMI-matched control individuals.

A higher consumption of cereals was significantly associated with lower risks of diabetes and diabetic complications. Polygenic of HbA1c mediates the effect of cereALS on incident diabetes. Among people with diabetes without CVD, a higher intake of aforementioned four individual cereal was associated with a 13%-32 % lower risk of developing CVD.

Frailty and sleep disturbances are two major concerns in late adulthood. Both constructs represent dynamic states that are preventable and reversible. Understanding the potential pathways to and effects of these variables on one another is critical.

Study included 203,372 women who have given birth in UK Biobank. GDM was associated with higher odds of T2DM, coexisting T 2DM and vascular disease.

Allostatic load (AL) is a biomarker of chronic stress associated with various chronic diseases. No study has evaluated the relationship between AL and lung cancer risk.

Cardiovascular magnetic resonance (CMR) imaging has become a modality with superior power for the diagnosis and prognosis of cardiovascular diseases. One of the essential quality controls of CMR images is to investigate the complete cardiac coverage, which is necessary for the volumetric and functional assessment. This study examines the full cardiac coverage using a 3D dual-domain convolutional model.

Mitochondrial DNA copy number (mtDNAcn) from blood may predict cognitive decline and dementia risk. The effect of somatic mutations or frailty is unknown. We estimated mtDNAcn using fastMitoCalc and microheteroplasmies using mitoCaller, from Whole Genome Sequencing (WGS) data. In 189,566 participants free of dementia at study entry (mean age = 56 +/- 8), we examined the association between mt DNAcn and subsequent dementia diagnosis.

Low skeletal muscle volume may increase dementia risk through mechanisms affecting brain structure. It is unclear whether this relationship exists outside of sarcopenia and/or varies by other factors. We aimed to study the interplay between skeletal muscleVolume and factors, such as age, sex, and body mass index (BMI), in explaining brain structure at midlife.

Consumption of ultra-processed foods (UPF) has been associated with increased risks of various age-related diseases. We aim to assess the associations between consumption of UPF and risk of AREDs including age- related macular degeneration (AMD), cataract and glaucoma.

Sex-differential selection can have profound impacts on the maintenance of genetic variation, disease risk, and other key aspects of natural populations. Because the sexes mix their autosomal genomes each generation, quantifying SDS is not possible using conventional population genetic approaches.

Triglyceride-rich lipoproteins cholesterol (TRLs-C) has been associated with atherosclerotic cardiovascular disease (ASCVD) We assessed the associations with myocardial infarction (MI) and ischemic stroke (IS)

Polygenic risk scores (PRSs) are expected to be helpful in precision medicine. It remains unclear whether high-PRS groups are more likely to benefit from preventive interventions for diseases. Recent methodological advancements enable us to predict treatment effects at the individual level.

Brain age gap (BAG) is difference between predicted brain age and chronological age. BAG is a general biomarker for a variety of neurological, psychiatric, and other diseases or disorders. Study examined differences in BAG values derived from T1-weighted scans.

Elevated C-reactive protein (CRP), a marker of inflammation, is common in many chronic conditions. We aimed to examine to what extent elevated CRP in chronic conditions could be explained by concurrent adiposity. We analysed UK Biobank data on 10 chronic conditions reported at baseline.

High sodium and low potassium consumption are related to hypertension and cardiovascular disease. We aimed to determine the relationship between the frequency of salt addition and potassium consumption with the risk of new-onset atrial fibrillation. The study used the UK Biobank cohort, which included over 500,000 individuals enrolled from the United Kingdom between 2006 and 2010.

High well-being was associated with a significantly reduced risk of various CVDs. Mediation analysis indicated that lifestyle and inflammatory markers partially mediated the relationship. The role of lifestyle factors and inflammation as a mediator provides insight into possible biological pathways linking psychological states and cardiovascular health.

Data from the UK Biobank cohort participants aged 40-69 without prior cancer diagnosis were analyzed. We assessed the magnitude of associations of excess weight with the incidence of obesity-related cancers combined.

Liver effects of concentrated vs. more evenly distributed moderate-to-vigorous physical activity (MVPA) patterns remain unclear. We aimed to examine the association of accelerometer-measured MVPA and different MVPA patterns with liver outcomes.

Study aims to clarify the point of genetics between non-alcoholic fatty liver disease (NAFLD) and sarcopenia. Increasing appendicular lean mass (ALM) decreased the risk of NAFLD (OR = 0.906, 95%CI 0.838-0.980) Those older than 60 were more likely to suffer from NAFLd if they had low grip strength. The presence of specific single nucleotide polymorphisms (SNPs) has been identified in the PNPLA3, APOE, and MAU2 proteins.

Polygenic scoring is an approach for estimating an individual's likelihood of a given outcome. We have implemented the leading polygenic scoring methodologies within an easy-to-use pipeline called GenoPred. The pipeline is a Snakemake pipeline with associated Conda software environments.

Study used 24-h accelerometry time series from UK Biobank participants aged 42 to 79 years. A pattern of continuous day-long activity was inversely associated with colorectal cancer risk. A second pattern of late-day activity was suggestively inversely related to risk.

The clinical validity of the multifactorial BOADICEA model for epithelial tubo-ovarian cancer (EOC) risk prediction has not been assessed in a large sample size. We evaluated the model discrimination and calibration in the UK Biobank cohort comprising 199,429 women.

Anemia may contribute significantly to the onset of Parkinson's disease (PD) Current research on the association between anemia and PD risk is inconclusive. This study aims to investigate the relationships between. anemia, blood cell indicators, andPD risk using a thorough prospective cohort study.

We assess the UK Biobank (UKB) Polygenic Risk Score (PRS) Release. PRSs for 28 diseases and 25 quantitative traits have been made available on individuals in UKB. We also release a benchmarking software tool to enable like-for-like performance evaluation.

Data came from 79,294 participants in the UK Biobank who completed at least two 24-h dietary assessments. Higher Klemera-Doubal Method Biological Age (HKDM-BA), higher PhenoAge (HPA), higher allostatic load (HAL), and longer telomere length (LTL) were estimated to assess biological aging. Substitution model was performed to assess the effect of dietary protein substitutions.

The S4 + LDpred2 method provided overall improved PGS accuracy across a variety of phenotypes for UK Biobank participants. The method had the best estimated P GS accuracy in Finnish and Japanese populations.

Weight-adjusted-waist index (WWI) and all-cause mortality as well as cardiovascular mortality in individuals with type 2 diabetes. We used data from the National Health and Nutrition Examination Survey from 1999 to 2018 and the UK Biobank database.

Using Mendelian randomization (MR) approach, we investigated associations between dietary intake and colorectal cancer. We calculated genetic risk scores of diet-related variants and used them as instrumental variables in the two-stage least square MR framework. In MR analysis, genetically predicted fruit intake was significantly associated with a 21% decreased risk of CRC. null findings were observed in multivariable analysis.

Cardiometabolic multimorbidity (CM) is an increasing public health concern. Previous observational studies have suggested inverse associations between coffee, tea, and caffeine intake and risks of CM. This prospective study involved 172 315 (for caffeine analysis) and 188 091 (tea and coffee analysis) participants free of any cardiometric diseases at baseline.

Multiple large longitudinal cohorts provide opportunities to address questions about predictors of pain and pain trajectories. This focus article uses two empirical examples to illustrate the processes of assessing the measurement properties of data from large cohort studies. In both examples, data were screened to select candidate variables that captured the impact of chronic pain.

Elevated VAT or PDFF exhibited associations with adverse left ventricular (LV) structure and impaired LV function. The high VAT-high PDFF group displayed the most pronounced cardiac alterations. The findings suggested that VAT and PDFF was related to SBP, diabetes, dyslipidemia, lipid profile, liver function and glucose.

Study explores effects of stress during childhood and adulthood on grey matter macro- and microstructure. Findings showed that childhood stress is associated with changes in microstructural measures bilaterally within the hippocampus and amygdala. No effects of adulthood stress on brain microst Structure were found.

Eight out of 23 brain areas had significant negative associations with depression in the whole population. These relationships were abolished in seven areas when SES was included in the analysis. The precentral gyrus was robustly associated with depression across all analyses.

Loneliness is now widely regarded as a health risk factor. However, whether the associations between loneliness and multiple diseases are consistent with causal effects remains largely unexplored. We combined behavioural, genetic and hospitalization data from the UK Biobank to examine the associations of loneliness with a wide range of non-overlapping diseases.

There is a connection between abdominal obesity and chronic kidney disease (CKD) There is a lack of systematic research investigating the specific roles of serum metabolites, including lipid metabolites, amino acid metabolites, carbohydrate metabolites and inflammatory substances in explaining this associations.

Neurocognitive dysfunction is observationally associated with the risk of psychiatric disorders. Blood metabolites, which are readily accessible, may become highly promising biomarkers for brain disorders. The causal role of blood metabolites in neurocognitive function and the biological pathways underlying their association with psychiatric disorders remain unclear.

Sepsis is an inflammatory disease that leads to severe mortality. Proteomic research serves as a primary source for drug target identification. We employed proteome-wide Mendelian randomization (MR), genetic correlation analysis, and colocalization analysis.

Restricting salt, caffeine, and alcohol intake is commonly recommended as a first-line treatment for patients with M&#233;ni&#232;re's disease (MD) However, it remains unclear whether these interventions effectively improve symptoms of MD. We conducted a bidirectional two-sample Mendelian randomization (MR) analysis to evaluate the relationship between these dietary modifications and MD.

The metabolomic profile of aging is complex. Here, we analyse 325 nuclear magnetic resonance (NMR) biomarkers from 250,341 UK Biobank participants. We develop a metabolomic aging score that outperforms other aging metrics in predicting short-term mortality risk.

Community-dwelling adults (N = 491,323) in the UK Biobank completed a neuroticism scale between 2006 and 2010. Vital status was tracked up to December 2022 via linkage with the UK National Health Service. Loneliness was the component of neuroticism most strongly associated with premature mortality.

A normal diet supplemented with 1.25% cholesterol (high cholesterol diet) caused more severe colitis in mice. Cholesterol aggravated DSS-induced intestinal epithelial barrier impairment and nuclear sterol regulatory element-binding protein 2 (nSREBP2) inhibition. In humans, SREBF2 gene single nucleotide polymorphism (CC) and serum TC levels are associated with IBD incidence.

The heritability of abdominal aortic aneurysm (AAA) is high. AAA partially shares genetic architecture with other cardiovascular diseases. Genetic information could help inform AAA screening strategies.

A causal link between air pollution exposure and cardiovascular events has been suggested. Few studies have investigated the shape of the associations at low levels of air pollution and identified the most important temporal window of exposure. We assessed long-term associations between particulate matter 2.5 at low concentrations and multiple cardiovascular endpoints using the UK Biobank cohort.

Insulin resistance causes multiple epidemic metabolic diseases, including type 2 diabetes, cardiovascular disease, and fatty liver. To discover novel insulin resistance genes in the general population, we conducted genome-wide association studies in 382,129 individuals. We identified 251 independent loci, of which 62 were more strongly associated with TG/HDL compared to TG or HDL alone.

Little evidence from population-based cohort to analyze relationship of wildfire-related PM 2.5 with cancer-specific mortality. Study consisted of 492394 participants (age: 38-73 years) recruited by UK Biobank during 2004-2010. Each 10 &#956;g/m 3  increment of 3-year cumulative exposure was related to a 0.4 % greater risk of total cancer.

An understanding of human brain individuality requires the integration of data on brain organization across people and brain regions, molecular and systems scales, as well as healthy and clinical states. Here, we help advance this understanding by leveraging methods from computational genomics to integrate large-scale genomic, transcriptomic, neuroimaging, and electronic-health record data sets.

Large biobanks have dramatically advanced our understanding of genetic influences on human brain anatomy. Most studies have combined rather than compared male and female participants. We screen for sex differences in the common genetic architecture of over 1000 neuroanatomical phenotypes in the UK Biobank.

There is a growing interest in the linkage of cardiovascular health (CVH) with depression/anxiety. The evidence of "Life's Essential 8" CVH score is scarce. We evaluated the associations ofCVH score with risk of incident depression/Anxiety among 0.4 million participants.

Exome-wide sequencing and association analysis (ExWAS) in 75 K Pakistanis identified NM_000435.3(NOTCH3):c.3691 C > T, encoding the missense amino acid substitution p.Arg1231Cys. variant is attributable for approximately 2.0% of hemorrhagic strokes and 1.1% of all strokes in South Asians. Findings highlight the value of diversity in genetic studies.

Allostatic load (AL) reflects the cumulative burden of chronic stress throughout life. The associations between AL, colorectal cancer (CRC) risk and all-cause mortality in patients with CRC remain unclear.

 ehrapy is a modular open-source Python framework designed for exploratory analysis of heterogeneous epidemiology and EHR data. It incorporates a series of analytical steps, from data extraction and quality control to the generation of low-dimensional representations.

Dietary habits of 190,893 participants from UK-Biobank were assessed. An inverse association between adherence to EAT-Lancet diet and all-cause dementia (high vs. low) was observed only in individuals with high socioeconomic status. On the contrary, no protective effects of the diet on early-onset dementia were observed.

Hip fractures present a significant healthcare challenge, especially within aging populations. This paper focuses on the prediction of hip fracture risk in older and middle-aged adults. The study cohort included 547 patients, with 94 experiencing hip fracture.

Study aimed to examine associations between healthful and unhealthful plant-based dietary patterns with risk of all-cause mortality among CKD patients for the first time. Participants with the highest hPDI scores showed a 34% lower risk of mortality.

Risky behavior is a heritable trait that can have negative mental health consequences. It has been associated with variability in cortical structure and function. The relation between cortex, gene expression and risky behavior remains unclear.

Sedentary behavior (SB) has emerged as a significant health concern that deserves attention. This study aimed to examine the associations between prolonged sedentary behavior and the risk of all-cause and cause-specific mortality. It also explored desirable alternatives to sitting in terms of physical activity (PA)

The emergence of biobank-level datasets offers new opportunities to discover novel biomarkers and develop predictive algorithms for human disease. We present an ensemble machine-learning framework (machine learning with phenotype associations, MILTON) to predict 3,213 diseases in the UK Biobank.

The relationship between psoriasis and site-specific cancers remains unclear. We use observational and genetic data from the UK Biobank to investigate the potential causal associations. In the unselected PheWAS analysis, Psoriasis is associated with higher risks of 16 types of cancer.

Migraine is a highly prevalent and complex neurovascular disease. Currently available therapeutic drugs often fall to adequately meet clinical needs. This study aims to identify putative novel targets for migraine treatment through proteome-wide Mendelian randomization (MR)

Analysis of rare protein-coding variants in 106,973 women from the UK Biobank study implicates genes with effects around five times larger than previously found for common variants. The SAMHD1 association reinforces the link between ovarian ageing and cancer susceptibility.

Cardiovascular disease (CVD) risk increases with age. Statins reduce cardiovascular risk but their effects are less certain at older ages. We assessed the long-term effects and cost-effectiveness of statin therapy.

Few studies have shown that drinking coffee and tea may be associated with the risk of hypertension and dementia. Limited research exists on their impact on dementia risk in hypertensive patients. This study aimed to determine the association between coffee and Tea consumption and dementia development in the hypertensive population.

The American Heart Association introduced Life's Essential 8 (LE8) as a new cardiovascular health (CVH) metric. There is limited understanding of LE8's impact on the risk of transitions between different stages of CVH. The current study investigated whether adhering to LE8 during a healthy stage could mitigate the progression from hypertension to cardiovascular diseases.

No study has examined whether excessive visceral and subcutaneous adipose tissue are associated with musculoskeletal pain. Abdominal MRI scans were performed at two imaging visits. Pain in the neck/shoulder, back, hip, knee or 'all over the body' was assessed.

The expansive collection of genetic and phenotypic data within biobanks offers an unprecedented opportunity for biomedical research. The frequent occurrence of missing phenotypes presents a significant barrier to fully leveraging this potential. Our goal is to leverage the large dataset of genotypes (but without the phenotype) and a separate GWAS summary dataset of the phenotype to impute the phenotypes.

A total of 283,579 individuals with paid employment or self-employment aged 37-73 years were included from the UK Biobank with a median follow-up period of 14.0 years. Compared with that of day workers, the adjusted hazard of all-cause mortality was increased by 12.0% in shift workers. Only individuals who worked night shifts for 20-30 years exhibited a substantially increased hazard of cardiovascular disease mortality.

Step cadence-based and machine-learning (ML) methods have been used to classify physical activity (PA) intensity in health-related research. This study examined the association of intensity-specific PA duration with all-cause (ACM) and CVD mortality. The ML elicited the greatest mortality risk reduction.

High heritability of salt sensitivity suggests an essential role for genetics in the relationship between sodium intake and blood pressure (BP) The role of glycosaminoglycan genes, which are crucial for salinity tolerance, remains to be elucidated.

Chronic cardiovascular-kidney disorder (CCV-KD) is increasingly prevalent. Few studies have assessed the association between the two conditions. We conducted a prospective cohort study using data from UK Biobank.

We aimed to develop and validate a protein risk score for predicting Alzheimer's disease. We compared its performance with a validated clinical risk model and apolipoprotein E (APOE) genotypes. The top 10 proteins with the highest coefficients contributed most of the predictive power for AD risk.

Amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (ALS) causes profound impairments in neurological function. Study aimed to identify pre-disposing genetic, phenotypic, and exposure-related factors for ALS using multi-modal data and assess their joint predictive potential.

There is increasing evidence of shared genetic factors between psychiatric disorders and brain magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) phenotypes. New approaches are needed to infer potential genetic structure underlying those phenotypes, says the study.

Gene-based association analysis is a powerful tool for identifying genes that explain trait variability. It aims to eliminate influence of SNPs outside the gene, which are in linkage disequilibrium with intragenic SNPs. We suggest a new TauCOR method for conditional gene-based analysis using summary statistics. This method accounts the influence of the full regional polygenic background.

The associations of ambient air pollution exposure and low-grade inflammation with lung function remain uncertain. In this study, 276,289 subjects were enrolled in the UK Biobank. The median concentrations of air pollution were 9.89 &#181;g/m 3 for PM 2.5. One-unit increase in INFLA score was linked with 12.41 and 11.31-ml decreases in FVC and FEV 1 , respectively.

UK Biobank study included 384,758 participants aged 56.6 +/- 8.0 years. After a median of 11.9 years of follow-up, 8,885 (2.3%) participants were diagnosed with VTE. A healthy sleep score inversely affected VTE risk for participants with a score of 5, the hazard ratio of VTE was 0.813.

People with multiple LTC (MLTC) have increased risk of sarcopenia. It has not yet been established whether this is driven by specific combinations of LTC. Decision trees identified several LTC combinations associated with increased risk. These included drug/alcohol misuse and osteoarthritis.

Study used data from the UK Biobank to investigate the relationship between alcohol consumption and dementia risk. 313,958 White British current drinkers, who were free of dementia during 2006-2010, were followed up until 2021. During a mean follow-up of 13.2 years, 5394 (1.7%) developed dementia. Findings suggested that there was no safe level of alcohol consumption for dementia.

Genome-wide data from 52 ancient individuals from eight sites in Cambridgeshire covering the period of Roman occupation. Low levels of genetic ancestry differentiation between Romano-British sites and indications of larger populations than in the Bronze Age and Neolithic.

A balanced diet and adequate physical activity (PA) are recognized as pivotal components among modifiable environmental factors. The independent impact on NDD incidence has been previously debated. This investigation seeks to delineate the association between PA and NDDs across various levels of adherence to a plant-based diet.

Study assessed data from two large-scale longitudinal surveys. Long-term PM1 exposure can contribute to rapid cognitive decline at concentrations exceeding 23 and 5.5 &#956;g.m-3 in CHARLS and UKB participants, respectively.

Identifying modifiable causal risk factors for cancer is challenging because both exposure and outcome are strongly impacted by genetics and environment. We propose a novel two-sample MR method, namely, Multiple forms of IV-to-exposure effects. Unraveling shared confounding using GWAS Summary-level Effects.

Study aims to compare performance of contemporary machine learning models with statistical models in predicting all-cause mortality in patients with type 2 diabetes mellitus. A prospective cohort study was conducted including 22,579 people with diabetes from the UK Biobank.

The prevalence of end-stage renal disease (ESRD) is rising worldwide. Hyperglycaemia, hypertension, and dyslipidaemia are known risk factors. This study aims to explore the relationship between different cardiorenal risk factors and ESRD to address this global challenge.

Study of multiple cohorts identifies CHEK2 as a candidate susceptibility gene for DFSP. Additional epidemiologic and functional studies are needed to further characterize this potential gene-tumor relationship.

Eosinophils have the potential to exhibit both anti-tumor properties and tumor-promoting effects. The use of drugs that modulate eos inophilia may increase the risk of colorectal cancer.

We conducted a genome-wide association study (GWAS) in normal pressure hydrocephalus (NPH) In the GWAS comparing patients with NPH with the controls, we identified 6 gene regions significantly. The genes near the top loci have previously been associated with blood-brain barrier and blood-CSF barrier function.

Cerebral small vessel disease is the most common pathology underlying vascular dementia. Diffusion tensor imaging is more sensitive to white matter damage and better predicts dementia risk than conventional magnetic resonance imaging sequences. We developed a deep learning model to synthesize FA/MD from T1.

Adiposity, measured by BMI, is a known risk factor for postmenopausal breast cancer. Whether the association of BMI with breast cancer risk differs among women with and without cardiovascular diseases (CVD) or type 2 diabetes (T2D) is uncertain. We used individual participant data from the European Prospective Investigation into Cancer and nutrition (EPIC) and UK Biobank.

High adherence to a flavonoid-rich diet score was associated with a lower risk of dementia, with reductions more pronounced in individuals with a high genetic risk, hypertension, and depressive symptoms. The greatest risk reduction was observed in participants consuming at least 2 of the following per day: 5 servings of tea, 1 serving of red wine, and 0.5 servings of berries.

Genome-wide significant AP variants were tested for association with AP-affiliated arrhythmias. Three common missense variants were associated with APs, in the genes CCDC141 (p.Arg935Trp) and SCN1073Val. The 3 variants associated with PSVT and theSCN10A variant associated with AF, supporting an effect on AP- affiliated arrhythias. All 3 AP risk alleles were associated to higher heart rate and shorter PR interval.

Dysbetalipoproteinemia (DBL) is a disorder of remnant cholesterol metabolism associated with a severe risk of atherosclerotic cardiovascular disease (ASCVD) The objective of this study was to investigate the univariate and multivariate predictors of ASCVD in individuals with DBL. Age, hypertension, waist circumference and a polygenic risk score for coronary artery disease (PRSCAD) were independent predictors.

Oculomics is the association between the retina and systemic health. Unlike conventional AI models trained on well-recognized retinal features, the retinal phenotypes that most oculomics models use are more subtle. We found that the NAP generated from our framework was correlated to the clinically relevant endpoint of cardiovascular risk.

Study included 375,665 participants without diabetes at baseline in the UK Biobank study. Dietary patterns were derived through principal component analysis of food frequency questionnaire data. Immune function was assessed using 14 individual inflammatory markers and an integrated low-grade inflammation score (INFLA-score) The prudent diet was negatively and the full-cream dairy diet was positively associated with most inflammatory markers.

Accelerated decline in lung function is associated with incident COPD, hospitalizations and death. However, identifying this trajectory with longitudinal spirometry measurements is challenging in clinical practice. The proteomic respiratory susceptibility score was derived based on these circulating proteins and applied to the UK Biobank and COPDGene studies.

Few studies have explored the association between stair climbing and osteoarthritis. This study prospectively evaluated the associations among stair climbing, genetic susceptibility, and their interaction with the risk of incident hip/knee OA.

The association between the American Heart Association (AHA) Life's Essential 8 (LE8) and the risk of pancreatic cancer (PC) remains unclear. This cohort consisted of 234,102 participants from the UK Biobank. Participants with a high LE8 score and a low polygenic risk score (PRS) had the lowest risk of PC.

Phosphate is important for several metabolic functions and essential for bone mineralization. Sex-differences exist in the relation between serum phosphate and certain diseases. The reference interval for phosphate is age-adjusted in infants, but most institutions use the same intervals for adult men and women.

Study aims to evaluate impact of ultra-processed food (UPF) on type 2 diabetes (T2D), cardiovascular disease (CVD), hypertension, and cardiometabolic multimorbidity (CMM) Participants with high UPF consumption had a higher risk of T2D, CVD, and CMM.

Non-small cell lung cancer (NSCLC) ranks among the most prevalent and lethal malignancies globally. Fatty acids play a significant role in diverse physiological and pathological mechanisms, yet their precise involvement in NSCLC remains poorly understood. This study utilized a large-scale prospective cohort of 249,132 participants.

Pathogenic variants in RAD51C confer an elevated risk of breast and ovarian cancer, while individuals homozygous for specific RAD 51C alleles may develop Fanconi anemia. Using saturation genome editing (SGE), we functionally assess 9,188 unique variants, including >99.5% of all possible coding sequence single-nucleotide alterations.

Family history of cancer and polygenic risk scores (PRS) are pivotal for cancer risk assessment. Yet their combined impact remains unclear. Participants in the UK Biobank were recruited between 2006 and 2010. Cox regression was used to examine associations between FH, PRS, and cancer risk.

 insomnia, daytime sleepiness, and short or long sleep duration, as well as sleep risk score were associated with an increased risk of rheumatoid arthritis. Participants with unfavorable sleep patterns and high genetic risk showed the highest risk.

Recent studies have shown an ascending trend in global added sugar consumption. Evidence for the long-term consequences of added sugar on all-cause mortality and cardiovascular diseases (CVDs) remains limited. This study aimed to examine the associations between added sugar from various sources and the risk of all- Cause mortality and CVDs.
