Waist circumference (WC) is most common but imprecise method for measuring abdominal adiposity. Study aimed to determine whether elevated VAT or ASAT provides greater prognostic value for CVD events compared to elevated WC in the general population.

GC-rich tandem repeat expansions (TREs) often associated with DNA methylation, gene silencing and folate-sensitive fragile sites. TREs underlie several congenital and late-onset disorders. A GCC expansion in the promoter of AFF3 was associated with a 2.4-fold reduced probability of completing secondary education.

 Quantification of body compartments is emerging as novel a biomarker of metabolic health. The present study evaluated the impact of liver transplant (LT) on bodycompartments. The findings provide data needed to design future studies developing radiomics-based risk-stratification strategies in LT recipients.

Neutrophil extracellular traps (NETs) in healthy human urine provide an antibacterial defense strategy within the urinary tract. Peptidyl arginine deiminase 4 (PADI4) inhibition in mice blocked NETosis.

Prediabetes and type 2 diabetes mellitus are growing global health concerns. Lifestyle modifications, including dietary interventions, offer promising avenues for prevention and management. Our hypothesis was that proportions of n3 PUFA would by inversely associated with the prediabetes prevalence.

Robust and accurate prediction of cardiovascular disease (CVD) risk facilitates early intervention to benefit patients. Relationship between mental health disorders and CVD is widely recognized. Existing models often overlook psychological factors, relying on a limited set of clinical and lifestyle parameters.

Instrumental variables (IVs) are widely used to study the causal effect of an exposure on an outcome. IVs require an instrument that (a) is associated with the exposure, (b) has no direct effect on the outcome except through the exposure and (c) is not related to unmeasured confounders. This article reviews works where instruments may not satisfy conditions b or c, which we refer to as invalid instruments.

Study reveals integrated pathways that explain the interplay between brain, body, environment and lifestyle. Using multimodal brain imaging and organ-specific physiological markers from more than 18,000 adult participants.

Physical activity commonly follows a "weekend warrior" pattern, in which most moderate-to-vigorous physical activity is concentrated in 1 or 2 days. We tested associations between physical activity pattern and incidence of 678 conditions in 89 573 participants of the UK Biobank prospective cohort study.

Cerebral small vessel disease (cSVD) is the most common pathology underlying vascular cognitive impairment. A comprehensive description of cSVD associations with clinical phenotypes at scale is lacking. We included participants from the UKB imaging study who had available information on total volume of white matter hyperintensities (WMHs)

Methylated tandem repeat expansions resemble the FMR1 CGG repeat that causes fragile X syndrome. AFF3 expansion carriers had a 2.4-fold reduced probability of completing secondary education.

Biological age can be predicted using artificial intelligence (AI) trained on electrocardiograms (ECGs) We developed an AI model to predict age from an ECG and compared baseline characteristics.

Limited epidemiological evidence exists concerning the impact of healthy dietary patterns on reducing the risk of cholelithiasis. We aimed to examine the association of seven established dietary patterns with subsequent choleLithiasis risk and whether this association was modified by genetic risk. We conducted a prospective cohort study from the UK Biobank, including 155,323 participants.

Predictive Risk modeling using Mendelian Randomization (PRiMeR) leverages risk factors and genetic data from a healthy cohort. After training, the learned predictor can be used to assess risk for new patients solely based on risk factors.

Telomere length is a cellular aging marker implicated in various health outcomes. There have been no studies focused on the relationship between LTL and the future risk of depression and anxiety. Data from 364,331 UK Biobank participants were analyzed.

This article considers the problem of classifying individuals in a dataset of diverse psychosis spectrum conditions. We consider both support vector machines (SVMs) and graph convolutional networks (GCNs) for classification. We also employ the MultiVERSE algorithm to generate network embeddings of the functional and structural networks. The best models among SVMs and GCNs yielded accuracies >63%.

Albinism is an archetypal rare condition associated with hypopigmentation. We analyse data from the Genomics England 100,000 Genomes Project alongside a cohort of 1120 individuals with albinism. We show that, when both variants are present, the probability of receiving a diagnosis is significantly increased. The approach discussed opens up new avenues for the investigation of oligogenic patterns in apparently Mendelian disorders.

Previous studies suggest that prevalent heart failure (HF) differs based on left ventricular ejection fraction (LVEF) The aim of this study was to evaluate prevalent and incident HF based on LVEF and CMR-determined LV size within a large community-dwelling cohort.

Time spent in moderate-to-vigorous physical activity (MVPA) was classified into four categories. Compared with very-low level MVPA, moderate MVPA might reduce the risk of depression. Prolonged sedentary behavior was associated with a higher risk of Depression. The WHO guideline of 150-300 min/week of MVPA may reduce depression by 29% and anxiety by 20%.

Deciphering the relationships between genes and complex traits can enhance our understanding of phenotypic variations and disease mechanisms. Here we present a framework to decipher the total and direct causal effects of individual genes. BN-GWAS leverages imputed expression profiles from GWAS and raw expression data from a reference dataset.

Conditional testing via the knockoff framework allows one to identify-among a large number of possible explanatory variables-those that carry unique information. This approach is particularly well suited to the analysis of genome-wide association studies.

UK Biobank study in a cohort of participants who wore accelerometers for one week. Patterns of physical activity were compared. Meeting physical activity guidelines is necessary to reduce all-cause mortality in those at the lower and middle thirds of handgrip strength.

TM6SF2 represents a good candidate for this approach due to its known association with steatotic liver disease (SLD) We screened participants with whole-exome sequences in the Penn Medicine Biobank (PMBB, n >40,000) and the UK Biobanks (UKB, n  >200,000). Missense variants in TM6 SF2 (E167K, L156P, P216L) were associated with an increased risk of clinically diagnosed and imaging-proven steatosis.

raining using unlabeled data increased the specificity for the NORM class to 0.961. Longitudinal strain features slightly improved classification metrics, except for HCM-AUC. Feature analyses showed that strain features were important for disease labeling.

The X chromosome has remained enigmatic in Alzheimer disease (AD) Yet it makes up 5% of the genome and carries a high proportion of genes expressed in the brain, making it particularly appealing as a potential source of unexplored genetic variation in AD. This large-scale XWAS of AD identified the novel SLC9A7 locus.

Shanghai Textile Workers Cohort was established in 1981 with 35 years of follow-up, assessing textile workers' lung functions every five years. We employed four distinct models to examine the association between forced expiratory volume in one second (FEV1) and proteins. Five proteins were significantly associated with the rate of decline of FEV1.

Small cell carcinoma of the ovary, hypercalcemic type (SCCOHT) is an extremely rare, highly aggressive cancer (mean age of onset, 24 years) Nearly all cases are associated with somatic or germline pathogenic variants (GPVs) in SMARCA4. Early bilateral oophorectomy is recommended for unaffected females with a SMarCA4 GPV.

Sarcopenia represents a substantial public health challenge, particularly among the geriatric population. The ingestion of oily fish and cheese was significantly correlated with augmented ALM, diminished risk of low hand grip strength, and enhanced walking pace. cooked vegetables, fresh fruit, dried fruit, cereal, and raw vegetables were protective of one or both of the sarcopenia-associated phenotypes.

Gallstone diseases affect intestinal inflammation, bile flow, and gut microbiota. Gallstone disease may increase the risk of inflammatory bowel disease (IBD) Studies exploring the associations between gallstone diseases and subsequent IBD risk have been limited.

The G haplotype is a group of co-inherited single nucleotide variants in the F5 gene that reduce venous thromboembolism (VTE) risk. Seven percent of the population is homozygous for the G haplotypes (F5-G/G) The underlying mechanism of VTE protection is poorly understood.

A total of 129,408 participants in the UK Biobank were included in this study. Over a median follow-up period of 13.26 years, 2421(1.87%) participants developed IBS. After adjusting for the confounders, individuals in the proinflammatory diet category had a higher risk of IBS compared with the antiinflammatory category.

Since 2006, the UK biobank has recorded prescription medication and mortality data for over 500'000 participants, aged between 40 and 70 years old. As expected, most drugs were linked to a shorter lifespan, likely due to the life-limiting nature of the diseases they are prescribed to treat. A few drugs were associated with increased lifespans, including notably Sildenafil, Atorvastatin, Naproxen and Estradiol.

Climbing 10-50, 60-100, 110-150, and &#8805;160 steps of stairs per day were associated with significant reductions in the risk of AF, compared to not climbing any stairs. Risk reduction appeared more pronounced in women than in men.

A total of 2180 genetic variants were used to develop nine PRSs for lung cancer. The metaPRS was associated with lung cancer risk with a hazard ratio of 1.33 (95% confidence interval: 1.27-1.39) per standard deviation increased. The addition of metaPRs to the clinical risk model showed continuous net reclassification improvement.

Recent studies have reported that gout is associated with a risk of cardiovascular disease (CVD) later in life. However, the predictive value of genetic predisposition to gout combined with lifestyle habits for CVD risk remains unclear. This study aimed to examine the association between genetic risk and lifestyle habits and the risk of developing CVD.

The impact of pain intensity on the progression trajectories of cardiometabolic multimorbidity (CMM) is not well understood. We attempted to dissect the relationship of short-term pain (STP) and chronic pain intensity with the temporal progression of CMM.

Increasingly large samples in genome-wide association studies (GWASs) for alcohol use behaviors (AUBs) have led to an influx of implicated genes. Yet the clinical and functional understanding of these associations remains low. This study applied a multidimensional framework to investigate the latent genetic structure underlying heterogeneous dimensions of AUBs.

Hidradenitis suppurativa (HS) is associated with an increased prevalence of cardiovascular diseases compared with the general population. This cohort study used a polygenic risk score (PRS) for HS to examine the risks of coronary artery disease (CAD) and diabetes. Participants were enrolled from January 1, 2006, to December 31, 2010.

The complex associations of socioeconomic status (SES) and lifestyle with dementia are unclear. Lifestyles explained &#8804;7.8% of socioeconomic disparities in dementia. Unhealthy lifestyle categories were associated with a higher risk of dementia.

Air pollution and genetic susceptibility increase the risk of all-cause mortality and cardiovascular outcomes in patients with atrial fibrillation (AF) AF patients aged between 40-69 years old registered in the United Kingdom Biobank from 2006 to 2010 were included.

Systemic immune-inflammation index (SII), neutrophil-to-lymphocyte ratio (NLR), and platelet-to.lymphocytes ratio (PLR) are novel inflammatory biomarkers used to determine various disease prognoses. We examined the effects of systemic inflammatory markers on all-cause mortality using random survival forest (RSF) and Cox proportional hazards models. Thresholds established by the RSF model could potentially refine prognostic decision-making.

Little is known about the underlying relationship between mosaic loss of chromosome Y (mLOY) and the risk of age-related lung diseases. Results from two cohorts showed that expanded mLOY was associated with increased risks of all lung diseases and lung cancer. There was evidence of positive interactions between mLOY and smoking behavior.

A total of 77,315 participants from the UK Biobank were included in this study. High MRS significantly increased the risk of stroke. MRS provided modest improvement to the stroke risk prediction model. The lifestyle-related metabolic signature could reduce 20% stroke risk.

It remains unclear whether the associations between dietary patterns and non-alcoholic fatty liver disease (NAFLD) vary by body mass index (BMI) We aimed to explore the association between dietary. patterns and severe NAFLD incidence, and further investigate the interaction of BMI with dietary patterns. We used a prospective cohort study using UK Biobank data.

Air pollution and genetic risk have been found to contribute to both onset and development of psoriasis. However, the extent to which genetic susceptibility modifies the effects of air pollutants on the risk of incident Psoriasis remains unknown. Our study aimed to assess the association between joint exposure to multiple air pollutants and the risk.

Multiparametric MRI markers of liver health corrected T1 (cT1) and proton density fat fraction (PDFF) have shown utility in the management of various chronic liver diseases. We assessed the normal population reference range of both cT1 and PDFF in healthy child and adult volunteers without any known liver disease.

The study was the largest and most rigorous analyses of body composition and cardiac parameters to date. VAT was associated with increased left ventricular mass (LVM) and wall thickness in women but not in men. MFI association with cardiac parameters was similar to VAT but not significant in women.

The Lancet Commission has highlighted 12 modifiable risk factors for dementia. We compared the association between risk factors and dementia by frailty. Except for smoking, depression, and excessive alcohol use, the other 10 risk factors had a stronger association with dementia among frailer individuals.

The physical and mental health of intersex individuals is woefully understudied. A recent survey found high rates of self-reported cognitive issues. There were no differences in intelligence between intersex and non-intersex people.

Study included 349 085 white British individuals from the UK Biobank study. Genetic risk of high BP was estimated using a weighted polygenic risk score. Muscle strength was assessed using a hand dynamometer and expressed relative to fat-free mass.

Metabolic dysfunction-associated steatohepatitis (MASH) is associated with more than a 10-fold increase in liver-related death. We established a MASH prediction score based on 44 clinical parameters and 250 serum metabolites. The score identified patients with MASH with AUROCs of 0.87 (95% CI 0.83-0.91) in the Chinese and Finnish cohorts.

The human sex ratio (fraction of males) at birth is close to 0.5 at the population level. Past human studies yielded conflicting results regarding the existence of sex ratio-influencing mutations. Here we show that because a person's offspring sex ratio has an enormous measurement error, a gigantic sample is required to detect OSR-influence genetic variants.

The polyconnectomic score (PCS) measures the extent to which an individual's functional connectivity mirrors the whole-brain circuitry characteristics of a trait. PCS was consistently higher in out-of-sample patients across six of the eight neuropsychiatric and across all three investigated neurodegenerative disorders. Individuals with elevated PCS levels exhibited higher neuroticism (p FDR   -5 ), lower cognitive performance and lower general wellbeing.

Study aimed to investigate impact of tea and coffee consumption on transitions from diabetes-free status to incident type 2 diabetes (T2D), and subsequently to T2D-related complications and death. Included 438,970 participants in the UK Biobank who were free of diabetes and diabetes complications at baseline.

Biliary tract cancer (BTC) is potentially influenced by metabolic dysregulation. Previous metabolomic evaluations are limited. We prospectively investigated associations of blood metabolites and BTC risk in the UK biobank cohort study.

Study examined the association of consumption of coffee, including different types (instant and ground) and with different additives, with new-onset hypertension. A total of 98 765 participants free of hypertension enrolled in the UK Biobank between 2006 and 2010 were included. Regardless of coffee type and whether adding milk to coffee, there was a U-shaped association.

Study aims to investigate the connections between proteomics and genetics in relation to acne across extensive population cohorts. Employed a longitudinal cohort of 54,306 participants from the UK Biobank Pharmacological Proteomics Project (UKB-PPP) Identified 19 proteins significantly associated with the risk of acne.

Fibroblast growth factor 21 (FGF21) modulates macronutrient and alcohol preferences, but evidence of such regulation in humans remains scarce. We aimed to map the relationships between plasma FGF21 levels, F GF21 genetic variation and habitual macronsutrient intake in a large human population.

Individuals with genetic polymorphisms in UGT1A1 exhibit bilirubin levels that belie their risk of liver disease. It is not known if this phenomenon extends to other common liver blood tests (LBTs)

Alcohol consumption has complex effects on diabetes and metabolic disease. Genetic factors may play a role and warrant exploration. The aim was to elucidate genetic variants modulating the impact of alcohol consumption on insulin sensitivity and pancreatic beta cell function.

Metabolic remodeling has recently been found to play an important role in the pathological process of atrial fibrillation (AF) The purpose of this study was to evaluate the associations of circulating KB levels with incident AF risk in the general population.

Study used data from the UK Biobank to investigate the association between pre-diagnostic peripheral immunoinflammatory cells and the risk of epilepsy. Monocyte count, NLR, PLR, and SII increased the risk, whereas lymphocyte count and LMR decreased it.

Measurements below the limit of quantification (BLQ) are often tagged in quality control fields, but these flags are currently underutilized in human genetics studies. We hypothesize that genetic drivers, along with environmental and technical factors, contribute to the presence of BLQ flags. Applying our hMG approach to n = 227,469 UK Biobank individuals with metabolomic profiles, we reveal more than 5% heritability.

Long-term fine particulate matter (PM 2.5 ) exposure has been linked to incident heart failure (HF) We aimed to investigate the associations of PM2.5 constituents with incident HF, and further evaluate the modification effects of genetic susceptibility. Among 411 807 individuals in the UK Biobank, 7554 participants developed HF during a median follow-up of 12.05 years. EC (43%) played the most important role, followed by NH 4   +  and SO 4 Â  2- .

The relationship between socioeconomic status (SES) and stroke remains controversial. This study aimed to assess the causal relationship of SES with stroke and its subtypes. The study included 372,437 participants from the UK Biobank.

PM 2.5 -mortality associations in the UK Biobank cohort using detailed information on confounders and exposure. An increase of 10 &#956;g/m&#179; in PM2.5 was associated with hazard ratios of 1.27 for all-cause, 1.24 for nonaccidental, 2.07 for respiratory, and 1.66 for lung cancer mortality.

The diagnosis of myalgic encephalomyelitis/chronic fatigue syndrome (CFS) is based on a constellation of symptoms which center around fatigue. However, fatigue is commonly reported in the general population by people without CFS. Does the biology underlying fatigue in patients with CFS also drive fatigue experienced by individuals without C FS?

The American Heart Association's Life's Essential 8 (LE8) constitutes a research and public health construct capturing key determinants of cardiovascular health. We tested the hypothesis that worse LE8 profiles are associated with higher composite risk of the most important clinical endpoints related to poor brain health.

Central obesity (waist/height ratio 0.5 or greater) was associated with a 48% increased risk of POP regardless of BMI. Overweight without central obesity (BMI 25-29.9 and waist/ height ratio less than 0. 5) was linked to a 23% higher risk.

Integrating multimodal data, such as medical imaging, electronic health records (EHRs), and genomic data, is critical for comprehensive healthcare diagnostics. However, these data sources' high dimensionality present challenges in developing robust and accurate diagnostic models. This paper proposes a hybrid deep learning architecture that combines Convolutional Neural Networks (CNNs), Recurrent neural Networks (RNNs) and Transformer models.

Study aimed to investigate the associations between HLA alleles and sleep behaviours. Data were sourced from the UK Biobank. Logistic regression analyses were performed to explore the associations. HLA molecules play a crucial role in the immune response.

Fine mapping aims to pinpoint the potentially causal variants from a large number of correlated SNPs possibly with group structure in GWAS-enriched genomic regions. Existing multivariate variable selection methods for fine mapping select variables for all responses without considering possible heterogeneity across different responses.

Nicotine addiction profoundly impacts brain functions through interactions with neural pathways. Despite its significance, the impact of tobacco smoking on the whole-brain functional connectome remains largely unexplored. We conducted a whole- brain analysis on 24,539 adults aged 40 and above from the UK Biobank cohort.

Vigorous intermittent lifestyle physical activity (VILPA) refers to brief bouts of intense physical activity embedded into daily life. We examined sex differences in the dose-response association of VILPA with major adverse cardiovascular events (MACE) and its subtypes.

When combining imputed and sequenced data in a single gene-based association analysis, the problem of reconstructing genetic correlation matrices arises. We propose an efficient method based on maximising the determinant of the matrix. This method has a number of useful properties and has an analytical solution for our task.

1,854 solid tumor patients were identified, of whom 453 (24.4%) experienced critical care admission. Unadjusted rates of metastatic disease and death were higher for the critical care cohort with lower progression-free survival. At five years, 25% of critical care survivors and 14% of the hospitalized survivors had developed metastatic Disease.

Cannabis use during adolescence and young adulthood has been associated with brain harm. Despite a rapid increase in cannabis use among older adults in the past decade, the impact on brain health in this population remains understudied.

Hospital admission to critical care is associated with subsequent disease progression in patients with non-metastatic solid tumors. Unadjusted rates of metastatic disease and death were higher for the critical care cohort with lower progression-free survival.

Previous studies have reported inconsistent results with positive, negative, and J-shaped associations between alcohol consumption and the hazard of aortic aneurysm and dissection (AAD) This study aimed to examine the connections between weekly alcohol consumption. and the subsequent risk of AAD.

Previous studies suggested that smoking behavior was associated with an elevated risk of chronic kidney disease (CKD) Yet whether this association is causal remains uncertain. We used data for half million participants aged 40 to 69 years from the UK Biobank cohort.

Genome-wide association studies (GWAS) have identified over 150 risk loci linked to colorectal cancer. However, the specific causal gene and the functional regulatory mechanisms in this region remain unresolved. We employed an RNA interference-based functional approach to identify genes critical for CRC cell proliferation at the GWAS locus 17p13.3.

Hearing loss affects &#8764;430 million people globally. Fish consumption and long-chain n-3 polyunsaturated fatty acid (PUFA) intake were inversely associated with risk of hearing loss. Study includes 175,177 UK Biobank participants (40-69y, 54 % women) with data on plasma n- 3 PUFA and hearing status.

Metabolites associated with type 2 diabetes (T2D), coronary heart disease (CHD) and stroke were measured. Most lipoprotein metabolites were associated with risks of T2D and CHD but not with the risk of stroke. Phospholipids within intermediate-density lipop Protein or large low-density Lipoprotein particles showed positive associations with CHD and inverse associations with T2d.

SNP heritability is an important parameter in understanding the genetic architecture underlying various diseases and traits. Methods that aim to estimate SNP heritability from individual genotype and phenotype data are limited by their ability to scale to Biobank-scale data sets. These limitations have motivated the development of methods that only require summary statistics.

Ventricular repolarization time (ECG QT and JT intervals) is associated with malignant arrhythmia. Genome-wide association studies have identified 230 independent loci. 50% of their heritability remains unexplained. We hypothesized calcium interactions could explain a proportion of the missing heritability.

We link the circulating proteome to human heart failure (HF) propensity. We observe a broad array of genes encoding proteins linked to HF phenotypes and outcomes. Many identified targets do not have wide precedent in large-scale genomic discovery or human studies.

Vitamin B3 (VB3) induces antitumor immunity against liver cancer through biased GPR109A axis in myeloid cell. Nutritional epidemiology studies suggest that higher VB3 intake reduces liver cancer risk.

The recent development of artificial intelligence (AI) technology has revolutionized many fields. While DNN plays a central role in modern AI technology, it has rarely been used in genetic data analysis due to analytical and computational challenges. We developed a C++ package, AIGen, based on two newly developed neural networks.

 Transcriptome-wide association studies (TWAS) integrate GWAS and expression reference panels to identify associations at gene level with tissue specificity. We applied our method to three different complex traits: systolic and diastolic blood pressure, as well as a brain aging biomarker white matter brain age gap in UK Biobank. We identified critical biologically relevant pathways and genes associated with these traits.

The hippocampus atrophies with age and is implicated in neurodegenerative disorders including Alzheimer's disease (AD) We examined the interplay between age and apolipoprotein E ( APOE ) genotype on total hippocampal volume. No association between APOE and total hippocampus volume was detected before age 60.

Many studies either neglect genetic confounding altogether or rely on adjusting for polygenic scores (PGS) in regression analysis. We unveil that the commonly employed PGS approach is inadequate for removing genetic confounding due to measurement error and model misspecification. To tackle this challenge, we introduce PENGUIN, a principled framework forpolygenic genetic confounding control.

Aging is a complex process manifesting at molecular, cellular, organ, and organismal levels. By applying elastic net regularization to plasma proteome data of over 50,000 human subjects in the UK Biobank, we report interpretable aging models.

Short-chain fatty acid acetate has gained attention for its contrasting roles. Evidence suggests it may offer cardiovascular protection but also promote cancer. However, these influences have been scarcely assessed in epidemiological research. We investigated relationship between acetate and ischemic heart disease, diabetes, and cancers related to sex hormones.

Lower lung function is associated with lower cognitive function and an increased risk of dementia. This has not been adequately explained and may partly reflect shared developmental pathways. In UK Biobank participants of European ancestry, we tested the association between lung function measures and cognitive traits. The strongest association was between forced vital capacity and vascular dementia.

Statins are routinely prescribed to prevent cardiovascular diseases, but their effects on brain alterations remain largely unknown. Very few studies have examined the differences in brain volumes between statin users and non-users. This study showed that statin use is associated with higher white matter hyperintensity volumes and lower total and peripheral cortical grey matter volumes.

The risk of cardiovascular disease increases in patients with acute pancreatitis (AP) It remains unknown whether this increase varies between sexes. We compared sex difference in MACCE incidence using incidence rate per 1000 person-years.

A total of 195,250 participants in the UK Biobank cohort were included in this study from 2006-2010. Polygenic risk scores (PRSs) were calculated for hypertension using single-nucleotide polymorphisms (SNPs) Concentrations of plasma FAs, including polyunsaturated fatty acids (PUFAs) and monounsaturated fatty acid (MUFAs) were tested by nuclear magnetic resonance. Increased plasma MUFAs or SFAs and decreased plasma PUFAs were associated with hypertension risk.

UK Biobank is a large-scale research and biomedical data collection resource that added several COVID-19 related data fields. This study aimed to analyze this data to understand how it was collected and how it can be used.

Apolipoprotein E (APOE) &#949;4 allele is the strongest genetic risk factor for late onset Alzheimer's disease (AD) This case-cohort study used targeted plasma biomarkers and large-scale proteomics to examine the biological mechanisms that allow some APOE&#949%;4 carriers to maintain normal cognitive functioning in older adulthood.

We examined the impact of exposure to sugar restrictions within 1000 days after conception on type 2 diabetes and hypertension. Rationing restricted sugar intake to levels within current dietary guidelines, and consumption nearly doubled immediately after rationing ended.

Modifying dietary behaviors into healthier habits may attenuate the risk of colorectal cancer (CRC) risk. Women were more likely to follow dietary recommendations than men. Increasing fruit and vegetable consumption was inversely associated with CRC risk among men.

Data from 45,821 adults in the UK Biobank was used to estimate biological ages for 12 major organs. All age gaps increase the risk of all-cause mortality by 6-60%. The risk of death varied from 5.54 to 29.18 times depending on the number of aging organs.

WHO convened an effort to develop, evaluate, and illustrate revised risk models. Models included information on age, smoking status, systolic blood pressure, history of diabetes, and total cholesterol. For a given risk factor profile, we found substantial variation across global regions.

Mood disorders (including major depressive disorder and bipolar disorder) affect 10% to 20% of the population. Multiple approaches have shown considerable sharing of risk factors across mood disorders. We meta-analyzed data from the latest Psychiatric Genomics Consortium genome-wide association studies.

Four thousand five hundred and ninety participants of the UK Biobank (54% female, mean age 61.1 +/- 7.2 years) underwent cardiac magnetic resonance. Visceral obesity was associated with a smaller LV EDV and subclinical lower LV systolic function in men.

Genetic variants can be used to prioritize risk factors as potential therapeutic targets via Mendelian randomization (MR) An agnostic statistical framework using Bayesian model averaging (MR-BMA) can disentangle the causal role of correlated risk factors with shared genetic predictors. The top combination of risk factors ranked by the model score contains apolipoprotein B (ApoB) only.

The incremental value of polygenic risk scores in addition to well-established risk prediction models for coronary artery disease (CAD) is uncertain. To examine whether a polygenicrisk score for CAD improves risk prediction beyond pooled cohort equations, a study of UK Biobank participants was conducted from 2006 to 2010.

Refractive errors, in particular myopia, are a leading cause of morbidity and disability worldwide. We conducted a meta-analysis of genome-wide association studies that involved 542,934 European participants. We identified 336 novel genetic loci associated with refractive error.

Study looked at genetic instruments associated with normal range thyrotropin (TSH) and free thyroxine levels or Hashimoto's thyroiditis and Graves' disease. A 1 standard deviation increase in TSH was associated with a 5% decrease in the risk of stroke. MR analyses did not show a causal association between normal range thyroid function and CAD.

Non-alcoholic fatty liver disease (NAFLD) is highly prevalent and causes serious health complications in individuals with and without type 2 diabetes (T2D) Early diagnosis of NAFLD is important, as this can help prevent irreversible damage to the liver and, ultimately, hepatocellular carcinomas. We sought to expand etiological understanding and develop a diagnostic tool using machine learning.

Surgical menopause (e.g. endometriosis and fibroids) was associated with over 20% higher risk of CVD (HR 1.22, 95% CI 1.16-1.28) After the stratified analysis, a graded relationship for incident CVD was observed with lower age at menopaser. The findings lend some support to the position that elective bilateral oophorectomy at hysterectomy for benign diseases should be discouraged. In clinical practice, women who experienced natural menopera or had surgical menophere at an earlier age need close monitoring and engagement for preventive health measures.

Lipoprotein-associated phospholipase A2 (Lp-PLA2) activity has been shown to predict calcific aortic valve stenosis (CAVS) outcomes. Our objective was to test the association between plasma Lp- PLA2 activity and genetically elevated CAVS in humans.

There is a lack of epidemiological data on the associations between psychiatric disorders and COVID-19 testing rates and testing outcomes. Individuals with psychiatric disorders were overrepresented among the 1474 UK Biobank participants with test data.

Birth weight influences not only brain development, but also mental health outcomes, including depression. As birth weight is highly heritable, the polygenic risk scores of birth weight were calculated from the UK Biobank cohort. Positive associations were observed between birth weight and brain volumes.

A common genetic variant near MBOAT7 (rs641738C>T) has been previously associated with hepatic fat and advanced histology in NAFLD. We aimed to establish whether this variant is a risk factor across the spectrum of NAFLd and to characterise its role in the regulation of related metabolic phenotypes. Data from 1,066,175 participants (9,688 with liver biopsies) across 42 studies were included in the meta-analysis.

Study looked at sleep duration, insomnia, and obstructive sleep apnea (OSA) in a cohort of patients with type 2 diabetes (T2D) on glucose-lowering medications. Long sleep duration and a high risk for OSA were independently associated with higher HbA1c values.

Phenome-wide association studies (PheWASs) are known to be a powerful tool in discovery and replication of genetic association studies. The SAIGE method has been proposed to control for case-control imbalance and sample relatedness in a tractable manner. We present a new high-performance statistical R package (SAIGEgds) for large-scale PheWas using generalized linear mixed models.

Chronic liver disease (CLD) is frequently diagnosed at a late stage when prognosis is poor. We aimed to determine the patient factors associated with a late CLD diagnosis and its impact on survival.

Untreated hyperthyroidism is associated with accelerated bone turnover, low bone mineral density (BMD) and increased susceptibility to fragility fractures. By using Mendelian randomization (MR) analysis, we aimed to assess the causal association of hyperthy thyroid states with BMD and fractures using the UK Biobank.

Serum testosterone concentrations are affected by factors unrelated to hypothalamo-pituitary-testicular axis pathology. We evaluated the impact of sociodemographic, lifestyle and medical factors, on serum testosterone and sex hormone-binding globulin in men aged 40-69 years. Age and BMI were inversely associated with testosterone and cFT, while SHBG was associated with age and inversely with BMI.

"CKD Patch" is a validated method to calibrate and improve the predicted risk from established equations according to CKD measures. The median (IQI) of the ratio of predicted risk for CVD mortality with CKD Patch vs. original prediction with SCORE was 2.64.

Previous research suggested a differential association of 25-hydroxyvitamin D (25(OH)D) metabolites with type 2 diabetes (T2D) We aimed to examine the potential causality of these associations using Mendelian randomisation (MR) analysis. We identified genetic variants for MR analysis to investigate the causal association.

Cannabis use disorder has a strong genetic component and is associated with negative outcomes. The aim of the study was to identify novel genetic variants associated with cannabis use disorder. We identified two genome-wide significant loci: a novel chromosome 7 locus and a previously identified chromosome 8 locus. Cannabis use disorder and cannabis use were genetically correlated (r g  0.50, p=1.50 Ã— 10 -21 ), but they showed significantly different genetic correlations with 12 of the 22 traits.

Interleukin 6 (IL-6) is a key player, in the pathophysiology of type 2 diabetes (T2D) However, it is unknown whether IL-6 mediated inflammation is implicated in T2D. We performed a meta-analysis of 15 prospective studies to investigate associations. We also estimated the association of a loss-of-function missense variant (Asp358Ala) in the IL6 receptor gene (IL6R)

Dementia is associated with a high burden of dependency and disability. Physical frailty is a multisystem dysregulation that has been identified as a risk factor for dementia. The aim of this study was to examine the association of frailty and its individual components with all-cause dementia incidence in a cohort of UK adults.

High plasma vitamin C levels are associated with lower type 2 diabetes risk, but whether this association is causal is uncertain. To investigate this, we studied the association of genetically predicted vitamin C with type 2 Diabetes. We identified 11 genomic regions associated with vitamin C, with the strongest signal at SLC23A1 and 10 novel genetic loci. There was no association between genetically predicted plasma Vitamin C and type 2abetes.

Cross-ethnic analyses were conducted using data from 440,581 UK Biobank participants. The prevalence of vitamin D deficiency was highest among participants of Asian ancestry. Participants with higher socioeconomic deprivation were more likely to have 25(OH)D deficiency compared to less deprived participants. Regular consumption of oily fish was associated with reduced odds of Vitamin D deficiency.

Psychiatric disorders are among the largest and fastest-growing categories of the global disease burden. Few studies have examined associations between socioeconomic factors and psychiatric disorders from a genetic perspective. We randomly divided 501,882 participants in the UK Biobank cohort with socioeconomic Townsend deprivation index (TDI) data.

Small studies have correlated hypertension with pneumonia risk; whether this is recapitulated in larger prospective studies is unclear. We estimated the risk for prevalent hypertension with incident respiratory diseases over mean follow-up of 8 years among 377,143 British participants in the UK Biobank.

Few genetic variants have been identified that impact risk of cirrhosis. We aimed to identify new genetic variants that predispose to the disease. We also aimed to test whether such variants, aggregated into a polygenic score, enable genomic risk stratification.

Insulin-like growth factor-1 (IGF-1) plays a key role in the pathogenesis of metabolic syndrome, which is in turn associated with asthma. Whether IGF-1 contributes to asthma causation or asthma severity is largely unknown. In a large study of British adults, higher serum IGF- 1 levels were associated with lower odds of asthma and current wheezing.

Kidney function declines faster in men. Testosterone levels may mediate the sex disparity. Levels of sex hormone binding globulin (SHBG), which modulates sex hormones, might also be relevant. The sex-specific role of SHBG is unclear.

Chronic pain is often experienced alongside other long-term conditions (LTCs) Yet our understanding of this, particularly in relation to multimorbidity (&#8805;2 LTCs), is poor. We aimed to examine associations between the presence/extent of chronic pain with type/number of L TCs experienced.

Study aimed to determine whether unique brain networks are associated with the COVID-19 infection risk. Functional magnetic resonance imaging scans in a cohort of general population were used to compute whole-brain functional connectomes.

Upper gastrointestinal cancers (oesophageal/stomach) have high mortality rates and are often diagnosed after the disease has progressed. Study aims to determine if there is an association between a broad range of long-term conditions (LTCs) and incidence of UGI cancers.

UK Biobank data on individuals diagnosed with schizophrenia ( n  = 1544) were used to examine the prevalence of major cardiovascular events, specifically myocardial infarction, stroke, heart failure and cardiovascular death. Prevalence was significantly higher among participants with daytime sleepiness, independent of snoring, and muscular weakness.

UK Biobank included 392,287 middle-aged and older participants. 7,262 incident cases of T2D were identified during a median 10.1 years of follow-up. Participants who reported regular fish oil use at baseline had a 9% (95% CI 4-14%) lower risk.

Long-term heavy coffee consumption may adversely affect individuals' cardiovascular disease (CVD) risk. As hyperlipidemia is a well-established contributor to CVD risk, we investigated the association between habitual coffee intake and plasma lipid profile.

The apolipoprotein E4 ( APOE4 ) gene may be associated with cancer-related cognitive decline. We studied a cohort of patients from the UK Biobank who had breast cancer; some also had AD. There was no significant difference in survival among genotypes.

Genetic predisposition to type 2 diabetes (T2D), hyperglycemia, insulin resistance, and pancreatic &#946;-cell dysfunction on risk of stroke subtypes and related cerebrovascular phenotypes. We examined associations with ischemic stroke (60,341 cases, 454,450 controls), intracerebral hemorrhage (1,545 cases, 1,481 controls), and related phenotypes (carotid atherosclerosis, imaging markers of cerebral white matter integrity, and brain atrophy)

Parkinson's disease (PD) is a genetically complex neurodegenerative disease with ~20 genes known to contain mutations that cause PD or atypical parkinsonism. We present here the Parkinson's Disease Sequencing Browser: a Shiny-based web application that presents comprehensive summary-level frequency data.

Fatty liver disease (FLD) is expected to be the leading cause of end-stage liver disease within the next decade. Both environmental and genetic factors contribute to the susceptibility of FLD. Several genetic variants contributing to FLD have been identified in exome-wide association studies.

The Australian Autism Biobank (AAB) is an initiative of the Cooperative Research Centre for Living with Autism (Autism CRC) to establish an Australian resource of biospecimens, phenotypes and genomic data for research on autism. The genetic data were used to confirm familial relationships and assign ancestry, which was majority European. We generated polygenic scores (PGS) for ASD, IQ, chronotype and height.

LiverPRO is a software tool for detection of clinically significant liver fibrosis in primary care. In the development cohort, LiverPRO diagnosed clinically significant fibrosis with good accuracy (transient elastography &#8805;8 kPa area under the receiver operating characteristic curve [AUC] 0.86 [95% CI 0.83-0.90]

High soluble urokinase plasminogen activator receptor (suPAR) levels are associated with adverse outcomes in chronic heart failure (HF) The authors assessed the association between proteomics-based suPAR levels and incident HF risk in the general population.

Coronary artery disease (CAD) comprises one of the leading causes of morbidity and mortality both in the European population and globally. All established clinical risk stratification scores and models require blood lipids and physical measurements. The model developed and validated relies solely on ten questionnaire variables, overcoming the limitations of existing models that depend on physical measurements or biomarkers.

Little is known about the associations between choline metabolites (total choline, phosphatidylcholine, and glycine) and the incidence of heart failure (HF) This study followed 245,072 participants from the UK Biobank from baseline (2006-2010) until March 30, 2023. During a median follow-up of 14.1 years, 5,468 incident HF cases were documented.

There are limited data on impact of feedback of incidental findings (IFs) from research imaging. We evaluated the impact of UK Biobank's protocol for handling potentially serious IFs in a multi-modal imaging study of 100,000 participants. Compared to systematic radiologist review, radiographer flagging resulted in substantially fewer participants with potentiallyserious IFs.

The carbohydrate-insulin model of obesity is that insulin secretion drives weight gain. However, fasting hyperinsulinemia can also be driven by obesity-induced insulin resistance. We used genetic variation to isolate and estimate the potentially causal effect of insulin secretion on body weight.

Despite evidence of high heritability, monogenic disorders are identified in a minor fraction of individuals with early-onset coronary artery disease (EOCAD) We calculated in 111 418 British participants from the UK Biobank cohort a genetic risk score (GRS) based on the presence of 182 independent variants. Participants with a diagnosis of EOCAD who underwent a revascularization procedure (n=96) had a significantly higher GRS182.

Vascular aging results in stiffer arteries and may have a role in the development of cardiovascular disease (CVD) Arterial stiffness index (ASI) and pulse pressure (PP) are 2 independent vascular aging indices. We investigated whether ASI or PP predict new-onset CVD and mortality in a large community-based population.

With an estimated one billion hypertension cases worldwide, the role of the built environment in its prevention and control is still uncertain. The present study aims to examine the associations between neighbourhood walkability and hypertension in a large and diverse population-based cohort.

Elevated SUA level is convincing to cause gout and inflammatory polyarthropathies. It might act as a marker for the wider range of diseases with which it associates. Our findings support further investigation on the clinical relevance of SUA levels with cardiovascular, metabolic, autoimmune and respiratory diseases.

The CCL3L1-CCR5 signaling axis is important in a number of inflammatory responses, including macrophage function and T-cell-dependent immune responses. Small molecule CCR5 antagonists exist, including the approved antiretroviral drug maraviroc, and therapeutic monoclonal antibodies are in development.

Handgrip strength, a measure of muscular fitness, is associated with cardiovascular (CV) events and CV mortality. But its association with cardiac structure and function is unknown. The goal of this study was to determine if handgripstrength is. associated with changes in cardiac structure.

UK Biobank participants were assessed for neuroticism. Suicide risk was modelled using Cox regression stratified by gender. Neuroticism increased the risk of suicide in both men and women.

Low-risk limits recommended for alcohol consumption vary substantially across different national guidelines. We studied individual-participant data from 599 912 current drinkers without previous cardiovascular disease. For all-cause mortality, we recorded a positive and curvilinear association with the level of alcohol consumption.

Residential greenness, a fundamental component of urban design, has been shown to reduce the public health burden of mental disorders. The study investigates the association between residential green exposure and prevalence of major depressive disorders. A protective effect of greenness on depression was consistently observed. The results point to the benefits of well designed green environments on mental health.

Fluid intelligence declines with advancing age, starting in early adulthood. To support healthy aging, the mechanisms underlying these declines need to be better understood. We applied latent growth curve modelling to investigate the neural determinants of longitudinal changes in fluid intelligence across three time points in 185,317 individuals.

Heart rate recovery (HRR) is commonly defined as the decrease of heart rate at 1 minute after cessation of exercise. HRR is an important predictor of all-cause mortality and death associated with coronary artery disease. However, HRR at earlier time intervals after cessation has not been well evaluated and might better reflect PNS reactivation.

A recent genome-wide association study (GWAS) identified 99 loci that contain genetic risk variants shared between asthma, hay fever, and eczema. Many more risk loci shared between these common allergic diseases remain to be discovered, which could point to new therapeutic opportunities.

There are limited data on impact of feedback of incidental findings (IFs) from research imaging. We evaluated the impact of UK Biobank's protocol for handling potentially serious IFs in a multi-modal imaging study of 100,000 participants. Compared to systematic radiologist review, radiographer flagging resulted in substantially fewer participants with potentiallyserious IFs.

Structural integrity of the white matter is a marker of cerebral small vessel disease. This is the major cause of vascular dementia and a quarter of all strokes. The aim was to identify common variants associated with microstructural integrity.

Body mass index, body fat percentage, and waist circumference influence smoking status and intensity. Mendelian randomisation analysis indicated that each standard deviation increment in body mass index (4.6) increased the risk of being a smoker.

Selenium is an essential trace element obtained through diet that plays a critical role in DNA synthesis and protection from oxidative damage. Selenium intake and polymorphisms in selenoproteins have been linked to the risk of certain cancers though data for glioma are sparse.

Study looked at 67 798 men and women from England, Scotland, and Wales in the UK Biobank cohort with available information for years of completed education and refractive error. Genetic variants used as proxies for myopia and years of education were derived from 23andMe and Social Science Genetic Association Consortium (SSGAC)

Cognitive ability is an important predictor of lifelong physical and mental well-being. impairments are associated with many psychiatric disorders. Higher cognitive ability is also associated with greater educational attainment and increased household income. The current study found that variation in brain resting-state functional connectivity was associated with individual differences in cognitive ability.

Heritability estimates have revealed an important contribution of SNP variants for most common traits. But single-trait genome-wide association studies (GWAS) has failed to uncover their impact. In this study, we applied a multitrait GWAS approach to discover additional factor of the missing heritability of human anthropometric variation.

Depression is associated with poor sleep quality. Understanding the neural connectivity that underlies both conditions is likely to lead to better-directed treatments for depression and associated sleep problems.

A cohort of 359,033 adults aged 40-69 years were identified from the UK Biobank. During eight years of follow-up 294 oesophageal cancer and 217 gastric cancer cases were identified. Physical activity and screen-based sedentary behaviour levels were not associated with overall oesphago-gastric cancer risk.

Coronary artery disease (CAD) has substantial heritability and a polygenic architecture. The potential of genomic risk scores to help predict CAD outcomes has not been evaluated comprehensively. This study sought to construct a genomic risk score for CAD.

Limited evidence suggests that exposure to maternal smoking in utero or early life might be associated with chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD) Our objective was to examine the independent and combined association of maternal and own smoking with adult lung function and COPD.

 Depression is more common in obese than non-obese individuals, especially in women. Previous studies have used genetic variants associated with BMI to provide evidence that higher body mass index (BMI) causes depression. We tested whether this relationship is driven by the metabolic consequences of BMI nor for differences between men and women.

Combinations of lifestyle factors interact to increase mortality. The effect of socioeconomic deprivation on these extended lifestyle risks remains unclear. We aimed to examine whether deprivation modifies the association between an extended score of lifestyle-related risk factors and health outcomes.

Few genetic studies that focus on moderate-to-severe asthma exist. We identified 24 genome-wide significant signals of association with moderate- to- severe asthma. Three novel signals were identified, including several signals in innate or adaptive immune-response genes. The MUC5AC signal was not associated with asthma when analyses included mild asthma. We also report for the first time genetic variants associated with the risk of developing moderate to severe asthma that regulate mucin production.

The p.Gln368Ter (rs74315329) risk allele in the myocilin gene (MYOC) was initially reported to have high penetrance in glaucoma registry-based studies. We investigated this disparity using data from Australia and the United Kingdom. In the UKBB, the minor allele frequency of the MYOC p. Gln 368Ter variant was 1 in 786 individuals (0.13%). In the Australian registry studies, the odds of the variant were 12.16 (95% CI, 6.34-24.97) in patients with advanced glaucma.

PCSK9 (proprotein convertase subtilisin/kexin type 9) inhibitors are safe and reduce risk of cardiovascular diseases. But their long-term safety is unclear. Genetic variants associated with lower activity of a gene can act as proxies to identify potential side effects of drugs.

Schizophrenia is associated with a marked reduction in reproductive success. Yet alleles that are common contribute substantially to the liability of the disorder. Authors sought to test this hypothesis, isolating the effects of risk alleles on fecundity from the effects that are contingent on expressing schizophrenia.

Cytokines and growth factors have been implicated in the initiation and propagation of vascular disease. Our objective was to explore whether genetically determined circulating levels of these factors are associated with stroke and its etiologic subtypes. Genetic instruments were obtained from a genome-wide association study of 8293 healthy adults.

Studies have shown strong positive associations between serum urate (SU) levels and chronic kidney disease (CKD) risk. We evaluate whether genetic data are consistent with a causal impact of SU level on the risk of CKD and estimated glomerular filtration rate (eGFR)

Iron is essential for life but contributes to oxidative damage. In Northern-European ancestry populations, HFE gene C282Y mutations are relatively common. Iron excess can be prevented or treated but diagnosis is often delayed or missed. Data on sarcopenia, pain, and frailty are scarce.

HFE p.C282Y genetic variant responsible for most hereditary haemochromatosis type 1. Study compared prevalent and incident morbidity and mortality between those with the variant and those with no.

We identified a locus at genome-wide significance in an intron of PLEKHG1 (rs275350, &#946; [SE] = 0.071 [0.013];  p  = 1.6 Ã— 10 -8 ), a Rho guanine nucleotide exchange factor that is involved in reorientation of cells. The same single nucleotide polymorphism was associated with all ischemic stroke.

Diverticular disease is a common complex disorder characterised by mucosal outpouchings of the colonic wall that manifests through complications such as diverticulitis, perforation and bleeding. We report the to date largest genome-wide association study (GWAS) to identify genetic risk factors for diverticular disease.

Research demonstrates a negative relationship between alcohol use and affect. But the value of deprecation is unknown and thus cannot be included in estimates of the cost of alcohol to society. This paper aims to examine this relationship and develop econometric techniques to value the loss in affect attributable to alcohol consumption.

We used Mendelian randomization to assess the role of thyroid dysfunction for cardiovascular disease (CVD) Single-nucleotide polymorphisms associated with thyroid function were identified from a genome-wide association meta-analysis. Genetically predicted thyroid-stimulating hormone levels and hyperthyroidism were significantly associated with atrial fibrillation but no other CVDs.

 MAGO is a magnitude-based reconstruction that embodies multipeak liver fat spectral modeling and multipoint optimization. It is compatible with asymmetric echo acquisitions. MAGO was shown to be more robust to artefacts compared to LMS IDEAL.

Study was designed to test the hypothesis that refractive errors such as myopia and hyperopia cause an increased risk of age-related macular degeneration. The risk AMD was caused by a 1-diopter (D) change in refractive error.

Major depression (MD), alcohol dependence (AD), and alcohol consumption (AC) have established clinical associations. We leveraged genome-wide data from the Psychiatric Genomics Consortium (PGC) and UK Biobank to test for the presence of shared genetic mechanisms. Positive genetic correlation was observed between MD and AD.

Lower-complexity cardiac malformations constitute the majority of adult congenital heart disease (ACHD) Long-term risks of adverse cardiovascular events and relationship with conventional risk factors in this population are poorly understood. We aimed to quantify the risk of adverse. cardiovascular events associated with lower- complexity ACHD that is unmeasured by conventional. risk factors.

Schizophrenia is a neurodevelopmental disorder with many genetic variants of individually small effect contributing to phenotypic variation. Lower cortical thickness (CT), surface area, and cortical volume have been demonstrated in people with schizophrenia. A range of obstetric complications (e.g., lower birth weight) are consistently associated with an increased risk for schizophrenia. We investigated whether a high polygenic risk score for schizophrenia (PGRS-SCZ) is associated with CT, surface area and corticalVolume.

Study uses data from 77 743 UK Biobank participants. Found significant difference in experienced temperature of ~1.8&#176;C between the periods of coldest and hottest external temperature. People of Chinese ethnic background experienced 0.65&# 176;C lower temperatures than other groups.

 Syncope is a common condition associated with frequent hospitalization or visits to the emergency department. Family aggregation and twin studies have shown that syncope has a heritable component. We investigated whether common genetic variants predispose to syncope and collapse. We report on a genome-wide significant locus located on chromosome 2q32.1.

There is mounting evidence that our environment and lifestyle has an impact on epigenetic regulatory mechanisms, such as DNA methylation. It has been suggested that these molecular processes may mediate the effect of risk factors on disease susceptibility. Using genetic variants as surrogate variables, we have used two-sample Mendelian randomization (2SMR) to investigate the potential implications of putative changes to DNA methylated levels.

There may be differences in hematological parameters between meat-eaters and vegetarians. Blood count was carried out in all UK Biobank participants at recruitment. People with low or no red meat intake generally had lower hemoglobin concentrations.

Novel, effective, and safe drugs are warranted for treatment of ischemic stroke. Circulating protein biomarkers with causal genetic evidence represent promising drug targets. No systematic screen of the proteome has been performed.

Study aimed to explore potential side effects and repurposing potential of antihypertensive drugs. Mendelian randomization estimates for drug effects on coronary heart disease and stroke risk were compared with randomized, controlled trial results. Suitable genetic proxies for angiotensin-converting enzyme inhibitors and calcium channel blockers were identified.

Mendelian randomisation allows for the testing of causal effects in situations where clinical trials are challenging to do. We used genome-wide data available from the UK Biobank to construct a genetic risk score of 76 variants related to BMI. After Bonferroni correction, PheWAS identified that BMI geneticrisk score was associated with hospital-diagnosed obesity and 58 other outcomes.

Genetic variants at the LPA locus are associated with both calcific aortic valve stenosis (CAVS) and coronary artery disease (CAD) Whether these variants are linked with CAVS in patients with CAD vs those without CAD is unknown. This study included patients undergoing cardiac surgery from the Genome-Wide Association Study on Calcific Aortic Valve Stenosis in Quebec. Data were collected from January 1993 to September 2018.

A data-driven accelerometer metric, the acceleration above which a person's most active minutes are accumulated, can quantify the prevalence of meeting current physical activity guidelines for global surveillance. Unlike cut-point methods, the metric is population-independent (e.g. age) and potentially comparable across datasets.
